superEntry.entry:
alphabetical letter H H
The sixth letter of the alphabet: called HaMCN [and HaA (respecting which latter see the letter b). It is one of the letters termed mahomuwsap, or nonvocal, i. e. pronounced with the breath only, without the voice; and of those termed HaloqiyRap i. e. faucial, or guttural, for] the place of its utterance is in the fauces; and were it not for a hoarse aspiration with which it is pronounced, it would resemble E: next after it [with respect to the place of utterance] is h: [E having the lowest place of utterance; then H; and then h:] and H and h are never consociated in any uncompounded word of the which the letters are all radicals, because of the mutual nearness of their places of utterance: they occur together in HayRahalo; but this is only a compound word in the classical language; and as the name of a certain kind of tree it is a post-classical word. (Kh, L.) ＝ -A2- [It is often put for HiynaYicK. ＝ -A3- As a numeral, it denotes Eight.]

HaA HA
HaA and HaMCN: see the letter H, and see arts. HwO and HI.

1 HabRa Hb
1. HabRa [signifying He, or it, was, or became, loved, beloved, an object of love, affected, liked, or approved, is originally Habuba or Habiba]. You say, HabRa UilaIRa hecaA AlXRaIoCu, [aor.
Habuba
or
Hababa
,] inf. n. HubRN, This thing was, or became, an object of love to me. (K. [The meaning is there indicated, but not expressed. In the CK, AlXRaICa is erroneously put for AlXRaIoCu.]) And Habubotu Uilayohi I became loved, beloved, or an object of love, to him: [said to be] the only instance of its kind except Xarurotu and labubotu. (K.) And maA kunota HabiybFA walaqado Habibota, with kesr, Thou wast not loved, and thou hast become loved. (S.) See also 5. ― -b2- HabRa, formed from Habuba, by making the former b quiescent and incorporating it into the latter, is also a verb of praise [signifying Beloved, lovely, pleasing, charming, or excellent, is he, or it]; (TA;) and so HubRa, [which is more common,] formed from the same, by incorporating the former b into the latter after transferring the dammeh of the former to the H. (ISk, S, TA.) A poet says,
wazaAdahu kalafFA fiI AlHubRi Oano manaEato
waHabRa XayoYFA AlaI AlAnosaAni maA muniEaA
[And her denying increased his devotion in love: for lovely, as a thing, to man, is that which is denied]. (TA.) And Sá'ideh says,
hajarato gaDuwbu waHabRa mano yatajanRabu
waEadato EawaAdK duwna waloyika taXoEibu
[Ghadoob hath forsaken thee, (and lovely is the person who withdraweth far away,) and obstacles in the way of thy drawing near have occurred to separate thee and her]. (S, TA.) [See also HabRacaA, below.] ― -b3- [Both are also verbs of wonder.] You say, HabRa bifulaAnK, (As, S, and so in copies of the K,) and HubRa, (I 'Ak p. 236, [where both forms are mentioned as correct,] and so in the CK,) How beloved, or lovely, &c., is such a one (As, S, K) to me! (As, S.) [See also 4.] A'Obeyd and Fr read this HabRa, saying that it means Habuba bflAn, and that the former b is rendered quiescent by the suppression of its dammeh, and incorporated into the latter. (S, * TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 4, in two places. ＝ -A3- Also HabRa, [aor., accord. to analogy,
Habiba
,] He stood still, stopped, or paused. (K.) ＝ -A4- And HubRa, with damm, He was fatigued, or tired. (K.)

2 HbRbhu UilaIRa Hbbh AlI Hbbh Aly
2. HbRbhu UilaIRa He, or it, [rendered him, or it, an object of love, lovely, or pleasant, to me;] made me to love, affect, like, approve, or take pleasure in, him, or it. (K.) You say, HbRbhu UilaIRa UiHosaAnuhu [His beneficence made him an object of love to me]. (A, TA.) And HabRaba QllRehu Uilayohi AlUiymaAna [God made faith lovely to him]. (A, TA.) And HubRiba UilaIRa biOano tazuwraniI [Thy visiting me hath been made pleasant to me]. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- HbRb AldRawaMCa [He formed the medicine into pills, or little clots or balls: see its quasi-pass., 5]. (K in Hvr, &c.) ＝ -A3- And HbRb He filled a water-skin &c. (AA, TA.) ＝ -A4- See also 5.

3 muHaAbRapN mHAbh mHAbp
3. muHaAbRapN, (S,) or muHaAbabapN, (K,) and HibaAbN signify the same [as inf. ns. of HAbR]. (S, K.) [You say, HAbR baEoDuhumo baEoDFA They loved, affected, liked, approved, or took pleasure in, one another.] And HAbRhu He acted, or behaved, in a loving, or friendly, manner with him, or to him. (A, TA.) ― -b2- See also 4.

4 AHbRhu AHbh AHbp OHb OHbh OHbp Hb HbA Hbyb
4. AHbRhu, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. UiHobaAbN; (KL;) and HabRahu↓, (S,) first pers. Hababotuhu, (Msb, K,) aor.
Habiba
, which is anomalous, (S, Msb, K,) the regular aor. being
Habuba
, which is unused, (Msb,) [said to be] the only instance of a trans. verb whose second and third radical letters are the same having the measure yafoEilu as that of its aor. without having also the measure yafoEulu, (S,) and therefore by some disapproved, as not chaste, and disallowed by Az, though he allows the pass. form HubRa, (TA,) inf. n. HubRN, (K,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) and HibRN; (K;) and [HabRahu↓,] first pers. Habibotuhu, aor.
Hababa
; and HaAbRhu↓, inf. n. HibaAbN, of the dial. of Hudheyl; (Msb;) and AstHbRhu↓; (Msb, K;) signify the same; (S, Msb, K;) He loved, affected, liked, approved, or took pleasure in, him, or it: (A, K, and KL in explanation of the first and last:) he held him, or esteemed him, as a friend: (KL in explanation of the first and last:) or AisotiHobaAbN signifies the esteeming [a person or thing] good: (S:) and the preferring, or choosing, [a person or thing,] as also UiHobaAbN: (KL:) and AstHbRhu EalaI gayorihi means he loved, or esteemed, him, or it, above another, or others; preferred him, or it, to another, or others. (K, A, * TA.) maA OaHabotu celika, in the dial. of the tribe of Suleym, is for mA OaHobabotuhu [I loved not, or liked not, that]; like Zanotu for Zananotu, and Zalotu and Zilotu for Zalilotu. (Lh, TA.) [OuHibRu Oano yakwuna kacaA may be rendered I would that it were thus, or that such a thing were.] It is said of Ohod, in a trad., huwa jabalN yuHibRunaA wanuHibRuhu, meaning It is a mountain whose inhabitants love us, and whose inhabitants we love: or it may mean we love the mountain itself, because it is in the land of people whom we love. (IAth, TA.) And one says fiI saAEapK yuHibRuhaA AlTRaEaAmu for yuHabRu fiyhaA [In an hour, or a time, in which food is loved, or liked]. (TA.) ― -b2- maA OaHabRahu UilaIRa i. q. HabRa bihi [How beloved, lovely, pleasing, charming, or excellent, is he, or it, to me!]; (As, S, K, * TA;) and so OaHobibo UilaIRa bihi. (A, TA.) [De Sacy, in his Gram. Ar., sec. ed., ii. 221, mentions the saying, maA OaHabRa AlmuWomina llRehi wamaA OaHabRahu UilaI QllRehi, as meaning How greatly does the believer love God! and how great an object of love is he to God!] ＝ -A2- AHbR, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) also signifies He (a camel) kneeled and lay down, and would not spring up: (K:) or was restive: or kneeled and lay down: (S:) or was afflicted by a fracture, or disease, and would not move from his place until cured, or remained there until he died: (AZ, S, K:) or became jaded: (TA: [agreeably with this last explanation the act. part. n. is rendered in the S and K on the authority of Th:]) or was at the point of death,
by reason of violent disease, and therefore kneeled and lay down, and could not be roused. (AHeyth, TA.) Accord. to AO, OaHobabotu HubRa Alxayori Eano cikori rabRiI [in the Kur xxxviii. 31] means I have stuck to the ground, on account of my love of the horses, [lit., of good things,] and so been diverted from prayer, until the time of prayer has passed: (TA:) by Alxyr is meant Alxayol. (Jel.) ＝ -A3- Also He became in a state of recovery from his disease. (K.) ＝ -A4- And It (seed-produce) had, bore, or produced, grain. (S, K.)

5 tjbRb jb tjbb
5. tjbRb He manifested, or showed, love, or affection, (S, K,) Uilayohi to him. (S.) tHbRb and HabRa↓ are both syn. with tuwdRd. (TA.) ― -b2- [Also, app., He became, or made himself, an object of love or affection to him: see muHabRabN, said to be syn. with mutaHabRibN.] ＝ -A2- He became swollen, or inflated, like a jar (HubR), from drinking. (A, TA.) ― -b2- It (a water-skin &c.) became full. (AA, TA.) ― -b3- He began to be satiated with drink. (K.) ― -b4- He (an ass &c.) became filled with water: (S:) and HabRaba↓ also is used in this sense, but ISd doubts its correctness: (TA:) one says, Xaribati AlUibilu HatRaI HabRabato The camels drank until they were satiated. (S.) ＝ -A3- tHbRb Aljaliydu kaAllRuWoluWi AlSRigaAri [The hoar-frost formed into grains like small pearls]. (TA in art. SOb.) ― -b2- tHbRb AlrRiyqu EalaI AlOasonaAni [The saliva formed, or collected, in little bubbles upon the teeth]. (Az, TA.) ― -b3- taqaTRaEa AllRabanu wataHabRaba [The milk became decomposed, and formed little clots of curd]. (S in art. bHvr.) ― -b4- tHbRb AlzRubodu [The butter formed into little clots, when first appearing in the milk or cream]. (S and K in art. vmr.) The verb is also used in like manner in relation to honey, (K in art. Hvr,) and dibos (S in that art.,) and medicine. (TA in that art. [See also 2.]) ― -b5- tHbRb Aljilodu [The skin broke cat with pimples, or small pustules: so in the language of the present day: see HabRN]. (TA in art. Hvr.)

6 tHAbRwA HAbI tHAb tHAbwA
6. tHAbRwA They loved, or affected, or liked, one another. (S, A, * K. *)

10 UisotaHobaba
10: see 4. ＝ -A2- AisotaHabRato kariXu AlmaAli The stomachs of the cattle, or camels &c., retained the water [that they had drunk], and the time between the two waterings thereof became long, or became lengthened. (K.) This is at the conjunction of [the periods of] AlTRarof and Aljabohap [the ninth and tenth of the Mansions of the Moon, which, in central Arabia, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, took place on the 12th of August, O. S., (see manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl,)] when Canopus rises with them. (TA. [AlSRarofap is there put for AlTRarof; but evidently by a mistake of a copyist. There is also another mistake, though a small one, in the foregoing passage: for Canopus rises, in central Arabia, after AlTrf, and before Aljbhp; and rose aurorally, in that latitude, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, on the 4th of August, O. S.])

Habo Hb
Habo and HabK A cry by which a he-camel is chidden, to urge him on. (TA voce Hawobi, q. v.)

HabRN Hb
HabRN, (S, Msb, K,) a [coll.] gen. n., (Msb,) n. un. HabRapN; (S, Msb, K;) Grain of wheat, barley, lentils, rice, &c.: (Az, TA:) accord. to Ks, only of wheat and barley: (TA:) or wheat &c. while in the ears or other envelopes: (Msb:) [but applied also to various other seeds; among which, to beans, (as in the Mgh in art. bql,) and peas and the like; and kernels; and] the stones of grapes, dates, pomegranates, and the like: (Mgh voce EjamN:) by some it is applied even [to berries; as, for instance,] to grapes: you say HabRapN mino EinabK, as well as mina AlburRi, and mina AlXRaEiyri, and the like: (TA:) [and hence, to beads: (see HibRN:)] the pl. (of HabRN, Msb) is HubuwbN (S, Msb, K) and HubRaAnN, like tumoraAnN, (K,) pl. of tamorN; (TA;) and (of HabRapN, Msb) HabRaAtN (Msb, K) and HibaAbN, [or this is pl. of HabRN also,] like kilaAbN as pl. of kalobapN [and of kalobN]: (Msb:) and HabRN is also called [by lexicologists, but not by grammarians,] a pl. of HabRapN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Seed-produce, whether small or large. (TA.) ― -b3- And AlHabRapu AlxaDoraMCu (S, K) i. q. AlbuTomu [The fruit of the terebinth-tree, or pistacia terebinthus of Linn. (Delile, Flor. Æg. no. 936.)] (K.) ― -b4- And AlHabRapu AlsRawodaMCu (S, K) i. q. AlXRuwniyzu [The black aromatic seed of a species of nigella]. (K.) [But see art. swd. And for other similar terms, see the latter word of each.] ― -b5- And HabRa AlgamaAmi and HabRu Almuzoni and HabRu qurRK Hail. (S. [See a metaphorical usage of the first of these in a verse cited voce OanRa.]) ― -b6- [Hence likewise,] HabRN also signifies Pimples, or small pustules: [so in the present day: and any similar small extuberances: a coll. gen. n.: n. un. with p.] (S and K * in art. Hvr.)

HubRN Hb
HubRN Love; affection; syn. wudRN, (A,) or widaAdN; (K;) inclination of the nature, or natural disposition, towards a thing that pleases, or delights; (Kull p. 165;) contr. of bugoDN: (Mgh, TA:) HubRN and HibRN↓ and HubRapN↓ [this being said in the S to be syn. with HubRN and in the K to be syn. with maHabRapN, and it is used as an inf. n. in an ex. cited voce daAHN in art. dwH,] and HubaAbN↓ (S, K) and HibaAbN↓ (K) and maHabRapN↓ (S) signify the same; (S, K;) i. e., as above. (K.) The degrees of HubR are as follow: first, hawFI, the “ inclining of the soul, or mind; ” also applied to the “ object of love itself: ” then, EalaAqapN, “ love cleaving to the heart; ” so termed because of the heart's cleaving to the object of love: then, kalafN, “ violent, or intense, love; ” from kulofapN signifying “ difficulty, or distress, or affliction: ” then, EiXoqN, [“ amorous desire; ” or “ passionate love; ”] in the S, “ excess of love; ” and in the language of the physicians, “ a kind of melancholy: ” then, XagafN, “ ardour of love, accompanied by a sensation of pleasure; ” like lawoEapN and laAEijN; the former of which is “ ardour of love; ” and the latter, “ ardent love: ” then, jawFI, “ inward love; ” and “ violence of amorous desire, ” or “ of grief, or sorrow: ” then, tatayRumN, “ a state of enslavement by love: ” then tabolN, “ lovesickness: ” then, walahN, “ distraction, or loss of reason, in love: ” and then, huyaAmN “ a state of wandering about at random in consequence of overpowering love. ” (Kull ubi suprà.) [Accord. to the Msb, it is a simple subst.: but accord. to the K, an inf. n.; and hence,] HubRFA limaA OaHobabotumo, meaning OuHibRu HubRFA [I love with loving, i. e. much, what ye have loved]. (Har p. 186.) Hence the phrase, wakaraAmapF naEamo waHubRapF↓ [Yea; and with love and honour will I do what thou requirest: or for the sake of the love and honour that I bear thee: or HbRp may be here used for HubRFA to assimilate it in termination to krAmp: see what follows]. (S, TA.) Hence also the saying of Abu-l-' Atà EsSindee,
fawaQllRehi maA OadoriI waUinRiI laSaAdiqN
OadaMCN EaraAniI mino HubaAbiki Oamo siHoru
[And by God, I know not (and indeed I am speaking truth) whether disease have befallen me in consequence of love of thee, or enchantment]: (S, TA:) but IB says that the reading best known is mino HibaAbiki↓; and that HibAb, here, may be an inf. n. of HaAbabotuhu; or it may be pl. of HubRN, like as EiXAXN is of EuXRN; (TA;) or it may be an inf. n. of Hababotuhu: some also read mino HabaAbiki↓, with fet-h to the H, said to mean on account of the love of thee, and of the main amount thereof: (Ham p. 26:) and some read mino janaAbiki “ from thy part ” [or “ from thee ”]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also HabiybN. ＝ -A2- Also a Persian word, arabicized, (AHát, S, Msb,) from xunob, (AHát, TA,) [or xubo or xuPo,] i. q. xaAbiyapN, (S, Msb,) A jar, (K, MF,) whether large or small, used for preparing wine: (MF:) or a large jar: (K:) or one for water: (IDrd, TA:) or the four pieces of wood upon which is placed a two-handled, or two-eared, jar: (K, TA: [in the CK, by a misplacement of words, this last signification is assigned to HabaAb:]) pl. [of pauc.] OaHobaAbN (K) and [of mult.] HibaAbN and HibabapN. (S, Msb, K.) From this last signification is [said to be] derived the phrase HubRFA wakaraAmapF [pronounced HubRFA wakaraAmaho, lit. A jarstand and a cover will I give thee, or the like], krAmp signifying the “ cover ” of a jar, (K, TA,) whether of wood or of baked clay. (TA.) [If this be the true derivation, the phrase may have originated from a person's asking of another the loan or gift of a jar, and the latter's replying “ Yea; and I will give thee a jar-stand and a cover; ” meaning “ I will do what thou requirest, and more: ” but this phrase is now, and perhaps was in early times, generally used, agreeably with the more common significations of the two words, in the sense assigned above to the phrase HubRapF wakaraAmapF.]

HibRN Hb
HibRN: see HubRN: ― -b2- and HabiybN, in four places: ＝ -A2- and HibRapN. ＝ -A3- Also, and HibaAbN↓, [but the latter is doubted by the author of the TA, and thought to be perhaps syn. with HibRN in the sense of muHibRN, and in the L it is said to be syn. with HbRN, but in
what sense is not explained,] An ear-ring [formed] of one HabRap [or bead]. (K.)

HabRapN Hb Hbh Hbp
HabRapN n. un. of HabRN [q. v.]. (S, Msb, K.) [Hence,] jaAbiru bonu HabRapa a name of (assumed tropical:) Bread. (ISk, S.) ― -b2- See also HibRapN, in two places. ― -b3- [A grain; meaning the weight of a grain of barley;] a wellknown weight. (K.) ― -b4- A [small] piece, or portion, of a thing. (S, K.) ― -b5- HabRapu Alqalobi The heart's core; (AA, TA;) the black, or inner, part of the heart; or i. q. vamaratuhu; (S, A, K;) which is that [same thing]: (S:) or a black thing in the heart: (K:) or the black clot of blood that is within the heart: (T, TA:) or the heart's blood. (K.) You say, OaSaAbato fulaAnapu HabRapa qalobihi [Such a woman smote his heart's core]. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- A want: or an object of want; a needful, or requisite, thing: syn. HaAjapN. (K.)

HubRapN Hb Hbh Hbp
HubRapN: see HubRN, in two places: ― -b2- and HabiybN. ― -b3- [It is also used in a pl. sense.] You say, huwa mino HubRapi nafosiI [He is of the beloved of my soul]. (TA voce HumRapN.) ― -b4- And HubRatuka also signifies What thou lovest to receive as a gift, or to have. (K.) You say, Aixotaro HubRataka Choose thou what, or whom, thou lovest; as also muHabRataka↓. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A grape-stone: sometimes without teshdeed; (K;) i. e. HubapN. (TA.)

HibRapN Hb Hbh Hbp
HibRapN, a pl., [or rather quasi-pl. n.,] The seeds of desert-plants that are not used as food; pl. HibabN: (S:) or seeds of herbs, or leguminous plants, (buquwl,) and of odoriferous plants: (K:) or of the latter only; (Ks, Az, TA;) and one of such seeds is called HabRapN↓; (Az, TA;) or HibRapN; the coll. n. being HibRN↓: (Msb:) or different seeds of every kind: or the seeds of the herbage called EuXob: or all seeds of plants: sing. the same, and HabRapN↓: or this signifies everything that is sown: and HibRapN, the seed of everything that grows spontaneously, without being sown: or a small plant growing among the kind of herbage called HaXiyX: (K:) and dry herbage, broken in pieces, and heaped together: (Aboo-Ziyád, K:) or dry herbs or leguminous plants: (K:) or the seeds of wild herbs or leguminous plants, and of those of the kind called EuXob, and their leaves, that are scattered and mixed therewith; such as the quloqulaAn and basobaAs and curaq and nafal and mulRaAH, and all kinds of those herbs or leguminous plants that are eaten crude, and those that are thick, or gross, and bitterish: upon these seeds and leaves, cattle, or camels &c., pasture and fatten in the end of [the season called] the Sayof (T, TA.)

HababN Hbb
HababN: see HabaAbN. ― -b2- Also, (S, K,) and HibabN↓, (K,) A beautiful arrangement of the teeth in regular rows. (S, K.) ― -b3- And Streaks of saliva on the teeth. (TA.) ― -b4- And (both accord. to the K, but the latter only accord. to the TA,) The saliva that flows over the teeth, or collects in the mouth, in little bubbles. (T, K, TA.)

HibabN Hbb
HibabN: see HabaAbN: ― -b2- and HababN.

HabaAbN HbAb
HabaAbN: see HubRN. ― -b2- HabaAbuka Thine utmost: (Msb:) or the utmost of thy power: (S:) or the utmost of thy love: or, of thine endeavour (jahodika [like juhaAdaAka and HumaAdaAka and quSaAraAka and gunaAmaAka and nuEaAmaAka]). (K. [In the CK juhodika.]) You say, HabaAbuka kacaA, (K,) and HbAbk Oano tafoEala celika, (S, Msb, * TA,) and HbAbk Oano yakuwna celika, (TA,) Thine utmost, (Msb,) or the utmost of thy power, (S,) or of thy love, or of thine endeavour, (K,) will be such a thing, (K,) and thy doing that, (S, Msb, * TA,) and that event's taking place. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, and HababN↓ and ↓, The main body, the mass, or bulk, or greater part or portion, of water, (S, K,) and of sand, (K,) and of [the beverage called] nabiyc: but it is said that the third word applies particularly to water: (TA:) or the first signifies the streaks, or lines, of water, (As, K, TA,) resembling variegated work: (As, TA:) or the waves of water that follow one another: (TA:) or the bubbles (S, A, K) of water, (S, K,) or of wine, (A, TA,) that float upon the surface; (S, A, K;) as also the second (AHn, A) and the third: (AHn, TA:) [it is a coll. gen. n., in this sense, of which the n. un. is with p:] accord. to IDrd, Hbbu AlmaMCi and HbAbu AlmaMCi signify takasRaruhu [app. meaning the ripple, or broken surface, of water, such as is seen when it is slightly fretted by wind, and when it flows over uneven ground]. (TA.) Tirota biEubaAbihaA wafuzota biHabaAbihaA, in a trad. of 'Alee, relating to Aboo-Bekr, is explained as meaning Thou hast outrun others, and attained to the place where the flood of El-Islám collects, and reached the first [springs] thereof, and drunk the purest of it, and become possessor of its excellencies: [this is the only explanation of it that I have found:] but it is also otherwise explained. (Hr and others, TA in art. Eb.) ― -b2- HabaAbN also signifies (tropical:) Dew-drops; (A;) the dew (IAth, K) that is on trees &c. in the evening. (IAth, TA.) It is said in a trad., of the inhabitants of Paradise, that their food shall turn into a sweat like HbAb Almsok, by which is meant Musky dew: or, perhaps, musky bubbles. (IAth, TA.)

HubaAbN HbAb
HubaAbN: see HubRN, in two places: ― -b2- and HabiybN. ＝ -A2- Also The serpent: (S, IAth, K:) or a serpent not of a malignant species: (TA:) and the name of a devil, (S, K,) accord. to some; (S;) but said to be so only because a serpent is called XayoTaAn. (A 'Obeyd, S, TA.) ― -b2- And a pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of which the sing. [or n. un.] is HubaAbapN [accord. to the CK HubaAbapu], meaning A certain black aquatic insect or small animal. (K.) ＝ -A3- OumRu HubaAbK (tropical:) The present world; (K, TA;) metonymically used in this sense. (TA.)

HibaAbN HbAb
HibaAbN: see HubRN, in two places: ＝ -A2- and HibRN.

HabiybN Hbyb
HabiybN A person loved, beloved, affected, liked, or approved; (S, * A, Msb, * K;) as also maHobuwbN↓ and muHabRN↓, (S, Msb, K,) of which two the former is generally used for the latter, (S, K, TA,) in like manner as are used mazokuwmN and maHozuwnN and majonuwnN and makozuwzN and maqoruwrN, each of which has its proper verb of the measure fuEila, (TA,) and HibRN↓ (S, K) and HubaAbN↓ and HubRFpN↓, which last is also applied to a female, and has for its pl. HubabN: (K:) the fem. of HabiybN is with p; (Msb, K;) and so is that of maHobuwbN↓, (K, TA,) [and that of muHabRN↓,] and that of HibRN↓: (TA:) the pl. of HabiybN is OaHibRaMCu, instead of HubabaMCu, which would be the reg. pl. but for the repetition of the b; and the pl. of HabiybapN is HabaAYibu: (Msb:) the pl. of HibRN↓ is OaHobaAbN [a pl. of pauc.] and HibRaAnN (K) and HubRaAnN (MF) and HubuwbN and HibabapN and HubRN↓, which last is rare (EaziyzN) [as a pl.], or is a quasi-pl. n. (K.) Though muHabRN↓ is uncommon it occurs in the following verse of 'Antarah:
walaqado nazalot falaA taZunRI gayorahu
minRiI bimonozilapi AlmuHabRi Almukorami
[And thou hast taken (and imagine not otherwise), in respect of me, i. e. of my heart, the place of the beloved, the honoured; or become in the condition of the beloved, &c.]. (T, TA.) ― -b2- Also, (IAar, KL, TA,) and HibRN↓, (K, KL,) A person loving; a lover; a friend; (KL;) i. q. muHibRN↓: (IAar, K, TA:) [fem. of each with p:] the pl. of the first (i. e. Hbyb) is OaHobaAbN (TA) [and OaHibRaMCu and OaHibRapN, mentioned by Golius as from the S, but not in my copies of the S: both, however, are correct: the former, the more common: the latter, a pl. of pauc.]. You say AimoraOapN lizawojihaA muHibRapN↓ and muHibRN↓ [A woman loving to her husband]. (Fr, S, K. *) ― -b3- Oabuw HabiybK The kid. (Har p. 227.) ― -b4- AlHabiybapu: see muHabRN.

HubaAHibN HbAHb
HubaAHibN, (K,) or Oabuw HubaAHibK, (S,) [A kind of fire-fly;] a fly that flies in the night, (K,) resembling fire, (S,) emitting rays like a lamp: (K:) AHn says that HbAHb and AbwHbAHb were both unknown to him, and that nothing respecting them had been heard by him from the Arabs; but that some people asserted the insect thus called to be the yaraAE, a moth that, when it flies by night, no person not knowing it would doubt to be a spark of fire: Aboo-Tálib says, as on the authority of Arabs of the desert, that HbAHb is the name of a flying thing longer than the common fly, and slender, that flies between sunset and nightfall, resembling a spark of fire: (TA:) or, accord. to As, it is a flying thing, like the common fly, with a wing that becomes red; when it flies appearing at a distance like a lighted piece of fire-wood. (Har p. 500.) naAru AlHubaAHibi (S, K) and naAruOabiI HubaAHibK and simply AlHubaAHibu (S) mean The fire of the fly above mentioned: or of El-Hobáhib or Aboo-Hobáhib: (TA:) [for] El-Hobáhib, (S,) or Aboo-Hobáhib, (K,) is said to have been a niggardly man, who never lighted any but a faint fire, fearing to attract guests, so that his fire became proverbial. (S, K.) El-Kumeyt says, describing swords,
yaraI AlrRaAWuwna biAlXRafaraAti minohaA
kanaAri OabiI HubaAHiba waAlZRubiynaA
[The beholders see, in the sides of the blades thereof, and the extremities, the semblance of the fire of the fire-fly]: (S:) here the poet has made HbAHb imperfectly decl., regarding it as a fem. [proper] name [of the fly above mentioned]. (TA.) Or nArAlHbAHb (S, K) and simply AlHbAHb (S) signify The fire that is struck by a horse's hoofs: (Fr, S:) or the sparks of fire that are made to fly forth in the air by the collision of stones: or the sparks that fall from the pieces of wood that are used for producing fire [by means of friction]: (K:) or they are derived from HaboHabapN, (IAar, K,) signifying “ weakness, ” (IAar, TA,) [and their meaning is faint fire.] ― -b2- OumRu HubaAHibK A flying insect resembling the [species of locust called] junodab, (K, * TA,) spotted with yellow and green: when people see it, they say, barRidiI yaA HubaAHibu [Spread forth thy wings (burodayoki), hobáhib]; whereupon it spreads its two wings, which are adorned with red and yellow. (TA.)

HabRacaA c
HabRacaA, meaning HabiybN, as in the phrase HabRacaA AlOamoru [Loved, beloved, affected, loved, or approved, is the thing, or affair; or lovely, charming, or excellent, is it]; (K;) and in HabRacaA zayodN [Loved, beloved, &c., is Zeyd]; (S;) is composed of HabRa, (Sb, Fr, S, K,) a verb of praise, in the pret. form, invariable, originally Habuba, (Fr, S,) and caA, (Sb, Fr, S, K,) its agent, (S,) which together constitute it a single word, (Sb, S, K,) a noun, (Sb, K,) or occupying the place of a noun, (S,) governing the noun [particularized by praise] that follows it in the nom. case; (Sb, S, K;) the place that it occupies in construction making it virtually in the nom. case as an inchoative, and the noun that follows it being its enunciative: (S:) [but see what follows.] It is used in the same manner as a prov.; (Sb, K;) [i. e., it is not altered to agree in number or gender with the noun particularized by praise, which follows it;] remaining the same when used in the dual and pl. and fem. sense; so that one says, HbRcA zayodN and AlzRayodaAni and AlzRayoduwna and hinodN and Oanota and OanotumaA and Oanotumo [&c.]; (Ibn-Keysán, TA;) and HbRcA QmoraOapN, not HabRacihi AlmaroOapu; (Sb, S, K; *) which shows that the noun that follows it may not be regarded as a substitute for cA: (S:) [but see what follows.] It is allowable, but bad, to say, zayodN HabRacaA. (TA.) [There are, however, various opinions respecting HbRcA and the noun that follows it.] Some hold that HbRcA is a noun, composed of HabRa and cA, and is an inchoative, and that the noun particularized by praise is its enunciative; or that the former is an enunciative, and the latter an inchoative, reversing the usual order: others hold that HabRa is a verb in the pret. form; and cA, its agent; and that the noun particularized by praise may be an inchoative, of which HbRcA is the enunciative; or it may be an enunciative of which the inchoative is suppressed, so that HbRcA zayodN is for HbRcA huwa zayodN [Loved, or beloved, &c., is this person: he is Zeyd], or HbRcA AlmamoduwHu zayodN [loved, &c., is this person: the person praised is Zeyd]: others hold that HbRcA is a pret. verb, composed of HabRa and cA, and that the noun following it is its agent; but this is the weakest of opinions: one also says, in dispraise, laAHabRacaA zayodN. (I 'Ak p. 235.)

1. Habarahu, (S, Msb, TA,) aor.
Habura
, (Msb,) inf. n. HaborN; (S, Msb, TA;) and HbRrhu↓, (TA,) inf. n. taHobyrN; (S, K, TA;) or the latter has an intensive signification; (Msb;) He made it beautiful, beautified it, (S, K, TA,) or adorned it, or embellished it, (Msb,) and made it plain; (TA;) namely, handwriting, and poetry, &c., (S, K, both in relation to the latter verb, and TA in relation to both verbs,) such as language, or speech, and science, (S, TA,) and pronunciation, and a recitation; meaning, with respect to the last, the voice [with which he recited]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Habarahu, (S, A, L, Msb, but in the Msb “ or, ” not “ also, ”) aor.
Habura
, inf. n. HaborN (S, Msb) and HaborapN; (S;) and AHbrhu↓; (K;) and in an intensive sense HbRrhu↓; (Msb;) He, (God, A,) or it, (a thing, or an affair or event, S, L,) made him happy, joyful, or glad; (S, A, L, Msb, K;) affected him with a happiness, joy, or gladness, that made his face to shine, or of which the mark, or sign, (HabaAr, i. e. Oavar,) appeared upon his countenance; (Bd in xliii. 70, in explanation of the pass. form of the first of these verbs;) he made him to enjoy a state of ease and plenty; and treated him with honour: (Lth and S in explanation of the pass. form of the first verb as used in the Kur xxx. 14:) or treated him with extraordinary honour. (Bd in xliii. 70, and TA.) [Hubira, properly signifying He was made happy, &c., may be used as meaning he was, or became, happy, &c.; like surRa; and HubuwrN, and its syns. mentioned with it below, may be regarded as its inf. ns. Golius, app. from his finding HabarN explained in the KL as an inf. n. meaning The being happy, &c., (XaAdo Xudano,) assigns to Hubira jiloduhu, as on the authority of that lexicon, the meaning of “ hilaris lætusque fuit; ” but I have not found this verb in any Arabic work.] ＝ -A2- Hubira jiloduhu His skin was beaten so that there remained the mark of the beating. (K.) ＝ -A3- Habira AljuroHu, (S, K,) aor.
Habara
, (K,) inf. n. HabarN, (S,) The wound broke out afresh: (S, K:) or became healed, but left scars. (Ks, S, K.) ― -b2- Habrato OasonaAnuhu, aor.
Habara
, (S, A, * Msb, K,) inf. n. HabarN, (S, Msb, *) His teeth became of a yellow colour mingled with the whiteness: (K:) or became yellow; (A, Msb;) syn. qaliHato. (S.) [See also HibirN.]

HaborN Hbr
HaborN: see HubuwrN, in two places: ― -b2- and HiborN, in two places: ― -b3- and HibirN. ＝ -A2- Also HaborN and HiborN↓; (S, A, Msb, K, &c.;) but As says, I know not whether it be the former or the latter: (S:) IAar says both: A 'Obeyd says that some of the lawyers say the former; and some, the latter; (TA;) and that in his opinion it is the former: (S, TA:) AHeyth, that it is the former only: (TA:) Th mentions the former only: (Msb:) Fr says it is the latter only: (TA:) and the latter is [said to be] the more chaste because the pl. is of the measure OafoEaAlN, and not fuEuwlN: (S, TA:) [but a pl. of the latter measure is also mentioned:] A learned man (As, S, Msb, K) of the Jews: (S, A:) or whether he be a Christian or Jewish or Sabean subject of a Muslim government, who pays a poll-tax for his freedom and toleration, or one who, having been such, has become a Muslim: or one skilled in the beautifying of language: (A 'Obeyd, S:) or a good, or righteous, man: (Kaab, K, TA:) pl. (of the former, Msb) HubuwrN, (Msb, K,) [but this is seldom used,] and (of the latter, Msb) OaHobaArN. (IDrst, S, A, Msb, K, &c.)

HiborN Hbr
HiborN Ink, syn. madaAdN, (Msb,) and niqosN, (K,) with which one writes: (S, Msb:) so called because it is one of the means of beautifying writings; (Mohammad Ibn-Zeyd, TA;) or because it beautifies, and makes plain, handwriting; (Hr, TA;) or because of the marks that it leaves: (As, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaHobaArN (IDrst, TA) and [of mult.] HubuwrN. (TA.) ― -b2- I. q. waXoIN [The variegation, or figuring, of cloth or of a garment; or a kind of variegated, or figured, cloth or garment]: (IAar, K:) pl. HubuwrN. (K, * TA.) [See also HibarapN.] ― -b3- A mark, or sign, of the enjoyment of ease and plenty: (As, S, K: [in one copy of the S, and in the CK, for Oavaru AlnRaEomapi, I find, erroneously, Oavaru AlnRiEomapi:]) and [hence,] beauty; (As, S, A, K;)
beauty of aspect; or a beautiful and pleasing aspect, that satisfies the eye by its comeliness: (As, S, TA:) colour; complexion: (Fr, IAar, S, TA:) pl. OaHobaArN (S) and HubuwrN. (K, * TA.) One says, UinRahu laHasanu AlHibori waAlsRibori Verily he is beautiful, and of goodly appearance: (As, S:) or of beautiful complexion. (IAar.) And cahaba Hiboruhu wasiboruhu His colour, or complexion, (Fr, S,) or beautiful, (A,) and goodliness of form or aspect, departed: (Fr, S, A:) from the saying, jaMCati AlOabilu Hasanapa AlOaHobaAri waAlOasobaAri [The camels came beautiful in colours and in appearances]. (Fr, S, A. *) One says also, waAlsRabori fulaAnN Hasanu AlHabori↓: where Hbr seems to be the inf. n. of Habarotuhu “ I made him, or it, beautiful. ” (S.) ― -b4- Also, (S, K,) and HaborN↓ (TA) and HabarN↓ (K) and HabaArN↓ (S, K) and HibaArN↓, (A, K,) A mark, or trace, (S, A, K,) of beating, (A,) or of a blow that has not brought blood, or of a healed wound, (TA,) or of work, or labour: (A, TA:) pl. of the first [or second] HubuwrN (Yaakoob, S, K) and [of the first and third, accord. to analogy,] OaHobaArN; (TA;) and of the fourth HabaAraAtN, (Yaakoob, S, TA,) it having no broken pl. (TA.) One says, bihi HubuwrN Upon him are marks [of beating, &c.]. (S.) And AlDRarobi bijilodihi HibaAru↓ Upon his skin is the mark of beating. (A.) And AlEamali biyadihi HibaAru↓ Upon his hand is the mark of work, or labour. (A.) ― -b5- See also HibirN. ― -b6- And see HubuwrN. ＝ -A2- Also, [like the Hebrew ???, and the Chaldee ???,] A like; an equal; a fellow. (K.) ― -b2- See also HaborN.

HabarN: see HubuwrN: ＝ -A2- and HiborN: ― -b2- and HibarapN.

HibirN, (Msb, K,) the only subst. of this form beside UibilN, (Msb,) [and a few rare dial. vars.,] and HiborN↓ (K) and HaborN↓ (A, K) and HibirapN↓ (S, Msb, K) and HaborapN↓ (A, K,) and HuborapN↓; (K;) or HibirN, without p, [as also HiborN and HaborN,] is a pl. [or rather a coll. gen. n.], (S,) and with p it is said to be a n. un.; (Msb;) A yellowness that mingles with the whiteness of the teeth; (K;) a yellowness of the teeth; (Sh, A, Msb;) what is termed qalaHN in the teeth: (S:) or qalaHN is when they become green: and when the crust increases so as to encroach upon the gums, and to make the roots of the teeth to appear, this is what is termed HaforN and HafarN: (Sh, Msb, TA:) pl. HubuwrN and HaborN↓, (S, K,) or HiborN↓, with kesr, (Msb,) and HabarN↓, which last occurs in a verse of El-'Ajjáj, for HaborN, [by poetic license,] (S,) and HaborapN↓ (A, K) and HabarapN↓, (K,) Happiness, joy, or gladness: (S, Msb, K:) or the first signifies cheerfulness; i. e. pleasure, or delight, and dilatation of the heart, which has a visible effect in the aspect: (TA voce suruwrN:) and the same word (IAth) and HaborapN↓ (Az, IAth, K) and HaborN↓, (K,) a state of ease and plenty; syn. naEomapN: (IAth, K: [in the CK and in a MS. copy of the K, erroneously, niEomap:]) or a state of complete, or perfect, ease and plenty: (Az:) and ampleness of the circumstances of life. HabiyrN Hbyr

(K.) ― -b3- And Clouds; syn. saHaAbN: (S:) or clouds spotted (munamRarN); (K;) in which one sees what resembles tanomiyr, by reason of the abundance of their water; but Er-Riyáshee disapproves of this. HubaAraI HbAr HbArI HbAry
HubaAraI [a word respecting which J says,] its alif [written I] is not the fem. alif nor the alif of quasi-coordination; [as F says of the alif of qabaEovarFI, though he finds fault with J for saying thus of the alif of HubaAraI; (see Oalifu AltRakoviyri, in art. A)] the name [says J] being only composed with it, so that it is as it were a part of the word itself, which is imperfectly decl. when determinate and when indeterminate; i. e., without tenween: (S:) but its alif is the fem. alif; for were it not so, it would be perfectly decl.; (K;) and J says that it is imperfectly decl.: (TA:) and his saying that the alif is [as it were] a part of the word itself is a strange expression, for which it would be difficult to give an answer, and which therefore requires not exorbitance: but “ it is sufficient excellence for a man that his faults may be counted: ” (M:) [A species of bustard;] a certain bird, (S, Msb, K,) well known, of the form of the goose, with a dustcolour upon its head and belly, and the back and wings of which are for the most part of the colour of the quail; (Msb;) or it is a long-necked bird, of an ash-colour, of the form of the goose, with a beak somewhat long, and that is preyed upon, but does not itself prey: Az says that it does not drink water, and that it lays its eggs in distant sands: [the truth is, that it drinks seldom: the male bird has a pouch, extending from beneath the tongue to the breast, said to be large enough to contain seven quarts of water; and it has been supposed by some that he fills this with water for the supply of himself and his mate:] and Az further says, We used, when we journeyed, to proceed in the mountains of EdDahnà, and sometimes we picked up in one day between four and eight of its eggs: it lays four eggs, of a bluish colour, more delicious in taste than those of the domestic hen and than those of the ostrich: and others say that it brings its food from a greater distance than any other bird; sometimes from a distance of many days' journey: also, that it is constantly provided with a thin excrement, or dung, which it voids upon the hawk when pursued by the latter; thus saving itself,
by preventing the hawk from continuing its flight, and, as some say, causing its feathers to drop off: whence the prov., OasolaHu mino HubaAraI: [see art. slH:] (TA:) HubaAraI is applied alike to the male and the female, and used as sing. and pl.: (S, K:) but it has pl. forms, (TA,) namely, HubaArayaAtN (S, Msb, K, TA) and HubaAraAtN: (TA:) accord. to Sb, it has not HabaArK, [in the TA incorrectly written HabaAriI, as though it had the article Al prefixed to it, or were prefixed to another noun,] nor HabaAYiru, [though both of these are mentioned as pls. of it in several of the grammars of the Arabs,] in order to distinguish between HubaAraI and nouns of the measures faEolaMCu and fiEaAlapN and the like. (TA.) It is said in a prov.,
wakulRu XaIoCK qado yuHibRu waladaho
HatRaI AlHubaAraI wataTiyru Eanadahu
[And everything certainly loves its offspring: even the bustard; and it flies by its side]: (S, Mgh: *) [in the TA, wayadifRu Eanadaho:] it flies by the side of its young one to teach it to fly before its wings have grown, because of its stupidity: (TA:) the HbArI is thus specially mentioned because it is proverbial for stupidity, and, notwithstanding its stupidity, loves its offspring, and teaches it to fly. You say, laA yuHobasu darRukumo meaning, laA tuHobasu cawaAtu AldRari [Your milch animals shall not be confined, or restrained from pasturing]. (TA.) And Habasa Almiloka Ealayohi (assumed tropical:) [He confined, or restricted, the property to him, by will or otherwise]. (Mgh in art. wqf.) And Habasa nafosahu EalaI kacaA [He confined, or restricted, himself to such a thing]. (S and K voce tHbRs.) And Habasahu Eano wajohihi [He restrained, or withheld, him from his course, purpose, or object]. (S in art. Alt; &c.) And Habasahu Eano HaAjatihi [He withheld, or debarred, him from the thing that he wanted]. (K in art. byt; &c.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Habasahu, (IDrst, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. HabosN; (TA;) and AHbshu↓, (S, IDrst, Mgh, Msb, K, [in one copy of the S, and in one of the A, AHtbshu↓, which is perhaps allowable,]) inf. n. (K, TA.) Mohammad is related to have said to 'Omar, respecting some palm-trees belonging to the latter, (Mgh, TA,) which he (the latter) desired to give in charity, (TA,) AlOaSola HabRisi↓ wasabRili AlvRamarapa (tropical:) Make thou the property itself to remain unalienable, (Mgh, TA,) in perpetuity, (Mgh,) not to be inherited nor sold nor given away, (TA,) and assign thou the profit arising therefrom to be employed in the cause of God, or religion. (Mgh, TA.) [See HabiysN.]

HabaTN, (Az, S, K, &c.,) He (a beast, Az, S, or a camel, ISd, K) ate much, (S,) or had pain in his belly from pasture which he found unwholesome, or from eating much of herbage, (ISd, K,) so that he became swollen, or inflated, thereby (S, ISd, K) in his belly, (S,) and there would not come forth from him (S, ISd, K) what was in it, (S,) or anything;
(ISd, K;) he did not void either thin dung or urine, his belly being bound: (Az:) or he (a sheep, or goat, ISk, S) became swollen, or inflated, in his belly, in consequence of eating [the herb called] curaq, (ISk, S, K, *) which is the Hanoda quwq [i. e. the herb lotus, melilot, or bird's-foot-trefoil]: (ISk, S:) or he (a beast) lighted upon good pasturage, and ate immoderately, so that he became swollen, or inflated, and died: (Z, IAth:) or, in speaking of a horse, you do not say, HabiTa Alfarasu, but HabiTa quSayoraI Alfarasi, or xaASiratuhu, or mawoqifuhu, because it means that the horse's belly became swollen, or inflated: (ISd, Z, L:) you say also, HabiTa baTonuhu his belly became swollen, or inflated, so that he died: (Az, TA:) or his (a man's) belly became swollen, or inflated, by food &c.: (Mbr, TA in art. (S, TA.) ― -b2- The scars, or marks, of a wound, or of whips, upon the body, after healing: or the swollen scars, or marks, (of whips, TA,) not lacerated: when mangled and bleeding, they are termed Euluwb [pl. of Ealob]: (K:) the excrescent flesh upon the scars of wounds. (Sgh.)

HabanoTaOapN, or, as it is written in the L, HabanoTaMCapN, but this I think a mistranscription]. (TA.) When you form the dim., you may reject the n, and change the A [which is the final letter] into I, so that [the dim. becomes originally HubayoTiIN, for which, accord. to a wellknown rule,] you say HubayoTK↓, with kesr to the T, and with tenween; for the A is not to denote the fem. gender, that the letter preceding it should be with fet-h, as in [HubayolaI and buXayoraI] the dims. of HubolaI and buXoraI: you may also retain the n, and reject the A; saying HubayoniTN↓: and thus you may do in the case of any noun having two letters added for the purpose of quasi-coordination: you may also put a compensation for the letter rejected in either place, or not: if you put a compensation in the former instance, you say HubayoTiIRN↓, with teshdeed to the I, and with kesr to the T; and in the latter instance, you say HubayoniyTN↓. biquDobaAnK, i. e. with twigs,]) put crosswise, and then bound, or tied: (Az, TA:) or pieces of wood put together like a HaZiyrap, and then bound in the middle with a cord, or rope, that joins them together. HabiykapN↓, (K,) are the tracks of the stars: (S, K:) and HabaAYikN↓ signifies also streaks, or tracks, in the sky: and the heavens; because in them are the paths of the stars: and HubukN, the streaks of a mountain: (TA:) and Hubuku diroEK, the rows of rings of a coat of mail: (TK in art. HrXf:) [in a passage in the S, cited above, it seems to be implied that it means the rimples, or folds, thereof:] or the scales of silver with which a coat of mail is ornamented; likened to the scales on the back of a fish, by their being termed the HaroXafa of a coat of mail: (TA in art. HrXf:) and HibaAku AlHamaAmi, the blackness of the part above the wings of the pigeon. (Ibn-'Abbád, A, K.) The phrase raOosuhu HubukN, in a description of Ed-Dejjál [or Antichrist], means The hair of his head is rimpled (mutakasRirN) by reason of crispness; like stagnant water, and sand, when the wind blows upon them, and they in consequence thereof become rippled (yatajaERadaAni); and marked with streaks: or, as some say, it is AlXRaEari muHabRaku↓, as in the K, meaning the same; (TA;) or crisp-haired: (K:) or Hubuku AlXRaEira, (IDrd, K, * TA,) meaning the same: (TA:) or UinRa XaEarahu HubukN HubukN: (S:) or raOosuhu HubukN HubukN. (TA.) In the phrase, in the Kur [li. 7], wa AlsRamaMCi caAti AlHubuki, it is said that AlHbk means the tracks of the stars, (S, Er-Rághib, TA,) and the milky way: or ideal tracks: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or streaks of clouds: (TA:) or beautiful TaraAYiq [which is generally understood to mean, in this instance, streaks, or the like; but may also be rendered stages, one above another, to the number of seven]: (Zj, TA:) or structures, or construction: (Mujáhid, TA:) or beautiful construction. 8: see 1, in four places.

HabolN Hbl
HabolN i. q. rasanN [as meaning A rope, or cord]; (S;) a certain thing well known; (Msb;) a thing with which one ties, binds, or makes fast, a beast &c.; syn. ribaATN: (M, K:) and i. q. rasanN [as meaning a halter]; (M, Msb, K;) as in the Kur cxi. 5; (TA;) and so muHabRalN↓: (M, K:) in the former sense, the pl. [of pauc.] is OaHobulN (S, M, K) and OaHobaAlN (M, K) and [of mult.] HibaAlN (S, M, Msb, K) and HubuwlN (M, K) and HibaAlapN (L voce juroHN) [and HubuwlapN, agreeably with a usage of the Arabs, which is, to add p to any pl. of the measure fiEaAlN or of that of fuEuwlN, (see HajarN,)] and HabaAYilu↓, which is anomalous, as in the phrase HabaAYilu AllRuWoluWi [cords of pearls], occurring in a trad.; or this is a mistranscription for janaAbicu, (K, TA, [in the CK HanAYidu,]) with j [and n] and c: (TA:) and in the latter sense, the pl. is HubuwlN. (M, Msb, K.) In a trad. in which it is said that a man's hand is to be cut off for his stealing a
Habol, the Hbl of a ship may be mean. (Mgh in art. byD.) ― -b2- [Hence, (assumed tropical:) A bond; cause of union; or link of connexion:] connexion with another by the bond of love or friendship or the like; (S, K, TA;) pl. HibaAlN: (TA:) mutual connexion by such a bond. (ISd, Msb, K.) You say, waSala fulaAnN fiI Haboli fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) Such a one married his daughter to such a one. (Har p. 223.) And huwa yaxoTubu fiI Haboli fulaAni (assumed tropical:) He aids such a one in seeking, or demanding, a woman in marriage. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., UinRa bayonanaA wa bayona Alqawomi HibaAlFA wa naHonu qaATiEuwhaA (assumed tropical:) Verily there is between us and the party a connexion by the bond of love or friendship or the like, and we are severing it. (TA.) You say also, UinRahu lawaAsiEu AlHaboli (tropical:) Verily he is large, or liberal, in disposition; [or in the scope of his friendship;] and DayRiqu AlHaboli (tropical:) narrow therein. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A covenant, or compact: (S, Msb, K, TA:) (tropical:) a covenant, or an obligation, by which one becomes responsible for the safety, or safe-keeping, of a person or thing: (K, TA:) and (tropical:) a promise, or an assurance, of security, or safety; (A 'Obeyd, S, Msb, K, TA;) such as a man, desiring to make a journey, used [and still uses] to take from the chief of a tribe: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) pl. HibaAlN. (TA.) You say, kaAnato bayonahumo HibaAlN faqaTaEuwhaA (tropical:) There were between them covenants, and obligations whereby they were responsible for one another's safety, and they broke them. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur [iii. 108], UilRaA biHabolK mina QllRehi wa HabolK mina AlnRaAsi (tropical:) Unless [they have] a covenant from God and a covenant from men: (Ibn-'Arafeh, TA:) for the unbeliever requires a covenant from God, which consists in his being of those who have a revealed scripture without which he cannot retain his religion nor enjoy protection, and a covenant granted to him by men. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And it is also said in the Kur [iii. 98], waQEotaSimuwA biHaboli QllRehi i. e. (tropical:) [And hold ye fast] by the covenant of God: (TA:) or (tropical:) the means of approach, or access, unto God; i. e. the Kur-án, and the Prophet, and intelligence, &c., which are the means of obtaining the protection of God; for HabolN is metaphorically applied to (tropical:) any means of access to a thing: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or these words of the Kur mean (tropical:) and follow ye the Kur-án, and abstain from schism. (A'Obeyd, TA.) And in like manner, the saying of Ibn-Mes'ood, Ealayokumo biHaboli QllRehi, means (tropical:) Keep ye to the Book of God; for it is a security for you, and a covenant, against the punishment of God. (A'Obeyd, TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) An elongated, or extended, tract of sand, (T, S, M, Mgh, K,) collected together, abundant, and high: (T, TA:) or HabolN mina AlrRamoli means a long, extended, tract of sand, collected together, and elevated: (Msb:) [or simply a long, or long and elevated, tract of sand; likened to a rope, as is indicated in the Mgh:] pl. HibaAlN. (TA.) ― -b5- [(assumed tropical:) A long, creeping, or twining, stalk or shoot or branch; likened to a rope or cord: pl. HibaAlN: often occurring in descriptions of plants by AHn and others.] ― -b6- See also HabalapN. ― -b7- AlHabolu (assumed tropical:) The wariyd; [a name applied to each of the two carotid arteries, and sometimes to each of the two external jugular veins;] also called Habolu Alwariydi; a vein between the windpipe and the [two sinews called the] EilobaAwaAni; (Fr, TA;) a certain vein in the neck, (S,) or in the Haloq. (Msb.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) The EaAtiq [or part between the shoulder-joint and the neck]: (K:) or AlHabolu, (K,) or Habolu AlEaAtiqi, (TA,) signifies the Tariyqap [app. here meaning, as it does in some other instances, oblong muscle] that is between the neck and the head of the shoulder-blade: or a sinew between the neck and the shoulderjoint: (K:) or Habolu AlEaAtiqi signifies a bond, or ligament, between the EAtq and the neck; (T, Msb, TA;) or between the neck and the shoulderjoint: (Lth, TA:) or certain sinews. (S.) ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) A certain vein, or nerve, (Eiroq,) in the fore arm, (K, TA,) extending from the wrist until it becomes concealed in the shoulder-joint: (TA:) or Habolu AlcRiraAEi is [a vein, or nerve,] in the arm: (S:) or HibaAlu AlcRiraAEayoni signifies the sinews that appear upon the two fore arms; and in like manner, those of a horse. (TA.) One says, huwa EalaI Haboli ciraAEika, (S, TA,) a prov., (S,) meaning (tropical:) He, or it, is near to thee: (T, S, Sgh:) or within thy power, or reach; or possible, or practicable, to thee; or easy to thee. (ISd, Z, TA.) ― -b10- Also, (K,) or Habolu AlfaqaAri, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) A certain vein, or nerve, (Eiroq,) in the back, (K, TA,) extending from the beginning thereof to its end. (TA.) ― -b11- AlHibaAlu fiI AlsRaAqi, (K,) or HibaAlu AlsRaAqayoni, (M,) (assumed tropical:) The sinews of the two shanks. (M, K.) ― -b12- AlHibaAlu fiI AlcRakari, (K,) or HabaAYilu↓ AlcRakari, (M,) (assumed tropical:) The veins (Euruwq) of the penis. (M, K.) ― -b13- AlHabolu also signifies The station of the horses collected for a race, before they are let go. (K.) [Probably it was marked by an extended rope; and for that reason was thus called.] ＝ -A2- Also Heaviness; weight, or weightiness; ponderousness; syn. viqalN. (Az, K.)

HubolN Hbl
HubolN: see HubolapN.

HibolN Hbl
HibolN A calamity, or misfortune; (S, K;) as also HabuwlN↓: (K:) pl. HubuwlN. (S, K.) ISd cites as an ex. the saying of El-Akhtal,
wa kunotu saliyma Alqalobi HatRaI OaSaAbaniI
mina AllRaAmiEaAti AlmuboriqaAti Hubuwlu
[And I was sound of heart until calamities befell me from the resplendent females, exhibiting their beauty]. (TA.) ― -b2- rajulN HibolN (assumed tropical:) A learned, sagacious, intelligent man. (IAar, K. *) [And HibolN also signifies (assumed tropical:) Very intelligent, or very cunning. Pl. OaHobaAlN.] You say, UinRahu laHibolN mino OaHobaAlihaA, meaning (tropical:) Verily he is one who possesses much intelligence, or much cunning: and verily he is a gentle manager of cattle. (ISd, K, TA.)

HabalN Hbl
HabalN: see HabalapN. ＝ -A2- It is also an inf. n.; i. e., of Habilato. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ＝ -A3- And it is also a simple subst.: (K, TA: [in the CK, wAsomu jamoEK is erroneously put for wQsomN:]) [i. e.] it also signifies The fœtus in the womb: (Mgh:) pl. OaHobaAlN. (K.) It is said in a trad., nahaI Eano Habali AlHabalapi↓, (S, Mgh,) or nahaI Eano bayoEi Habali AlHabalapi, (Msb, K,) i. e. He forbade the selling of the offspring of the offspring (S, Msb, K) in the belly (Msb, TA) of the she-camel &c.; (Msb;) [i. e.,] the offspring of the fœtus (A'Obeyd, S, Msb) in the belly of the she-camel [&c.]; (A'Obeyd, Msb;) [i. e.,] what the fœtus will bring forth, if it be a female; (Mgh;) the p in AlHblp being the sign of the fem. gender; (A'Obeyd, Mgh, Msb;) or a sign of intensiveness of the signification: (IAmb, TA:) for the Arabs in the Time of Ignorance used to sell the offspring of the offspring in the bellies (T, M, Msb, TA) of pregnant beasts, (T, Msb,) or of sheep or goats: (M, TA:) or the meaning is, what is in the belly of the she-camel: (A'Obeyd, Esh-Sháfi'ee, K:) or the produce of the grape-vine before it has attained to maturity: (M, K:) but Suh disapproves of this last explanation, as a mistake occasioned by the p in AlHblp. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Anything that is in another thing: thus, for instance, the pearl is the Habal of the oyster-shell; and the wine is the Habal of the glass bottle. (A, TA.) ＝ -A4- (tropical:) Fulness; (ISd, K, TA; [see Habila;]) as also HubaAlN↓. (IAar, K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Anger: (K, TA:) (tropical:) anger and grief; as in the saying bihi HabalN (tropical:) In him is anger and grief: (Az, ISd, K, TA:) from the same word as meaning the “ pregnancy ” of a woman. (Az, TA.) ＝ -A5- Habalo Habalo A cry by which sheep or goats are chidden. (Sgh, K.)

HabolapN Hbl Hblh Hblp
HabolapN: see HabolapN.

HubolapN Hbl Hblh Hblp
HubolapN The fruit, or produce, of the [kind of trees called] EiDaAhu, (S, K,) in general: (K:) or the pod, or receptacle of the seeds, of the samur and salam; [so accord. to AZ; as appears from a comparison of passages in art. bl in the T and TA;] that of other [trees of the kind called] EDAh being termed sinofapN: (TA:) or the fruit, or produce, of the samur, resembling the [species of kidney-bean called] luwbiyaMC; (IAar, TA;) or of the salam and sayaAl and samur, (M, K,) which is a curved thing, containing small black grains, resembling lentils: (M, TA:) or, accord. to AO, a species of tree; as is the samur: (Az, TA:) pl. HubolN↓, [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] and [the proper pl. is] HubalN. (K.) Hence, in a trad. of Saad, wa maA lanaA TaEaAmN UilRaA AlHubolapu wa waraqu AlsRamuri [We having no food except the Hblp and the leaves of the smr]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- A kind of ornament worn by women, (S, K, TA,) fashioned in the form of the fruit thus called, (TA,) and put upon necklaces, (S, TA,) used in the Time of Ignorance. (As, TA.) ― -b3- A certain herb, (baqolapN, ISd, K,) sweet, or pleasant, of the herbs termed cukuwr: so says ISd: and in one place he says, a certain tree which [the lizards termed] DibaAb eat. (TA.) ― -b4- See also what next follows.

HabalapN Hbl Hblh Hblp
HabalapN (M, A, K) and HabolapN↓, (M, A,) or HubolapN↓, (K,) (assumed tropical:) A grape-vine; (M, A, K;) its branches being likened to ropes, or cords: (A, TA:) or a stock of a grape-vine: (K:) the first of these words has the latter signification (Mgh, TA) accord. to As: (TA:) or it signifies a stock of a grape-vine having its branches spread upon its
trellises: (TA:) or the first and second signify a branch of a grape-vine: (S) or, accord. to Lth, Hblp [thus in the TA, without any syll. sign,] signifies a grape-vine: and also a TAq [app. here meaning an arch] of the branches of a grape-vine: so in the T: (TA:) and Habala↓ and HabolN↓ [are coll. gen. ns., and] signify grapevines. (K.) ― -b2- Habalapu EamorKw A sort of grapes of Et-Táïf, white, and pointed at the extremities. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also HabalN: ＝ -A3- and see what next follows.

HubolaI Hbl HblI Hbly Hblyy
HubolaI Pregnant; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also HaAbilapN↓; (K;) and HabolaAnapN↓ also occurs in the same sense: (ISd, K) applied to a woman, (S, Mgh,) or, accord. to AZ, to any animal having a nail, (S,) or to any beast, as, for instance, a sheep, or goat, and a cat: (Msb:) pl. of the first HabaAlaI (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and HubolayaAtN (Msb, K) and HabaAlayaAtN, (S, TA,) which last is pl. of HabaAlaI: (TA:) and the pl. of HaAbilapN is HabalapN↓, (K,) which is extr. (TA.) One says, AllRayolu HubolaI lasota tadoriI maA talidu (assumed tropical:) [The night is pregnant: thou knowest not what it will bring forth]: meaning that the events of the night are not to be trusted. (TA.) ― -b2- See also HabolaAnapN.

HuboliIRN Hbl HblI Hbly Hblyy
HuboliIRN and HubolawiIRN↓ Of, or relating to, one that is HubalaI, i. e. pregnant. (S, K.)

HabolaAnapN HblAn HblAnh HblAnp
HabolaAnapN: see HubolaI. ― -b2- [Hence,] HabolaAnu (tropical:) Full [of beverage, or wine, and of water; see Habila]; as also HubolaAn↓: fem. of the former HabolaI; and of the latter; HubolaI↓ [which is anomalous]: (AHn, ISd, K, TA:) and OaHobalu↓ a man full of beverage or wine. (Z, TA.) ― -b3- And HabolaAnu (tropical:) Angry; (K, TA;) full of anger; EalaI fulaAnK against such a one: (TA:) fem. with p. (Ibn-'Arafeh, K, TA.)

HubolaAn Hbl HblAn
HubolaAn: see the next preceding paragraph. [By rule, it should be with tenween, like EuroyaAnN, and should form its fem. with p.]

HubolawiIRN HblwI Hblwy
HubolawiIRN: see HuboliIRN.

HubolaAwiIRN HblAwI HblAwy
HubolaAwiIRN: see HuboliIRN.

HubaAlN HbAl Hbl
HubaAlN: see HabalN. ＝ -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) Much hair. (Az, TA.)

HabuwlN Hbl Hbwl
HabuwlN: see HibolN.

Habiylu baraHK Hbyl brH
Habiylu baraHK (assumed tropical:) One who stands in his place like the lion, not fleeing: (S:) or (tropical:) courageous: (K, TA:) and an appellation given to (tropical:) a lion; (K, TA;) as though he were prevented, as by a snare, or by a rope, from quitting his place; not quitting it, by reason of his boldness. (TA.)

HibaAlapN HbAlh HbAlp Hbl
HibaAlapN (S, Msb, K) and OuHobuwlapN↓ (Lth, Msb, K) and OuHobuwlN↓ (Lth, K) A snare; or thing by means of which one takes, catches, or snares, game, or wild animals, or birds; (S, M, K;) of whatever kind it be; (M, TA;) a Xarak, and the like: (Msb:) or HbAlp peculiarly applies to the cord (Habol) of him who takes, catches, or snares, game or the like: (Er-Rághib, TA:) pl. of the first HabaAYilu, (Msb, TA,) and of the second [and third] OaHaAbiylu. (Msb.) It is said in a prov., xaXRi cuWaAlapa biAlHibaAlapi [Frighten thou the wolf to catch him with the snare]; cWAlp meaning the wolf: applied to him whose threatening is not cared for: i. e., threaten another than me; for I know thee. (Meyd, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlnRisaMCu HabaAYilu AlXRayoTaAni (assumed tropical:) [Women are the snares of the Devil]. (TA.) And HabaAYilu Almawoti (assumed tropical:) The causes of death. (K.) And huwa HibaAlapu AlUibili (assumed tropical:) He is one who takes good care of the camels, so that they do not escape from him. (TA.) ― -b3- For the pl. HabaAYilu, see also HabolN, in two places; in the first sentence, and near the end of the paragraph.

HaAbilN HAbl
HaAbilN One who binds, ties, or makes fast, a rope, or cord. (TA.) Hence, (TA,) yaA HaAbilu Qcokuro HalRFA, a prov., (K, TA,) meaning O binder, or tyer, of the rope, bear in mind the time of untying. (TA.) ― -b2- The setter of the snare (HabaAlap) for game; (S, TA;) as also muHotabilN↓. (TA.) It is said in a prov., AixotalaTa AlHaAbilu biAlnRaAbili (S) (assumed tropical:) The setter of the snare became confounded with the shooter of the arrows: (TA in art. xlT:) or, in this instance, (S,) AlHAbl signifies the warp; and AlnAbl, the woof. (S, K.) And in another prov., vaAra HaAbiluhumo EalaI naAbilihimo (assumed tropical:) They kindled mischief among themselves: (K, TA:) AlHAbl [properly] signifying the owner of the HibaAlap; and AlnAbl, the shooter with nabol, or the owner of nabol: i. e., their case became confused: and sometimes it is applied to a party whose case has become turned from its proper state, and who become roused, or stirred up, one against another. (Az, TA.) One says also, HawRala HaAbilahu EalaI naAbilihi (assumed tropical:) He turned it upside down. (K.) And AijoEalo HaAbilahu naAbilahu, and HaAbilahu EalaI naAbilihi, (assumed tropical:) Turn thou it upside down. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) An enchanter. (Sgh, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- A [lizard of the kind called] DabR that feeds upon the Hubolap [q. v.]; (S, M, K;) and so a gazelle. (TA.) ＝ -A3- HaAbilapN: see HubolaI.

HaAbuwlN HAbwl
HaAbuwlN A rope [in the form of a hoop] by means of which one ascends palm-trees; (S, M, K;) made of bark, or of [the fibres of the palmtree called] liyf. (Har pp. 544-5.)

OaHobalu c
OaHobalu: see HabolaAnu, voce HabolaAnapN.

OuHobuwlN c
OuHobuwlN and OuHobuwlapN: see HibaAlapN.

maHobalN mHbl
maHobalN The time of pregnancy: (K:) [or the time of one's mother's pregnancy: for] you say, kaAna celika fiI maHobali fulaAnK That was in the time of such a one's mother's being pregnant with him. (S, TA.) So in the saying of El-Mutanakhkhil El-Hudhalee:
xuTRa lahu celika fiI AlmaHobali
laA taqihi Almawota waqiyRaAtuhu
[His possessions by means of which he preserves himself shall not preserve him from death: that was written for him in the time when his mother was pregnant with him: or the last word is Almahobili: so in the TA in arts. hbl and wqI: see what here follows, in the next sentence]: or the meaning is that here following. (TA.) ― -b2- [The register of God's decrees; which is called] the first writing: (ISd, K:) but in the verse cited above, the last word, accord. to some, is AlmaHobil↓, (TA,) which means Almahobil, (K, TA,) and this is the reading best known, signifying the place of gestation in the womb. (TA.)

maHobilN mHbl
maHobilN: see what next precedes.

muHabRalN mHbl
muHabRalN: see HabolN, first sentence. ― -b2- Also Hair crisped, or twisted and contracted: so accord. to the K; in which is added, Xibohu Aljavoli; but the right reading is Xibohu AlHaboli [like the rope or cord]: or having its locks twisted like ropes or cords: [thus many Ethiopian races, and some of the Arab women, twist their hair, like cords; and thus, generally, did the ancient Egyptians:] or, accord. to the M, i. q. maDofuwrN [meaning plaited, or twisted]. (TA.)

maHobuwlN mHbwl
maHobuwlN A wild animal caught, or entangled, in a HabaAlap [or snare]: (S:) or one for which a HbAlp has been set, though he may not as yet have fallen into it: and muHotabalN↓ [in the CK erroneously muHotabil] one that has fallen into it, (ISd, K,) and been taken. (ISd, TA.)

muHotabalN mHtbl
muHotabalN: see what next precedes. ― -b2- Also [The place of the hobble; i. e.] (tropical:) the pastern of a beast: (T, TA:) or the pasterns of a horse: (S, K:) originally used in relation to a bird caught in a snare. (A, TA.)

muHotabilN mHtbl
muHotabilN: see HaAbilN.

1 Habina Hbn
1. Habina, aor.
Habana
; (S, K;) and Hubina; inf. n. (of the former, TA) HabanN and (of the latter, TA) HabonN; (K;) He (a man) had the dropsy; as also AHtbn↓: (KL:) he had a disease in the belly, whereby it became large and swollen. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Habina Ealayohi, aor.
Habana
, (K,) inf. n. HabanN, (TA,) (tropical:) He became filled with anger against him. (K. TA.)

4 AHbnhu AHbnh AHbnp OHbn OHbnh
4. AHbnhu [It caused him, or his belly, to become large and swollen]: said of a disease [app. dropsy] that has befallen one; or of much eating. (TA.)

8 UiHotabana
8: see 1.

HabonN Hbn
HabonN The tree called difolaI [q. v.]; as also HabiynN↓. (K.)

HibonN Hbn
HibonN and HibonapN↓ i. q. dumRalN [all which are applied in the present day to A boil]: (K:) and [small swellings or pustules, of the kind termed] xuraAj, (K,) like dumRal: (S K:) or a thing that comes upon the body, or person, generating pus, or thick purulent matter, and swelling: pl. [of the former] HubuwnN. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also, the former, An ape, or a monkey; syn. qirodN. (Kr, K.)

HabanN Hbn
HabanN The dropsy; (S;) a disease in the belly, whereby it becomes large and swollen. (K.) ― -b2- The yellow water [of the blood; i. e. the serum: a superabundant effusion of which, in the body, constitutes dropsy]. (TA.)

HibonapN Hbn Hbnh Hbnp
HibonapN: see HibonN.

HabiynN Hbyn
HabiynN: see OaHobanu: ＝ -A2- and see also HabonN.

OmRu HubayonK c
OmRu HubayonK A certain small beast or reptile, (S, K,) well known; (K;) the EiZaAyap: (Mgh:) or a species of the [kind of lizards termed] EiZaMC; of stinking odour: (Msb:) so called because of the largeness of its belly; from OaHobanu [q. v.]: also called Hubayonapu↓; (S, Msb, K;) and sometimes the article Al is prefixed to it, (S, Msb, K,) so that it is called OumRu AlHubayoni, (S, Msb,) by poetic license: (TA:) it is of the form of the HirobaMC [or chameleon], broad in the breast, and large in the belly: (TA:) or, accord. to some, (TA,) it is the female of the HirobaMC: (S and Msb and K in art. Hrb, and TA in the present art.:) accord. to Az, it is a small reptile resembling the [kind of lizard called] DabR: (Msb:) or, as some say, a certain reptile of the size of a man's hand: or, accord. to Ibn-Ziyád, a dust-coloured reptile, with four legs, and of the size of a frog that is not large; and when the children hunt it, they say to it,
AnRa AlOamiyra naAZirN Uilayoki
OumRa AlHubayoni AunoXuriI burodayoki
[Umm-el-Hobeyn, spread forth thy two wings: verily the commander is looking at thee]: they hunt it until fatigue overcomes it, when it stops, standing upright upon its two kind legs, and spreads forth two wings that it has, of the same dust-colour; and when they hunt it further, it spreads forth wings that were beneath those two wings, than which nothing more beautiful in colour has been seen, yellow and red and green and white, in streaks, one above another, very many; and when it has done this, they leave it: no offspring of it is found; nor any genital organ: (TA:) the appellation OumRu HubayonK is determinate, like Aibonu EirosK and Aibonu MwaI; (S, Msb;) and [so is Hubayonapu↓,] like OusaAmapu; (S;) but determinate as a generic appellation: (S, Msb:) the suppression of the article does not render it indeterminate; which is contr. to rule: (S, K:) the pl. is OumRu HubayonaAtK, [which is strange,] and OumRaAtu HubayonK. (Msb.) ― -b2- The Arabs say, in one of their imprecations, SabRa QllRehu Ealayoka OumRa HubayonK maAxiDFA meaning (assumed tropical:) [May God pour upon thee] the night. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA in art. mxS.)

Hubayonapu Hbynh Hbynp
Hubayonapu: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

OaHobanu c
OaHobanu Having the dropsy; (S, Mgh, Msb;) as also maHobuwnN↓ (KL) [and HabiynN↓; so in the Lex. of Golius; and so in the present day]: having a disease in the belly, whereby it becomes large and swollen: (K:) fem. AHtbI He drew together and confined his back and his shanks (S, Mgh, Msb, and Har p. 179) with his ridaMC, (S,) or with a garment, or piece of cloth, or with some other thing, (Mgh, Msb, and Har ubi suprà,) when sitting, to be like him who is leaning [his back against a wall]: (Har ubi suprà:) he drew his legs against his belly with a garment, or piece of cloth, confining them therewith, together with his back, and binding it, or making it tight, upon them, so as to preserve him from falling, [when he sat,] like a wall: (IAth, TA:) and tHbRI↓ signifies the same: (TA:) or AHtbI biAlvRawobi he inwrapped himself with the garment: or he drew together and confined his back and his shanks with a turban or the like: (K:) for the Arabs not having walls in their deserts to lean against in their assembling, the man used to set up his knees in his sitting, and put against them a sword, or surround them [and his back] with a piece of cloth, or knit his hands, or arms, together upon them, and rest against them; this standing him in stead of leaning. HatRaI HtI Hty
HatRaI is a particle, used in three senses: (Mughnee:) it is a particle denoting the end of an extent; (Mughnee, K;) which is its predominant meaning; (Mughnee;) asserted by some to be always its meaning: (TA:) and denoting a cause, or motive: and syn. with UilRaA as an exceptive; (Mughnee, K;) which last is the rarest, and is mentioned by few. (Mughnee.) ― -b2- It is used as a preposition governing the gen. case, in the same manner as UilaI (S, Mughnee) in respect of meaning and government, (Mughnee,) denoting the end of an extent; (S;) [signifying To, till, until, or to the time of;] but the word that it so governs must be a noun properly so called, not a pronoun except in a case of poetic license; and must signify the last part, or portion, of what is signified by that which precedes HtRI, as in the saying, Oakalotu AlsRamakapa HatRaI raOosihaA [I ate the fish, even to its head]; or must be prefixed to the word signifying that part, or portion, as in the saying, [in the Kur xcvii. last verse,] salaAmN hiIa HatRaI maTolaEi Alfajori [A night of peace, or of salutation, is it, until the time of the rising of the dawn]. (Mughnee.) It is also followed by a mansoob aor., as in sirotu HatRaI OadoxulahaA [I journeyed until I entered it, AdxlhA here virtually meaning daxalotuhaA], Oano being here understood after HtRI, and the An together with the verb being rendered in grammatical analysis by an inf. n. governed in the gen. case by HtRI [so that HtRI An AdxlhA means HtRI duxuwliI UiyRaAhaA]: this is one of the cases in which HtRI differs from UilaI; for one may not say, sirotu UilaI OadoxulahaA [with Oano understood after AlI]: and in the same sense it is used in the phrase, [in the Kur xx. 93,] HatRaI yarojiEa UilayonaA muwsaI [Until Moses return to us]. (Mughnee.) ― -b3- It is also syn. with kaIo, denoting a cause or motive [of action &c., signifying To the end that, in order that, or so that], as in the saying, Oasolimo HatRaI tadoxula AljanRapa [Become a Muslim, to the end that, or in order that, or so that, thou mayest enter Paradise]; being in this case, likewise, followed by a mansoob aor. (Mughnee.) ― -b4- It is also used [as a preposition virtually governing the gen. case, Oano being understood after it,] in the sense of UilRaA, meaning Except, or unless, likewise followed by a mansoob aor., as in the following verse:
layosa AlEaTaMCu mina AlfuDuwli samaAHapF
HatRaI tajuwda wamaA ladayoka qaliylu
[The giving of superfluities is not liberality: (giving is not liberality) except, or unless, (or here we may also say until,) thou be bountiful when little is in thy possession]. (Mughnee.) ― -b5- It is also a conjunction, like wa, [signifying And, or rather even,] (S, Mughnee,) but on three conditions: first, that the word following it and conjoined by it be a noun properly so called, not a pronoun: secondly, that this noun signify a part, or portion, of what is signified by that which precedes HtRI, as in qadima AlHujRaAju HatRaI AlmuXaApu [The pilgrims arrived: even those on foot], and Oakalotu AlsRamakapa HatRI raOosahaA [I ate the fish: even its head]: thirdly, that the noun following it and conjoined by it denote either the greatest or the least [literally or figuratively] of what are included in the signification of the noun that precedes HtRI, as in maAta AlnRaAsu HatRaI AlOanobiyaMCu [Men have died: even the prophets], and zaAraka AlnRaAsu HatRaI AlHajRaAmuwna [The people visited thee: even the cuppers]. (Mughnee.) ― -b6- It is also used as an inceptive particle, (S, Mughnee,) preceding a nominal proposition, (Mughnee,) as in the following verse (of Jereer [so in a copy of the S]):
famaA zaAlati AlqatolaI tamujRa dimaMCahaA
bidijolapa HatRaI maMCu dijolapa OaXokalu
[And the slain ceased not to emit their blood into the Tigris, so that the water of the Tigris was of a mixed colour consisting of red and white]: (S, Mughnee:) and preceding a verbal proposition, of which the verb is a pret., as in the phrase, [in the Kur vii. 93,] HatRaI EafawoA waqaAluwA [So that they became numerous, and said]: (Mughnee:) and preceding a marfooa aor., as in the phrase, [in the Kur ii. 210,] HatRaI yaquwlu AlrRasuwlu [So that the Apostle said, or, as in the S, so that this was the case: the Apostle said], accord. to him who reads yaquwlu; (IHsh, in De Sacy's “ Anthol. Gramm. Ar., ” p. 82 of the Arabic text;) others reading yaquwla, which, as well as yaquwlu, here means qaAla. (Jel.) ― -b7- [Respecting the cases in which the mansoob aor. is used after HARI, and those in which the marfooa aor. is used, the following observations are made.] When HtRI precedes a future, the latter is mansoob, by reason of Oano understood before it, as in the saying, sirotu UilI Alkuwfapi HatRaI OadoxulahaA [I journeyed to El-Koofeh until I entered it: see above]: (S:) it is not mansoob unless the verb is a future: if it is future with respect to the time of speaking, it must be mansoob, as in HatRaI yarojiEa UilayonaA muwsaI [cited above]: if the verb is future with respect to what precedes, only, it may be mansoob, as in HatRaI yaquwla AlrRasuwlu [mentioned above]; or it may be marfooa; but not unless [somehow] denoting a present time; (Mughnee;) and if present with respect to the time of speaking, it must be marfooa, as in the saying, sirotu UilaI Alkuwfapi HatRaI OadoxuluhaA [I have journeyed to El-Koofeh so that now I am entering it]; (S, Mughnee; *) but if not really present, it is not marfooa unless denoting a past event as though it were present, as in HatRaI yaquwlu AlrRasuwlu [explained above]; nor may it be marfooa unless denoting an effect of what precedes it; so that you may not say, sirotu HatRaI taToluEu AlXRamosu, nor maA sirotu HatRaI OadoxuluhaA unless the mA is regarded as prefixed to the entire affirmative phrase that follows it, nor halo sirota HatRaI tadoxuluhaA; nor may it be marfooa unless it denote a complement to what precedes it, so that you may not say syorI HatRaI OadoxuluhaA, as the inchoative would in this case be without an enunciative. (Mughnee.) ― -b8- [The following verse of El-Farezdak is cited in the Mughnee as an ex. of HtRI used as an inceptive particle:
fawaAEajabaA HatRaI kulayobN tasubRuniI
kaOanRa OabaAhaA nahoXalN wamujaAXiEu
and it is there added that yasubRuniI AlnRaAsu must be understood in this verse before HtRI: but I rather think that HtRI is here a conjunctive particle, and
that the meaning is, And alas, my wonder! the people revile me: even Kuleyb revile me, as though their father were Nahshal and as though he were Mujáshi'.] ― -b9- It should be observed that HtRuI may be used in three different ways in some sentences: thus you may say, using it as a preposition (in the sense of UilaI), Oakalotu AlsRamakapa HatRaI raOosihaA [I ate the fish, even to its head]; and, using it as a conjunction, HatRaI raOosahaA [even its head]; and, using it as an inceptive particle, HatRaI raOosuhaA [for HatRaI raOosuhaA maOokuwlN so that its head was eaten]. (Mughnee.) ― -b10- It is said in the K that HtRI renders makhfood and marfooa and mansoob; and that therefore Fr said, Oamuwtu wafiI nafosiI mino HatRaI XaIoCN [“ I shall die with something respecting HtRI (remaining unsettled) in my mind ”]: this is said on the supposition that HtRI deviates in government from an established rule, which is, that a particle which governs one part of speech governs that only; those, for instance, which render mansoob and mejzoom governing verbs only, and the particles that govern nouns governing none but nouns: but the truth is, that HtRI governs only the gen. case; a marfooa noun or aor. after it would be so without it, as HtRI in this case is only an inceptive particle; and a mansoob aor. after it is rendered so by Oano understood, so that HtRI in this case virtually governs a noun in the gen. case [as has been shown above]: therefore the remark quoted above from the K is faulty, and confounds things that should be distinguished. (MF, TA.) ― -b11- Some say that HtRI is [a noun] of the measure faEolaI, from AlHatRu↓ the ceasing from a thing, having finished it; or the becoming unoccupied by a thing; like XatRaI from AlXRatRu: but Az disapproves of this, because, were it so, the pronunciation termed UimaAlap would be allowable in its case, and it is not so: HtRI, he says, is a particle, not a noun, nor a verb. (TA.) ― -b12- HatRaAma is originally HatRaI maA [Till when? until when? or how long?]: the A of mA is elided because the expression is used interrogatively, like as it is when any preposition is prefixed to it if used interrogatively, as in bima and fiyma and EamRa. (S.) ― -b13- In the dial. of Hudheyl, EatRaI is said for HatRaI. (L.)

HajRu Hj
HajRu and HijRN↓, the former an inf. n., and the latter a simple subst., (S, Msb, K,) or the latter also is an inf. n., (Sb, L,) [both used as substs.,] The pilgrimage to Mekkeh, (S, K,) or to the Kaabeh, (Msb,) to perform the religious rites and ceremonies prescribed to be observed on that occasion: (S, Msb, K:) Ks makes no difference between these two words: some say that the former is employed to signify the religious rites and ceremonies of the pilgrimage because they follow the repairing to Mekkeh, or because they are completed by shaving [the head], or because people continue long going to and fro to perform them: accord. to Az, it signifies the performance of the religious rites and ceremonies of the pilgrimage of one year; and some say HijRN↓ and HijRapN↓: (TA:) or this last signifies a single pilgrimage, for the performance of its appointed religious rites and ceremonies; deviating from rule; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) for by rule it should be HajRapN↓, (S, Mgh, K,) which, Th says, has not been heard from the Arabs: (Mgh, Msb:) Ks says that Hajajotu HijRapF↓ and raOayotu ruWoyapF are the only deviations from the model of faEalotu faEolapF in all the language of the Arabs: but El-Athram and others are related to have said, We have not heard from the Arabs Hajajotu HijRapF nor raOayotu riYoyapF; they saying only Hajajotu HajRapF↓: (L, TA:) whence it appears that HajRapN↓ and HijRapN↓ were both used: (TA:) the pl. of the latter is HijajN: (Mgh, Msb:) so in the saying, nacara xamosa HijajK [He made a vow to perform five pilgrimages]. (Mgh.) Hence, cuw AlHijRapi↓ (S, Mgh, Msb) and cw AlHajRapi↓, (Msb, TA,) which latter is said by Kz and 'Iyád and Ibn- Kurkool to be the more common, (TA,) [or, accord. to Fei, the contr. is the case, for he says,] some pronounce it in the latter manner, (Msb,) [The last month of the Arabian calendar;] the month of the pilgrimage; (S, Mgh, Msb;) so called because the pilgrimage to Mekkeh, and the religious rites and ceremonies thereof, are performed in it: (TA:) pl. cawaAtu AlHjRhi: (S, Msb:) they did not say cawuw AlHajRpi agreeably with the singular. (S.) [Hence also,] waHajRapi↓ QllRehi laA OafoEalu [By the pilgrimage which is the ordinance of God, I will not do this or that thing]: a form of oath used by the Arabs. (S, K.) What is commonly termed AlHajRu is sometimes termed AlHajRu AlOakobaru [The greater pilgrimage]: AlEumorapu [q. v.] being termed AlHajRa AlOaSogaru [the minor pilgrimage]. (Kull p. 168.) ― -b2- See also HaAjRN.
