HijaAbN [A thing that prevents, hinders, debars,or precludes:] a thing that veils, conceals, hides, covers, or protects; (S, Msb, K TA;) because it prevents seeing, or beholding: (Msb:) a thing, (A, K,) or body. (Msb,) that intervenes (A, Msb, K) between two things, (A, K,) or between two bodies; which is [said to be] the primary signification; (Msb;) [a partition, a bar, a barrier, or an obstacle:] and sometimes applied to ideal things: (Msb:) pl. jujubN. (A, Msb, K.) You say, Duriba AlHijaAbu EalaI AlnRisaMCi [The veil, or curtain, was put, or let down, over the women]. (A, TA.) And lahu daEawaAtN taxoriqu AlHujuba [He has prayers that rend the veils]. (A, TA.) And maA lidaEowapi AlmaZoluwmi HijaAbN [There is no veil, or obstacle, to the prayer of the wronged]. (A, TA.) It is said in a trad., mani QTRalaEa AlHijaAbi waAqaEa maA waraMCahu [He who gets sight and knowledge of the veil falls into that which is behind it]: i. e., when a man dies, he falls into what is behind [one of] the two veils, that of Paradise and that of Hell: (ISh, TA:) or, accord. to some, AiTalaAEu AlHijaAbi signifies the stretching out the head [and looking over the veil]; for he who examines into a thing stretches out his head to see what is behind the veil, or covering. (TA.) And in another trad., a saying of Mohammad, (TA,) UinRa QllReha yagofiru liloEabodi maA lamo yaqaEi AlHijaAbu [Verily God forgiveth the servant (his creature) as long as the precluding event shall not have happened]: AlHjAb here meaning the dying in the belief in a plurality of gods: (K, * TA:) as though one were precluded from true belief by death. (TA.) One says also, AlEajozu HajaAbN bayona AlUinosaAni wamuraAdihi [Inability is a bar between man and his desire]. (Msb.) And AlmaEoSiyapu HijaAbN bayona AlEabodi wabayona rabRihi [Disobedience is a bar between the servant and his Lord]. HujubN, and of pauc. OaHojibapN and HijaAbaAtN.] ― -b3- [Hence also,] A thin piece of flesh, (K,) resembling a piece of shin, (TA,) in the interior of the body, between the two sides, intervening between the lungs and the qSb [in the K AlqaSab, but this is evidently a mistranscription for AlquSob the lower intestines; for the HjAb is the diaphragm, or midriff]: (K, TA:) and HijaAbu Alqalobi, (A,) or HajaAbu Aljawofi, (S,) signifies [the same; as also HajaAbu Alkabidi; (see xilobN;)] what intervenes between the heart and the rest of the jwf; (S;) the piece of skin that intervenes between the heart and the belly: (A, TA:) or HijaAbu Alqalobi signifies a certain fat that clothes the heart: (AHeyth, TA in art. Xgf:) [or it signifies, or signifies also, the septum cordis: see qalobN:] pl. HujubN (A, TA.) Hence the saying, hataka Alxawofu HijaAba qalobihi (tropical:) [Fear rent open his midriff: or his septum cordis]. (A, TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The horizon: [because it terminates the view:] so in the phrase, tawaArato biQloHijaAbi (assumed tropical:) It (the sun) became concealed by the horizon; occurring in the Kur [xxxviii. 31], and in a trad. (TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A mountain: (A:) or an elevated part of a mountain. (K.) You say, qaEada fiI ZilRi AlHijaAbi (tropical:) He sat in the shade of the mountain. (A.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) The place where a [stony tract such as is called] HarRap ends. (K.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) A tract of sand uniformly continuous, and long. (K.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) The light of the sun: or the tract, or side, of the sun: (K, TA:) or [like HaAjibN] a side, or part, of the sun. (TA.)

HajorN: see HijorN, in three places. ＝ -A2- Also, and HijorN↓, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K TA,) [the latter of which I have found to be the more common in the present day,] and HujorN↓, (K, [but this I have not found in any other lexicon, and the TA, by implication, disallows it,]) The HiDon; (Mgh, Msb, K;) [i. e. the bosom; or breast; agreeably with explanations of HiDon in the K: or] the part beneath the armpit, extending to the flank; (Mgh, Msb;) [agreeably with other explanations of HiDon;] of a man or woman: (S A, Mgh, Msb, K:) pl. HujuwrN. (S, Msb.) Hence the saying, (Mgh,) fulaAnN fiI Hajori fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) Such a one is in the protection of such a one; (AZ, T, Mgh, Msb;) as also fI Hajoratihi↓. (TA.) And naXaOa fiI Hijorihi↓ and Hajorihi (assumed tropical:) He grew up in his care and protection. (K.) ― -b2- Also HijorN↓ (T, K) and HajorN (T, TA) [The bosom as meaning] the fore part of the garment; or the part, thereof, between one's arms. (T, K.) ― -b3- See also HajorapN: ― -b4- and maHojiru AlEayoni. ＝ -A3- Also An extended gibbous tract of sand. (K.)

HujorN Hjr Hjrp
HujorN: see HijorN, in three places: ＝ -A2- and HajorN: ― -b2- and maHojiru AlEayoni.

HijorN Hjr Hjrp
HijorN (S A, Mgh, Msb, K) and HujorN↓ (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and HajorN↓, (S, K,) of which the first is the most chaste, (S,) and maHojarN↓ (S, K) and HaAjuwrN↓ (K) [and maHojuwrN↓], Forbidden, prohibited, unlawful, inviolable, or sacred. (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K.) Each of the first three forms occurs in different readings of the Kur vi. 139. (S.) You say, hecaA HijorN Ealayoka This is forbidden, or unlawful, to thee. (A.) In the time of paganism, a man meeting another whom he feared, in a sacred month, used to say, HijorFA maHojuwrFA↓, meaning It is rigorously forbidden to thee [to commit an act of hostility against me] in this month: and the latter, thereupon, would abstain from any aggression against him: and so, on the day of resurrection, the polytheists, when they see the punishment, will say to the angels, thinking that it will profit them: (Lth, S: *) but Az says that I' Ab and his companions explain these words [occurring in the Kur xxv. 24] otherwise, i. e., as said by the angels, and meaning, the joyful annunciation is forbidden to be made to you: and accord. to El-Hasan, the former word will be said by the sinners, and the latter is said by God, meaning it will be forbidden to them to be granted refuge or protection as they used to be in their former life in the world: but Az adds, it is more proper to regard the two words as composing one saying: (TA:) and the latter word is a corroborative of the former, like maAYitN in the expression mawotN maAYitN. (Bd.) The same words in the Kur xxv. 55 signify A strong mutual repugnance, or incongruity; as though each said what one says who seeks refuge or protection from another: or, as some say, a defined limit. (Bd.) A man says to another, “ Dost thou so and so, O such a one?” and the latter replies HijorFA, or HujorFA↓, or HajorFA↓, meaning [I pray for] preservation, and acquitment, from this thing; a meaning reducible to that of prohibition, and of a thing that is prohibited. (Sb.) The Arabs say, on the occasion of a thing that they disapprove, lahu HujorFA↓, with damm, meaning, May it be averted. (S.) ― -b2- Homeyd Ibn-Thowr says,
fahamamotu Oano OagoXaI UilayohaA maHojarFA
walamivoluhaA yugoXaI Uilayohi AlmaHojaru
meaning, And I purposed doing to her a forbidden action: and verily the like of her is one to whom that which is forbidden is done. (S, K.) maHojarN↓ is also explained as signifying HuromapN; [app. meaning a thing from which one is bound to refrain, from a motive of respect or reverence;] and to have this meaning in the verse above. (Az.) ― -b3- Also, the first of these words, Any HaAYiT [i. e. garden, or walled garden of palm-trees,] which one prohibits [to the public]. (S.) ― -b4- And AlHijoru That [space] which is comprised by [the curved wall called] the HaTiym, (S, A, Mgh, K,) which encompasses the Kaabeh on the north [or rather north-west] side; (S, A, K;) on the side of the spout: (Mgh:) or the HTym [itself], which encompasses the Kaabeh on the side of the spout. (Msb.) [It is applied to both of these in the present day; but more commonly to the former.] ― -b5- Also, HijorN, The anterior pudendum of a man and of a woman; and so HajorN↓: (K, TA:) the latter the more chaste. (TA.) ― -b6- A mare; the female of the horse: (S, A, Msb, K:) and a mare kept for breeding; (A;) as though her womb were forbidden to all but generous horses: (T:) but in the latter sense the sing. is scarcely ever used; though its pl., the first of the following forms, (as well as the second, A,) is used to signify mares kept for breeding: (K:) HijorapN↓, as a sing., is said by F and others to be a barbarism: it occurs in a trad.; but perhaps the p is there added to assimilate it to bagolapN, with which it is there coupled: (MF:) the pl. [of pauc.] is OaHojaArN (Msb, K) and [of mult.] HujuwrN (A, Msb, K) and HujuwrapN. (K.) A poet says,
UicaA xarisa AlfaHolu wasoTa AlHujuwri
waSaAHa AlkilaAbu waEaqRa Alwalado
When the stallion, seeing the army and the gleaming swords, is mute in the midst of the mares kept for breeding, and does not look towards them, and the dogs bark at their masters, because of the change of their appearances, and children behave undutifully to their mothers whom fear diverts from attending to them. (A.) ― -b7- Relationship [that prohibits marriage]; nearness with respect to kindred. (Msb, K.) ― -b8- Understanding, intelligence, intellect, mind, or reason: (S, A, Msb, K:) so in the Kur lxxxix. 4: (S, Bd:) thus called because it forbids that which it does not behoove one to do. (Bd.) One says, fiI celika EiborapN liciy HijorK In that is an admonition to him who possesses understanding, &c. (A.) ＝ -A2- See also HajurN, in three places.

HajarN Hjr Hjrp
HajarN [A stone; explained in the K by SaxorapN; but this means “a rock,” or “a great mass of stone” or “of hard stone”]; (S, K, &c.;) so called because it resists, by reason of its hardness; (Mgh;) and OuHojurRN↓ signifies the same: (Fr, K:) pl. (of pauc., of the former, S) OaHojaArN (S, Mgh, K) and OaHojurN (K) and (of mult, S) HijaArN and [more commonly] HijaArapN, (S, K,) which last is extr. [with respect to rule], (S,) or agreeable with a usage of the Arabs, which is, to add p to any pl. of the measure fiEaAlN or of that of fuEuwlN, as in the instances of cikaArapN and fiHaAlapN and cukuwrapN and fuHuwlapN. (AHeyth.) And (metonymically, TA) (tropical:) Sand: (IAar, K;) pl. OaHojaArN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Oaholu AlHajari The people of the desert, who dwell in stony and sandy places: occurring in a trad., coupled with Oaholu Almadari. (TA.) ― -b3- AlHajaru AlOasowadu, and simply AlHajaru, The [Black] Stone of the Kaabeh. (K, TA.) El-Farezdak applies to it, in one instance, the pl. AlOaHojaAru, considering the sing. as applicable to every part of it. (TA.) ― -b4- One says, fulaAnN Hajaru AlOaroDi, meaning (assumed tropical:) Such a one is unequalled. (TA.) And rumiIa fulaAnN biHajari AlOaroDi (tropical:) Such a one has had a very sagacious and crafty and politic man made to be an assailant against him. (K, * TA.) El-Ahnaf Ibn-Keys said to 'Alee, when Mo'á- wiyeh named 'Amr Ibn-El-'Ás as one of the two umpires, qado rumiyta biHajari AlOaroDi faQjoEalo maEahu Qbona EabRaAsK faUinRahu laA yaEoqidu EuqodapF UilRaA HalRahaA (assumed tropical:) Thou hast had a most exceedingly sagacious and crafty and politic man made to be an assailant against thee: so appoint thou with him Ibn-'Abbás; for he will not tie a knot but he shall untie it: meaning one that shall stand firm like a stone upon the ground. (L from a trad.) One says also, rumIa fulaAnN biHajarihi, meaning (tropical:) Such a one was coupled [or opposed] with his like: (A:) [as though he
had a stone suited to the purpose of knocking him down cast at him.] ― -b5- liloEaAhiri AlHajaru, occurring in a trad., means (assumed tropical:) For the fornicator, or adulterer, disappointment, and prohibition: accord. to some, it is meant to allude to stoning; [and it may have had this meaning in the first instance in which it was used;] but [in general] this is not the case; for every fornicator is not to be stoned. (IAth, TA.) [See also art. Ehr.] ― -b6- AlHajaru Gold: and silver. (K.) Both together are called AlHajaraAni. (S.)

HajirN Hjr Hjrp
HajirN [Stony; abounding with stones]. You say OaroDN HajirapN [so in several copies of the K; in the CK HajorapN;] Land abounding with stones; as also HajiyrapN↓ and mutaHajRirapN↓. (K.)

HujurN Hjr Hjrp
HujurN The flesh surrounding the nail. (K.)

HajorapN Hjr Hjrh Hjrp
HajorapN A severe year, that confines men to their tents, or houses, so that they slaughter their generous camels to eat them. (L in art. nbt, on a verse of Zuheyr.) ＝ -A2- A side; an adjacent tract or quarter; (ISd, K;) as also HajorapN↓: (EM p. 281:) pl. of the former HajorN↓, [or rather this is a coll. gen. n., of which the former is the n. un.,] and HajaraAtN (S, K) and HawaAjiru↓: (K:) the last is mentioned by ISd as being thought by him to be a pl. of HajorapN in the sense above explained, contr. to analogy. (TA.) Hence, HajorapN qawomK The tract or quarter adjacent to the abode of a people. (S.) And HajorataA AlTRariyqi The two sides of the road. (TA.) And HajorataA EasokarK The two sides of an army; (A, TA;) its right and left wings. (TA.) And qaEada HajorapF He sat aside. (A.) And saAra HajorapF He journeyed aside, by himself. (TA.) And maHojarFA↓ is also said to signify the same, in the following ex.: taroEaI maHojarFA wataboruku wasaTFA She (the camel) pastures aside, and lies down in the middle. (TA.) It is said in a prov., yarobiDu HajorapF wayarotaEiI wasaTFA He lies down aside, and pastures in the middle: (S:) or fulaAnN yaroEaI wasaTFA wayarobiDu HajorapF Such a one pastures in the middle, and lies down aside: (TA:) applied to a man who is in the midst of a people when they are in prosperity, and when they become in an evil state leaves them, and lies down apart: the prov. is ascribed to Gheylán Ibn-Mudar. (IB.) Imra-el--Keys says, [addressing Khálid, in whose neighbourhood he had alighted and sojourned, and who had demanded of him some horses and riding-camels to pursue and overtake a party that had carried off some camels belonging to him (Imra-el-Keys), on Khálid's having gone away, and returned without anything,]
fadaEo Eanoka nahobFA SiyHa HajaraAtihi
walekino HadiyvFA maA Hadyvu AlrRawaAHili
[Then let thou alone spoil by the sides of which a shouting was raised: but relate to me a story. What is the story of the riding-camels?]: hence the prove., AlHukomu lilRhi
wadaEo Eanoka nahobFA SiyHa fiI HajaraAtihi
[Dominion belongeth to God: then let thou alone &c.]; said with reference to him who has lost part of his property and after that lost what is of greater value. (TA.) [And hence the saying,] qadi QnotaXarato Hajoratuhu (assumed tropical:) His property has become large, or ample. (S.) ― -b2- See also HajorN.

HujorapN Hjr Hjrh Hjrp
HujorapN An enclosure (HaZiyrapN) for camels. (S, K.) ― -b2- [And hence,] The Hujorap of a house; (S;) [i. e.] a chamber [in an absolute sense, and so in the present day]; syn. bayotN: (Msb:) or an upper chamber; syn. gurofapN: (K:) pl. HujarN and HujuraAtN (S, Msb, K) and HujaraAtN and HujoraAtN. (Z, Msb, K.) ― -b3- See also HajorapN.

HijorapN Hjr Hjrh Hjrp
HijorapN: see HijorN.

HujoriIRN Hjr HjrI Hjrp Hjry Hjryy
HujoriIRN and HijoriIRN A right, or due; a thing, or quality, to be regarded as sacred, or inviolable; (K;) a peculiar attribute. (TA.)

OaroDN HajiyrapN c
OaroDN HajiyrapN: see HajirN.

HaAjirN HAjr
HaAjirN The part of the brink (Xafap) of a valley that retains the water, (S, K,) and surrounds it; (ISd;) as also HaAjuwrN↓: pl. of the former HujoraAnN. (S, K.) High land or ground, the middle of which is low, or depressed; (K;) as also maHojirN↓: (TA:) and maHaAjiru↓ [pl. of the latter] low places in the ground, retaining water. (A.) A fertile piece of land, abounding with herbage, low, or depressed, and having elevated borders, upon which the water is retained. (AHn.) A place where water flows, or where herbs grow, surrounded by high ground, or by an elevated river. (T, TA.) A place where trees of the kind called rimov grow; where they are collected together; and a place which they surround: (M, K:) pl. as above. (K.) ― -b2- A wall that retains water between houses: so called because encompassing. (TA.)

HaAjuwrN HAjwr
HaAjuwrN: see HijorN: ― -b2- and HaAjirN. ― -b3- Also A refuge; a means of protection or defence: analogous with EaAvuwrN, which signifies “a place of perdition:” whence,
waqaAla qaAYiluhumo UinRaI biHaAjuwri
And their sayer said, Verily I lay hold on that which will protect me from thee and repel thee from me; mutamasRikN being understood. (TA.)

HawaAjiru HwAjr
HawaAjiru: see HajorapN.

HanojarapN Hnjr Hnjrh Hnjrp
HanojarapN and HunojuwrN↓, (S, K,) each with an augmentative n, (S, Msb,) [The head of the windpipe; consisting of a part, or the whole, of the larynx: but variously explained; as follows:] the windpipe; syn. HuloquwmN: (S, K:) or the former [has this meaning, i. e.], the passage of the breath: (Mgh, Msb:) or the extremity of the Hlqwm, at the entrance of the passage of the food and drink: (Bd in xxxiii. 10:) or [the head of the larynx, composed of the two arytenoides;] two of the successively-superimposed cartilages of the Hlqwm (TabaqaAni mino OaTobaAqi AlHuloquwmi), next the galoSamap [or epiglottis], where it is pointed: or the inside, or cavity, of the Hlqwm: and so HunojuwrN↓: (TA in art. Hnjr:) or ↓the latter is syn. with HaloqN [q. v.]: (Msb:) pl. HanaAjiru. (K.)

HunojuwrN Hnjwr
HunojuwrN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places. ― -b2- Also A small safaT [or receptacle for perfumes and the like]. (K.) ― -b3- And A glass flask or bottle (qaAruwrap), (K, TA,) of a small size, (TA,) for cariyrpa [q. v.]. (K, TA.)

OuHojurRN c
OuHojurRN: see HajarN.

maHojirN mHjr
maHojirN: see HijorN, in four places. ― -b2- Also, (S,) or maHojirN↓ and miHojarN↓, (K,) The tract surrounding a town or village: (S, K:) [pl. maHaAjiru.] Hence the maHaAjir of the kings (OaqoyaAl) of ElYemen, which were Places of pasturage, whereof each of them had one, in which no other person pastured his beasts: (S, K:) the mHjr of a qayol of El-Yemen was his tract of land into which no other person than himself entered. (T.) ― -b3- See also HajorapN. ― -b4- And see maHojru AlEayoni.

maHojirN mHjr
maHojirN (S, K) and miHojarN↓ (K) A garden surrounded by a wall; or a garden of trees; syn. HadiyqapN: (S, K:) or a low, or depressed, place of pasture: (T, TA:) or a place in which is much pasture, with water: (A, * TA:) pl. maHaAjiru. (S, A.) See also HaAjirN for the former word and its pl.: and see maHojarN. ― -b2- maHojiru AlEayoni (S, K, &c.) and maHojaruhaA↓ (TA) and miHoHaruhA↓ (K) and simply AlmHjr (Msb, TA) and AlHajoru↓ (K) and AlHujoru↓, which occurs in a verse of El-Akhtal, (IAar,) [The part which is next below, or around, the eye, and which appears when the rest of the face is veiled by the niqaAb or the buroquE:] that part [of the face, next below the eye,] which appears from out of the [kind of veil called] niqaAb (T, S, A, Msb, K) of a woman (A, Msb, K) and of a man, from the lower eyelid; and sometimes from the upper: (Msb:) or the part that surrounds the eye (Msb, K) on all sides, (Msb,) and appears from out of the [kind of veil called] buroquE: (Msb, K:) or the part of the bone beneath the eyelid, which encompasses the eye: (TA:) and mHjr AlEyn means also what appears from beneath the turban of a man when he has put it on: (K: [accord. to the TA, the turban itself; but this is a meaning evidently derived from a mistranscription in a copy of the K, namely, EimaAmatuhu for EimaAmatihi:]) also mHjruAlwajohi that part of the face against which the nqAb lies: and AlmHjr the eye [itself]: (T, TA:) the pl. of mHjr is maHaAjiru. (A, Msb.)

miHojarN mHjr
miHojarN: see maHojarN: ― -b2- and see also maHojirN, in two places.

maHojuwrN Ealayohi mHjwr Elyh mHjwr Elyp
maHojuwrN Ealayohi, for which the doctors of practical law say maHojuwrN only, omitting the preposition and the pronoun governed by it, on account of the frequent usage of the term, A person prohibited [by a kádee] from using, or disposing of, his property according to his own free will: (Msb:) or prohibited from consuming, or wasting, or ruining, his property. (Mgh.) ― -b2- See also HijorN, in two places.

OaroDN mutaHajRirapN c
OaroDN mutaHajRirapN: see HajirN.

1 Hajazapu Hjz Hjzh Hjzp
1. Hajazapu, aor.
Hajuza
(S, K) and
Hajiza
, (K,) inf. n. HajozN (S, K) and HijaAzapN and HijRiyzaI↓, (K,) [or the last is rather a quasi-inf. n. of taHaAjazuwA, and, accord. to some, it is of an intensive form,] He, or it, prevented, hindered, impeded, withheld, restrained, or debarred, him, or it; syn. manaEahu, (S, K,) and kafRahu. (K.) It is said in a trad., waliOaholi Alqatiyli Oano yaHojuzuwA AlOadonaI faAlOadonaI And it is for the family of the slain person to prevent the nearest [in relationship] and then the nearest [after him] from retaliating the slaughter. (TA.) And one says, kaAnato bayona Alqawomi rimRiyRaA vumRa SaArato UilaI HijRiyzaI↓ There was a shooting of arrows or the like [or a great shooting &c.] between the people; then they withheld themselves [or withheld themselves much] from each other: (S, L:) which is a prov. (TA.) It is also said in another prov., maA yuHojazu fulaAnN fiI AlEilomi (tropical:) Such a one's case [with respect to knowledge or science] cannot be concealed. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Hajaza bayonahumaA, (A, Msb, K,) aor.
Hajuza
(Msb, K) and
Hajiza
, (K,) inf. n. HajozN, (Msb,) He, or it, intervened as, or made, or formed, a separation, a partition, a fence, a barrier, or an obstacle, or obstruction, between them two; he separated, or parted, them; (Msb, K;) i. e., two things; (Msb;) or two persons or things facing, or opposite to, each other. (Az, A, TA.)

2 saToHN lamo yuHajRazo bijidaArK sTH lm yHjz bjdAr
2. saToHN lamo yuHajRazo bijidaArK [A flat roof that has not been fenced round with a wall to prevent persons falling from it]. (K in art. jlH.)

3 HaAjazuwA EaduwRahumo HAjzwA Edwhm
3. HaAjazuwA EaduwRahumo, (A,) inf. n. muHaAjazapN, (S, K,) They reciprocally prevented their enemy from fighting with them, or reciprocally abstained from fighting with them, and made peace with them; syn. kaAfRuwhumo, (A,) and syn. of the inf. n. mumaAnaEapN, (S, K, TA,) and musaAlamapN. (TA.) It is said in a prov., Uino Oaradota AlmuHaAjazaho faqabola AlmunaAjazaho [If thou desire the reciprocal prevention of fighting, and the making of peace, let it be before fighting]: (S, TA:) or AlmuHaAjazaho qabola AlmunaAjazaho [The reciprocal prevention of fighting, and the making of peace, should be before fighting]. (A.) [See also art. njz.]

4: see 8.

6 taHaAjazaA tHAjzA
6. taHaAjazaA They prevented one another, or mutually abstained, from fighting, [and made peace, one with another; (see also 3;)] syn. tamaAnaEaA: (S * K, TA:) said of two troops. (S.) ― -b2- tHAjz Alqawomu The people separated themselves, one from another; they left, forsook, or relinquished, one another; as also AnHjzwA↓ and AHtjzwA↓. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also tHAjz Alqawomu The people took, or took hold of, one another by the Hujaz [pl. of HujozapN]; took hold of one another's Hujaz: (TA:) [or sought aid, or refuge and protection, one of another: see HajozapN.]

7 AnHjz AnHjz
7. AnHjz quasi-pass. of Hajazahu in the first of the senses explained above; (TA;) He, or it, was, or became, prevented, hindered, impeded, withheld, restrained, or debarred; he withheld, or restrained, himself; he refrained, forbore, or abstained. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- AnHjz Eanohu He left, forsook, or relinquished, it. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 6. ＝ -A2- See also 8.

8 AHtjz bihi AHtjz bh AHtjz bp
8. AHtjz bihi He, or it, was, or became, defended, or he defended himself, by it; syn. AmotanaEa. (TA.) [See also another explanation in what follows.] ― -b2- AHtjzA They two were, or became, separated, or parted, each from the other. (TA.) See also 6. ＝ -A2- AHtjzhu He carried it in his Hujozap: (A, K: *) like as AiHotaDanahu signifies “he carried it in his HiDon” (A.) ― -b2- AHtjz biUizaArihi He tied his AzAr upon [or around] his waist; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) he made the two ends thereof to meet, and tied it upon his waist; (A, TA;) he wrapped it round his waist. (TA.) ― -b3- Hence, AHtjz biAlHiraAri waAljibaAli It was encompassed by the stony tracts called HrAr [pl. of HarRapN], and by the mountains. (Mgh.) ＝ -A3- AHtjz He, (a man, TA,) or it, (a party of people, S,) came to the province called El-Hijáz; (S, K;) as also AnHjz↓; (ISk, S, K;) and AHjz↓, (K,) inf. n. UiHojaAzN. (TA.)

HajozN Hjz
HajozN One who abstains from what is unlawful and indecorous. (TA.) [See also HujozapN.]

HijozN Hjz
HijozN: see HujozapN, in two places.

HajozapN Hjz Hjzh Hjzp
HajozapN A severe year, that confines men to their tents or houses, so that they slaughter their generous camels to eat them. (L in art. nbt, on a verse of Zuheyr.)

Hujozapu AlUizaAri Hjzp AlAzAr
Hujozapu AlUizaAri The place [or part] of the AzAr where it is tied [round the waist]; (S, Msb, K, TA;) the place where the end of the AzAr is folded, or doubled, in wrapping it round: (Lth, TA:) and [in like manner] Hujozapu AlsRaraAwiyli [the tuck, or doubled upper border, of the trousers, through which passes the waist-band, i. e., the band or string that binds them round the waist;] the part of the trousers in which is the tikRap [or waist-band]; (S;) the place of the tikRap: (K:) pl. HujazN (Msb, TA) and HujuzaAtN and HujazaAtN: (TA:) and hence HujozapN is applied to the garment called UizaAr itself; as also HijozN↓; of which latter the pl. is HujuzN, with two dammehs, [app. contracted into HujozN,] and pl. pl. HujuwzN: Z says that HijozN↓ and HujozN signify the same. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, XidRapN AlHujozapi (tropical:) Patience, (K, TA,) and hardiness. (TA.) HadRN Hd
HadRN Prevention, hinderance, an impediment, a withholding, restraint, a debarring, inhibition, forbiddance, prohibition, or interdiction; (S, Mgh, L, Msb, K, TA;) as also HadadN↓: (S, L, K:) and, both words, a repelling, or an averting. (K. [See 1.]) A poet says, (S,) namely, Zeyd Ibn-' Amr Ibn-Nufeyl, (TA,)
laA taEobudanRa UilehFA gayora xaAliqikumo
waUino duEiytumo faquwluwA duwnahu Hadadu↓
[Ye shall by no means worship any deity except your Creator; and if ye be invited to do so, say ye, There is an impediment in the way of it, or a prohibition against it]. (S, TA.) And one says, duwna maA saOalota Eanohu HadadN↓ (A, * L) There is an impediment, or a prohibition, in the way of that respecting which thou hast asked. (L.) And Eanohu laAHadada↓ There is nothing to prevent, or hinder, one from it. (L. [But this admits of another meaning, as will be seen, under the word HadadN, below.]) ― -b2- [Hence,] A restrictive ordinance, or statute, of God, respecting things lawful and things unlawful: pl. HuduwdN. (L.) The Huduwd of God are of two kinds: first, those ordinances prescribed to men (T, Mgh, L) respecting eatables and drinkables and marriages &c.; what are lawful thereof and what are unlawful: (T, L:) the second kind, castigations, or punishments, prescribed, or appointed, to be inflicted upon him who does that which he has been forbidden to do; (T, Mgh, L;) as the HdR of the thief, which is the cutting off of his right hand for stealing a thing of the value of a quarter of a deenár or more; and that of the fornicator or fornicatress, which is flogging with a hundred stripes and banishment for a year; and that of the adulterer or adulteress, which is stoning; and that of the person who [falsely] charges an honest or a married woman with adultery, which is flogging with eighty stripes [as is also that of the person who has committed the crime of drunkenness]: (T, L:) the first kind are called Hdwd because they denote limits which God has forbidden to transgress: the second, because they prevent one's committing again those acts for which they are appointed as punishments; (T, Mgh, L;) or because the limits thereof are determined: (Mgh:) the latter kind of HdR is also explained as being that [castigation, or punishment,] which prevents the criminal from returning to his crime, and prevents others from committing his crime. (L, K. *) lawo raOayotahu EalaI HadRK, in a saying of ' Omar, means Hadst thou seen him engaged in an affair requiring the infliction of the HdR. (Mgh.) ― -b3- A bar, an obstruction, a partition, or a separation, (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, * K,) between two things, (S, A, L, K,) or between two places, (Mgh,) [or between two persons,] to prevent their commixture, or confusion, or the encroachment of one upon the other: (L:) an inf. n. used as a subst.: (Mgh:) pl. HuduwdN. (L.) ― -b4- A limit, or boundary, of a land or territory: pl. as above. (L.) [Hence, jaAwaza AlHadRa (assumed tropical:) He, or it, exceeded the proper, due, or common, limit; was excessive, immoderate, beyond measure, enormous, inordinate, or exorbitant.] ― -b5- [And hence, in logic, (assumed tropical:) A definition.] It is applied by the learned to the Haqiyqap of a thing, [or that by being which a thing is what it is,] because it is [a term] collective and restrictive. (Mgh.) ― -b6- The end, extremity, or utmost point, of a thing: (S, L, K:) pl. as above. (L.) ― -b7- [(assumed tropical:) The point, or verge, of an event.] The saying musolimapN mawoquwfapN EalaI HadRi maHoramK means (assumed tropical:) A Muslimeh brought to the point, or verge, of being subjected to an infidel's lying with her: and in like manner, musolimN mawoquwfN EalaI HadRi kuforK (assumed tropical:) A Muslim brought, by beating or slaughter, to [the point, or verge, of] denying God. (Mgh.) ― -b8- The edge, or extremity of the edge, (S, L,) and point, (L,) of anything, (S, L,) as of a sword, a knife, a spear-head, and an arrow: (L:) the part of a sword [&c.] with which one cuts: (MF:) pl. as above. (L.) ― -b9- See also HidRapN, in four places. ― -b10- [And hence, app.,] Arms, or weapons; as in the phrase cawuw HadRK [Possessors of arms or weapons: or this may mean (tropical:) persons endowed with valour]. (Ham p. 143.) ― -b11- A side, region, quarter, or tract. (L.) ― -b12- (assumed tropical:) Station, standing, rank, condition, or the like; syn. marotabapN. (KL.) ― -b13- [(assumed tropical:) A case: as when a noun is said to be fiI HadRi AlrRafoEi in the nominative case. ― -b14- And (assumed tropical:) A class, or category: as when a verb is said to be mino HadRi Daraba of the class, or category, of Daraba.] ― -b15- [(tropical:) A quarter of the year.] You say, OaqaAma HadRa AlrRabiyEi (tropical:) He remained, stayed, or abode, during the quarter of the rbyE. (A.) ＝ -A2- See also maHoduwdN.

HadiydN i. q. muHaAdRN↓. (A.) You say, fulaAnN Hadiydu fulaAnK Such a one is the close, or next, neighbour of such a one; meaning that the house of the former is next by the side of that of the latter; (A, * L;) or that the land of the former is adjacent to that of the latter. (S, L.) And huwa HadydiI fiI AldRaAri, i. e. muHaAdRiI↓ [He is my next neighbour in respect of house]. (A.) And daAriI Hadiydapu daArihi, and muHaAdRatuhaA↓ (L, K,) or lidaArihi muHAdRapN↓, (A,) My house is close, or next, or adjoining, to his house; meaning that the limit of the former is like that of the latter. (L, K. *) ＝ -A2- Also, (S, L, Msb, K,) used as masc. and fem. without p, and also as fem. with p, (L,) and HaAdRN↓, (S, L, Msb,) but this is disapproved by IKh, (TA,) though allowed by some as agreeable with analogy, (MF,) and HudaAdN↓, (As, L, K,) and HudRaAdN↓, (AA, S, L, K,) [Edged, or sharpened; or] sharp; applied to a sword, (S, Msb,) a knife, (L, Msb, K,) [and the like: and pointed, or sharp-pointed:] pl. [of the first] HidaAdN, (S, L, K,) masc. and fem.; (L;) and HadiydaAtN and HadaAYidu, (L, K,) fem. (L.) And naAbN HadiydN and HadiydapN A sharp canine tooth: (L, K:) HudaAdN thus applied has not been heard. (L.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rajulN HadiydN (tropical:) A man who is sharp [or effective] in respect of eloquence, and of intellect or understanding, and (as also muHotadRN↓, S) of anger: pl. And rajulN Hadiydu AlnRaAZiri (tropical:) [A man who looks sharply, or boldly;] a man not suspected of evil, so that he should cast down his eyes. (L.) fabaSaruka Alyawoma HadiydN [in the Kur 1. 21] means (assumed tropical:) And thy sight, or intellect, to-day, is] sharp, or piercing; so that thou perceivest therewith what thou didst not know, or what thou deemedst improbable, in thy life on earth: (Jel:) or thy judgment, to-day, is penetrating. (L.) [Hence also,] raAYiHapN HadiydapN (L) and HaAdRapN↓ (L, K) (tropical:) A sharp, or pungent, odour. (L, K.) And naAqapN Hadiydapu AljirRapi (tropical:) A she-camel whose cud has a pungent odour; (K, TA;) which is a quality approved. (TA.) ＝ -A3- HadiydN also signifies [Iron;] a certain substance, (L,) well known; (S, L, K;) so called because of its resistance: (S, L:) HadiydapN↓ is a more particular term, (S,) signifying a piece thereof; (L;) [and an instrument, or implement, thereof:] pl. HadaAYidu (S, L, K) and HadaAYidaAtN; (S L;) the latter (which is erroneously written in the K HadiydaAtN, TA) is a pl. pl., (L,) sometimes occurring in poetry. (S.) It is said in a prov.,

And in another, taDoribu fiI HadiydK baAridK [Thou beatest upon cold iron]: applied in relation to him who hopes for that of which the attainment is remote, or improbable; and to him in whom is nothing to be hoped for. (Har p. 633.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Like iron in hardness: applied in this sense to solid hoofs. (Mgh.)

HidaOapN, (S, Msb, K,) or HidaON↓, [but see what follows,] sometimes pronounced HadaON↓, (Mgh,) [The kite; vulgarly called HidaAyap;] a certain bird, (S, Mgh, K,) well known; (S, K;) a certain noxious bird; (Msb;) surnamed OabuwAlxaTRaAfi and Abw AlSRaloti; (TA;) that preys upon large field-rats (jirocaAn): (Mgh, TA:) J and Sgh say that the word should not be pronounced HadaOapN↓; but AHei mentions this pronunciation on the authority of [some of] the Arabs; and accord. to IAar and IAmb, the faOos [see above] and this bird were sometimes called alike HadaOapN↓ and HadaON↓: the more approved pronunciation of the name of the bird, however, is with kesr [i. e. HidaOapN]: the pl. is HidaON↓ (S, Msb, K) and HidaMCN, (K,) both extr., (TA,) [or rather the former is a coll. gen. n.,] and HidoMnN: (Msb, K:) and the following are variations of the name of this bird: HudRaI, and HudayRaA, (TA,) the latter said by AHát to be an erroneous form of the word, used by the people of El-Hijáz, (Mgh, TA,) and HudayoYiyapN↓, app. a dim., for HudayoYapN↓, also pronounced HudayRapN, (TS, TA,) and HuduwRN, occurring in a trad. in conjunction with OufoEuwRN [for OafoEFI], (Mgh, TA,) of the dial. of the people of Mekkeh. (TA in art. Hdw.)
Hence the saying, waraMCaki bunoduqap HidaOa HidaOa↓, (S, K, TA,) for which the vulgar say, HadaA HadaA, (S,) [accord. to some, meaning O kite, O kite, a bullet is behind thee: accord. to others, O Ḥidà, O Ḥidà, Bunduḳah is behind thee:] Esh-Sharḳee (Ibn-El-Ḳuṭámee, Ta) Says, (S,) HidaON and bunoduqapu were two tribes, descendants of HidaOu bonu namirapa and bunoduqapu bonu maZRapa, (S, K, *) and both of saEodu AlEaXiyrapi; (S, TA;) the former in El-Koofeh, and the latter in El-Yemen: the former attacked the latter, and obtained spoil from them; and then the latter attacked the former, and destroyed them: (TA:) and hence this saying: (S, K, TA:) or HidaOa is here an apocopated form of HidaOap: (S, K:) so says ISk: (S:) and AO says that by it is here meant the bird [i. e. the kite]; and by bndqp, the thing with which one shoots [from a cross-bow, namely, a bullet]; and the prov. is used to caution a person: accord. to Ibn-El-Kelbee, it is applied to him who esteems himself cunning in an affair, and is outwitted therein by another: accord. to the A, to him who is threatened with an evil near at hand. (TA.) ＝ -A2- HidaOapN also signifies The saAlifap (meaning the fore part, TA, [or the fore part from beneath the ear to the middle of the collarbone,]) of the neck of a horse: (As, K:) pl. HidaMCN. (As, TA.) ＝ -A3- See also HadaOapN.

HuduwvN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and HadaAvapN, (A, K,) It was new, or recent; contr. of qaduma: (S, * A, K:) it (a thing) came into existence; began to be; had a beginning; began, or originated; existed newly, for the first time, not having been before: (S, Mgh, Msb, TA:) but when mentioned with qaduma, it is written Haduva, with damm to the d, (S, Mgh, K,) as in the saying, OaxacaniI maA qaduma wamaAHaduva, (S,) or Oaxacahu Alx, (A, Mgh,) meaning Old and new anxieties and thoughts [came into my mind, or his mind, or overcame me, or him]; (TA;) or old and new griefs or sorrows; (Mgh;) the former saying occurring in a trad.: (TA:) the verb is not thus in any other case [in this sense]. HuduwvN is of two kinds: HuduwvN zamaAniIRN, which is A thing's being preceded by non-existence: and HuduwvN caAtiIRN, which is a thing's being dependent upon another for its existence. HadavN Hdv
HadavN A novelty, or new thing; an innovation; a thing not known before: and particularly relating to El-Islám [i. e. to matters of religious doctrine or practice or the like]: (Mgh:) [and so OamorN muHodavN↓; for] muHodavaAtu AlOumuwri (pl. of muHodavN, TA) signifies innovations of people of erroneous opinions, (Msb, TA,) inconsistent with the doctrines, or practices, of the just of preceding times: or what is not known in revealed scripture, nor in the Sunneh, nor in the general conventional tenets of the doctors of the law: and HadavN, [in like manner,] an innovation that is disapproved, not agreeable with custom, or usage, and not known in the Sunneh. (TA.) MwaI muHodavFA↓, occurring in a trad., means He entertained an innovation; [i. e. he embraced, or held, it;] or he was content, or pleased, with it; or he bore it patiently: or, as some say, it is MwaI muHodivFA↓, meaning he entertained, or harboured in his dwelling, a criminal, or an offender, and protected him from retaliation. (TA.) ― -b2- Also i. q. HaAdivapN↓ and HadavaAnN↓ [in some copies of the S HidovaAn↓] and HudovaI↓ [signifying An accident, an event, a hap, or a casualty: and generally an evil accident or event, a mishap, a misfortune, a disaster, a calamity, or an affliction]: (S:) [the most common of these words is HaAdivapN↓; and its pl., HawaAdivu, is more common than the sing.:] the pl. of HadavN is OaHodaAvN. (TA.) OaHodaAvu AldRahori and HawaAdivuhu↓ (A, K) and HidovaAnuhu↓, (K,) or, as is said by Fr and others, this last is HadavaAnuhu↓, (TA,) signify The accidents, or casualties, of time or fortune; or the evil accidents, or calamities, of time or fortune. (A, K.) HawaAdivu↓ occurs used as a sing., said to be put by poetic license for HadavaAnN↓: and this latter is also used [as a pl.] for HawaAdivu: so say Az and AAF: and it is said to be a noun in the sense of HawaAdivu AldRahori and nawaAYibu AldRahori: accord. to Fr, the Arabs say, [using it as a pl.,] OaholakatonaA AlHadavaAnu [The accidents, or evil accidents, of time, or fortune, destroyed us]: some say AlHadavaAni, making it dual of HadavN, and meaning thereby the night and day; like as they say [in the same sense] AljadiydaAni and AlmalawaAni &c. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence] HadavN is a term applied by Sb to The maSodar [or infinitive noun]; because all mSAdir are [significant of] accidents [considered as subsisting in, or proceding from, agents]: and the pl. which he assigns to it in this sense is OaHodaAvN. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The voiding of ordure; or the breaking of wind; syn. UibodaMCN: (K:) or legal impurity that forbids, or prevents, one's performing prayer &c.: (KT:) or a state annulling legal purity: pl. OaHodaAvN. (Msb.) [See 4.] ― -b5- I. q. waliIRN (assumed tropical:) [The rain following that called the wasomiIR]: (L:) or AlOaHodaAvu [pl. of AlHadavu] signifies the rains of the commencement, or first part, of the year. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. xabarN [Information; a piece of information; intelligence; an announcement; news, or tidings; a piece of news; an account; a narration, or narrative; a story; &c.]; (S, K;) employed to signify little and much; (S;) and HidRiyvaI↓ signifies the same: (K:) or a thing, or matter, that is talked of, told, or narrated, and transmitted: (Msb:) [and talk, or discourse:] and [in like manner] OuHoduwvapN↓ signifies a thing that is talked of, told, or narrated: (S, K:) or this last signifies a wonderful thing: (IB, TA:) it has been asserted, says MF, that there is no difference between AHdwvp and Hdyv in usage, and in denoting what is good and what is evil; in contradiction to such as say that the former peculiarly signifies that [kind of story] in which there is no profit nor any truth; such as amatory stories, and the like fictions of the Arabs: Fr asserts it to signify peculiarly a laughable and an absurd story; differing from Hdyv: and Ibn-Hishám El-Lakhmee, in his Expos of the Fs, says that it is only used to denote what is bad, or evil: but Lb replies against him, in his Expos., that it is sometimes used to denote what is good; as in a saying mentioned by Yaakoob, which see below: (TA:) the pl. of HadiyvN is OaHaAdiyvu, contr. to analogy, (S, K,) said by Fr to be pl. of OuHoduwvapN↓, and then used as pl. of Hdyv, (S,) but IB says that this is not the case; (TA;) and HidovaAnN and HudovaAnN are also pls. of Hdyv, (K, TA,) sometimes occurring; the latter, rare. (TA.) You say, samiEotu HadiyvFA HasanFA (TA) and HasanapF HidRiyvaI↓ (S, A, * TA) [I heard a good story or narrative &c.]; both meaning the same. (TA.) And AinotaXara HasanapN lahu fiI AlnRaAsi OuHoduwvapN↓ [A good story of him became spread abroad among the people]: a saying mentioned by Yaakoob in his “ Isláh. ” (TA.) And maliyHapN OvHoduwvapN↓ [A pretty story], and OaHaAdiyvu milaAHN [pretty stories]. (A.) And qado SaAra fulaAnN OaHoduwvapF↓ [(tropical:) Such a one has become the subject of a story, or of a wonderful story: and in like manner, as is said in the A, SaAruwA OaHaAdiyva: there said to be tropical]. (IB, TA.) ― -b2- Hence the Hadiyv of the Apostle of God: (Msb:) [i. e.] HadiyvN also signifies A narration of a muHadRiv: (L:) [meaning HadiyvN nabawiIRN, i. e. a tradition, or narration, relating, or describing, a saying or an action &c. of Mo- hammad:] this word and xabarN both signify a tradition that is traced up to Mohammad, or to a Sahábee, or to a Tábi'ee: (TA in art. rqO:) or Hdyv is applied to what comes from the Prophet: xabarN, to what comes from another than the Prophet; or from him or another: and OavarN to what comes from a Companion of the Prophet; but it may also be applied to a saying of the Prophet: (Kull p. 152:) the word in this sense, i. e. the Hdyv of the Prophet, has for its pl. only OaHaAdiyvu; and therefore Sb mentions it in the category of those words which have pls. anomalously formed; such as EaruwDN, pl. OaEaAriyDu; and baATilN, pl. OabaATiylu. (TA.) [AlHadiyva written at the end of a quotation of a part of a trad. is for AiqoraOi AlHadiyva Read the tradition.] ― -b3- HadiyvN qudosiIRN [A holy tradition or narration] means what God has told to his prophet by inspiration, or by a dream, or in sleep, and the prophet has told in his own phraseology: the Kur-án is esteemed above this, because [it is held that] its words also were revealed: (KT:) that of which the words are from the apostle, but the meaning is from God, by inspiration, or by a dream, or in sleep. And Hadasotu Ealayohi ZanRiI I formed my opinion of it, not being certain of it; as also nadasotu. (TA.) And Hadasa AlkalaAma EalaI EawaAhinihi He spoke without anything to guide him, and without caution. (TA.) And Hadasa AlXRaIoCa He computed by conjecture the quantity, measure, or the like, of the thing. (A.) 1 HadaA AlUibila HdA AlAbl
1. HadaA AlUibila, (S, Mgh,) or Hada biAlUibili, (Msb,) or both, (K) and HudaMCN (S, K) and HidaMCN, (K,) He drove the camels; (S, Mgh, K;) and chid them: (K:) [and AHtdAhA↓ app. has the former signification:] and he sang to them: (S:) or he urged, or excited, the camels by singing to them, which
is termed HudaMCN↓: (Msb:) or HadaA lahaA signifies he sang to them. (Mgh.) The Arabs in driving their camels used commonly to sing verses of the kind termed rajaz. (TA in art. rjz.) [It is said that] HudaMCN↓ originated from the fact of a DesertArab's beating his young man, or boy, and biting his fingers; whereupon he went along saying daIo daIo, meaning yaA yadaIRa [“ O my two hands! ”]; and the camels went on at his cry; therefore his master bade him keep to it: (K in art. dI:) so says IAar. (TA in that art. [Other (similar) accounts of its origin are mentioned by MF in remarking on this passage of the K.]) HadaA signifies also He raised his voice with [the singing termed] AlHudaMC. (Har p. 576.) [And He breathed short (anhelavit), and sent forth a voice or sound. (Golius, from a gloss in the KL.)] ― -b2- You say also of the north wind, taHoduw AlsRaHaAba, i. e. (assumed tropical:) It drives along the clouds. (S.) ― -b3- And HadaAhu EalaI kacaA (assumed tropical:) He urged him, incited him, or put him in motion or action, to do such a thing. (Msb, TA.) ― -b4- And HadaAhu (assumed tropical:) It followed it; namely, the night the day; (K;) as also AHtdAhu↓: (AHn, K:) and so the [wild] he-ass his she-asses; and anything any other thing. (TA.) Hence the saying, laA OafoEaluhu maA HadaA AllRayolu AlnRahaAra (assumed tropical:) I will not do it as long as the night follows the day]. (TA.) ― -b5- See also 5.

5 tHdRAhu OHd Hd tHdAh tHdAp tHdI
5. tHdRAhu, in its primary sense, is form AlHudaMCu, and signifies He (a driver of camels) vied, competed, or contended for superiority, with him, or emulated him, (namely, another driver,) in driving camels, or urging them by singing to them; each of them desiring to elicit the ability of the other in doing so. (Z, TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] He vied, or competed, and contended for superiority, with him, (S, K, * mentioned in the K in art. HdI,) in an action or a work [of any kind]. (S.) You say, taHadRayotu AlnRaAsa AlquroMna I sought to elicit the ability of the people in order that it might be known which of us was most skilled in reading or reciting [the Kur-án]: it means like as does the saying of a person contending with others for the superior glory of his people, “ Bring ye a people like my people, or like one of them. ” (Msb.) It is said of Mohammad, in a trad., taHadRaI AlEaraba biAlquroMni [He vied, or contended, with the Arabs by means of the Kur-án]. (TA.) And one says, taHadRaI SaAHibahu AlqiraMCapa, and AlSRiraAEa, [He vied, or contended, with his companion in reading, or reciting, and in wrestling,] in order that it might be seen which of them was the superior reader or reciter, and the superior wrestler. (TA.) ― -b3- Also He aimed at it; made it his object; sought, endeavoured after, pursued, or endeavoured to reach or attain or obtain, it; intended or purposed it; (AA, and K * and TA in art. HdI;) as also HadaAhu↓, (AA, TA,) and AHdAhu↓. (Sgh, and K ib.) Hence the saying of Mujáhid, kunotu OataHadRaI AlquroMna faOaqoraOu [I used to aim at reading, or reciting, the Kur-án, and so to read, or recite]. (AA, TA.)
