qarabN HacoHaAcN (assumed tropical:) A quick [night-journey to water]; (S, L, K;) like HavoHaAvN: (S, A, L:) and farextending, or distant; as also HucaAHicN↓. (L.) And ximosN HacoHaAcN (L) and OaHacRu↓ (K) [A journey of five days whereof the second and third and fourth are without water] in which is no languor, or flagging; (L;) and quick. (K.)

HucaAHicN c
HucaAHicN: see what next precedes.

OaHacRu c
OaHacRu Deprived of an arm, or a hand, &c., by amputation: fem. HacRaMCu: [pl. HucRN:] thus OaHacRu Alyadi means having the arm, or hand, amputated: and [hence] (assumed tropical:) not having the means of acquiring eminence, or nobility. (L.) [Hence, also,] OaSuwlu biyadK HacRaMCa, in a trad. of 'Alee, means (assumed tropical:) Shall I assault the enemy with a short arm, that will not attain to that which I desire? or, accord. to one reading, it is jacRaMCa, meaning amputated: alluding to his companions' falling short of their duty, and keeping back from the war. (L in arts. Hc and jc.) [Another meaning of OaHacRu Alyadi will be found below.] ― -b2- A light-tailed camel: (S, L:) a horse light, or scanty, in the hair of the tail: (A, L:) or having it (the tail, Msb) cut off: (A, Msb:) a short-tailed ass. (L.) qaTaApN HacRaMCu A bird of the kind called qaTFA having a light, or scanty, tail; having a tail of which the feathers have become light, or scanty; (S, L;) having few feathers in the tail: (A:) or short-tailed: (L:) or (assumed tropical:) light and quick in flight. (A, * L.) And liHoyapN HacRaMCu A light, or scanty, beard. (L.) ― -b3- Lean, lank, or light of flesh; or slender; or lank in the belly. (K.) ― -b4- Smooth; (Kh, Msb;) a thing to which nothing clings, or attaches. (Msb, * TA.) walRati AldRunoyaA HacRaMCa, in a xuTobap of 'Otbeh Ibn-Ghazwán, means (tropical:) The world hath retired, passing away quickly, (A, * L, K *) nothing clinging to it [so as to retard it]: (L, K:) or the people thereof not clinging to aught of it [so as to retard it]: (A:) or quickly; its latter part being cut off. (Az, L.) ― -b5- A sword quick in cutting. (A.) ― -b6- (tropical:) Light-handed; (S, A, L, K;) quick-handed; (L;) i. e. thievish; or quick in
getting, or attaining: (A:) [and so OaHacRu Alyadi, as is implied in the S and L.] El-Farezdak uses the expression OaHacRa yadi AlqamiySi, (S, L,) meaning thereby OaHacRa Alyadi. (L.) naAqapN HacRaMCu (assumed tropical:) A she-camel quick in pace. (A.) ― -b7- qalobN OaHacRu (assumed tropical:) A sharp, quick, active mind. (L.) ― -b8- sayorN OaHacRu (tropical:) A very quick, unpleasant journey or pace. (A.) See also HacoHaAcN. ― -b9- OamorN OaHacRu (tropical:) An affair, or event, quick in passing: (L:) or decisive and quick: (TA:) or severe and abominable; (A, L, K;) without a parallel: (A:) or as though it eluded every one, so that he could not attain to it, and was not sufficient for it: (A:) pl. HucRN. (L, K.) ― -b10- yamiynN HacRaMCu (tropical:) An oath which a man takes quickly: (S, K:) or an abominable, severe oath, whereby one decides a right, or due: (A, L:) some say jacRaMCu. (S.) It is said in a prov., tazabRadahaA HacRaMCa (tropical:) He swallowed it [i. e. took it, namely, an oath, hastily,] like as one swallows butter. (TA.) ― -b11- EaziymapN HacRaMCu (tropical:) An energetic and effective resolution, from which one does not turn to anything. (A.) ― -b12- HaAjapN HacRaMCu (tropical:) A light want, quickly accomplished. (A, L.) ― -b13- raHimN HacRaMCu (tropical:) A bond of relationship [cut, or severed, or] not made close by affection; expl. by UicaA lamo tuwSalo: (Fr, S, K:) as also jacRaMC [q. v.]. (Fr, S.) ― -b14- OaHacRu OabacRu: see bacRN.

1 Hacira c
1. Hacira, aor.
Hacara
, inf. n. HacarN; and AHtcr↓; (Msb, K;) He was cautious, wary, or vigilant; was on his guard; took care; (K, TA;) was in a state of preparation; (Msb;) was in fear; feared. (TA.) [You say, Hacira mino OamorK and AHtcr↓ minohu He was cautious, &c., of a thing, or an event. And Hacira Ealayohi mino kacaA and AHtcr↓ He was cautious, &c., for him, of such a thing. And both verbs are also trans.: for you say,] Hacirahu, (S, A, Msb,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (S;) and AHtcrhu↓, (TA,) and HAcrhu↓; (A;) He was cautious of it; guarded, or was on his guard, against it; (S, A;) prepared, prepared himself, or was in a state of preparation, against it; (TA;) feared it. (Msb, TA.) [And Hacira Oano yafoEalahu and AHtcr↓ He was cautious of doing it; or he feared doing it.] And Hucira AlXRaIoCu faHacirahu The thing was an object of fear, and so he feared it. (Msb.) And Hucira Almawoti [Death was an object of fear]: and Almawota HAcr↓ [He feared death]. (A.)

2 taHociyrN c
2. taHociyrN [The cautioning another; putting him on his guard; making him to be cautious or wary or vigilant, to be on his guard, to take care, or to be in a state of preparation;] the making to fear, or be in fear. (S, TA.) [You say, HcRrhu mino OamorK He cautioned him against a thing. And the verb is also doubly trans.: you say,] HcRrhu AlOamora [He cautioned him against, or made him to fear, the thing, or event]. (TA.) And OaHacRirukahu [I caution thee against him, or it]. (K.) And it is said in the Kur [iii. 27 and 28], yuHacRirukumu QllRehu nafosahu God maketh you to fear Himself. (TA.)

3 HaAcaraA c
3. HaAcaraA, (TK,) inf. n. muHaAcarapN (S, K) and HicaArN, (S,) They two were cautious, or in fear, each of the other; were on their guard, or in a state of preparation, each against the other. (TK.) HicaArN is syn. with muHaAcarapN, (S,) and muHaAcarapN is between two. (K.) ― -b2- See also 1, in two places.

8 UiHotacara
8: see 1, in five places.

11 AHdArR AHdAr
11. AHdArR He was angry, (K,) and prepared himself to do mischief, (TA,) and drew himself together (taqabRaDa): so in some copies of the K and in other lexicons: or became enraged (tagayRaZa): so in other copies of the K. (TA.)

HicorN c
HicorN: see what next follows, in two places.

HacarN c
HacarN and HicorN↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) the former an inf. n., (S, Msb,) and the latter a simple subst., (Msb,) Caution, wariness, vigilance, guard, or care; (S, A, K;) as also maHocuwrapN↓; (K;) or a state of preparation; (Msb;) or fear; (Mgh, * TA;) and so maHocuwrapN↓: (S, Msb, K:) [pl. OaHocaArN.] You say, Oaxaca Hicorahu↓ He took care; was cautious, or vigilant. (Bd in iv. 73 and 103.) And huwa Qbonu OaHocaArK (tropical:) He is a son [i. e. a person] of resolution, or determination, and caution, or wariness. (S, K.) And Hacaraka zayodFA: see HacaAri. ― -b2- Oabuw HacarK The male chameleon: (K:) because of its frequent changes. (TA.)

HacurN c
HacurN, and its pl.: see what next follows.

HacirN c
HacirN (S, A, Msb, K) and HacurN↓ (S, A, K) Cautious; wary; vigilant; on his guard; careful; (S;) or in a state of preparation; (Msb;) as also HaAcirN↓; (S, A, Msb;) and fearful: (S:) or very cautious or wary or vigilant or careful; as also HaAcuwrapN↓ (K) and HicoriyaAnN↓: (A, K:) or this last signifies very fearful and cautious &c.: (S:) pl. of the first Haciruwna and HacaAraI. (S, K.) Sb cites, as an ex. of HacirN used transitively,
HacirN OumuwrFA laA tuxaAfu wa MminN
maA layosa munojiyhi mina AlOaqodaAri
[Cautious, or very cautious, of things not to be feared, and trusting in that which will not save him from the decrees of destiny]: but this is extr.; for an epithet of the measure faEilN is not [regularly] trans., so as to govern an objective complement. (S, TA.) In the Kur xxvi. 56, some read HaAciruwna↓; and some, Haciruwna and Hacuruwna↓: HAcrwn signifying in a state of preparation; (Zj, S;) or fully equipped with arms: (Sh:) and Hcrwn, in a state of fear; (S;) or in a state of preparation; (TA;) or in a state of preparation with the accoutrements of war; (Ibn-Mes'ood;) or cautious, or vigilant. (Zj.)

HicoriyapN c
HicoriyapN A rugged piece of ground: (S, K:) or the top of a mountain, when it is hard and rugged, but level: (Aboo-Kheyreh:) and rough ground: (TA:) and a rugged [hill such as is termed] Oakamap; as also HicoriyaMCu↓: (K:) pl. HacaAraI and HacaArK. (S.) ＝ -A2- Also The Eiforiyap [or feathers of the back of the neck] of a cock: (S, K:) pl. as above. (K)

HicoriyaMCu c
HicoriyaMCu: see what next precedes.

HicoriyaAnN c
HicoriyaAnN: see HacirN.

AlHucurRaI c
AlHucurRaI, [like AlbucurRaI,] What is false, vain, or ineffectual; syn. AlbaATilu. (K.)

HacaAri c
HacaAri [an imperative verbal noun] meaning Beware; be cautious, wary, or on thy guard; or take care. (S, A, K.) The poet (Abu-n-Nejm, TA) says,
HacaAri mino OaromaAHinaA HacaAri
Beware of our spears: beware. (S, A.) And you say, sumiEato HacaAri fiI Easokarihimo [The cry “ Beware ” was heard in their army]. (TA.) When the word is repeated, the second is sometimes with tenween: (K:) but this is only in poetry, when required by the metre, as in the following verse, cited by Lh:
HacaAri HacaArK mino fawaArisi daArimK
OabaA xaAlidK mino qaboli Oano tatanadRamaA
[Beware, beware of the horsemen of Dárim, O Aboo-Khálid, before that thou repent]. (TA.) You say also, HacaArika, [with the k of allocution,] meaning Beware thou. (Lh, TA.) And when you caution a person [against another], Hacaraka↓ zayodFA [Beware thou of Zeyd]; (K, * TA;) and HacaArayoka zayodFA, (K,) which latter means Beware thou, and beware thou again, of Zeyd: both then [also] being verbal nouns. (TA.)

HaciyrN c
HaciyrN [A cautioner]. You say, OanaA Haciyruka minohu i. e. muHacRiruka [I am thy cautioner against him, or it]; (TA;) or OuHacRirukahu [I caution thee against him, or it]: (K:) known to As as heard only from Lth. (TA.) [See also what next follows.]

HucaAriyaAtN c
HucaAriyaAtN Persons who make others to fear: (K:) or rather, as others than F explain it, munociruwna [cautioners, or warners, &c.]. (TA.)

HaAcirN c
HaAcirN and HaAciruwna: see HacirN.

HaAcuwrapN c
HaAcuwrapN: see HacirN.

OaHocaru c
OaHocaru [More, and most, cautious, wary, vigilant, careful, or fearful]. You say, OaHocaru mina AlguraAbi More fearful [or cautious, &c.] than the raven: a prov. (Mgh.)

maHocuwrN c
maHocuwrN A thing that is feared. (Msb.) One says, waqaAka QllRehu kulRa maHocuwrK [May God preserve thee from everything that is feared]. (A.)

maHocuwrapN c
maHocuwrapN A calamity that is feared, or regarded with caution: (K:) or a troop of horse making a hostile attack, or incursion, upon a people: or i. q. SayoHapN [app. as meaning a hostile attack, or incursion, when it comes upon a tribe suddenly, or unexpectedly; or it may here mean a punishment, or chastisement; or a crying-out, which is the primary signification]: (A:) and war. (K.) ― -b2- See also HacarN, in two places.

1 Hacafahu c
1. Hacafahu, (S, * Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
Hacifa
, (Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. HacofN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) He cut
it off: (Mgh, Msb:) or he cut it [so as to lessen it] at its extremity; (TA;) he cut off somewhat from the extremity of it; he curtailed it; as, for instance, the tail of a beast: (Lth, TA:) and he made it to fall; dropped it; rejected it. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) One says, Hacafotu mino XaEariI, (S,) or mn XaEarihi, (Msb, K, *) and mn canabi AldRaAbRapi, (S, Msb,) [XayoYFA being understood,] I took, or cut off, [somewhat] from my hair, [or his hair,] and from the tail of the beast; (S, K; *) I clipped it. (Msb.) And Hacafa AlXRaEara [He clipped the hair]: said of a cupper. (TA.) And AHtcf↓ AlvRawoba He cut off a piece from the garment, or cloth. (TA.) And Hacafotu raOosahu biAlsRayofi I cut off a portion of his head with the sword: (IF, Msb:) I struck his head with the sword and cut off a portion of it. (S.) ― -b2- Also, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He elided it, struck it off or out, or rejected it; namely, a letter, [and a syllable,] from a word: (MA, PS:) he omitted it. (MA.) [(assumed tropical:) He suppressed it; namely, a word of a proposition or sentence.] And Hacafa AlsRalaAma, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He made the salutation to be light [of utterance], and concise; (K, TA;) i. e., the salutation in prayer. (TA.) And Hacafa fiI qawolihi, (Msb,) and fI AlOacaAni, and AlqiraMCapi, aor. and inf. n. as above, (Mgh,) (assumed tropical:) He was concise, (Mgh, Msb,) and quick, in his saying, (Msb,) and in the call to prayer, and the recitation, or reading. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Hacafahu biAlEaSaA He struck him, or beat him, with the staff, or stick: (TA:) and he cast, or threw, at him the staff, or stick. (S, K, TA.) It is said in a prov. of the Arabs, mentioned by Sb, UiyRaAkumo wa Oano yaHocifa OaHadukumu AlOaronaba, i. e. [Beware ye] lest any one of you cast at, or shoot, the hare: because this animal is of evil omen. (TA. [But the reading there given is AyRAI: an evident mistranscription.]) Or Hacafahu, inf. n. as above, signifies He struck, or he cast at, or shot, him, or it, from one side. (Lth, TA.) ― -b4- [Hence,] Hacafa fulaAnFA bijaAYizapK (tropical:) He gave such a one a gift. (Z, K.) ― -b5- And Hacafa bihaA (assumed tropical:) He broke wind. (Ibn- 'Abbád, TA.) ― -b6- Hacafa fiI maXoyatihi He moved about his side and his hinder parts (in the CK he moved about his hinder parts and his shoulderjoint) in his gait: and (in the CK “ or ”) he went with short steps. (En-Nadr, K, TA.)

2 HcRfhu c
2. HcRfhu, [inf. n. taHociyfN,] He clipped it much: he took, or cut off, from its lateral parts, whatever it was, so as to make it even: (Msb:) he (a workman, or an artificer,) made it (a thing) becomingly even; as though he cut off from it whatever required to be cut off, so that it became free from everything unseemly, and was nicely, neatly, or properly, trimmed. (A, TA.) taHociyfu AlXRaEari [or AlrRaOosi] signifies The cutting of the hair so as to form a TurRap [q. v.], by taking from its sides so as to make it even [with the cut portion over the forehead]; (T, Mgh;) as is done by, or to, a girl: (Mgh:) or tHcyf AlrOs is a custom of women, consisting in the removing of the hair from [the sides of] the head as far as a line upon the side of the face made by putting one end of a string, or thread, upon the top of the ear, and the other end upon the angle of the jabiyn [or part above the temple]: (Msb:) accord. to En-Nadr, the tHcyf of the TurRap is the making a [TrRp such as is termed] sukayoniyRap, [i. e., after the fashion of Sukeyneh the daughter of El-Hoseyn, as is shown in the S and K &c. in art. skn,] like as do the Christians. (L, TA.) ― -b2- Also, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) He prepared it; or put it into a right, or good, state; and made it; or made it skilfully, or well. (S, K, TA.)

8 UiHotacafa
8: see 1.

HacafN c
HacafN Small, black sheep or goats, (S, Msb, K,) of El-Hijáz; (S, K;) or of Jurash, (ISh, K, TA,) of El-Yemen, small, with short, or short and fine, wool or hair, (ISh, TA,) without tails and without ears: (ISh, K, TA:) or the young ones of sheep or goats, in general: and metaphorically applied to (tropical:) gazelles: (TA:) n. un. with p. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- A certain kind of bird: (Sgh, K:) or small baTR [or ducks]: (K:) like [or likened to] the sheep, or goats, thus called: it is said by IDrd to be not a genuine Arabic word. (TA.) ― -b3- The small zaAg [or rook], which is eaten; (Lth, K;) the small black birds of the crow-kind, called ziygaAn [pl. of zAg], which are eaten: n. un. with p. (ISh, TA.) ＝ -A2- The leaves of seed-produce, (L,) or of grain. (O, K.)

HicofapN c
HicofapN A piece cut off from a garment. (L, TA.)

HucafapN c
HucafapN Short: applied to a woman: (Sgh, K:) and to a ewe. (Sgh.)

OucunN HacofaMCu c
OucunN HacofaMCu An ear that is as though it were clipped, or cut off. (K, TA.)

HucaAfapu c
HucaAfapu Clippings, or what one cuts off, of a hide, (Lh, S, Sgh, K,) &c.: (S, Sgh, K:) or what is cut off, of a thing, and thrown away. (TA.) — [Hence,] one says, maA fiI raHolihi HucaAfapN (tropical:) There is not in his travelling-utensils any food: (S, Sgh, K:) or any small quantity of food &c. (Z, TA.) And Oakala AlTRaEaAma famaA taraka minohu HucaAfapN (assumed tropical:) [He ate the food, and left not of it anything]. (ISk, S.) And AiHotamala raHolahu famaA taraka minohu HucaAfapF (assumed tropical:) [He took up and carried away his travelling-apparatus, and left not of it anything]. (ISk, S.) Accord. to the companions of A' Obeyd, the word is HcAfp, with q; but this is disallowed by Sh; and is wrong. (Az, TA.)

AlHacRaAfapu c
AlHacRaAfapu The anus, or the podex; syn. AlAisotu. (K.)

HaAcifN c
HaAcifN [act. part. n. of 1]. ― -b2- You say, humo maA bayona HaAcifK wa qaAcifK, i. e. [They are partly, or in part,] beating with the staff, or stick, and [partly, or in part,] pelting with stones; [or some beating &c., and the others pelting &c.] (TA in the present art.; and S and TA in art. qcf, but without maA before byn.)

rajulN muHacRafu AlkalaAmi c
rajulN muHacRafu AlkalaAmi (tropical:) A man chastened, good, free from every fault, in respect of speech: and you say also muHacRafapu AlklAmi; in which the p is added to give intensiveness to the signification: the latter occurring in a trad. (TA.)

HicofaArN c
HicofaArN (S, K) and HucofuwrN↓ (K) A side; or a lateral, or an adjacent, part; (S, K, TA;) of a thing: and the upper, or uppermost, part of a thing: (S:) pl. HacaAfiyru. (S, K.) You say, Oaxacahu biHucofuwrihi↓ and biHicofaArihi and biHacaAfiyrihi He took it altogether: (K, TA:) or with its lateral parts: or with its higher, or highest, parts. (TA.) And OaEoTaAhu AldRunoyaA biHacaAfiyrihaA He gave him the world, or worldly goods, altogether: (S, TA:) or with the lateral parts thereof: or with the higher, or highest, parts thereof. (TA.) And jaAWuwA biHacaAfiyrihimo They came altogether. (TA.)

HucofuwrN c
HucofuwrN: see above, in two places. ― -b2- Also A numerous congregation or assemblage. (K.) ― -b3- And An eminent, an elevated, or a noble, man: (K, TA:) pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b4- And the pl., (as some say, TA,) Persons prepared for war. (K.) Whence the phrase, AuXodudo HacaA fiyraka Prepare thyself (K, TA) for war, &c. (TA.)

1 Hacaqahu c
1. Hacaqahu, aor.
Haciqa
, inf. n. HacoqN (S, K, TA, in the CK Hicoq) and HacaAqapN, (K, TA, in the CK HicAqap,) He cut it; (S, K;) namely, a rope, (S,) or a thing: (K:) or he stretched it, or extended it, to cut it with a reaping-hook and the like, (K, TA,) so that there remained not of it anything. (TA.) ― -b2- Hacaqa AlrRibaATu yada AlXRaApi The bond made an impression upon the fore leg of the sheep, or goat, (IDrd, K,) by cutting. (IDrd.) ― -b3- Hacaqa faAhu, (IDrd, S, K,) inf. n. HacoqN, (S,) said of vinegar, (IDrd, S, K,) and of milk [when sour], and of the beverage called nabiyc, and the like, (TA,) (tropical:) It stung, bit, or burned, his mouth, by its strength and sharpness, (IDrd, S, K, TA,) and contracted it. (K.) ― -b4- And Hacaqa, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
Haciqa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. HucuwqN, said of vinegar, (S, Msb, K,) and of milk, (TA,) (tropical:) It was, or became, sour, (S, Msb, K, TA,) in the utmost degree, (Msb,) so that it burned the tongue. (Msb, TA.) ― -b5- Hacaqa AlquroMna, and (so in the S, but in the K “ or ”) AlEamala, aor.
Haciqa
; and Haciqa, aor.
Hacaqa
; (S, K;) or Hacaqa fiyhi, and Haciqa; (TA;) inf. n. (of both, S) HicoqN and (of the former, S) HacoqN and HicaAqN and HacaAqapN (S, K) and HacaAqN and HicaAqapN; or ↓this last is a simple subst.; (K;) (tropical:) He (a boy) was, or became, skilled in the Kur-án, and the work; (S) or learned the whole of it, and was, or became, skilled in it: (K, TA:) from AlHacoqu signifying “ the act of cutting. ” (Z, TA.) You say, hecaA yawomu HicaAqihi This is the day of his finishing [the learning or reciting] of the Kur-án. (S, K.) And Hacaqa fiI SanoEatihi, [and bihaA also,] aor.
Haciqa
; and Haciqa, aor.
Hacaqa
; (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, skilled in his art, or habitual work or occupation, and knew its abstrusities and niceties. (Msb.)

2 taHociyqN c
2. taHociyqN, [inf. n. of HcRqhu (assumed tropical:) He, or it, made, or rendered, him skilful,] from AlHicoqu, rests upon analogy, not upon the authority of hearsay. (Mgh.)

4 AHcqhu c
4. AHcqhu (assumed tropical:) It (the heat) rendered it sour, so that it burned the tongue; namely, vinegar. (TA.)

5 tHcRq c
5. tHcRq (assumed tropical:) He feigned, or made a show of, skilfulness to us. (TA.) And Hacolaqa↓, (S, K, mentioned in the latter in art. Hclq,) with an augmentative l, (S,) inf. n. HacolaqapN, (A, TA,) (tropical:) He feigned, or made a show of, skilfulness, and [in some copies of the K “ or ”] laid claim to more than he possessed; as also taHacolaqa↓: (S, K, TA:) or HacolaqapN↓ signifies (assumed tropical:) the employing oneself, or using art or artifice, with skilfulness, cleverness, or ingeniousness: and fiI tHclq↓ kalaAmihi (assumed tropical:) he feigned, or made a show of, skilfulness, cleverness, or ingeniousness, in his speech. (L.) You say, fiyhi HacolaqapN↓ and taHacoluqN↓ (tropical:) [In him is a quality of feigning, or making a show of, skilful ness, &c.]. (A, TA.)

7 AnHcq c
7. AnHcq It (a rope) was, or became, cut. (K, TA.) Hence the saying of the poet,
yakaAdu minohu niyaATu Alqalobi banoHaciqu
[The suspensory of the heart is near to becoming severed in consequence thereof]. (TA.)

Q. Q. 1 Hacolaqa c
Q. Q. 1. Hacolaqa, inf. n. HacolaqapN: see 5, in three places. ＝ -A2- Also, [perhaps originally,] It was, or became, sharpened. (TA.)

Q. Q. 2 taHacolaqa c
Q. Q. 2. taHacolaqa: see 5, in three places.

xicoqapN c
xicoqapN A piece, or portion cut off, of a rope: pl. HicaAqN and HucaAqN; as in the phrase, tarakotu AlHabola HicaAqFA and HucaAqFA [I left the rope in pieces]. (K.) [See also what next follows.]

HaciyqN c
HaciyqN (S, K) and maHocuwqN↓ (K) Cut: (S, K, * TA:) pl. OaHocaAqN. (Lh, TA.) One says HabolN OaHocaAqN A rope altogether worn out; as though it were cut: (Lh, K, * TA:) every part of it being termed Haciyq. (Lh, TA.)

maAEinodahu HucaAqapN c
maAEinodahu HucaAqapN (tropical:) He has not aught of food. (K, TA.) [See also HucaAfapN, with f.]

HicaAqapN c
HicaAqapN: see 1.

HucaAqiIRN c
HucaAqiIRN Sharpened: applied to a knife: (Ibn- 'Abbád, K:) and HicolaAqN↓ signifies the same, applied to a thing [of any kind]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also HaAciqN. ― -b3- (tropical:) A man chaste, or eloquent, of tongue; (S, K, * TA;) perspicuous in language. (S.) ＝ -A2- A young ass; syn. HajoXN. (K.)

HicoliqN c
HicoliqN (assumed tropical:) A loquacious man; who affects to be commended for, or glories in, that which he does not possess. (TA.)

HicolaAqN c
HicolaAqN: see HucaAqiIRN.

HaAciqN c
HaAciqN Cutting, or sharp: (S, K: *) applied to a knife [&c.]. (S.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Wine (XaraAb) that has attained to its full maturity [of strength, so that it stings, bites, or burns; the tongue; see 1]: (AHn, TA:) likewise applied to vinegar [in the same sense; or as meaning sour, or sour in the utmost degree, so that it burns the tongue; see again 1]; as also HucaAqiIRN↓. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) Skilled, or skilful, and thoroughly learned, [so as to know abstrusities and niceties, (see 1,)] in an art, or a habitual work or occupation, and in the Kur-án: pl. HucRaAqN. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN fiI SanoEatihi HaAciqN baAciqN (S, TA) (tropical:) Such a one is skilled, or skilful, &c., in his art, or habitual work or occupation; (TA;) using the latter word as an imitative sequent. (S, TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) Bad, evil, wicked, mischievous, or the like; syn. xabiyvN. (TA.)

maHocuwqN c
maHocuwqN: see HaciyqN.

mutaHacoliqN c
mutaHacoliqN Feigning, or making a show of, skilfulness, cleverness, or ingeniousness: or desiring to exceed his due bounds. (L.) [See 5.]

dictScrap.label: Hclq: For several words mentioned under this head in the K, see art. Hcq.

superEntry.entry:
1 Hacamahu c
1. Hacamahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
Hacima
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. HacomN, (S, Msb,) He cut it, or cut it off, (S, Msb, K,) in any manner: (TA:) or hastily, or quickly. (K.) ― -b2- And [He did it quickly: or] he was quick in it; [as also Hacama fiyhi;] i. e., in any action. (S, Msb.) You say, Hacama fiI maXoyihi, (Msb,) and qiraMCatihi, fI (S, K,) He was quick [in his walking, or going, and in his reading, or reciting]: (S, Msb, K:) and so in other things: (K:) by “ other things ” being here meant walking and the like; for HacomN, of which the verb is Hacama, signifies the being quick in walking, app. with a stretching out of the arms backwards: (TA:) and a light, an active, or an agile, walking. (S, TA.) [See also HacamaAnN, below.] Hence, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) 'Omar said, (S, TA,) to the muWacRn of Jerusalem, (TA,) UicaA OacRanota qatarasRalo waUicaA Oaqamota faQHocimo, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, TA,) i. e. [When thou chantest the OacaAn, be moderate; not quick: and when thou chantest the UiqaAmap,] cut short the lengthening of thine utterance; meaning, be quick in the AqAmp: (As, Mgh, TA:) another reading is said to have been given by Z, namely, [faQxocimo,] with x. (TA.)

HacamN c
HacamN The flight of a bird that has its wings clipt, (K, TA,) as the pigeon and the like. (TA.)

HacimN c
HacimN A sharp, or cutting, sword; as also HicoyamN↓, with kesr to the H, (K,) and with fet-h to the I; (TA;) or HaciymN↓. (So in two copies of the S.)

HucamN c
HucamN and HucamapN↓ Short in stature and in step; (K;) applied to a man: (TA:) and the latter is likewise fem.; (S, K, TA;) applied to a woman as meaning short in stature. (S, TA.)

HucumN c
HucumN Swift hares. (IAar, K. [See also HucamapN.]) ― -b2- And Skilful thieves. (IAar, K.)

HucamapN c
HucamapN; see HucamN. ― -b2- One says of the female hare, HucamapN lucamapN tasobiqu AljamoEa biAlOakamapi, i. e. Swift, persistent in running, she outstrips the company pursuing her upon the hill. (TA.)

HacamaAnN c
HacamaAnN Quickness in walking or going: (K:) accord. to Aboo-'Adnán, a pace of the kind termed camiylN, exceeding what is termed maXoIN. (TA.) ― -b2- And Slowness (K, TA) in walking or going: so says Aboo-'Adnán on the authority of Khálid Ibn-Jembeh. (TA.) Thus it bears two contrary meanings. (K.)

HucaAmN c
HucaAmN an epithet applied to a slave: so in the saying, AiXotaraI EabodFA HucaAma AlmaXoIi He bought a slave slow [in gait], lazy, (K, TA,) devoid of good: so says Khálid Ibn-Jembeh. (TA.)

HaciymN c
HaciymN: see HacimN.

HicoyamN c
HicoyamN Skilful (K, TA) in a thing. (TA.) ― -b2- See also HacimN.

1 HacaA AlnRaEola c
1. HacaA AlnRaEola, [aor. yaHocuw,] inf. n. HacowN and HicaMCN, He measured the sandal, or sole, or made it according to a measure; (K;) and cut it (T, K) according to a pattern: (T, TA:) or he made the sandal, or sole, liI for me. (Mgh.) And HacaA AlnRaEola biAlmivaAli He cut the sandal, or sole, by the pattern. (Mgh.) And HacaA AlnRaEola biAlnRaEoli, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. HacowN, (S,) He measured the sandal, or sole, by the sandal, or sole; or made it according to the measure thereof; (S, Msb, K;) and cut it according to the pattern and measure thereof: (Msb:) and in like manner, HacaA AlqucRapa biAlqucRapi He measured the feather for an arrow by the feather for an arrow; or made it according to the measure thereof. (K.) Hence the prov., (TA,) Hacowa AlqucRapi [meaning (assumed tropical:) With like for like]. (S, TA.) And the saying, jazayotuhu HadowaAlnRaEoli biAlnRaEoli, meaning (assumed tropical:) I requited him [with like for like]. (Har p. 43. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 345.]) One says also, huwa jayRadu AlHicaMCi He is good in respect of proportion, or conformation. (TA.) And [in like manner] a beast is said to be Hasanu AlHicaMCi Goodly, or beautiful, in respect of proportion, or conformation. (TA in art. HcI.) ― -b2- [And hence,] HacaAHacowa zayodK (assumed tropical:) [He did as Zeyd did;] he did the deed of Zeyd. (K.) And mivaAlahu AHtcI↓, (S, K,) or EalaI mivaAlihi, (T, TA,) (tropical:) He followed, or imitated, his example (T, S, K, TA) in his affair, or case: (TA:) or AHtcI bihi he followed, or imitated, his example in his affairs: (Msb:) syn. AqtdI. (T, S, Msb, K.) ― -b3- See also 3, in three places. ― -b4- HacaAhu naEolFA He put on him (namely a man [i. e. on his foot]) a sandal; as also AHcAhu↓: (K:) the former is authorized by As, but the latter is disallowed by him: Az explains the former by Hmlh ElI nEl [as though meaning he gave him a sandal upon which to walk; like as Hamalahu for Hamalahu EalaI daAbRapK means “ he gave him a beast upon which to ride ”]: and accord. to J, (TA,) naEolFA OaHocayotuhu↓ signifies I gave him a sandal. (S, TA.) ― -b5- HacaA zayodFA, (K,) inf. n. HacowN, (TA,) He gave to Zeyd. (K, TA. [See also 4 in art. HcI.]) ― -b6- HacaAminohu HicowapF He cut off from it a piece of flesh-meat. (TA.) ― -b7- HacaA Aljiloda, aor. yaHocuw, i. q. qawRarahu [He cut a piece out of the skin, generally meaning in a round form]. (TA.) ― -b8- HacaA lsaAnahu, (K,) aor.
as above, inf. n. HacuwN, (TA,) (tropical:) It (wine, or beverage,) bit his tongue; (AHn, K, TA;) a dial. var. of HacaI, aor. yaHocI, which is the word well known. (AHn, TA.) ＝ -A2- HacaA AltRuraAba fiI wujuwhihimo i. q. HavaAhu [i. e. He poured with his hand, threw, or cast, the dust in their faces]. (IAth, K.)

3 HaAcaAhu c
3. HaAcaAhu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. muHaAcaApN (Msb, TA) and HacaMCN, (Msb,) He, (Mgh, Msb,) and it, (Mgh,) was, or became, over against, or opposite to, him, or it; (S, Mgh, TA;) faced, or fronted, him, or it; (TA;) syn. MzaAhu, (Msb, * K,) and qaAbalahu; (TA;) as also HacaAhu↓, aor. yaHocuw, (Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. HacowN: (Msb:) [and] the latter, (S,) or each, (Har p. 43,) signifies he sat over against, or opposite to, him, or it. (S, and Har ibid.) raOosahaAmina AlXRaEari walaA yasotarosilu maA yaHocuw↓ means mA yuHaAciyhi [i. e. What is against, or opposite to, her head, of the hair, and does not hang down below it]. (Mgh. [See another ex. in an explanation of MxirapN.]) One also says, Oatayotu OaroDFA baqoluhaA EalaI OafowaAhi ganamihaA qado HacaA↓ I came to a land the herbs of which were opposite to the mouths of its sheep, or goats, not rising beyond them. (Sh, TA.) And biHicaMCi hecihi AlXRajarapi taHacRa↓ Be thou over against, or opposite to, this tree. (TA.) ― -b2- HaAcatohaA, said of a girl, She matched her, namely, another girl; she was, or became, her match, fellow, or equal; syn. taArabatohaA. (A and TA in art. trb.) ― -b3- [Hence muHaAcaApN signifying A conformity, a mutual resemblance, or a correspondence, with regard to sound, of two words occurring near together; like AizodiwaAjN &c.: see art. zwj.]

4 OaHocawa
4: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- AHcAhu also signifies He gave him a thing. (TA.) [See Hicowap: and see 4 in art. HcI.]

5 taHacRawa
5: see 3.

6 taHaAcaA c
6. taHaAcaA They were, or became, over against, or opposite to, each other; they faced, or fronted, each other. ― -b2- And They matched each other; each of them was, or became, the match, fellow, or equal, of the other.] ― -b3- AltRaHaAciI in selling and buying: see AltRaraAwuDu. [This, perhaps, may belong to art. HcI.]

8 AHtcI c
8. AHtcI He wore, or put on, a sandal, or sandals. (S, TA.) Hence the saying, xayoru mani QHotacaI AlnRiEaAla [The best of those who have worn sandals]. (TA.) A rájiz says,
kulRa AlHicaMCi yaHotaciI AlHaAfiI AlwaqiEo
[The barefooted whose sole is hurt by the rugged ground and stones will put on any sandal: a prov.]. (S. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 317.]) ― -b2- See also 1.

10 AstHcAhu c
10. AstHcAhu He asked him to give him a sandal [or a pair of sandals]. (S, * TA.)

HicapN c
HicapN: see HicaMCN, in three places. ― -b2- You say also, jaMCa AlrRajulaAni Hicatayoni The two men came together, side by side. (TA.) [See also HicoyapN, in art. HcI.]

HacowN c
HacowN [originally an inf. n. of 1, q. v.]: see HicaMCN, in three places.

Hucowapa c
Hucowapa: see HicaMC: ＝ -A2- and see also HucaAwapN.

HicowapN c
HicowapN A gift; (K, and Ham p. 596;) as also HucayRaA↓; (TA;) or HucoyaA: (Mgh, and Ham ubi suprà:) or a portion that is given of spoil. (S.) [See also HucoyaA, in art. HcI.] ― -b2- And A piece, (K,) or small piece, (TA,) of flesh-meat: (K, TA:) or a piece of flesh cut lengthwise; or so HicoyapN, accord. to some. (Mgh.) [See also HicoyapN, in art. HcI.] ＝ -A2- See also HicaMCN, in three places.

HicaMCN c
HicaMCN A sandal, or sole; syn. naEolN; (S, Msb, TA;) vulgarly called Hcwp: (TA [there written without any syll. signs]:) pl. OaHociyapN. (Msb.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The sole of a camel's foot and of the hoof of a horse (S, Msb, TA) or similar beast; (Msb;) as being likened to a naEol. (TA.) Hence the saying in a trad., (S, * Msb, * TA,) respecting a stray she-camel, (Msb, TA,) maEahaA HicaAWuhaA wasiqaAWuhaA (S, Msb, TA) (assumed tropical:) With her are her foot, with which she may defend herself from the smaller beasts of prey, and [her stomach, which, by her replenishing it, affords her means of long] endurance of the want of water: (Msb:) [or] it means that she has ability to traverse the land and to go to water. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A wife; because she is mawoTuwoCap, like the naEol. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, [originally an inf. n.,] i. q. UizaMCN [The front, as meaning the part, place, or location, that is over against, opposite, facing, fronting, or in front]. (S, K.) One says, jalasa biHicaAYihi [He sat in the place over against, opposite to, facing, or fronting, him; or simply he sat over against, &c.]. (S.) And huwa HicaMCaka and Hicowataka↓ and Hicataka↓ [in the CK, erroneously, Hicowatuka and Hicoyuka,] and muHaAcaAka↓ [He, or it, is over against, opposite to, facing, or fronting, thee]; (K;) and hw HucayRaAka↓; i. e. biUizaAYika. (K in art. HcI.) And daAriI HicaMCa (S) and Hicowapa↓ dArh (S, K) and dArh Hucowapa↓ (S) and dArh Hicapa↓ (S, K) and dArh Hacowa↓ and dArh Hicowapu↓ and dArh Hicapu↓ and dArh Hacowu↓ (K) i. e. UizaMCahaA [My house is over against, &c., his house]; (K;) and [so] biHicaMCi dArh. (Msb.) And rafaEa yadayohi Hacowa↓ Oucunayohi and HicaMCa Acnyh [He raised his hands over against, or opposite to, not higher than, his ears]: (Mgh, * Msb:) both are correct expressions. (Mgh.) [Hence, EalaI HicaMCK waAHidK Corresponding to, or matching, one another; uniformly disposed.] ＝ -A3- See also art. HcI.

HucaAwapN c
HucaAwapN and HicaAwapN and HucowapN↓ What falls, and is thrown away, of skins, when they are pared and cut: whence the saying in a trad. respecting the bridal furniture of Fátimeh, that one of her two beds was stuffed with Hcwp of the makers of sandals. (TA.)

HucayRaA c
HucayRaA [perhaps belonging to this art., like as HudayRaA and HujayRaA belong to arts. Hdw and Hjw]: see HicowapN, and art. HcI: ＝ -A2- and see also HicaMCN.

HacRaMCN c
HacRaMCN A maker of sandals: whence the prov.,
mano yaku HacRaMCF tajudo naEolaAhu
[He who is a maker of sandals, his pair of sandals is good]. (TA. [Freytag (Arab. Prov. ii. 665) gives it thus: mano yakuno Oabuwhu HacRaMCF tajudo naEolaAhu He whose father is a maker of sandals, his pair of sandals is good.])

HaAcK c
HaAcK A man wearing a sandal [or a pair of sandals]. (TA.)

huwa muHaAcaAka c
huwa muHaAcaAka: see HicaMCN.

1 Hacati AlXRaforapu AlnaEola c
1. Hacati AlXRaforapu AlnaEola, [aor. and inf. n. as below,] The shoemaker's knife cut the sandal, or sole. (S.) And HacaI yadahu He cut, or cut off, his arm, or hand, (T, S, K,) with a knife. (S.) And HacaI Oucunahu He cut off a piece of his ear. (TA.) ― -b2- HacaI Aljiloda, aor. yaHociI, He, or it, wounded the skin. (TA.) And HacaI AlUihaAba, (K,) inf. n. HacoIN, (TA,) He rent, or tore, much, or he made many holes in, the skin, or hide. (K, TA.) ― -b3- HacaI lisaAnahu, (S, Mgh, K,) and faAhu (S) or famahu, (TA,) aor. as above, (S, Mgh, Msb,) and so the inf. n., (S, TA,) (tropical:) It, namely, vinegar, and wine, or beverage, (S, Mgh,) and [sour] milk, (Mgh, K,) &c., (K,) bit his tongue, (S, Mgh, K,) and his mouth; (S, TA;) had a burning effect upon it, like cutting. (Mgh.) ― -b4- HacaI fulaAnFA bilisaAnihi (tropical:) He spoke evil of such a one, saying of him what would grieve him if he heard it; reviled, vilified, or vituperated, him; (K, TA;) [as though] he cut him with his tongue. (TA.) A man who does so is termed miHocaMCN↓. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also what next follows.

4 AHcAhu c
4. AHcAhu; (S, Mgh, K;) as also HacaAhu↓, first pers. Hacayotu; (Mgh;) He gave him a thing, or somewhat: (Mgh:) he gave him a portion, or share, of spoil. (S, Mgh, K.) [See also 4 in art. Hcw.] ― -b2- [Hence,] OaHocayotuhu TaEonapF (tropical:) [I gave him a thrust, piercing thrust, or stab;] I thrust, pierced, or stabbed, him. (Lh, TA.)

6 tHAcI Alqawomu fiymaA bayonahumo c
6. tHAcI Alqawomu fiymaA bayonahumo (tropical:) The party, or campany of men, divided among themselves (K, TA) water equally; like tSAfnwA. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 6 in art. Hcw.

HicoIN c
HicoIN: see HicoyapN.

HucoyapN c
HucoyapN, with damm, The diamond with which stones are cut and bored. (TA.)

HicoyapN c
HicoyapN A piece cut lengthwise (As, S, K) of flesh-meat: (As, S:) or a small piece (K) thereof. (TA.) [See also HicowapN, in art. Hcw.] Hence the saying in a trad., UinRamaA faATimapu HicoyapN minRiI yaqobiDuniI maA yaqobiDuhaA (assumed tropical:) [Fátimeh is only a piece of me: what distresses, or grieves, her, distresses, or grieves, me]. (TA.) ― -b2- jMCaA Hicoyatayoni They two came side by side: (K, TA:) and so jaMCaA, mentioned in art. Hcw. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A gift; as also HicoIN↓ (TA) and HucoyaA↓, (Mgh, and Ham p. 596,) or HucayRaA↓, (TA in art. Hcw,) and HicowapN. (K in that art., and Ham ubi suprà.) [See also HucayRaA.]

HucoyaA c
HucoyaA: see what next precedes. ― -b2- Also A share,
or portion, of spoil; (S, K;) and so HucayRaA↓ and HucaAyp (K) and HaciyRapN↓ (S, K) and HicowapN. (S.)

HicaMCN c
HicaMCN The gathering of the crop of grapes: or the time thereof: syn. qiTaAfN. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also art. Hcw.

HucaAyapN c
HucaAyapN: see HucoyaA.

HaciyRapN c
HaciyRapN: see HucoyiA.

HucayRaA c
HucayRaA A gift, or present, for bringing good news. (K, TA.) See also HicoyapN. You say, Oaxocahu biyona AlHucayRaA waAlxulosapi He took it as something between a gift and a thing carried off by force. (ISd, K.) ― -b2- See also HucoyaA. ＝ -A2- huwa HucayRaAka: see HicaMCN, in art. Hcw.

miHocFI c
miHocFI A large, or broad, knife; or such as is used by a shoemaker or maker of sandals. (TA.)

miHocaMCN c
miHocaMCN: see 1.

HarRa Hr
HarRa, see. pers. Harirota, aor.
Harara
; (S, A, Msb, K;) and HarRa, sec. pers. Hararota, aor.
Harira
and
Harura
; inf. n. HarRN and HuruwrN (S, Msb, K) and HaraArapN, (S, K,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) and HirRapN; (TA;) and AHrR↓, (S, K,) a dial. var. heard by Ks, (S,) and mentioned by Zj and IKtt; (TA;) It (a day, S, A, Msb, K, and food, Msb) was, or became, hot; (A, Msb, K;) or very hot. (TA.) And HarRati AlnRaAru, sec. pers. Hariroti, aor.
Harara
, The fire burned up, and became fierce or hot. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 10. ― -b3- HarRa, sec. pers. Harirota, aor.
Harara
, inf. n. HarRapN, He (a man, S) thirsted; was, or became, thirsty. (S, K.) Lh mentions Harirota yaA rajulu, aor.
Harara
, inf. n. HirRapN [perhaps a mistake for HarRapN] and HaraArapN: [app. in the same sense:] ISd says, I think he means [from] AlHarRu, not AlHurRiyRapu. (TA.) And HararN [an inf. n. of the same verb] signifies The liver's becoming dry from thirst or grief. (TA.) ＝ -A2- HarRa, sec. pers. Harirota, aor.
Harara
, (S, A, * Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. HaraArN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He (a slave, S) became free: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) and tHrRr↓ in the same sense is agreeable with analogy. (Mgh.) ― -b2- And HarRa, sec. pers. and aor. as above, inf. n. HurRiyRapN, He (a man) was freeborn, or of free origin. (S.) ＝ -A3- HarRa, [sec. pers. Hararota,] aor.
Harura
, inf. n. HarRN, He heated water (A, * K) &c. (A.) ＝ -A4- HarRa, aor.
Harira
, He cooked [what is termed] Hariyrap: (K:) and HarRato she made Hryrp. (A.) Hence, in a trad., curRiI waOanaA OaHirRu laki Sprinkle thou the flour, and I will make of it Hryrp for thee. (TA.)

2 HrRr Hrr
2. HrRr, inf. n. taHoriyrN, He freed, liberated, or emancipated, a slave. (A, Mgh, Msb.) And HrRr raqabapF He freed a neck [i. e. a slave]. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also He set apart a child for the worship of God and the service of the mosque or oratory: (S, TA:) or he devoted him to the service of the church as long as he should live, so that he could not relinquish it while he retained his religion. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) He made a writing &c. accurate, or exact; (S, K;) he made a writing beautiful, or elegant, and free from defects, by forming its characters rightly, and rectifying its faults: (A:) he wrote a writing well, or elegantly, and accurately, or exactly; (TK;) he wrote well, or elegantly: (KL:) and he made an account, or a reckoning, accurate, without mistake, and without omission, and without erasure. (TA.) [And simply (tropical:) He wrote a letter &c.]

4 AHrR AHr OHAr OHr OHrI HAr Hr HrI
4. AHrR: see 1. ― -b2- Also His (a man's) camels became thirsty. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- Also He (God) made a man's liver to become dry by reason of thirst or grief. (TA.) And He made a man's bosom thirsty; as in the saying, used by the Arabs in cursing a man, maA lahu OaHarRa QllRehu Sadorahu [What aileth him? May God make his bosom thirsty]: or the meaning is haAmatahu [app. here used as signifying the bird called haAmap, in the form of which the soul was believed to issue from a slain man, and to call incessantly for drink until the slaughter of the slayer]. (TA.)

5 taHarRaRa
5: see 1.

10 AstHrR OstHr AstHr QstHr
10. AstHrR (S, K) and HarRa↓ (S, TA) (tropical:) It (slaughter) was, or became, vehement, (S, K,) and great in extent; (TA;) and the same is said of death. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AstHrRhA He asked, or desired, of her [that she should make what is termed] Hariyrap. (A.) [See 1, last signification.]

HirN Hcr

HurRN Free, ingenuous, or free-born; contr. of EabodN: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) fem. HurRapN: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) pl. masc. OaHoraArN (Msb, K) and HiraArN; (IJ, K;) not HaraArN, as some say; nor is HiraArN an inf. n. as well as a pl., as others say: (MF:) pl. fem. HaraAYiru, (Msb, K,) contr. to analogy, and, as Suh says, the only instance of the kind except XajarN maraAYiru as pl. of XajarapN murRapN; for the [regular] pl. of fuEolapN is foEalN; but HurRapN has this form of pl. because it is syn. with kariymapN and EaqiylapN [as will be seen in what follows]; and murRapN, because it means xabiyvapu AlTRaEomi. (Msb.) Omar said to the women who used to go forth to the mosque, laOarudRanRakonRa HaraAYira [lit. I will assuredly make you to become free women]; meaning I will assuredly make you to keep to the houses: for the curtain is lowered before free women; not before slavewomen. (TA.) [See also HurRiyRapN.] ― -b2- (tropical:) Generous, noble, or well-born; like as EabodN is used to signify “ ignoble, ” or “ base-born: ” (Mgh:) and so the fem. HurRapN; (S, Mgh, K;) applied to a woman; (TA;) and to a she-camel: (S:) and so the masc. applied to a horse. (K, TA.) [Hence,] baAtato bilayolapi HurRapK (tropical:) [She passed a virgin's night] is said of her whose husband has not been able to devirginate her (S, A, K) in the night when she has been first brought to him: (TA:) because the HurRap is modest and repugnant: (Har p. 418:) in the contr. case one says, bilayolapi XayobaMCa: (S, L:) and one says also bilayolapK HurRapK; and bilayolapK XayobaMCa. (TA.) [And hence,] layolapu HurRap and layolapN HurRapN signify also (assumed tropical:) The first night of the [lunar] month: (K:) its last night is called layolapu XayobaMCa and layolapN XayobaMCu. (TA.) You say also wajohN HurRN (tropical:) [app. meaning An ingenuous countenance]. (A.) ― -b3- (tropical:) Generous, or ingenuous, in conduct: as in the saying of Imra-el-Keys,
laEamoruka maA qalobiI UilaI Oaholihi biHoro
[By thy life, my heart is not generous in conduct to its, or his, companion]; meaning that it is averse therefrom, and inclines to another. (Az, TA.) [Hence,] saHaAbapN HurRapN (tropical:) A cloud bountiful with rain; (A;) or abounding with rain. (S, K.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A good deed or action. (K, TA.) You say, maAhecaA minoka biHurRK (tropical:) This is not good, or well, of thee. (S, A.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) Anything good, or excel-lent; as poetry, &c. (TA.) (Mgh.) ― -b7- (tropical:) The middle, (S, A, K,) and best part, (TA,) of sand, (S, K, TA,) and of a house. (S, A, TA.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) The best of anything; (K, TA;) as, for instance, of fruit. (TA.) ― -b9- Also sing. of OaHoraAr in the term OaHoraAru Albuquwli, (TA,) which means (tropical:) Herbs, or leguminous plants, that are eaten without being cooked; (S, A;) as also Albuquwli HurRiyRapu↓: (A:) or such as are slender and succulent; and cukuwru Albuquwli means “ such as are thick and rough: ” (AHeyth:) or the former are such as are slender and soft; and the latter, “ such as are hard and thick: ” (TA in art. daEato saAqa HurRK taroHapF wataranRumaA
[And nothing excited this desire but a pigeon (see HamaAmN) that called sAq HrR, sorrowing and warbling]: or, accord. to IJ, the right reading is

[that called sAq HrR among other pigeons, warbling]: but some say that AlsAq is the pigeon; and HrR, its young one: or sAq HrR is the cry of the qmArIR, and is an onomatopœia: accord. to Aboo- 'Adnán, it is sAq HarR↓, and means the warbling of the pigeon: and Sakhr El-Gheí makes it a compound, and indecl.; using the phrase, tunaAdiI saAqa HurRa [she calls sAq HrR]: on which IJ observes, As says, sAq HrR is thought to mean the young one of the bird; but it is her cry: and he (IJ) adds, the fact that the poet [Sakhr] does not make it decl. is an evidence of the correctness of the assertion of As; for, were it decl., he would have said saAqa HurRK if it consisted of two nouns whereof the former was prefixed to the other so as to govern it in the gen. case, or sAq HurRFA if it were a compound; as it is indeterminate: and its being made decl. by Homeyd does not show it to be not significant of a sound; for sometimes an expression significant of a sound consists of two nouns whereof the former is prefixed to the latter so as to govern it in the gen. case, like xaAzu baAzK. (M, MF, TA.)

[of which the verb (Haraba) seems not to have been used as meaning “ he waged, or contended in, war ”], (El-Mázinee, S,) or in order that it may not be confounded with the dim. of HarobapN: (Msb:) Seer makes its origin to be the epithet HarobN, which, however, is originally an inf. n.: (L:) sometimes it is masc.; (IAar, Mbr, S, Msb, K;) but this is extr.: (L:) the pl. is HuruwbN. You say rajulN HarobN, (K, TA,) [in the CK HaribN, but it is] like EadolN, (TA,) A man vehement in war, and courageous; as also miHorabN↓ and miHoraAbN↓: (K:) or miHorabN↓ signifies a man of wars; (S;) or a man of war, as also miHoraAbN↓; and a known, experienced warrior. (TA.) [Being originally an inf. n.,] HarobN as an epithet is used in the same form as masc. and fem. and sing. and pl.: (K:) so that one says AimoraOapN HarobN and qawomN HarobN, (TA,) as also qawomN miHorabapN↓. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also An enemy, (S, K,) whether, or not, actually at war. (K.) So in the saying, OanaA HarobN limano HaArabanaIi [I am an enemy to him who wars with me, or who is an enemy to me]. (S.) And fulaAnN Harobu fulaAnK Such a one is the enemy of such a one. (TA.) Some hold that HarobN is a pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of HaAribN or muHaAribN. (TA.)

HarabN Hrb
HarabN inf. n. of Hariba. (A, Mgh, Msb.) waAHarabaA is an ejaculation expressive of grief, lamentation, or regret, [meaning Alas, my spoliation! or my loss! or my grief!] (ISd, Mgh, TA,) used in an absolute manner, like waA OasafaA, (ISd, TA,) or yaA OasafaA, (Mgh,) from Harabahu “ he despoiled him of his wealth, or property: ” (K:) [or from Hariba, q. v.:] or it originated from the fact that Harb the son of Umeiyeh, when any one died, used to ask his family what they required to expend on the occasion, and used to supply them therewith; (TA;) and when he himself died, the people of Mekkeh and its neighbourhood bewailed him, saying, waA HarobaA, (Th, K, * TA,) or waA HarobaAho, (TA,) [Alas for Harb!] and then they changed the expression to waA HarabaA, (Th, K,) or waAHarabaAho, and it
became used in the case of bewailing any person who was dear, and in the cases of other calamities: but this account of the origin did not please ISd. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Perdition. destruction, or death. (Har p. 158.)

HaribN: see HariybN. ＝ -A2- Also (tropical:) Angry: (A:) or violently angry: (S, K:) applied to a man and to a lion. (S, A.) And i. q. kalibN [meaning Affected with canine madness]: pl. HarobaI, (K,) syn. with kalobaI, but unknown to Az in this sense except in one instance. (TA.)

HarobapN Hrb Hrbh Hrbp
HarobapN [A dart, or javelin;] a certain weapon (K) resembling a spear, (Msb,) but smaller, (TA,) having a wide head; (As, TA;) not reckoned among rimaAH: (IAar, TA:) dim. HurayobapN↓: (Msb:) pl. HiraAbN. (S, A, Msb, K.) You say, OaxacuwA AlHiraAba liloHiraAbi [They took the darts, or javelins, for contending in war, or battle]. (A.) ＝ -A2- A thrust, stick, or stab. (K.) ― -b2- Spoliation. (K.) ― -b3- Corruptness of religion. (K.) ＝ -A3- Harobapu a name of Friday; (K, TA;) accord. to the Námoos, because it is a time for warring with oneself: (TA:) pl. HarabaAtN and HarobaAtN. (K.)

HirobapN Hrb Hrbh Hrbp
HirobapN A mode, or manner, of war, battle, fight, or conflict. (K.)

HirobaACN HrbAC
HirobaACN [The male chameleon;] the male of what is called OumRu HubayonK; (S, Msb, K; [but see the latter appellation in art. Hbn;]) a well-known animal: (TA:) or a certain reptile, like the EaZaMCap, (K,) said to be larger than this latter, (Msb,) somewhat larger, (S,) that turns itself, (S, Msb,) or its head, (K,) towards the sun, (S, Msb, K,) turning with the sun as the sun turns, and assuming various colours (S, Msb) by reason of the heat of the sun: (S:) Az describes it as a reptile resembling in form what is called saAmRu OaboraSa, with four legs, slender head, [which is not correct as applied to the chameleon,] and striped back; that all the day looks towards the sun; and he adds that its flesh is impure, and the Arabs never eat it: (TA:) [accord. to Freytag, the word, thus applied, is said (but I know not on what authority) to be from xurobaA, meaning HAfZ AlXms (guardian of the sun):] the fem. is with p: (S:) and the pl. HaraAbiIRu. (S, Msb.) [The word HrbAC is used in passages cited in the TA as masc. and fem.; whence it seems that it may be written HirobaMCu as well as HirobaMCN.] The Arabs used the expression HirobaMCu tanoDubK or tanoDuba, like cYobu gaDFA: (S:) [the latter word in each of these cases being the name of a tree:] the former is proverbially applied to a prudent man; because the HrbAC does not quit the first branch but to leap upon the second. (TA.) The phrase AinotaSaba AlEuwdu fiI AlHirobaMCi is used, by inversion, for AntSb AlHrbACu fI AlEwdi [The male chameleon stood erect upon the branch]: for it stands erect upon stones, and upon the roots or trunks of trees, looking towards the sun, and declines as the sun declines. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) The back: or its flesh: (K:) or HirobaMCu Almatoni means the flesh along either side of the backbone: (TA:) or this, (TA,) or AlHrbACu, (K,) the ridge of the backbone: (K, TA:) or HaraAbiIRu Almatoni (S, L, TA) signifies the portions of flesh, (S,) or the flesh, (L, TA,) along either side of the backbone: (S, L, TA:) the sing. is HirobaMCN; likened to the HrbAC [or male chameleon] of the desert, and therefore tropical: Kr says that the sing. of HaraAbiIRu AlZRuhuwri is HirobaMCN accord. to rule; showing that it has no known sing. on the authority of hearsay. (L, TA.) ＝ -A2- The nails, (S,) or a nail, (K,) of a coat of mail: (S, K:) or the head of a nail in a ring of a coat of mail: (K:) pl. as above. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And Rugged ground: (K:) or rugged and hard ground; accord. to Th; but the word commonly known is HizobaMCN, with záy. (TA.) [This meaning has been supposed to be assigned in the K to muHorabiYapN; but the TA shows that such is not the case.]

(of the first, TA) HarobaI and HurabaMCu. (K.) And HariybapN and maHoruwbapN↓ A woman deprived of her child, or children. (TA.) And mHrwb↓ (assumed tropical:) Despoiled of his religion; rendered, or become, an unbeliever. (TA.)

HurayobapN Hrybh Hrybp
HurayobapN dim. of HarobapN, q. v.

HaAribN [act. part. n. of Haraba]. ― -b2- It occurs in a trad. as signifying One who strips people forcibly of their clothes. (TA.)

miHorabN mHrb
miHorabN and miHorabapN: see HarobN, in three places.

AlmuHarRabu and AlmutaHarRibu↓ The lion. (K, TA.)

miHoraAbN mHrAb
miHoraAbN: see HarobN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also The upper end of a sitting-room, (Msb, and so accord. to an explanation of the pl. maHaAriybu, in the S, on the authority of Fr,) or of a house, or tent, or chamber; (K;) the chief, or most honourable, sitting-place; (AO, L, Msb, K; *) whence, in a trad., kaAna yakorahu AlmaHaAriyba [he used to dislike the uppermost, or chief, sitting-places in rooms]: (L:) the place where kings and chiefs and great men sit: (Msb:) a high place: (As, Hr, TA:) a [chamber of the kind called] gurofap: (S, Msb, K:) the highest chamber in a house: a chamber to which one ascends by stairs: (Zj, TA:) a king's closet, or private chamber, into which he retires alone, out of the way of the people: (K:) a [pavilion, or building of the kind called] qaSor: (As, TA:) the station of the Imám in a mosque: (K:) the miHoraAb [or niche which shows the direction of the kibleh] of a mosque; from the same word as signifying the “ upper end of a sittingroom; ” (Fr, S, Msb;) or, as some say, because the person praying wars with the devil and with himself by causing the attention of his heart: (Msb:) the highest place in a mosque: (Zj, TA:) the kibleh: (L, TA:) a mosque, or place of worship; so in the Kur xix. 12: (S, L:) a place of assembly. (As, TA.) maHaAriybu baniI UisoraAYiyla means The places of worship of the Children of Israel, (T, K,) in which they used to assemble for prayer, (T, TA,) or in which they used to sit; (K;) as though they sat therein to consult respecting war. (S, Msb, K) and
Hariba
, (K,) inf. n. HarovN, (S, A, Msb, K,) He gained, acquired, or earned, (S, A, K,) wealth; (S;) as also AHtrv↓: (Az, TA:) he collected wealth. And it is said in a trad., AuHoruvo lidunoyaAka kaOanRaka taEiyXu OabadFA (S, TA) Labour for thy good in the present world as though thou wert to live for ever: and, in continuation, waQEomalo liMxiratika kaOanRaka tamuwtu gadFA (tropical:) and work for thy good in the world to come as though thou wert to die to-morrow. (TA.) ― -b3- Also Harava, (T, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.

and
Haraba
, (K,) inf. n. HarovN (T, Mgh, Msb, K) and HiraAvapN; (TA;) and AHtrv↓; (T, S;) He sowed; (T, S, K;) he cast seed upon the ground: (T, TA:) [accord. to Bd (xlii. 19), this is the primary signification: see HarovN, below:] and the former verb, he tilled, or cultivated, land, either by sowing or by planting: (TA:) or he ploughed up land for sowing: (Mgh, Msb:) or he ploughed land; because the doing so is a means of gain. (Ham p. 70.) And the former verb, He ploughed up the ground by much walking upon it; as also AHrv↓. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, the former verb, (L, K,) aor.
Haruba
and
Hariba
, (K,) inf. n. HarovN, (A, L, K,) He took, or had, four wives together. (A, L, K.) ― -b5- Immoderatè inivit: (A, K:) multùm inivit. (IAar, L.) And Harava QmoraOatahu Multùm inivit mulierem suam. (IAar, L.) ― -b6- (tropical:) He emaciated, or rendered lean, (IAar, S, A, K,) a beast, (K,) or a camel, (IAar, TA,) or a she-camel, (IAar, S, A,) and a horse, (IAar, TA,) by journeying (IAar, S, A, K) thereon; (IAar, S, K;) as also AHrv↓, (so in the
A and L and TA, and in some copies of the S, in this art., and so in the S and L and K in art. lhd,) or AHtrv↓. (So in some copies of the S in the present art.) ― -b7- (tropical:) He stirred a fire, (S, A, K,) and made it to burn up, (TA,) with the miHoraAv. (A, TA.) ― -b8- (tropical:) He examined, looked into, scrutinized, or investigated: (K, TA:) app. in an absolute sense: but accord. to some of the leading lexicologists, he examined, looked into, scrutinized, or investigated, and studied, the book, or the Kur-án: (TA:) he studied the Kur-án: (S:) or he studied the Kur-án long, and meditated upon it. (A, TA.) ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) He called to mind a thing, or an affair, and became excited thereby: [for ex.,] Ru-beh says,
waAlqawolu manosiIRN UicaA lamo yuHoravi
[And the saying is forgotten if it be not called to mind so as to produce excitement]. (TA.) ― -b10- (assumed tropical:) He applied himself to the study of Alfiqoh [i. e. the law]; or he learned the science so called. (K.)

HarovN Hrv
HarovN Gain, acquisition, or earning; (Jel in xlii. 19;) as also HariyvapN↓; of which the pl. is HaraAYivu: (K:) and recompense, or reward. (Bd and Jel in xlii. 19, and TA. [Accord. to Bd, in the place here referred to, this is from the same word as meaning “ seed-produce: but the reverse seems to be the case accord. to the generality of the lexicologists.]) mano kaAna yuriydu Harova AlMxirapi, in the Kur xlii. 19, means (assumed tropical:) Whoso desireth the reward, or recompense, (Bd,) or the gain, i. e. reward, or recompense, (Jel,) [of the world to come.] ― -b2- A lot, share, or portion. (TA.) ― -b3- Worldly goods. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Seed-produce: (S, * K, * TA:) (tropical:) what is grown, or raised, by means of seed, and by means of date-stones, and by means of planting: (Mgh:) an inf. n. used as a proper subst.: (Mgh, Msb:) pl. HuruwvN. (Msb.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) A place ploughed for sowing; (Mgh, Msb;) as also maHoravN↓, (Msb,) pl. maHaArivu: (Mgh, Msb:) or land prepared for sowing: (Jel in ii. 66:) and it is said to signify also a plain, or soft, place; perhaps because one ploughs in it. (Ham p. 70.) [Being originally an inf. n., it is also used in a pl. sense.] It is said in the Kur ii. 223, nisaMWukumo HarovN lakumo (Mgh, Msb) (tropical:) Your wives, or women, are unto you things wherein ye sow your offspring: (Bd, Jel:) they are thus likened to places that are ploughed for sowing. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b6- [And hence,] (tropical:) A wife; as in the saying, kayofa Harovuka (tropical:) [How is thy wife?]. (A, TA.) ― -b7- A road, or beaten track, or the middle of a road, that is much trodden [as though ploughed] by the hoofs of horses or the like. (K, * TA.) ― -b8- [A ploughshare: so in Richardson's Pers. Ar. and Engl. Dict., ed. by Johnson; and so, app., in the Munjid of Kr, voce EuqaAbN.]

(TA.) [Hence,] miHoraAvu AlHarobi (assumed tropical:) That which [or he who] stirs up, or excites, war. (TA.) ― -b2- [In the present day, it signifies A plough: and (like HarovN) a ploughshare.]

1 Harija Hrj
1. Harija, aor.
Haraja
, inf. n. HarajN, It (a number of things) became collected together: and, necessarily, became close, strait, or narrow: (so accord. to an explanation of the inf. n. by Er-Rághib, in the TA:) said of anything, it was, or became, close, strait, or narrow. (KL.) One says of dust, Harija UilaI HaAYiTK, or sanadK, It rose, (Lth, Az, TA,) in a narrow place, (TA,) and became collected [against a wall, or an acclivity or the like]. (Lth, Az, TA.) ― -b2- Harija Sadoruhu, aor. and inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) His bosom became strait, or contracted; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, TA;) not expanded, or dilated, by reason of what was good. (TA.) And Harija alone, aor. and inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He became disquieted, and contracted in bosom: and (assumed tropical:) he became in doubt; he doubted; because doubt disquiets the mind. (So accord. to explanations of the inf. n. by Er-Rághib, in the TA.) ― -b3- Also Harija, aor. and inf. n. as above, [(assumed tropical:) He became straitened, or in difficulty: and particularly, by the commission of a sin, or crime: (see HarajN, below:) and hence, simply,] (assumed tropical:) he committed a sin, a crime, or an act of disobedience for which he deserved punishment. (Msb.) ― -b4- Also He looked, and was unable to move from his place by reason of fear and rage. (T, TA.) And Harijati AlEayonu, (S, A, K,) aor.
Haraja
, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) The eye became dazzled, (HaArat, S, K, TA,) or sank in its socket, (gaArat,) and its vision became straitened: (A, TA:) or it did not turn about, nor wink, by reason of intent gazing. (TA.) ― -b5- Also, (S, A, K,) aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (S, K,) (tropical:) It was, or became, forbidden, or prohibited, (S, A, K,) and attended with straitness, or difficulty. (A.) So in the saying, Harija EalaIRa Zulomuka (tropical:) The wronging of thee is forbidden, or prohibited, to me. (S, TA.) And Harija Ealayohi AlsRaHuwru (tropical:) The meal termed sHwr became forbidden, or prohibited, to him, (A, TA,) namely, a man fasting, and attended with difficulty, (A,) by reason of the straitness of the time thereof. (TA.) And Harijati AlSRalaApu (tropical:) Prayer became forbidden, or prohibited, (A, and TA as from the K, [but not found by me in the copies of the K,]) EalayohaA to her [by reason of legal impurity, as is shown in the A]. (A, TA.) ― -b6- Harija Uilayohi (tropical:) He betook himself, or had recourse, to him, or it, for protection from a strait, or difficulty. (TA.) And Harija UilaI kacaA wa kacaA (assumed tropical:) He betook himself to such and such things. (TA.)

HariXa
, inf. n. HaroXN (S, K) and taHoraAXN, (K,) He hunted, or sought to capture or catch, or captured or caught, the [lizard called] DbR; syn. SaAdahu; (S, A, K;) by moving about his hand at its hole, (S, K,) at the entrance thereof, (K,) in order that it might imagine it to be a serpent, and put forth its tail to strike it, whereupon he would seize it; (S, K;) as also AHtrXhu↓: (A, K:) or, as also AHtrXhu↓, and tHrRXhu↓, and bihi tHrRX↓, he traced its hole, and made a noise with his staff, or stick, at it, and inserted the end of this into the hole, and the DbR, hearing the sound, thought it to be a beast desiring to come in upon it, so it came backwards upon its feet and kinder part, fighting, and striking with its tail, whereupon the man hastened with it, and seized it firmly by its tail, and it was unable to escape from him. (TA.) And hence, He hunted, or sought to capture, or captured, the DbR in any manner. (Ham p. 61.) Hence also the saying, lahuwa Oaxobavu mino DabRK HaraXotahu [Verily he is worse than a DbR which thou hast hunted]: for sometimes the DbR scents [its pursuer], and circumvents [him], and cannot be caught. (TA.) And hence the prov., alluding to one's discoursing to a learned man with the desire of instructing him, OatuEolimuniI biDabRK OanaA HaraXotuhu [Dost thou acquaint me with a DbR which I have captured?]. (A 'Obeyd, Az.) Hence also the prov., hecaAOajalRu mina AlHaroXi [This is a greater matter than the hunting, or capturing, of the DbR]: (M, A, K:) originating in one of their fables, to the effect that a DbR said to its young one, “ O my little son, beware thou of AlHaroX: ” and the young one heard, one day, the fall of a digging-implement upon the mouth of the hole; so he said, “ O my father, is this AlHaroX? ” to which his father answered, “ O my little son, this is a greater matter than AlHaroX: ” (M, K: *) and it became a prov., which is applied to him who fears a thing and falls into that which is more severe. (M.) [Hence also the saying,] DabRa AlEadaAwapi bayonahumo AiHotaraXa↓ (tropical:) [He roused the rancour of enmity between them]. (TA.) ― -b2- HaraXahu, (S, K,) aor.

HuroDN, (Mgh,) or HuruDN↓, (Msb,) or both, (S, K,) the former mentioned by Sb, but in some of the copies of his book written with fet-h (HaroDN↓), i. q. Xajaru AlOuXonaAni [The trees, or plants, from which potash is obtained; the kind of plants called kali, or glasswort, &c.]; which are of the kind called najiyl: (Az, TA:) Aboo-Ziyád says that what is termed HuroD is slender in the extremities (duqaAqu AlOaToraAfi), but its tree is large, being sometimes used for shade, and affords firewood, and it is that with which people wash clothes; and he adds, we have not seen any HuroD purer or whiter than some which grows in ElYemámeh, in a valley thereof called jawRu AlxaDaArimi: (TA:) i. q. [But see HarRaADN.]) So in the Kur [xii. 85], accord. to one reading, (K,) the reading of El- Hasan El-Basree, (Sgh,) HatRaI takuwna HuruDFA↓, (Bd,) meaning Until thou be like AXnAn in dryness; as explained in the K, except that nuHuwlFA is there erroneously put for quHuwlFA: (TA:) but EsSuddee disapproved of this reading. (Sgh.) ＝ -A2- Also HuroDN, [and app. HuruDN also,] i. q. jiSRN [or Gypsum]. (TA.)

HaraDN Corruptness in the body, and in the intellect, (Ibn-'Arafeh, A, K,) and (assumed tropical:) in one's course of conduct, or tenets. (Ibn-'Arafeh, K.) [See 1.] ＝ -A2- A man in a corrupt, or disordered, state, and sick, or diseased, (S, K,) so that he defiles himself (yuHodivu [but in some copies of the S this word is omitted]) in his clothes; (S;) as also HaAriDapN↓ and HaAriDN↓ and HariDN↓; (K;) ↓which last also signifies a man having his stomach in a corrupt, or disordered, state; and suffering protracted disquietude of mind, and disease: (TA:) also the first, (HaraDN,) weary, or fatigued: (K:) and at the point of death; (Msb, K;) as also HaAirDN↓; (K;) which last also signifies one near to dying, or to perishing; and having his body corrupted, or disordered, by disease, so as to be at the point of death, and so HariDN↓; (TA;) and [in like manner] muHoraDN↓ signifies dying, or perishing, from disease, being neither living so as to be an object of hope, nor dead so as to be an object of despair: (T, TA:) HaraDN also signifies emaciated (lit. dissolved) by grief, or by excessive love; (AA accord. to the S, or AO accord. to the TA, and K;) as also muHoraDN↓, (S,) or muHarRaDN↓: (K:) and heavily oppressed by disease; or constantly affected thereby so as to be at the point of death: so in the Kur xii. 85: (K:) [in the CK, HaraDFA is her erroneously put for maraDFA:] or it there signifies heavily pressed upon by disease; or affected by constant disease: (AZ:) or extremely aged; or old and weak: (Katádeh:) and anything withering: (TA:) [the following observation, which is inserted in the S after the first of the significations here given of HaraDN used as an epithet, and in the K after a later signification which is said to be tropical, applies to it, when so used, in all its senses:] it is employed alike as sing. as pl. (Fr, S, K) and masc. (Fr) and fem.; (Fr, K;) being originally an inf. n.: (Fr, Msb:) or, like every inf. n. used as an epithet, it is for cuw followed by the inf. n., and therefore has no dual nor pl.
form: (Zj:) but some of the Arabs use HaAriDN↓ as an epithet applied to a male, and HaAriDapN↓ as applied to a female; and these have duals and pls.: (Fr:) and sometimes HaraDN has pls.; namely OaHoraADN; (K;) which is also pl. of HariDN and of HaAriDN; or, accord. to the L, it is allowable as a pl. of HariDN, in the place of the more common pl. HariDuwna; (TA;) and HuroDaAni↓; (K;) which is more approved; (TA;) and HariDapN. (K: [this last being expressly said in the TA to be thus written, but in the CK it is written HaraDap.]) ― -b2- Also, applied to a man, (A,) (tropical:) Possessing no good; (A, K;) like HaAriDapN↓, (TA,) which latter is explained by As as signifying a man in whom is no good: (T, TA:) or the former, one whose good is not hoped for, nor his evil feared: (K:) and a bad man: (K:) and low, base, mean, or sordid; unable to rise from, or quit, his place; as also HariyDN↓ and HariDN↓ and muHarRaDN↓, (K, [this last, in the CK, written muHarRiD,]) or muHoraDN↓, (TA,) and UiHoriyDN↓: (K:) or low, base, mean, or sordid; in whom is no good: (TA:) and [in like manner] HaAriDN↓ signifies bad, corrupt, or vitious, and neglected, or forsaken; (K;) and so maHoruwDN↓, (TA,) and HiroDapN↓, of which the pl. is HiraDN; (TA;) maHoruwDN↓ also signifying made, or asserted, to be low, base, mean, or sordid; (K, TA;) and so HaAriDN↓, and HiroDapN↓; and this last signifying also having in him no good: (TA:) and HaraDN likewise signifies one who does not take to himself arms, nor fight: (Lth, K:) its pl. is OaHoraADN (A, TA) and HuroDaAnN↓: (TA:) both these pls. signify weak men, who will not fight: (S:) and the former of them is explained as signifying the lowest, basest, or meanest, sort of mankind: and men corrupt in their course of conduct, or tenets: also the latter of them as signifying men who know not the place of their chief: and HaAriDN↓, of which the fem. is with p, signifies a stupid man. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, applied to a she-camel, Lean, or emaciated: (K, TA:) and HuroDaAnN↓, so applied, vile: and perishing, or dying; in which sense it is likewise applied to a male camel. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, applied to language, or speech, (assumed tropical:) Bad; (K;) and so, by poetic license, HaroDN↓; or this, accord. to Sgh, is a dial. var.: (L, TA:) and perishing: pl. OaHoraADN. (TA.)

3 Huwrifa Hwrf
3. Huwrifa He was debarred from the means of subsistence; because he of whom this is said is aloof (biHarofK) from the means of subsistence. (Mgh.) And Huwrifa kasobu fulaAnK Such a one was made to experience difficulty (S, TA) in his buying and selling, and was straitened (TA) in his means of subsistence; as though his means of subsistence were turned away from him: (S, TA:) or he had his gain, or earnings, turned away from him. (Msb.) It is said in a trad. of Ibn-Mes'ood, mawotu AlmuWomini Earaqu Aljabiyni taboqaI Ealayohi AlbaqiyRapimina AlcRunuwbi fayuHaArifu bihaA Einoda Almawoti, i. e. [The death of the believer is accompanied with sweating of the side of the forehead: some sins remain chargeable against him, and] he is made to experience difficulty by them [in dying], in order that his sins may be diminished. (S.) ＝ -A2- muHaArafapN has also a meaning like mufaAxarapN: Sá'ideh says,
faqado EalimuwA fiI Algazowi kayofa nuHaArifu
[And they certainly know, in warfare, how we vie for superiority in glory: or] accord. to Skr, it means how we deal with them; as when one says
to a man, What is thy Hirofap (i. e. thine occupation) and thy lineage? (TA:) [or the meaning may be how we requite; for] ＝ -A3- HArfhu bisuwoCK signifies He requited him for evil (K, TA) that he had done. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., UinRa AlEabodi layuHaArafu Eano Eamalihi Alxayora Oawo AlXRarRa, i. e. [Verily the servant] shall be requited [for his deed; the good I mean, or the evil]. (IAar, TA.) And AHrf↓ also signifies He requited for good or evil. (IAar, K.) ＝ -A4- muHaArafapN signifies also The measuring a wound with the miHoraAf, i. e. the probe. (K, * TA.)

HarofN Hrf Hrfp
HarofN The extremity, verge, border, margin, brink, brow, side, or edge, (S, Mgh, * K, TA,) of anything; (S, K;) as, for instance, the side of a river or rivulet, and of a ship or boat, (TA,) and of the notch of an arrow; (Msb;) and the edge of a sword: (L, TA:) pl. [of mult. HuruwfN, and of pauc.] OaHorufN. (TA.) Hence, (S,) [A point, a ridge, a brow, and a ledge, of a mountain:] the pointed, sharp, or edged, summit of a mountain: (S, Msb, K:) a projecting portion in the side of a mountain, in form like a small dukRaAn [i. e. bench] or the like: and a portion in the summit of a mountain, having a thin edge, or ridge, rising above the upper part of the back: (Sh, TA:) pl. (of the word thus used in relation to a mountain, TA) HirafN; (Fr, S, Msb, K;) accord. to Fr, (Msb,) the only instance of the kind except TilalN as pl. of TalRN. (Msb, K.) [Hence, also,] A nib, of a writing-reed, obliquely cut: so in the phrase qalamN laA Harofa lahu, in the S and K in art. jzm, a writingreed not having a nib obliquely cut. (TA in that art. [See 2 in the present art.]) And HarofaA AlrRaOosi The two lateral halves of the head. (TA.) [Hence, also, the phrase] fulaAnN EalaI HarofK mino Oamorihi [and biHarofK minohu (see 3, first sentence,)] Such a one is [standing] aloof with respect to his affair, (EalaI naAHiyapK minohu, ISd, TA,) [in suspense,] waiting, and looking to the result, if he see, in regarding it from one side, what he likes; (TA;) turning from it if he see what does not please him. (ISd, TA.) The saying, in the Kur xxii. 11, wamina QlnRaAsi mano yaEobudu QllReha EalaI HarofK means And of men is he who serves God standing aloof with respect to religion, in a fluctuating state, like him who is in the outskirts of the army, who, if sure of victory and spoil, stands firm, and otherwise flees: (Ksh, Bd: *) or the meaning is, who serves God in doubt, or suspense, (Zj, K, Jel,) being unsteady like him who alights and abides upon the Harof [i. e. point, or ridge, or brow,] of a mountain: (Jel:) or in a state of disquietude respecting his case; (Ibn- 'Arafeh, K;) i. e. not entering into the religion firmly, or steadily: (K:) or who serves God in one mode of circumstances; i. e. when in ample circumstances, and not when straitened in circumstances; (Az, S, K;) as though good fortune and plenty were one side, and an evil state were another side: (Az, TA:) [hence,] HarofN sometimes signifies a mode, or manner, and a way. (Msb.) ― -b2- A letter of the alphabet: pl. HuruwfN: (S, Msb, K:) the letters being thus called because they are the extremities of the word [and of the syllable]. (Kull.) The saying of the lawyers, tuboTalu AlSRalaApa biHarofK mufohimK [Prayer is made null by a significant letter] means only by an imperative of a verb of which the first and last radical letters are infirm; such as fi from wafaI, and qi from waqaI, and the like. (Msb.) ― -b3- As a grammatical term, (assumed tropical:) [A particle; i. e.] what is used to express a meaning, and is not a noun nor a verb: every other definition of it is bad: (K:) pl. HuruwfN. (Msb, &c.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) A word [absolutely: often used in this sense in lexicons &c.]. (Kull.) ― -b5- A dialect, an idiom, or a mode of expression, peculiar to certain of the Arabs: pl. [of pauc.] OaHorufN: so in the saying (of Mohammad, TA) nazala AlquroMnu EalaI saboEapi OaHorufK The Kur-án has been revealed according to seven dialects, of the dialects of the Arabs: (A'Obeyd, Az, IAth, K:) or this means, according to seven modes, or manners, (Mgh, Msb,) of reading: whence fulaAnN yaqoraOu biHarofi Qboni masoEuwdK Such a one reads in the manner of reading of Ibn-Mes'ood. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- Applied to a she-camel, (assumed tropical:) Lean, or light of flesh; or lean, and lank in the belly; (S, K;) and firm, strong, or hardy; likened to the Harof of a mountain; (S;) or to the Hrf of a sword, (Z, O, TA,) in respect of her leanness, or thinness, and her sharpness and effectiveness in pace; (Z, TA;) or to a letter of the alphabet, meaning the letter A, in respect of her leanness: (TA:) or excellent, or high-bred, or strong and light and swift, sharp and effective in pace, rendered lean by journeyings; likened to the Hrf of a sword: (L:) or emaciated: (S, K:) so As used to say: (S:) but this is inconsistent with Dhu-r-Rummeh's description of a she-camel by the epithets jumaAliyRapN HarofN sinaAdN: (TA:) [see HariyvapN:] or [in the CK “ and ”] great; big; of great size; (K, TA;) likened to the Hrf of a mountain: (TA:) it is applied only to a she-camel: one may not say jamalN HarofN.
