2 HrRmhu Hrm Hrmh Hrmp
2. HrRmhu, inf. n. taHoriymN, (S, Msb, K,) said of God, (K,) and of a man, (S, Msb,) He forbade it, prohibited it, or made it unlawful, (S, Msb, K, *) Ealayohi to him; (S;) as also AHrmhu↓, (S, * Msb, K,) inf. n. UiHoraAmN. (S.) The saying AallRehu Oakobaru at the commencement of prayer is termed takobiyrapu AltRaHoriymi [The tkbyrp of prohibition], because it prohibits the person praying from saying and doing anything extraneous to prayer: and it is also termed tkbyrpu AlUiHoraAmi↓, meaning the tkbyrp of entering upon a state of prohibition by prayer. (TA.) It is said in a trad., of Ibn- 'Abbás, UicaA HarRama AlrRajulu QmoraOatahu fahiIa yamiynN yukafRiruhaA [When the man declares his wife to be forbidden to him, it is an oath, which he must expiate]: for the taHoriym of a wife and of a female slave may be without the intention of divorce. (TA.) And HarRamotu AlZRuloma EalaI nafosiI, occurring in another trad., [lit. I have forbidden myself wrongdoing, said by Mohammad,] means I am far above wrongdoing. (TA.) taHoriymN [as the inf. n. of HurRimN] means The being refractory, or untractable; [as though forbidden to the rider;] whence muHarRamN [q. v.] applied to a camel. (TA.) ― -b2- [Also He made, or pronounced, it, or him, sacred, or inviolable, or entitled to reverence or respect or honour; whence AlmuHarRamu applied to the Haram of Mekkeh, &c.:] he, or it, made him, or it, to be reverenced, respected, or honoured. (KL.) ＝ -A2- He bound it hard; namely, a whip. (KL.) ― -b2- He tanned it incompletely [so that it became, or remained, hard]; namely, a hide. (KL.) ＝ -A3- See also 4, in two places.

4 AHrAm AHrAm OHrAm UHrAm Hrm
4. AHrAm, [inf. n. UiHoraAmN,] He entered upon a thing [or state or time] that caused what was before allowable, or lawful, to him to be forbidden, or unlawful. (S, * Msb. [See also 5.]) And hence, (S, Msb,) He purposed entering upon the performance of the HajR or the Eumorap: (Msb:) or he (the performer of the HajR or the Eumorap) entered upon acts whereby what was allowable, or lawful, to him became forbidden, or unlawful; (K, TA;) as venereal intercourse, and the anointing of oneself, and wearing sewed garments, and hunting and the like: (TA:) you say, AHrAm biAlHajRi and biAlEumorapi, because what was allowable to the person became forbidden; as the killing of objects of the chase, and [venereal intercourse with] women. (S.) And He entered into the Haram, i. e. Mekkeh or El-Medeeneh, (K, TA,) or the sacred territory of cither of those cities: (TA:) or he entered into a sacred, or an inviolable, state; or into a state of security or safety, (S, K, TA,) being assured by a compact, or bond, that he should not be attacked [&c.]: (TA:) or it signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (S,) he entered upon a sacred month; (S, Msb, K;) and so HrRm↓, (K, TA, [in the CK Harama,]) inf. n. taHoriymN. (TA.) And He entered [as a subject] into the covenanted state of security of the government of the Khaleefeh. (TA.) 'Omar said, AlSRiyaAmu UiHoraAmN [Fasting is a state of prohibition], because the faster is prohibited from doing that which would break his fast. (Sh, TA.) And AlrRajulu yuHorimu fiI AlgaDabi, a saying of El-Hasan, means The man swears in anger, because he becomes prohibited thereby (bihi litaHarRumihi↓) [from doing, or refraining from, a thing]. (TA.) See also 2, second sentence. ― -b2- AHrAm Eanohu He refrained from it [as though he were prohibited from doing it]. (ElMufaddal, TA.) ＝ -A2- AHrmhu: see 2, first sentence. ― -b2- See also 1. ＝ -A3- Also He overcame him in contending for stakes, or wagers, in a game of hazard; (AZ, Ks, S, K;) and so HrRmhu↓, (K,) inf. n. taHoriymN. (TA.)

5 tHrRm Hrm tHrm
5. tHrRm [He became in a state of prohibition]: see 4. [Thus it is similar to 4 in the first of the senses assigned to this latter above. Like as you say, AHrm biAlHajRi and biAlEumorapi, so] you say, tHrRm biAlSRalaApi [He became in a state of prohibition by prayer; i. e.] he pronounced the takobiyr [or takobiyrapu AltRaHoriymi, also termed takobiyrapu AlUiHoraAmi, (see 2,)] for prayer; he entered upon prayer. (MA.) ― -b2- [Also He protected, or defended, himself.] You say, tHrRm minohu biHuromapK, meaning tmnRE and tHmRI [He protected, or defended, himself] bicimRapK [by a compact, or covenant, whereby he became in a state of security or safety, or by a promise, or an assurance, of security or safety]; (K;) or biSuHobapK [by companionship]; or biHaqRK [by a right, or due]. (TA.) And tHrRm biSuHobatihi [He protected, or defended, himself by his companionship: or, as explained in the PS, he sought protection, or security, by his companionship]. (S.) ― -b3- Also [He was, or became, entitled to reverence, respect, or honour; or] he possessed what entitled him to reverence, respect, or honour. (KL.)

Golius and Freytag explain AiHotarama as meaning “ Dignitate et præsidio venerabilis fuit: ” but it is the pass., AuHoturima, that has this meaning; or rather, he was held in reverence, &c.; was reverenced, &c.]

wa Uino xaliylN yawoma masoOalapK
yaquwlu laA gaAYibN maAliI wa laA Harimu
[And if a friend come to him, on a day of solicitation, he says, My cattle are not, or my property is not, absent, nor forbidden, or refused]: (S, IB, TA:) [in the S, this is cited as an ex. of HarimN as syn. with HiromaAnN, which is an inf. n. of Haramahu, q. v.: but] IB says that Harim means mamonuwE: (TA:) yqwl in this verse is marfooa though commencing an apodosis, because meant to be understood as put before [in the protasis], accord. to Sb; as though the poet said, yaquwlu Uino OataAhu xaliylN: accord. to the Koofees, it is so by reason of fa understood. (S, TA.)

HuromapN Hrm Hrmh Hrmp
HuromapN The state of being forbidden, prohibited, or unlawful: (KL:) [and of being sacred, or inviolable; sacredness, or inviolability: (see Haruma, of which it is an inf. n.:)] and the state of being revered, respected, or honoured. (KL.) See also maHoramN. ― -b2- Also, (Az, Mgh, Msb, K,) and HurumapN↓, (Mgh, K,) and HuramapN↓, (K,) Reverence, respect, or honour; (Az, K, TK;) a subst. from AiHotiraAmN, (Mgh, Msb,) like furoqapN from AifotiraAqN; (Msb;) and maHoramN↓ signifies the same; but properly, a place of Huromap: (Mgh:) pl. of the first HuramaAtN and HurumaAtN and HuromaAtN, like grfAt pl. of gurofapN. (Msb) When a man has relationship [to us], and we regard him with bashfulness, we say, lahu HuromapN [Reverence, &c., is due to him; or is rendered to him]. (Az, TA.) And we say, lilomusolimi EalaI Almusolimi HuromapN [Reverence, &c., to the Muslim is incumbent on the Muslim]. (Az, TA.) ― -b3- Also A thing that should be sacred, or inviolable; (S, Msb, K;) and so maHoramapN↓ and maHorumapN↓ (S, Msb) and maHoramN↓: (Msb:) as, for instance, a man's honour, or reputation: (TK:) a thing which one is under an obligation to reverence, respect, or honour [and defend]: (Jel in ii. 190:) a thing of which one is under an obligation to be mindful, observant, or regardful: (Bd ibid.:) [everything that is entitled to reverence, respect, honour, or defence, in the character and appertenances of a person: a thing that one is bound to do, or from which one is bound to refrain, from a motive of reverence, respect, or honour: (see the next sentence:) and any attribute that renders the subject thereof entitled to reverence, respect, or honour:] the pl. of HuromapN is HurumaAtN (Bd and Jel ubi suprà, and TA) [and HuramaAtN and HuromaAtN, as above,] and HuramN; (Msb;) and that of maHoramN↓ [and maHoramapN↓ and maHorumapN↓] is maHaArimu; (Msb;) and maHoramaAtN and maHorumaAtN [also] are pls. of maHoramapN↓ and maHorumapN↓. (As, S.) HurumaAtu QllRehi means [The inviolable ordinances and prohibitions of God: or] the ordinances of God, and other inviolable things: (Bd and Jel * in xxii. 31:) or what it is incumbent on one to perform, and unlawful to neglect: (Zj, K:) or all the requisitions of God relating to the rites and ceremonies of the pilgrimage and to other things: (Ksh in xxii. 31:) or the Haram [or sacred territory] and the requisitions relating to the pilgrimage: (Bd ubi suprà:) or the requisitions relating to the pilgrimage in particular: (Ksh ubi suprà:) or the Kaabeh and the sacred mosque and the sacred territory and the sacred month and the person who is in the state of UiHoraAm: (Ksh and Bd ibid.:) or the inviolability (Huromap) of the sacred territory and of the state of UiHoraAm and of the sacred month: (TA:) or Mekkeh and the pilgrimage and the Eumorap, and all the acts of disobedience to God which He has forbidden: (Mujáhid, TA:) or [simply] the acts of disobedience to God. ('Atà, TA.) ― -b4- And [hence, because it should be regarded as sacred, or inviolable,] i. q. cimRapN [A compact, a covenant, or an obligation; and particularly such as renders one responsible for the safety, or safe-keeping, of a person or thing, or for the restoration of a thing, or for the payment of a sum of money, &c.; or by which one becomes in a state of security or safety: and simply responsibility, or suretiship: and security, or safety; security of life and property; protection, or safeguard; a promise, or an assurance, of security, safety, protection, or safeguard; indemnity; or quarter: or an obligation, a duty, or a right, or due, that should be regarded as sacred, or inviolable, or the nonobservance of which is blameable]. (K.) ― -b5- And [hence also] A man's Huram [i. e. his wives, or women under covert,] and his family: (S:) and [in like manner the pl.] HuramN, accord. to the K HuromN, but correctly like zufarN, (TA,) a man's wives, or women [under covert], (K, TA,) and his household, or family, (TA,) and what he protects, or defends; as also maHaArimu, of which the sing. is maHorumapN↓ and maHoramapN↓: (K, TA:) and hence HuromapN is applied by the vulgar to signify a wife. (TA.) [In Har, p. 377, a man's Huromap is said to mean his Haram and his family: and in p. 489, a man's Haram is said to mean his family and his wives and those whom he protects, or defends. See also HariymN.] ― -b6- Also A share, portion, or lot; syn. naSiybN. (K.)

HiromapN Hrm Hrmh Hrmp
HiromapN (K) and HaramapN↓ (Lh, S, K) The desire of a female cloven-hoofed animal, (K,) or of a ewe, or she-goat, (S,) and of a she-wolf and of a bitch, (K,) for the male: (S, K:) HaramapN in ewes, or she-goats, is like DabaEapN in she-camels, and HinaMCN in ewes. (S.) It is also used, in a trad., in relation to male human beings. (K.) It is said in a trad., respecting those whom the hour [of the resurrection] shall overtake, tuboEavu Ealayohimu AlHiromapu wa yusolabuwna AlHayaMCa, i. e. Venereal desire [shall be made to befall them, and they shall be bereft of shame]. (S.)

HaramapN Hrm Hrmh Hrmp
HaramapN: see what next precedes.

HuramapN Hrm Hrmh Hrmp
HuramapN: see HuromapN.

HurumapN Hrm Hrmh Hrmp
HurumapN: see HuromapN.

HaromaI Hrm HrmI Hrmp Hrmy Hrmyy
HaromaI, applied to a female cloven-hoofed animal, (K,) or to a ewe, or she-goat, (S,) and to a she-wolf and to a bitch, (K,) Desiring the male: pl. HiraAmN and HaraAmaI, (S, K,) like EijaAlN and EajaAlaI, (S,) or the latter pl. is HuraAmaI; (so accord. to some copies of the K [like EujaAlaI];) as though its masc., if it had a masc., were HaromaAnu. (S.) ＝ -A2- HaromaI wa QllRehi means the same as OamaA wa QllRehi [Verily, or now surely, by God]; (K;) as also HazomaI wa QllRehi. (K in art. Hzm.)

HiromiIRN Hrm HrmI Hrmp Hrmy Hrmyy
HiromiIRN, applied to a man, Of, or belonging to, the Haram: fem. HiromiyRapN. (S, Msb, TA.) [In the TA it is said that Mbr mentions two forms of the epithet HrmyRp as applied to a woman: it does not specify what these are; but one seems to be HuromiyRapN, for he says that it is from the phrase wa Huromapi Albayoti “ by the sacredness of the House ” of God.] Az says, on the authority of Lth, that when they applied the rel. n. from AlHaramu to anything not a human being, [as, for instance, to a garment, or piece of cloth,] they said vawobN HaramiIRN↓: (Msb:) [but] they also said HiromiyRapN, (S,) or sihaAmN HiromiyRapN, (Msb,) meaning Arrows of the Haram: (S, Msb:) and HiromiyRapN [also, or qawosN HiromiyRapN,] meaning A bow made of a tree of the Haram. (Ham p. 284.) ― -b2- Also A man of the Haram whose food was eaten by a pilgrim, and in whose clothes this pilgrim performed his circuiting round the Kaábeh: and a pilgrim who ate the food of a man of the Haram, and performed his circuiting round the Kaábeh in this man's clothes: each of these was called the HiromiIR of the other: every one of the chiefs of the Arabs who imposed upon himself hardship, or strictness, in his religious practices had a HrmIR of the tribe of Kureysh; and when he performed the pilgrimage, would not eat any food but that of this man, nor perform his circuiting round the Kaabeh except in this man's clothes. (TA.)

HaramiIRN Hrm HrmI Hrmp Hrmy Hrmyy
HaramiIRN: see the next preceding paragraph.

HaraAmN HrAm
HaraAmN Forbidden, prohibited, or unlawful: and sacred, or inviolable; as in the phrases Albayotu AlHaraAmu [the Sacred House of God (i. e. the Kaabeh)] and Almasojidu AlHaraAmu [the Sacred Mosque of Mekkeh] and Albaladu AlHaraAmu [the Sacred Town or Territory]: (Msb:) contr. of HalaAlN; (S;) as also HaramN↓ (S, Msb) and HiromN↓ (S, Msb, K) and HarimN↓ [q. v.] (TA) [and in its primary sense HariymN↓] and maHoramN↓: (S, Mgh, Msb:) the pl. [of HaraAmN, agreeably with analogy,] is HurumN; (K;) and maHaArimu↓ also is a pl. of HaraAmN, contr. to rule, (TA,) and signifies things forbidden by God. (K.) See also HiromN. ― -b2- HaraAma QllRehi laA OafoEalu, (as in some copies of the S,) or HaraAmu AllReh lA AfEl, (as in other copies of the S and in the K,) is a saying like yamiyna QllRehi laA OafoEalu, or yamiynu AllReh lA AfEl: (S, K:) it may mean a declaration that the wife or the female slave shall be forbidden [to him who utters it], without the intention of divorcing [thereby the former, or of emancipating the latter; so that it may be rendered, according to the two different readings, I imprecate upon myself, or that which I imprecate
upon myself is, what is forbidden of God, if I do it: I will not do such a thing: in like manner, EalaIRa AlHaraAmu is often said in the present day]. (TA. [See 2.]) ― -b3- [Aibonu HaraAmK An illegitimate son: and a disingenuous, or dishonest, person.] ― -b4- XahorN HaraAmN [A sacred month]: (Msb:) pl. HurumN. (S, Msb, K.) AlOaXohuru AlHurumu [The sacred months] (S, * Msb, K) were four; namely, cuw AlqaEodapi and cuw AlHijRapi and AlmuHarRamu and rajabN; (S, Msb, K;) three consecutive, and one separate: (S, Msb:) in these the Arabs held fight to be unlawful; except two tribes, Khath'am and Teiyi; unless with those who held these months as profane. (S, TA.) ― -b5- HaraAmN applied to a man signifies Entering into the Haram [or sacred territory of Mekkeh or of El-Medeeneh, or Mekkeh or El- Medeeneh itself]; and is applied also to a woman; and to a pl. number: (TA:) or i. q. muHorimN↓ (S, Msb) as meaning [in, or entering upon, the state of UiHoraAm: i. e. entering upon the performance of those acts of the HajR, or of the Eumorap, whereby certain things before allowable, or lawful, to him became forbidden, or unlawful; (see 4;) or] purposing to enter upon the performance of the HajR or the Eumorap: (Msb:) as also HiromN↓: you say, Oanota HilRN and Ant HiromN [Thou art one who has quitted his state of UiHoraAm and thou art in, or entering upon, the state of AHrAm]: (TA:) the pl. of HaraAmN thus applied is HurumN: (S, Msb:) the fem. of muHorimN↓ is with p; and the pl. masc. muHorimuwna; and the pl. fem. muHorimaAtN. (Msb.) ― -b6- See another meaning voce HiromN.

HiraAmN HrAm
HiraAmN: see HariymN.

HaruwmN Hrwm
HaruwmN A she-camel that does not conceive when covered. (AA, K. [In the CK, mugotATap is erro neously put for muEotaATap.])

HariymN Hrym
HariymN: see HaraAmN. ― -b2- [Hence,] The appertenances, or conveniences, (Huquwq and maraAfiq S, Msb, K,) that are in the immediate environs, (S, Msb,) of a thing, (Msb,) or of a well &c., (S,) or that are adjuncts [or within the precincts] of a house; (K;) because it is forbidden to any but the owner to appropriate to himself the use thereof: (Msb:) or, of a well, the place where is thrown the earth that has been dug out, (K, TA,) and the walking place on either side; in the case of a well dug in a waste land that has no owner, said in a trad. to be forty cubits: (TA: [but see badiIoCN:]) and of a river, or rivulet, or canal, the place where the mud is thrown out, and the walking-place on each side: (TA:) and of a house, the interior part upon which the door is closed: (Ibn-Wásil ElKilábee, TA:) or the interior part, or middle, (qaSabap,) thereof: (T, TA:) [and particularly the women's apartments, and the portion that is for bidden to men who are not related to the women within the prohibited degrees of marriage:] and the court of a mosque: (T, TA:) [and in general,] a place which it is incumbent on one to defend [from intrusion]: (Ham p. 492:) a thing that one protects, and in defence of which one fights; [and particularly, like HuromapN as used by the vulgar, a man's wife; and also his female slave; or any woman under covert; and, like HuramN, pl. of HuromapN, as used in the classical language, his wives, or women under covert, and household;] as also HaramN↓: pl. HurumN, (K,) the pl. of HariymN; (TA;) and OaHoraAmN, (K,) which is the pl. of HaramN↓. (TA.) ― -b3- A partner, copartner, or sharer. (K.) ― -b4- A friend: so in the saying, fulaAnN HariymN SariyHN Such a one is a genuine, or sincere, friend. (TA.) ― -b5- The garment of the muHorim (S, K,) [which he wears during the performance of the HajR or the Eumorap;] called by the vulgar UiHoraAmN↓ and HiraAmN↓ (TA.) ― -b6- The clothes which the muHorimuwn used to cast off, (S, * K, TA,) when, in the time of paganism, they performed the pilgrimage to the House [of God, at Mekkeh], namely, those that were upon them when they entered the Haram [or sacred terri tory,] (TA,) and which they did not wear (K, TA) as long as they remained in the Haram: (TA:) for the Arabs used to perform their circuiting round the House naked, with their clothes thrown down before them during the circuiting; (T, S, TA;) they saying, “ We will not perform the circuiting round the House in clothes in which we have committed sins, or crimes: ” and the woman, also, used to perform the circuiting naked, except that she wore a rahoT of thongs. (TA.) A poet says,
kafaI HazanFA marRiI Ealayohi kaOanRahu
laqFI bayona OayodiI AlTRaAYifiyna Hariymu
[Sufficiently grievous is my passing by him as though he were a thing thrown away, a cast-off garment of a muHorim, before those performing the circuiting round the Kaabeh]. (S.

HariymapN Hrym Hrymh Hrymp
HariymapN Anything eagerly desired, or coveted, that escapes one, so that he cannot attain it. (S.) And Hariymapu AlrRabRi That which the Lord denies to whomsoever He will. (K.)

HaArimN HArm
HaArimN Denying, refusing, or refusing to give. (TA.) ― -b2- huwa biHaArimi EaqolK, (so in the copies of the K,) or maA huwa biHaArimi EaqolK, (so in the TA,) means He has intellect, or intelligence: (K:) a phrase mentioned, and thus explained, by AZ: and so biEaArimi EaqolK. (TA.) [The right reading is evidently that given in the TA.]

UiHoraAmN AHrAm OHrAm UHrAm Hrm
UiHoraAmN inf. n. of 4. ＝ -A2- See also HariymN.

maHoramN mHrm
maHoramN: see HaraAmN, with which it is syn. (S, Mgh, Msb.) [And see an ex. voce HadRN.] ― -b2- See also HuromapN, in three places. ― -b3- Also A female relation whom it is unlawful to marry: (T, Msb:) [and such a male relation likewise:] and raHimo maHoramN relationship that renders it unlawful to marry. (K.) You say, hiIa lahu maHoramN [She is a relation to him such as it is unlawful for him to marry]: and huwa lahaA maHoramN and huwa maHoramu minohaA (Mgh) and huwa cuw maHoramK minohaA he is one whom it is unlawful for her to marry, (S,) and cuw raHimK maHoramK and cuw raHimK maHoramN, applying mHrm as an epithet to rHm and to cw; (Mgh, Msb;) and cuw fiI AlqaraAbapi HuromapK↓: (Ham p. 669:) and in the case of a woman, caAtu raHimK maHoramK. (Msb.) ― -b4- maHaArimu AllRayoli (tropical:) The fearful places of the night, (IAar, S, K, TA,) which the coward is forbidden to traverse. (IAar, S, TA.) [See also maxaArimu, pl. of maxoramN.]

muHorimN mHrm
muHorimN: see HaraAmN, in two places: Contr. of muHilRN: and as such signifying [also] one with whom it is unlawful to fight: (S:) or, as such, whom it is unlawful to slay: (TA in art. Hl:) and, as such also, one who has a claim, or covenanted right, to protection, or safeguard. (S in art. Hl.) Er-Rá'ee says,
qataluwA Qboni EafRaAna Alxaliyfapa muHorimFA
(S,) meaning [They slew ('Othmán) Ibn-' Affán, the Khaleefeh,] while entitled to the respect due to the office of Imám and to the [sacred] city and to the [sacred] month: for he was slain [in ElMedeeneh and] in [the month of] Dhu-l-Hijjeh. (Ham p. 310.) And one says, UinRahu lamuHorimu Eanoka Verily he is one whom it is unlawful for thee to harm: (K:) or for whom it is unlawful to harm thee: (IAar, Th:) or whom it is unlawful for thee to harm and for whom it is unlawful to harm thee. (Az, TA.) And musolimN muHorimN A Muslim is secure, as to himself and his property, by the respect that is due to El-Islám: or a Muslim refrains from the property of a Muslim, and his honour, or reputation, and his blood. (TA.) ― -b2- One who is at peace with another. (IAar, K.) ― -b3- One who is in the Hariym of another. (K.) You say, huwa muHorimN binaA He is in our Hariym. (TA.) ― -b4- Fasting, or a faster: because the faster is prohibited from doing that which would break his fast. (TA.) ― -b5- And, for a like reason, Swear ing, or a swearer. (TA.)

maHoramapN mHrm mHrmh mHrmp
maHoramapN and maHorumapN pl. maHaArimu (K) and maHoramaAtN and maHorumaAtN: (As, S:) see each voce HuromapN, in four places.

muHarRamN mHrm
muHarRamN [Forbidden, prohibited, or made un lawful: and made, or pronounced, sacred, or in violable, or entitled to reverence or respect or honour]. It is said in a trad., OamaA Ealimota OanRa AlSRuwrapa muHarRamapu, i. e. [Knowest thou not that the face is] forbidden to be beaten? or that it has a title to reverence or respect or honour? (TA.) ― -b2- AlmuHarRamu The first of the months (S, Msb, K, * TA) of the year (Msb) of the Arabs [since the age of pagan ism]; (TA;) the article Al being prefixed because it is originally an epithet; but accord. to some, it is not prefixed to the name of any other month; or, accord. to some, it may be prefixed to Sfr and XwRAl: (Msb:) and [in the age of paganism, the seventh month, also called] Xahoru QllRehi AlOaSabRu (K, TA.) [AlASbR being app. a dial. var. of AlOaSamRu,] i. e. rajabN; [for] Az says, the Arabs used to call the month of rajab in the age of paganism, AlOaSamRu and AlmuHarRamu; and he cites the saying of a poet,
OaqamonaA bihaA XahoraIo rabiyEK kilaAhumaA
waXahoraIo jumaAdaI waQsotaHalRuwA AlmuHarRamaA
[We stayed in it during the two months of Rabeea, both of them, and the two months of Jumádà; and they made El-Moharram to be profane; app. by postponing it, as the pagan Arabs often did]: the Arabs called it thus because they did not allow fighting in it [unless they had postponed it]: (TA:) the pl. is muHarRamaAtN (Msb, K) and maHaArimu and maHaAriymu. (K.) ― -b3- See also HaramN — muHarRamN applied to a camel means Refractory, or untractable: (TA:) [or,] thus applied, [like EaruwDN, q. v.,] submissive in the middle part, [but] difficult to be turned about, [i. e. stubborn in the head,] when turned about: (K: [in the CK, AlcRaluwlu AlwasaTu is erroneously put for AlcRaluwlu AlwasaTi: in my MS. copy of the K, AlcRaluwlu AlwasT:]) and with p a she-camel not broken, or not trained: (TA:) or not yet completely broken or trained: (S, TA:) and muHarRamapu AlZRahori a she-camel that is refractory, or untractable; not broken, or not trained: in this sense heard by Az from the Arabs. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A skin not tanned: (K:) or not completely tanned: (S:) or tanned, but not made soft, and not thoroughly done. (TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A new whip: (K:) or a whip not yet made soft. (S, A, TA.) ― -b6- (tropical:) An Arab of the desert rude in nature or disposition, chaste in speech, that has not mixed with people of the towns or villages. (TA.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) The part of the nose that is soft in the hand. (K.)

maHoruwmN mHrwm
maHoruwmN Denied, or refused, a gift: (Msb, * TA:) or denied, or refused, good, or prosperity: (Az, K:) in the Kur lxx. 25, (I' Ab, S,) [it has this latter, or a similar, meaning;] i. q. muHaArafN [q. v.]; (I' Ab, S, K;) who hardly, or never, earns, or gains, anything: (K:) or who does not beg, and is therefore thought to be in no need, and is denied: (Bd:) and who has no increase of his cattle or other property: (K:) opposed to mazoruwqN: (Az, TA:) accord. to some, who has not the faculty of speech, like the dog and the cat &c. (Har p. 378.) ― -b2- Held in reverence, respect, or honour; reverenced, respected, or honoured; and so muHotaramN↓. (KL. [But the latter only is commonly known in this sense.])

maHaArimu mHArm mHrm mHrmp
maHaArimu an anomalous pl. of HaraAmN, q. v.: (TA:) ― -b2- and pl. of maHoramapN and maHorumapN: (K:) ― -b3- and also of AlmuHarRamu. (K.)

maHaAriymu mHArym
maHaAriymu a pl. of AlmuHarRamu. (K.)

muHotaramN mHtrm
muHotaramN [erroneously written in the Lexicons of Golius and Freytag muHotarimN]: see maHoruwmN.

1 Harana HAr Hrn Hrnn
1. Harana aor.
Haruna
; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and Haruna; (S, Msb, K;) inf. n. HiraAnN (Mgh, Msb, K) and HuruwnN, (Mgh, Msb,) or the former is a simple subst., and the latter is the inf. n., (S,) and HuraAnN; (K;) said of a horse (S, Mgh, Msb, K) or similar beast, (Msb, K,) He was, or became, restive, or refractory, and, when vehemently running, stopped: (S:) or stopped, and was restive, or refractory: (Mgh:) or stopped when one desired to call into action his power of running: said peculiarly of a solid-hoofed animal: (M, K:) or, accord. to Lh, one says also Hrnt AlnRaAqapu, meaning the she-camel stood still, and would not move from her place: and HiraAnN is used by AO in relation to a she-camel. (TA.) And Harana, inf. n. HuruwnN i. q. taOaxRara [He went back or backwards, drew back, receded, &c.]. (As, TA.) ― -b2- Harana biAlmakaAni, inf. n. HuruwunapN, [perhaps a mistranscription for HuruwnN,] He kept, or clave, to the place, and did not quit it. (TA.) ― -b3- Harana fiI AlbayoEi (tropical:) He did not exceed nor fall short in selling. (S, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Harana AlquTona He separated and loosened the cotton [by means of a bow and a kind of wooden mallet, by striking the string of the bow with the mallet]; syn. nadafahu. (K.)

HiraAnN Hr HrAn
HiraAnN a subst. from Harana said of a horse [or similar beast; i. e. Restiveness, or refractoriness, &c.]: (S:) or an inf. n. (Mgh, Msb, K.)

HaruwnN Hrwn
HaruwnN an epithet applied to a horse (S, Mgh, Msb, K) or similar beast, (Msb, K,) [meaning Restive, or refractory, &c.,] from Harana (S, Mgh, Msb, K) or Haruna: (S, Msb, K:) pl. HurunN, with two dammehs. (TA.) ― -b2- Also An animal of the chase that does not quit the higher, or highest, part of the mountain. (S, K.)

miHoranN mHrn
miHoranN The wooden implement (a kind of mallet) with which, together with a bow, by striking with the former the string of the latter, cotton is sepa rated and loosened; syn. minodafN. (K.)

miHoraAnN mHr mHrAn
miHoraAnN Honey: (K:) pl. maHaAriynu. (So in the TA, as from the K.) ― -b2- See also the pl. below.

maHaArinu mHArn
maHaArinu: see what follows.

maHaAriynu mHAryn
maHaAriynu (S, K) and maHaArinu↓ (S [in which the latter occupies the first place, the former occurring in an ex.,]) (tropical:) The bees that stick to the honey, and are extracted with the maHaAbiD, (S, K, TA,) or wooden implements with which the honey itself is extracted: (TA:) or the bees that stick in the hive, and are with difficulty extracted: or the bees that die in the honey: (T, TA:) sing. miHoraAnN↓ (K.) ― -b2- And The pods of cotton. (K.)

HarowapN Hrwh Hrwp
HarowapN A burning (M, K) which a man experiences (M) in the fauces (AlHaloq) and the chest and the head, by reason of anger, wrath, or rage, and of pain. (M, K.) — Acritude (S, K) of food, (S,) or in the taste of mustard (K, TA) and the like; (TA;) as also HaraAwapN↓. (S, K.) 5. tHrRI signifies qaSada AlHaraI; i. e. He sought, or repaired to, the vicinage, quarter, tract, or region, of a people: this is said to be the primary signification: (Mgh:) and tHrRAhu he sought, or repaired to, his vicinage, &c.; (qaSada HaraAhu;) as also HaraAhu↓, aor. yaHoriI: (TA:) he aimed at it; made it his object; sought, endeavoured after, pursued, or endeavoured to reach or attain or obtain, it; intended or purposed it; namely, a thing. (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA.) Hence, in the Kur [lxxii. 14], faOuwlaAYika taHarRawoA raXadFA Those have aimed at, or sought, &c., a right course. (S, TA.) And taHarRayotu maroDaAtahu I aimed at, or sought, &c., his approval. (Mgh.) And the trad., taHarRawoA layolapa Alqadori fiI AlEaXori AlOawaAxiri Seek ye the Night of Alqdr in the last ten [nights of Ramadán]. (TA.) — Also He sought what was most meet, suitable, fit, proper, or deserving, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) to be done, (S, K,) of two things, (Mgh, Msb,) according to the opinion predominating in his mind, (S,) fiI AlOamori [in the affair, or case]: (Msb:) or he sought, or endeavoured, and strove in seeking, and deciding upon, the singling out of a thing, by deed and by word. (TA.) — And He tarried, waited, or paused in expectation, biAlmakaAni in the place. (S, K.)

And OaHosasotu Alxabara, and OaHasotuhu, and Hasiytuhu↓, and Hasotuhu, I knew somewhat of the news. (T, L, TA.) And maA OaHosasotu biAxabari, and AaHasotu bih. maA, and bh mA Hasiytu↓, and mA Hasotu, I knew not aught of the news. (T, L, TA.)

[See also HisRN, last signification.] And OaSaAbatohumo HaAsRapN (tropical:) Injury befell them (S, TA) from cold (S, A, TA) or some other cause. (S.) HaAsRapN also signifies (assumed tropical:) Wind that removes the dust into the pools of water left by torrents, and fills them, so that the moist earth dries up. (AHn, TA.) And (assumed tropical:) Locusts eating the herbage of the land. (TA.) You say also, marRato biAlqawomi HawaAsRu, meaning (assumed tropical:) Severe years passed over the people. (Lh, TA.)

1. Hasabahu, (S, A, Mgh, &c.,) aor.
Hasuba
, (S, Mgh, Msb, &c.,) inf. n. HasobN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and HusobaAnN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and HisobaAnN (K) and HisaAbN (S, K,) which is generally an inf. n. of this verb, but sometimes of HaAsaba, (TA,) and HisaAbapN (S, K) and HisobapN, (Msb, K,) or this is like qiEodapN and rikobapN, [denoting a mode, or manner,] as in a verse of En-Nábighah cited below, (S,) and HasobapN, which is of rare occurrence, (MF, TA,) He numbered, counted, reckoned, calculated, or computed, it; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) namely, property [&c.]. (A, Mgh, Msb.) You say, mano yaqodiru EalaI EadRi AlrRamoli waHasobi AlHaSaI [Who can count the sands, and number the pebbles?]. (A.) And Oaloqi hecaA fiI AlHasobi [Throw thou this into the reckoning]; i. e., into what thou hast reckoned. (A.) waAlXRamosu waAlqamaru biHusobaAnK, in the Kur [lv. 4], means And the sun and the moon [run their courses] according to a [certain] reckoning; or through a series of mansions [or constellations], the bounds of which they do not transgress: (TA:) or bHsbAn alludes to the numbers of the months and years and all other times: [but properly speaking,] HsbAn is here an inf. n.: (Zj, TA:) or, accord. to Akh, a pl. of HisaAbN; (S, TA;) and so says AHeyth: or, accord. to some, it is here a proper subst., signifying the firmament. (TA.) HusobaAnFA in the Kur vi. 96 is held by Akh to be for biHusobaAnK, meaning biHisaAbK [as in the phrase quoted above, from the Kur lv. 4, accord. to the first explanation]. (TA.) And HusobaAnuka EalaI QllReh signifies HisaAbuka ElI AllReh [On
God be it to reckon with thee: see also Hasiybuka QllRehu]. (TA.) Az says that the reckoning in buying and selling is termed HisaAbN because one knows thereby what is sufficient. (TA.) waQllRehu sariyEu AlHisaAbi, in the Kur [ii. 198, &c., God is quick in reckoning], signifies that his reckoning is necessary, or of necessity, and that his reckoning with one person does not divert Him from reckoning with another. (TA.) And yarozuqu mano yaXaMCu bagayori HisaAbK, in the Kur [ii. 208, &c., He supplieth whom He willeth, without reckoning], means without sparing, or scanting; as when a man expends without reckoning: but the phrase is variously explained, as meaning without appointing for any one what is deficient: or without fearing that any one will call Him to account for it: or without the receiver's thinking that He will bestow upon him, or without his reckoning upon the supply; so that it may be from Hasiba “ he thought, ” or from Hasaba “ he reckoned. ” (L, TA.) The saying, cited by IAar,
yaA jumolu OasoqaAki bilaA HisaAbaho
as related by J [in the S], but correctly Ousoqyt, (TA,) means [O Juml, mayest thou be given rain] without reckoning, and without measure. (S.) An instance of HisobapN as similar to qiEodapN and rikobapN occurs in the saying of En-Nábighah,
fakamRalato miAYapF fiyhaA HamaAmatuhaA
waOasoraEato HsobapF fiI celika AlEadadK
[And she completed a hundred, in which was her pigeon; and she was quick in the mode of computing that number]. (S.) ＝ -A2- Hasibahu kacaA, [a verb of the kind termed OafoEaAlu Alquluwbi, having two objective complements, the former of which is called its noun, and the latter its enunciative,] aor.
Hasaba
and
Hasiba
; (S, Msb, K;) the former the more approved, (TA,) of the dialects of all the Arabs except Benoo-Kináneh; the latter aor. being peculiar to the dial. of this tribe, (Msb,) and contr. to analogy, (S, Msb,) for by rule it should be
Hasaba
[only]; and Hasiba is the only verb of the measure faEila having both yafoEalu and yafoEilu as the measures of its aor. except naEima and yaYisa and yabisa [and waEir a and waHira and baYisa and waliha and wahila mentioned by Ibn-Málik (with the preceding) cited in the TA voce wariva]; but eight verbs having an unsound letter for the first radical have kesreh to the medial radical in the pret. and aor., viz., waviqa and wariva and wariEa and warima and wariya and wafiqa and waliIa and wamiqa; (S;) inf. n. HisobaAnN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and maHosabapN and maHosibapN (S, K) and HisaAbN; (TA; [but see what follows;]) He [counted, accounted, reckoned, or esteemed, meaning] thought, or supposed, him, or it, to be so. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) You say, Hasibotuhu SaAliHFA [I counted him, or thought him, good, or righteous]. (S.) And Hasibotu zayodFA qaAYimFA [I thought Zeyd to be standing]. (Msb.) And maA kaAna fiI HisobaAniI kacaA [Such a thing was not in my thought]: you should not say fI HisaAbiI, (K,) unless you mean thereby it was not included in my reckoning, or, by amplification of the sense, I did not think it. (MF.) ＝ -A3- Hasuba, aor.
Hasuba
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. HasaAbapN (S, K) and HasabN, (Msb, K,) He was, or became, characterized, or distinguished, by what is termed HasabN as explained below [i. e. grounds of pretension to respect or honour; &c.]. (S, Msb, K.)

2. HsRbhu, inf. n. taHosiybN: see 4. ― -b2- Also He placed a pillow for him; supported him with a pillow; (S, K;) seated him upon a HusobaAnap, or maHosabap. (TA.) ― -b3- And hence, He honoured him. (L.) ― -b4- He buried him: (TA:) or buried him in stones: [see HasobN:] or buried him wrapped in grave-clothing: namely, a dead person. (K, TA.) ― -b5- Nuheyk El-Fezáree says, (S, TA,) addressing 'Ámir Ibn-Et-Tufeyl, (TA,)
lataqayota biAlwajoEaMCi TaEonapa murohafK
HarRaAna Oawo lavawayota gayora muHasRabi↓
(S, TA) Thou wouldst have avoided, by turning thy hinder part, the thrust [of a thin, thirsty weapon], or thou wouldst have taken thy restingplace (TA) not honoured, or not shrouded, (S, TA,) or not pillowed: gyr mHsRb being variously rendered: one person prefers the meaning not buried: Az says that the signification of burial in stones and that of wrapping in grave-clothes, assigned to the verb, were unknown to him; and that gyr mHsRb signifies not supported with a pillow. (TA.)

3 HAsbhu HAsb HAsbh HAsbp
3. HAsbhu, inf. n. muHaAsabapN (S, TA) and sometimes HisaAbN, which is also an inf. n. of Hasaba, or, accord. to Th, it seems to be a quasi-inf. n., (TA,) [He reckoned with him.] And HAsbhu Ealayohi [He called him to account for it]. (TA.)

4 AHsbhu AHsbh AHsbp OHsbh Hsb
4. AHsbhu, (Th, S, K,) inf. n. UiHosaAbN, (TA,) He gave him what sufficed, or satisfied, him, mino kulRi XaIoCK of everything: (Th, TA:) he contented him: (K:) or he gave him what contented him; as also HsRbhu↓: (S:) and both verbs, inf. n. of the latter taHosiybN, he gave him to eat and drink until he was satisfied: (K:) and the former, [or both,] he gave him until he said HasobiI [It is sufficient for me]. (AZ, S.) You say also, OaEoTaI faOaHosaba He gave, and (assumed tropical:) gave much: (S:) and AiHotasabotuhu↓, [if not a mistranscription for OaHosabotuhu,] (tropical:) I gave him much. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Also It (a thing, S, Msb,) sufficed him: (S, A, Msb:) he sufficed him. (TA.) You say, mararotu birajulK OaHosabaka mino rajulK, and [mino rajulayoni] birajulayoni OaHosabaAka, and [mino rijaAlK] birijaAlK OaHosabuwka, I passed by a man sufficient for thee as a man, i. e., supplying to thee the place of any other [by his excellent qualities], and by two men &c., and by men &c. (S.) [The verb here is rendered, in grammatical analysis, by its act. part. n. See also Hasobu.]

5 tHsab Hsb tHsb
5. tHsab (tropical:) He sought, or sought leisurely and repeatedly, to learn news: (A, K, * TA:) he sought after news: (K, * TA:) he inquired, or asked, respecting news; (S, K, * TA; [in the CK, Asotaxoyara is erroneously put for Aisotaxobara;]) of the dial. of El-Hijáz: (TA:) he searched after news as a spy. (A 'Obeyd, TA.) It is said in a trad., accord. to one reading, kaAnuwA yajotamiEuwna fayataHasRabuwna AlSRalaApa (tropical:) They used to assemble, and endeavour to ascertain the time of prayer: but the common reading is yataHayRanuwna. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also He reclined upon a pillow. (K.)

8 AHtsb AHtsb OHtsb QHtsb
8. AHtsb [for AHtsb OajorFA He reckoned upon a reward: or] he sought a reward [from God in the world to come]. (TA.) wayarozuquhu mino Hayovu laA yaHotasibu, in the Kur lxv. 2, means [And He will supply him with the means of subsistence] whence he does not reckon, or expect; whence does not occur to his mind. (Bd, Jel.) And mano SaAma ramaDAna UiymaAnFA waQHotisaAbFA, in a trad., Whoso fasteth during Ramadán, believing in God and his Apostle, and [reckoning upon a reward, or] seeking a reward from God. (Mgh, * TA.) You say also, AHtsb bikacaA OajorFA Einoda QllRehi (S, K) He reckoned upon obtaining, [or he sought,] by such a thing, or such an action, a reward from God: (PS:) or he prepared, or provided, such a thing, seeking thereby a reward from God. (K.) And AHtsb Einoda QllRehi xayorFA He prepared, or provided, in store for himself, good, [i. e. a reward,] with God. (A, Mgh.) And AHtsb AlOajora EalaI QllRehi He laid up for himself, in store, the reward, with God, not hoping for the reward of the present life; AiHotisaAbu AlOajori relating only to an action done for the sake of God. (Msb.) [Hence,] AHtsb waladahu, (A, Mgh,) or Qbonahu, (Msb,) or QbonFA, or bnotFA, (S, K, *) is said when one has lost by death an adult child or son or daughter; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) meaning He prepared, or provided, in store for himself, a reward, by his patience on the occasion of his being afflicted and tried by the death of his adult child: (Mgh, * TA:) when a man has lost by death a child not arrived at the age of puberty, you say of him, AifotaraTahu. (S, A, Msb, K.) [Hence also,] AHtsb Eamalahu [He reckoned upon, or prepared for himself, a reward by his deed: or] he did his deed seeking a reward from God in the world to come. (L, TA.) ― -b2- AiHotasabotu baAlXRaIoCi I included the thing in a numbering, or reckoning; or made account of it; accounted it a matter of importance. (Msb.) And fulaAnN laA yuHotasabu [for lA yHtsb bahi] Such a one is made no account of; is not esteemed, or regarded, as of any account, or importance. (A, TA.) ― -b3- AiHotasabotu Einodahu means Aikotafayotu [I was, or became, sufficed, or contented, thereat, or with him, or at his abode]. (A, TA.) [And IbrD thinks that the verb has the same signification in the phrase AiHotasabotu Ealayohi biAlmaAli, quoted in the TA from the A; holding Elyh to be here used in the sense of Eanohu; so that the meaning is I was, or became, sufficed, so as to have no need of him, or it, by the property: but I doubt whether this phrase be correctly transcribed.] ― -b4- AHtsb also signifies AinotahaI [He abstained, or desisted; app. as one sufficed, or contented]. (K.) ― -b5- And AHtsb Ealayohi kacaA He disapproved and disallowed his doing, or having done, such a
thing; (S, K; *) namely, a foul deed: (TA:) whence the appellation muHotasibN↓. (K.) And accord. to some, AHtsb QllReha Ealayohi means He said, May God take, or execute, vengeance upon him; or punish him; for his evil deeds. (Har p. 371. [See HasiybN.]) [In the present day, AHtsb Ealayohi is used as meaning He prayed for aid against him by saying, HasobunaA QllRehu God is, or will be, sufficient for us.] ― -b6- You say also, AHtsb fulaAnFA, (K,) or AHtsb maA Einodahu, (A,) meaning (tropical:) He endeavoured to learn what such a one had [in his mind, or in his possession]. (A, K, * TA.) ― -b7- See also 4.

9 AHsbR AHsb OHsb Hsb
9. AHsbR He (a camel) was, or became, of a white colour intermixed with red (S, TA) and with black. (TA.)

HasobN Hsb
HasobN Sufficiency. (K voce hasobN.) ― -b2- Hasobu is a [prefixed] noun (S) [syn. with kafoIu, as is implied in the K voce qaTo; or] syn. with kaAfiI; (Msb;) or [virtually] meaning kafaI [as a pret. in the sense of an emphatic aor.]; (S, K;) or yakofiI: (TA:) Sb says that it is used to denote the being sufficed, or content. (TA.) You say, Hasobuka dirohamN [and biHasobika dirohamN, in which latter the b is redundant; meaning Thy sufficiency, or a thing sufficing thee, is a dirhem; a phrase which may be used in two ways; as predicating of what is sufficient, that it is a dirhem; and as predicating of a dirhem, that it is sufficient; in which latter case, bHsbk is an enunciative put before its inchoative, (as also Hasobuka,) so that the meaning is, a dirhem is a thing sufficing thee, i. e. a dirhem is sufficient for thee; as is shown in a marginal note in my copy of the Mughnee, in art. bi; or, accord. to the S and K, a dirhem suffices thee: accord. to Bd (iii. 167), bHsbk means muHosibuka, and kaAfiyka, from OaHosabahu meaning kafaAhu; and is shown to have this meaning by its not importing a determinate signification in consequence of its being a prefixed noun with its complement in the saying, hecaA rajulN Hasobuka This is a man sufficing thee]. (S, Msb, K.) You say also, Hasobuka celika That is, or will be, [or let that be,] sufficient for thee. (TA.) And Hasobuka QllRehu, in the Kur viii. 65, God is, or will be, sufficient for thee. (Fr, TA. See also Hasiybuka QllRehu.) And Hasobuka biSadiyqinaA [A person sufficing thee is our friend]; in which the b is added to denote emphatic praise. (Fr, TA in art. bi.) In the saying, hecaA rajulN Hasobuka mino rajulK This is a man sufficing thee as a man, i. e. supplying to thee the place of any other [by his excellent qualities], (S, K,) and mararotu birajulK Hasobika mino rajulK I passed by a man sufficing thee as a man, (TA,) Hsbk is an expression of praise, referring to the indeterminate noun [rjl]; because, in its case, [what is originally (see below)] an inf. n. (fiEolN [under which term lexicologists, but not grammarians, include the maSodar]) is rendered, in grammatical analysis, by another word, [i. e., by an act. part. n.,] as though one said muHosibN laka, or kaAfK laka. (S. [Thus Hsbk in these two instances is a Sifap, i. e. an epithetic phrase; and mn rjl is a tamoyiyz, i. e. a specificative phrase.]) When the noun to which Hsbk refers is determinate, you put Hsb in the accus. case, as a HAl, i. e. a denotative of state; as in the saying, hecaA Eabodu QllRehi Hasobaka mino rajulK This is 'Abd-Allah; being one sufficing thee as a man. (S. [Here mn rjl is, as before, a specificative phrase.]) [See also 4, the corresponding verb.]) Hsb, in this manner, is used alike as sing. and dual and pl.; (S, K;) being [originally] an inf. n. (S.) It is also used alone, [as a prefixed noun of which the complement is understood,] as in the phrase zayodN Hasobu, without tenween, for HasobiI or Hasobuka [&c., meaning Zeyd is sufficient for me or for thee &c.]; like as one says, jaMCaniI zayodN layosa gayoru, for layosa gayoruhu EinodiI. (S. [That is, Hasobu, when thus used, is subject to the same rules as gayoru and qabolu, and baEodu &c. when so used.]) ― -b3- See also HasabN, in three places. ＝ -A2- Also, (TA,) and HisobapN↓, (K,) Burial of the dead: (TA:) or burial of the dead in stones [app. meaning in a grave cased with stones]: or burial of the dead wrapped in grave-clothes: like taHosiybN. (K. [See 2.])

HasabN Hsb
HasabN i. q. maHosuwbN↓; (S, K;) of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, like nafaDN in the sense of manofuwDN; (S;) Numbered, counted, reckoned, calculated, or computed. (S, K.) ― -b2- A number counted. (L.) ― -b3- Amount, quantity, or value. (L.) Sometimes, (S, L, K,) by poetic license, (S,) and in prose, (L,) HasobN↓. (S, L, K.) You say, AlOajoru biHasabi maA Eamilota, and biHasobi↓, The recompense is, or shall be, according to the amount, or quantity, or value, of thy work. (L.) And yujozaI AlmaroCu EalaI Hasabi Eamalihi The man is, or shall be, paid according to the amount, or quantity, of his work. (Msb.) And EalaI Hasabi maA Oasodayota UilaIRa XukoriI laka [and HasobamaA↓ (for EalaI Hasabi maA)] According to the amount, or value, of the benefit, or benefits, that thou hast conferred upon me are my thanks to thee. (L.) And liyakuno Eamaluka biHasabi celika Let thy deed, or work, be correspondent to the quantity, or number, of that: or adequate, or equivalent, to that. (S.) And hecaA biHasabi caA This is equal in number or quantity, or is equivalent, to that. (K.) And maA OadoriI maA Hasabu Hadiyvika, i. e. mA qadoruhu [app. I know not what is the value of thy story]. (Ks, S.) And OaHosanotu Uilayohi Hasaba AlTRaAqapi and EalaI Hasabi AlTRaAqapi I benefited him according to the measure of ability. (Mgh.) ― -b4- Also [Grounds of pretension to respect or honour, consisting in any qualities (either of oneself or of one's ancestors) which are enumerated, or recounted, as causes of glorying: and hence signifying nobility; rank or quality; honourableness, or estimableness, from whatever source derived:] originally, (MF,) what one enumerates, or recounts, of the deeds, or qualities, in which his ancestors have gloried: (S, A, Mgh, * K, MF:) secondly, what one enumerates, or recounts, of his own deeds, or qualities, in which he glories: thirdly, what one enumerates, or recounts, of any deeds, or qualities, that are causes of his glorying, of whatever kind they be: (MF:) or the memorable deeds, or qualities, of one's ancestors; and one's own deeds, or qualities, in which he glories; because they were enumerated, or recounted, by the Arabs in contending, or disputing, for glory; (T, Msb, * TA;) the latter consisting in such qualities as courage, and good disposition, and liberality: (Msb:) or what are enumerated, or recounted, of generous actions, or qualities: (Msb:) or good actions, or conduct, of oneself, and of one's ancestors: (Sh, Mgh:) or generosity, or nobility, of actions or conduct: (IAar, K:) or righteous, virtuous, or good, actions or conduct: (K:) or good disposition: (TA:) or religion; (S, Msb, K;) piety; because true nobility consists in religion or piety: (MF:) or wealth; (S, K;) because it serves in lieu of true nobility: (TA:) in this sense, and in the sense next preceding, it has no corresponding verb: (TA:) or state, or condition; [i. e. good state or condition;] syn. baAlN [i. q. HaAlN]: (K:) or intellect, or understanding: (MF:) and a man's relations, consisting of his children and others: pl. OaHosaAbN. (Az, Mgh.) Accord. to ISk, (S, Msb,) HasabN and karamN may pertain to him who has not noble ancestors; but not XarafN nor majodN. (S, Msb, * K.) HasabN is also used elliptically, (Mgh, TA,) [in the sense of HasiybN, q. v.,] for cuw HasabK, (TA,) and for cawuw HasabK. (Mgh.) ― -b5- AiXotaraI biAlHasabi He bought a thing in an honourable manner with respect to himself and the seller: Hsb, here, is said to be from HasRabahu “ he honoured him; ” or from HusobaAnapN “ a small pillow ” [because him for whom you put a pillow you honour: see 2]. (TA.)

HusobapN Hsb Hsbh Hsbp
HusobapN, in a camel, A colour in which are whiteness and redness (K, TA) and blackness: (TA:) in a man, [a reddish colour such as is termed] Xuqorap in the hair of the head: (K:) and also in a man, (K, TA,) and in a camel, (TA,) whiteness and redness produced by a whiteness of the skin arising from disease and infecting the hair [so as to turn it red]: (K, TA:) accord. to IAar, blackness inclining to redness. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Leprosy. (K.)

HisobapN Hsb Hsbh Hsbp
HisobapN [originally The act of numbering, counting, &c.: or a mode, or manner, of numbering, &c.: see 1. ― -b2- ] A subst. from AiHotasaba OajorFA; (S, Msb, K;) syn. with AiHotisaAbN (A) [as meaning A reckoning upon, or seeking, or preparing or providing, or laying up for oneself in store, a reward in the world to come]. You say, faEalahu HisobapF [He did it reckoning upon, or seeking, &c., a reward in the world to come]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- huwa Hasanu AlHisobapi He is good in respect of managing, conducting, ordering, or regulating, (S, A, Msb, K,) and examining, or judging, (Msb,) and sufficing, (A,) fiI AlOamori in the affair. (S, A, Msb.) This is not from AiHotisaAbu AlOajori; for AHtsAb AlAjr relates only to an action done for the sake of God. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- A reward, or recompense: pl. HisabN. (S, K.) ＝ -A3- [The office of the muHotasib.] ＝ -A4- See also HasobN, last sentence.

HusobaAnN HsbAn
HusobaAnN: see HisaAbN. ＝ -A2- Also A punishment. (S, K.) ― -b2- A calamity; an affliction with which
a man is tried. (Aboo-Ziyád, K.) ― -b3- Evil; mischief. (Aboo-Ziyád, K.) ― -b4- Locusts. (Aboo-Ziyád, S, K.) ― -b5- Dust: or smoke: syn. EajaAjN. (K.) ― -b6- Fire. (TA.) This, and each of the five significations next preceding, and that next following, have been assigned to the word as used in the Kur xviii. 38. (TA.) See also HusobaAnapN. ― -b7- Small arrows, (Mgh, Msb, K,) or short arrows, (S,) which are shot from Persian bows: (Mgh, Msb:) said by IDrd to be, in this sense, postclassical: (TA:) or arrows which a man shoots in the hollow of a reed, or cane; drawing the bow, he discharges twenty of them at once, and they pass by nothing without wounding it, whether it be an armed man or another object; they come forth like rain, and scatter among the people: (ISh, TA:) or small arrows, with slender heads, in the hollow of a reed, or cane, which, when discharged, come forth like a shower of rain, and scatter, and pass by nothing without wounding it: (Az, Msb:) or iron-headed arrows, like large needles, slender, but somewhat long, and without edges [to the heads]: (Th, TA:) n. un. with p. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ＝ -A3- It is also said to signify The circumference of a mill-stone: ― -b2- and hence, in the Kur lv. 4, [see 1, above,] to mean The [revolving] firmament. (El-Khafájee, MF.)

HasakN Hs Hsk
HasakN [is applied, app. in the classical language, as it is in the present day, to Various species of thistle, and other prickly plants: also to the heads of thistles and the like: and particularly to the caltrop, or tribulus: and hence the explanations here following:] the Hasak [or prickly heads] of the [plant called] saEodaAn: (S:) or a certain herb, (Aboo-Ziyád, Mgh, TA,) inclining to yellowness, (Aboo-Ziyád, TA,) having [a head of] prickles of rounded form: (Aboo-Ziyád, Mgh, TA:) seldom, or never, does any one walk upon it, when it has dried up, without putting upon his feet boots or sandals: and the ants transport its produce [or heads] to their nests: (Aboo-Ziyád, TA:) a certain plant, the produce [or head] whereof (which is rough [or prickly], TA) clings to the wool of sheep, (K,) and to the fur of camels, in their places of pasturing: (TA:) its leaves are like those of purslane (AlrRijolap), or narrower, and at its leaves are compact and hard prickles, having three forks: [hence it seems to be a species of three-horned caltrop: or for “ three, ” we should perhaps read four: (see another application of the word in what follows:)] the drinking [of an infusion] thereof has the effect of crumbling the stone of the kidneys and bladder; and the drinking of the expressed juice of its leaves is good for the venereal faculty, and for difficulty in the discharge of urine, and for the bite of vipers; and the sprinkling it in the dwelling kills fleas: (K:) also, accord. to Aboo-Nasr, the produce of the [plant called] nafal: (TA:) and sharp. hard prickles or thorns: (TA in art. msk:) n. un. with p: (S, Mgh:) which some hold to apply to any fruit, or produce, of a plant, that is of the kind termed EuqodapN [i. e. forming a compact and roundish head]; and hence, to the pod of the cotton-plant: and it also signifies a prickle, or thorn. (TA.) [Hence,] UinRahu laHasakapN↓ (tropical:) Verily he is rough. (A, TA.) And UinRahumo laHasakN OamoraAsN (assumed tropical:) Verily they are strong: and of one person you say marisN HasakapN↓. (TA.) And masakapN huwa HasakapN↓ (tropical:) He is courageous: (K and TA in art. msk:) and of a number of persons you say HasakN masakN. (TA in that art., q. v.) [See also HasikN.] ― -b2- See also HasiykapN ― -b3- Also [(assumed tropical:) Caltrops, as meaning] a kind of instrument used in war, (S, K,) made like the Hasak mentioned in the first sentence of this paragraph, (S,) or like the prickles of the Hasak, (K,) of iron, (S, K,) or of canes, (K,) and sometimes of wood, (TA,) and cast, (K,) or set up, (TA,) around the army, (K, TA,) in the ways of the horses. (TA.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; and enmity; (K, TA;) as also HasakapN↓, (K,) and HasiykapN↓ and HusaAkapN↓. (S, K. [The last in the CK written HasAkap; but expressly said in the TA to be with damm, and so written in copies of the S and K.]) You say, fiI Sadorihi EalaIRa HasiykapN↓ and HusaAkapN↓ [In his bosom is rancour, &c., against me]. , (Msb, K,) inf. n. HasomN, (Mgh, Msb,) He cut it; or cut it off: (S, Msb, K:) he cut it off entirely. , inf. n. HusuwmN, It caused them to pass away, come to an end, cease, perish, or come to nought. (Zj, TA.) See, again, HusuwmN, below. ＝ -A2- Hasama fiI AlEamali, (TK,) inf. n. HusuwmN, (Yoo, K,) He strove, laboured, toiled, or exerted himself, and wearied himself, in work. (Yoo, K, TK.)

HusuAmN A sword; because it cuts that upon which it comes: (Msb:) or a sharp sword; (S, K, TA;) and in the same sense applied to a [knife such as is termed] mudoyap: (TA:) and (so in the S, but in the K “ or ”) the edge of a sword, with which one strikes. HusuwmN Unluckiness, or inauspiciousness. (S, * K, * TA.) Some explain it thus in the passage here following. (S, * TA.) ― -b2- saxRarahaA Ealayohimo saboEa layaAli wa vamaAniyapa OayRaAmK HusuwmFA, in the Kur lxix. 7, means He sent it (the wind) upon them by force, (Jel,) or made it to prevail against them by his power, (Bd,) [seven nights and eight days] consecutively; (T, S, Bd, K, Jel;) an expression taken from the repetition of the act of cauterization, (T, Bd, Jel.) i. e. the act of the HaAsim↓; (Jel;) whence this word (HAsm) is applied to anything made consecutive; (T, TA;) and HusuwmN is its pl.: (T, Bd, TA:) or HusuwmN signifies the making consecutive. and, as an epithet, consecutive, and continuous from first to last: (Fr, TA:) or, accord. to some, AlOayRaAmu AlHusuwmN means the days that are consecutive with evil especially; and such ISd thinks to be the meaning: (TA:) or AllRayaAliI AlHusuwmu means the nights that cut off good, or prosperity, (taHRsimu↓ Alxayora,) from their people: (S, * K: [and the like is said by Bd in lxix. 7:]) or HusuwmFA in the Kur means causing them to pass away, come to an
end, cease, perish, or come to nought: (Zj, T:) or it may be an inf. n., meaning for the purpose of cutting off: or an inf. n. of a verb meant to be understood, as a denotative of state; i. e. taHosimuhumo↓ HusuwmFA [agreeably with the explanation of Zj]; and this is confirmed by the reading with fet-h [i. e. HasuwmFA, though this is a very rare form of inf. n.]: (Bd:) you say OayRaAmN HusuwmN, (K,) in which case the latter word is an inf. n. used as an epithet, meaning cutting off, or preventing, good, or prosperity; (TA;) and OayRaAmu HusuwmK, which has a similar meaning. (K, TA.)

HaAsimN; pl. HusuwmN: see this latter word.

maHosamapN A cause, or means, of cutting off, or stopping; (T, K, TA;) syn. maqoTaEapN. (T, TA.) And hence, (TA,) Ealayokumo biAlSRawomi faUinRahu maHosamapN liloEiroqi wa macohabapN liloOaXari, a trad., (T, S, TA,) meaning [Keep ye to fasting, for it is] a cause, or means, of stopping venereal intercourse, [and a cause, or means, of dispelling exultation, or excessive exultation, and resting the mind upon things agreeable with natural desire:] (TA:) or an impediment to venery, and a cause of diminishing the seminal fluid, and of stopping venereal intercourse or passion, &c. Hence the prov., walogu juraIRK kaAna maHosuwmFA [The lapping of a little puppy that had been badly fed]: said on the occasion of a greedy person's taking much of a thing that he had not been able to obtain, and that he had became able to obtain; or in ordering one to take much when able. 1. Hasuna, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) which may also be written and pronounced Hasona, with the dammeh suppressed, (S,) and Hasana, (K,) aor.
Hasuna
, (TA,) inf. n. HusonN (S, * Msb, K, * TA) and HusonaI, (Ham p. 657, and Bd in ii. 77,) He, or it (a thing, S, Msb), had, or possessed, the quality termed HasonN [which see below; i. e., was, or became, good, or goodly, (generally the latter,) beautiful, comely, or pleasing, &c.; and tHsRn↓ often signifies the same, as in the phrase tHsRn Einodahu it was, or became, good, &c., in his estimation]: (S, K, TA:) and [in like manner] zayodN OaHosana↓ means Zeyd became possessed of Huson. (Mughnee in art. bi.) ― -b2- One may not say Husona, transferring the dammeh of the s to the H and making the former letter quiescent, except in one case; because it is [virtually, together with its agent expressed or implied, in this case,] a predicate: [see I'Ak p. 234:] this is allowable only in the case of a verb of praise or dispraise; Husona, in respect of the transference of the medial vowel, being likened to niEoma and biYosa, which are originally naEima and baYisa: and thus one does in all verbs like these two in meaning: a poet says,
lamo yamonaEi AlnRaAsu minRiI maA Oaradotu wa maA
OuEoTiyhimu maA OaraAduwA Husona caA OadabaA
[Men have not withheld from me what I have desired, nor do I give them what they have desired: good, or very good, is this as a mode of conduct!]: meaning Hasuna hecaA OadabFA. (S, TA.) You say also, Hasuna zayodN, [meaning Good, or goodly, &c., or very good &c., is Zeyd! or] meaning bihi OaHosino↓ [i. e. how good, or goodly, &c., is Zeyd! as also maA OaHosanahu↓]. (B, TA in art. bi.)

(TA.) You say, AlHalRaAqu raOosahu OaHosana↓ The shaver beautified, or trimmed, his head. (TA.) And AlRaciI kulRa XaIoCK xalaqahu OaHosana↓ [Who hath made good, or goodly, everything that He hath created], in the Kur [xxxii. 6], means HasRana xaloqa kulRi XaIoCK [hath made good, or goodly, the creation of everything]. 4. AHsn as an intrans. v.: see 1. ― -b2- Also He did that which was Hasan [meaning good, comely, or pleasing; he acted well]; (Msb;) he did a good deed: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [for] UiHosaAnN is the contr. of UisaMCapN: (K:) it differs from UinoEaAmN in being to oneself and to another; whereas the latter is only to another: (TA:) and it surpasses EadolN, inasmuch as it means the giving more than one owes, and taking less than is owed to one; whereas the latter means the giving what one owes, and taking what is owed to one. (Er-Rághib, TA.) You say, OaHosanotu Uilayohi and bihi [I acted, or behaved, with goodness, well, or in a good or comely or pleasing manner, towards him; did good to him; benefited him; conferred a benefit, or benefits, upon him]: both signify the same: (S, TA:) and hence, in the Kur [xii. 101], qado OaHosana biI Uica OaxorajaniI mina AlsRijoni meaning UilaIRa [i. e. He hath acted well towards me, when he brought me forth from the prison]: (AHeyth, Az:) or, accord. to some, the verb in this case is made to import the meaning of laTafa [which is trans. by means of bi, i. e. He hath acted graciously with me]. (Mughnee in art. bi.) ― -b3- AlUiHosaAnu is also explained as meaning AlUixolaASu [i. e. The being sincere, or without hypocrisy; or the asserting oneself to be clear of believing in any beside God]; which is a condition of the soundness, or validity, of AlUiymaAn and AlUisolaAm together: and as denoting watchfulness, and good obedience: and as meaning the continuing in the right way, and following the way which those [of the righteous] who have gone before have trodden; this last being said to be the meaning in the Kur ix. 101. (TA.) ＝ -A2- As a trans. v.: see 2, in three places. ― -b2- AHsnhu also signifies (tropical:) He knew it: (S, K, TA:) [or] he knew it well; (Er-Rághib, Msb;) and so AHsn bihi, as in the saying, huwa yuHosinu biAlEarabiyRapi (assumed tropical:) He knows well the Arabic language. AlnRaAsu OabonaMCu maA yuHosinuwna is another saying of 'Alee, meaning (tropical:) Men are named, or reputed, in relation to what they know, and to the good deeds that they do. (TA.) ― -b3- OaHosino bihi and maA OaHosanahu: see 1, last sentence. You say also, maA OuHayosinahu↓ [i. e. How very good, or goodly, &c., is he!]; using the dim. form; like maA OumayoliHahu [q. v.]. (S and K in art. mlH.) ＝ -A3- Also He (a man, IAar) sat upon a high hill, or heap, of sand, such as is termed HasanN. (IAar, K.)

10. AstHsnhu He counted, accounted, reckoned, or esteemed, him, or it, Hasan [i. e. good, goodly, beautiful, comely, pleasing, &c.; he approved, thought well of, or liked, him, or it]; (S, K;) as also HsRnhu↓, inf. n. taHosiynN. Hence the saying, Sarofu hecaA QsotiHosaAnN wa AlmanoEu qiyaAsN [The making this word perfectly declinable is approvable, but the making it imperfectly declinable is agreeable with analogy]. (TA.)

HusonN Hsn Hsnn
HusonN (S, K, &c.) and HusunN↓, which is of the dial. of El-Hijáz, and HasanN↓, (MF, TA,) Goodness, or goodliness, [generally the latter,] beauty, comeliness, or pleasingness; contr. of quboHN: (S:) i. q. jamaAlN: (K:) but accord. to As, [when relating to the person,] HusonN is in the eyes, and jamaAlN is in the nose: (TA:) symmetry; or just proportion of the several parts of the person, one to another: (Kull:) or anything, moving the mind, that is desired, or wished for; such as is approved by the intellect; and such as is approved by natural desire; and such as is approved by the faculty of sense: in the common conventional language, mostly applied to what is approved by the sight: in the Kur, mostly to what is approved by mental perception: it is in accidents as well as in substances: (Er-Rághib, TA:) the pl. is maHaAsinu↓, (S, K,) like malaAmiHu pl. of lamoHapN, and maXaAbihu pl. of XabahN, &c., (Har p. 9,) contr. to rule, (S, K,) as though pl. of maHosanN↓ or muHosanN↓: (S accord. to different copies:) or, accord. to Lh
and Eth-Tha'álibee, maHaAsinu has no proper sing. (TA.) wa quwluwA lilnRaAsi HusonFA, in the Kur [ii. 77], means And say ye to men a saying having in it goodness (qawolFA caA HusonK): or HusonFA may mean HasanFA: (Zj, TA:) and some read here HasanFA: and some, HusunFA, accord. to the dial. of El-Hijáz: and some, HusonaI↓, as an inf. n., like buXoraI: (Bd:) but AHát and Zj disallow this; the former saying that HusonaI is like fuEolaI [as fem. of OafoEalu denoting the comparative and superlative degrees], and therefore should have the article Al. (TA.) wa waSRayonaA AlUinosaAna biwaAlidayohi HusonFA, in the Kur [xxix. 7], means [in like manner] And we have enjoined man to do to his two parents what is good (maA yaHosunu HusonFA): (TA:) and here [also] some read HasanFA; and some, UiHosaAnFA. (Bd.) [See another ex. of a similar kind, from the Kur xviii. 85, voce UimRaA, near the beginning of the paragraph.] ― -b2- sitRu AlHusoni [The convolvulus caïricus of Linn.; abundant in the gardens of Cairo;] a certain plant that twines about trees and has a beautiful flower. (TA.) ― -b3- See also HasanN.

HasanN Hsn Hsnn
HasanN Having, or possessing, the quality termed HusonN [which see above; good, or goodly, (generally the latter,) beautiful, comely, pleasing or pleasant, &c.]; (Msb, K, TA;) either intrinsically, as when applied to belief in God and in his attributes; or extrinsically, as when applied to war against unbelievers, for this is not good in itself: said to be the only epithet of its measure except baTalN: (TA:) and HasiynN↓ signifies the same, (IB, K,) because from Hasuna, like EaZiymN and karyimN from EaZuma and karuma, (IB, TA,) and HusaAnN↓, (K,) but this is an intensive epithet, [signifying very good or goodly &c.,] (IB, TA,) and HusRaAnN↓, (K,) also an intensive epithet, (S, IB,) and HaAsinN↓, (K,) [properly signifying being, or becoming, good or goodly &c.,] cited by Lh as used in a future sense, (TA,) and muHasRanN↓ as applied to a face: (K:) the fem. is HasanapN, and HasonaMCu↓, applied to a woman, (S, Msb, K,) though the corresponding masc. of this latter, namely, OaHosanu↓, is [said to be] not used (S, K) as applied to a man [in the sense of HasanN], (S,) [but the phrase huwa OaHosanuhumo wajohFA as meaning Hasanuhumo wajohFA is mentioned in the S in art. byD, (see bayaADN, and see also the pl. OaHaAsinu in what here follows,)] and HusRaAnapN↓: (S, K:) the pl. masc. is HisaAnN, (Msb, K,) pl. of HasanN used as an epithet; but when HasanN is used as a [proper] name, its pl. is Hasanuwna; (Msb;) and HisaAnN may also be pl. of HasiynN; (TA;) and HusRaAnuwna, (Sb, K,) pl. of HusRaAnN↓, which has no broken pl.: (Sb:) and OaHaAsinu Alqawomi means HisaAnuhumo [the good, or goodly, &c., of the party, or company of men]: (K:) the pl. fem. is HisaAnN, (K,) like the masc., pl. of HasonaMCu, and the only instance of its kind except EijaAfN, pl. of EajofaMCu. (TA.) You say rajulN HasanN basanN [A man very good or goodly &c.], using bsn as an imitative sequent [for the purpose of corroboration]. (S.) ― -b2- [HadiyvN HasanN A tradition of good authority; generally applied to one transmitted in the first instance by two or more relaters. ― -b3- Also meaning Good, comely, goodhumoured, pleasing, or pleasant, discourse or talk.] ― -b4- AlHasanu The bone that is next to the elbow; as also AlHusonu↓: (K:) or the extremity of the bone of the upper half of the arm next the shoulder-joint, because of the abundance of flesh that is upon it; the extremity of that bone next the elbow being called AlqabiyHu: (TA in art. qbH:) or the upper part of that bone; the lower part thereof being called AlqbyH. (Fr, TA in that art.) ― -b5- A kind of tree, of beautiful appearance, (K, TA,) also called the OalMC, that grows in rows upon a hill, or heap, (kaviyb,) of sand; so called because of its beauty; whence the kvyb is called naqaA AlHasani: thus described by Az, on the authority of 'Alee Ibn-Hamzeh. (TA.) ― -b6- [And hence, perhaps,] HasanN signifies also A high kaviyb [or hill, or heap, of sand]: (IAar, K:) whence it is used as a [proper] name of a boy. (IAar, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also HusonN, first sentence.

(S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also, [used as a subst., or as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, A good act or action;] an act of obedience [to God; often particularly applied to an alms-deed]: (Ksh and Bd in iv. 80:) and the reward [of a good action]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) a good, benefit, benefaction, boon, or blessing: (Ksh and Bd ibid.:) contr. of sayRiYapN [in all these senses]: (S, K:) as contr. of this latter word, it signifies any rejoicing, or gladdening, good or benefit &c. that betides a man in his soul and his body and his circumstances: (Er-Rághib, TA:) pl. OaHosanu c
OaHosanu, fem. HasonaMCu, pl. OaHaAsinu: see HasanN. ― -b2- AlOaHosanu denotes the comparative and superlative degrees [of HusonN]; as in the phrase huwa AlOaHosanu [He, or it, is the better, and best; or the more, and most, goodly or beautiful or comely &c.]: (K:) AlHusonaI↓ is the fem.; as in the phrase AlOasomaMCu AlHusonaI The best names; those of God; which are ninety and nine: (Jel in vii. 179:) it signifies the contr. of AlsRuwoCaI: (S, K:) the pl. of AlOaHosanu is AlOaHaAsinu. (K.) In the saying, in the Kur [vi. 153 and xvii. 36], wa laA taqorabuwA maAla Alyatiymi UilRaA biAlRatiI hiIa OaHosanu [And approach ye not the property of the orphan, to make use of it,] except by that act which is best to be done with it, the meaning is, such an act as the taking care of it, and increasing it: (Bd:) or, as some say, the meaning is, the taking, of his property, what will [suffice to] conceal those parts of one's person that should not be exposed, and stay one's hunger. (TA.) [The fem.] AlHusonaI↓ is applied to accidents only: not to substances. (Er-Rághib, TA.) It means also, [as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates, That which is better, and that which is best. And hence,] The good final or ultimate state or condition [appointed for the faithful]: (K:) so, it is said, in the Kur xli. 50. (TA.) And The view, or vision, of God; (K;) accord. to some: but it is said that in the Kur x. 27, it means Paradise; and ziyaAdapN, which there follows it, means the view, or vision, of the face of God. (TA.) And Victory: and martyrdom: (Th, K:) whence, [in the Kur ix. 52,] UiHodaI AlHusonayayoni [one of the two best things]; (K;) victory or martyrdom. (Ksh, Bd, Jel.) And The saying laA UilaAha UilRaA QllRehu. (Jel in xcii. 6 and 9.) The pl. of AlHusonaI↓ is AlHusonayaAtu and AlHusanu↓, (K, [the latter like rujaEN pl. of rujoEaI, but misunderstood by Freytag as syn. with AlmaHaAsinu, which next follows it in the K,]) neither of which is used without the article Al. (TA.) You say, fulaAnapu kaviyrapu AlmaHaAsini Such a woman has many beautiful places [or parts] of the body. (TA.) And maHaAsinu Alwajohi wa masaAwiyhi [The beauties of the face, and its defects]: (K in art. lmH:) [for] maHaAsinu signifies the contr. of masaAwK. 1 HasaA Hs HsA
1. HasaA, (S, Msb, K,) aor. yaHosuw, (Msb,) inf. n. HasowN, (S, Msb,) and some say that HasowapN also is an inf. n., (Msb,) [but this is properly an inf. n. of un.,] He (a man) supped, or sipped, or drank by little and little, (K,) soup, or broth, (S, K,) or sawiyq, and the like; (Msb;) as also AHtsI↓ (S, K) and tHsRI↓, (K,) or the last means, in a leisurely manner. (Sb, S.) You say also, Hasawotu HasowapF waAHidapF [I supped, or sipped, one sup, or sip]. (S.) And Hasawotu as meaning I drank [or supped or sipped] what is termed HasuwC and HasaMC. (ISk, TA.) [Hence,] kaOosa AlmanaAyaA AiHotasawoA↓ (assumed tropical:) [They sipped the cup of death; lit, deaths]: and AiHotasawoA↓ OanofaAsa AlnRawomi (assumed tropical:) [They sipped the draughts of sleep; meaning they took naps]. (TA.) ― -b2- One says also of a bird, HasaA AlmaMCa, (Msb, K,) aor. as above, (Msb,) inf. n. HasowN, (Msb, K,) like as one says of a man, Xariba; (TA;) [He sipped the water:] one should not say, in this case, Xariba. (Msb, K.) Hence the prov., (Msb,) nawomN kaHasowi AlTRayori [A sleeping like the sipping of the bird] i. e., of short duration; (S, M, Msb, TA;) likened, in its quick ending, to a bird's swallowing water: (Msb:) in the copies of the K, yawomN [a day]; and so in [some copies of] the S, and in the A. (TA.) And the saying, nimotu nawomapF kaHasowi AlTRayori I slept [a sleep like the sipping of the bird; meaning,] a short sleep. (T, Msb. *)

AlHusaI limivolihaA kunotu OuHasRiyka↓
[For the like thereof I used to give thee the mouthfuls of soup to sup, or sip;] meaning (assumed tropical:) for the like of this case I used to act with goodness to thee. (A, TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 437; where we read OuHasRiyhaA.]

8: see 1, in three places. ― -b2- [Hence also,] AHtsI sayora Alfarasi, and Aljamali, and AlnRaAqapi, (assumed tropical:) He elicited, or exacted, the utmost pace, or power of going on, of the horse, and of the he-camel, and of the she-camel. (TA.)

HasowapN A single act of supping or sipping; (S, * K;) as also HusowapN↓; but the former is the more chaste: (K:) some say that these are dial. vars., like nagobapN and nugobapN, and jaroEapN and juroEapN: but accord. to Yoo, the former denotes the act, and the latter is the [proper] subst. (TA.) See also what next follows.

HusowapN Hs HsA Hsw Hswh Hswp
HusowapN A sup, or sip; i. e. a small quantity of what is supped, or sipped: (K:) or as much as is supped, or sipped, (yuHosaI,) at once: (S:) or a mouthful of what is supped, or sipped; and some say that HasowapN↓ is a dial. var.; but others, that this is an inf. n. [of un.]: (Msb:) pl. HusFI [for an ex. of which see 4] (Msb, TA) and HusowaAtN or HusawaAtN or HusuwaAtN (Msb) and [of pauc.] OaHosiyapN and OaHosiwapN [in some copies of the K, erroneously, OaHosuwapN], and pl. pl. OaHaAsiI [or rather OaHaAsK], (K,) which ISd thinks to be rather a pl. of HasaMCN↓, contr. to rule. (TA.) You say, fiI AlUinaMCi HusowapN [In the vessel is a sup, or sip]. (S, Msb.) See also HasowapN.

HasaMCN HsMC
HasaMCN A well-known kind of food; (S;) soup; i. e. what is supped, or sipped; (K;) thin cooked food, (Sh, IAth, Msb,) that is supped, or sipped, (IAth, Msb,) such as is prepared for one who has a complaint of his chest, (Sh,) made of flour and water and oil or grease, and sometimes sweetened: (IAth:) also called HasuwRN↓ (Sh, S, Msb, K) and HasiyRapN↓ (Sh, K) and ↓and HasowN↓; (K;) the last two, the latter of which is like the inf. n., mentioned by IAar, but regarded by ISd as of doubtful authority. (TA.) See also HusowapN.

HasuwRN Hsw
HasuwRN: see what next precedes. ― -b2- Also One who sups, or sips, much: (S, K:) an epithet applied to a man. (S.)

HasiyRapN Hsy Hsyh Hsyp
HasiyRapN: see HasaMCN.

HaAsK HAs

maHosFI [The mouth; lit. the place of supping, or sipping]. One says of him who is short, huwa qariybu AlmaHosaI mina AlmafosaI [He has the mouth near to the anus]. (TA.)

And HasiIa maA fiI nafosihi He knew what was in his mind; as also AHtsAhu↓. (K.) One says also, mino hali QHotasayota↓ fulaAnK XayoYFA, meaning Hast thou found, or discovered, [or learned,] anything from such a one? (Az, TA.)

4: see 1.

8. AHtsI He dug out the sand from a HisoI to procure the water beneath: (S:) he dug out the earth for the water to come forth: (TA:) and AHtsI HisoyFA (T, K) he fetched out, by digging, the water of a HisoI; so as heard by Az from more than one of Benoo-Temeem: (TA:) or he dug a HisoI; as also HasaAhu↓. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) He asked, or sought, information, news, or tidings. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 1, in two places.

HasoIN: see what next follows.

HisoIN Hs HsI Hsy
HisoIN (T, S, K) and HisFI↓ (Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà, AAF, K) and HasoIN↓, accord. to the K, but this is unknown, and the correct word is HasFA, [or rather HasFI↓,] mentioned by IAar, (TA,) Water which the earth imbibes from sand [above it], and which, when it reaches what is hard, is arrested thereby: one digs out the sand from over it, and draws it forth: (S:) or accumulated sand, beneath which is hard rock, so that, when the sand is rained upon, it imbibes the water of the rain, which, reaching the rock beneath, is arrested thereby, and the sand prevents the heat of the sun from drying up the water; wherefore, when the heat is vehement, the upper portion of the sand is dug out from over the water, and it wells
forth, cold and sweet, and is taken by little and little: (Az, TA:) or soft, or plain, ground, in which water remains and collects: or rugged ground, over which is sand, that collects the rainwater; so that whenever a bucketful is drawn forth, another collects: (K, TA:) so in the M: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaHosaMCN (S, K) and [of mult.] HisaMCN: (K:) OaHosaMCN is syn. with kiraArN. (S.) [See also HaXorajN.] ― -b2- HisoIN also signifies A small quantity of water; and so HasaMCN↓. (Th, TA.)

HasFI: see HisoIN.
