HasaMCN HsMC
HasaMCN: see HisoIN.

1 HaXRa c
1. HaXRa, (Msb, K,) aor.
HaXuXa
, [contr. to general rule in the case of an intrans. v. of this class, unless the sec. pers. of the pret. be HaXuXota, which seems to be not improbable,] inf. n. HaXRN, (Msb,) It (a plant, or herbage, Msb, or a shoot of a palm-tree cut off from the mother-tree, or plucked forth from the ground, and planted, K) dried, or dried up. (Msb, K.) [Accord. to my copy of the Msb, the same is said of a well; but I incline to think that biYor is here written by mistake for tibon (meaning straw) or some similar word.] You say also, HaXRa Alwalad, (IAar, S, A, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) or inf. n. HuXuwXN, (IAar,) and, as some say, HuXRa; (A'Obeyd, S;) and AstHXR↓; (TA;) The child, or young one, (S, A, K,) of a she-camel, (IAar,) dried up in the belly, (S, A, K,) or womb, (TA,) the time of the birth having been exceeded. (TA.) And HaXRati Alyadu, (A, K,) and HuXRat, (Yoo,) and AHXRv↓, (S, K,) and AstHXRt↓, (Yoo, K,) The arm, or hand, dried up; (S, A;) and became unsound in its veins or ducts, and so rendered motionless; syn. XulRat: (S, K:) or, as some say, became slender and small. (TA.) ＝ -A2- HaXRahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
HaXuXa
, [in this case agreeable with general rule,] inf. n. HaXRN, (Msb, TA,) He cut it, namely, HaXiyX [or dry herbage]: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) and he collected it; as also AHtXRhu↓: (TA:) or the former has the former signification [only]; and ↓the latter signifies he sought it, and collected it. (S, K, TA.) You say also, HaXRa libaEiyrihi He collected dry herbage (HaXiyX) for his camel. (TA in art. bql.) And HaXRa EalaI daAbRatihi He cut dry herbage (HXyX) for his beast. (TA.) And HaXRa EalaI ganamihi He beat the branches of the trees so that its leaves became scattered [for, or upon, his sheep or goats]; like haXRa. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (S, K,) aor. as above, (S, A, K,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) He threw to him (namely a horse) HaXiyX [or dry herbage]; (S, K;) he fed him therewith. (A, TA.) Az says, I have heard the Arabs say to a man HuXRa farasaka [Feed thou thy horse with dry herbage]. (TA.) Hence the prov., OaHuXRuka wa taruwvuniI [I feed thee with dry herbage and thou dungest upon me]: (S, A, K:) and if it were said with s [OaHusRuka, “ I carry thee, ”] it would not be strange: (S:) applied to him who does evil to one who does good to him: (Az, K:) or to any one to whom a benefit has been done and who requites it with the contrary thereof, or is not grateful for it nor profits by it: and thus the prov. is related in the T and S and M and A [and K]; but by 'Abd-es-Selám El-Basree, OaHuXRaki wa taruwviynaniI. (TA.) ― -b3- Hence, (A,) HaXRa AlnRaAra, (S, A, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S,) and Az adds biAloHaTabi, (TA,) (tropical:) He kindled the fire; or made it to burn, or to burn fiercely; (S, A, K;) and fed it with firewood, like as one feeds a beast with HaXiyX: (A, TA:) or he collected to it what was scattered of the firewood: (TA:) and he stirred it. (K.) ― -b4- And HaXRa AlHaroba, aor. and inf. n. as above, (tropical:) He kindled, and excited, or provoked, war, or the war. (TA.) ― -b5- And HaXRa fulaAnFA (tropical:) He improved, or made good, the condition, (A, K,) or property, (O,) of such a one. (A, O, K.) ― -b6- And HaXRa maAlahu (tropical:) He multiplied his property, or made it to be much, (A, K, *) by [adding to it] the property of another: (A:) or HaXRa bihi maAlFA he put property into, or among, his property: (Skr:) or he strengthened him with property. (El-Báhilee.) ― -b7- And HaXRa sahomahu, (S, A, O,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He feathered his arrow: (A, O:) or stuck the feathers upon the sides of his arrow: (S:) or mounted them upon his arrow. (TA.)

4 AHXR c
4. AHXR It (herbage) became in such a state that it might be cut (ISh, K) and gathered, (TA,) being dried up. (ISh.) ― -b2- OaHaXRati Alyadu: see HaXRat. ― -b3- Also AHXRt She (a woman, S and K, and a camel, TA) had her child, or young one, dried up in her belly. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- OaHaXRa QllRehu yadahu [May God make his arm, or hand, to dry up; or to become unsound in its veins or ducts, and so rendered motionless;] is a form of imprecation used by the Arabs. (TA.) ― -b2- AHXR fulaAnFA He cut (K) and collected (TA) HaXiyX [or dry herbage] with such a one; (K;) as though he helped him in doing so. (TA.)

8 AHtXRhu c
8. AHtXRhu: see HaXRahu, in two places.

10 AstHXR Alwaladu c
10. AstHXR Alwaladu; and AstHXRt Alyadu: see HaXRa; and HaXRat.

HaXRN c
HaXRN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and HuXRN↓, (S, Msb, K,) but the former is the more common, (Msb,) and HiXRN↓, (K,) A garden: (El-Fárábee, S, Mgh, Msb, K: *) or a garden of palm-trees: (AHát, Msb:) pl. HiXRaAnN (S, Msb) and HuXRaAnN. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, (tropical:) A privy; (El- Fárábee, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) likewise called bayotu AlHaXRi or AlHuXRi↓: (Msb:) because they used to ease themselves in the gardens: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) then, when they made privies, they applied thus this appellation: (Msb:) and in like manner, maHaXRN↓; but accord. to the Abridgment of the 'Eyn., this is proper, not tropical: (Msb:) or this last, also written miHaXRN↓, signifies the same; (TA;) or a place in which human ordure has become collected: (K:) the pl. of HXR as applied to a privy is HuXuwXN (S, Mgh, K) and HuXRuwna. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ＝ -A2- See also maHaXRapN.

HuXRN c
HuXRN: see HaXRN, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see HaXiyXN.

HiXRN c
HiXRN: see HaXRN.

HuXaAXN c
HuXaAXN: see maHaXRN: ＝ -A2- and see HuXaAXapN.

HiXaAXN c
HiXaAXN: see maHaXRN.

HaXuwXN janiynuhaA c
HaXuwXN janiynuhaA [Having her fœtus dried up in her womb]. (L from a verse of Ibn-Mukbil.)

HaXiyXN c
HaXiyXN Dry herbage; (Msb;) dry pasture, or fodder: (El-Fárábee, S, Mgh, Msb, K:) of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure faAEilN: (Msb:) what is fresh is not so called: (S, Msb:) but EuXobN is applied to what is fresh and what is dry: this, says ISd, is the opinion of the generality of the lexicologists: some [he adds] assert that HXyX is green pasture or herbage, as well as dry: but he says that this is not correct; [and the like is said in the Msb;] for this word is properly applied to denote dryness and contraction: ISh says that it is applied to all herbs, or leguminous plants, fresh as well as dry; as also EalafN and xalFI: Az says that when they use it unrestricted, the Arabs mean thereby HaliIR, [which is the herb called naSiIR when it has become dry and white,] in particular; and that this is the best kind of fodder; that horses thrive upon it, and it is one of the best pastures for camels, or for camels and sheep and goats; a good supply in years of scarcity: (TA:) or it signifies cut herbage or pasture; and is of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (Msb:) the n. un. is with p, signifying a fascicle, or wisp, of HaXyX: (TA:) [and sometimes a herb of any kind: the pl. is HaXaAYiXu.] ― -b2- [It is also applied, in the present day, to Hemp, used for its intoxicating property; both fresh and dry: app. what is termed HaXiyXu AlHaraAfiyXi in the K, voce banojN, q. v.: and also termed HaXiyXapN AlfaqaraMCi: see De Sacy's “ Chrest. Arabe, ”, see. ed., vol. i. pp. 210-283. ― -b3- HaXiyXapu AlsRuloTaAni: see xarodalN.] ― -b4- HaXiyXN also signifies A child, or young one, that has dried up in the belly of its mother; (Mgh, Msb, TA;) and so HaXRN↓ and maHoXuwXN↓ and OuHoXuwXN↓: (TA:) or HuXRN [and the rest], a child, or young one, that perishes in the belly of its mother. (K.) It is said in a trad., faOaloqato HXiyXFA And she cast forth a child, or young one, dried up. (Mgh.) And you say, Oaloqato waladahaA HaXiyXFA She (a camel) cast forth her young one dried up. (Msb.)

HuXaAXapN c
HuXaAXapN The [last] remains of the spirit (S, A, * Msb, K) in the heart, (TA,) [or of life;] in a sick man, (S, Msb, K,) and in one who is wounded; (K;) as also HuXaAXN↓, (S, Msb, K,) the p being sometimes elided. (Msb.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Any remains, or relic. (TA.) You say, maA baqiIa mina AlmuruwoCapi UilRaA HuXaAXapN tataradRadu fiI OaHoXaMCi muHotaDarK (tropical:) [There remained not, of manliness, save a last relic going to and fro, or wavering, in the entrails of one at the
point of death]. (A, TA.) And maA baqiIa mina AlXRamosi UilRaA HuXaAXapN naAziEN (tropical:) [There remained not, of the sun, save a last departing relic]. (A, TA.)

HaXaAYiXiIRN c
[HaXaAYiXiIRN One skilled in the knowledge of herbs: so in modern works. ― -b2- Accord. to Golius, as on the authority of the KL, but not in my copy of that work, A collector of hay; a forager.]

HuXRaAXN c
HuXRaAXN, [pl. of HaAXRN↓,] Cutters, or cutters and collectors, of HaXiyX [or dry herbage]: (TA:) or seekers and collectors thereof. (S) ＝ -A2- See also miHaXRN.

HaAXRN c
HaAXRN: see its pl. HuXRaAXN.

OuHoXuwXN c
OuHoXuwXN: see HaXiyXN, last signification.

maHaXRN c
maHaXRN, (S, A, TA,) or miHaXRN↓, (K, [but this seems to be a mistake occasioned by the accidental omission of waAlmaHaXRu, as is indicated by the addition of wayukosaru shortly after, referring to the word in a sense different from that which is here next mentioned,] A place, (S,) or land, (K,) in which is much HaXiyX [or dry herbage]; (S, K) as also maHaXRapN↓: (K:) or a place in which one cuts HXyX: (A:) and the first (maHaXRN) a place in which are much pasture, or herbage, and wealth, or good things. (K.) You say, hecaA maHaXRu SidoqK, meaning This is a [good] region abounding in HaXiyX. (TA.) And UinRaka bimaHaXRi SidoqK falaA taboraHohu Verily thou art in a place abounding in good things, therefore do not quit it: so in some copies of the S; and accord. to this explanation, the word is tropically used: in other copies of the S, in a place abounding in HaXiyX. (TA.) ― -b2- See also HaXRN. ― -b3- Also the former, A thing in which HaXiyX is put; and so miHaXRN↓; but the former is the more chaste; (A 'Obeyd, S, K;) and miHaXRapN↓, (K,) and maHaXRapN↓, which is more chaste; so in some copies of the K; (TA:) and HuXaAXN↓, like guraAbN; of which the pl. is OaHoXiXapN: (TA:) the first two of these words are applied to a woollen kisaMC [q. v.] in which HaXiyX is put: (IAth:) and HiXaAXN↓, with kesr, signifies a [sack of the kind called] juwaAliq in which is HaXiyX. (K.) ― -b4- See also miHaXRN.

muHiXRN c
muHiXRN A woman, (S, K,) and a she-camel, (TA,) whose child, or young one, dries up in her belly. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- An arm, or a hand, (yad,) drying up; or becoming unsound in its veins or ducts, and so rendered motionless: or becoming slender and small. (TA.)

miHaXRN c
miHaXRN An instrument with which HaXiyX [or dry herbage] is cut; (A 'Obeyd, S;) as also HuXRaAXN↓, like rumRaAnN: (TA:) or a plain [i. e. not serrated] minojal [or reaping-hook] with which HaXiyX is cut; as also maHaXRN↓; but the former is the more chaste; (K;) or, accord. to the L, the latter is the better. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also maHaXRN, in two places. ＝ -A3- Also An iron instrument with which a fire is stirred; and so miHaXRapN↓: (S, K:) pl. maHaAXRu. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence, (tropical:) A kindler, an exciter, or a provoker, of war: or] a courageous man. (K.) Of such one says, niEoma miHaXRu Alkatiybapi (tropical:) [Excellent is the exciter of the army, or troop]. (S, A.) And miHaXRu HarobK signifies (tropical:) A kindler and an exciter of war: (K, TA:) or a conductor of war. (Ham p. 14.) You say, humo maHaAXRu AlHuruwbi (tropical:) They are the kindlers and exciters of wars. (A.) ＝ -A4- See also HaXRN.

maHaXRapN c
maHaXRapN: see maHaXRN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also (tropical:) The podex: or anus: (S, Mgh, Msb, * K: *) and so HaXRN↓: (TA:) pl. of the former maHaAXRu; (S, Mgh, K;) and of the latter HuXuwXN: (TA:) the former also occurs written with s. (S, Mgh.)

miHaXRapN c
miHaXRapN: see maHaXRN: ＝ -A2- see also miHaXRN. ― -b2- Also A staff, or stick: or a rod, wand, or twig. (TA.)

maHoXuwXN c
maHoXuwXN: see HaXiyXN, last signification.

4 AHXbhu c
4. AHXbhu He angered him. (K.)

8 AHtXbwA c
8. AHtXbwA They collected themselves together; congregated. (El-Muarrij, K.)

HiXobN c
HiXobN: see what next follows.

HaXiybN c
HaXiybN A thick, coarse, or rough, garment or piece of cloth; (Aboo- Semeyda' El-Aarábee, K;) as also HiXiybN and HiXobN↓. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also HawoXabN.

HXybI c
HXybI: see what next follows.

HawoXabN c
HawoXabN The fetlock-joint (mawoSilu AlwaZiyfi) in the pastern (rusog) of a beast: (S, K:) or, (K,) as also HXyb↓ and HXybI↓, (so in the TA,) a bone in the inside of the hoof, between the tendons (EaSab) and the waZiyf [or shank; app. the lower pastern-bone]: (K:) or the contents (HaXow) of the hoof: (AA, TA:) or a small bone, like a sulaAmaI [or finger-bone, a description aptly applying to either of the pastern-bones, the upper of which seems to be here meant], at the extremity of the waZiyf, between the head thereof and the place where the hoof is set on, (As, S, K,) entering into the jubRap: (As, S: [see this last word (jbRp), to which various significations are assigned; here said in the TA to be that which contains the HwXb and daxiys (both of which words seem to be syn.), between, or amid, the flesh and the tendons:]) or the bone of the rusog [or pastern]: (T, K:) or a name applied to each of the two bones of the pastern (rsg) of a horse. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Lean, and lank in the belly. (K.) ― -b2- And Bigbellied: or big in the sides: (TA:) or swollen, or inflated, in the sides: (S, K:) or swollen in the belly, and short: (Skr p. 57: [see an ex. in a verse cited voce mujorK in art. jrw:]) bearing two contr. significations: (K:) fem. with p: (TA:) pl. HawaAXibu. (Skr, S.) ＝ -A3- The male hare: (K, * TA:) and [so in the K; but accord. to the TA, “ or ”] the calf. (K.) Also, accord. to the K, the “ male fox: ” but this is a mistake, occasioned by the occurrence of the words HawoXab and qaEonab together in a verse: the latter of these two signifies the “ male fox. ” (TA.) ＝ -A4- A company of men; as also HawoXabapN↓: (El-Muarrij, K: *) a large number of men collected together. (TA.)

HawoXabapN c
HawoXabapN: see what next precedes.

1 HaXada c
1. HaXada, aor.
HaXuda
(A, Msb, K) and
HaXida
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. HaXodN, (A, Msb, K,) He collected together (A, Msb, K) people, or a company of men. (A, Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] bitRu fiI layolapK taHoXudu EalaIRa Alhumuwma (tropical:) [I passed a night that brought anxieties crowding together upon me]. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- HaXaduwA, (S, A, Msb,) aor.
HaXida
, inf. n. HaXodN, (S,) or HuXuwdN; (A;) and AHtXdwA↓, and tHXRdwA↓; (S, A;) They collected themselves together, or assembled, (S, A, Msb,) and came round about (HafRuwA [but see what follows]) aiding one another: (A:) or HaXaduwA signifies they were prompt, or active, [instead of HafRuwA, in the K, I read xafRuwA, as in the L,] in aiding one another: or they complied quickly, when called, or summoned: (L, K:) the verb is thus generally used in relation to a collective number: seldom in relation to one: (L:) or they collected themselves together, or assembled, for one thing or affair; as also AHXdwA↓, and AHtXdwA↓, and tHAXdwA↓. (L, K.) And HXdwA Ealayohi, (L,) and Ealayohi tHAXdwA↓, They collected themselves together, aiding one another against him. (A.) And Alqawomu lifulaAnK AHtXd↓ The people, or party, collected themselves together to such a one, and prepared, equipped, or furnished, themselves [for action]. (TA.) ― -b2- HaXaduwA lahu They combined for him, [or on his account,] and took pains, or exerted themselves, in treating him with courtesy and honour; and so HafaluwA lahu. (Fr, L.) And They showed honour, and gave a hospitable entertainment, to him; namely, a guest. (L.)

4 OaHoXada
4: see 1.

5 taHaXRada
5: see 1.

6 taHaAoXada
6: see 1, in two places.

8 UiHotaXada
8: see 1, in three places. ― -b2- AHtXd lahu fiI kacaA He prepared himself for him [in such a case, or in such an affair]. (A.) ― -b3- AHtXd fiI AlDRiyaAfapi and lilDRiyaAfapi He strove, laboured, or exerted himself, in, and for, the entertainment of a guest or guests. (A.)

HaXodN c
HaXodN, (S, K,) originally an inf. n., (S,) and HaXadN↓, (K,) An assembly, or a collected or congregated body or party, (S, K,) of men. (S.)

HaXadN c
HaXadN: see what next precedes.

HaXidN c
HaXidN One who does not leave [unemployed] any endeavour or aid or property that he possesses; as also muHotaXidN↓; (L, K;) and HaAXidN↓, pl. HuXudN. (L.) ― -b2- waAdK HXidN A valley similar to land such as is termed HaXaAdN: (K:) a valley which a small and an inconsiderable quantity of water causes to flow. (TA.)

OaroDN HaXaAdN c
OaroDN HaXaAdN Land that does not flow with water save in consequence of much rain: (S:) or in
consequence of [lasting, or continuous, rain, such as is termed] diymap: (K:) or that flows with water in consequence of the least rain; (ISk, M, K;) as also zahaAdN and XaHaAHN and nazilapN: (ISk:) or such as is the quickest to flow with water: (AA in a marginal note in a copy of the S:) or HaXaAdN signifies a water-course of which the ground is hard, quickly flowing with water, having many minor water-courses (XiEaAb) pouring into its bed and uniting one with another. (ISh.)

HaAXidN c
HaAXidN [A people collecting themselves together, or assembling, &c. (see 1)]: pl. HuXRadN, occurring in a trad., followed by wufRadN. (L.) ― -b2- jaMCa fulaAnN HaAfilFA HaAXidFA and muHotafilFA muHotaXidFA↓ Such a one came [full of energy,] prepared, furnished, equipped, or accoutred. (S.) See also HaXidN.

maHoXuwdN c
maHoXuwdN A man with whom is an assembly, or a collected body, or party, of men: (L:) or one to whom others collect themselves together; who is served, or waited on: (A:) or obeyed by others, (S, K,) among his people, (TA,) and whom they are prompt [instead of yaHifRuwna, in most of the copies of the K, I read yaxifRuwna, as in others and in the S,] to serve, (S, K,) and to whom they collect themselves together. (TA.)

maHaAXidu c
maHaAXidu Places where people are collected to go forth: or it is a pl. of HaXodN, contr. to rule, like maXaAbihu [pl. of XabahN] and malAmiHu [pl. of lamoHapN]. (L from a trad.) [See maxaATibu.]

muHotaXidN c
muHotaXidN: see HaXidN, and HaAXidN.

1 HaXara c
1. HaXara, aor.
HaXura
and
HaXira
, (S, Msb, K,) the former of which aors. is found in the seven readings of the Kur, (Msb,) inf. n. HaXorN, (S, Msb, K,) He congregated, or collected together, (S, Msb, K,) men: (S, Msb:) or he congregated them, or collected them together, and drove them: (Msb, TA:) he made them to go forth, collected together, from one place to another: (Bd in lix. 2:) he, or it, compelled them to emigrate: (K, * TA: [in the CK AlxalaMCu is put by mistake for AljalaACu, the explanation of the inf. n.:]) and [simply] he drove towards a place or quarter. (TA.) Hence yawomu AlHaXori (tropical:) [The day of congregation, &c.; meaning] the day of resurrection: (S, * TA:) [see also maHoXirN:] and suwrapu AlHaXori (tropical:) [The Chapter of the Compulsion to emigration; which is the fifty-ninth chapter of the Kur-an]. (TA.) It is said by most of the expositors of the Kur that the wild animals and other beasts, and even the flies, will be collected together (tuHoXaru) for retaliation; and they cite a trad. on this subject. (TA.) So in the Kur [lxxxi. 5], wa UicaA AlwuHuwXu HuXirato And when the wild animals shall be collected together, (Bd, Jel,) from every quarter, (Bd,) after resurrection; (Jel;) or raised to life, (Bd,) for the purpose of their retaliating, one upon another; after which they shall return to dust: (Bd, Jel:) or the meaning is, shall die, (Az, S,) in the present world; accord. to some: (Az:) and thus says 'Ikrimeh, (S, TA,) on the authority of I'Ab, (TA,) as is related by Sa'eed Ibn-Masrook: (S, TA:) but accord. to some, the two meanings are nearly the same; for each denotes collection. (TA.) HaXorN also signifies The going forth with a people fleeing or hastening or dispersing themselves in war; when used absolutely. (TA.) ― -b2- HaXaratohumu AlsRanapu, aor.
HaXura
and
HaXira
(Lth,) inf. n. HaXorN, (K,) (tropical:) The year of dearth destroyed their camels and other quadrupeds; because it causes the owners to collect themselves from the various quarters to the cities or towns: (Lth:) or it caused them to go down to the cities or towns: (A:) or it distressed them; app., because of their collecting themselves together from the desert to the places of settled abodes: (Abu-t- Teiyib:) and HaXarati AlsRanapu maAla fulaAnK The year of dearth destroyed the camels &c. of such a one. (S, K. *) ＝ -A2- HaXarahu, (S, A,) inf. n. HaXorN, (S, K,) (tropical:) He made it (a spear-head, S, A) thin, or slender: (S, A, K:) he made it (a spear-head, and a knife,) sharp, or pointed, and thin, or slender: (TA:) he made it small, and thin, or slender: (Th:) he pared it; namely, a stick: (TA:) he pared it, and made it sharp, or pointed. (S.)

7 AnHXrwA c
7. AnHXrwA They (people) became collected together from the desert to the places of settled abodes. (Abu-t-Teiyib.)

HaXorN c
HaXorN (tropical:) Anything thin, or slender, or elegant. (TA.) You say Oucunu HaXorN (tropical:) A thin, or an elegant, ear; (Lth, ISk, S, A, K;) as though it were pared, (Lth, S,) and made sharp: (S:) or small, elegant, and round: (Lth:) or thin at the end: (Th:) or sharp-pointed: (TA:) and the epithet is the same for the dual also and the pl.: (K:) [J says that] it does not admit the dual form nor the pl., because it is originally an inf. n., and the expression above mentioned is like maMCN gaworN and maMCN sakobN: but Acn HaXorapN is sometimes said: (S:) and the pl. HuXuwrN occurs in a verse of Umeiyeh Ibn-Abee-'Áïdh: (TA:) and you also say Acn maHoXuwrapN↓. (TA.) HaXorN is also applied in the same sense as an epithet to other things. (S) You say qucRapN HaXorN (tropical:) A thin, or an elegant, feather of an arrow; (Lth, S, A, K;) as though it were pared: (Lth:) or sharp-pointed. (TA.) Also sinaAnN HaXorN (tropical:) A thin, or slender, spear-head: (S, K:) or sharp, or sharp-pointed: and sikRiynN HaXorN in like manner: and HarobapN HaXorapN: (TA:) and sahomN HaXorN, and sihaAmN HuXorN: like jawonN and juwnN, and warodN and wurodN: (Akh, S:) or sahomN HaXorN signifies an arrow having straight, or even, feathers; and so shm maHoXuwrN↓; and HaXirN↓, of the same measure as katifN, an arrow having good feathers attached to it. (TA.) You also say baEiyrN HaXoru AlOucuni (tropical:) A camel having a thin, or an elegant, ear. (TA.)

HaXirN c
HaXirN: see HaXorN.

HaXarapN c
HaXarapN and HaXaraAtN, (K,) each being a coll. n. without a sing.; (TA;) or the former is sing. of the latter; (S, Msb;) Any small animals that creep or walk upon the earth; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as jerboas and hedgehogs and lizards of the kind called DabR and the like: (TA:) or the former, (Msb,) or latter, (Mgh,) is applied to rats or mice, and jerboas, and lizards of the kind above mentioned, (Mgh, Msb,) colleted together: (Msb:) or any venomous or noxious reptiles or the like, such as scorpions and serpents; syn. hawaAmRu; (As, K;) as also OaHoraAXN and OaHonaAXN. (As.) ― -b2- Also the former, Whatever is captured, snared, entrapped, hunted, or chased, of wild animals or the like, birds, and fish, &c.; (K;) whether small or great: (TA:) or the great thereof: or what is eaten thereof: (K:) thus in all the copies of the K; but the pronoun [in the latter case] does not refer to the animals &c. above mentioned: it is expressly said in the T and M that the word signifies whatever is eaten of herbs, or leguminous plants, of the earth, such as the duEaAE and favR. (TA.)

HaAXirN c
HaAXirN One who congregates, or collects together, people. (TA.) With the article Al, applied to Mohammad; (S, K;) because he collects people after him (S, IAth) and to his religion. (IAth.) ― -b2- A collector of spoils: (El-Hulwánee, Mgh:) and [its pl.] HuXRaArN signifies collectors of the tithes and poll-tax. (TA.)

maHoXirN c
maHoXirN (S, K) and maHoXarN (K) A place of congregation: (S, K:) a term used when people are collected together to a town or country, and to an encampment, and the like. (TA.) Hence, yawomu AlmaHoXiri [The day of the place of congregation; meaning the day of judgment]. (TA.)

maHoXuwrN c
maHoXuwrN; and its fem., with p: see HaXorN.

Q. 1 HaXoraja c
Q. 1. HaXoraja, (TA,) inf. n. HaXorajapN, (S, K, TA,) He rattled in the throat, in dying: he made his breath, or spirit, (nafasahu, or nafosahu, accord. to different copies of the S and K,) to reciprocate: (S, K:) said also of the chest: or he made the sound of his breath to reciprocate in his throat, or fauces, without uttering it with his tongue. (TA.) Also said of an ass, He made his voice to reciprocate in his throat: (S, K, TA:) or uttered his voice from his chest. (TA.)

HaXorajN c
HaXorajN Water that is beneath the ground, unperceived, in the wide water-channels that contain small pebbles, and which, when one has dug to the depth of a cubit, gushes forth abundantly: waters of this description are called by the Arabs OaHosaMCN [pl. of HisoIN] and kiraArN [pl. of karRN] and HaXaAriju: and sweet water, of the water of a HisoI: (Az, TA:) or water that runs, clear and shallow, over pebbles, or over small pebbles: (TA:) what is termed HisoIN, among pebbles: (ISk, S, K:) or what is termed HisoIN, having pebbles in it: (K accord. to the TA:) or what resembles that which is termed HisoIN, in which waters collect: or a small, or round, hollow, or cavity, in a mountain, in which water becomes clear, (Az, K, TA,) after collecting: (Az, TA:) or water in a small, or round, hollow, or cavity, in a mountain. (A.) ― -b2- Soft foraminous stones (kacRaAn) of the ground: n. un. with p. (K.) ― -b3- A small, (A, TA,) or thin, (K,) and clean, (TA,) kuwz [or mug], (A, K, TA,) in which water is cooled, (A,) of the manufacture of El-Heereh. (K.) ― -b4- The cocoanut. (Kr, TA.)

HaXorajapN c
HaXorajapN inf. n. of HaXoraja [q. v.]. ― -b2- [The rattles;] the voice of a sick person reciprocated in the throat, or fauces. (A.)

1 HaXafa c
1. HaXafa, said of a she-camel's dug, Its milk became drawn up or withdrawn or withheld, or it went away, from it. (IDrd, L, TA. [See also 4 and 10.])

2 HXRf Eayonahu c
2. HXRf Eayonahu, inf. n. taHoXiyfN, He (a man, TA) contracted his eyelids, and looked through the interstices of their lashes. (IDrd, K.)

4 AHXf c
4. AHXf, said of a she-camel's udder, It became contracted, and like an old worn-out water-skin or milk-skin. (TA. [See also 1 and 10.]) ― -b2- AHXft AlnRaxolapu The palm-tree bore dates such as are termed HaXaf. (S, Mgh, Msb.)

5 tHXRf c
5. tHXRf He wore old and worn-out clothing, (O, L, KL, TA,) such as is termed HaXiyf: (O, L, TA:) in the copies of the K, erroneously, AstHXf↓. (TA.)

10 AstHXf c
10. AstHXf, said of an udder, (Jm, K,) It became contracted: (Jm:) or became dried up and contracted. (K. [See also 1 and 4.]) And AstHXft AlOucunu The ear became dried up (Mgh, Msb, K) and contracted. (K.) And AstHXf AlOanofu The cartilage of the nose became dried up from want of natural motion. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 5.

HaXofN c
HaXofN Dry bread. (K.)

HaXafN c
HaXafN The worst kind of dates; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) that dry up without ripening, so that they have no flesh: (Msb:) or dates without firmness, having no stones; (K;) like XiyS: (TA:) or dry, or tough, bad dates; (K;) for when they dry up, they become hard and bad, without taste and without sweetness: (TA:) or of which the lower portion has become bad and rotten, while in its place: (IAar, TA in art. xXw:) n. un. with p. (Msb.) [Hence,] OaHaXafFA wa suwoCa kiylapK, a prov., (S, Meyd, O,) meaning Dost thou combine the worst of dates and bad measure? applied to him who combines two bad qualities. (Meyd, O.) ― -b2- A worn-out udder; (S, K;) as also HaXifN↓: (K:) or an udder of which the milk has dried up, so that it has become contracted. (EM p. 67.) ― -b3- A thing that is lean, and dry, or withered. (KL.)

HaXifN c
HaXifN: see HaXafN. — tamorN HaXifN Dates having many such as are termed HaXaf. (TA.)

HaXafapN c
HaXafapN The head [or glans] of the penis: (TA:) or the part of the penis, (S, K,) [i. e.] the part of the head of the penis, (Mgh,) that is above [i. e. beyond] the place of circumcision: (S, Mgh, K:) [accord. to the latter explanation, somewhat more than the glans:] the mulct for the cutting off of which is the whole price of blood. (TA.)

HaXiyfN c
HaXiyfN Old, and worn-out: applied to clothing or a garment. (S, K, TA.)

naxolapN miHoXaAfN c
naxolapN miHoXaAfN [A palm-tree that bears dates such as are termed HaXaf]. (S and L voce miEoraArN.)

mutaHaXRifN c
mutaHaXRifN A man clad in old and worn-out clothing [such as is termed HaXiyf]: (S, TA:) a man in evil condition; slovenly in his person; threadbare, shabby, or mean, in the state of his apparel: or dried up, and shrivelled: or having his garment tucked up. (TA.)

1 HaXakati AldRirRapu c
1. HaXakati AldRirRapu, aor.
HaXika
, inf. n. HaXokN and HuXuwkN; for the former of which, HaXakN is used by poetic license: (S:) or HaXikat, aor.
HaXaka
, (TA,) inf. n. HaXakN (K, TA) and HuXuwkN: (TA:) The flow of milk became full: (S:) or became vehement in the udder: or collected quickly therein: (K, TA:) but accord. to Lth, HaXokN and HaXakN↓ are like nafoDN and nafaDN, and naqoDN and naqaDN; the former being an inf. n., and the latter a subst. [in the proper sense of the term, app. signifying milk collected, or collected quickly, in the udder]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] HaXakati AlsRaHaAbapu, (K,) aor.
HaXika
, inf. n. HaXokN, (TA,) (tropical:) The cloud had much water. (K, TA.) And HaXakati AlsRamaMCu, aor.
HaXika
, inf. n. HaXokN, (assumed tropical:) The sky let fall a rain such as is termed HaXokapN. (AZ, S.) And HaXaka AlwaAdiI, (assumed tropical:) The valley poured (dafaEa) with water. (TA.) ― -b3- And HaXakati AlnRaxolapu (tropical:) The palm-tree bore much fruit. (Yaakoob, S, K, TA.) ― -b4- And HaXaka Alqawomu, (S, K,) inf. n. HaXokN, or, accord. to Th, HaXakN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The people collected themselves together, or assembled. (Th, S, K.) ＝ -A2- HaXakato labanahaA, inf. n. HaXokN and HuXuwkN, She (a camel) collected her milk. (K.) ― -b2- HaXaka AlnRaAqapa, (S, K,) aor.
HaXika
, (K,) inf. n. HaXokN, (TA,) He left milking the she-camel until her milk collected (S, K, TA) in her udder. (TA.)

HaXakN c
HaXakN: see 1.

HaXakapN c
HaXakapN (assumed tropical:) A rain exceeding such as is termed bagoXapN; like HafoXapN and gaboyapN. (S).

jaAWuwA biHaXakatihimo c
jaAWuwA biHaXakatihimo, (K,) or, as in the Moheet, jaMCa fulaAnN biHaXakatihimo, (TA,) means (assumed tropical:) [They came, or such a one came,] with their company. (K, TA.)

HiXaAkN c
HiXaAkN, (IDrd, S, Sgh,) thus correctly written, like kitaAbN, but in [most of] the copies of the K like saHaAbN, (TA, [in the CK like saHaAbapN,]) A piece of wood which is put in the mouth of a kid, (S, K,) across, (S,) and tied (S, K) at the back of his neck, (S,) to prevent him from sucking: (S, K:) also called XibaAmN. (IDrd, S.)

HaXuwkN c
HaXuwkN A she-camel collecting milk in her udder (S, K) quickly. (S.)

HaAXikN c
HaAXikN [act. part. n. of HaXaka]. You say XaApN HaAXikapN A sheep, or goat, abounding with milk. (TA in art. ljb.) [And hence,] naxolapN HaAXikN (tropical:) A palm-tree bearing much fruit. (Yaakoob, S, K.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Consecutive, or uninterrupted. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.)

1 HaXima c
1. HaXima, aor.
HaXama
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. HaXamN, (Msb,) He was, or became, angry; (Msb, K;) as also AHtXm↓: (Msb:) or the latter signifies he became angered. (TA.) ― -b2- And He was, or became, confounded and stupified by shame; or ashamed and confounded or stupified, and remained speechless and motionless. (Msb.) See also 8. ＝ -A2- HaXamahu, aor.
HaXima
, inf. n. HaXomN; (Msb;) or HaXimahu, aor.
HaXama
; (K;) He angered him; (Msb, K;) as also AHXmhu↓, (IAar, S, Msb, K,) and HXRmhu↓. (K.) And, accord. to AZ (S) and El-Fárábee, (Msb,) HaXamahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
HaXima
and
HaXuma
, (K,) He annoyed him, (S, Msb, K,) and said to him what he disliked, (K,) and angered him; (S, Msb;) namely, a man sitting with him. (S, Msb, K.) An Arab of chaste speech is related to have said, baniI fulaAnK celika mimRaA yuHoXimu↓, meaning That is of the things that anger the sons of such a one. (S.) ― -b2- Accord. to IAar, (S,) HaXamahu signifies He caused him to become confounded and stupified by shame; or to become ashamed and confounded or stupified, and to remain speechless and motionless; (S, K;) as also AHXmhu↓: (S, Msb, K:) and both signify it caused him to be affected with shame, shyness, or bashfulness; or to shrink; as in the saying, to one shrinking from food, maA AlRaciI HaXamaka, or OaHoXamaka↓, What caused thee to be affected with shame, &c.? (TA.) ＝ -A3- HaXama, aor.
HaXima
, inf. n. HuXuwmN, He became fat, or in a good condition of body, after leanness. (K.) And HaXamati AldRaAbRapu fiI OawRali AlrRabiyEi, (K,) aor.
HaXima
, inf. n. HaXomN, (TA,) or HuXuwmN, (TK,) The beast obtained somewhat of the [herbage called] rbyE, in the beginning thereof, and became fat, and in good condition, and large in the belly, (K, TA,) and goodly: (TA:) or, as En-Nadr says, HaXamati AldRawaAbRu the beasts became in good condition. (S.) ― -b2- maA HaXama mino TaEaAminaA He ate not of our food (K, TA) aught. (TA.) ― -b3- maA HaXama AlSRayoda He hit not, or obtained not, or found not, the game, or object of the chase. (K.) ＝ -A4- HaXama, inf. n. HaXomN (TA) and HuXuwmN, (K,) He was, or became, fatigued, tired, or wearied. (K, TA.) The Arabs say, AlHusuwmu yuwrivu AlHuXuwma Labour, or toil, occasions fatigue. (Yoo, TA.)

2 HaXRama
2: see 1.

4 OaHoXama
4: see 1, in four places.

5 taHaXRama
5: see 8. ― -b2- You say also, huwa ytHaXRamu AlmaHaArima He guards against things forbidden. (TA.)

8 AHtXm c
8. AHtXm: see 1. ― -b2- Also He felt, or had a sense of, or was moved or affected with, shame, or shyness, or bashfulness. (Msb.) AHtXm minohu (S, Mgh, K) and Eanohu, (K,) and AHtXmhu, (S, Mgh,) or this last is not allowable except when mino is meant to be understood, (TA,) signify the same; (S, Mgh;) i. e. He was ashamed of it, or abashed at him; or was ashamed to do it, or shy of doing it: (Mgh, K:) or it signifies, (Mgh,) or signifies also, (K,) he shrank from it, or him: (Mgh, K:) or, as some say, thus used it is vulgar; for HiXomapN, with the Arabs, is only anger: (Mgh:) but IB cites, from Kutheiyir,
UinRiI mataI lamo yakuno EaTaAWuhumaA
EinodiI bimaA qado faEalotu OaHotaXimu
as meaning [Verily I, when the gift of them two
in my possession is not for what I have done,] am ashamed, or abashed: and in a trad. of 'Alee, respecting the thief, occurs the saying, UinRiI laOaHotaXimu Oano laA OadaEa lahu yadFA, meaning Verily I am ashamed not to leave him a hand; and I shrink from it. (TA.) [And HaXama↓ app. signifies the same; for,] accord. to As, (TA,) [the inf. n.] HuXuwmN signifies The act of shrinking. (K.) You say also, UinRiI minohu laOataHaXRamu↓ Verily I abstain from it, or refrain from it, to shun blame, or through disdain and pride; disdain, or scorn, it; (OatacamRamu minohu;) and am ashamed of it. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also He was, or became, master of many HaXam [or dependents &c.] and servants. (KL.)

HaXamN c
HaXamN A man's special dependents, consisting of his family and slaves [and others], or his neighbours, who are angry on his account (K, TA) when an event befalls him; (TA;) as also HuXomapN↓; (Yoo, TA;) in the K, erroneously, HaXamapN; (TA;) and OaHoXaAmN; (K;) which IAar thinks to be pl. of HaXamN used in a sing. sense; (TA;) [for] this word is applied to one [of such persons] as well as to a pl. number: (K:) you say, hecaA AlgulaAmu HaXamN liI [This young man, or slave, is a dependent of mine]: (IAar, TA:) or HaXamN signifies, (ISk, Mgh, Msb,) or signifies also, (K,) a man's relations and household; (ISk, Mgh, Msb, K;) or his servants; (S, Msb;) and those who are angry on his account (ISk, S, Mgh, Msb) when an event befalls him; (Mgh, Msb;) for which reason they are thus called: (S:) or a man's followers; and those on whose account he should be angry: (Ham p. 614:) or the HaXam of a man are those who are angry on his account; or those on whose account he is angry: (Har p. 164:) accord. to ISk, (Msb,) it is a word having a pl. signification, and having no proper sing.: (Mgh, Msb:) but some say that it has for its pl. OaHoXaAmN: (Mgh:) and accord. to the K, HuXamaMCu↓ [in the CK HaXomaAC] signifies neighbours and guests; as though it were pl. of HaXiymN, like as kuramaMCu is of kariymN: but [perhaps this should be OaHoXaAmN; for] we find in the M, heWulaMCi OaHoXaAmiI, meaning These are my neighbours, and my guests: (TA:) and HuXumN↓, with two dammehs, signifies slaves; (IAar, TA;) or, as some say, followers, whether slaves or free persons. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also An object of desire or quest; syn. TalabapN [in the CK Talabap]; and so HuXuwmN↓. (K.) You say, huwa HaXamuhu It is his object of desire or quest. (TK.)

HuXumN c
HuXumN Persons having, or possessing, (cawuw, as in the explanation of IAar, for which cuw is erroneously substituted in the copies of the K, TA,) consummate shame, shyness, bashfulness, or pudency. (IAar, K, TA.) ― -b2- See also HaXamN.

HuXomapN c
HuXomapN (in the K, erroneously, HaXamapN, TA): see HaXamN. ― -b2- Also [in the CK, erroneously, HuXamap] A woman, or a wife; syn. maroOapN. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- I. q. cimaAmN [app. as meaning protection, safeguard, or security of life and property]. (Yoo, K.) So in the phrase, lahu AlHuXomapu [Protection, &c., is due to him]. (Yoo, TA.) ― -b2- Relationship. (K.) So in the phrase, fiyhimo HuXomapN [Among them is relationship]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also HaXomapN.

HiXomapN c
HiXomapN Anger. (As, S, Mgh, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- And Shame, shyness, bashfulness, or pudency; (S, Msb, K;) and a shrinking (Lth, Mgh, K, TA) from one's brother in a place of eating, and in seeking, or requesting, a thing that one wants. (Lth, Mgh, TA.) It has been asserted, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) on the authority of As, (Msb, TA,) that it signifies only “anger:” (Mgh, Msb, TA:) but several authors have refuted this assertion, by showing that it occurs in trads. as meaning “shame.” (MF, TA.) ― -b3- Also The act of annoying a person sitting with one, and saying to him what he dislikes; and so HuXomapN↓. (K.)

HuXamaMCu c
HuXamaMCu, in the CK HaXomaAC: see HaXamN.

HuXuwmN c
HuXuwmN: see HaXamN, last sentence but one. ＝ -A2- It is also an inf. n. of 1. (K.)

HaXiymN c
HaXiymN, (S, K,) in some of the copies of the S HiXRiymN, which is app. a mistake, (TA,) [thus I find it in one of my copies of the S,] i. q. muHotaXamN↓; (S, K;) i. e. Regarded with reverence, veneration, respect, honour, awe, or fear; (TA;) applied to a man. (S.)

HaAXimN c
HaAXimN A man being, or becoming, fat, or in a good condition of body, after leanness. (TA.)

maHoXuwmN c
maHoXuwmN Angered. (TA.) [But it is implied in the S that it signifies Confounded and stupified by shame; or ashamed and confounded or stupified, and remaining speechless and motionless.] A poet says,
laEamoruka UinRa quroSa OabiI xubayobK
baTiIoCu AlnRuDoji maHoXuwmu AlOakiyli
[By thy life, verily the round cake of bread of Aboo-Khubeyb is slow in becoming thoroughly baked: the eater is angered, or confounded and stupified by shame, &c.]. (S, TA.)

muHotaXamN c
muHotaXamN: see HaXiymN.

UinRahu lamuHotaXimN biOamoriI c
UinRahu lamuHotaXimN biOamoriI Verily he is grieved and disquieted (muhotamRN) by my affair, or case. (AA, TA.)

1 HaXaA c
1. HaXaA, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) aor. yaHoXuw, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. HaXowN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He filled, (K, TA,) or stuffed, (KL, PS,) a pillow, or cushion, [and a garment, (see HaXowN, below,)] &c., (S, Mgh, * Msb, K,) with a thing, (K,) with cotton, (Msb, TA,) and the like. (TA.) [And He stuffed a lamb, or a fowl, and a vegetable, &c., with rice &c.] ― -b2- Hence, HaXaA AlgayoZa, aor. and inf. n. as above, (tropical:) [He stuffed wrath into a man's bosom: see an ex. in a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. HZl:] and HuXiIa AlrRajulu gayoZFA wa kiborFA (tropical:) [The man was stuffed with wrath and pride], and HuXiIa AlrRajulu biAlnRafosi and HuXiIa AlnRafosa (assumed tropical:) [The man was stuffed with pride, or self-magnification, or with disdain, or scorn]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] SigaAru AlUibili taHoXuw AlkibaAra (assumed tropical:) The young camels enter, or occupy the spaces, among the old ones. (TA.) ― -b4- [rasama kitaAbFA wa lamo yaHoXuhu, a phrase occurring in the 1st nawoE of the Mz, means (assumed tropical:) He sketched out a book, and did not fill it up.] ― -b5- HaXaAhu [also signifies He foisted it into a thing. ― -b6- And] He hit, or hurt, his HaXFA [q. v., like HaXaOahu]. (K.) You say, HaXaAhu sahomFA, inf. n. as above, He hit, or hurt, his HaXFA [with an arrow]. (TA.)

3 maA OajalRahu wa laA HaAXaAhu c
3. maA OajalRahu wa laA HaAXaAhu He gave him not a jaliylap [i. e. a she-camel that had brought forth once] nor HaAXiyap [i. e. small, or young, camels]: (K:) or maA OajalRaniI wa laA OaHoXaAniI↓ He gave me not a she-camel that had brought forth once nor gave he me a young, or small, camel. (S in art. jl.)

4 OaHoXawa
4: see 3.

5 taHaXRawa
5: see 8. ― -b2- tHXRI fiI baniI fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) He became received among the sons of such a one, and harboured, protected, or lodged, by them. (TA in art. HXI [but belonging to the present art.].)

7 UinoHaXawa
7: see 8. ― -b2- AnHXI SawotN fiI SawotK [app. (assumed tropical:) A sound became blended in a sound], and HarofN fiI HarofK [a letter in a letter]: mentioned by Az. (TA in art. HXI [but app. belonging to the present art.].)

8 AHtXI c
8. AHtXI It (a thing) became filled [or stuffed; as also AnHXI↓]. (K.) And in like manner you say of a man, AHtXI mina AlTRaEaAmi He became filled [or stuffed] with food. (TA.) And AiHotaXati AlrRumRaAnapu biAlHabRi The pomegranate became filled with the grains, or seeds. (TA.) ― -b2- AiHotaXato She (a musotaHaADap) stuffed her vulva (nafosahaA) with the [rags termed] mafaArim [in the CK, erroneously, maqaArim], (K, TA,) and the like: and in a similar sense AHtXI is used as said of a man having the [disorder termed] Uiboridap. (TA.) And AiHotaXato biAlkurosufi (S, Mgh, TA) and Alkurosufa (Mgh, TA) She (a HaAYiD, S, Mgh) stuffed her vulva with cotton, (Mgh, TA,) to arrest the blood. (S.) ― -b3- AiHotaXato HaXiyRapF and biHaXiyRapK She (a woman) wore a HaXiyRap; (IAar, K;) as also taHaXRato↓ [alone]. (Az, TA in art. HXI.) A poet says,
laA taHotaXiI UilRaA AlSRamiyma AlSRaAdiqaA
[She will not wear any stuffing but that which is genuine and true]: meaning that she will not wear HaXaAyaA because the largeness of her posteriors renders it needless for her to do so. (IAar, TA.)

HiXapN c
HiXapN, pl. HiXuwna: see waHoXN.

HaXFA c
HaXFA The contents of the belly: (K:) or a bowel, or an intestine, into which the food passes from the stomach; syn. miEFI: (Msb:) pl. OaHoXaMCN: (Msb, K:) and HuXowapN↓ and HiXowapN↓ signify the bowels, or intestines; [like OaHoXaMCN;] syn. OamoEaMCN: (Msb:) or these are called AlbaToni HuXowapu↓ and HiXowatuhu↓: (S, TA:) or HXwp signifies all that is in the belly except the fat; so accord. to Az and Esh-Sháfi'ee: or, accord. to As, the place of the food, comprising the OaHoXaMC and the OaqoSaAb: (TA:) [see also maHoXFI:] AlHaXaA is the name of all the places of the food: (Zj in his “Khalk
el-Insán:”) [see also, for other meanings, its dial. var. HaXFI, in art. HXI:] the word belongs to this art. and to art. HXI; the dual being HaXawaAni and HaXayaAni. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A side, (Msb, TA,) region, quarter, or tract. (Msb.) You say, OanaA fiI HaXaA fulaAnK I am in the quarter and protection of such a one: pl. as above. (Har p. 61.) [See, again, HaXFI, in art. HXI.]

HaXowN c
HaXowN, like the inf. n., (TA,) Stuffing; (PS;) [i. e.] what is put into a pillow, or cushion, &c.: (K, TA:) and [hence] cotton: and the seeds used for seasoning food, [and the rice &c.,] with which the belly of a lamb is stuffed: pl. maHaAXK↓, deviating from rule. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) The soul of a man. (K, TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) [A parenthesis;] a redundant part, or portion, of speech, or of a sentence, (K, TA,) upon which nothing is syntactically dependent. (TA. [See Har pp. 85 and 86.]) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) [A digression.] ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) The portion of either hemistich of a verse that is comprised between the first and last foot. (KT, &c.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) Small, or young, camels, (S, K,) among which are no great, or old, ones; (S, TA;) as also HaAXiyapN↓: (S, K:) so called because they enter, or occupy the spaces, among the latter; or because they go against the sides of the latter: (TA:) accord. to ISk, (S,) AlHaAXiyataAni↓ signifies [the camel termed] Aibonu AlmaxaADi and [that termed] Aibonu AllRabuwni: (S, and K in art. HXI:) the pl. [of HaAXiyapN] is HawaAXK↓. (TA.) It is said in a trad. respecting the poorrate, OamowaAlihimo Huco mino HawaAXiI↓, i. e., accord. to IAth, (assumed tropical:) Take thou of the small, or young, of their camels; such as those termed Abn AlmxAD and Abn Allbwn. (TA. [But see another explanation of this saying voce HaAXiyapN in art. HXI.]) ― -b7- And HaXowN and HaAXiyapN↓ signify also (assumed tropical:) The like of mankind; (S;) [i. e.] HaAXiyapN signifies (tropical:) the lower or lowest, baser or basest, meaner or meanest, sort, or the rabble, or refuse, of mankind, or of the people; (TA in art. HXI, and Har p. 61;) as also HaXowN [which is of frequent occurrence in this sense]; (KL;) and HiXowapN↓; (S, TA;) such as servants and the like. (Har ubi suprà, in explanation of HAXyp. [See also this word in art. HXI.]) You say, jaMCa fulaAnN maEa HaAXiyatihi↓ (assumed tropical:) Such a one came with those who were in his quarter and protection: but this may be from HaXFA signifying “a region, quarter, or tract;” servants and followers being in the quarter and protection of their master. (Har ubi suprà.) And fulaAnN baniI fulaAnK mino HiXowapi↓ (assumed tropical:) Such a one is of the lower or lowest, &c., of the sons of such a one. (S.) ― -b8- See also HuXowapN. ＝ -A2- Also A stuffed garment. (Mgh.)

OaroDN HaXaApN c
OaroDN HaXaApN (tropical:) Black land, in which is no good. (K, TA.)

HuXowapN c
HuXowapN and HiXowapN: for each, see HaXFA, in two places: ― -b2- and for the latter, see also HaXowN, in two places. ― -b3- You say also, maA Oakovara HuXowapa OaroDihi and HiXowapa ArDh, i. e. HaXowahaA↓ and dagalahaA [app. meaning (tropical:) How many are the thickets, or the like, that obstruct the tracts of his land!]. (Lh, K, TA.)

HaXiIRN c
HaXiIRN Herbage that has become dry in its lower part, and rotten: (IAar, K:) or dry: (As, S, K:) like xaXiIRN [q. v.]. (S, TA.)

HaXiyRapN c
HaXiyRapN A stuffed bed: (K:) pl. HaXaAyaA. (TA.) ['Antarah says that a saddle was to him what the HaXiyRap, or stuffed bed, is to others: see EM p. 229.] ― -b2- Also, (K,) and miHoXFI↓, (S, K,) A pillow, (K,) or the like, (S,) with which a woman makes her posteriors (S, K) or her body (K) to appear large: (S, K:) pl. of the former as above; (TA;) and of the latter maHaAXK. (S, TA. [In the S, it is only said of the former that it is the sing. of HaXaAyaA.]) ― -b3- [Also the former, The pad of a raHol (or camel's saddle): see mirobaTapN.]

HaAXiyapN c
HaAXiyapN, and its dual and pl.: see HaXowN, in six places. ― -b2- See also art. HXI.

maHoXFI c
maHoXFI The place of the food in the belly. (K.) [See also HaXFA, and maHoXaApN.]

miHoXFI c
miHoXFI: see HaXiyRapN.

maHoXaApN c
maHoXaApN [The rectum;] the lowest of the places of the food, (As, TA,) [i. e.] the portion of the intestines which is the lowest of the places of the food, (IAth, TA,) leading [immediately] to the place of egress; (As, TA;) in a beast, i. q. maboEarN: (TA: [explained in the K in art. HX, to which it does not belong:]) pl. maHaAXK. (IAth, TA.) Hence, UiyRaAkumo wa UitoyaAna AlnRisaMCi fiI maHaAXiyhinRa faUinRa kulRa maHoXaApK HaraAmN. (TA.)

miHoXaApN c
miHoXaApN A coarse [garment of the kind called] kisaMC, (As, S, TA,) that abrades the skin: (TA:) pl. maHaAXK. (As, S.) [But accord. to some, a garment of this kind is called miHoXaON or miHoXaMCN.]

maHoXuwRN c
[maHoXuwRN and maHoXiIRN Filled, or stuffed..]

maHaAXK c
maHaAXK pl. of miHoXFI, (S, TA,) and of maHoXaApN, (IAth, TA,) and of miHoXaApN, (As, S,) and irreg. pl. of HaXowN, q. v. (TA.)

1 HaXiIa c
1. HaXiIa, [aor. yaHoXaI,] inf. n. HaXFI, He (a man walking quickly, and one speaking with sharpness, or hastiness, of temper, TA) breathed short, or unintermittedly; panted for breath; or was out of breath. (S, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 3.

2 HXRI c
2. HXRI, (TA,) inf. n. taHoXiyapN, (KL, TA,) He made a HaAXiyap to a garment, or piece of cloth. (KL.) ― -b2- And [hence,] (assumed tropical:) He wrote a note or comment, or notes or comments, upon the margin, or margins, of a book: (KL, TA:) in this sense it is vulgar [or post-classical]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [Also, app., He, or it, caused one to breathe short or unintermittedly, to pant for breath, or to be out of breath: see muHaXRiyapu AlkilaAbi, below.]

3 HAXAhu minohumo c
3. HAXAhu minohumo, (IAmb, K, &c.,) inf. n. muHaAXaApN, (KL,) He set him aside as excluded from the description of them; [excluded him from them;] did not include him among them: (IAmb, TA:) from HaXFI meaning the “side” of a thing: (Az, TA;) he excepted him from them; as also tHXRAhu↓. (Lh, K, TA.) You say, Xatamotuhumo wa maA HaAXayotu minohumo OaHadFA and mA taHaXRayotu↓, i. e. [I reviled them and] I did not say [of any one of them] HaAXaI lifulaAnK [Far is such a one from being included among those of whom I speak! or from any cause of reproach!]; or I did not except, of them, any one. (Lh, TA. [The same saying is repeated in the TA, in the supplement to this art. of the K, but with the substitution of HXyt for HAXyt; perhaps by a mistake of the copyist: or it may be inferred from a statement of Fr and IAmb, which will be found below, that one also says mA HaXayotu↓.]) And En-Nábighah [Edh-Dhubyánee] says, (Mbr, S.)
wa laA OaraI faAEilFA fiI AlnRaAsi yuXobihuhu
wa maA OuHaAXiI mina AlOaqowaAmi mino OaHadi
[And I shall not see an actor among mankind resembling him; and I do not except, of the companies of men, any one]: which shows HaAXiI to be a verb perfectly inflected. (Mbr, S, Mughnee.) And hence the trad. of the Prophet, qaAl OusaAmapu OaHabRu AlnRaAsi UilaIRa maA HaAXaI faATimapa, i. e. [He said, Usámeh is the most beloved of men to me:] he did not except Fátimeh: mA being here a negative; not, as Ibn-Málik imagines, supposing this clause to be of the words of the Prophet, the mA which, with a verb following it, conveys the meaning of an inf. n. (Mughnee.) ― -b2- HaAXaI also denotes exception as a particle, or as a verb (S, Mughnee) having but one tense and no inf. n., (Mughnee,) according as it governs a gen. or an accus. case. (S.) You say, zayodK Darabotuhumo HaAXaI↓ [I beat them, except Zeyd], using it as a particle; and Drbthm HAXI zayodFA, using it as a verb. (S, I 'Ak * p. 169.) And sometimes one says, qaAma Alqawomu maA HaAXaI zayodFA [The party stood, except Zeyd]; (Mughnee, I' Ak p. 169;) like maA xalaA; though Ibn-Málik [like Sb] disallows it: (I' Ak:) this being shown to be allowable by the saying of the poet,
raOayotu AlnRaAsa maA HaAXaI qurayoXFA
faUinRaA naHonu OafoDaluhumo faEaAlaA
[I have seen mankind, except Kureysh, that we are the most excellent of them in conduct]. (Mughnee, I' Ak p. 170.) The agent of HAXI [used as a verb having but one tense and no inf. n.] is a pronoun implied, relating to the inf. n. of the preceding verb, or to its act. part. n., or to a portion of what is meant by the [preceding] general noun: so that when one says, qaAma Alqawomu HaAXaI zayodFA, the meaning is, [The party stood, but] their standing, or the stander of them, or a portion of them, was apart from Zeyd. (Mughnee.) [In the K, its use as a verb of this kind is not mentioned; but it is there said to govern the gen. case, like HatRaI.] ― -b3- It also denotes remoteness from imperfection or the like, or freedom therefrom; as in the phrase llRehi HaAXaI↓ [I ascribe unto God remoteness from every imperfection or the like, or freedom therefrom; generally implying wonder or admiration, so that it may be rendered, how
far, or how free, is God from every imperfection!]: (Mughnee:) or this phrase means maEaAca QllRehi [I seek protection by God; or, as often used by late writers, and in the present day, God forbid!]; as also llRehi HaAXa↓; (S, K;) the former being the original expression: (S:) it occurs, read in both these ways, in the Kur xii. 31 and 51; where it implies wonder at the power of God as manifested in the creation of such a person as Joseph. (Ksh, Bd.) Mbr and IJ and the Koofees hold that it is a verb; and that, in the [latter] verse the meaning is, Joseph hath kept aloof from disobedience for the sake of God; but such an interpretation as this is not suitable in the case of [the former verse,] HaAXa llRehi maA hecaA baXarFA: the truth is, that it is a noun, syn. with Altanoziyh or AlbaraMCap, [accord. to different copies of the Mughnee, meaning tanoziyhFA or baraMCapF,] as is shown by another reading, llRehi HaAXFA↓, with tenween, like baraMCapF llRehi; and by the reading of Ibn-Mes'ood, QllRehi HaAXa↓, like maEaAca QllRehi: some assert that it is a verbal noun, meaning OatabarRaOu [I assert myself to be free, or clear, to God], or tabarRaOotu [I have asserted myself &c.]; but its being decl. in some dials. contradicts this. (Mughnee.) One says also, HaAXaAka↓ and laka HaAXaI↓ [Far art thou from being included among those of whom I speak! or from any cause of reproach! or the like]; both meaning the same. (S, K.) And some of the Arabs say HaXaI↓, (Fr, IAmb, TA,) dropping the A (IAmb, TA.) ― -b4- Sb says, (S, Mughnee,) with most of the Basrees, (Mughnee,) that it is only a particle governing the gen. case, (S, Mughnee,) syn. with UilRaA; (Mughnee;) because, if it were a verb, it would be allowable to make it a connective to maA, like xalaA; and this he asserts to be not allowable. (S.) Mbr says that it is sometimes a verb; as is shown by the verse of En-Nábighah cited above; and by the saying HaAXaI lizayodK, because a particle cannot be made to precede immediately another particle; and because it suffers elision, as in the phrase HaAXa lizayodK, seeing that elision takes place in nouns and verbs only, exclusively of particles: (S, Mughnee *:) and IJ and the Koofees say the like: but Mbr also holds, in common with El-Jarmee and El-Mázinee and Zj and Akh and AZ and Fr and Aboo-'Amr EshSheybánee, that it is often a particle governing the gen. case, and seldom a trans. verb having but one tense and no inf. n., because syn. with UilRaA. (Mughnee.) ＝ -A2- See also 5, in two places.

5 tHXRI c

And quwluwA maA yaHoDurukumo (assumed tropical:) [Say ye what is in your minds; or] what is ready with you. (TA from a trad.) ＝ -A3- HaDara,
(Msb,) inf. n. HiDaArapN, (AZ, S, K,) or HaDaArapN, (As, S, A,) or both, (Msb,) [see badaA, the contr. of HaDara, in art. bdw,] He resided, dwelt, or abode, in a region, district, or tract, of cities, towns, or villages, and of cultivated land; (S, Msb, K;) [as also tHDRr↓: or this latter signifies he became an inhabitant of such a region, district, or tract:] you say badawiIRN yataHaDRaru↓ [an inhabitant of the desert who becomes an inhabitant of a region, district, or tract, of cities &c.]; and [contr.] HaDariIRN yatabadRaI. (A.) [See also 8.]

3 HaADarotuhu HADr HADrp HADrth HADrtp
3. HaADarotuhu, (A, TA,) inf. n. muHaADarapN, (TA,) I witnessed it; saw it, or beheld it, with my eye. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- muHaADarapN between people is One's giving to another the answer, or reply, that presents itself to him: and HADr AljawaAba signifies He gave the answer, or reply, readily, or presently. (Har p. 189.) ― -b2- HaADarotuhu, (S,) inf. n. as above, (K,) [also] signifies I sat with him, with my knee to his knee, each of us sitting upon his knees, in contending or disputing, (jaAvayotuhu, S, K, *) in the presence of the Sultán: (S, K:) the meaning is similar to that of mugaAlabapN and mukaAvarapN, (S,) or mukaAbarapN [which seems to be the right reading]. (TA.) ― -b3- [And HADrhu bikacaA He disputed, debated, or bandied words, with him respecting such a thing.] ― -b4- And HADrhu biHaqRihi, (Lth, TA,) inf. n. as above, (Lth, K,) He contended, or disputed, with him for his (the latter's) right, or due, and overcame him, and went off with it: (Lth, K:) and mujaAladapN, also, [which is one of the explanations assigned to muHaADarapN in the K,] is syn. with muHaADarapN as the inf. n. of the verb in this sense [unless it be a mistranscription for mujaAdalapN, which I think not improbable]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also HaADarotuhu, (S, A,) inf. n. as above, (K,) I ran with him: (S, K:) or I vied, or contended, with him in running; syn. EaAdayotuhu; from AlHuDoru. (A.)

4 AHDrhu AHDrh AHDrp OHDr OHDrh HDr
4. AHDrhu, (S, A, K,) [inf. n. UiHoDaArN,] He caused him, (S, A,) or it, (K,) to be present; he brought him, or it. (S, K.) [It is also doubly trans.] You say, AHDrhu UiyRaAhu He caused him, or it, to be present with him, to attend him, to come into his presence, or to come to him; or he brought him, or it, to him. (K.) And Talabotu fulaAnFA faOaHoDaraniyhi SaAHibuhu [I demanded such a one, and his companion caused him to come to me, or brought him to me]. (A.) [Hence,] OaHoDiro cihonaka (tropical:) [Summon thine intellect; have thy wits about thee]. (A.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) He made it ready, or prepared it; syn. OaEadRahu. (TA in art. Ed.) ＝ -A2- AHDr, (S,) inf. n. UiHoDaArN; (S, A, K, &c.;) and AHtDr↓; (S;) He (a horse, S, K, and a man, Kr) ran; syn. EadaA: (S:) or rose in his running; [app. meaning trotted;] syn. AirotafaEa fiI Eadowihi. (K.)

5 taHaDRara
5: see 1, in five places.

8 UiHotaDara
8: see 1, in seven places. ＝ -A2- [AHtDr also signifies He came to a region, district, or tract, of cities, towns, or villages, and of cultivated land. See muHotaDirN, voce HaADirN; and see also HaDara, last signification.] ＝ -A3- See also 4.

10 AstHDrhu OstHDrh AstHDrh AstHDrp QstHDr QstHDrh
10. AstHDrhu He desired, or demanded, his presence. (A.) [He desired, or required, or requested, that he, or it, should come, or be brought.] ＝ -A2- He made him (a horse) to run; syn. OaEodaAhu. (S.)

HaDorN HDr
HaDorN The intruding uninvited at feasts. (IAar, K.)

HuDorN HDr
HuDorN (Az, S, K) and [in poetry] HuDurN↓ (Ham p. 277) and HDaArN↓ (Az, TA) A run, or running; syn. EadowN: (S:) or the rising of a horse in running; [app. meaning trotting;] syn. AirotifaAEu farasK fiI Eadowihi: (K:) or vehement running. (Ham p. 277, in explanation of HuDurN.) It is said in a trad., OaqoTaEa Qbona AlzRubayori HuDora farasihi biOaroDi Almadiynapi [He assigned to Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr the extent of his horse's run in the land of El-Medeeneh]. (TA.)

HaDarN HDr
HaDarN: see HaDorapN. ＝ -A2- Also, (S, A, Msb, K,) and HaADirapN↓ (S, A, K) and HaDorapN↓ and HiDaArapN↓ and HaDaArapN↓, (K,) [or the last two are app. only inf. ns. of HaDara as contr. of badaA,] A region, district, or tract, of cities, towns, or villages, and of cultivated land; (S;) contr. of badowN (S, A, Msb) and baAdiyapN: (S, K:) pl. [of the second] HawaADiru. (A.) You say, huwa mino Oaholi AlHaDari (A) and AlHaADirapi↓ (S, A) and AlHawaADiri (A) He is of the people of the region, or regions, &c., of cities, towns, or villages, and of cultivated land; (S, A; *) contr. of mino Oaholi AlbaAdiyapi. (S.) ― -b2- And the first signifies also Residence at home; contr. of safarN. (M and K in art. sfr.)

HaDurN HDr
HaDurN: see HaDirN: ― -b2- and HaADirN.

HaDirN HDr
HaDirN One who intrudes uninvited at feasts; a smell-feast; a spunger; (TA;) one who watches for the time of (yataHayRanu) the feeding of others, in order that he may attend it; as also HaDurN↓, (K,) and HuDurN↓. (IAar, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- A man unfit for journeying: (T, S:) or one who does not desire journeying: or i. q. HaDariIRN. (K.)

HuDurN HDr
HuDurN: see HaDiru: ＝ -A2- and HuDorN.

HaDorapN HDr HDrh HDrp
HaDorapN, originally an inf. n., signifying Presence: and afterwards applied to signify (tropical:) a place of presence [as also the several forms occurring in the following phrases]. (MF.) You say, kalRamotuhu bHiaDorap fulaAnK, (S, A, * Msb,) and kaAna celika baHaDoratihi, (K, * TA,) and HuDoratihi↓ and HDorataha↓ (S, K) and HaDarihi↓ (Yaakoob, S, Msb, K) and HaDaritaha↓ (K) and maHoDarihi↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) all syn. expressions, (K,) meaning (tropical:) [I spoke to him, and that was or happened,] in the presence, i. e. the place of presence, of such a one. (S, A, Msb.) And fulaAnN Hasanu AlHiDorapi↓ (S, M, A, K) and AlHuDorapi↓ (S, M) (tropical:) Such a one is a person whose presence is attended by good. (K.) And gaTRi UinaMCaka biHaDorapi AlcRubaAbi (tropical:) [Cover thy vessel in the presence of the flies, lest they taint it.] (A, TA. [Or perhaps this is a mistranscription, for yaHoDurohu AlcRubaAbu, meaning, if thou do not, the flies will come to it, and taint it.]) ― -b2- It is also applied as a title, by writers of letters and the like, to any great man with whom people are wont to be present; [and sometimes to God; and meaning (tropical:) The object of resort;] as in the phrase, AlHaDorapu AlEaAliyapu taOomuru bikacaA (tropical:) [The exalted object of resort commands such a thing]. (MF.) [It is similar to AljanaAbu; but is generally considered as implying greater respect than the latter. It is often prefixed to the name of the person to whom it is applied, or to a pronoun: as HaDorapu fulaAnK (tropical:) The object of resort, such a one: and HaDoratuka (tropical:) The object of resort, thyself.] ― -b3- Also (tropical:) The vicinity of a thing, (T, A,) and of a man. (S. [So accord. to two copies of the S; but AlrRajuli is there an evident mistranscription, for AlrRaHoli, “ of the house, ” or “ abode: ” see what follows.]) You say, kunotu biHaDorapi AldRaAri (tropical:) I was in the vicinity of, or near to, the house. (T, A.) And kunRaA biHaDorapi maMCK (tropical:) We were by a water. (TA from a trad.) And biHaDorapi AlmaMCi (tropical:) In the vicinity of, or near to, the water. (A.) ― -b4- Also The finaMC of a rajul. (S. [So accord. to two copies of the S; where it is said, HaDorapu AlrRajuli qurobuhu wafinaAWuhu: but the right reading is evidently AlrRaHoli: so that the second of the two meanings thus explained is, The court, or yard, in front, or extending from the sides, of a house, or an abode.]) ＝ -A2- And (tropical:) Apparatus for building, such as baked bricks, and gypsum-plaster: so in the saying, jamaEa AlHaDorapa yuriydu binaMCa daArK (tropical:) [He collected the apparatus, such as the baked bricks, &c., desiring to build a house]. (A.) ＝ -A3- See also HaDarN.

HuDorapN HDr HDrh HDrp
HuDorapN: see HaDorapN, in five places.

HiDorapN HDr HDrh HDrp
HiDorapN: see HaDorapN, in five places.

HaDarapN HDr HDrh HDrp
HaDarapN: see HaDorapN, in five places.

HaDariIRN HDr HDrI HDry
HaDariIRN An inhabitant of a region, district, or tract, of cities, towns, or villages, and of cultivated land; (S, A, * Msb;) opposed to badawiIRN. (S, A.) [See also HaDirN.]

HaDaAri HDAr
HaDaAri [an imperative verbal n.] Be thou present. (A.) ＝ -A2- Also A certain star, (S, K,) upon the right hoof of Centaurus: upon his other fore leg is Alwazonu. (Kzw.) It is said, HaDaAri waAlwazonu muHolifaAni [Hadári and El-Wezn are two causes of swearing]: they are two stars that rise before Canopus (Suheyl); and when either of them rises, it is thought to be Canopus, because of their resemblance to it: (AA, S: *) they are termed mHlfAn because of the disagreement of their beholders when they rise; one swearing that the one rising is Canopus, and another swearing that it is not. (AA, TA.) Th says that it is a dim, distant, star; and cites this verse:
Oaray naAra layolaI baAlEaqiyqi kaOanRahaA
HaDaAri UicaA maA OaEoraDato wafuruwduhaA
I see the fire of Leylà, in El-'Akeek, dim in the distance, as though it were Hadári, when it appears, with its Furood, which are dim stars around Hadári. (TA.) ＝ -A3- HaDaArN: see what next follows.

HiDaArN HDAr
HiDaArN (S, K) and HaDaArN↓ (K) White: (Sh, T:) or excellent and white: (S, K:) or red: (K:) but this requires consideration: (TA:) applied to camels, and to a single camel: (S, K:) or having no sing. (K.) And the former, A she-camel combining strength with excellence of pace: (El-Umawee, T, S, K:) but Sh says that he had not heard it used in this sense; and that it only signifies “ white, ” as applied to camels. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also HuDorN.

HaDiyrN HDyr
HaDiyrN (tropical:) One who always forms right opinions, or judgments, respecting things, or affairs. (A.) ＝ -A2- See also HaDiyrapN, in three places.

HaDaArapN HDArh HDArp
HaDaArapN and HiDaArapN: see HaDarN.

HaDiyrapN HDyrh HDyrp
HaDiyrapN The collective body of a people: (Fr, K:) so in the following ex., (Fr,) from a poem of Selmà El-Juhaneeyeh, in which she bewails the death of her brother As'ad, and celebrates his praises: (S:)
yaridu AlmiyaAha HaDiyrapF wanafiyDapF

nfyDp OfAD fAD nfyDh nfyDp
nfyDp signifying the same: (Fr:) [so that the meaning is, Coming to the waters in a collective and congregated body:] or the former signifies waters by which people are dwelling, or staying; and the latter, “ by which there is not any one: ” (IAar, Sh:) or the former, people dwelling, or staying, by the waters; and the latter, men “ going before an army as scouts, or explorers: ” (As:) but what IAar says, mentioned above, is better: (Az:) or the former, a company of seven, or eight, men; and the latter, “ one; ” and also men “ who explore a place thoroughly: ” (A'Obeyd:) or the former, a company of four, or five, men, (S, K,) engaged in a warring and plundering expedition: (S:) or seven: (TA:) or eight: or nine: (K: in some copies of the K “ seven; ” but the former is the right reading: TA:) or ten: or a company of men not more than ten (nafarN) with whom one goes on a warring and plundering expedition: (K:) or, accord. to AAF and the M and K, the foremost, or preceding, portion of an army: and accord. to IB, nfyDp signifies “ a party sent to a place to discover whether there be there an enemy or any cause of fear: ” (TA:) pl. HaDaAYiru. (S.) ＝ -A2- A place where dates are dried: (ElBáhilee, ISk, Az, Mgh, Msb, K:) because frequented: pl. as above. (Mgh.) [See also HaSiyrapN and HaZiyrapN.] ＝ -A3- Also, (S,) or HaDiyrN↓, (K, TA,) What collects in a wound, (S, K,) of thick purulent matter. (S.) ― -b2- And the former What collects in the membrane that encloses the fœtus, of the [fluid called] suxod, (S,) and the like. (TA.) You say, Oaloqati AlXRaApu HaDiyratahaA The ewe, or she-goat, ejected her suxod and water and blood, after having brought forth. (S.) ― -b3- And What a woman emits after childbirth and [after] the stopping of her blood: and HaDiyrN↓ is its pl. [or a coll. gen. n.]. (K. [Or, accord. to some copies of the K, and the TA, The stopping of her blood, or its ceasing to flow, is a signification distinct from what precedes it.)] ― -b4- And What a she-camel emits after bringing forth: or, accord. to AO, the membrane that envelops the fœtus. (TA.) ― -b5- And (K, TA, [in the CK “ or ”]) ↓the latter signifies Thick blood which collects in the membrane that encloses the fœtus. (K, * TA.)

HaADirN HADr
HaADirN A man present: (A, K:) pl. [HaADiruwna and] HuDRarN and [more commonly] HuDuwrN, (S, K,) which last is originally an inf. n. (S.) You say, faEalotuhu wafulaAnN HaADirN I did it such a one being present. (A.) And hawa mino HaADiriI Almaliki [He is of those who are in the presence of the king]. (A.) ― -b2- So, too, applied to a time: and you say, AlSRalaApu HaADirapN, for waqotuhaA HaADirN, (tropical:) The time of prayer is come. (Msb.) ― -b3- [Also (assumed tropical:) Ready, or prepared: often used in this sense in the lexicons &c., as in modern Arabic. See 4.] You say, quwluwA maA huwa HaADirN Einodakumo (assumed tropical:) Say ye what is ready with you [or in your minds]. (TA.) And huwa HaADirN biAljawaAbi (tropical:) [He is ready with the answer, or reply]; and biAlnRawaAdiri (tropical:) [with rare words or expressions]; (A;) as also HaDurN↓: (TA:) which latter word, alone, signifies a man having the quality of perspicuity of speech, and intelligence; syn. cuw AlbayaAni waAlfiqohi. (K.) ― -b4- A visiting angel: and HaADirapN↓ is applied to a class or company [of visiting angels]. (TA.) ― -b5- One coming to a region, district, or tract, of cities, towns, or villages, and of cultivated land; contr. of baAdK; (S, K;) as also muHotaDirN↓. (S.) ― -b6- A man staying, residing, dwelling, or abiding, bamawoDiEK in a place. (S.) ― -b7- [A man, or people,] staying, or dwelling, by water; (S, * TA;) contr. of baAdK: (K:) pl. HuDuwrN (TA) and HuDRaArN and HaDarapN: (S:) one says, maA EalaI AlmaMCi HaADirN [There is not any one staying, or dwelling, by the water]: and heWulaMCi qawomN HuDRaArN and maHaADiru [which is pl. of maHoDarN↓, a syn. of xaADirN in this sense; i. e. These are a people staying, or dwelling, by water]: (S:) or HaADirN signifies any people that have alighted and taken up their abode by a constant source of water, and do not remove from it in winter nor in summer, whether they have alighted and taken up their abode in towns or villages, and cultivated land, and houses of clay, or pitched their tents by the water, and remained there, and sustained their beasts with the water and herbage around them: (TA:) or HaIRN HaADirN, without p, signifies a tribe that has alighted and is abiding by a constant source of water: (T, TA:) and HaADirapN↓ and HaADiruwna, a people staying, or dwelling, by waters; alighting there in the hottest time of summer: when the weather becomes cool, they migrate from the constant sources of water, and go into the desert, seeking the vicinity of herbage; and then they are termed baAdiyapN and baAduwna. (T in art. bdw.) ＝ -A2- Also A great tribe (S, K) or company of men: (TA:) or a tribe, (ISd,) or company of men, (Mgh,) when staying, or dwelling, in the abode which is their place of assembling; (ISd, Mgh;) as also HaADirapN↓. (Mgh.) One says HaADiru TaIRiCK The great tribe of Teiyi. (S.) It is a pl., (S,) or coll. n., (ISd,) [or quasipl. n.,] like saAmirN and HaAjRN (S, ISd) for sumRaArN and HujRaAjN. (S.) ＝ -A3- Also, of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (TA,) A place where people are present; or where people stay, or dwell, by waters: syn. makaAnN maHoDuwrN: one says, nazalonaA HaADira baniI fulaAnK [We alighted and took up our abode, or sojourned, at the place where the sons of such a one were present; or were staying, or dwelling, by waters]. (El-Khat- tábee.) [See also maHoDarN.]

HaADirapN HADr HADrh HADrp
HaADirapN: see HaADirN, in three places: ＝ -A2- and see HaDarN, in two places.

maHoDarN mHDr
maHoDarN A place where people are present, or assembled. (K, * TA.) See also HaDorapN. ― -b2- A place to which people return (marojiEN [here a n. of place, agreeably with analogy,]) to the waters, (S, K;) or to the constant sources of water; (T, TA;) contr. of mabodF I: (T and S in art. bdw:) a place to which one goes (macohabN) in search of herbage is called munotajaEN; and every such place is called mabodF I, of which the pl. is mabaAdK: watering-places (manaAhil) are called maHaADiru [pl. of maHoDarN] because of the congregation and presence of men at them. (T, TA.) [See also HaADirN, last signification.] ＝ -A2- [People present, or assembled; an assembly: so in the present day.] ― -b2- A people dwelling, or staying, by waters: (K, * TA:) [pl. maHaADiru:] see HaADirN. ＝ -A3- The record of a kadee (or judge), in which his sentence is written, syn. sijilRN: (S, K:) or what is written when a person brings a charge against another: when the latter makes his reply, and proves it, it [the writing] is [called] tawofiyqN; and when judgment is given, sijilN. (Kull p. 352.) This is thought by MF to be a recent conventional term; but it has been heard from the Arabs [of the classical times], and is mentioned by ISd and others. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A signature (xaTRN) that is written at the end of the record of the signatures (xuTuwT) of the witnesses, in testimony of the truth of the contents of what precedes. (K. [In the CK, waAqaEapK is erroneously put for waAqiEapi; and xuTuwTu, for xuTuwTi.]) But this is a recent conventional application. (MF, TA.) ＝ -A4- fulaAnN Hasanu AlmaHoDari (assumed tropical:) Such a one is a person who speaks well of the absent. (S.)

miHoDaArN mHDAr
miHoDaArN: see miHoDiyrN.

maHoDuwrN mHDwr
maHoDuwrN [pass. part. n. of HaDarahu]. [Hence,] AllRabanu maHoDuwrN, (S, A, K,) and muHotaDarN↓, (S, A,) fagaTRi UinaMCaka, (S,) (tropical:) Milk is much subject to taint, or much tainted; [lit.] come to [and tainted; i. e.,] by the jinn, or genii, (As, T, S, K,) and beasts, &c.; (As, T;) [therefore cover thou thy vessel.] And (in like manner [one says], K) Alkunufu maHoDuwrapN (assumed tropical:) [Privies are haunted by jinn, or genii]. (S, K.) It is said in a trad., UinRa hecihi AlHuXuwXa muHotaDarapN↓ (assumed tropical:) [Verily these privies are haunted by jinn]. (TA.) And in another trad., UinRahaA maXohuwdapN maHoDuwrapN Verily it (the prayer of daybreak) is attended by the angels of the night and the day. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (Msb,) and muHotaDarN↓, (Mgh, Msb,) (tropical:) At the point of death; in the agony of death: (Msb:) [visited by death; or by the angel, or angels, of
death: (see 1:)] or the latter, near to death. (Mgh.)

miHoDiyrN mHDyr
miHoDiyrN, applied to a horse, (S, A, K, &c.,) and to a mare, (S, M,) That runs much, or vehemently; syn. kaviyru AlEadowi, (S,) or Xadiydu AlHuDori; (M;) as also miHoDaArN↓, applied without p to a mare; (M;) or this latter is not allowable; (S, K;) or is of weak authority: (K:) pl. [of both] maHaADiyru. (A.)

muHotaDarN mHtDr
muHotaDarN: see maHoDuwrN, in three places. Also (assumed tropical:) A man afflicted by demoniacal possession, or insanity, or madness. (TA.) kulRu XirobK muHotaDarN, in the Kur liv. 28, Every share of the water shall be come unto in turn, means, the water shall be come to by the people on their day, and by the she-camel on her day: (Jel:) or it means, the people shall come to their shares of the water, and the she-camel shall come to her share thereof. (K.)

muHotaDirN mHtDr
muHotaDirN: see HaADirN.

1 HaDana AlSRabiIRa HDn AlSbI HDn AlSby
1. HaDana AlSRabiIRa, (K,) aor.
HaDuna
, (TA,) inf. n. HaDonN and HiDaAnapN, He put the child in his HiDon [i. e. under his arm, or in his bosom]: or he nourished him, reared him, fostered him, brought him up, (K, TA,) and took care of him; (TA;) as also AHtDnhu↓. (K, TA.) And HaDanato waladahaA, (S, Mgh,) aor.
HaDuna
, (Mgh, TA,) inf. n. HiDaAnapN, (Mgh,) said of a woman, (S, Mgh, TA,) She put her child in her HiDon, and [thus] carried him [under her arm,] on one of her two sides: (TA:) it has a similar meaning to the phrase next following: (S:) or it means she had charge of her child, and carried him, and reared him, or fostered him. (Mgh.) ― -b2- HaDana bayoDahu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and EalaI bayoDihi, (TA,) aor.
HaDuna
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. HaDonN (Mgh, Msb) and HiDaAnapN (Msb, K) and HiDaAnN and HuDuwnN, (K,) said of a bird, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He pressed, or compressed, his eggs (S, Msb) to himself, (S,) beneath his wing, (S, Msb,) or beneath his two wings; (so in some copies of the S;) he sat upon his eggs, protecting them with his two sides (biHiDonayohi); (Mgh;) he brooded upon his eggs to hatch them: (K:) as also AHtDn↓. (KL.) ― -b3- HaDana bayoDapF taHota dajaAjapK lahu HatRaI Oaforaxato, meaning He put an egg beneath a hen belonging to him, and made her to sit [or brood] upon it [until it became hatched], if remembered to have been heard [from any of the Arabs of pure speech], is a tropical usage of the verb, like as when one says ” The Emeer built the city: “ otherwise, it is correctly [HaDRana↓,] with teshdeed. (Mgh.) ― -b4- HaDanahu Eano kacaA, inf. n. HaDonN and HiDaAnapN, (tropical:) He made him to turn away, withdraw, or retire, from such a thing, and had it to himself exclusively; (S, K, TA;) as though he put him aside from it, or by its side: he excluded him from participation in it; in which sense minohu OaHoDanahu↓ is disapproved: (TA:) he impeded him, or debarred him, from it. (ISd, TA.) It is related in a trad. of Ibn-Mes'ood that, when he made his will, he said, wa laA tuHoDanu zayonabu Eano celika, meaning (assumed tropical:) And Zeyneb (his wife) shall not be precluded from looking into that and executing it; namely, his will: or shall not be precluded from it, nor shall any matter [relating to it] be decided without her. (TA.) And you say also, HaDanahu Eano HaAjatihi He withheld him from the object of his want; as also AHtDnhu↓. (S, ISd, K.) And HaDana maEoruwfahu, (K,) and Hadiyvahu, (TA,) Eano jiyraAnihi, (K,) and maEaArifihi, (TA,) inf. n. HaDonN, (K,) (assumed tropical:) He turned his beneficence, (K, TA,) and his discourse, (TA,) from his neighbours, (K, TA,) and his acquaintances, to others: on the authority of Lh. Hafufa
, (S,) inf. n. HafRN (S, TA) and HifaAfN; (TA [accord. to a meaning there assigned to it];) and HfRfwA↓ and AHtfRwA↓; all signify the same; (K, TA;) They went round about, circuited, compassed, or surrounded, it, or him. (S, Ksh, Bd, Msb, TA.) You say, HafRa Alqawomu biAlbayoti, [or rather Hawola Albayoti,] The company of men went round about the House [called the House of God, i. e. the Kaabeh]. (Msb.) And it is said in a trad., fayaHufRuwnahumo biOajoniHatihimo And they circuit round about them with their wings. (TA.) And in a prov., mano HafRanaA Oawo rafRanaA faloyaqotaSido, i. e. Whoso goes round about us, and minds, or manages, our affairs, (K, TA,) and treats us with honour; (TA;) or [in the K “ and ”] serves us, (S, K,) and guards us, defends us, or takes care of us, and regards us, or behaves towards us, with benevolence and solicitude; (S, TA;) or [in the K “ and ”] praises us; (A 'Obeyd, K, TA;) let him [act moderately, and] not exceed the due bounds, (A 'Obeyd, K, TA,) but speak truth. (A 'Obeyd, TA.) Hence the saying, (K,) walaA raAfRN maA lahu HaAfRN↓ (S, K) [He has not any who goes round about him, and minds, or manages, his affairs, &c.]. And cahaba mano kaAna yaHufRuhu wayarufRuhu (S, K) [He went away, or has gone away, who used to go round about him, &c.; or] who used to give to him, and bring him corn or food: (TA:) [for] HafRahu signifies also he gave to him. (Msb.) And huwa yaHufRu wayarufRu He stands and sits: and he acts as a sincere, or faithful, adviser, and with benevolence and solicitude. (As,) (TA.) [See also art. rf.] One says, of persons in want, HafRatohumu AlHaAjapu, (S, K,) aor.

, (S,) inf. n. HafRN, (TA,) (tropical:) [Want beset, or encompassed, them; or has beset, &c.;] and humo qawmN maHofuwfuwna↓ (tropical:) [They are persons beset, or encompassed, by want]. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- HafRahu biAlXRaIoCi, aor.

HufuwfN, His head remained long without ointment, (As, S, K,) and its hair was shaggy, matted, frouzy, or dusty: (TA:) and HafRati AllRiHoyapu, aor. and inf. n. as above, The beard was shaggy, matted, frouzy from long want of ointment, or dusty. And of a bird, meaning It made a [rustling] sound (K, TA) with its wing [or wings]: (TA:) and HafoHafa↓ signifies the same, said of the wing of a bird; and likewise, of a hyena, (IDrd, K,) as also xafoxafa.
