HafRapN i. q. minowaAlN; i. e. The web-beam of a loom; the wooden thing [or roller] upon which the weaver winds the web, or piece of cloth [as it is woven]: HafRN↓ signifying the minosaj [which generally means the weaver's loom; but explained in the TK as meaning here the stay of a weaver's loom; in the KL, said to be what is called in Persian kAr Jwb, but this is the HafRap, to which the same explanation is assigned in the KL]: (S, K: *) so accord. to As: [for] Aboo-Sa'eed [i. e. As] says, the HafRap is the minowaAl; and it should not be called the HafR↓; for the HafR is the minosaj: (S, O:) [the former is also applied to the yarnbeam, upon which the yarn is rolled: see niyrN:] in the L, it is said that the HafRap of the weaver is the wide piece of wood with which he arranges the woof between [the threads of] the warp: or, as some say, the three canes: and some say that it is HifRapN↓, with kesr: and it is said to be the thing with which the weaver strikes, like a sword: and the HafR↓ is the cane that comes and goes [or goes to and fro; app. meaning the shuttle]: Az says, thus it is with the Arabs: and its pl. One says, maA Oanota biHafRapK walaA niyrapK [Thou art neither a Hfap nor a nyrap]; the nyrp being the transverse piece of wood: alluding to him who neither profits nor harms; meaning that he is good for nothing. (TA.) ― -b5- AlnRaqodu Einoda AlHaAfirapi↓, (S, A, K,) and AlHaAfiri, (A, K,) is a prov., (S,) meaning, (tropical:) The payment in ready money is on the occasion of the first sentence spoken (Yaakoob, T, * S, K) by the seller, when he says “ I have sold to thee ” [such a thing]. (T.) The origin of the saying was this: horses were the most excellent (K) and precious (TA) of the things that they possessed; and they used not to sell them on credit: a man used to say the words above to another; meaning that its hoof should not remove until he received its price: (K:) and he who says End AlHAfrp (since he makes AlHAfr to mean the beast, AldRaAbRap, itself, and since its use in this sense is frequent without the mention of caAt [prefixed to it],) subjoins to it the sign [p] of the fem. gender to show that caAti AlHaAfiri is meant by this name. (TA.) Or they used to say this on the occasion of racing and betting: and the meaning is, when the horse's hoof first falls upon the dug ground [at the goal]: (Abu-l-'Abbás, Az, K:) HaAfirapN↓, (Abu-l-'Abbás,) or HaAfirN, (K,) signifying dug ground; (Abu-l- 'Abbás, K; *) ground that is dug by a horse's feet; (Har p. 653;) like as one says maMCN daAfiqN, meaning madofuwqN. (TA.) Lth says that the saying means, when thou buyest it, thou dost not quit thy place until thou payest ready money. (TA.) This was its origin: then it came to be so often said as to be used with reference to any priority. (K.) ― -b6- [Thus,] HaAfirapN↓ signifies (tropical:) The original state or constitution of a thing; that wherein it was created: and the returning in a thing, so that the end thereof is brought back to its beginning. (K.) It is said in the Kur [lxxix. 10], OaYinRaA lamaroduwduwna fiI AlHaAfirapi↓, i. e., (tropical:) Shall we indeed be restored to our first state? (S:) i. e., to life? (Fr:) or to the present world, as we were: (IAar:) or to our first creation, after our death. (TA.) IAar cites the following verse:
EalaI SalaEK waXayobK OaHaAfirapF
maEaAca QllRehi mino safihK waEaAri
meaning (tropical:) Shall I return to my first state, wherein I was in my youth, when I indulged in amatory conversation, and silly and youthful conduct, after hoariness, and baldness of the fore part of my head? [I beg God to preserve me from lightwittedness and shameful conduct.] (S.) One says also, rajaEa UilaI HaAfiratihi↓, (A,) and HaAfirihi, (TA,) (tropical:) He became old and decrepit: (A, TA:) [as though he returned to his first state; or became in a state of second childishness.] And AilotaqawoA faQqotataluwA Einoda AlHaAfirapi↓ (S, A, K) and AlHaAfiri (A) (tropical:) They met, and fought one another at the first of their meeting. (S, K.) And faEala kacaA Einoda AlHaAfirapi↓ and AlHaAfiri (tropical:) He did so at the first, without delay. (TA.) And rajaEa EalaI HaAfiratihi↓ (tropical:) He returned by the way by which he had come: (T, S:) or by which he had come forth. (K.)

, (K,) inf. n. care, being careful; (M;) being mind ful, regardful, attentive, or considerate: (M, K:) [see also 5:] and bihi AHtfZ↓ signifies the same as HafiZahu. (S, Msb.) [Hence,] you say, HafiZa AlmaAla He kept and tended, or pastured and defended, the camels or the like. (K.) [And HafiZa Huromapa SaAHibihi He was regardful of everything entitled to reverence, respect, honour, or defence, in the character and appertenances of his companion, or friend.] And HafiZa AlsRirRa He kept the secret. (TA.) [And HafiZa yamiynahu He kept his oath: but this has also another meaning, as will be seen below.] And HafiZa AlquroMna He kept, or retained, the Kur-án in his mind, or memory; got it, knew it, or learned it, by heart. (S, * Msb, K.) [See also 5.] And HafiZa Eino fulaAnK [He learned by heart from such a one: and, followed by an accus. case, the same; or he retained in his memory, as learned, or heard, from such a one; or he remembered to have heard from such a one]. (TA &c. passim.) And one says of God, qado HafiZa EalaI xaloqihi waEibaAdihi maA yaEomaluwna mino xayorK Oawo XarRK [He hath preserved from oblivion, for, or against, his creatures and his servants, what they do of good or evil]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also He kept it from being used, or employed, on, or for, ordinary, mean, or vile, occasions, or purposes. (Mgh, Msb.) You say, fulaAnN yaHofaZu nafosahu walisaAnahu Such a one keeps himself and his tongue from ordinary, mean, or vile, employment, in that which does not concern him. (Mgh.) And hence the saying in the Kur [v. 91], waQHofaZuwA OayomaAnakumo, accord. to one of the modes of interpreting it; i. e. And keep ye your oaths from being used, or uttered, on, or for, ordinary, mean, or vile, occasions, or purposes; agreeably with what is said in ii. 224 of the Kur, where ordinary and frequent swearing by God is forbidden. (Mgh.) [Another meaning of which this phrase is susceptible has been shown above.]

1 HaqRa Hq
1. HaqRa, aor.
Haqiqa
(S, Msb, K, &c.) and
Haquqa
, (IDrd, Msb, K,) [the latter irregular,] inf. n. HaqRapN (K, TA) and HaqRN (IDrd, TA) and HuquwqN, (TA,) i. q. SaAra HaqRFA [i. e., accord. to the primary meaning of HaqRN, as explained below, on the authority of Er-Rághib, It was, or became, suitable to the requirements of wisdom, justice, right or rightness, truth, or reality or fact; or to the exigencies of the case]: (TA:) it was, or became, just, proper, right, correct, or true; authentic, genuine, sound, valid, substantial, or real; established, or confirmed, as a truth or fact: and necessitated, necessary, requisite, or unavoidable; binding, obligatory, incumbent, or due: syn. wajaba; (T, S, Msb, K, &c.;) and vabata: (Msb, TA:) it was, or became, a manifest and an indubitable fact or event; as explained by IDrd in the Jm; (TA;) it happened, betided, or befell, surely, without doubt or uncertainty. (K.) It is said in the Kur xxxvi. 6, laqado HaqRa Alqawolu EalaI Oakovarihimo, i. e. The saying, “ I will assuredly fill Hell with genii and men together, ” [Kur xi. 120 and xxxii. 13,] (Bd,) or the sentence of punishment, (Jel,) hath become necessitated [as suitable to the requirements of justice, or as being just or right,] to take effect upon the greater number of them; syn. wajaba, (Jel, TA,) and vabata. (TA.) And this, namely, vabata, is the meaning of the verb in the phrase, HaqRa Ealayoka AlqaDaMCu [The sentence was, or, emphatically, is, necessitated as suitable to the requirements of justice to take effect upon thee; or it was, or is, necessary, just, or right, that the sentence should take effect upon thee]. (TA.) [In like manner,] one says, yaHiqRu Ealayoka Oano tafoEala kacaA It is necessary for thee [as suitable to the requirements of wisdom or justice or the like], or incumbent on thee, or just or proper or right for thee, that thou shouldst do such a thing. (TA.) [Thus one says,] AlHaqiyqapu maA yaHiqRu Ealayoka Oano taHomiyahu [The Hqyqp is that which it is necessary for thee &c., or that which it behooveth thee, that thou shouldst defend it, or protect it]. (S, * K.) Accord. to Sh, the Arabs said, HaqRa EalaIRa Oano OafoEala celika and HuqRa: but accord. to Fr, when you say HaqRa, you say Ealayoka; and when you say HuqRa, you say laka. (TA.) [Accordingly] one says, HuqRa laka Oano tafoEala caA and Huqiqota Oano tafoEalahu: both mean the same: (Ks, S, K:) [i. e., each has one, or the other, or both, of the meanings next following:] or the former means It was, or, emphatically, is, rendered HRqR [or suitable to the requirements of wisdom or justice &c.] for thee, or necessary for thee, or incumbent on thee, or just or proper or right for thee, [or it behooved or behooves thee,] that thou shouldst do, or to do, this, or that: and [the latter, or] Huqiqota biOano tafoEala, Thou wast, or, emphatically, art, rendered Haqiyq [or adapted, disposed, apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, proper, competent, or worthy,] that thou shouldst do, or to do, this, or that]: (A, TA:) and in like manner, HuqRato signifies in the Kur lxxxiv. 2 and 5: (Bd, Jel: *) or Huqiqota biOano tafoEala may mean thou wast, or art, known by the testimony of thy circumstances to be Haqiyq &c. (A, TA.) And maA kaAna yaHuqRuka Oano tafoEalahu
[virtually] means the same as maA HuqRa laka [best rendered in this case It did not behoove thee to do it]. (TA.) One says also, HaqRa Oano tafoEala [It was, or, emphatically, is, necessary &c. that thou shouldst do or to do such a thing]: but they did not say, Haqaqota Oano tafoEala. (Fr, TA.) ― -b2- But HaqRa EalaIRa Oano tafoEala kacaA means Thy doing so distressed, or hath distressed, or afflicted, me; or, emphatically, distresses, or afflicts, me; like EazRa EalaIRa. (S and K and TA in art. Ez.) And in like manner, HaqRa OanRaka caAhibN [or HaqRa maA OanRaka caAhibN] means EazRa maA OanRaka caAhibN [It is distressing to me that thou art going away]. (TA in art. Ez.) And laHaqRa maA is used in the same manner as laEazRa maA, q. v. (A and TA in art. Ez.) You say also, HaqRati AlHaAjapu Want befell, or betided, or happened, and was severe, or distressing: (Msb, TA:) [which is said to be] from the phrase, HaqRati AlqiyaAmapu, aor.
Haquqa
, The resurrection included, or shall include, within its sphere [all] the created beings. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- HaqRato, aor.
Haqiqa
, (K,) inf. n. HiqRapN (S, * Msb, K,) and HiqRN, (K,) or, accord. to ISd, it should rather be HaqaAqapN and HuquwqapN, because HiqRapN is used as an epithet, [as will be seen below,] and the inf. n. in a case like this, by rule, should differ from the epithet, (TA,) She (a camel) became a HiqR, or HiqRap; i. e., entered the fourth year: (K:) and OaHaqRa↓, inf. n. UiHoqaAqN, he (a camel) became a HiqR: because, so they say, he is then fit to be laden: (Msb:) and AHqRt↓ she (a young camel) completed three years; (Aboo-Málik, K;) became a HiqRap; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) like HaqRato. (TA.) You say, huwa HaqRN bayRinu AlHiqRapi [He is a HqR, bearing evidence of being such]: (S:) and hiIa HiqRN (K) and HiqRapN (Msb, K) bayRinapu AlHiqRapi [she is a HqR or HqRp, bearing evidence &c.]: (Msb:) [a phrase] to which a parallel is scarcely known, (Msb,) or to which there is no parallel (K) except OasadN bayRinu AlOasadi [a lion bearing evidence of being like a lion in boldness]. (TA.) ― -b2- HiqRN [as inf. n. of HaqRato] also signifies A she-camel's overpassing the days [corresponding to those] in which she was covered [in the preceding year]: (K:) or her completing [the time of] her pregnancy; as also AisotiHoqaAqN↓. (TA.) ― -b3- And HaqRato and AHqRt↓ and AstHqRt↓ She (a camel) became fat. (TA. [See also 8, last signification.]) ＝ -A3- HaqRahu, (K,) aor.
Haquqa
, inf. n. HaqRN, (TA,) He, or it, rendered it [suitable to the requirements of wisdom, justice, rightness, truth, or reality or fact; or to the exigencies of the case; (see the first of the significations in this art.;) or] necessary, requisite, or unavoidable; binding, obligatory, incumbent, or due; or just, proper, or right; syn. Oawojabahu; (K;) [whence HuqRa laka Oano tafoEala caA, explained above;] as also HqRqhu↓ (K) and AHqRhu↓; (S, K;) which last some explain by SayRarahu HaqRFA [meaning as above; or he rendered it true;] or SyRrh HqRFA laA XakRa fiyhi [he rendered it true, so that there was no doubt respecting it]; as also HaqRahu, inf. n. HaqRN: and HaqRahu signifies also he established it so that it became true and undoubted in his estimation: (TA:) or HaqRahu signifies, (S, Msb,) or signifies also, (K,) he assured, or certified, himself of it; he ascertained it; he was, or became, sure, or certain, of it; (A 'Obeyd, S, Msb, * K; *) and so tHqRqh↓ (A 'Obeyd, S, K) and AHqRhu↓: (S, Msb: *) or he pronounced it, or held or believed it, to be established as a necessary truth or fact; as also AHqRhu↓: and HqRqhu↓ has a similar, but intensive, signification: (Msb:) or AHqRhu↓ signifies he established it as true; or he judged, or decided, it to be so: (TA: [contr. of OaboTalahu: see an ex., from the Kur viii., voce OaboTala:]) and HqRqhu↓, inf. n. taHoqiyqN, signifies SadRaqahu [as meaning he verified it, or proved it to be true or veritable; or he found it to be true or veritable; both of which significations are of very frequent occurrence]; (S, K;) as also HaqRahu, inf. n. HaqRN: and accord. to IDrd, HqRqhu↓ signifies [also] SadRaqa qaAYilahu [he proved, or found, or pronounced, the sayer of it to be ture]: and HqRq is also said to signify he said, “ This thing is the truth; ” like SadRaqa. (TA.) You say, Haqaqotu Ealayohi AlqaDaMCa, aor.
Haquqa
, inf. n. HaqRN, I necessitated the sentence [as suitable to the requirements of justice] to take effect upon him; or necessitated [as suitable &c.] the taking effect of the sentence upon him; syn. Oawojabotuhu; as also OaHoqaqotuhu↓, inf. n. UiHoqaAqN. (TA.) And OuHiqRa↓ Ealayoka AlqaDaMCu The sentence was, or, emphatically, is, necessitated [as suitable to the requirements of justice] to take effect upon thee; syn. Ouvobita. (TA.) And Haqaqotu Hacarahu, (S, K,) or Hicorahu, (so in one copy of the S,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S,) [I rendered his caution, or fear, necessary; or justified it; meaning] I did that of which he was cautious, or that which he feared; (S, K;) as also Hcrh OaHoqaqotu↓: (S:) or, accord. to Az, the latter only is right. (TA.) And Haqaqotu ZanRahu; (Ks, TA;) and HaqRaqotuhu↓, (Ks, S, TA,) inf. n. taHoqiyqN: (S:) both signify the same; (Ks, TA;) i. e. SadRaqotu; (S;) which means I found his opinion to be true; (Ksh and Bd and Jel, in xxxiv. 19;) or proved it to be true: (Ksh, ibid.:) and so qawolahu his saying: (S:) and taHoqiyqN signifies [also] the strengthening, or confirming, a saying; or making it strong, or firm. (KL.) And OanaA OaHaqRu lakumo hecaA Alxabara I will know, or ascertain, the truth, or real nature, of this piece of news or information, for you. (TA.) And OaZunRuhu wa laA OaHuqRuhu [I think it, but I do not know the truth of it, or am not certain of it]. (T in art. UiyRaA; &c.) And Haqaqotu AlEuqodapa, [written in the TA without any syll. signs, so that it may be either thus or HaqRaqotuhu↓; but it is most probably the former, as the quasi-pass. is not tHqRqt, but AnHqRt: it signifies lit. I made the knot right, or sure; meaning] (tropical:) I tied, or made fast, or tightened, the knot; (Ibn-'Abbád, TA;) or I tied, or tightened, firmly the knot. (A, TA.) ― -b2- [He, or it, rendered him Haqiyq, i. e. adapted, disposed, apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, proper, or worthy, to do a thing &c.; whence Huqiqota Oano tafoEalahu, or biOano tafoEala, explained above. ― -b3- It was necessary for him, or incumbent on him, or just or proper or right for him, or it behooved him, to do a thing &c.; whence maA kaAna yaHuqRuka Oano tafoEalahu, explained above.] ― -b4- Also, (S, K,) aor.

, (K,) inf. n. HaqRN, (TA,) He overcame him in disputing, or contending, for a right, or due; (S, K, * TA;) and so AHqRhu↓, (K,) inf. n. UiHoqaAqN, mentioned by Az on the authority of Ks, but, he adds, disallowed by A 'Obeyd. (TA.) See 3. ― -b5- Also He (a man) came to him, namely, another man; (A 'Obeyd, S, K;) and so AHqRhu↓. (A 'Obeyd, S.) [Hence, app.,] HaqRatoniI AlXRamosu The sun reached me. (TA.) And laA yHqRu maA fiI hecaA AlwiEaMCi riTolFA [app. yaHuqRu] What is in this receptacle [does not reach, or amount, to a pound; i. e.,] does not weigh a pound. , (TA,) inf. n. HaqRN, (TK,) He went upon the HaAqR of the road; (K;) i. e. the middle of it: the doing of which is forbidden, in a trad., to women. (TA.) 4. AHqR, [inf. n. UiHoqaAqN,] He spoke truth; said what was true: [very common in this sense; contr. of OaboTala:] or he revealed, or manifested, or showed, a truth, or a right or due: or he laid claim to a right, (or to a thing, TA) and it was, or became, due to him. 5 tHqRq OHq Hq Hqq tHqq
5. tHqRq [It was, or became, or proved to be, a truth, a reality, or a fact.] [Hence,] tHqRq Einodahu Alxabaru The information was, or proved, true, right, correct, or valid, in his estimation. (S, K. *) ＝ -A2- tHqRqhu: see HaqRahu.

6 taHaAqRN OHAq HAq tHAq
6. taHaAqRN is syn. with taxaASumN; and AiHotiqaAqN↓, with AixotiSaAmN; [The disputing, litigating, or contending, together;] (S, K;) [for] taxaASamuwA and AixotaSamuwA signify the same; (K in art. xSm;) [or rather] the meaning of [tHAqR and] AHtqAq↓ is [the disputing, &c., together for a right, or due;] each one's, or every one's, saying, “ The right is mine, ” and “ with me; ” or demanding his right, or due. (TA.) One says, taHaAqRNwA [They disputed, &c., together for a right, or due]. (TK.) And AiHotaqRaA↓ They two disputed, &c., (K, TA,) each of them demanding his right, or due. (TA.) And fulaAnN wa fulaAnN AHtqR↓ [Such a one and such a one disputed, &c., together for a right, or due]. (S.) One does not say of a single person [tHAqR nor] AHtqR↓; like as one does not say of one only [txASm nor] AxtSm. (S.)

8: see 6, throughout. ＝ -A2- AiHotaqRato bihi AlTRaEonapu (assumed tropical:) The thrust, or piercing, killed him: (AA, K:) or (tropical:) went right, or directly, into him: (As, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) penetrated into his belly, or inside: (L, TA:) or hit, or struck, the socket, or turning-place, of his hip, which is termed its HuqR. 10 AstHqRhu OstHqh AstHqh AstHqp QstHq QstHqh
10. AstHqRhu He demanded it as his right, or due. (TA.) [And hence,] He had a right, or just title or claim, to it; he was, or became, entitled to it; he deserved it, or merited it; syn. Aisotawojabahu: (S, Msb, K:) or these two verbs are nearly the same; (TA;) [the former meaning he was, or became, adapted, disposed, apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, competent, or proper, for it; which is the most proper meaning of the phrase SaAra HaqiyqFA bihi, as well as of the verb AstHqR; but this verb has also the former of these two meanings.] When a man purchases a house, and another lays claim to it, and establishes a just evidence of his claim, and the judge decides for him according to his evidence, one says of him, qadi QsotaHaqRahaA EalaI AlmuXotariI [He has a right to it in preference to the purchaser]; meaning that he is to possess it in preference to the purchaser. (TA.) And of a camel such as is termed HiqR one says, AstHqR Oano yurokaba [He was, or has become, fit to be ridden], (K,) and Oano yuHomala Ealayohi [to be laden]: (S, Msb:) and AstHqR AlDRiraAba [He was, or has become, fit for covering]. (L, K.) ― -b2- [Hence, It (an action, and anything,) deserved it, merited it, or required it.] And AstHqR UivomFA He did what necessitated sin; (Ksh and Bd and Jel in v. 106;) [was guilty of a sin;] and deserved its being said of him that he was a sinner; (Ksh ibid.;) i. q. Aisotawojabahu. (TA.) And AstHqRwA They committed sins for which he who should punish them would be excusable, because they deserved punishment; like OawojabuwA, and OaEocaruwA, and AisotalaATuwA. (IAar, TA in art. lwT.) ― -b3- AstHqRt UibilunaA rabiyEFA: see 4, last sentence. ― -b4- AstHqRt AlnRaAqapu laqaAHFA The she-camel conceived, or became pregnant; and AstHqR laqaAHuhaA [signifies the same]. (TA.) ― -b5- See also 1, as an intrans. verb, last two sentences.

R. Q. 1 HaqoHaqa HqHq
R. Q. 1. HaqoHaqa, inf. n. HaqoHaqapN, He went the pace, or in the manner, termed HaqoHaqapN; (TA;) which means a pace, or manner of going, in which the beast is made to exert himself to the very utmost, and which is the most fatiguing to the Zahor [meaning the camel that is ridden, or the beast that carries one]: (S, Mgh, K:) or a journeying in the beginning, or first part, of the night; (Lth, S, K;) which is forbidden: (Lth, S, TA:) or, as some say, the fatiguing a while, and abstaining a while: (Lth, TA:) but Az says that Lth is not correct in either of his explanations of this word: (TA:) or an obstinate persisting in journeying: or an obstinate persisting in journeying until the camel that one is riding perishes or breaks down: (K:) or, accord. to Az, the correct meaning, confirmed by what the Arabs said, is the making the camel to go on, and urging him to that which fatigues him, and that which is beyond his power, until he breaks down with his rider: or, accord. to IAar, the jading of the weak [beast] by hard journeying. (TA.) It is related in a trad., that Mutarrif Ibn-Esh-Shikhkheer said to his son, when he took extraordinary pains in religious exercises, (S, TA,) and was immoderate therein, (TA,) xayoru AlOumuwri OawosaATuhaA wa AlHasanapu bayona AlXRayoYayoni wa XarRu AlsRayori [The best of affairs, or actions, or cases, are such of them as are between two extremes; and the good action is between the two things; and the worst kind of journeying is that in which the beast is made to exert himself to the very utmost, &c.]: (S, TA:) meaning, pursue thou the middle course in religious exercises, and burden not thyself, lest thou become disgusted; for the best of works is that which is continued, though it be small. (TA.)

HaqRN Hq
HaqRN contr. of baATilN [used as a subst. and as an epithet or act. part. n.]: (S, Msb, K:) or, as an inf. n. [and used as a simple subst.], contr. of buTolaAnN; and as an act. part. n., and a simple epithet, contr. of baATilN. (Kull.) [As a subst.,] its primary signification is Suitableness to the requirements of wisdom, justice, right, or rightness, truth, reality, or fact; or to the exigencies of the case; as the suitableness of the foot of a door in respect of its socket, for turning round rightly: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [and particularly] the suitableness of a judgment, and of what involves, or implies, a judgment, [i. e., of a saying, and a religion, and a persuasion, or the like, (as will be shown by one of the explanations of its meanings as an epithet,)] to reality or fact; and the suitableness of reality or fact to a judgment: (Kull:) [the state, or quality, or property, of being just, proper, right, correct, or true; justness, propriety, rightness, correctness, or truth; reality, or fact; the state, &c., of being established, or confirmed, as a truth or fact; of being necessary, requisite, or unavoidable; of being binding, obligatory, incumbent, or due: (as shown above: see 1, first sentence:)] and existence in relation to substances, absolutely: and everlasting existence [in relation to God]: (Kull:) pl. HuquwqN and HiqaAqN: it has no pl. of pauc. (TA.) As an act. part. n. and a simple epithet, it is applied to a judgment [as meaning] suitable to reality or fact; and to a saying, and a religion, and a persuasion, considered as involving, or implying, such a judgment: (Kull:) to that which is suitable to the requirements of wisdom, justice, right, or rightness; as when one says that every act of God is HaqR: to a belief, in a thing, suitable to the reality of the case; as when one says that belief in the resurrection is HaqR: and to an action, and a saying, accordant to what is requisite or obligatory, in quality and measure and time; as when one says that the action of another is HaqR, and that his saying is HaqR: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [thus it signifies just, proper, right, correct, or true; authentic, genuine, sound,
valid, substantial, or real; established, or confirmed, as a truth or fact: and necessary, requisite, or unavoidable: and binding, obligatory, incumbent, or due:] also the necessarily-existing by his own essence [applied to God; as an epithet of Whom it has other meanings assigned to it by some, as will be seen below]: and anything existing, of an objective kind: (Kull:) existing as an established fact, or truth, (K, TA,) so as to be undeniable. (TA.) In the saying, hecaA Eabodu QllRehi AlHaqRa laA AlbaATila [This is 'Abd-Allah, truly; not falsely], the article Al is prefixed as it is in the phrase, OarosalahaA AlEiraAka; but sometimes it is dropped, so that one says HaqRFA laA baATilFA. (Sb, TA.) And in the phrase, laHaqRu laA Mtiyka, a form of oath, the nom. case is used without tenween; but when the l is dropped, one says, HaqRFA laA Mtiyka: (S, TA:) [the latter means Truly I will not come to thee: the former seems to be best explained by what here follows:] accord. to the A, laHaqRu laA OafoEalu is originally laHaqRu QllRehi laA OafoEalu [The truth, or existence, of God is that by which I swear, I will not do such a thing]; the affixed noun [AllReh] being suppressed, and meant to be understood. (TA.) AlHaqRu biyadiI [The right is mine] and AlHaqRu maEiI [The right is with me and AlHaqRu Ealayoka The right is against thee, which last is often used as meaning thou art in fault, or in the wrong,] are said by one disputing, or contending, for a thing. (TA.) [And in like manner one says AlHaqRu biyadika and maEaka as meaning Thou art in the right, and AlHaqRu EalaIRa as meaning I am in the wrong.] One says also, kaAna celika Einoda HaqRi laqaAHihaA, and laqaAHihaA HiqRi↓ (tropical:) That was on the occasion of the establishment of the fact of her conception, or pregnancy. (S, A, K, * TA.) And hecaA AlEaAlimu HaqRa AlEaAlimi, [like hecaA AlEaAlimu jidRa AlEaAlimi,] This is the learned man, the extremely learned man. (Sb, TA.) And HaqRu EaliymK means Very [or extremely] knowing. (Ham p. 139.) [Respecting the expressions AlHaqRu Alyaqiynu and HaqRu Alyaqiyni, see art. yqn.] ― -b2- [From the primary and general signification, explained in the first sentence of this paragraph, are deduced several particular meanings here following.] ― -b3- Equity, or justice. (K.) ― -b4- [The right mode, or manner, of acting or being.] ― -b5- Veracity (K) in discourse. (TA.) ― -b6- Prudence. (K, TA.) ― -b7- [A right, or due, of any kind: a just claim: a desert, or thing deserved: anything that is owed; as a fee, hire, or pay, and a price: a duty; an obligation:] the sing. of HuquwqN. (S, K.) [You say, hecaA HaqRiI This is my right, or due, &c. And hecaA HaqRN liI This is a right, or due, belonging to me; or a thing due, or owed, to me: or this is a duty to me. And hecaA HaqRN EalaIRa This is a right, or due, the rendering of which is binding, obligatory, or incumbent, on me: or this is my duty. And hence, HaqRu AlTRariyqi The duty that relates to the road: see art. Trq.] HaqRapN↓ is a more particular, or peculiar, or special, term. (S, K.) You say, hecihi HaqRatiI↓ [This is my particular, or peculiar, or special, right or due &c.: but it is explained as] meaning HaqRiI. (S.) And hecihi HiqRatiI↓ This is my just, or necessary, or incumbent, right or due &c. (K.) ― -b8- A share, or portion; as in the saying, OaEoTi kulRa ciI HaqRK HaqRahu Give thou to every one to whom belongs a share, or portion, his share, or portion, that is appointed, or assigned, to him. (TA.) ― -b9- Property: a possession. (K.) ― -b10- [An appertenance. Hence the pl.] HuquwqN signifies The maraAfiq [or appertenances, or conveniences, such as the privy and the kitchen and the like,] of a house. (Msb, TA.) ― -b11- [A necessary, or requisite, thing.] ― -b12- A thing, or an event, that is decreed, or destined. (K, TA.) It is said to have this meaning in the Kur [xv. 8], in the words, maA nunazRilu AlmalaAYikapa UilRaA biAlHaqRi [We send not down the angels save with that which is decreed, or destined]: (TA:) or, as some say, it means here revelation: (Ksh, Bd:) or punishment. (Ksh, Bd, Jel.) ― -b13- [And hence,] Death. (K.) So accord. to some in the Kur [1. 18], where it is said, wa jaMCato sakorapu Almawoti biAlHaqRi [And the confusion of the intellect by reason of the agony of death shall come with death: but other and obvious meanings are assigned to it in this instance]. (TA.) ― -b14- [As an epithet,] AlHaqRu is one of the names of God: or one of the epithets applied to Him: (K:) meaning the Really-existing; whose existence and divinity are proved to be true: (IAth, TA:) or the Creator according to the requirements of wisdom, justice, right, or rightness. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b15- It is also applied to The Kur-án. (K.) ― -b16- And to [The religion of] El-Islám. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also HaqiyqN, in two places. ＝ -A3- And see HaAqRN, in two places.

HuqRN: see HuqRapN. ― -b2- Also The breast, or mamma, of an old woman. (TA.) ― -b3- A tuber of a truffle. (TA.) ― -b4- The small hollow upon the head of the shoulder-blade: (K:) or, as some say, the HuqR of the shoulder-blade is the head of the upper arm, in which is the waAbilap: (TA:) or this latter is another signification of HuqR. (K.) ― -b5- The head, (K,) or lower part of the head, (TA,) of the hip, in which is the thigh-bone; (K, TA;) the socket, or turning-place, of the hip. (TA.) ― -b6- The socket, or turning-place, of the foot of a door. (TA.) You say, laqiytuhu Einoda HuqRi baAbi Almasojidi, meaning I met him, or found him, near to the mosque: and Almasojidi laqiytuhu mino HaAqRi↓ [app. means the same]. (TA.) ― -b7- See also HaAqRN, in two places. ― -b8- Also The web of a spider. (Az, K.)

HiqRN Hq
HiqRN A camel three years old, (S, Mgh,) that has entered the fourth year: (S, Mgh, Msb:) or a camel entering the fourth year: (K:) so called because fit to be laden (S, Msb) and made use of; (S;) or because fit to be ridden; or because fit for covering: (K:) the female is termed HiqRapN↓, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and HiqRN also: (S, K:) the pl. (of HiqRN, Msb) is HiqaAqN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and (of HiqRapN, Msb) HiqaqN, (Msb, K,) and the pl. pl., (K,) i. e. pl. of HiqaAqN, (S,) is HuquqN, (S, K,) and sometimes HaqaAYiqu, (S, TA,) or this is a pl. of HiqRapN. (TA: see 3.) Or [so in the K, but it should rather be “ and, ”] HiqRN signifies A she-camel whose teeth have fallen out by reason of extreme age. (K.) ― -b2- One says, raOayotahaA wa hiIa HiqRapN as meaning (assumed tropical:) [I saw her when she was] like a she-camel termed HqRp in bigness. (TA.) ― -b3- And [the pl.] HiqaAqN is applied to The young ones of trees: (TA:) and particularly of the [species of mimosa termed] EurofuT: (K, TA:) as being likened to the camels termed HqAq. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also (tropical:) The time of year in which a she-camel was covered in the preceding year; (S, TA;) and so HiqRapN↓: (TA:) or the usual period of her gestation. (L in art. nDj.) You say, Oatati AlnRaAqapu EalaI HiqRihaA (tropical:) The she-camel arrived at the time of year in which she had been covered in the preceding year: (S, TA:) and Att ElI HiqRatihaA↓ signifies the same; or she completed her period of gestation, and overpassed by some days the time of year in which she had been covered in the preceding year, to complete the formation of the fœtus. (TA.) And jaAzati AlHiqRa She (a camel) overpassed the year without bringing forth. (As, S.) [See also the last sentence but one in the explanations of 1 as an intrans. verb.] ― -b2- kaAna celika Einoda HiqRi laqaAHihaA: see HaqRN

Amr:)] pl. HuqRN↓, [or rather this is a coll. gen. n., as is indicated in the TA, and it is now used as a sing., like HuqRapN,] and HuqaqN, (S, K,) which latter is pl. of HuqRapN, (ISd, TA,) and HiqaAqN (S, K) and HuquwqN and [of pauc.] OaHoqaAqN, (K,) which three are pls. of HuqRN. HuquqN [app. pl. of the act. part. n. HaAqRN, like buzulN pl. of baAzilN, &c.,] Persons who have recently known, or been acquainted with, events, or affairs, good and evil. (TA.) ― -b2- And Persons establishing a claim or claims. (TA.)

HaqiyqN Hqyq
HaqiyqN Adapted, disposed, apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, proper, competent, or worthy; syn. xaliyqN, (Sh, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and jadiyrN; (K;) as also HaqRN↓, (Ibn- 'Abbád, K,) and [some say] maHoquwqN↓: (Sh, S, Mgh, K:) HaqiyqN is said to be of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the
measure mafoEuwlN; but accord. to the A, it is not so, because its fem. is with p; but is from the supposed verb Haquqa, and is like xaliyqN from xaluqa, and jadiyrN from jadura: and maHoquwqN↓ signifies [properly] rendered adapted &c.: (TA:) the pl. of Hqyq is OaHiqRaMCu; and that of mHqwq↓ is maHoquwquwna. (S.) You say, huwa HaqiyqN bihi (Sh, S, Msb, K) and bh maHoquwqN↓ (Sh, S, K) and bh HaqRN↓ (Ibn-'Abbád, K) [He is adapted, &c., for it; or worthy of it]. And to a woman, Oanota HaqiyqapN bikacaA (A, TA) and HaqiyqapN licelika and licelika maHoquwqapN↓ [Thou art adapted, &c., for such a thing and for that thing; or worthy of it]. (TA.) And Oanota HaqiyqN biOano tafoEala (A, Mgh) and maHoquwqN↓ (A) [Thou art adapted, &c., for thy doing such a thing; or worthy of doing it]. And huwa HaqiyqN Oano yafoEala kacaA [He is adapted, &c., for his doing such a thing; or worthy to do it]; (S;) in which case, An is for biOano. (Mgh.) [And HaqiyqN bikacaA also signifies Having a right, or just title or claim, to such a thing; entitled to such a thing.] It is said in the Kur [vii. 103], HaqiyqN EalaI Oano laA Oaqowla EalaI QllRehi UilRaA AlHaqRa, meaning I am disposed [not] to say [of God aught save] the truth: or, as some say, I am vehemently desirous [that I should not say &c.]; for, accord. to Aboo-'Alee, OanaA HaqiyqN EalaI kacaA means I am vehemently desirous of such a thing: but one reading, that of Náfi', is HaqiyqN EalaIRa Oano laA Oaquwla, It is binding, or obligatory, or incumbent, on me [that I should not say]. (TA.)

HaqiyqapN Hqyq Hqyqh Hqyqp
HaqiyqapN The essence of a thing as meaning that by being which a thing is what it is; [or that in being which a thing consists;] as when we say that a rational animal is the Hqyqp of a human being: (KT:) or that by being which a thing is what it is, considered with regard to its reality, is termed HaqiyqapN: considered with regard to its individuality, huwiyRapN: and without regard thereto, maAhiyRapN: (KT, TA:) the ultimate and radical constituent of a thing. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- [Also The essence of a thing as meaning the property or quality, or the aggregate of properties or qualities, whereby a thing is what it is; the essential property or quality, or the aggregate of the essential properties or qualities, of a thing; that which constitutes the particular and distinguishing nature of a thing or of a genus or species; i. q. caAtiyRapN: and] the truth, reality, or true or real nature or state [or circumstances or facts, the very nature, and the gist, and the pith, marrow, or most essential part], of a case, or an affair: pl. HaqaAYiqu: see 3. (TA.) One says, balaga Haqiyqapa AlOamori He arrived at [the knowledge of] the truth, reality, or true or real nature or state [&c.], of the case, or affair. (TA.) And AlHaqRapu↓ signifies Haqiyqapu AlOamori; (S, K;) as also AlHaAqRapu↓. (TA.) Hence the saying, lamRaA Earafa minRiI haraba AlHaqRapa↓ [When he knew the truth, reality, or true or real nature or state &c., of the case, or affair, from me, he fled]. (S, TA.) And minRiI haraba lamRaA raOaI AlHaAqRapa↓ [When he saw the truth, &c.]. (TA.) [HaqiyqapF is often used as meaning In truth, or truly; in reality, or really; and in fact.] You say also, Earafotuhu Haqiyqapa AlmaEorifapi [I knew it with reality of knowledge]. (Msb in art. knh.) And Haqiyqapu AlUiymaAni means Genuine belief or faith; reality of belief or faith. (TA.) [And you say, hecaA XaIoCN laA Haqiyqapa lahu This is a thing having no reality.] ＝ -A2- [Also A word, or phrase, used in its proper or original, or in a proper or an original, sense;] that which is constantly used according to its original application; or a name for that whereby is meant what it was [originally] applied to denote; (TA;) contr. of majaAzN: (S, K:) of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of the measure faAEilapN, from HaqRa AlXRaIoCu signifying vabata: the p is affixed for the conversion of the word from an epithet to a subst.: (TA:) [pl. as above]. [It is also called HaqiyqapN lugawiyRapN, and HaqiyqapN lugapF; to distinguish it from what is termed HaqiyqapN EurofiyRapN, and HaqiyqapN EurofFA, which is A word, or phrase, so much used in a particular tropical sense as to be, in that sense, conventionally regarded as proper; as, for instance, EadolN in the sense of “ just; ” it being properly an inf. n.] A majaAz, when much used, becomes what is termed HaqiyqapN EurofFA. (Mz 24th nwE.) [HaqiyqapN means also A proper (opposed to a tropical) signification.] ＝ -A3- AlHaqiyqapu also signifies (tropical:) That which, or those whom, it is necessary for one, or it behooveth one, to defend, or protect, (S, L, K, TA,) of the people of one's house, (L,) or such as the wife, and the female neighbour, and property, &c.: (Ham p. 181:) pl. as above. (L.) You say, fulaAnN HaAmiI AlHaqiyqapi (tropical:) [Such a one is the defender, or protector, of that which, or those whom, it is necessary, &c., to defend, or protect]. (S, TA.) [See also cimaArN. And see an ex. of this signification, or of the next, in a verse cited in p. 288.] ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) The banner, or standard: (S, K, and Ham ubi suprà:) this being included in the preceding meaning. (Ham.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) That which is sacred, or inviolable; that which one is under an obligation to respect, or honour. (TA.)

[HaqiyqaIRN rel. n. of HaqiyqapN, Essential, &c.]

HaqRaAniIRN HqAnI HqAny
HaqRaAniIRN [Of, or relating to, AlHaqR as meaning justness, propriety, rightness, correctness, or truth; &c.: and hence just, proper, &c.; like HaqRN when used as an epithet: and of, or relating to, AlHaqR as meaning God:] a rel. n. from AlHaqRu, like rabRaAniIRN from AlrRabRu. (TA.)

qarabN HaqoHaAqN qrb HqHAq
qarabN HaqoHaAqN [A night-journey to water] made with labour or exertion or haste; (K;) as also haqohaAqN and qahoqaAhN; and so muHaqoHiqN↓. (TA.) [See R. Q. 1.]

HaAqRN HAq
HaAqRN i. q. SaAdiqN [as used in the phrase SaAdiqu AlHalaAwapi and SaAdiqu AlHamolapi, &c.: see art. Sdq]: so in the phrase HaAqRN AljuwEi [Vehement hunger]: (K:) occurring in a trad. of Aboo-Bekr: but accord. to one reading, it is HaAqu AljuwEi, without teshdeed to the q, from HaAqa bihi AlbalaMCu, inf. n. HayoqN and HaAqN, “ trial, or trouble, beset him; ” and means the besetting of hunger: or it may mean HaAYiqu AljuwEi [besetting hunger]. (TA.) One says also, rajulN HaAqRu AlrRajuli and AlrRajuli HaAqRapu↓ A man perfect in manliness: and HaAqRu AlXRujaAEi and HaAqRapu↓ AlXRujaAEi perfect in courage. (K, * TA.) And Az relates that he heard an Arab of the desert say, of a mark of mange, or scab, that appeared upon a camel, hecaA HaAqRu SumaAdiHi Aljarabi [This is a most sure, or a truth-telling, evidence of genuine mange, or scab]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also The middle of the head; (S, K;) as also HaqRN↓: (K:) and of the back of the neck; as also HuqRN↓: (TA: [thus the latter is there written, in this instance, with damm:]) and of the eye: (TA:) and of a road: (K, * TA:) and of winter. (S.) One says, saqaTa EalaI HaAqRi raOosihi (S, K) and rOsh HaqRi↓ (K) He fell upon the middle of his head: (S, K:) and ElI HaAqRi AlqafaA and AlqfA HuqRi↓ upon the middle of the back of the neck. (TA.) And OaSaAba HaAqRa Eayonihi He, or it, hit the middle of his eye. (TA.) And rakiba HaAqRa AlTRariyqi He went upon the middle of the road. (K, * TA.) And jiYotuhu fiI HaAqRi AlXRitaMCi I came to him in the middle of winter. (S.) And laqiytuhu mino HaAqRi Almasojidi: see HuqRN. ― -b2- huwa fiI HaAqRK mino kacaA He is in straitness by reason of such a thing. (TA.)

HaAqRapN HAq HAqh HAqp
HaAqRapN: see HaqiyqapN, in two places. [In the sense in which it is there explained, its pl. is HawaAqRu; and so in other senses; agreeably with analogy: see the second of the sentences here following.] ― -b2- Also A severe calamity or affliction, the happening of which is fixed, or established; and so HaqRapN↓; (K;) which signifies also, [according to another explanation,] like HuqRapN↓, [simply,] a calamity; or a great, formidable, terrible, or momentous, thing, or event: (Az, K:) and HaAjapN HaAqRapN a want that befalls, or happens, and is severe, or distressing. (Msb.) ― -b3- And AlHaAqRapu [in the Kur lxix. 1 and 2] means The resurrection: (S, Msb, K:) because in it shall be [manifest] the true natures (HawaAqR) of things, or actions; or because in it shall be [or shall happen (Bd)] severe calamities (HawaAqRu AlOumuwri); (Fr, S, Bd, K;) namely, the reckoning and the recompensing: (Bd:) or because in it things shall be surely known (Bd, Jel) which are denied; namely, the raising of the dead, and the reckoning, and the recompensing: (Jel:) or because including within its sphere [all] the created beings. (Msb. [Several other reasons are assigned; but these which I have mentioned appear to be the most generally approved.]) ― -b4- See also HaAqRN, in two places.

OaHaqRu c
OaHaqRu [comparative and superlative of HaqiyqN]. You say, huwa OaHaqRu bikacaA [He is more, and most, adapted, disposed, apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, proper, or competent, for such a thing; or more, and most, worthy, or deserving, of it: and he has a better, and the best, right to such a thing; or a more just, and the most just, title or claim
to it; or he is more, and most, entitled to it]: this phrase is used in two senses: first, as denoting the possession of an exclusive right or title, i. e., without the participation of another; as when you say, zayodN OaHaqRu bimaAlihi Zeyd is entitled to his property exclusively of any other person: secondly, as denoting the possession of a right or title in participation with another person, but in a superior degree; as in the saying, AlOayRimu OaHaqRu binafosihaA mino waliyRihaA, (Msb,) i. e. The woman that has not a husband and is not a virgin [is more entitled to dispose of herself than is her guardian]; (Mgh in art. Aym;) meaning that they participate [in the right], but that her right is the stronger: (Msb:) a saying of Mohammad, in which the AyRm is opposed to the bikor, for it is added that the bkr is to be asked her permission: but one reading substitutes AlvRayRibu for AlAyRm. (Mgh ubi suprà.) In the saying, in the Kur [v. 106], laXahaAdatunaA OaHaqRu mino XahaAdatihimaA, it may be formed from AisotaHaqRa by rejection of the augmentative letters, so that the meaning is, [Verily our testimony is] more deserving of being accepted [than the testimony of them two]: or it may be from HaqRa AlXRaIoCu signifying vabata, and so mean more true, or valid. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Applied to a horse, That does not sweat. (S, K.) ― -b2- And, likewise thus applied, That puts down his hind hoof in the place [that has just before been that] of his fore hoof. (S, * K.) [See HaqaqN.]

muHiqRN mHq
muHiqRN Speaking truth; saying what is true; (Msb;) contr. of muboTilN: (K:) or revealing, or manifesting, or showing, a truth, or a right or due: or laying claim to a right [or to a thing (see 4)] which is, or becomes, due to him. (Msb.)

muHaqRaqN, [in the CK, erroneously, HuqRaq,] applied to speech, or language, (tropical:) Sound, or compact, (S, K, TA,) and orderly. (TA.) ― -b2- And, applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, (tropical:) Firmly, or compactly, woven, (S, K, TA,) and figured with the form of Huqaq [pl. of HuqRapN, q. v.]. (TA.)

miHaAqRN, applied to cattle, Such as have not brought forth, nor been milked (lamo yuHolabona [in the CK, erroneously, lm yujolabona]), in the next preceding year: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) or whose first and second milkings are of biestings. (AHát, TA.)

TaEonapN muHotaqRapN (in [some of] the copies of the K, erroneously, muHaqRaqapN, TA) A thrust, or piercing, in which is no swerving from the right direction. (S, A, O, L, K.)

muHaqoHiqN mHqHq
muHaqoHiqN: see HaqoHaAqN.

1. Haqiba, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
Haqaba
, (A, Msb, K,) inf. n. HaqabN, (Msb, TA,) It (a camel's urine) became suppressed: and, elliptically, (Msb,) he (a camel) suffered suppression of his urine, (S, Msb,) or had difficulty in staling, (A, K,) in consequence of the pressure of his Haqab [or hind girth] upon his sheath, (S, A, K,) which sometimes kills the beast; as also AHqb↓. (TA.) And Haqibato She (a camel) suffered suppression of her milk in consequence of the pressure of the Haqab upon her udder. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] said of rain, (IAar, L, Msb, K,) &c., (K,) (tropical:) It was delayed; (L, Msb;) was withheld; (IAar, L, K;) as also AHqb↓. (TA.) And of a year (EAm), (tropical:) Its rain was withheld. (S, R, A.) And of a mine, (tropical:) [It ceased to yield; or] nothing was found in it; as also AHqb↓. (K, TA.) And of a gift, or benefit, (tropical:) It became little, or ceased. (TA.) And of an affair, (tropical:) It became perverted, marred, or disordered, and impeded. (L.) ＝ -A2- See also 8.

4. AHqb He girded a camel with a Haqab. (S.) ― -b2- He made a person to ride behind him on the same beast; (A, TA;) as also AstHqb↓, (A,) or AHtqb↓, q. v. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, in three places.

8. AHtqb He bound a Haqiybap behind [on his camel or horse]; (Az, TA;) as also AstHqb↓: (Ham p. 289:) he bound anything behind the [camel's saddle called] raHol or qatab: (K:) he put on, or conveyed, a Hqybp behind him on his horse [or camel]; as also Haqaba↓: (Msb:) he carried, or conveyed, a thing behind him [on his beast]; as also AstHqb↓: and he made a person to ride behind him on the Hqybp. honour, or reputation]. (TA.) ― -b6- Haqana AlmariyDa (S, * Mgh, Msb, K *) He administered to the sick person what is termed Huqonap, i. e. Hence the saying, (Mgh, TA,) in a trad., (TA,) laA raOoIa liHaAqinK walaA HaAqibK walaA HaAziqK (S, * Mgh, TA *) No counsel, or advice, is possible to one who has much urine retained and collected, nor to one suffering suppression of the feces, nor to one who is pinched by a tight boot. (Mgh, TA. *) ― -b2- [Collecting grease, or melted grease, in a skin.] You say, OanaA minohu kaHaAqini AlUihaAlapi (assumed tropical:) I am a person skilled in it; because such a one does not collect the AhAlp in a skin until he knows that it has cooled, lest the skin should be burnt. (K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A moon a little after or before the change (hilaAl) having its two extremities elevated, and its back decumbent. (K.) Hence the saying, hilaAlN waAqifN xayorN mino hilaAlK HaAqinK (tropical:) [A hlAl erect (here meaning nearly erect) is better, or more auspicious, than a hlAl decumbent]. (A, TA.) Hbl, q. v.]; (AA, S, K; *) the two together being termed [the] HaAqinataAni: (AA, S:) the pit of each collar-bone: (T, TA:) the part between the collar-bone and the neck: (TA:) or the lower part of the belly: (S, K:) pl. AlHawaAqinu. (T, TA.) [See also AlcRaAqinapu.] Hence, (K,) it is said in a prov., laOuloHiqanRa HawaAqinaka bicawaAqiniki, (S, K,) i. e. [I will assuredly conjoin] the lower part of thy belly with the upper part thereof: or the part of thy belly that retains, or collects, the food, with the lower part of thy belly, and with thy knees. (TA.) The caAqinap is [also said to be] the extremity of the Huloquwm [or windpipe]: and hence the saying attributed to 'Áïsheh, that the Prophet died [with his head] between her HaAqinap and her caAqinap. (S.)

(K.) ― -b2- And A funnel with which the milk is poured into the skin: (Az, K: *) or a funnel which is put into the mouth of a skin, into which one then pours wine, and water. (TA.)

[See an ex. in a verse cited voce samoEN.] ― -b2- (tropical:) The part of an arrow which is the place of the feathers: (K:) or the slender part of the hinder portion, next the feathers; (S, TA;) or, as in the A, below the feathers. , (S, Msb,) inf. n. HakRN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) [He scratched, scraped, rubbed, grated, chafed, or fretted, it: or] he scraped off, abraded, or otherwise removed, its superficial part: (Mgh, Msb:) HakRN signifies the act of scratching: (KL:) or the making a body to pass upon another body with collision: (K:) [as meaning scratching and the like,] it is with the nail, and with the hand, &c. (TA.) maA HakRa ZahoriI mivolu yadiI [Nothing has scratched my back like my hand] is a prov., meaning that one should abstain from relying upon others: and the same meaning is intended in the following verse:
maA HakRa jilodaka mivolu Zuforiko
fatawRala Oanota jamiyEa Oamoriko
[Nothing has scratched thy skin like thy nail: so manage thou thyself all thine affair]. (Har pp. 432 et seq.) The saying, in a trad., UicaA Hakakotu qaroHapF damRayotuhaA [lit. When I scratch a sore, I make it bleed,] means (tropical:) when I desire an object, I attain it. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] HakRa fiI SadoriI, and AHkR↓, and AHtkR↓, (K,) the first whereof, which is mentioned by IDrd preceded by the negative maA, is the most approved, (TA,) (tropical:) It wrought, or operated, in, or upon, my mind: (K, TA:) said of a suggestion of the devil, that comes into one's mind. (TA.) Or HakRa fiI Sadorihi kacaA, aor.
Hakuka
, means (assumed tropical:) Such a thing occurred to his mind as a thing outweighed in probability, or a matter of suspicion. (Msb.) And you say maA HakRa fiI SadoriI (assumed tropical:) It did not make an impression upon my mind. (Har p. 648.) It is said in a trad., AlUivomu maA HakRa fiI Sadorika (assumed tropical:) Sin is that which makes an impression upon thy mind, and induces a suspicion that it is an act of disobedience, because the mind is not dilated thereby. (Mgh. [See also HaAka, in arts. Hwk and Hyk; and see HazRa.]) You say also, maA HakRa fiI SadoriI minohu XaIoCN (tropical:) Nothing thereof was unsettled, so as to be doubtful, in my mind. (S, TA.) And maA HakRa fiI SadoriI kacaA (tropical:) Such a thing did not cause dilatation [or pleasure] in my mind. (S, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 8. ＝ -A3- Hakikati AldRaAbRapu, aor.
Hakaka
, (Kr, K,) a verb of an unusual form, with the reduplication distinct, like laHiHato in the phrase laHiHato Eayonuhu, &c., (TA,) The beast had its hoof worn away at the edges. (K, * TA.)

(So in a copy of the “ Jámi' es-Sagheer ” of Es-Suyootee.) ― -b3- [The exercise of judicial authority; jurisdiction; rule; dominion; or government. Hence the phrase Hukoma AlEaAdapi According to custom or usage; properly, according to the ordinance of custom or usage. ― -b5- A rule in grammar &c.; as when one says, Hukomu AlfaAEili AlrRafoEu or Oano yurofaEa, i. e. The rule applying to the case of the agent is that it be put in the nom. case; and Hukomuhu Hukomu kacaA, or kaHukomi kcA, i. e. The rule applying to it is the same as the rule applying to such a thing, or like the rule applying to such a thing. ― -b6- It may often be rendered Predicament: (thus the last of the foregoing exs. may be rendered Its predicament is the same as the predicament of such a thing, or like the predicament of such a thing:) and HukomFA, or fiI AlHukomi, predicamentally, or in respect of predicament; and virtually; as distinguished from lafoZFA (literally), and HaqiyqapF (really), and the like.] ― -b7- Also Knowledge of the law in matters of religion. HikomapN Hkm Hkmh Hkmp
HikomapN [properly, or primarily,] signifies What prevents, or restrains, from ignorant behaviour: (Mgh:) [in its most usual sense, which is wisdom, agreeably with explanations here following,] it is derived from HakamapN, signifying a certain appertenance of a beast, [a kind of curb,] because it prevents its possessor from having bad dispositions: (Msb:) it means knowledge; or science; (S, K;) as also HukomN↓: (S, TA:) or [generally] knowledge of the true natures of things, and action according to the requirements thereof; and therefore it is divided into intellectual and practical: or a state, or quality, of the intellectual faculty: this is the theological Hikomap: in the Kur xxxi. 11, by the Hikomap given by God to Lukmán, is meant the evidence of the intellect in accordance with the statutes of the law: (TA:) in the conventional language of the learned, it means the perfecting of the human mind by the acquisition of the speculative sciences, and of the complete faculty of doing excellent deeds, according to the ability possessed: (Bd on the passage of the Kur above mentioned:) or it means the attainment of that which is true, or right, by knowledge and by deed: so that in God it is the knowledge of things, and the origination thereof in the most perfect manner: and, in man, the knowledge and doing of good things: or it means acquaintance with the most excellent of things by the most excellent kind of knowledge: (TA:) [and in the modern language, philosophy: pl. HikamN:] see HukomN. ― -b2- Also Equity, or justice, (K, TA,) in judgment or judicial decision; and so HukomN↓. (TA.) ― -b3- And i. q. HilomN; (K, TA;) i. e. [Forbearance, or clemency, or] the management of one's soul and temper on the occasion of excitement of anger: which, if correct, is nearly the same as equity or justice. (TA.) ― -b4- And Obedience of God: and knowledge in matters of religion, and the acting agreeably therewith: and understanding: and reverential fear; piety; pious fear; or abstinence from unlawful things: and the doing, or saying, that which is right: and reflection upon what God has commanded, and doing according thereto. (TA.) ― -b5- And [Knowledge of] the interpretation of the Kur-án, and saying that which is right in relation to it: so in the Kur ii. 272. (TA.) ― -b6- And The gift of prophecy, or the prophetic office; (K, TA;) and apostleship: so in the Kur ii. 252 and iii. 43 and xxxviii. 19: (TA:) or in the [first and] last of these instances it means ― -b7- The Book of the Psalms [of David]: or, as some say, any saying, or discourse, agreeable with the truth: (Mgh:) and it also means [in other instances] the Book of the Law of Moses: (TA:) and the Gospel: and the Kur-án: (K:) because each of these comprises what is termed AlHikomapu AlmanoTuwqu bihaA, i. e. the secrets of the sciences of the law and of the course of conduct; and AlHikomapu Almasokuwtu EanohaA, i. e. the secrets of the science of the Divine Essence. (TA.)

HakamapN [A kind of curb for a horse;] a certain appertenance of a beast; so called because it renders him manageable, or submissive, to the rider, and prevents him from being refractory and the like; (Msb;) or because it prevents him from vehement running: (TA:) it is the appertenance of the lijaAm [or bridle] that surrounds the Hanak [or part beneath the chin and lower jaw]: the Arabs used to make it of untanned thong or of hemp; because what they aimed at was courage, not finery: (S:) or the appertenance of the ljAm that surrounds the HanakaAni [which word app. here means the two jaws] of the horse, and in which are [attached] the EicaAraAni [or two side-pieces of the headstall, that lie against the two cheeks]: (K:) or a ring which surrounds
the marosin [or part of the nose which is the place of the halter] and the Hanak [or part beneath the chin and lower jaw], of silver or iron or thong: (IDrd in his Book on the Saddle and Bridle:) or a ring which is upon (fI) the mouth of the horse: (ISh, TA:) pl. HakamaAtN (S, TA) and [coll. gen. n.] HakamN↓. (TA.) Zuheyr says, describing horses,
HakamaAti AlqidRi wa AlOabaqaA qado OuHokimato↓
meaning qado OuHokimato biHakamaAti AlqidRi wa biHakamaAti AlOabaqi [That had been curbed with curbs of untanned thong, and with curbs of hemp]: (S, TA:) or, accord. to Abu-l-Hasan, [the meaning is that had been furnished with curbs &c.; for he says that] AHkmt is here made trans. because it implies the signification of qulRidato: (TA:) some relate the hemistich thus:
HakamaAti AlqidRi wa AlOabaqaA maHokuwmapF↓
[furnished with curbs of untanned thong, and hemp]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The chin of a sheep (S, K) or goat. (S.) ― -b3- And, of a man, (tropical:) The fore part of the face: (K, TA:) or, as some say, the lower part of the face: a metaphorical term from the Hakamap of the lijaAm: (TA:) or [in some copies of the K “ and ”] (tropical:) his head: [accord. to the CK, or the fore part of the head of a man:] and (tropical:) his state, or condition: and (tropical:) rank, and station. (K, TA.) You say, rafaEa QllRehu Hakamatahu (tropical:) God exalted, or may God exalt, his head, or his state, or condition, and his rank, and station: because the stooping of the head is a characteristic of the low, or abject. (Bd in iii. 5.) And AlmuHokamu The portion of the Kur-án called AlmufaSRalu [q. v.]; because nought thereof has been abrogated: or, as some say, what is unequivocal, or unambiguous; because its perspicuity is made free from defect, or imperfection, and it requires nothing else [to explain it]. (TA. [See also a similar saying below, in the second paragraph.]) And AlXRufoEapu kaHalRi AlEiqaAli [The right of preemption is like the untying of the cord with which a camel's fore shank and arm are bound together]: meaning that it is accomplished as quickly and easily as the EqAl is untied: the explanation that it passes away quickly, like the camel when his EqAl is untied, is improbable. (Mgh, Msb. *) And hence the saying [in the Kur xx. 28], wa QHolulo EuqodapF mino lisaAniI (assumed tropical:) [And loose Thou an impediment of, or from, my tongue]. (Er-Rághib, TA.)
