HllRehu: see 1, in two places: ― -b2- and see also 4, in four places. ― -b3- HlRl Alyamiyna, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. taHuliylN (Mgh, K) and taHilRapN↓, (S, * Mgh, K,) and taHilRN↓, which is anomalous, (K,) or taHilRapN↓ is a simple subst., (Msb,) [and] so is HilRN↓, (K, TA,) (assumed tropical:) He expiated the oath: (K:) or (assumed tropical:) he freed the oath from obligation by making an exception, or saying Uino XaMCa QllRehu, or by expiation: (Mgh, Msb:) or (assumed tropical:) he did that whereby he became free from violating, or failing of keeping, the oath; [generally meaning he made an exception in the oath, or he expiated it;] as also HalRahaA↓: (Msb:) and fiI yamynh tHlRl↓ (assumed tropical:) he made an exception, or said Uino XaMCa QllRehu, in his oath, (S, Mgh, K,) immediately: (TA:) and minohaA tHlRl↓ (assumed tropical:) he became quit of it by expiation, (Mgh, TA,) or by a violation of it requiring expiation, or by making an exception, or saying An XAC AllReh, in it. (TA.) One says to him who goes to a great length in threatening, or him who exceeds the due bounds in what he says, OabaA fulaAnK HilRFA↓, meaning (assumed tropical:) Make thou an exception, or say An XAC AllReh, O father of such a one, in thine oath; regarding him as a swearer: and in like manner one says, yaA HaAlifu Qcokuro HilRFA↓ (assumed tropical:) [O swearer, bear in mind the making an exception, or saying An XAC AllReh]. (S, * TA. [See a similar saying in the second sentence of this art.]) In the saying laOafoEalanRa kacaA celika Oano OafoEala kacaA UilRaA HilRa↓, [the particle] AlRA is syn. with lekinRa; and the meaning is said to be, (assumed tropical:) [I will assuredly do such a thing: but] the annulling of the obligation, or the expiation, of [that] my asseveration (qasamiI taHilRapa↓, or taHoliylahu,) shall be my doing such a thing. (TA.) One says also, Alqasami faEalotuhu taHilRapa↓, meaning (assumed tropical:) I did it only enough to annul the obligation of, or to expiate, the oath; not exceeding therein the ordinary bounds. (S, Msb.) It is said in a trad., laA yamuwtu Alqasami lilomuWomini valaAvapu OawolaAdK fatamasRahu AlnRaAru UilRaA taHilRapa↓, meaning (assumed tropical:) [Three children of the believer shall not die and the fire of Hell touch him]. save enough to annul the obligation of, or to expiate, the oath that is implied in the saying in the Kur [xix. 72], “ There is not any of you that shall not come to it. ” (A' Obeyd, S, TA.) Hence taHoliylN came to be applied to anything in which the ordinary bounds were not exceeded. (S, Msb.) One says, Darabotuhu taHoliylFA, (S, TA,) or DarobFA taHoliylFA, (K,) meaning (assumed tropical:) I beat him moderately; not exceeding the ordinary bounds. (K, * TA.) And Kaab Ibn-Zuheyr says, speaking of the feet of a she-camel, waqoEuhunRa AlOaroDa taHoliylu, meaning Their falling on the ground is without vehemence. (S.) [In like manner, also,] Alqasami taHilRapa↓ is descriptive, by way of comparison, of littleness; as is Alyamiyni taHilRapa↓: (Mgh:) or of anything occupying little time: (TA:) and Alqasami UilRaA taHilRapa↓, in the trad. cited above, means (assumed tropical:) [slightly, or] with a slight touch. (Mgh.) A poet says,
OaraI UibiliI jaduwda falamo tacuqo
muqosami bihaA qaTorapF UilRaA taHilRapa↓
(assumed tropical:) [I see my camels loathed the water of Jadood, so that they did not taste in it a drop save sparingly]. (S.) ― -b4- HlRl maA bihi mina AldRaMCi, inf. n. taHoliylN, (assumed tropical:) He, or it, removed what was in him, of disease. (Har p. 231.) ＝ -A2- HllRehu AlHulRapa He clad him with the HulRap. (TA.)

3 HAlRhu HAl HAlh HAlp
3. HAlRhu He alighted, or descended and stopped or sojourned or abode or lodged or settled, with him; and simply he took up his abode, lodged, or settled, with him; syn. HalRa maEahu. (K.) You say, yuHaAlRuhu fiI daArK waAHidapK [He takes up his abode, lodges, or settles, with him in one house]. (S.) And, of a woman, tuHaAlRu zawojahaA fiI firaAXK [She takes her place with her husband in a bed]. (Mgh.) 4. AHlRhu He made him to alight, or descend and stop or sojourn or abide or lodge or settle; and simply he made him to take up his abode, to lodge, or to settle; syn. Oanozalahu; (S, K;) as also HllRehu↓, and bihi HalRa↓: (K:) said also of a place [as though meaning it invited him to alight, &c.]. (ISd, TA.) So in the phrases AHlRhu AlmakaAna and biAlomakaAni, and AlmakaAna HllRehu↓, He made him to alight, or descend and stop &c., in the place. (K.) ― -b2- AHlR binafosihi (assumed tropical:) [He caused punishment (AlEuquwbapa being understood) to alight, or descend, upon himself; or] he did what necessitated, or he deserved, punishment. (S, K.) ― -b3- AHlRhu QllRehu Ealayohi (assumed tropical:) God necessitated it, as suitable to the requirements of justice, to take effect upon him; namely, his threatened punishment (Oamorahu). (K, * TA.) ― -b4- And AHlRhu (tropical:) He (God, Msb and K, and a man, S, Msb) made it lawful, allowable, or free; as also HllRehu↓, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) inf. n. taHoliylN and taHilRapN↓. (S.) Hence, [in the Kur ii. 276,] OaHalRa QllRehu AlbayoEa (assumed tropical:) God has made selling to be lawful, or allowable, giving the choice to practise it or abstain from it. (Msb.) And hence also, OaHolalotu lahu AlXRaIoCa (assumed tropical:) I made, or have made, lawful, allowable, or free, to him, the thing. (S.) And OaHolalotu AlmaroOapa lizawojihaA (assumed tropical:) I made, or have made, the woman lawful to her husband. (S.) ― -b5- And OaHolalotuhu and HalRalotuhu↓ (assumed tropical:) I made him, or pronounced him, free from, or quit of, obligation, or responsibility, with respect to what was between me and him. (Ham p. 446.) And tHllRehu↓ (assumed tropical:) He made him, or pronounced him, free from, or quit of, obligation, or responsibility, with respect to himself. (TA.) ― -b6- OaHilRuwA QllReha yagofiro lakumo, or OajilRuwA, with j, accord. to different readings of a trad.: see 4 in art. jl. ＝ -A2- AHlR as an intrans. verb: see 1, near the end of the paragraph. Also (assumed tropical:) He entered upon [any of] the profane months. (S, K.) And (assumed tropical:) He went forth to the HilR: (S, K:) or he became in the HilR; which means the region without the Haram [or sacred territory]: (Msb:) or he became free from, or quit of, an obligation [of any kind] that was upon him. (S, K.) ― -b2- It is said in a trad., OaHilRa bimano OaHalRa bika, meaning (assumed tropical:) Whoso quits the state of UiHoraAm, and makes it lawful to attack thee, and fights with thee, do thou so with him, though thou be in the state of AHrAm: or it means, if a man make lawful to him what is unlawful to him, as thy honour or reputation, and thy property, repel him from thyself in such a way as thou canst. (Sgh, TA.) ― -b3- AHlRt (assumed tropical:) She (a ewe or goat) secreted milk in her udder without bringing forth: (S, O:) or (assumed tropical:) she, (a ewe or goat, K, and a camel, TA,) after her milk had become scanty, or had dried up, yielded her milk abundantly in consequence of her having eaten the [herbage termed] rabiyE: in which case she is said to be muHilRN↓. (K.) And AHlRt EalaI waladihaA (assumed tropical:) She (a camel) yielded her milk abundantly to her young one. (ISd, TA.)

5 tHlRl OHl Hl Hll tHll
5. tHlRl It passed away by becoming dissolved, melted, or liquefied. (KL.) [And tHlRl Uilayohi (assumed tropical:) It became reduced by analysis to it: occurring in
this sense in the TA, art. qTE, in two places.] ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) It (a disease) went away by degrees. (Har p. 231.) ― -b3- See also 1, near the end of the paragraph. [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) He became HalaAl↓, meaning he finished his prayer. (Har p. 348.) ― -b4- tHlRl fiI yamiynihi: and tHlRl minohaA: see 2. ― -b5- tHlRl AlsRafaru biAlrRajuli (assumed tropical:) [The journey caused the man to fall sick after it; or] the man fell sick after arriving from the journey. (ISd, K.) ＝ -A2- tHlRlhu: see 4.

7 AnHlRt AlEuqodapu AnHlt AlEqdh AnHlt AlEqdp
7. AnHlRt AlEuqodapu The knot became untied, or undone, (K, TA,) or opened. (S.) ― -b2- [And AnHlR It became dissolved, melted, or liquefied. ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) It (a problem, or riddle, &c.) became solved. ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) It (a thing) became analyzed. ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) He relaxed; or became free from self-restraint.] ― -b6- AnHlRt Alyamynu (assumed tropical:) The oath became freed from obligation [by an exception made in it, or by expiation]. (Msb.)

8 AHtlR AHtl OHtl QHtAl QHtl
8. AHtlR: see 1, in four places.

10 AstHlRhu OstHlh AstHlh AstHlp QstHl QstHlI QstHlh
10. AstHlRhu (assumed tropical:) He reckoned it, accounted it, esteemed it, or deemed it, lawful, allowable, or free: (S, O:) [and consequently, he profaned, desecrated, or violated, it; i. e., a thing that should be regarded as sacred, or inviolable:] or he took it as, or made it, lawful, allowable, or free: or he asked him to make it so to him. (K.)

R. Q. 1 HaloHalahumo HlHl HlHlhm
R. Q. 1. HaloHalahumo He removed them, (S, K,) or unsettled them, from their place, (S,) or from their places, and put them in motion. (K.) ― -b2- HaloHalo biAlnRaAqapi, (S,) or biAlUibili, (K,) He said to the she-camel, (S,) or to the camels, (K,) Halo, (S, K,) or HalK HalK. (K.)

R. Q. 2 taHaloHala Eano makaAnihi tHlHl En mkAnh tHlHl En mkAnp
R. Q. 2. taHaloHala Eano makaAnihi He removed from his place; or quitted it. (S.) And taHaloHaluwA They removed from their places, and became in motion, (K, TA,) and went away. (TA.)

Halo Hl
Halo (S, K) and HalK, the latter used in the case of connexion with a following word, (S,) or HalK HalK, (K,) A cry by which a she-camel is chidden, like as a male camel is by the cry Hawob: (S:) or a cry by which camels are chidden; (K, * TA;) but only female camels; as also Haliy. (TA.)

HalRN Hl
HalRN Oil of sesame, or sesamum. (S, K.)

HulRN Hl
HulRN: see 1, near the end of the paragraph.

HilRN Hl
HilRN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.], in several senses. (S, K &c.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Xuhuwru AlHilRi, (S,) or OaXohuru AlHilRi, (K,) [The profane months; i. e. all the months except those termed AlOaXohuru AlHurumu: see HaraAmN.] ＝ -A2- Also a simple subst. from HlRl Alyamiyna: see 2, in four places. ＝ -A3- See also HalaAlN, in seven places. ― -b2- [Hence,] AlHilRu (assumed tropical:) The region that is without the Haram [or sacred territory]. (S, Msb, K.) ＝ -A4- See also HaAlRN. ＝ -A5- Also A butt; an object of aim, at which one shoots or throws. (K.)

HRlRapN Hl Hlh Hlp
HRlRapN: see maHalRN. ＝ -A2- A large basket, (K,) or a thing of the form of a large basket, (Sgh, TA,) of reeds, or canes, (Sgh, K, TA,) in which wheat is put: so in the conventional language of the people of Baghdád: (Sgh, TA:) but in that of Egypt, a copper cooking-pot: (TA:) [pl. HilalN.] ＝ -A3- The direction (jihap, and qaSod,) of a thing; as also HilRapN↓: (K:) as when you say HlRapa Algawori in the direction of the Ghowr; syn. qaSodahu. (Sb, TA.) ＝ -A4- fiyhi HalRapN In him is weakness, and languor; as also HilRapN↓. (M.)

HulRapN Hl Hlh Hlp
HulRapN [A dress consisting of] an UizaAr [i. e. a waist-wrapper] and a ridaMC [or wrapper for the whole body], (S, M, Mgh, K,) or a burod [which is another kind of wrapper for the whole body], or some other garment: (M, K:) only applied to a dress consisting of two garments (S, M, Nh, Msb, K) of one kind: (Nh, Msb:) or either of the two garments by itself: or a ridaMC and a shirt, completed by a turban; or a good garment; but not so called when upon a man; for in this case it means two garments, or three: or any good new garment that is worn, thick or coarse, or fine or thin: (TA:) or a lined garment: (K:) but with the Arabs of the desert it means [a dress consisting of] three garments, i. e. a shirt and an UizaAr and a ridaMC: (TA:) pl. HulalN (Msb) [and HilaAlN, as below]: accord. to A'Obeyd, HulalN means buruwd of El-Yemen, (S, TA,) from various places; and a garment of this kind is asserted to be meant in a trad. in which it is said that the best kind of grave-clothing is the HulRap: it is also said that HulalN is applied to the waXoI and Hibar and xazR and qazR and quwhiIR and marowiIR and Hariyr. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A weapon, or weapons: (Sgh, K:) pl. HulalN and HilaAlN. (K.) You say, labisa HulRatahu, meaning (assumed tropical:) He wore, or put on, his weapon, or weapons. (Sgh, TA.) ― -b3- Also [like UizaArN] (tropical:) A wife. (TA.)

HilRapN Hl Hlh Hlp
HilRapN A mode, or manner, of Huluwl [i. e. alighting, taking up one's abode, lodging, or settling]. (K.) ― -b2- See also HaAlRN, in three places. ― -b3- And see maHalRN, in two places. ― -b4- Also (tropical:) A collection of buyuwt [i. e. tents, or houses,] (Msb, K) of men; (K;) as also maHalRapN↓: (Har p. 333:) or (K) a hundred thereof, (Msb, K,) and more: pl. HilaAlN. (Msb.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) A sitting-place, or the people thereof; syn. majolisN: [or] (assumed tropical:) a place of assembly: pl. as above. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also HalRapN, in two places.

HalalN Hll Hlp
HalalN A laxness in the legs of a beast: or in the tendons, or sinews, (K,) and weakness in the nasaA [q. v.], (TA,) with laxness of the hock: or it is peculiar to camels: (K:) and signifies a weakness in the Euroquwb [i. e. hock, or hock-tendon,] of a camel; (Fr, S, O;) or in each Erqwb of a camel: (M, TA:) if in the knee, it is termed TaraqN. (Fr, S.) ― -b2- And Paucity of flesh in the posteriors and thighs; or smallness and closeness of the buttocks; or paucity of flesh in the thighs; syn. rasaHN; (K;) in a woman. (TA.) ― -b3- And Pain in the hips, or haunches, and the knees, in a man. (K.)

HalaAlN HlAl
HalaAlN (tropical:) Lawful, allowable, or free; contr. of HaraAmN; (S, Msb, K;) as also HilaAlN↓ (K) and HilRN↓ (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and HaliylN↓: (K:) a metaphorical signification, from HalRu AlEuqodapi [“ the untying of the knot ”]: according to some, meaning what is not forbidden; and therefore including what is disapproved and what is not disapproved: accord. to others, that for which one is not punishable. (TA.) [Hence, maAlN HalaAlK (assumed tropical:) Wealth lawfully acquired. And Aibonu HalaAlK (assumed tropical:) A legitimate son: and an ingenuous, or honest, person.] And AlHulowu AlHalaAlu (tropical:) Language in which is nothing that induces doubt, or suspicion: (K, TA:) and the man in whom is nothing that induces doubt, or suspicion. (TA in art. Hlw.) And laka huwa HilRN↓ (tropical:) It is lawful, allowable, or free, to thee. (TA.) And bilRN huwa HilRN↓, meaning the same; (S;) or wRbilRN HilRN↓; (K;) and hiya wabilRN liXaAribK HilRN↓: (TA:) see art. bl. ― -b2- (tropical:) A man who has quitted his state of UiHoraAm; (S, Msb, K;) as also muHilRN↓, (Msb,) and HilRN↓, (S, Msb,) and mina AlUiHoraAmi HilRN↓; (S, TA;) or this last signifies one who has not become in that state: (TA:) by rule one should say HaAlRN, which is not used in this sense. (K.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A woman free from any obstacle to marriage, as, for instance, by having accomplished the EidRap. (Msb.) ― -b4- See also 5.

HilaAlN HlAl
HilaAlN: see HalaAlN.

HaliylN Hlyl
HaliylN: see HalaAlN. ― -b2- Also A fellow-lodger, or fellow-resident, of another, in one house: fem. with p. (S.) ― -b3- And hence, (TA,) A husband: (S, Msb, K:) and with p a wife; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also without p: (K:) or they are so called because each occupies a place, in relation to the other, which none beside occupies: (Msb:) [but there may be two or more wives to one man:] accord. to some, they are so called because the husband is lawful to the wife, and the wife to the husband: but the word, [or rather each word,] thus applied, is ancient: not a law-term: the pl. is HalaAYilu. (TA.) ― -b4- Also A neighbour: (Msb:) fem. with p. (S.) ― -b5- And A guest. (Msb.)

HalRaAlN HlAl
HalRaAlN (assumed tropical:) One who solves astronomical problems. (TA.)

HalRaAnN Hl HlAn
HalRaAnN: see taHilRapN. ― -b2- damuhu HulRaAnN (assumed tropical:) His blood goes for nothing; or is of no account. (K.)

HaloHaAlN HlHAl
HaloHaAlN [The act of chiding a she-camel, or she-camels, by the cry Halo: a subst. from HaloHala; like zalozaAlN from zalozala: or] a subst. derived from Halo, or HalK. (TA.)

HulaAHilN HlAHl
HulaAHilN A grave, staid, or sedate, chief: (S:) or one who is grave, staid, or sedate, in his sittingplace; a chief among his kinsfolk: (TA:) or a courageous chief: or a portly man, characterized by much manly virtue: or grave, staid, or sedate, with a forbearing, or clement, disposition: applied to a man: (K:) never to a woman: (TA:) and muHaloHalN↓ signifies the same: (K:) or the former, a chief with whom men often alight, or abide: (Har p. 69:) pl. HalAHilu. (S.)

HaAlRN HAl
HaAlRN [Untying, undoing, or opening, a knot:]
act. part. n. of HalRa in the phrase HalRa AlEuqodapa. (Msb.) ― -b2- [And hence, (see 1,)] Alighting, or descending and stopping or sojourning or abiding or lodging or settling; or simply taking up one's abode; or abiding, lodging, or settling; in a place; syn. naAzilN; (K, TA;) as also HilRN↓; occurring in the Kur xc. 2: (TA:) pl. of the former HuluwlN and HulRaAlN and HulRalN, (K,) and quasi-pl. n. HilRapN↓; (TA [in which it is in one place called a pl. (not a quasi-pl. n.) of HaAlRN];) and the pl. of HilRapN is HilaAlN. (TA.) You say HaIRN HuluwlN A tribe that is [abiding] in one place. (Ham p. 171.) And qawomN HilRapN↓ A people, or party, alighting, &c., (S, Msb, K,) and comprising a numerous company: and in like manner, HiIRN HilRapN↓, (S,) and HaIRN HilaAlN, (S, TA,) a numerous tribe [alighting, &c.]. (TA.) [See also naZarN.] ― -b3- Hence, AlHaAlRu AlmurotaHilu (assumed tropical:) He who completes the reading, or reciting, of the Kur-án, and then immediately recommences it; likened to him who travels much, and does not come to his family: or the warrior who does not return from his warring. (TA.) ― -b4- dayonN HaAlN (assumed tropical:) A debt of which the appointed term, or period, is ended; (Msb;) a debt falling due; (TA;) contr. of muWajRalN. (Mgh.) ― -b5- See also muHalRalN.

OaHalRu c
OaHalRu Having what is termed HalalN [q. v.]: fem. HalRaMCu: and pl. HulRN, applied to horses, (K, TA,) and to camels, and to wolves: (TA:) a camel having a weakness in the Euroquwb [i. e. hock, or hock-tendon]: (Fr, S:) and having a laxness in his legs: it is discommended in everything, except the wolf. (S.) ― -b2- The fem., applied to a woman, signifies Having little flesh in the posteriors and thighs; or having small and close buttocks; or having little flesh in the thighs. (TA.)

UiHoliylN AHlyl UHlyl
UiHoliylN (S, Msb, K) and tiHoliylN↓ (K) The orifice through which the urine passes forth (S, Msb, K) from the penis of a man: (K:) and the orifice through which the milk passes forth from the breast (S, Msb, K) and from the udder. (S, Msb.)

taHilRN OHAl OHl HAl Hl HlI Hlw Hly tHl tHly
taHilRN: see 2, near the beginning.

taHilRapN OHAl OHl HAl Hl HlI Hlw Hly tHlh tHlp
taHilRapN: see 2, in nine places: and see also 4. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A thing with which an oath is expiated; (K;) [and so HulRaAnN↓; as in the saying,] OaEoTihi HulRaAna yamiynihi (assumed tropical:) Give thou to him that with which he may expiate his oath. (ISd, K.)

tiHoliylN tHlyl
tiHoliylN: see UiHoliylN.

maHalRN mHl
maHalRN A place where a person or party alights, or descends and stops or sojourns or abides or lodges or settles; a place of alighting, or descending and stopping &c.; or simply where one takes up his abode, abides, lodges, or settles; (S, Msb, TA;) as also maHilRN↓: (Msb:) and maHalRapN↓ (S, Msb, K) and HilRapN↓, (S,) or HalRapN↓, (K,) signify a [particular, or special,] place of alighting, or descending and stopping &c., (S, Msb, K,) of a people or party: (S, Msb:) the pl. of maHalRN is maHaAlRu; and the pl. of maHalRapN is maHalRaAtN. (TA.) You say, SidoqK huwa fiI HilRapi↓, i. e. SidoqK fI maHalRapi↓ [He is in a good, or an excellent, place of alighting, &c.]. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence, (assumed tropical:) A place, in a general sense. Thus in the phrase, HalRa maHalRa kacaA: see 1. And in the phrases, used in grammar, maHalRuhu AlrRafoEa (assumed tropical:) Its place in construction is that of the nominative case; and marofuwEN maHalRFA (assumed tropical:) Virtually in the nominative case by reason of the place which it occupies in construction; and the like.] ― -b3- [Hence, also,] a term applied by Ks to (assumed tropical:) An adverbial noun of place or time. (T voce ZarofN.) ― -b4- [Hence, also, (assumed tropical:) A person, considered as one in whom some quality has place.] You say, huwa maHalRN liOano yuqaAla fiyhi UinRahu laxayorN waEasaI Oano yafoEala xayorFA (assumed tropical:) [He is a person fit, or proper, for one's saying of him, Verily he is good, and may-be he will do good]. (A and TA in art. An.) ＝ -A2- It is also an inf. n. (S, TA. [See 1.])

maHilRN mHl
maHilRN: see maHalRN. ― -b2- Also The lawful place of slaughter of a beast for sacrifice; (S;) accord. to some, to the pilgrim on the general day of sacrifice, and to the performer of the Eumorap on the day of his entering Mekkeh; or, as others say, to him who is in the state of UiHoraAm. (TA.) ― -b3- And The term, or period, of falling due of a debt. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- It is also an inf. n. (K, TA. [See 1.])

muHalRN mHl
muHalRN: see muHalRalN.

muHlRN mHl
muHlRN [Making one to alight, or descend and stop &c.]. [Hence,] AlmuHilRataAni (assumed tropical:) The cooking-pot and the hand-mill: and AlmuHilRaAtu the cooking-pot and the hand-mill and the bucket and the knife and the axe and the instrument for striking light (qadRaAHap, S, or zanod, K) and the water-skin (S, K) and the bowl: (K:) for he who has with him these things alights, or abides, wheresoever he will; but he who has not must be near to persons from whom he may borrow some one or more thereof. (S.) [Hence, also,] taloEapN muHilRapN (assumed tropical:) A tlEp [q. v.] comprising one bayot [or tent], or two. (O, K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) [Making a debt to fall due.] The Arabs used to say, when they saw the new moon, laA maroHabFA bimuHilRi AldRayoni wa muqarRibi AlMjaAli (assumed tropical:) [No welcome be to that which makes the debt to fall due, and makes near the appointed periods!]. (TA.) ― -b3- See also HalaAlN. ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) One with whom it is lawful to fight: (S in art. L.,) and employed by them in many diseases, as a bechic and carminative; brought from Europe: (Rouyer, in the “ Descr. de l'Egypte, ” xi. 452 of the 8vo. ed.:)] a kind of odoriferous tree: (A:) a certain tree having a grain (HabR [which may mean a kernel]) that is put into perfumes and aromatics; (Msb, * TA;) the perfume in which it is incorporated being termed maHolabiyRapN↓: so say IDrst and others: AHn says that he had not heard of its growing anywhere in the country of the Arabs: accord. to Aboo-Bekr Ibn-Talhah, a tree having a grain (HabR) like that of the rayoHaAn [which is likewise used in medicine, called bizoru AlrRayoHaAni, i. e. the seed of the ocimum basilicum, or common sweet basil]: accord. to Aboo-'Obeyd El-Bekree, the [tree called] OaraAk: (TA:) [J says,] HabRu AlmaHolabi is an aromatic medicine, the place whereof is AlmaHolabiyRapu, (S,) which is a town (baladN) near El-Mósil: (K, TA:) IKh calls it a kind of perfume: some say it is the grain of the xirowaE [or castor-oil-plant]: others, that the mHlb is the fruit, or produce, of the kind of tree termed Xajaru Alyusori, which the Arabs call AlOusor: IDrd says that it is the grain with which one perfumes; calling the grain by the name of mHlb: (TA:) the best is the white, pearly, and clear. HilotiytN; (S, K;) for which you should not say HilotiyvN, with v; sometimes written HilRitiytN; (S; as in one copy; but in another, and in that from which SM quotes, HilRiytN;) and HilRiyitN↓; (K;) [Assa, or asa: of which there are two kinds; HilotiytN munotinN, or assa fœtida; and HltytN TayRbN or assa dulcis:] the gum of the OanojucaAn: (S K:)
ISd says, Hltyt is an Arabic or an arabicized word: [and is the name of a certain plant:] I have not heard that it grows in Arabia; but it grows between Bust and the country of El-Keekán: it is he says, a plant that lies prone upon the ground, and from the middle of it there comes forth, and rises high, a reed, or cane, at the head whereof is a knob (kuEoburapN): it is also, he adds, the name of the gum that comes forth at the roots of the leaves of that reed, or cane: the people of the part above mentioned, he says, cook the plant thus called, and eat it; and it is not a plant that remains during the winter. (TA.) In the T, Az states that Hltyt is said, on the authority of Lth, to be the same as Anjrd [app. a mistake for Oanojurap; or for Oanojizad, from the Persian OanoGi\xQ698Yado, signifying assa fœtida]; but, he adds, the word that I remember to have heard as the same as Anjrd is xltyt, with x; and I do not think it to be genuine Arabic. (TA, here and in art. xlt.)

HalojN, He separated, or cleared, the cotton from its seeds, with the wooden implement termed miHolaj: (Msb:) or he separated and loosened the cotton (nadafahu) with the miHolaAj upon the miHolaj, (TA,) or upon the miHolajap. (A.) [Golius describes the operation thus: “ e nucibus parum excerptum, inter ferramenta duo (quorum superius, axiculo seu specillo simile, ceu torno vertitur, inferius quiescit, simul autem inter sese arcte cohærent,) attrahitur et à semine duriore segregatur: ” but see miHolaAjN and miHolajN.] ― -b2- [Hence,] Halaja signifies also (tropical:) He made a cake of bread round (A, K) [by rolling it] with the miHolaAj. (A.) ― -b5- (tropical:) He twisted a rope. (A, TA.)

And maA taHalRaja fiI SadoriI minohu XaIoCN (tropical:) [Nothing of it was doubtful in my mind;] I doubted not respecting aught of it. (A.) You say, daEo maA taHalRaja fiI Sadorika and mA taxalRaja (tropical:) [Leave thou that which has been doubtful in thy mind]. (Lth, TA.) tHlRj fiI SadoriI and txlRj mean (tropical:) I doubted respecting it: (As, TA:) or both mean nearly the same. (Sh, TA.) The saying of 'Adee, (K,) [or,] correctly, the saying of the Prophet to 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd, (TA,) laA yataHalRajanRa fiI Sadorka TaEaAmN DAraEota fiyhi AlnRaSoraAniyRapa, or lA yaHotalijanRa↓, [accord. to different copies of the K, in the CK DAraEato fyhi AlnRaSorAniyRapu,] means (tropical:) Let not aught [of doubt] enter thy heart on account of it; [i. e., on account of food in respect of which thou hast resembled those who follow the Christian religion;] i. e., it is clean. (Sh, K, TA.) Accord. to IAth, this is from HalojN↓, signifying motion, and commotion, or agitation: and it is also related with x [in the place of H], meaning the same. (TA.)

HalazuwnN [The snail;] a certain creeping thing (daAbRapN), (K in art. Hlzn:) its flesh is good for the stomach, and for the wound of the mad dog, and for dissolving hard tumours, and curing ulcers; its shell, burnt, clears the mange, or scab, and the [species of leprosy termed] bahaq [q. v.], and the teeth; and the application of it externally draws forth the salaA [or perhaps it should be sulRaMC (or prickles of the palm-tree)] from within the flesh, and, mixed with vinegar, stops bleeding from the nose: (K in art. Hlzn:) Az agrees with the author of the K in mentioning this as a triliteral-radical word; but As and J hold the n to be a radical letter, (TA in art. Hlz,) and so do Lth and A 'Obeyd. (TA in art. Hlzn.)

10. AstHlshu He made it to be as a Hilos. (TA.) ― -b2- So the verb signifies in the phrase AstHls fulaAnN Alxuwofa [in the CK fulAnFA Alxawofu] (TA) (tropical:) Such a one relinquished not fear. HilosN A piece of cloth (kisaMC), (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) of thin texture, (S, TA,) which is put on the back of a camel, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) beneath the barocaEap, (S, A, Mgh, K,) or beneath the raHol; (Msb;) a piece of hair-cloth used as a covering for a horse or the like: (A:) or anything that is next the back of the camel or other beast, beneath the saddle, in the place of the miroXaHap, being beneath the felt cloth: (TA:) and a [piece of cloth of the kind called] kisaMC, (S, * A, Mgh, K,) or a piece of hair-cloth, (A,) or the like, (TA,) or a carpet, (IAar, Msb,) that is spread in a house or tent, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) beneath the best of the pieces of cloth: (S, Mgh,
K:) and HalasN↓ signifies the same, in both applications: (A 'Obeyd, S, K:) pl. [of pauc.] OaHolaAsN (S, Msb, K) and [of mult.] HuluwsN (K) and HilasapN. (Fr, Sgh, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] fulaAnN mino OaHolaAsi Alxayoli (tropical:) Such a one is of those who train and manage horses and are constantly upon their backs. (TA.) And naHonu OaHolaAsu Alxayoli (tropical:) We are acquirers of horses and constantly upon their backs. (S.) ― -b3- OumRu AlHilosi (assumed tropical:) The she-ass. (S, K.) ― -b4- huwa Hilosu bayotihi (tropical:) He is one who does not quit his place [or house or tent]: (K:) said [generally] in dispraise; meaning, that he is not fit for anything but to keep to the house or tent. (Az, TA.) [But it does not always imply dispraise; for] it is said in a trad., (S,) kuno Hilosa bayotika, (S, A,) or kuno HilosFA mino OaHolaAsi bayotika, (TA,) (tropical:) Keep thou to thy house or tent; (A;) quit not thou thy house or tent: (S:) meaning, in a case of sedition. (TA.) You say also, fulaAnN mino OaHolaAsi AlbilaAdi, and HilosN bihaA (tropical:) Such a one does not quit the country, by reason of his love of it: and this is said in praise; meaning, that he is a person of might and strength, and that he does not quit it, not caring for debt nor for dearth or drought, waiting until the country be fruitful. (Az, TA.) And fulaAnN kaAloHilosi AlmuloqaI [Such a one is like the castaway Hls] meaning, (assumed tropical:) is one who stands in no stead when an event presses heavily upon him, or oppresses him suddenly: and, accord. to El-Marzookee, huwa kaAloHilosi, as meaning (assumed tropical:) He is one who does not sit a horse well; is not a horseman. (Ham ibid.) ― -b5- HilosN mina AlnRaAsi (tropical:) A great one of men; syn. kabiyrN; (K, TA;) because he keeps to his place of abode, not quitting it: but [SM adds] I have seen, in the Moheet, this expression explained by kaviyrN [a multitude of men]; and Sgh explains it as meaning a company of men. (TA.) ― -b6- huwa HilosuhaA [app., (assumed tropical:) He is the careful and skilful manager of it, constantly attending to it]: accord. to Fr, this expression, and huwa Qbonu buEovuTihaA, and surosuwruhaA, and Qbonu bajodatihaA, and Qbonu simosaArihaA, and safiyruhaA, all signify the same. (TA.) ― -b7- rafaDotu fulaAnFA wa nafaDotu OaHolaAsahu (tropical:) I have forsaken, or abandoned, such a one. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- AlHilosu The fourth of the arrows used in the game called Almayosir; (A 'Obeyd, S, K;) as also AlHalisu↓: (IF, K:) it has four notches, and four portions assigned to it if it be successful, and the forfeiture of four portions if unsuccessful. (Lh, TA.)

, inf. n. HalifN and HalofN (S, Msb, K) and HilofN (K) and maHoluwfN, (S, K,) like majoluwdN and maEoquwlN and maEosuwrN, (S,) and maHoluwfapN (Lth, K) [and maHoluwfaMCu, like maXoEuwraMCu, as will be seen from what follows], He swore. (S.) You say, Halaba biQllRehi [He swore by God]. (Msb.) [And Halafa UinRhu kacaA He swore it was so. And Halafa lahu EalaI kacaA He swore to him to do such a thing.] And Halafa yamiynFA (T in art. vnI, &c.) and EalaI yamiynK (El-Jámi' es Sagheer voce mano, &c.) [He swore an oath]. And laA wamaHoluwfaAYihi laA OafoEalu [No, by the swearing it, (meaning no, I swear it,) I will not do such a thing]. (Ibn-Buzurj, K. *) And maHoluwfapF biQllRehi, meaning OaHolifu maHoluwfapF, i. e. [I swear] an oath [by God]. (Lth, K.) Accord. to IAth, the primary signification of HalifN is The act of confederating, or making a compact or confederacy, to aid, or assist; and making an agreement: [but this meaning is afterwards said in the TA to be tropical:] when the object of this, in the time of paganism, was to aid in sedition or the like, and in fighting, and incursions into the territories of enemies, it was forbidden by Mohammad: when the object was to aid the wronged, and for making close the ties of relationship, and the like, he confirmed it. (TA.)

(TA.) ― -b2- Also, (S, * K, * TA,) inf. n. muHaAlafapN and HilaAfN, (TA,) (tropical:) He united with him in a confederacy, league, compact, or covenant, (S, K, TA,) [respecting, or to do, such a thing.] ― -b3- And HAlfhu (tropical:) He clave, clung, kept, or held fast, to it: (K, TA:) see a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb in art. xlf, voce xaAlafa. 4. AHlfhu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. UiHolaAfN; (Msb;) and HlRfhu↓, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. taHoliyfN; (Msb, K;) and AstHlfhu↓; all signify the same; (S, Msb, K;) [He made him to swear: and ↓the last, he asked him, or required him, to swear: and he conjured him, or adjured him; as is shown in the M in art. blw; (see 8 in that art. in the present work;) and so ↓the second; as is shown in the explanation of the phrase OuEamRiruka QllReha Oano tafoEala in the K and TA:) said [for instance] of a judge. (TA.) You say, biQllRehi maA faEala AstHlfhu↓ and HlRfhu↓ and AHlfhu [He made him to swear by God he did not, or had not done, such a thing]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] OaHolafa AlgulaAmu The boy passed the time when he had nearly attained to puberty: (K:) so says Lth; adding that some say, qado OuHolifa: and this Z mentions also, and he adds, so that it was doubted whether he had attained to puberty: but Az says that OaHolafa AlgulaAmu in this sense is a mistake; and that it means only he nearly attained to puberty; so that those who looked at him differed in opinion; one saying and swearing that he had attained to puberty, and another saying and swearing the contrary. (TA.) ― -b3- And OaHolafati AlHalofaMCu The HlfAC attained to maturity. (IAar, K.) [By AlHlfAC would seem to be here meant the clamorous female slave: for when this word means a kind of grass, the A is not that which denotes the fem. gender, but is a letter of quasicoordination, if its n. of un. be HalofaMCapN, as in the Msb: but accord. to Sb, it is in this sense sing. and pl.; and as pl., it is fem.; and in a description of it by Aboo-Ziyád, cited by AHn, it is made fem.]

1 Halaqa raOosahu c
1. Halaqa raOosahu, (S, K,) and XaEarahu, (S, M, Msb,) aor.
Haliqa
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. HaloqN (S, * M, Msb, K) and HilaAqN (S, * Msb, K *) and taHolaAqN, (S, * K,) He removed the hair of his head [with a razor, or shaved his head], (K,) [and he shaved off his hair;] as also AHtlqhu↓; (S, K;) and HlRqhu↓, (K,) inf. n. taHoliyqN: (TA:) or the latter verb has an intensive signification, (O, Msb,) and applies to many objects, (S, Msb,) as in the phrase, HalRaquwA ruWuwsahumo [they shaved their heads]: (S:) and you say also, Halaqa maEozahu [he shore his goats]; but not jazRa save in the case of sheep: (S:) [for] AlHaloqu with respect to the hair of human beings and of goats is like AljazRu with respect to wool. (M, TA.) [Hence,] UinRa raOosahu lajayRidu AlHilaAqi [Verily his head is well shaven]. (S, K. *) And yawomu taHolaAq AllRamami [The day of the shaving off of the locks termed lmm]; which was a day fought by Teghlib (S, K) against Bekr Ibn-Wáïl; (S;) because their [i. e. Teghlib's] distinctive sign was shaving (AlHaloq), (S, K,) on that day. (S.) ― -b2- EaqorFA HaloqFA, or EaqoraI HaloqaI↓, (S, K, *) is an expression occurring in a trad.: (S:) the latter is rare; or is an incorrect variation of the relaters of traditions: (K:) A 'Obeyd says, it is EaqorFA HaloqFA, for which the relaters of traditions say EaqoraI HaloqaI↓; and the original form and meaning is EaqarahaA QllRehu waHalaqahaA, (S,) or EaqarahaA QllRehu EaqorFA waHalaqahaA HaloqFA, (TA,) i. e., [accord. to A 'Obeyd,] May God wound her body, and afflict her with pain in her Haloq [or fauces]: (S, K: *) but this explanation is not valid: accord. to the T, it is a form of imprecation uttered against a woman, [not in earnest, though denoting a degree of displeasure,] meaning may she be bereft of her husband, or became a widow, so that she shall shave off her hair: and Az says that EaqoraI HaloqaI↓ means she is unlucky [to others] and annoying: ISd says, it is said to mean she is unlucky [to others]; but I am not sure of it. (TA.) Accord. to Aboo-Nasr (S, TA) Ahmad Ibn-Hátim, (S,) one says on the occasion of an event at which one wonders, xamoXaI EaqoraI HaloqaI↓, as though [meaning May she who has occasioned this, scratch and wound her face, and shave off her hair:] from AlHaloqu [the act of shaving] and AlEaqoru [the act of wounding] and AlxamoXu syn. with AlxadoXu [the act of scratching]: (S, TA: *) and he cites this verse:
OalaA qawomiI Ouwluw EaqoraI waHaloqaI↓
limaA laA qato salaAmaAnu bonu ganomi
(TA, and so in some copies of the S,) meaning [Now surely] my people have women who have wounded and scratched their faces and shaven off their hair [on account of what the tribe of Selámán Ibn-Ghanm has experienced]: so, says IB, IKtt relates this verse, and so Hr in the Ghareebeyn: but ISk, thus:
OalaA qawomiI UilaI EaqoraI waHaloqaI
[and so I find it in one copy of the S:] and IJ explains it by saying that EqrI wHlqI originally denotes the case of a woman who, when some one honourable in her estimation has been smitten, or wounded, takes a pair of sandals, and beats with them her head, and wounds or scratches it, and shaves off her hair; and the poet means, my people have come to the condition of wounded, or scratched, and shaven, women. (TA.) [Fei says,] HaloqFA lahu waEaqorFA is a form of imprecation, meaning May God afflict him with pain in his Haloq [or fauces], and wound his body: but the relaters of traditions say EaqoraI HaloqaI↓, with the fem. alif, making them act. part. ns.; [the former meaning, accord. to one of the explanations given above, an unlucky woman to others, though this is doubtful; and] the latter meaning a woman annoying her people: (Msb:) or both these words are inf. ns., like daEowaI. (TA in art. Eqr. [See more in that art]) ― -b3- They said also, bayonahumu QHoliqiI waquwmiI [Among them is heard the saying, Shave, O woman, and arise]; i. e. among them is trial, or trouble, and distress, affliction, calamity, or adversity: and yuwomu QHoliqiI waquwmiI [A day of the saying Shave, &c.; i. e., of trial, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b4- Also Halaqa AlXRaIoCa. aor.

, inf. n. HloqN, He peeled the thing; or stripped off, or otherwise removed, its superficial part: or he peeled, stripped, pared, scraped, or rubbed, off the thing: syn. qaXarahu. (TA.) ― -b6- And, aor. as above, (assumed tropical:) He (a man) pained, or caused to suffer pain. (IAar,

HaloqN [The fauces: and hence, by a synecdoche, the throat, or gullet, i. e. the œsophagus:] the place of the galoSamap [or epiglottis]; and the place of slaughter in an animal: (AZ, TA:) or the fore part of the neck: (Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán: ”) or the passage of, or place by which pass, the food and drink, into the mariIoC [or œsophagus]: (TA:) or i. q. HuloquwmN↓: (S, Msb, K:) [but] the latter is the windpipe; the passage of the breath; (Zj ubi suprà, Az, Msb;) which has branches branching from it into the lungs, [namely, the bronchi, consisting of two main branches, which divide into smaller and smaller,] called the qaSab: (Zj ubi suprà, and Msb:) [this word (Hlqwm), however, as well as the former, is sometimes applied to the throat, or gullet: but the former (Hlq) generally signifies the fauces; and the latter (Hlqwm), the windpipe: (see another explanation of the latter word in art. HaloqapN Hlq Hlqh Hlqp
HaloqapN [A single act of shaving]. One says to a beloved child, when he belches, HaloqapF wakaborapF waXaHomapF fiI AlsRurRapi, i. e. May thy head be shaven time after time, (Ibn-'Abbád, K, *) so that thou mayest grow old, (Ibn-'Abbád, TA,) [and acquire fat at the navel:] or mayest thou be preserved so as to have thy head shaven, and to grow old. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- As meaning A ring; i. e. anything circular; as a Hlqp of iron, and of silver, and of gold; (TA;) a Hlqp of a coat of mail, &c.; (Mgh;) the Hlqp of a door; and a Hlqp of people; (S, K;) in this last instance meaning a ring of people; (Msb, TA;) it is also with fet-h to the l; i. e. HalaqapN↓; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) mentioned by Yoo, on the authority of Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà, (S, Msb,) and with kesr; (K;) i. e. HaliqapN↓; mentioned by Fr and El-Umawee, as of the dial. of Belhárith Ibn-Kaab; accord. to the O; or HiloqapN↓, accord. to the L: (TA:) or there is no such word as HalaqapN↓, (S, K,) in chaste speech, (TA,) except as pl. of HaAliqN; (S, K;) accord. to Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee; (S;) or it is a dial. var. of weak authority; (K;) accord. to Th, allowed by all, though of weak authority; (S;) or it is used by poetic license; (Mgh:) Lh says that the Hlqp of a door is HaloqapN and HalaqapN↓; Kr says the same of the Hlqp of a company of men; Lth says that it is the former in this case, but that some say the latter; A 'Obeyd prefers the latter in the case of a Hlqp of iron, but allows the former; and prefers the former in the case of a Hlqp of people, but allows the latter; and Abu-l-'Abbás prefers the former in both cases, but allows the latter: (L:) the pl. is HalaqN↓, (S, Msb, K,) which is anomalous in relation to HaloqapN, (S, Msb,) or [rather] a quasipl. n., (TA,) but regular in relation to HalaqapN, (Msb, TA,) [as a coll. gen. n.,] like qaSabN in relation to qaSabapN; (Msb;) and, (K,) accord. to As, (S,) HilaqN, (S, K,) as pl. of HaloqapN meaning a Hlqp of men and of iron, (TA,) like bidarN (S, K) pl. of badorapN, and qiSaEN pl. of qaSoEapN; (S;) or this is a regular pl. of HiloqapN; (TA;) and HalaqaAtN, (AA,
Yoo, S, K,) which is pl. of HalaqapN; (TA;) and HilaqaAtN, (K,) which is pl. of HiloqapN; (TA;) and HilaAqN in relation to a company of men. (TA.) You say, AinotazaEotu Haloqatahu [lit. I pulled off his ring], meaning, (app., Ibn-'Abbád,) (assumed tropical:) I outwent him, or preceded him. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) And kaAlHaloqapi Almuforagapi [Like the solid and continuous ring]: a prov., applied to a company of men united in words and action. (TA.) And DarabuwA buyuwtahumo HilaAqFA They pitched their tents in one series, (K, TA,) so as to form a ring [or rings]: the last word being a pl. of HaloqapN or of HlqapN. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., nuhiIa Eani AlHilaqi qabola AlSRalaApi, i. e. Rings of men [sitting in the mosque before prayer are forbidden]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] HaloqataA AlrRaHimi (tropical:) [The two rings of the womb]: one of these is the mouth of the vulva, at its extremity; [the meatus of the vagina:] and the other is that which closes upon the maMC [or seminal fluid] and opens for the menstrual discharge; [the os uteri:] (K:) or, as some say, the other is that whence the urine is emitted; [the meatus urinarius: but the former is the right explanation: and hence] one says, maMC AlnRuTofapu fiI Haloqapi AlrRaHimi (tropical:) The seminal fluid fell into the entrance of the womb. (TA.) [Hence also,] Haloqapu AldRuburi (assumed tropical:) The anus; syn. HitaAruhu and Xarajuhu. (Mgh in art. Xrj.) [See also xaAtamN, last sentence but two.] ― -b3- HaloqapN also signifies A brand upon camels, (K, TA,) of a round form, like the Hlqp [or ring] of a door. (TA.) ― -b4- And A coat of mail: [because made of rings:] (K:) or coats of mail: (S, Mgh:) or arms, or weapons, in general, (M, Mgh, Msb,) and coats of mail, and the like. (M, TA.) It is said in a trad., UinRakumo Oaholu AlHaloqapi wAlHuSuwni [Verily ye are people of the coat of mail, &c., and of fortresses]. (TA.) ― -b5- And A rope. (K, TA.) ― -b6- And, of a vessel, (AZ, K,) and of a watering-trough, (AZ,) (tropical:) The portion that remains vacant after one has put in it somewhat (AZ, K) of food or beverage, up to the half; the portion that is above the half being thus called: (AZ:) [or] of a wateringtrough, (tropical:) the fulness; or less than that. (Aboo-Málik, K.) One says, wafRayotu Haloqapa AlHawoDi and AlUinaMCa (tropical:) [I filled up the Hlqp of the watering-trough and of the vessel]. (AZ, TA.)

HaAliqN HAlq
HaAliqN [Shaving: and] a shaver; (S, TA;) and a shearer of goats: (T, TA:) pl. HalaqapN: (T, S, K:) and HalRaAqN↓ is syn. with HaAliqN; (TA;) [or has an intensive signification, or denotes frequency of the action.] The saying laA tafoEalo caAka OumRuka HaAliqN means [Do not thou that:] may God cause thy mother to be bereft of her child so that she shall shave off her hair. (S.) And HaAliqapN occurs in a trad. as an epithet applied to a woman cursed by Mohammad; (TA;) meaning One who shaves off her hair in the case of an affliction: (K, TA:) or who shares her face for the sake of embellishment. (TA.) It is also applied to a wound on the head (XajRapN) That scrapes off the skin from the flesh. (TA in art. dmg.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Sharp; applied to a knife: (TA:) and so HaAluwqapN↓; applied to a sword; and also to a man. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) [Hence, perhaps,] fulaAnN HaAliqN UilaIRa biEayonihi (assumed tropical:) Such a one is looking at me intently, or sharply; as also muHalRiqN↓. (T, TA in art. znr.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Quick, or swift; and light, active, or agile. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Lean, or light of flesh; slender, and lean; or lean, and lank in the belly. (TA.) ― -b5- Accord. to A'Obeyd and the K, it means An udder: and accord. to the K, it means also full: (TA:) but it is an epithet applied to an udder; and thus applied, it has this latter meaning, i. e. (tropical:) full; (T, S, TA;) so ISd thinks; (TA;) as though the milk in it reached to its Haloq: (S, TA:) or big, so that it rubs off the hair of the thighs by reason of its bigness: (TA:) and it has also the contr. meaning; (T, TA;) raised (IAar, T, Kr, ISd, TA) towards the belly, (Kr, ISd, TA,) and contracted, (T, Kr, ISd, TA,) so that its milk has become scanty, (IAar, T, TA,) or has gone away: (Kr, ISd, TA:) pl. HulRaqN and HawaAliqu (S, TA) and HalaqapN. (TA. [The last is mentioned as pl. of HAlq in the latter sense.]) Accord. to As, OaSobaHato DarRapu AlnRaAqapi HaAliqFA means (assumed tropical:) The she-camel's udder became nearly full. (TA.) And one says naAqapN HaAlqN meaning A she-camel having much milk: (TA:) or having great abundance of milk, and a large udder: and UbilN muHalRiqapN↓ camels having much milk: (En-Nadr, TA:) and the pl. of HAlq is HawaAliqu and HulRaqN. (TA.) ― -b6- (tropical:) A high mountain, (S, K, TA,) rising above what surrounds it, and without vegetable produce: or, as some say, a mountain having no vegetable produce; as though it were shaven, or shorn; of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: but Z says that it is from HalRaqa, said of a bird: (TA:) and a high, or an overtopping or overlooking, place. (S.) One says also, hawaI mino HaAliqK, meaning (assumed tropical:) He fell from a high to a low place. (Har p. 37.) And its pl. HuluqN signifies (assumed tropical:) The vacant spaces between heaven and earth. (TA.) ＝ -A2- (tropical:) Unlucky (K, TA) to a people; as though peeling them; and so HaAliqapN↓, accord. to the copies of the K; but correctly HaAluwqapN↓, as in the O and Tekmileh. (TA.) ＝ -A3- A tendril, or twining portion, of a grape-vine, (S, K, TA,) and of a colocynth and the like, (TA,) hanging to the shoots: (S, K, TA:) because it has a circular form, like a Haloqap [or ring]. (T, TA.)

(TA.) ― -b3- See also HaAliqN, last sentence but one.

HuloquwmN The windpipe, or passage of the breath; (T, Mgh, TA;) by the cutting, or severing, of which, and of the mariIoC [or œsophagus] and wadajaAni [or two external jugular veins], the lawful slaughtering of an animal is completed: (T, TA:) accord. to the S and K, [and to the Msb, in art. Hlq, though it is there correctly and fully explained as meaning the windpipe,] i. q. HaloqN: but in the M it is explained [agreeably with general usage] as the passage of the breath, and of coughing, from the jawof [or chest]; consisting of a series of successively-superimposed cartilages (OaTobaAqu garaADiyfa), before which, in the exterior of the throat, is nothing but skin; having its lower extremity in the lungs, and its upper extremity at the root of the tongue: from it pass forth the breath and the wind and the saliva and the voice: [see also another explanation voce HaloqN, from Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán, ” and the Msb:] pl. HalaAqimu and HalaAqiymu. (TA.) Accord. to some, the m is augmentative: accord. to others, radical. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] they say, nazalonaA mivola Huloquwmi AlnRaEaAmapi, meaning (assumed tropical:) We alighted in a strait, or confined, place. (TA.) And HalaAqiymu AlbilaAdi means (assumed tropical:) The strait, or confined, parts of the country, or of countries: (Mgh:) or the lateral, and extreme, parts thereof. (TA.)

1 Halama Hlm
1. Halama, (S, Msb, K, [in the CK, erroneously, Haluma,]) aor.
Haluma
, inf. n. HulomN (Msb, TA) and HulumN, of which the former is a contraction, (Msb,) [both used also as simple substs.,] He dreamed, or saw a dream or vision (S, Msb, K) fiI nawomihi (K) in his sleep; (S, * Msb, K;) as also AHtlm↓ (S, ISd, Msb, K,) and AnHlm↓, (ISd, K,) and tHlRm↓. (K.) You say, Halama bihi, (S, K, [in the CK, again, erroneously, Haluma,]) and Eanohu, (K,)
and Eanohu tHlRm↓, (TA,) and Halamahu also, (S,) He dreamed, or saw a dream or vision, of it: (S, K:) or he saw it in sleep. (M, K.) And Halama biAlmaroOapi He (a man) dreamed in his sleep that he was compressing the woman. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] HulomN and AiHotilaAmN↓ signify [The dreaming of] copulation in sleep: (K:) and the verbs are Halama and AHtlm↓. (TA.) And [hence,] both signify The experiencing an emission of the seminal fluid; properly, in dreaming; and tropically if meaning, without dreaming, whether awake or in sleep, or by extension of the signification. (TA.) And hence, (Mgh,) Halama, (Mgh, Msb,) aor.
Haluma
, inf. n. HulomN; (Mgh;) and AHtlm↓; (Mgh, Msb;) He (a boy) attained to puberty, (Msb,) [or] to virility. (Mgh, Msb.) ＝ -A2- Haluma, with damm [to the l], inf. n. HilomN, (S, Msb, K,) [He was, or became, forbearing, or clement;] he forgave and concealed [offences]: or he was, or became, moderate, gentle, deliberate, leisurely in his manner of proceeding or of deportment &c., patient as meaning contr. of hasty, grave, staid, sedate, or calm; (S, K;) and (assumed tropical:) intelligent: (K:) or he managed his soul and temper on the occasion of excitement of anger. (TA.) [See HilomN below.] You say, Haloma Eanohu and tHlRm↓ [He treated him with forbearance, or clemency, &c.]: both signify the same. (TA.) And yaHolumu EamRano yasubRuhu [He treats with forbearance, or clemency, &c., him who reviles him]. (TA in art. Hml.) ＝ -A3- Halima, aor.
Halama
, (K,) inf. n. HalamN, (TA,) He (a camel) had [upon him] many ticks, such as are termed Halam. (K.) ― -b2- Also the same verb, (S, K,) with the same inf. n., (S,) It (a hide, or skin,) had in it worms, such as are termed Halam, (S, K, TA,) whereby it was spoilt and perforated, (S, TA,) so that it became useless. (TA.) A poet says, (S,) namely, El-Weleed Ibn-'Okbeh, TA,)
faUinRaka waAlkitaAba UilaI EaliIRK
kacaAbigapK waqado Halima AlOadiymu
[For verily thou, as to the letter, or writing, to 'Alee, art like a woman tanning when the hide has become spoilt and perforated by worms]: (S, TA:) he was urging Mo'áwiyeh to contend in battle with 'Alee, [as though] saying to him, Thou labourest to rectify a matter that has become completely corrupt, like this woman who tans the hide that has become perforated and spoilt by the Halam. (TA.) [The latter hemistich of this verse is a prov.: see Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 346.] ＝ -A4- Halamahu, (K,) inf. n. HalomN, (TA,) He plucked the Halam from it; [app., accord. to the K, the worms thus called from a hide, or skin;] as also HlRmhu↓: (K:) or, accord. to Az, he took from him, namely, a camel, the [ticks called] Halam. (TA.)

2 HlRmhu Hlm Hlmh Hlmp
2. HlRmhu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. taHoliymN (S, K) and HilRaAmN, like kicRaAbN, (K,) signifies jaEalahu HaliymFA [i. e. He made him to be forbearing, or clement, &c.; or he pronounced him to be so; or he called him so; or he held, or believed, or though, him to be so]: (S, K:) or he enjoined him AlHilom [i. e. forbearance, or clemency, &c.]: (K:) or he attributed to him AlHilom. (Mgh, Msb.) ＝ -A2- Hlm [so in the TA, evidently HlRm, (see 5, its quasi-pass.,)] also signifies It fattened a lamb, or kid; said of sucking. (TA.) ― -b2- And He filled a skin. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also 1, last sentence.

4 AHlmt AHlmt
4. AHlmt She (a woman) brought forth HulamaMC [i. e. children that were forbearing, or clement, &c.]. (K.)

5 tHlRm Hlm tHlm
5. tHlRm: see 1, first and second sentences. ― -b2- Also He affected, or pretended, to dream, or see a vision in sleep: whence, in a trad., taHalRama maA lamo yaHolumo [He affected, or pretended, to have dreamed that which he did not dream]. (TA.) And He asserted himself falsely to have dreamed, or seen a vision in sleep. (TA.) And tHlRm AlHuloma i. q. AisotaEomalahu [He feigned the dream; or made use of it as a pretext]. (K.) ＝ -A2- He affected, or endeavoured to acquire, (takalRafa) [the quality termed] AlHilom [i. e. forbearance, or clemency, &c.]. (S, K.) A poet says,
taHalRamo Eani AlOadonayona waQsotaboqi wudRahumo
walano tasotaTiyEa AlHiloma HatRaI taHalRamaA
[Endeavour thou to treat with forbearance the meaner sort of people, and preserve their love; for thou wilt not be able to be forbearing unless thou endeavour to be so]. (S.) ― -b2- See also Haluma Eanohu. ― -b3- [Hence,] taHalRamati Alqidoru (tropical:) The cooking-pot ceased to boil; contr. of jahilat (TA in art. jhl.) ― -b4- See also 6. ＝ -A3- It became fat; said of the [kind of lizard called] DabR; (L in art. mlH;) and likewise of cattle: (K:) [or] it became fat and compact; said of a child, and of the DabR: (S:) [or] it began to be fat; said of a child, and of the DabR, (K,) and of the jerboa, and of the quraAd [or tick]; in the K, erroneously, jaraAd. (TA.) ― -b2- taHalRamati Alqirobapu The skin became full. (TA.)

6 tHAlm tHAlm
6. tHAlm He made a show of having AlHilom [i. e. forbearance, or clemency, &c.], not having it; (S, TA; *) and tHlRm↓ [in like manner] signifies [sometimes] he made a show of AlHilom; expl. by OaZohara AlHiloma. (TA in art. fSH.)

7 UinoHalama
7: see 1.

8 UiHotalama
8: see 1, in four places.

HalomN Hlm
HalomN: see HilomN.

HulomN Hlm
HulomN an inf. n. of Halama; as also HulumN↓. (Msb.) ― -b2- And A dream, or vision in sleep; (S, K;) as also HulumN↓: (K:) accord. to most of the lexicologists, as well as F, syn. with ruWoyaA: or it is specially such as is evil; and rWyA is the contr.: this is corroborated by the trad., AlrRuWoyaA mina QllRehi waAlHulomu mina AlXRayoTaAni [The rWyA is from God, and the Hlm is from the Devil]: (MF:) and by the phrase, in the Kur [xii. 44 and xxi. 5], OaDogaAvu OaHolaAmK [The confused circumstances of dreams, or of evil dreams]: but each is used in the place of the other: (TA:) OaHolaAmN is the pl. (K.) ― -b3- OaHolaAmu naAYimK [lit. The dreams of a sleeper;] a kind of thick cloths, or garments, (IKh, Z, TA,) striped, of the people of El-Medeeneh. (Z, TA.)

HilomN Hlm
HilomN [Forbearance; clemency;] the quality of forgiving and concealing [offences]: (Msb:) or moderation; gentleness; deliberateness; a leisurely manner of proceding, or of deportment, &c.; patience, as meaning contr. of hastiness: gravity; staidness; sedateness; calmness: syn. OanaApN: (S, K:) or these qualities with power or ability [to exercise the contrary qualities]; expl. by OanaApN and sukuwnN with qudorapN and quwRapN: (Kull p. 167:) or the management of one's soul and temper on the occasion of excitement of anger: (TA:) or tranquillity on the occasion of emotion of anger: or delay in requiting the wrongdoer: (KT:) it is described by the term viqalN, or gravity; like as its contr. [safahN] is described by the terms xiqRapN and EajalN, or levity, or lightness, and hastiness: (TA in art. rjH:) also (assumed tropical:) intelligence; (K;) which is not its proper signification, but a meaning assigned because it is one of the results of intelligence: and HalomN↓, with fet-h, is likewise said to have this last meaning; but this requires consideration: (TA:) the former is one of those inf. ns. that are [used as simple substs., and therefore] pluralized: (ISd, TA:) the pl. [of pauc.] is OaHolaAmN and [of mult.] HuluwmN. (K.) Hence, in the Kur [lii. 32], Oamo taOomuruhumo OaHolaAmuhumo bihecaA (K,) said to mean (assumed tropical:) Do their understandings enjoin them this? (TA.) And Ouwluw AlOaHolaAmi, occurring in a trad., means (assumed tropical:) Persons of understanding. (TA.)

HalamN Hlm
HalamN: see HalamapN, in two places.

HalimN Hlm
HalimN A camel having [upon him] many ticks, such as are called Halam. (K.) And A camel spoilt by the abundance of those ticks that were upon him. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A hide, or skin, spoilt and perforated by [the worms termed] Halam: and HaliymN↓, [in like manner,] a hide, or skin, spoilt by the Halam before it is stripped off. (TA.) And EanaAqN HalimapN A she-kid whose skin has been spoilt by the Halam; (K, * TA;) as also taHolimapN↓, of which the pl. is taHaAlimu: (K:) the pl. of HalimapN is HilaAmN. (TA.)

HulumN Hlm
HulumN: see HulomN, in two places. ― -b2- Also A [dream of] copulation in sleep. (K.) Hence, balaga AlHuluma He attained to puberty, or virility, in an absolute sense. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [xxiv. 58], waUicaA balaga AlOaTofaAlu minokumu AlHuluma faloyasotaOocinuwA [And when your children attain to puberty, or virility, they shall ask permission to come into your presence]. (TA.) [And hence,] OaDoraAsu AlHulumi, (also called OaDoraAsu AlEaqoli, TA in art. Drs,) [The teeth of puberty, or wisdom-teeth,] so called because they grow after the attaining to puberty, and the completion of the intellectual faculties: (S, L, Msb, all in art. njc:) they are four teeth that come forth after the [other] teeth have become strong. (TA in art. Drs.)

HalamapN Hlm Hlmh Hlmp
HalamapN A small tick: (K:) or a large tick; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) like EulRN; (S;) and said to be
like the head [or nipple, when small,] of a woman's breast: (Msb:) or a tick in the last stage of its growth; for at first, when small, it is called qamoqaAmapN; then, HamonaAnapN; then, quraAdN; and then, HalamapN: (As, TA:) the pl., (S,) or [rather] coll. gen. n., (Mgh, Msb,) is HalamN↓. (S, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- And hence, as being likened thereto, (Mgh,) (assumed tropical:) The head [or nipple, when small,] of a woman's breast, (T, S, Mgh,) in the middle of the saEodaAnap [or areola]; (T, TA;) in like manner called quraAdN: (Mgh:) the little thing rising from the breast of a woman: (TA:) the HabRap [or small extuberance like a pimple] upon the head of the breast of a woman: (Msb:) the vuWoluwl [or small excrescence] in the middle of the breast of a woman: (K:) and the head [or nipple] of each of the two breasts of a man: (Msb:) the two together are termed iHalamataAn: (S:) the protuberant piece of flesh is termed HalamapN as being likened in size to a large tick. (Msb.) ― -b3- Also A certain worm, incident to the upper and lower skin of a sheep or goat, (As, S,) in consequence of which, when the skin is tanned, the place thereof remains thin: (S:) or a certain worm, incident to skin, which it eats, so that, when the skin is tanned, the place of the eating rends: pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] HalamN↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- And A species of plant; (S, K;) accord. to As, also called yanamapN: (S:) As is also related to have said that it is a plant of the kind termed EuXob, having a dusty hue, a rough feel, and a red flower: another says that it grows in Nejd, in the sands, has a blossom, and roughish leaves, and thorns resembling the nails of a man; and that the camels suffer adhesion of the spleen to the side, and their young are cast, [for wtzl AxyAkhA (an evident mistranscription in the TA), I read watzilRu OaHobaAluhA,] when they depasture it from the dry branches: accord. to AHn, it is [a plant] less than a cubit [in height], having a thick, or rough, leaf, and branches, and a flower like that of the anemone, except that it is larger, and thicker, or rougher: accord. to the K, it signifies also the tree [or plant] called saEodaAn; which is one of the most excellent kinds of pasture: but Az says, it has nothing in common with the sEdAn, which is a herb having round [heads of] prickles; whereas the Hlmp has no prickles, but is a well-known kind of janobap; and I have seen it: (TA:) [Dmr, accord. to Golius, describes it as “ a herb less than the arnoglossa ” (or arnoglossum), “ whitening in the leaves, and downy. ”]

HaliymN Hlym
HaliymN Having Hilom [i. e. forbearance, or clemency, &c.; forbearing, or clement, &c.]: (Mgh, Msb, K:) pl. HulamaMCu and OaHolaAmN. (K.) In the Kur xi. 89, it is said to be used by way of scoffing [or irony]. (TA.) AlHaliymu is one of the names of God; meaning [The Forbearing, or Clement, &c.; or] He Whom the disobedience of the disobedient does not flurry, nor anger against them disquiet, but Who has appointed to everything a term to which it must finally come. (TA.) ― -b2- HaliymapN mugotaAZapN (tropical:) [lit. Calm, angry; or the like; because what it contains is sometimes still and sometimes boiling;] is an appellation given to a stone cooking-pot. (A and TA in art. gyZ.) ＝ -A2- A fat camel: (S:) or a camel becoming fat. (ISd, K.) ISd says, I know not any unaugmented verb belonging to it in this sense. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And Coming fat. (ISd, K.) ＝ -A4- See also HalimN.

HaAlimN HAlm
HaAlimN originally signifies muHotalimN↓ [i. e. Dreaming: and particularly dreaming of copulation: and experiencing an emission of the seminal fluid in dreaming]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Hence used in a general sense, (Mgh,) meaning One who has attained to puberty, or virility; (A Heyth, Mgh, Msb, TA;) as also muHotalimN↓. (Msb, TA.)

HaAluwmN HAlwm
HaAluwmN A sort of OaqiT [q. v.; i. e. a certain preparation of dried curd]: (ISd, K:) or milk that is made thick, so that it becomes like fresh cheese; (S, K;) but this it is not: (S:) a word of the dial. of Egypt. (TA.)

OaHolaAmN c
OaHolaAmN Bodies; syn. OajosaAmN. (ISd, K.) ISd says, I know not any sing. of it [in this sense]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- It is also pl. of HulomN: ＝ -A3- and of HilomN: ＝ -A4- and of HaliymN. (K.)

taHolimapN Hlm tHlmh tHlmp
taHolimapN: see HalimN.

muHotalimN mHtlm
muHotalimN: see HaAlimN, in two places.

And in like manner, HalaAliI [It was, or became, sweet to me]. (Msb.) And Haluwati AlfaAkihapu, aor.

HlI) and fiI SadorI (ISd) is from AlHaloIu, (ISd, K,) meaning the thing that is worn, because it signifies It was beautiful in my eye, like the HaloI; not from HalaAwapN; (ISd, and TA in art. HlI;) but this saying is not valid, nor approved. (TA in the present art.) Accord. to Lh, one says, Haliyati AlmaroOapu biEayoniI and fiI EayoniI, and biqalobiI and fiI qalobiI, aor.

, inf. n. HalaAwapN; and Halato, aor.

, inf. n. HalaAwapN; [The woman was pleasing in my eye, and in my mind, or heart.] (TA.) ― -b3- maAyamurRu wamaA yaHoluw (tropical:) He is not bitter at one time, and he is not sweet at another. (IAar, K, TA. [In some copies of the K, walaA yaHoluw.]) And OamarRu waOaHoluw and OamurRu waOaHoluw (tropical:) I am bitter at one time, and I am sweet at one time. (IAar, M in art. mr.) [See also 4.] ＝ -A2- HaliIa AlXRaIoCa, aor.
Halawa
, (K,) inf. n. HalaAwapN; (TK;) and AstHlAhu↓, (S, Msb, K,) from AlHalaAwapu, like AstjAdhu from Aljawodapu, (S,) [the most common form,] and tHlRAhu↓, (K,) and AHlwlAhu↓, (S, K,) which is the only trans. verb of its measure except one other, in the phrase AiEoraworayotu Alfarasa; (S;) all signify the same; (K;) He esteemed the thing sweet [both properly and metaphorically as is indicated in the TA]: (Msb in explanation of the second of these verbs, and TK in explanation of all of them:) and [in like manner] OaHolayotuhu↓ I found it to be sweet: (S, K:) or this signifies I made it sweet: (K:) or it has both of these significations: (S:) you say, OaHolayotu hecaA AlmakaAna, meaning AisotaHolayotuhu↓ [I esteemed, or found, this place to be sweet, or pleasant]. (TA.) And Haliyatohu AlEayonu [The eye esteemed, or found, him, or it, to be pleasing, or goodly, or beautiful]. (IAar, TA in art. HlI.) ― -b2- HaliIa minohu bixayorK, (K,) aor.

; (TA;) and HalaA, (K,) aor.

; (TA;) He found, or experienced, or he got, or obtained, from him, or it, good. (K.) [See also 1 in art. HlI.] ＝ -A3- HalaAhu AlXRaIoCa, (Msb, * K,) or HalaAhu kacaA maAlFA, (S,) aor.

, (S, Msb,) inf. n. HalowN (S, K [in the CK Hulow]) and HulowaAnN, (S,) He gave him (S, Msb, K) the thing, (K,) or such a piece of property, [as a gratuity,] for something that he had done; not as hire, or pay, or wages. You say, HalaAhu, inf. n. HalowN [in the CK HulowN, and HuluwRN also,] and HulowaAnN, He gave him in marriage his daughter, or his sister, (K, TA,) or any woman, (TA,) for a certain dowry, on the condition that he should assign to him a certain portion of it. (K, TA.) ＝ -A4- Halawotu AlmaroOapa i. q. HalayotuhaA, i. e. I assigned, or gave, to the woman HuliIR [or ornaments]. (S.)

2. HlRAhu, (S, K, [erroneously written in the CK without the sheddeh,]) inf. n. taHoliyapNu, (K,) He made it sweet; (S, K;) namely, food; (S;) or a thing; (K;) as also AHlAhu↓: (S:) and so HalRaOahu, which is anomalous: (K:) sometimes they said, HalRaOotu AlsRawiyqa [I sweetened the meal of parched barley, or the mess made thereof]; pronouncing with hemz that which is not [properly] with hemz: (S:) this is said by Lth to be a mistake on their part. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] HalRayotu AlXRaIoCa fiI Eayoni SaAHibihi [I made the thing to seem pleasing, or goodly, or beautiful, in the eye of its possessor]. (S.)

3. HaAlayotuhu, (inf. n. muHaAlaApN, TK,) (tropical:) I jested, or joked, with him. (S, K, TA.)

(assumed tropical:) He said not anything: (S, TA:) or the meaning is similar to that of the phrase next following. [See a similar phrase near the middle of the first paragraph.] ― -b3- See also another signification in the first paragraph. ― -b4- maA OaHolaAhu [How sweet, &c., is it!] is said by some to be an instance of a verb having a dim. form; so that you say, maA OuHayolaAhu↓ [How very sweet, &c., is it!]; like maA OumayoliHahu [q. v.]. 5. tHlRAhu: see 1.

6. taHaAlato She (a woman) affected, or made a show of, sweetness, and self-conceitedness. (S.)

10: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- AstHlAhu also signifies He sought [to elicit] its, or his, sweetness. (TA.)

12. AHlwlI: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- [Hence,] said of a man, He was, or became, sweet in disposition. (IAar.) ＝ -A2- AHlwlAhu: see 1.

HalFA Hl HlA
HalFA A medicine mixed, or moistened, with water or the like. (K.)

HulowN Hlw
HulowN Sweet; contr. of murRN; (S, K;) i. e., in the mouth: and in like manner, in the eye [meaning pleasing, or goodly, or beautiful: see 1]: (TA:) applied also to a saying, and to an action: (K:) fem. with p. (Msb.) And AlHulowu AlHalaAlu (assumed tropical:) Language in which is nothing that induces doubt, or suspicion: (K and TA in art. Hl:) and the man in whom is nothing that induces doubt, or suspicion. (TA in the present art.) Hulowuwna, and pl. fem. HilowN: (K:) there is no broken pl., masc. or fem. (TA.)

HulowN Hlw
HulowN A small HafR [q. v., in the CK, erroneously, xufR,] with which one weaves: (K, TA:) or the wooden thing which the weaver turns round: [app. meaning the yarn-beam, upon which the yarn is rolled; termed HafRapN:] the poet Shemmákh likens the tongue of a braying [wild] ass to a Hilow that has slipped from the back of a loom. (TA.)

HalowaI: see HalowaMCu.

HulowaI Hlw HlwI Hlwy Hlwyy
HulowaI: see OaHolaI.

HalowaMCu HlwMC
HalowaMCu and HalowaI↓, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) the latter mentioned by As, of the fem. gender, (TA,) [Sweetmeat; as also HalaAwapN↓; (see HalRaMCN, below;) this last and HalowaI used in this sense in the present day;] an eatable, (T, S, M, Msb,) well known, (K,) prepared with sweetness; (T, M, Msb;) said to be peculiarly applied to such as is prepared with art [as distinguished from such as in naturally sweet]: (TA:) the HlwAC mentioned in a trad. is said to be that which is termed majiyE [made of dates kneaded with milk]: (MF, TA:) the pl. of HalowaI is HalaAwaI, with fet-h to the w. (Msb.) ― -b2- The former is also applied by some to Fruit: syn. faAkihapN: (T, TA:) or both, (K,) or the former, (TA,) to sweet fruit. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also HulaAwap.

HulowaAnN Hlw HlwAn
HulowaAnN is a subst. [as well as an inf. n.], signifying A gift: (Msb:) [a gratuity: so in the present day:] the hire, or pay, of a broker; (Lh, K;) and of a diviner, (As, S, * Msb, * K,) for divination, (As,) which is forbidden in a trad.: (S, Msb:) and a requital; see 1. (IAar, K.) Also The dowry, or nuptial gift, of a woman: (Msb, K:) [or a portion thereof which the father or guardian of the bride used, in some cases, to take for himself; see 1:] or a gift to a woman in consideration of having her as a wife during a certain fixed period; (K;) according to a practice obtaining in Mekkeh: (TA:) or a gift of the nature of a bride. (K.)
