(K.) ＝ -A2- Blackness; (S, TA;) the colour denoted by the epithet OaHamRu [q. v.]: (S, K:) a colour between duhomap [or blackness] and kmotap [or a blackish red], inferior [in depth, or brightness,] to what is termed HuwRap [app. as meaning redness inclining to blackness]. (M, K.) ― -b2- The black sediment of clarified butter, and the like, in the bottom of the skin. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also i. q. HubRapN: so in the phrases fulaAnN HumRap nafosiI [Such a one is the beloved of my soul] (Az, TA) and huwa mino HumRapi nafosiI [He is of the beloved of my soul]: and the m is said to be a substitute for b. (TA.) [See also OaHamRu, which is used as syn. with OaHabRu.]

HimRapN Hm Hmh Hmp
HimRapN: see HamiymN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also Death; or the decreed term of life: (K:) pl. HimamN. (TA.)

HumamN Hmm
HumamN Charcoal: (S, Mgh, K:) or cold charcoal: (TA:) or burnt wood and the like: (Msb:) or charcoal that does not hold together: (Msb in explanation of the n. un. in art. qbs:) and ashes: and anything burnt by fire: (S, TA:) n. un. with p: (S, Msb, K:) which is tropically applied to (tropical:) live coals [or a live coal]. (Msb.) [Hence] the n. un. is also used as meaning (assumed tropical:) Blackness of complexion. (TA from a trad. of Lukmán Ibn- 'Ád.) And jaAriyapN HumamapN means (assumed tropical:) A black girl or female slave. (TA. [See also OaHamRu.])

HamaAmN HmAm
HamaAmN [The pigeon, both wild and domestic, but more properly the former; and sometimes not strictly confined to denote the pigeon-kind:] a certain wild bird, that does not keep to the houses; well-known: (ISd, K:) or any collared, or ringed, bird; (S, Msb, K;) so with the Arabs; such as the fawaAxit and the qamaAriIR and saAqu HurR and the qaTaA and the waraAXiyn and the like, (S, Msb,) and the domestic [pigeons] (AldRawaAjin), also, (El-Umawee, S, Msb,) that are taken into houses for the purpose of producing their young ones; (El-Umawee, S;) to which last alone the term is applied by the vulgar: accord. to Ks, it is the wild [species]; and the yamaAm is that which keeps to the houses: accord. to As, the latter is the HamaAm waHoXiIR [or wild pigeon]; a species of the birds of the desert: (S, Msb:) or, accord. to Esh-Sháfi'ee, HamaAmN signifies any kind of bird that drinks in the manner denoted by the verb EabRa, [i. e. continuously,] and cooes; including the qamaAriIR and waraAXiyn and fawaAxit; whether it be, or be not, collared, or ringed; domestic or wild: (Az, TA:) the flesh
thereof strengthens the venereal faculty, and increases the seminal fluid and the blood; the putting it, cut open while alive, upon the place stung by a scorpion, is a proved cure; and the blood stops bleeding from the nose: (K:) the n. un. is with p; (S, Msb;) which is applied to the male and the female: (S Msb, K:) and in like manner, HamaAmN, because the p is added to restrict to unity, not to make fem.: (S:) but to distinguish the masc., you may say, raOayotu HamaAmFA EalaI HamaAmapK, i. e. I saw a male [pigeon] upon a female [pigeon]: (Zj, Msb:) accord. to ISd and the K, however, HamaAmN should not be applied to the [single] male: (TA:) in a verse of Homeyd Ibn-Thowr, cited voce HurRN, by the n. un. is meant a qumoriyRap: the pl. of HmAmp is HamaAmN, (S,) [or rather this is the coll. gen. n.,] and HamaAYimu (S, K) and HamaAmaAtN: (S:) and sometimes HamaAmN is used as a sing.: [so in an ex. above: and] Jirán-el-'Owd says,
wacakRaraniI AlSRibaA baEoda AltRanaAYiI
HamaAmapu OayokapK tadoEuw HamaAmaA
[And a female pigeon of a thicket, calling a male pigeon, reminded me of youth, after estrangement]: a poet also says,
HamaAmaA qaqorapK waqaEaA faTaAraA
[Two pigeons of a desert tract alighted and flew away]: and El-Umawee cites, as an ex. of HamaAm applied to the domestic [pigeons],
qawaATinFA makRapa mino wuroqi AlHamaI
[Inhabiting Mekkeh, of the pigeons of a white colour inclining to black]; by AlHmI [or rather it should be written AlHamaA] meaning AlHamaAm. (S.)

HumaAmN HmAm
HumaAmN The fever (HumRaI) of camels; (S;) as also HumRaMCu↓: (TA:) or of all beasts, (K, TA,) including camels: (TA:) accord. to ISh, when camels eat date-stones, [which are often given to them as food,] they are [sometimes] affected with HumaAm and qumaAH; the former of which is a heat affecting the skin, until the body is smeared with mud, or clay, in consequence of which they forsake the abundant herbage, and their fat goes away; and it continues in them a month, and then passes away. (Az, TA.) ― -b2- HumaAmu qurRK The disease termed muwm, which affects men. (TA.) ― -b3- See also HamiymN. ＝ -A2- A noble chief, or lord: (K:) thought by Az to be originally humaAmN. (TA.)

HimaAmN HmAm
HimaAmN: see its syn. HumRapN; of which it is also a pl. (K.)

HamiymN Hmym
HamiymN The qayoZ [or summer: or the most vehement heat of summer, from the auroral rising of the Pleiades (at the epoch of the Flight about the 13th of May O. S.) to the auroral rising of Canopus (at the same period about the 4th of August O. S.): or vehemence of heat]: (S, K:) or a period of about twenty nights, commencing at the [auroral] rising of AldRabaraAn [at the epoch of the Flight about the 26th of May O. S.]. (AZ, T voce nawoCN.) ― -b2- Live coals with which one fumigates. (IAar, Sh.) ― -b3- Hot water; (T, S, ISd, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also HamiymapN↓: (S, ISd, K:) or so maMCN HamiymN: (Msb:) pl. HamaAYimu; (K;) i. e. pl. of HamiymN, accord. to IAar; but accord. to ISd, of HamiymapN. (TA.) ― -b4- And Cold water: (K:) or cold, applied to water: so, accord. to IAar, in the saying of a poet,
wasaAga liIa AlXRaraAbu wakunotu qidomFA
OakaAdu OagaSRu biAlmaMCi AlHamiymi
[And wine has become easy to swallow to me, whereas I used, in old time, nearly to be choked with cold water]: (Az, TA:) thus bearing two contr. significations. (Az, K.) ― -b5- The rain that comes in the time of vehement heat; (S;) or after the heat has become vehement, (M, K,) because it is hot; (M;) or in the Sayof [or summer], when the ground is hot. (TA.) ― -b6- (tropical:) Sweat; (Az, S, A, K;) as also HimRapN↓: (Az, A, K:) and HumaAmN↓ is said to signify the sweat of horses. (Ham p. 92.) One says, (to a person who has been in the bath, A, TA,) TaAba Hamiymuka and TaAbato HimRatuka↓, meaning May thy sweat be good, or pleasant; (Az, A, K;) and consequently, may God make thy body sound, or healthy: (A, TA:) or the former may mean as above, or may thy bathing be good, or pleasant: (IB:) one should not say, TaAba HamRaAmuka↓, (K, TA,) though MF defends it. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A relation, (Lth, S, K,) for whose case one is anxious or solicitous, (S,) or whom one loves and by whom one is beloved: (Lth, K:) or an affectionate, or a compassionate, relation, who is sharp, or hasty, to protect his kinsfolk: or an object of love; a person beloved: (TA:) or a man's brother; his friend, or true friend; because anxious, or solicitous, for him: (Ham p. 90:) and muHimRN↓ signifies the same: the pl. [of Hmym] is OaHimRaMCu: and sometimes HamiymN is used as a pl., and as fem.; (K;) as well as sing. and masc. (TA.) ― -b2- AlHamiymu biAlHaAjapi He who devotes himself to obtain the object of want; who is solicitous for it. (TA.) A poet says,
walaA yudoriku AlHaAjaAti UilRaA HamiymuhaA
[And none will attain the objects of want but he who devotes himself to obtain them; who is solicitous for them]. (IAar, TA.)

HamaAmapN HmAm HmAmh HmAmp
HamaAmapN n. un. of HamaAmN [q. v.]. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] (assumed tropical:) A woman: or a beautiful woman. (K, TA. [In the CK, only the latter.]) ＝ -A2- The middle of the breast or chest. (K, TA.) The qaSR [or breast, or head of the breast, or pit at the head of the breast, or middle of the breast, or the sternum,] of a horse. (K.) The callous protuberance upon the breast of a camel. (K.) ― -b2- The sheave of the pulley of a bucket. (K.) ― -b3- The ring of a door. (K.) ― -b4- The clean court of a qaSor [or palace, &c.]. (K.) ＝ -A3- See also the next paragraph.

HamiymapN Hmym Hmymh Hmymp
HamiymapN: see HamiymN. ― -b2- Also Heated milk. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also, (S, K,) as well as HamRN↓, (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, HumR,]) sing. of HamaAYimu signifying (tropical:) Such as are held in high estimation, precious, or excellent, or the choice, or best, (S, K, TA,) of cattle or other property, (S,) or of camels: (K:) and accord. to Kr, the sing. is used as a pl. in this sense: (ISd, TA:) HamaAmapN↓, likewise, signifies the choice, or best, of cattle or other property; and so HaAmRapN↓, of camels: (K:) or you say UibilN HaAmRapN, meaning excellent, or choice, camels. (S.)

HumayomapN Hmym Hmymh Hmymp
HumayomapN; accord. to the K, HumayomaAtN, but this is the pl.; (TA;) A live coal; syn. jamorapN: (K, TA:) or redness; syn. HumorapN: (CK, and so in a MS. copy of the K:) [in Freytag's Lex., the pl. is explained as meaning redness of the skin; and so HumaAmaI↓.]

HumaAmaI HmAm HmAmI HmAmy
HumaAmaI: see what next precedes.

HamaAmiIRN HmAm HmAmI HmAmy
HamaAmiIRN One who flies pigeons (HamaAm), and sends them [as carriers of letters] to various towns or countries. (TA.)

HumRI Hm HmI Hmp Hmy
HumRI, (S, K, &c.,) a subst. from HumR, (Lh, L, K,) imperfectly decl., because of the fem. alif [which terminates it], (Msb,) A fever; a disease by which the body becomes hot: from AlHamiymu: said to be so called because of the excessive heat; whence the trad., AlHumRaI mino fayoHi jahanRama [Fever is from the exhalation of Hell]: or because of the sweat that occurs in it: or because it is of the signs of AlHimaAm [i. e. the decreed, or predestined, case of death]; for they say, AlHumRaI raAYidu Almawoti [Fever is the messenger that precedes death], or bariydu Almawoti [the messenger of death], or baAbu Almawoti [the gate of death]: (TA:) and HumRapN↓ signifies the same: (K, TA:) pl. of the former HumRayaAtN. (Msb.)

HumRaMCu HmMC
HumRaMCu: see HumaAmN.

HamRaAmN HmAm
HamRaAmN [A hot bath;] a certain structure, (S,) well known; (Msb;) so called because it occasions sweating, or because of the hot water that is in it; accord. to ISd, derived from AlHamiymu; (TA;) i. q. dayomaAsN: (K:) of the masc. gender, (Mgh, K,) and fem. also, (Mgh,) generally the latter; (Msb;) but some say that it is a mistake to make it fem., (MF, TA,) though IB cites a verse in which a fem. pronoun is asserted to refer to a HmRAm: (TA:) pl. HamRaAmaAtN; (S, Mgh, K;) accord. to Sb, [not because the sing. is fem., but] because, though masc., it has no broken pl. (TA.) See also HamiymN.

HamRaAmiIRN HmAm HmAmI HmAmy
HamRaAmiIRN The owner [or keeper] of a HamRaAm [or hot bath]. (Mgh.)

HumoHumN HmHm
HumoHumN: see OaHamRu.

HimoHimN HmHm
HimoHimN: see OaHamRu, in two places.

HaAmRapN HAm HAmh HAmp
HaAmRapN The xaASRap [or particular, or special, friends, or familiars], (S, K,) consisting of the family and children (K) and relations, (TA,) of a man. (K.) You say, kayofa AlHaAmRapu waAlEaAmRapu [How are the particular, or special, friends, &c., and the common people?]. (S.) And heWulaMCi HaAmRapu AlrRajuli These are the relations of the man. (Lth, S.) [See HumRapN, and OaHmRu.] ― -b2- See also HamiymapN. ― -b3- Also
i. q. EaAmRapN. (K.) [It would seem that this signification might have been assigned to it in consequence of a misunderstanding of the words in the S, waAlHaAmRapu AlxaASRapu yuqaAlu kayofa AlHaAmRapu waAlEaAmRapu: but accord. to the TK, one says, jaAWuwA HaAmRapF, meaning EaAmRapF, i. e. They came generally, or universally.]

Mlu HaAmiyma Ml HAmym
Mlu HaAmiyma and cawaAtu HaAmiyma, (K,) or Mlu HemL↓ and cawaAtu HemL, (S,) Ml being prefixed in this case in like manner as in Mlu fulaAnK, (Fr, S,) Certain chapters of the Kur-án (S, K) commencing with HAmym [or HemL], (K,) [namely, the fortieth and six following chapters,] called by Ibn-Mes'ood diybaAju AlquroMni: (S:) one should not say HawaAmiym: (K:) this is vulgar: (S:) but it occurs in poetry. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) accord. to I'Ab, HemL↓ is One of the names of God; (Mgh;) or it is the most great name of God; (K;) occurring in a trad., in which it is said, Uino buyRitRumo faquwluwA HemL laA yanoSaruwna, meaning If ye be attacked by night, say ye HemL; and when ye say this, they shall not be made victorious: (Mgh:) or the meaning is, [say ye] O God, they shall not be made victorious; not being an imprecation; for were it so, it would be laA yunoSaruwA: (IAth, TA:) or it is an oath; (Mgh, K;) and the meaning of the trad. is, [say ye] By God, they shall not be made victorious: but HemL is not among the numbered names of God: it has therefore been deemed preferable to understand it as here meaning the seven chapters of the Kur-án commencing therewith: (Mgh:) or it is an abbreviation of AlrRaHomenu, wanting the letters Alrn to complete it: (Zj, K:) or, as some say, it means [HumRa maA huwa kaAYinN, i. e.] quDiIa maAhuwa kaAYinN [What is taking place has been decreed]. (Az, TA.) It is imperfectly decl. because determinate and of the fem. gender; or because it is of a foreign measure, like qaAbiylu and haAbiylu, (Ksh, Bd,) and determinate. (Ksh.)

OaHamRu c
OaHamRu Black; (S, K;) applied to anything; as also yaHomuwmN↓, (K,) and HmiHimN↓, (As, K,) or this signifies intensely black, (S,) and HumoHumN↓, (K,) which IB explains as a black hue of dye: (TA:) [the fem. of the first is HamRaMCu: and the pl. HumRN: and] the pl. of ↓the second is yaHaAmiymu, and by poetic license yaHaAmimu. (Sb, TA.) You say, rajulN OaHamRu A black man. (S.) And rajulN OaHamRu Almuqolatayoni A man having black eyes. (TA.) And kumayotN OaHamRu [A blackish bay horse]: pl. kumotN HumRN; which are the strongest of horses in skin and hoofs. (S.) And XaApN HimoHimN↓ A black sheep or goat. (TA.) And layolN OaHamRu Black night. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlHamRaMCu The anus (saAfilap, S, or Aisot, K) of a human being: (S:) pl. HumRN. (S, K.) ― -b3- And OaHamRu An arrow before it has been furnished with feathers and a head; syn. qidoHN. (K.) ― -b4- HamRaMCu applied to a lip (XafapN) and to a gum (livapN) means Of a colour between duhomapN and kumotapN. (M, TA. [See HumRapN.]) ― -b5- Accord. to some, (TA,) OaHamRu also signifies White: thus having two contr. meanings. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A more, or most, particular, or special, and beloved, friend or the like. (Az, TA. [See HumRapN, and HamiymN, and HaAmRapN.])

muHimRN mHm
muHimRN: see maHamRapN: ＝ -A2- and see also HamiymN.

miHamRN mHm
miHamRN i. q. qumoqumapN: (Mgh, Msb;) i. e. A vessel of copper [or brass], in which water is heated, (KL, and Msb in art. qm,) having a long and narrow neck: (KL:) or a small qumoqum [here meaning the same as qumoqumap], in which water is heated. (S.)

maHamRapN mHm mHmh mHmp
maHamRapN, applied to food [&c.], (TA,) Any cause of fever; or a thing from the eating of which one is affected with fever: (K, * TA:) such, for instance, the eating of fresh ripe dates is said to be. (TA.) And OaroDN maHamRapN (S, M, K) and muHimRapN↓, (M, K,) mentioned by AAF, but not known by the lexicologists except as agreeable with analogy, [see its verb, 4,] (M, TA,) A land in which is fever: (S, K:) or in which is much fever. (K.)

maHomuwmN mHmwm
maHomuwmN Fevered, or affected with fever, or sick of a fever. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ＝ -A2- Applied to water, like mavomuwdN [q. v.]. (Az, TA.) ＝ -A3- Decreed, or appointed. (S, TA.)

muHaAmRN mHAm mHAmy
muHaAmRN Keeping constantly, firmly, steadily, steadfastly, or fixedly, EalaI OamorK to an affair. (AZ, K. *)

musotaHamRN mstHm
musotaHamRN, (TA,) or musotaHamRapN, (Mgh,) A place in which one washes with hot water. (Mgh, * TA.)

yaHomuwmN yHmwm
yaHomuwmN: see OaHamRu, in two places. ― -b2- Also Smoke: (S, M, K:) or black smoke: (Bd in lvi. 42:) or intensely black smoke. (Jel ibid. and TA.) ― -b3- A black mountain: (K:) or a certain black mountain in Hell. (TA.) ― -b4- The canopy, or awning, that is extended over the people of Hell: so, as some say, in the Kur lvi. 42. (TA.) ― -b5- A certain bird: (K:) so called because of the blackness of its wings. (TA.) ― -b6- nabotN yaHomuwmN A plant, or herbage, green, full of moisture, and black. (TA.)

1 HamaOa AlbiYora c
1. HamaOa AlbiYora, (S, K,) aor.
HamaAa
, (K,) inf. n. HamoCN, (S,) He cleansed the well of its HamoOap [or black, fetid mud]. (S, K.) In the T, this signification is assigned to AlbYr AHmO↓; and the signification assigned below to the latter is given to HmO: but As says that he does not find this authorized by usage. (TA.) ＝ -A2- HamiYa, aor.
HamaAa
, inf. n. HamoCN and HamaON, It (water) was, or became, mixed with black, fetid mud, and so rendered turbid, (K, TA,) and altered in odour. (TA.) And HamiYati AlbiYoru, inf. n. HamaON, The well had in it black [fetid] mud (S, Msb) in abundance: (S:) and the like is also said of a spring. (TA.) ＝ -A3- HamiYa Ealayohi He was angry with him; (El-Umawee, S, K;) as also HamiIa. (Lh, TA.)

4 AHmO AlbiYora c
4. AHmO AlbiYora, (ISk, S, K,) inf. n. UiHomaMCN, (ISk, S,) He threw HamoOap [or black, fetid mud] into the well. (ISk, S, K.) ― -b2- See also 1.

HamoCN HmC
HamoCN and HamN and Hamuw [only used as a prefixed n. governing the gen. case (see HamN in art. Hmw)] and HamFA (S, Msb, K) and HamaON↓ (K) A woman's husband's father; (IF, Msb, K;) and a man's wife's father: (IF, Msb:) or a man's wife's father or wife's brother or wife's paternal uncle: (M, Msb:) or any one of a woman's husband's [male] relations, (S, O, K,) as the brother and the father (S, O) and the paternal uncle; (O, TA;) and of a man's wife's relations: (K:) pl. OaHomaMCN: (S, K:) the fem. is HamaAopN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also HamoOapN.

HamaON c
HamaON: see HamoCN: ＝ -A2- and see also what next follows.

HamoOapN c
HamoOapN (S, Msb, K) and HamaON↓, (S, K,) but accord. to some, the latter is the pl. [or rather quasipl. n.] of the former; and sometimes, by poetic license, it is written HamoCN↓; (TA;) Black mud: (S, Msb:) or black fetid mud. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also, the former, A certain plant, (K,) that grows in Nejd, in the sands, and in plain, or soft, land. (TA.)

HamiYu AlEayoni c
HamiYu AlEayoni A man of an evil eye, (Fr, K,) who injures with his eye him whom he sees and admires: no verb belonging to it has been heard. (Fr, TA.) ＝ -A2- HamiYapN A well (biYor) or a spring (Eayon) foul with black, fetid mud. (TA.)

1 Hamidahu Hmd Hmdh Hmdp
1. Hamidahu, aor.
Hamada
, inf. n. HamodN (S, L, Msb, K) and maHomadN and maHomidN (L, K) and maHomadapN (S, L, K) and maHomidapN; (L, K, and so in a copy of the S;) the last of these inf. ns. [and the third also] extr.; (L;) or the last is an inf. n. and the last but one signifies “ a praiseworthy quality, ” or “ a quality for which one is praised; ” (ElFenáree, MF;) or the last may be a simple subst.; (Har p. 392;) He praised, eulogized, or commended, him; spoke well of him; mentioned him with approbation; (Akh, S, L, Msb;) EalaI kacaA for such a thing; (L, Msb;) contr. of camRahu: (S, L:) accord. to IAmb, formed by transposition from madaHa: (marginal note in a copy of the MS:) but it is of less common application than the latter verb; (Msb in art. mdH;) signifying he praised him, &c., for something depending on his (the latter's) own will: thus, the describing a pearl as clear is not HamodN, but it is madoHN: (Kull p. 150:) or i. q. Xakarahu: (Lh, K:) but it differs [sometimes] from this; (Msb;) for XukorN is only on account of favour received; whereas HamodN is sometimes because of favour received, (Th, Az, Msb,) and sometimes from other causes; (Th;) [and thus] the latter is of more common application than the former; (S;) therefore you do not say, Xakarotuhu EalaI XajaAEatihi; but you say, Hamidotuhu ElI XjAEth I praised him, &c., for his courage. (Msb.) Hmd also implies admiration: and it implies the magnifying, or honouring, of the object thereof; and lowliness, humility, or submissiveness, in the person who offers it; as in the saying of the afflicted, AlHamodu lilRehi Praise be to God; since in this case there is no worldly blessing, favour, or
benefit. (Msb.) This last phrase is generally pronounced as it is written above: but some of the Arabs are related to have pronounced it AlHamoda lilRehi, putting the former word in the accus. case as the absolute complement of the verb OaHomadu understood: and others, AlHamodililRehi; assimilating the final vowel of the former word to the vowel immediately following it: and others, AlHamodu lulRehi; assimilating the first vowel in llReh to the vowel immediately preceding it: Zj, however, disapproves of the latter two modes of pronouncing it: some of them also said, badaOotu biAlHamodu lilRehi, meaning I began with the saying Praise be to God. (L.) [See also HamodN below.] You say, OaHomadu Uilayoka QllReha I praise God (Az, A, * L, K) to thee, or in thy presence: (L:) or with thee: (Kh, Az:) or I praise to thee God's benefits, and his blessings, or favours; or I praise to thee God's blessings, or favours, and discourse to thee of them. (L.) And Hamida lahu OamorFA (tropical:) He approved of a thing for him. (L, K. *) And Hamida Uilayohi OamorFA (tropical:) He approved of a thing for him, and commanded, or enjoined, him to do it. (L.) And jAwarotuhu famaA Hamidotu jiwaArahu (tropical:) [I became his neighbour, and did not approve of being so]. (A.) See also 4. ― -b2- Also, (aor. and inf. n. as above in the beginning of this art., K,) He recompensed, or requited, him: he gave him, or paid him, his due. (L, K.) ＝ -A2- Hamida Ealayohi, aor.
Hamada
, (L, K, *) inf. n. HamadN, (TA,) He was angry with him. (L, K.)

2 HmRd Hmd
2. HmRd, inf. n. taHomiydN, has a more intensive signification than Hamda; (S;) [He declared the praises of God: or] he praised God much, with good forms of praise (biAlmaHaAmidi AlHasanapi): (T, L:) or repeatedly; or time after time. (L, K.) tHmyd [used as a simple subst.] has a pl., namely, taHaAmiydu. (A.) [See an ex. voce xaAtamN, in the latter part of the paragraph.]

4 AHmd AHmd OHmd Hmd
4. AHmd He (a man, S) came to a state, or result, such as was praised, or commended, or approved; properly, his affair, or case, came to such a state or result: (S, L, K:) or (so in the K, but in the L “ and ”) he did, or said, that for which he should be praised, or commended; or that which was praiseworthy, or commendable; (A, L, K; *) contr. of OacamRa. (A.) And AHmd Oamoruhu (assumed tropical:) His affair, or case, was, or became, praiseworthy, or approvable, in his estimation: (K:) or AHmd Oamorahu (as in the L) he esteemed his affair, or case, praiseworthy, or approvable. (L [agreeably with what next follows].) ＝ -A2- AHmdhu He found him (a man, A, L) [or it] to be such as is praised, commended, or approved; or praiseworthy, commendable, or approvable; (S, A, L, Msb;) contr. of OacamRahu: (TA in art. cm:) he made it manifest that he was worthy of praise, eulogy, commendation, or approbation: (L:) he approved of his action, and his course of conduct, or his tenet or tenets, and did not expose it, or them, to others. (K.) And OaHomadotu SaniyEahu (tropical:) [I found his action to be praiseworthy, or commendable, or approvable]. (A.) And AHmd AlOaroDa (tropical:) He approved the land as a dwelling-place: (A:) or he found the land to be such as is praised, commended, or approved; as also HamidahaA↓; (L, K;) but the former verb is the more chaste in this sense. (L.) And AHmd mawoDiEFA (tropical:) He found a place to be such as is praised, commended, or approved, and convenient, or suitable, so that he approved it as a dwelling-place, or for its pasture. (S, L.)

5 tHmRd Hmd tHmd
5. tHmRd He affected, or made a show of, (takalRafa,) praise. (A.) You say, wajadotuhu mutaHamRidFA↓ mutaXakRirFA [I found him affecting, or making a show of, praise and thanks]. (A.) ― -b2- He praised himself. (KL.) [Golius assigns this meaning to AHtmd↓, as on the authority of the KL; but it is not assigned to this verb in my copy of the KL.] ― -b3- fulaAnN yataHamRadu AlnRAs [app. a slight mistranscription, for lilnRaAsi, i. q. UilaI AlnRaAsi, as in an ex. in the next sentence but one,] Such a one pretends to men, or shows them, that he is praiseworthy, bijuwdihi for his liberality. (L.) ― -b4- tHmRd Ealayohi He reproached him for a favour, or benefit, which he (the former) had bestowed, or conferred; or recounted his gifts, or actions, to him; syn. AimotanRa. (S, L, K.) One says, mano Oanofaqa maAlahu EalaI nafosihi falaA yataHamRado bihi EalaI AlnRaAsi [Whoso expends his property upon himself, he shall not reproach men therewith as for favours, or benefits, bestowed]: (S, A:) or flA ytHmRd bih UilaI AlnRaAsi [he shall not pretend to men that he is praiseworthy on account of it]: a prov., meaning that a man is not praised for his beneficence to himself, but for his beneficence to others. (L.)

6 tHAmdwA tHAmdwA
6. tHAmdwA (tropical:) [They praised, or commended, a thing, one to another]. You say, AlrRuEaMCu yataHaAmaduwna AlkalaOa (tropical:) [The pastors praise, or commend, one to another, the herbage]. (A.)

8 AHtmd AHtmd
8. AHtmd: see 5. ＝ -A2- Said of heat, [It burned, or burned fiercely; or was, or became, vehement:] formed by transposition from AHtdm. (S.)

entry.key: AisotaHomidi QllReha UilaI xaloqihi biUiHosaAnihi Uilayohimo wUinoEaAmihi

superEntry.entry:
10 AisotaHomidi QllReha UilaI xaloqihi biUiHosaAnihi Uilayohimo wUinoEaAmihi c
10. AisotaHomidi QllReha UilaI xaloqihi biUiHosaAnihi Uilayohimo wUinoEaAmihi Ealayohimo [so I find it written, as though meaning Demand thou, of his creatures, the praising of God, by reason of his beneficence to them, and his bounty to them: but I think that we should read AisotaHomada QllRehu, and that the meaning is, God hath demanded praise of his creatures by his beneficence, &c.]. (A.)

HamodN Hmd
HamodN Praise, eulogy, or commendation; &c. (S, &c. [For further explanations of this word, and respecting the phrase AlHamodu lilRehi and its variations, see 1: and see also Xakara.]) suboHaAnaka QllRehumRa wabiHamodika, said by a person praying, means [I extol, or celebrate, or declare, thy remoteness, or freedom, from every impurity, or imperfection, &c., O God, (see art. sbH,)] and I begin with praising Thee; OabotadiYu being understood: (Az, L, Msb:) or by bHmdk is meant AlHamodu laka praise be to Thee: and nearly the same is said in explanation of the phrase in the Kur [ii. 28], nusabRiHu biHamodika, that by bHmdk is meant HaAmidiyna laka: [see, again, art. sbH:] or by the expression wbHmdk is meant, accord. to Aboo-'Othmán ElMázinee, and by praising Thee I extol thy remoteness, or freedom, from every impurity, &c.; sabRaHotuka being understood: or the w is redundant, as it is in the phrase, rabRanaAwalaka AlHamodu [O our Lord, praise be to Thee], in which the w is sometimes omitted: or, accord. to Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà, the w is corroborative, as in the phrase, wahuwa laka, for huwa laka. (Msb.) liwaMCu AlHamodi biyadiI yawoma AlqiyaAmapi [The standard of praise shall be in my hand on the day of resurrection (said by Mohammad)] means that he shall be singularly distinguished by praise, or praising, on that day. (L.) ― -b2- See HamaAdi: ― -b3- and HumaAdaAka. ＝ -A2- See also HamiydN. ＝ -A3- It is also said to signify The young one of the kind of bird called qaTFA: so in the prov.,
Hmodu qaTaApK yasotamiI AlOaraAniba
A young one of a katà desires to make the hares its prey: applied to a weak man who desires to insnare a strong one. (Meyd, TA.) ＝ -A4- See also what next follows.

HamadapN Hmd Hmdh Hmdp
HamadapN The sound of the flaming, or blazing, of fire; (S, K;) as also HadamapN [from which it is formed by transposition: see 8: and HamodN↓ app. signifies the same: see HadomN]. (TA.)

HumadapN Hmd Hmdh Hmdp
HumadapN: see HamRaAdN.

HamaAdi lahu HmAd lh HmAd lp
HamaAdi lahu Praise, and thanks, be to him: (S, L, K:) i. e., to such a one: (S, L:) contr. of jamaAdi lahu [q. v.]. (S and A in art. jmd.) HamaAdi is indecl., with kesr for its termination, because it deviates from its original, which is the inf. n. [AlHamodu↓]: (S, L:) [i. e.,] it is [a quasi-inf. n., (see Aisomu maSodarK in art. Sdr,) being] a proper name for AlmaHomadapu [as syn. with AlHamodu]. (Sharh Shudhoor edh-Dhahab.)

HamuwdN Hmwd
HamuwdN: see what next follows.

HamiydN Hmyd
HamiydN and maHomuwdN↓ (S, A, L, K) and HamuwdN↓ (as in copies of the K, but this seems to be an intensive epithet,) Praised, eulogized, or commended; spoken well of; mentioned with approbation; approved; such as is praised, &c.; praiseworthy, laudable; commendable, or approvable: (S, L, K: [in which, as well as in numberless exs., all these significations are clearly indicated, though not so clearly explained; the Arabic words to which they apply exactly agreeing with the Latin “ laudatus, ” which means both “ praised ” and “ praiseworthy: ”]) the fem. of the first is with p, (L, K,) because the signification, though properly that of a pass. part. n., nearly agrees with that of an act. part. n.: (L:) you say, [hiIa HamiydapN She is praised, &c.; and] OafoEaAluhu HamiydapN (tropical:) [His actions are praised, &c.]. (A.) HamodN↓, also, [originally an inf. n., like its contr. camRN,] used as an epithet applied to a man, is syn. with maHomuwdN; (K;) and as an epithet applied to a woman, syn. with maHomuwdapN, (TA,) as is also HamodapN: (K, TA:) and you likewise say manozilN HamodN (K) and manozilahN HamodapN (Lh) (assumed tropical:) A place where one alights, sojourns, or abides, such as is praised, or approved, (K, TA,) and convenient, or suitable.
(TA.) AlHamiydu, meaning He who is praised, or praiseworthy, in every case, is an epithet applied to God; one of the names termed AlOasomaMCu AlHusonaI. (L.) AlmaqaAmu AlmaHomuwdu↓ [mentioned in the Kur xvii. 81] means (assumed tropical:) The station in which its occupant shall be praised by all creatures [on the day of resurrection] because of his being quickly reckoned with, and relieved from long standing: or it is the station of the intercessor. (L.)

HumaAdaAka Oano tafoEala kacaA c
HumaAdaAka Oano tafoEala kacaA (S, L, K *) and Hamoduka↓ (L) The utmost of thy power, or of thine ability, [or the utmost of thy praiseworthy actions, (see an ex. of the pl. in what follows,) will be] thy doing such a thing; syn. mabolagu jahodika, (L,) or quSaAraAka, (S, L,) and gaAyatuka: (S, L, K:) and in like manner, HumaAdiI The utmost of my power, &c. (K.) HumaAdayaAtu AlnRisaMCi gaDRu AlTRarofi, said by Umm-Selemeh, means The utmost of the praiseworthy qualities of women is the lowering of the eye. (L.)

HamRaAdN HmAd
HamRaAdN (TA) and HumadapN↓ (A, K) A man (TA) who praises things much; a great, or frequent, praiser: (A, K, TA:) or the latter, a man who praises things much and extravagantly. (S.) You say, UinRahu laHamRaAdN lilRehi Verily he is one who praises God much, or repeatedly, or time after time. (L, K.)

AlEawodu OaHomadu c
AlEawodu OaHomadu is a prov., (S,) meaning (tropical:) Repetition is more attributive of praise (Oakovaru HamodFA): (S, A, K:) for generally you do not desire to return to a thing save after experience, or knowledge, [and approbation,] thereof: [the act of returning, therefore, implies praise:] or the meaning is, when one begins a kind act, he attracts praise to himself; and when one repeats, he gains more praise for himself: or AHmd is from the pass. part. n., and the meaning is, the beginning is praised, or praiseworthy; and repetition is more deserving of being praised. (K.) [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 130]

maHomadapN mHmd mHmdh mHmdp
maHomadapN (S, Mgh) and maHomidapN (Mgh) (assumed tropical:) [A cause of praise, commendation, or approval; a praiseworthy, commendable, or approvable, quality or action;] a thing for which one is, or is to be, praised, commended, or approved: (Mgh:) [see 1, first sentence:] contr. of macamRapN: (S:) [pl. maHaAmidu.] You say, hecaA TaEaAmN layosato Einodahu maHomidapN, with kesr to the second m, (tropical:) [This is food in which is no approvable quality;] the eating of which is not approved. (A.) ― -b2- [The pl.] maHaAmidu signifies [also] (assumed tropical:) Forms of praise. (Msb in art. jmE; &c.) [See 2.]

muHamRadN mHmd
muHamRadN A man praised much, or repeatedly, or time after time: (L, K:) endowed with many praiseworthy qualities. (S, L.)

maHomuwdN mHmwd
maHomuwdN: see HamiydN, in two places.

yawomN muHotamidN ywm mHtmd
yawomN muHotamidN A day intensely, or vehemently, hot: (K:) as also muHotadimN [from which it is formed by transposition: see 8]. (TA.)

mutaHamRidN mtHmd
mutaHamRidN: see 5.

Q. 1 Hamodala Hmdl
Q. 1. Hamodala, (Msb and TA in art. bsml,) inf. n. HamodalapN, (K,) He said AlHamodu lilRehi: (K, and Msb and TA ubi suprà:) a word of the kind termed manoHuwtN. (TA.)

1 Hamara OHmr HmAr Hmr
1. Hamara, (S, K,) aor.
Hamura
, (S,) inf. n. HamorN, (TA,) He pared a thong; stripped it of its superficial part: (S, K:) or he (a sewer of leather or of skins) pared a thong by removing its inner superficial part, and then oiled it, previously to sewing with it, so that it became easy [to sew with; app. because this operation makes it to appear of a red, or reddish, colour]. (Yaakoob, S.) ― -b2- And [hence,] He pared, or peeled, anything; divested or stripped it of its superficial part, peel, bark, coat, covering, crust, or the like: and HmrR↓, inf. n. taHomiyrN, signifies the same in an intensive degree, or as applying to many objects; syn. qXRr. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, (S, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S,) He skinned a sheep [and thus made it to appear red]. (S, K.) ― -b4- He shaved the head [and thus made it to appear red, or of a reddish-brown colour, the common hue of the Arab skin]. (K.) And Hamarati AlmaroOapu jilodahaA [The woman removed the hair of her skin]. (TA.) The term HamorN is [also] used in relation to soft hair, or fur, (wabar,) and wool. (TA.) ― -b5- Hamarahu biAlsawoTi He excoriated him (qaXarahu) with the whip. (TA.) ― -b6- Hamara AlOaroD, aor. and inf. n. as above, It (rain) removed the superficial part of of the ground. (TA.) ― -b7- Hamarahu biAllRisaAni (assumed tropical:) He galled him (qaXarahu) with the tongue. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Hamira, aor.
Hamara
, (Lth, S, K,) inf. n. HamarN, (Lth, S,) He (a horse) suffered indigestion from eating barley: or the odour of his mouth became altered, or stinking, (K, TA,) by reason thereof: (TA:) or he became diseased from eating much barley, (Lth,) or he suffered indigestion from eating barley, (S,) so that his mouth stank: (Lth, S:) and in like manner one says of a domestic animal [of any kind]: part. n. HamirN↓. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Hamira EalaIRa, (Sh, K, *) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Sh,) He (a man) burned with anger and rage against me. (Sh, K. *) ＝ -A4- Hamirati AldRaAbRapu, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) [The horse] became like on ass in stupidity, dulness, or want of vigour, by reason of fatness. (K.)

2 HmRr OHmr HmAr Hmr
2. HmRr, inf. n. taHomiyrN: see 1. ― -b2- Also He cut [a thing] like pieces, or lumps, of flesh-meat. (K.) ― -b3- He dyed a thing red. (Msb.) ― -b4- [He wrote with red ink. ― -b5- See also taHomiyrN, below.] ＝ -A2- He called another an ass; saying, O ass. (K.) ＝ -A3- He rode a miHomar; i. e. a horse got by a stallion of generous race out of a mare not of such race; or a jade. (A, TA.) ＝ -A4- He spoke the language, or dialect, of Himyer; (S, K;) as also taHamoyara↓. (K.)

4 AHmr AHmr OHmr Hmr QHmr
4. AHmr He (a man, TA) had a white child (waladN OaHomaru,) born to him. (K.) ＝ -A2- He fed a beast so as to cause its mouth to become altered in odour, or stinking, (K, TA,) from much barley. (TA.)

5 tHmRr Hmr tHmr QHmr
5. tHmRr He asserted himself to be related to [the race of] Himyer: or he imagined himself as though he were one of the Kings of Himyer: thus explained by IAar. (TA.)

7 AnHmr maA EalaI Aljilodi AnHmr mA Ely Aljld
7. AnHmr maA EalaI Aljilodi [What was upon the skin became removed]: said of hair and of wool. (TA.)

9 AHmrR AHmr OHmr Hmr QHmr
9. AHmrR, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. AiHomiraArN, (K,) It became OaHomar [or red]; (Msb, K;) as also AHmArR↓: (K:) both these verbs signify the same: (S:) or the former signifies it was red, constantly, not changing from one state to another: and ↓the latter, it became red, accidentally, not remaining so; as when you say, jaEala yaHomaArRu marRapF wayaSofaArRu OuxoraI He, or it, began to become red one time and yellow another. (TA.) [It is also said that] every verb of the measure AifoEalRa is contracted from AifoEaAlRa; and that the former measure is the more common because [more] easy to be pronounced. (TA.) ― -b2- AHmrR AlbaOosu (tropical:) War, or the war, became vehement, or fierce: (S, A, IAth, Msb, K:) or the fire of war burned fiercely. (TA.)

11 UiHomaAorRa
11: see 9, in two places.

Q. Q. 2 taHamoyara tHmyr
Q. Q. 2. taHamoyara: see 2. ― -b2- Also He (a man, TA) became evil in disposition. (K.)

HamrN OHmr HmAr Hmr
HamrN, applied to a horse &c.: see Hamira. ＝ -A2- Also A man burning with anger and rage: pl. Hamiruwna. (Sh.)

HumarN OHmr HmAr Hmr
HumarN (incorrectly written, by some physicians and others, HumRarN↓, with teshdeed, MF) and HawomarN↓ (which is of the dial. of the people of 'Omán, a form disallowed by MF, but his disallowal requires consideration, TA) The tamarindfruit: (K:) it abounds in the Saráh (AlsRaraAp) and in the country of 'Omán, and was seen by AHn in the tract between the two mosques [of Mekkeh and El-Medeeneh]: its leaves are like those of the xilaAf called AlbaloxiIR: AHn says, people cook with it: its tree is large, like the walnut-tree; and its fruit is in the form of pods, like the fruit of the qaraZ. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, the former word, Asphaltum, or Jews' pitch; bitumen Judaicum; syn. qaforN yahuwdiIRN. (Ibn-Beytár: see De Sacy's Abd-allatif, ” p. 274.) ＝ -A3- See also HumRarN.

HumorapN OHmr HmAr Hmr Hmrh Hmrp
HumorapN [Redness;] a well-known colour; (Msb, K;) the colour of that which is termed OaHomaru: (S, A:) it is in animals, and in garments &c.; and, accord. to IAar, in water [when muddy; for it signifies brownness, and the like: but when relating to complexion, whiteness: see OaHomaru]. (TA.) ― -b2- AlHumorapu [Erysipelas: to this disease the term is evidently applied by Ibn-Seenà, in vol. ii. pp. 63 and 64 of the printed Arabic text of his qAnwn; and so it is applied by the Arabian physicians in the present day:] a certain disease which attacks human beings, in consequence of which the place thereof becomes red; (ISk, TA;) a certain swelling, of the pestilential kind; (T, K;) differing from phlegmone. (Ibn-Seenà ubi suprà.) ― -b3- cuw HumorapK Sweet: applied to fresh ripe dates. (K.) ― -b4- See also HimirRN.

HamoraI OHmr HmAr Hmr HmrI Hmry
HamoraI: see HamaArRapN.

HamoraMCu HmrMC
HamoraMCu [originally fem. of OaHomaru, q. v.]: see HamaArRapN.

HimirRN OHmr HmAr Hmr
HimirRN Violent rain, (S,) such as removes the superficial part of the ground. (S, K.) ― -b2- A severe night-journey to water. (TA.) ＝ -A2- The most copious portion of rain; and violence thereof. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The violence, vehemence, or intenseness, of anything; as also HimirRapN↓ and HumorapN↓. (TA.) ― -b3- See also HamaArRapN, in two places. ― -b4- Also The evil, or mischief, of a man. (K.)

HimirRapN OHmr HmAr Hmr Hmrh Hmrp
HimirRapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

HimaArN HmAr
HimaArN [The ass;] the well-known braying quadruped; (TA;) i. q. EayorN; (Az, S;) applied to the male; (Msb;) both domestic and wild: (Az, K:) the former is also called HimaArN OaholiIRN; (Msb;) and the latter, HimaArN waHoXiIRN, (K,) and HimaAru AlwaHoXi, and yaHomuwrN↓: (S, K:) OataAnN is the appellation applied to the female; and sometimes HimaArapN↓: (S, Msb, K: *) pl. [of pauc.] OaHomirapN and [of mult.] HamiyrN↓ [more properly termed a quasi-pl. n.] and HumurN (S, Msb, K) and HumorN (S) and HumuwrN and maHomuwraMCu↓, (K,) the last [a quasi-pl. n.] of a very rare form [of which see instances voce XayoxN], (TA,) and HumuraAtN, (S, K,) which is said to be a pl. of HumurN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] muqayyRidapu AlHimaAri (assumed tropical:) A stony tract, of which the stones are black and worn and crumbling, as though burned with fire; syn. HarRapN: because the wild ass is impeded in it, and is as though he were shackled. (TA.) ― -b3- And [hence,] banuw muqayRidapi AlHimaAri (assumed tropical:) Scorpions: because they are generally found in a HarRap. (TA. [See an ex. in verses cited voce rumoHN.]) ＝ -A2- A piece of wood in the fore part of the [saddle called] raHol, (K, TA,) upon which a woman [when riding] lays hold: and in the fore part of the [saddle called] UikaAf: and, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, the stick upon which [the saddles called] OaqotaAb [pl. of qatabN] are carried. (TA.) ― -b2- The wooden implement of the polisher, upon which he polishes iron [weapons &c.]. (Lth, K. *) ― -b3- Three pieces of wood, (T, K,) or four, (T,) across which is placed another piece of wood; with which one makes fast a captive. (T, K.) [The last words of the explanation are yuWosaru bihaA.]) ― -b4- HimaAru AlTRunobuwri [The bridge of the mandoline;] a thing well-known. (TA.) ― -b5- HamaAru qabRaAna [The wood-louse; so called in the present day;] a certain insect; (S, K;) a certain small insect, (Msb, TA,) that cleaves to the ground, (TA,) resembling the beetle, but smaller, (Msb,) and having many legs: (Msb, TA:) when any one touches it, it contracts itself like a thing folded. (Msb.) The HmAr qbRAn is also called HimaAru Albayoti; app. because its back resembles a qubRap. (TA in art. qb, q. v.) ― -b6- HimaAraAni Two stones, (S, K,) which are set up, (S,) and upon which is placed another stone, (S, K,) which is thin, (TA,) and is called EalaApN, (S,) whereon [the preparation of curd called] OaqiT is dried. (S, K.) ― -b7- AlHimaAraAni The two bright stars [a and HamiyrN] in Cancer. (Kzw.)

HamiyrN HmAr Hmyr
HamiyrN Anything pared, or peeled; divested, or stripped, of its superficial part, peel, bark, coat, covering, crust, or the like; as also maHomuwrN↓. (TA.) [See 1.] ― -b2- Also, and HamiyrapN↓, i. q. OuXokuzRN, i. e. A thong, or strap, (S, K,) white, and having its outside pared, (S,) in a horse's saddle, (K,) or with which horses' saddles are bound, or made fast: (S:) so called because it is pared. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also HimaArN.

HamaArapN HmAr HmArh HmArp
HamaArapN: see HamaArRapN.

HimaArapN HmAr HmArh HmArp
HimaArapN: see HimaArN. ― -b2- Also A great, (K,) or great and wide, (TA,) mass of stone, or rock: (K:) and stones set up around a watering-trough or tank, to prevent its water from flowing forth: (S:) and a stone, (K,) or stones, (S,) set up around the booth in which a hunter lurks: (S, K:) but J should have said that HamaAYiru signifies stones: that HimaArapN is the sing.: that this latter signifies any wide stone: and the pl., stones that are set round a watering-trough or tank, to prevent the water from overflowing: (IB:) and HamaAYiru AlmaMCi signifies four large and smooth masses of stone at the head of the well, upon which the drawer of the water stands. (TA in art. xlq.) Also, the sing., A wide stone that is put upon a trench or an oblong excavation, in the side of a grave, in which the corpse is placed: (K:) or upon a grave: (TA:) pl. as above. (K.) ― -b3- A piece of wood in the [woman's vehicle called] hawodaj. (K.) ― -b4- Three sticks, or pieces of palm-branches, having their [upper] ends bound together and their feet set apart, upon which the [vessel of skin called] UidaAwap is hung, in order that the water may become cool. (TA.) And its pl., HamaAYiru, Three pieces of wood bound together [in like manner], upon which is put the waTob [or milk-skin], in order that the [insect called] HuroquwS may not eat it. (TA.) ― -b5- HimaArapu Alqadami, (K,) or Alqdm HmArRp↓ [thus, without any vowel-sign written], with teshdeed to the r, (IAth,) The elevated, or protuberant, part of the foot, above the toes (K, TA) and their joints, where the food of the thief is directed, in a trad., to be cut off. (TA.)

HimaAriIRN HmAr HmArI HmAry HmAryy
[HimaAriIRN Of, or relating to, asses; asinine.]

HimaAriyRapN HmAr HmAryh HmAryp
HimaAriyRapN [Asinineness]. (A in art. xTb.)

HamiyrapN HmAr Hmyrh Hmyrp
HamiyrapN: see HamiyrN.

HumayoraMCu HmyrMC
HumayoraMCu dim. of HamoraMCu, fem. of OaHomaru, q. v.

AlHimoyariyRapu AlHmyryh AlHmyryp
AlHimoyariyRapu The language, or dialect, of [the race of] Himyer, who had words and idioms different from those of the rest of the Arabs. (TA.)

HamaArRN HmAr
HamaArRN: see what next follows.

HamaArRapN HmAr HmArh HmArp

OaHomaru c
OaHomaru [Red: and also brown, or the like:] a thing of the colour termed HumorapN: (Msb, K:) it is in animals, and in garments &c.; and, accord. to IAar, in water [when muddy]: and so yaHomuwrN↓: (K:) fem. of the former HamoraMCu: (Msb:) pl. HumorN and HumoraAnN: (K:) or when it means dyed with the colour termed HumorapN, the pl. is HumorN (S, Msb) and HumoraAnN; for you say viyaAbN HumorN and HumoraAnN [red garments]: (TA:) but if you apply it as an epithet to a man, [in which case it has other meanings than those explained above, as will be shown in what follows,] the pl. is OaHaAmiru (S) and HumorN: (TA:) or if it means a thing having the colour termed HumorapN, the pl. is OaHaAmiru, because, in this case, it is a subst., not an epithet. (Msb.) OaHomariIRN↓ also signifies the same as OaHomaru: (Ham p. 379:) or, as some say, it has an intensive sense. (TA voce karuwbiyRuwna.) It is said in the S, in art. dk, that HamoraAwaAtN is a pl. of HamoraMCu, like as dakRaAwaAtN, is of dakRaMCu; but it is not so. (IB in that art.) ― -b2- Applied to a camel, Of a colour like that of saffron when a garment is dyed with it so that it stands up by reason of [the thickness of] the dye: (TA:) or of an unmixed red colour; (As, S in art. kmt, and TA;) and so the fem. when applied to a she-goat. (TA.) It is said that, of she-camels, the HamoraMC is the most able to endure the summer midday-heat; and the waroqaMC, to endure nightjourneying; and that the SahobaMC is the most notable and the most beautiful to look at: so said Aboo-Nasr En-Na'ámee: and the Arabs say that the best of camels are the Humor and the Suhob. (TA.) [Hence,] Humoru AlnRaEami signifies (assumed tropical:) The high-bred, or excellent, of camels: and is proverbially applied to
anything highly prized, precious, valuable, or excellent. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b3- Applied to a man, (AA, Sh, Az,) White (AA, Sh, Az, K) in complexion; (Az;) because OaboyaDu might be considered as of evil omen [implying the meaning of leprosy]: (AA, Sh:) or, accord. to Th, because the latter epithet, applied to a man, was only used by the Arabs as signifying “ pure, ” or “ free from faults: ” but they sometimes used this latter epithet in the sense of “ white in complexion, ” applied to a man &c.: (IAth:) fem., in the same sense, HamoraMCu: the dim. of which, HumayoraMCu↓, occurs in a trad., applied to 'Áïsheh. (K, * TA.) So, accord. to some, in the trad., buEivotu UilaI AlOaHomari waAlOasowadi, (TA,) i. e. I have been sent to the white and the black; because these two epithets comprise all mankind: (Az, TA:) [therefore, by the former we should understand the white and the red races; and by the latter, the negroes: but some hold that by the former are meant the foreigners, and] by the latter are meant the Arabs. (TA.) One says also, [when speaking of Arabs and more northern races,] OataAniI kulRu Oasowada minohumo waOaHomara, meaning Every Arab of them, and foreigner, came to me: and one should not say, in this sense, OaboyaDa. (AA, As, S.) AlHamoraMCu, also, is applied to The foreigners (AlEajamu) [collectively]; (S, A, K;) because a reddish white is the prevailing hue of their complexion: (S:) or the Persians and Greeks: or those foreigners mostly characterized by whiteness of complexion; as the Greeks and Persians. (TA.) You say, layosa fiI AlHamoraMCi mivoluhu There is not among the foreigners (AlEajam) the like of him. (A.) And accord. to some, AlOaHomaru waAlOaboyaDu means The Arabs and the foreigners. (TA.) AlHamoraMCu [so in the TA, but correctly OabonaMCu AlHamoraMCi,] is an appellation applied to Emancipated slaves: and Aibonu HamoraMCi AlEijaAni, meaning Son of the female slave, is an appellation used in reviling and blaming. (TA.) ― -b4- Also (tropical:) A man having no weapons with him: pl. HumorN (A, K) and HumoraAnN. (K.) ― -b5- AlHusonu OaHomaru means Beauty is in AlHumorap [app. fairness of complexion; i. e. beauty is fair-complexioned]: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) beauty is attended by difficulty; i. e. he who loves beauty must bear difficulty, or distress: (IAth:) or the lover experiences from beauty what is experienced from war. (ISd, K.) ― -b6- AlOaHomaru A sort of dates: (K:) so called because of their colour. (TA.) ― -b7- AlOaHomaru waAlOaboyaDu Gold and silver. (TA.) And AlOaHomaraAni Flesh-meat and wine; (S, A, K;) said to destroy men: (S:) so in the saying, naHonu mino Oaholi AlOasowadayoni laA AlOaHomarayoni We are of the people of dates and water, not of flesh-meat and wine: (A:) or the beverage called nabiyc and flesh-meat. (IAar.) Also Wine and [garments of the kind called] buruwd. (Sh.) And Gold and saffron; (Az, ISd, K;) said to destroy women; i. e. the love of ornaments and perfumes destroys them: (Az:) or these are called AlOaSofaraAni; (AO, TA;) and milk and water, AlOaboyaDaAni; (TA;) and dates and water, AlOasowadaAni. (A, TA.) And AlOaHaAmirapu Flesh-meat and wine and [the perfume called] Alxaluwq: (S, K:) or gold and flesh-meat and wine; as also AlOaxaADiru: (TA in art. xDr:) or gold and saffron and Alxaluwq. (ISd, TA.) ― -b8- Almawotu AlOaHomaru (assumed tropical:) Slaughter; (L, K;) because it occasions the flowing of blood: (TA:) and [so in the L, but in the K “ or ”] (tropical:) violent death: (S, A, L, K:) or death in which the sight of the man becomes dim by reason of terror, so that the world appears red and black before his eyes: (A 'Obeyd:) or it may mean (assumed tropical:) recent, fresh, death; from the phrase next following. (As.) ― -b9- waToOapN HamoraMCu (tropical:) A new, or recent, footstep, or footprint: opposed to dahomaMCu. (As, S, A.) ― -b10- sanapN HamoraMCu (tropical:) A severe year; (S, K;) because it is a mean between the sawodaMC and the bayoDMC: or a year of severe drought; because, in such a year, the tracts of the horizon are red: (TA:) when Aljabohapu [the tenth Mansion of the Moon (see manaAzilu Alqamari in art. nzl)] breaks its promise [of bringing rain], the year is such as is thus called. (AHn.) ― -b11- See also HamoraMCu voce HamaArRapN. ― -b12- jaMCa biganamihi Humora AlkulaI, and, in like manner, suwda AlbuTuwni, (tropical:) He brought his sheep or goats, in a lean, or an emaciated, state. (A, * TA.)

be the only word of this form except HilRizN, meaning “ short, ” and jilRiqN, the name of a place in Syria, (S, TA,) but IAar did not know this latter form of the word; (Az, TA;) [The cicer arietinum; or chick-peas;] a certain grain, (S, Msb, K,) well known, (Msb, K,) of the description termed AlqaTaAni: (AHn:) n. un. HimRaSapN and HimRiSapN: (TA:) it is white, and red, and black, and of a sort called kirosiniIRN [or karosaniIRN?]; and is also wild, and cultivated in gardens: the wild sort is the hotter, and the more contracted; the nutriment of the garden-sort is the better; and the black is the most powerful in its operations: (the Minháj, TA:) it is flatulent, lenitive, diuretic, having the property of increasing the seminal fluid and the carnal appetite and the blood: (K:) Hippocrates says that it has in it two substances, which quit it by cooking; one of them salt, or saline, which is lenitive; and the other sweet, which is diuretic; and it clears away spots in the skin, and beautifies the complexion, and is beneficial for hot tumours, and its oil is serviceable for the ringworm, or tetter; and its meal, for the fluid of foul ulcers; and the infusion thereof, for toothache, and for swelling of the lip; and it clears the voice: (TA:) it also strengthens the body and the penis; (K;) wherefore it is given as fodder to the stallions of horses and the like, and of camels; (TA;) on the condition of its being eaten not before [other] food nor after it, but in the midst thereof; (K;) or, correctly, as in the Minháj, it should be eaten between two meals. (TA.)

HamoDN [a coll. gen. n.] A kind of plant in which is saltness, (A, Msb,) which camels eat as though it were fruit, and after which they drink: (A:) other plants are termed xulRap: (Msb:) or what is salt and bitter, of plants; (S, K;) such as the rimov and the Oavol and the TarofaMC and the like: (S:) what is sweet is called xulRap: (S, K:) or any kind of plant that is salt, or sour, rising upon [several] stems, and having no [single] OaSol [or stock]: (M [as cited in the L, but I doubt whether the passage be correctly transcribed]:) or any salt, or sour, kind of trees; having a juicy and quivering leaf, which, when squeezed, bursts forth with water; and having a pungent, or strong, odour; that cleanses the garment and the hand when they are washed with it; such as the najiyl and the xcoraAf and the UixoriyT and the rimov and the qiDap and the qulRaAm and the harom and the HuroD and the rugl and the TarofaMC and the like: (Lh:) or any plant that does not dry up in the rabiyE [or spring], but endures the hot season, having in it saltness; when camels eat it, they drink upon it; and when they do not find it, they become thin and weak: (Lth, T:) the Arabs say that the xulRap is the bread of camels, and the HamoD is their fruit, (S, A, Msb, K, *) or, as some say, their flesh-meat; (S;) or their xabiyS: (TA in art. xl:) and they say that flesh-meat is the HamoD of men: (TA:) the n. un. is with p: (Mgh:) and the pl. is HumuwDN. (S, K.) [In Isaiah xxx. 24, the word rendered “ clean ” in our authorized version is thought by some to mean “ salt ” or “ sour. ”] ― -b2- Hence the saying,
jaAWuwA muxilRiyna falaAqawoA HamoDaA
(tropical:) They came eagerly desiring evil, or mischief, and found him who cured them of that which affected them: which is like the saying of Ru-beh,
wanuwridu Almusotaworidiyna HamoDaA
(tropical:) And him who cometh to us seeking to do evil, or mischief, we cure of his disease: for camels, when they are satiated with xulRap, eagerly desire HamoD [to cure them of the effect of the former]. (TA. [See also xulRiIRN, in art. xl.]) ― -b3- Hence, also, by way of comparison, HamoD is applied to (tropical:) Evil, and war: and xulRap, to ease, or repose; freedom from trouble or inconvenience, and toil or fatigue; or tranquillity; and ampleness of circumstances: (T and TA in art. xl:) and the former, to death: and the latter, to life. (Ham p. 315.) ― -b4- fuWaAdN HamoDN and nafosN HamoDpN mean (assumed tropical:) A mind that takes fright at a thing, and shrinks from it, at first hearing it. (TA.)

HamoDapN (assumed tropical:) Eager desire for a thing. (S, K.) It is said in a trad., AlOucunu majRaAjapN walilnRafosi HamoDpN; (S, TA;) and in another, liloOucuni majRapN wllnfs HmDp; (TA;) [both meaning the same;] (assumed tropical:) The ear is wont to reject what it hears, not retaining it, when one is exhorted to do a thing, or forbidden to do it, while the mind has eager desire to hear: (IAth:) or the ear retains not all that that it hears, while having eager desire for what it deems elegant, of extraordinary matters of discourse and speech. (Az.) This usage of the word is taken from the eager desire of camels for HamoD when they have become weary of xulRap. (S.)

HumRaADN [Sorrel; or particularly the rose-flowered sorrel; more commonly called in the present day HumRayoD;] a certain plant having a red flower; (S;) a herb, or leguminous plant, of the kind termed cukuwr, having a produce, or fruit, red like blood; (Ham p. 823;) a certain herb (K, TA) growing in the mountains, of herbs of the [season called] rabiyE, (TA,) the leaves of which are like those of the hinodibaMC, (K, TA,) large and broad; (TA;) it is acid, (K, TA,) intensely so; its flower is red, and its leaves are green: (TA: [in which is here added wytnAws fI vmrh mvl HbR AlrmRAn, app. for wayatanawRasu Alx; meaning that it waves much to and fro when blown by the wind, and describing its fruit as containing what resemble the grains of the pomegranate:]) it is pleasant to the taste; (K, TA;) and is eaten by men, but in small quantity: AHn and Aboo-Ziyád say, it grows very tall, and has a wide leaf, and a red flower, which, when it is near to drying up, becomes white: and Aboo-Ziyád says, in our mountain-country it is abundant; and is of two species; one of these two is acid, [but] pleasant to the taste; (TA;) and one species thereof is bitter; (K, TA;) in the lower parts of each, when they are full grown, is a redness; and the seeds and leaves of the acid species are used medicinally: Az says, it is a wild herb, or leguminous plant, that grows in the days of the [season called] rabiyE, in the channels of water, and has a red flower, and is of the herbs, or leguminous plants, which are termed cukuwr: IB says, the places of its growth are the small channels of water, and the places to which valleys take their courses; and in it is acidity: sometimes, also, the people of settled habitations make it to grow in their gardens, and water it and sustain it so that it does not dry up in the time when the wild herbs, or leguminous plants, dry up: it is also said in the Minháj that it is both wild and growing in gardens; that the wild is called slq, [but this name is commonly applied to bete,] and in all of this there is not acidity: the garden-kind resembles the hndbAC, and in this is acidity, and an excessive viscous moisture: the best is the acid, gardenkind: here ends the quotation from the Minháj: (TA:) each species, (K, TA,) the bitter and the pleasant, or the garden-kind and the wild, (TA,) is good for thirst, and for inflammation arising from yellow bile; and strengthens the bowels; and allays heaving of the stomach, and hot palpitation, and tooth-ache; and is good for the black [or livid] jaundice; (K, * TA;) and, when cooked, and applied externally, for the leprosy; and for the ringworm (quwabaMC); and for glandular swellings in the neck, so much so that it is said to do good to him who has these even when hung upon the neck: with vinegar, also, it is good for the mange, or scab; and it is astringent; and puts a stop to malacia [so I render XahowapAlTRiyn, lit. “ the longing for clay ”]: its seeds are cold in the first degree, and have an astringent property, particularly when fried: (TA:) they say that if these be hung, in a purse, upon a woman's left upper arm, she will not become pregnant as long as they remain upon her: (K, * TA:) they are also good for the sting of scorpions; and if some of the seeds be swallowed before the scorpion's stinging, its stinging will not hurt. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also What is in the interior of the [kind of citron called] OutorujR: (A, K:) n. un. with p: (A:) it is cold and dry in the third degree; used as a liniment, it removes freckles and the like, and clears the complexion; and it suppresses (yaqomaEu) the yellow bile; and gives appetite for food; and is good for hot palpitation; and made into a beverage, it sweetens the odour of the mouth; and is good for looseness arising from yellow bile; and is suitable for those who are fevered. (TA.) [In the present day, in Egypt, this name is applied to A species of citron, itself, with a conical apex, and very acid pulp.]

OaHomaqu (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and HamiqN↓ (S, Msb) and HamoqaAn↓ [whether with or without tenween is not shown] (Sb, TA) Foolish, or stupid; i. e. unsound in intellect or understanding; (T, Mgh, Msb;) and stagnant, or dull, therein; (T, Mgh;) or deficient, or defective, therein; IF, Mgh;) or haring little, or no, intellect or understanding: (S, K:) fem. of the first HamoqaMCu; (S, Msb;) and of the second HamiqapN: (TA:) pl. of the first, applied to men and to women, (S, K,) HumoqN, (so in two copies of the S,) or HumuqN, with two dammehs, (K,) and HamoqaI and HamaAqaI (S, K) and HumaAqaI (Sgh, K) and HimaAqN. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.) Accord. to some, OaHomaqu is from the phrase AinoHamaqati AlsRuwqu: and accord. to some, from the phrase layaAlK muHomiqaAtN, because the AHmq deceives one at first by what he says. (TA.) The sounds of wailing for the dead, and trilling, or quavering, in playing, are termed OaHomaqaAni because of the Humoq of the person from whom they proceed. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Albaqolapu AlHamoqaMCu (S, K) and baqolapu AlHamoqaMCi, (K,) the latter for baqolapu AlHabRapi AlHamoqaMCi, i. q. AlrRijolapu [Garden purslane]; (S, ISd, K;) which is the name applied to it by the vulgar; (ISd, TA;) the chief of herbs, or leguminous plants: called by those names because exuding mucilage (mulaERibapN), so that it is likened to the OaHomaq whose slaver is flowing: IDrd says, they assert that it is so called because it grows in the tracks of men, so that it is trodden upon; and in water-courses, so that the water uproots it: IF says that it is so called because of its weakness: and it is said that some persons, hating 'Áïsheh, called it baqolapu EaAYiXapa; but this is one of their fanciful assertions; for such was its name in the time of utter paganism: so says Sgh. (TA.) ― -b3- [OaHomaqu also signifies More, and most, foolish, or stupid, &c. Hence,] it is said in a prov., OaHomaqu mino rijolapK [More foolish, or stupid, than a plant of gardenpurslane: explained by what precedes]. (TA.) [See also another prov. voce vamaAnuwna.] And in a trad., OaHomaqu AlHumoqi Alfujuwru [The most foolish of foolishness, or the most stupid of stupidness, is vice, or immorality, or unrighteousness]. (A in art. kys.)

OaHomuwqapN c
OaHomuwqapN is from AlHumoqu, like OuHoduwvapN from AlHadiyvu, and OuEojuwbapN from AlEajabu: (TA:) it signifies An action, or a deed, of those that are done by the HamoqaI [i. e. foolish, or stupid, persons]; (Mgh;) [a foolish, or stupid, action or deed:] it is like HumuwqapN↓, which means an action, a practice, or a habit, in which is Humoq [i. e. foolishness, or stupidity, &c.]. (TA.) One says, waqaEa fulaAnN fiI OuHomuwqapK [Such a one fell into the commission of a foolish, or stupid, action, &c.]. (TA.) [See HumRayoqapN.]

muHomiqN mHmq
muHomiqN and muHomiqapN (S, K) A woman who brings forth a child that is OaHomaq [i. e. foolish, &c.]; (S;) or who brings forth HamoqaI [i. e. foolish children]: (K:) or, accord. to IDrd, the latter has this signification; but the former signifies a man who begets HamoqaI; and he does not allow its application to a woman. (TA.) ― -b2- AlmuHomiqaAtu (tropical:) The nights [that make a fool of one; i. e.] during the whole of which the moon is above the horizon but intercepted by clouds; so that one imagines that he has arrived at the time of morning; (A, O, K, TA;) because he sees light, but sees not the moon: derived from AlHumoqu. (TA.) One says, garRaniI guruwra AlmuHomiqaAti (tropical:) [He, or it, deceived me with the deceiving of the nights thus called]. (TA.) And you say, sironaA fiI layaAli muHomiqaAtK (tropical:) [We journeyed during such nights]; because the rider therein thinks that he has arrived at the time of morning until he becomes weary. (TA.)

miHomaAqN mHmAq
miHomaAqN A woman who is accustomed to bring forth HamoqaI [i. e. foolish children]. (S, K.)

maHomuwqN mHmwq
maHomuwqN A man [or child] affected with HumaAq [q. v.]. (A 'Obeyd, S.)

1. Hamalahu, aor.
Hamila
, inf. n. HamolN (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c., in some copies of the S HimolN) and HumolaAnN, (Mgh, K,) He bore it, carried it, took it up and carried it, conveyed it, or carried it off or away, (MA,) EalaI Zahorihi (S, MA,) upon his back, or EalaI raOosihi upon his head; (MA;) and AHtmlhu↓ signifies the same: (Msb, K:) or the latter is used in relation to an object inconsiderable and small in comparison with that in relation to which the former is used; as in the saying of En-Nábighah, (TA,)
UinRaA QqotasamonaA xuTRatayonaA bayonanaA
fajaAri faHamalota barRapa waQHotamalotu↓
[Verily we have divided our two qualities between us, and thou hast borne as thy share goodness, and I have borne as my share wickedness]. (TA * in the present art., and S and TA &c. in arts. br and fjr.) Hence, in the Kur [xx. 100], faUinRahu yaHomilu yawoma AlqiyaAmapi wizorFA [He shall bear, on the day of resurrection, a heavy burden]. (TA.) Hence also, in the Kur [vii. 189], Hamalato HamolFA xafiyfFA [She bore a light burden]; (S, TA;) i. e., [as some say,] the seminal fluid. (TA.) Hence also, in the Kur [xxix. 60], wakaOayRino mino daAbRapK laA taHomilu rizoqahaA [And how many a beast is there that does not bear its sustenance!], meaning, (assumed tropical:) does not provide its sustenance, but is sustained by God. (TA.) yaHomilu AlHaTaba [lit. He carries firewood],
(A in art. HTb,) or AlHaTaba AlrRaToba [juicy, or fresh, firewood], (Er-Rághib, TA,) means (tropical:) he goes about with calumny, or slander. (A in art. HTb, and Er-Rághib * and TA. *) ― -b2- Hamalahu EalaI AldRaAbRap, (Msb, TA,) aor.
Hamila
, (TA,) inf. n. HamolN, (Msb, TA,) [He carried him, or mounted him, (namely, a man, Msb) upon the beast; as also AHtmlhu↓.] And Hamalahu [alone] He gave him a beast upon which to ride. (T, TA. [See Kur ix. 93.]) OaHomalahu is not used in this sense. (T, TA.) ― -b3- See also 4. ― -b4- Hamalati AlmaroOapu, aor.
Hamila
, (K,) inf. n. HamolN, (TA,) (tropical:) The woman became pregnant, or conceived: (K, TA:) and Hamalato waladahaA She became pregnant with, or conceived, her child: (Msb:) one should not say, Hamalato bihi; or this is rare; (K;) or one should not say this, but it is frequently said; (IJ, TA;) [for] as Hamalato is syn. with Ealiqato, (Msb, TA,) and the latter is trans. by means of bi the former is thus made trans., (TA,) therefore one says, Hamalato bihi fiI layolapi kacaA wafiI mawoDiEi kacaA, meaning She became pregnant with him, or conceived him, in such a night, and in such a place. (Msb.) Hamalato is also said of a ewe or she-goat, and of a female beast of prey, [and app. of any female,] accord. to IAar; meaning (assumed tropical:) She was, or became, in the first stage of pregnancy. (TA.) ― -b5- Hamalati AlXRajarapu, inf. n. HamolN, (assumed tropical:) The tree [bore, or] produced, or put forth, its fruit. (Msb.) ― -b6- Hamala bidayonK, and bidiyapK, inf. n. HamaAlapN, (assumed tropical:) [He bore, or took upon himself, the responsibility, or he was, or became, responsible, for a debt, and a bloodwit:] (Msb:) [for] Hamala bihi, aor.
Hamila
, inf. n. HamaAlapN, signifies kafala. (S, * K.) And Hamala AlHamaAlapa and tHmRlhA↓ (assumed tropical:) [He was, or became, responsible for the bloodwit, or debt or the like]: both signify the same: (S, TA:) and bihi tHmRl↓ (assumed tropical:) He took it upon himself, or became responsible, or answerable, for it: (Msb in art. kfl:) and muEoZamahu tHmRl↓ (assumed tropical:) He took, or imposed, upon himself, or undertook, the main part of it: (Jel in xxiv. 11:) and AlOamora AHtml↓ (assumed tropical:) He took, or imposed, upon himself, or undertook, the thing, or affair; he bore, or took upon himself, the burden thereof. (L in art. qld.) You say, Hamala qawomN Eano qawomK diyapF, (K, TA,) or garaAmapF, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) [A party bore, or took upon itself, for a party, the responsibility for a bloodwit, or a debt or the like;] as also tHmRl↓. (S.) [And Hamala Eano fulaAnK lifulaAnK kacaA (assumed tropical:) He bore, or took upon himself, for such a one, the responsibility, to such a one, for such a thing.] And HamaAlapF bayona tHmRl↓ qawomK (assumed tropical:) He bore, or took upon himself, the responsibility for the bloodwits between people, in order to make peace between them, when war had occurred between them, and men's blood had been shed. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b7- Hamala ZulomFA (assumed tropical:) [He made himself chargeable with wrongdoing]. (Kur xx. 110.) ― -b8- [Hamala AlOamaAnapa: see OamaAnapN: accord. to some, it means (assumed tropical:) He took upon himself, or accepted, the trust: accord. to others, he was unfaithful to it: and AiHotamalahaA↓ means the same.] ― -b9- Hamalotu UidolaAlahu: see 8. ― -b10- Hamala Eanohu: see 8. ― -b11- Hamala fulaAnN AlHiqoda EalaI fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) Such a one [bore or] concealed in his mind rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, against such a one. (TA.) And fulaAnN laA yaHomilu, i. e. yuZohiru gaDabahu [which may be meant as the explanation of lA yHml, i. e. (assumed tropical:) Such a one shows (or will not conceal) his anger; and thus SM understood it; or as the explanation of yHml alone, i. e. such a one will not show his anger]: (Az, TA:) [for] Hamala AlgaDaba, (K,) aor.
Hamila
, inf. n. HamolN, (TA,) means (tropical:) he showed, or manifested, anger. (K, TA.) And hence, it is said, is the saying, in a trad., UicaA balaga AlmaMCu qulRatayoni lamo yaHomilo xabavFA, i. e. (assumed tropical:) [When the water amounts to the quantity of two vessels of the kind called qulRap,] impurity does not appear in it: (O, K, * TA:) or the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) it does not admit the bearing of impurity: for one says, fulaAnN laA yaHomilu AlDRayoma, i. e. (assumed tropical:) such a one refuses to bear, or submit to, and repels from himself, injury. (Msb.) You say also, Hamala mino celika OanafFA (assumed tropical:) He conceived, in consequence of that, disdain, or scorn, arising from indignation and anger. (TA in art. Anf, from a trad.) ― -b12- Hamala AlHadiyva (assumed tropical:) [He bore in his memory, knowing by heart, the tradition, or narrative, or story; and in like manner, AlquroMna the Kur-án]. (Msb in art. rwI.) ― -b13- Hamala fulaAnFA, and bihi tHmRl↓ and Ealayohi, (assumed tropical:) He relied upon such a one in intercession, and in a case of need. (TA.) ― -b14- Humila EalaI AlnRaAqapi (assumed tropical:) The she-camel was covered by a stallion. (M in art. Smd.) ― -b15- Hamala Ealyohi [as syn. with HamRalahu]: see 2, in three places. ― -b16- Hamala EalaI daAbRatihi fawoqa TaAqatihaA fiI AlsRayori (assumed tropical:) [He tasked his beast beyond its power in journeying, or marching, or in respect of pace]. (S in art. jhd.) And Hamala EalaI nafosihi fiI AlsRayori (assumed tropical:) He jaded, or fatigued, himself, or tasked himself beyond his power, in journeying, or marching. (S, TA.) [See also 6.] ― -b17- Hamala Ealayohi fiI AlHarobi, inf. n. HamolapN [which is properly an inf. n. of un.], (T, S,) (assumed tropical:) He charged, or made an assault or attack, upon him in war, or battle. (TA.) ― -b18- Hamalotu EalaI baniI fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) I made mischief, or I excited disorder, disagreement, dissension, or strife, between, or among, the sons of such a one. (AZ, S.) ― -b19- Hamalahu EalaI AlOamori, aor.
Hamila
, (assumed tropical:) He incited, excited, urged, instigated, induced, or made, him to do the thing, or affair. (ISd, K.) ― -b20- [Hamala lafoZFA EalaI lafoZK Mxara, aor.
Hamila
, inf. n. HamolN, a phrase often used in lexicology and grammar, (assumed tropical:) He made, or held, a word, or an expression, to accord in form, or in meaning, or syntactically, with another word, or expression. One says, yuHomalu EalaI AlOakovari (assumed tropical:) It (a word) is made to accord in form with those words with which it may be compared that constitute the greater number: thus one says of raHomaAnu, which is made to accord in form with words of the measure faEolaAnu, though it has not a fem. of the measure faEolaI, in preference to faEolaAnN, because words of the measure faEolaAnu are more numerous than those of the measure faEolaAnN. And yuHomalu EalaI naqiyDihi (assumed tropical:) It (a word) is made to accord in form with its contrary in meaning: thus EijaAfN, an anomalous pl. of OaEoHafu, is made to accord. in form with simaAnN, a regular pl. of samiynN. And yaHmalu EalaI AlmaEonaI (assumed tropical:) It (a word) is made to accord syntactically with its meaning: and yuHomalu EalaI AllRafoZi (assumed tropical:) It is made to accord syntactically with its grammatical character: the former is said when, in a sentence, we make a mase. word fem., and the contrary, because the meaning allows us to substitute a fem. syn. for the masc. word, and a masc. syn. for the fem. word: for ex., it is said in the Kur vi. 78, falamRaA raOaI AlXRamosa baAzigapF qaAla hecaA rabRiI “ And when he saw the sun rising, he said, This is my Lord: ” here (by saying bAzgp) AlXms is first made to accord syntactically with its grammatical character (tuHomalu EalaI AllRafoZi); and then (by saying hecaA instead of hecihi) it is made to accord syntactically with its meaning (tuHomalu EalaI AlmaEonaI), which is Aljirom or the like: this is allowable; but the reverse in respect of order is of weak authority; because the meaning is of more importance than the grammatical character of the word. (Collected from the Kull pp. 156 and 157, and other works.)] ― -b21- Hamalahu OaHosana maHoyalK (assumed tropical:) [He put the best construction upon it; namely, a saying: mHml being here an inf. n.]. (TA in art. Abw) ― -b22- [Hamalahu EalaI AlnRaAsixi (assumed tropical:) He attributed it to, or charged it upon, the copyist; namely, a mistake. Humila ElaI AlnRaAsixi, said of a mistake, occurs in the K in art. rbx ― -b23- EalaI Mxara Hamala XayoYFA, in logic, means (assumed tropical:) He predicated a thing of another thing.] ― -b24- See also HumolaAnN.

2 HmRlhu AlXRaIoCa c
2. HmRlhu AlXRaIoCa, (Msb,) and AlrRisaAlapa, (S, TA,) inf. n. taHomiylN, (TA,) He made him, or constrained him, to bear or carry [the thing, and the message; and in like manner, Ealayohi AlXRaIoCa Hamala↓]. (S, Msb, * TA.) [And HmRlhu, alone, He loaded him; namely, a camel, &c.] You say also, HamRalahu AlOamora fataHamRalahu↓, inf. n. of the former taHomiylN and HimRaAlN, like kicRaAbN, [which is of the dial. of El-Yemen], and of the latter verb taHamRulN and tiHimRaAlN [like tikilRaAmN &c.], (K,) (assumed tropical:) He imposed upon him the affair, as a task, or in spite of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience, and he undertook it, as a task, &c. (Msb in art. klf.) And HamRalotuhu OamoriI famaA taHamRala↓ (assumed tropical:) [I imposed upon him my affair, as a task, &c., but he did not undertake it]. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [xxiv. 53], faUinRamaA Ealayohi maA HumRila waEalayokumo maA HumRilotumo (assumed tropical:) [Upon him rests only that which he has had imposed upon him; and upon you, that which ye have had imposed upon you]: i. e., upon the Prophet rests the declaring of that which has been revealed to him; and upon you, the following him as a guide. (TA.) And rabRanaA EalaI QlRaciyna mino EalayonaA UiSorFA kamaA Hamalotahu↓ taHomilN↓ qabolinaA rabRanaA walaA tuHamRilonaA maA laA TaAqapa lanaA bihi (assumed tropical:) [O our Lord, and do not Thou impose upon us a burden, like as Thou imposedst it upon those before us: O our Lord, and do not Thou impose upon us that which we have not power to bear]: (Kur ii. last verse:) or, accord. to one reading, tuHayRilo, which has an intensive signification [when followed by ElI]. (Bd.) ― -b2- [HmRlhu canobFA (assumed tropical:) He charged him
with a crime, or an offence: see a verse of En-Nábighah cited voce EarRN.]

AHmlhu He helped him to bear, or carry, (T, S,) that which he was bearing, or carrying: (T, TA:) or you say, AHmlhu AlHiyola he helped him to bear, or carry, the load, or burden: and Hamalahu↓, i. e. faEala celika bihi [he did that with him]. 6 tHAml Ealayohi tHAml Elyh tHAml Elyp
6. tHAml Ealayohi [He bore, bore his weight, pressed, or pressed heavily, upon it, or him]. (K, TA.) ― -b6- [AiHotamalato She (a woman) used a drug, or the like, in the manner of a suppository in the ragina: so in the present day: and so in the K, on the words qunRabiyTN and nifoTN &c.] ― -b7- AHtml He bought what is termed Hamiyl, i. e. a thing [in the CK llsRaboIi is put for lilXRaIoCi] carried from one country or town to another (K, TA) among a party of captives.
