R. Q. 1 Hawomala Hwml
R. Q. 1. Hawomala He carried water. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.)

HamolN Hml
HamolN [inf. n. of 1, q. v. ― -b2- (tropical:) Gestation: see an ex. voce UinoIN. ― -b3- And hence,] (assumed tropical:) The young that is borne in the womb (M, K) of any animal; (M, TA;) and (assumed tropical:) the fruit of a tree, (IDrd, S, M, Msb, K,) as also HimolN↓: (IDrd, S, M, K:) or the former, (assumed tropical:) the thing that is in a belly, or on the head of a tree: (ISk, S, M, Mgh, K:) and ↓the latter, a thing borne, or carried, (Msb, K,) on the back; [i. e. a load, or burden;] (Msb;) the thing that is on the back or on the head: (ISk, S, M, Mgh, K:) or the former, (assumed tropical:) a burden that is borne internally; as the young in the belly, and the water in the clouds, and the fruit in the tree as being likened to the Hamol of the woman: and ↓the latter, a burden that is borne externally; as the thing that is borne on the back: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or [when applied to fruit] the former signifies a fruit that is internal: and ↓the latter, a fruit that is external: (M, K:) or the former, fruit of a tree when large, or much: and ↓the latter, fruit when not large, or when not much and large: (K accord. to different copies:) this is the saying of AO, mentioned in the T, in art. Xml, where, in the copies of the T, is found mA lm ykvr, not mAlm ykbr: (TA:) and the former also occurs as meaning a burden that requires, for the carrying it, a beast or the hire of a porter: (Mgh:) the pl. [of pauc.] of the latter (Mgh, Msb, K) and of the former (K) is OaHomaAlN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and [the pl. of mult.] (of the former, K, * TA) HimaAlN (K) and (of the latter, Msb) HumuwlN (Msb, K) and HumuwlapN. (S, M, Mgh, Sgh.) Hence, (in a trad., TA) hecaA AlHimaAlu laAHimaAlu xayobara (assumed tropical:) [This is the fruit: not the fruit of Kheyber]: meaning that it is the fruit of Paradise; and that it does not fail, or come to an end. (M, K.) ― -b4- See also what next follows.

HimolN Hml
HimolN: see HamolN, in five places. ― -b2- HumuwlN, (S, M, K,) as pl. of HimolN, (M, K,) and of HamolN↓ also, (K,) signifies likewise [Vehicles of the kind called] hawaAdij [pl. of hawodajN], (M, K,) whether having in them women or not: (M, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) camels upon which are hwAdj, (AZ, S, M,
O, K,) whether there be in them women or not: (AZ, S, O:) it is not applied to camels unless they have upon them hwAdj. (M, TA.) ― -b3- See also maHomilN, and HamuwlapN.

HamalN Hml
HamalN A lamb; i. e. the young one of the ewe in the first year; (Mgh, Msb;) i. q. baraqN; (S;) or xaruwfN [explained in the K in art. xrf as the male young one of the sheep-kind; or such as has pastured, and become strong]: (K, and S and Msb in art. xrf:) or such as is termed jacaEN, [i. e. a year old, or from six to ten months,] of the young of the sheep-kind; and less than this [in age]: (ISd, K:) accord. to Er-Rághib, it signifies maHomuwlN [borne, or carried]; and the young of the sheep-kind is particularly called thus because borne, or carried, on account of its impotence, and of the nearness of the time when its mother was pregnant with it: (TA:) pl. HumolaAnN (S, M, Mgh, Sgh, Msb, K) and OaHomaAlN. (M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlHamalu (assumed tropical:) [The sign Aries;] a certain sign of the zodiac; (K;) the first of the signs of the zodiac; (S;) the constellation comprising, first, the XaraTaAni, which are its two horns; then, the buTayon; then, the vurayRaA. (T, TA.) One says, muTironaA binawoCi AlHamali and bnwC AlTRaliIRi (assumed tropical:) [We were, or have been, given rain by the auroral setting of Aries: so the pagan Arabs used to say: see nawoCN; and see manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl]. (TA.) One says also, hecaA HamalN TaAliEFA (assumed tropical:) [This is Aries, rising]; suppressing the Al, but making the noun to remain determinate; and thus one does in the case of every name of a sign of the zodiac, preserving the Al or suppressing it. (TA.) ― -b3- HamalN signifies also (tropical:) Clouds containing much water: (M, K, TA:) or black clouds: (T, TA: [see also HawomalN, below:]) or, as some say, the rain [supposed to be given] by the nawoC [see above] of AlHamal. (TA.)

HamolapN Hml Hmlh Hmlp
HamolapN (assumed tropical:) A charge, or an assault or attack, in war, or battle. (T, K.)

HumolapN Hml Hmlh Hmlp
HumolapN: see what next follows.

HimolapN Hml Hmlh Hmlp
HimolapN and HumolapN↓ Carriage from one dAr [app. here meaning country, or town, or the like,] to another. (K.)

HumolaAnN HmlAn
HumolaAnN an inf. n. of Hamala [q. v.]. (Mgh, K.) ＝ -A2- Also A beast upon which a present is borne. (M, Mgh, O, K.) ― -b2- Hire for that which is borne, or carried. (Lth, Mgh, TA.) ― -b3- And, as a conventional term (Mgh, O, K) of the SaAgap [or workers in gold and silver], (Sgh, K,) Adulterating alloy (giXR) that is added to dirhems, or coin (EalaI AldRaraAhimi yuHomalu↓). (Mgh, Sgh, K.) ― -b4- Also pl. of HamalN [q. v.]. (S, M, &c.)

HamaAlN HmAl
HamaAlN or HimaAlN: see HamaAlapN.

HamuwlN Hmwl
HamuwlN (assumed tropical:) Forbearing, or clement. (M, K.)

HamiylN Hmyl
HamiylN i. q. maHomuwlN↓ [Borne, carried, taken up and carried, conveyed, or carried off or away]. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- Hence, (Msb,) The rubbish, or rotten leaves, and scum, that are borne of a torrent. (S, Msb, K. *) ― -b3- A thing [XaIoC, accord. to copies of the K and the TA, but accord. to the CK saboI, agreeably with the next of the explanations here following,] that is carried from one country or town to another (K, TA) among a party of captives. (TA.) ― -b4- A captive; because carried from one country or town to another. (Msb.) ― -b5- One who is carried a child from his country, not born in [the territory of] El-Islám: (S, O:) or one who is carried from his country to the country of El-Islám: or a child with a woman who carries it, and says that it is her son: or any relation, or kinsman, in the territory of the enemy: (Mgh:) or one that is carried from the territory of the unbelievers to that of ElIslám, and who is therefore not allowed to inherit without evidence: (Th, TA:) or a child in the belly of his mother when taken from the land of the unbelievers. (K.) ― -b6- A foundling, or child cast out by his mother, whom persons carry off and rear: (K:) in some copies of the K, fayarivuwnahu is erroneously put for fayurabRuwnahu. (TA.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) One whose origin, or lineage, is suspected; or who claims for his father one who is not; or who is claimed as a son by one who is not his father; syn. daEiIRN. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) A stranger: (K:) as being likened to [the Hamiyl of] the torrent, or to the child in the belly. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) One who is responsible, or a surety, (S, Msb, K,) for (bi) a debt or a bloodwit; as also HaAmilN↓: (Msb:) because he bears [or is burdened with] the obligation, together with him upon whom the obligation properly rests. (TA.) ― -b10- (assumed tropical:) What is withered and black of the vumaAm and waXiyj (K, TA) and DaEap and Tariyfap. (TA.) ― -b11- (assumed tropical:) The [thong called] XiraAk [of a sandal]. (O, K.) In one copy of the K, AlXryk is put in the place of AlXrAk. (TA.)

HamaAlapN HmAl HmAlh HmAlp
HamaAlapN A bloodwit, (S, K, TA,) or a debt, an obligation, or a responsibility, that must be paid, discharged, or performed, taken upon himself by a person, (S, TA,) or taken upon themselves by a party of men, (K, TA,) for others; (S, K, TA;) as also HamaAlN↓, accord. to the T and M; or HimaAlN↓, accord. to the K: (TA:) or a responsibility which one takes upon himself for a debt or a bloodwit: pl. HamaAlaAtN: (Msb:) the pl. of HmAl is HumulN. (K.)

HimaAlapN HmAl HmAlh HmAlp
HimaAlapN The occupation, or business, of a porter, or carrier of burdens. (M, K.) ― -b2- Also said to be sing. of HamaAYilu, and syn. with miHomalN, which see, in two places.

HamuwlapN Hmwl Hmwlh Hmwlp
HamuwlapN A camel, or horse, or mule, or an ass, upon which burdens are borne: (Mgh, Msb:) and sometimes applied to a number of camels: (Msb:) camels that bear burdens: and any beast upon which the tribe carries, namely, an ass or other animal; (S;) or a beast upon which people carry, namely, a camel, and an ass, and the like; (K;) whether the loads be thereon or not: (S, K:) or such as are able to bear: (Az, TA:) or particularly applied to such as have on them the loads; as also HumuwlN↓: (ISd, TA:) accord. to the T, not including asses nor mules: applied to one and to more than one: (TA:) a word of the measure faEuwlN receives the affix p when it has the meaning of a pass. part. n. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Also, accord. to the K, The loads, or burdens, themselves: but this, accord. to the S and M [and Mgh] and Sgh, is [HumuwlapN, a pl. of HimolN,] with damm [to the H]. (TA.)

HamiylapN Hmyl Hmylh Hmylp
HamiylapN (assumed tropical:) i. q. kalRN and EiyaAlN: so in the saying, huwa HamiylapN EalayonaA (assumed tropical:) [He is a burden upon us; one whom we have to support]. (O, K.) ― -b2- Also said to be sing. of HamaAYilu, and syn. with miHomalN, q. v.

HamaAYilu c
HamaAYilu: see miHomalN, in two places.

HamRaAlN HmAl
HamRaAlN A porter, or carrier of burdens. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- HamRaAlapu AlHaTabi [is applied in the Kur cxi. 4 to a woman, lit. meaning The female carrier of firewood: and as an intensive epithet is applied to a man, as meaning] (tropical:) The calumniator, or slanderer. (TA.)

HaAmilN HAml
HaAmilN [Bearing, carrying, taking up and carrying, conveying, or carrying off or away;] act. part. n. of 1 having for its object what is borne on the back [&c.]: (Msb:) fem. with p: (S, Msb:) pl. masc. HamalapN: (S, TA:) and pl. fem. HaAmilaAtN. (TA.) Hence, Hamalapu AlEaroXi [The bearers of the ErX, or empyrean, held by the vulgar to be the throne of God]. (S, TA.) And the phrase faQloHaAmilaAti wiqorFA [in the Kur li. 2, lit. And the bearers of a load, or heavy load:] meaning (assumed tropical:) the clouds. (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to a woman, (tropical:) Pregnant; (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.;) as also HaAmilapN: (S, Msb, K:) the former as being an epithet exclusively applied to a female: the latter as conformable to its verb, which is Hamalato; (S, Msb;) or as being used in a tropical [or doubly tropical] manner, meaning pregnant in past time or in future time; (Msb;) or as a possessive epithet [meaning having a burden in the womb]: (TA:) [see an ex. of the latter in a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. mxS:] accord. to the Koofees, the former, not being applied to a male, has no need of the sign of the fem. gender: but the Basrees say that this [rule] does not uniformly obtain; for the Arabs say rajulN OayRimN and AimoraOapN OayRimN, and rajulN EaAnisN and AimoraOapN EaAnisN; and that, correctly speaking, HaAmilN and TaAliqN and HaAYiDN and the like are epithets masc. in form applied to females, like as raboEapN and raAwiyapN and xujaOapN are epithets fem. in form applied to males. (S.) It is also applied to a she-camel [and app. to any female] in the same sense. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Applied to trees (XajarN), (assumed tropical:) Bearing fruit: (TA:) fem. with p. (K.) ― -b4- See also HamiylN. ― -b5- [Respecting this epithet, and the phrases HaAmilu AlOamaAnapi and muHotamilu AlOamaAnapi, see also OamaAnapN, last sentence but one.] ― -b6- Hamalapu AlquraMni (assumed tropical:) [Those who bear in their memory the Kur-án, knowing it by heart]. (S, TA.)

HawomalN Hwml
HawomalN Clouds (saHaAbN) black by reason of the abundance of their water. (O, K.) [See also HamalN.] ― -b2- A clear torrent. (K.) ― -b3- The first of anything. (K.)

HaAmilapN HAml HAmlh HAmlp
HaAmilapN fem. of HaAmilN [q. v.]. (S, Msb.) ― -b2-
HawaAmilu is its pl.: and signifies The legs; (M, K;) because they bear the man. (TA.) ― -b3- And The sinews, or tendons, of the foot and of the fore arm; (M, K;) and the [veins called the] rawaAhiX thereof. (M, TA. [See Alwariydu.]) ― -b4- See also maHomilN.

maHomilN mHml
maHomilN [of which the primary signification is A place of bearing or carrying], (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) or miHomalN↓ [which primarily signifies An instrument for bearing or carrying], (M, Mgh,) or the latter is allowable, (Msb,) The [kind of vehicle called] hawodaj; (Msb;) as also HimolN↓: (M, K:) or the large hwdj termed HajRaAjiIRN: (Mgh:) or a pair of dorsers, or panniers, or oblong chests, (XiqRaAni,) upon a camel, in which are borne two equal loads, (K,) [and which, with a small tent over them, compose a hwdj;] first made use of by El-Hajjáj Ibn-Yoosuf Eth-Thakafee: (TA:) one of the maHaAmil of the pilgrims: (S:) maHaAmilu being the pl. (K.) Hence, maHaAmiliIRN↓ A seller of maHaAmil. (K.) [What is now particularly termed the mHml (vulgarly pronounced maHomal) of the pilgrims is an ornamented hwdj, which is borne by a camel, but without a rider, and is regarded as the royal banner of the caravan; such as is described and figured in my work on the Modern Egyptians. (See also maHaArapN, in art. Hwr.)] Its application to (tropical:) The camel that bears the mHml is tropical. (Mgh.) [See also HimolN. The assertion that it signifies also the silk covering that is sent every year for the Kaabeh is erroneous. This covering is sent from Cairo, with the baggage of the chief of the Egyptian pilgrim-caravan.] ― -b2- Also maHomilN, (K,) or miHomalN↓, (M,) A basket (zinobiyl) in which grapes are carried to the place where they are to be dried; and so HaAmilapN↓. (K.) ― -b3- One says also, maA EalaI fulaAnK maHomilN (assumed tropical:) There is no ground of reliance upon such a one; syn. muEotamadN: (S:) or no relying, or reliance: (MA:) or no ground (lit. place) for imposing upon such a one the accomplishment of one's wants. (M, TA.) And maA EalaI AlbaEiyri maHomilN mino viqali AlHimoli (assumed tropical:) [There is no ground of reliance, or no relying, upon the camel, by reason of the heaviness of the load.] (TA.)

muHomilN mHml
muHomilN A woman, (S, M, K,) and a she-camel, (S, M,) who yields her milk without being pregnant. (S, M, K.)

miHomalN mHml
miHomalN: see maHomilN, in two places. ― -b2- The EilaAqap of a sword (S, Msb, * K) &c.; (Msb;) i. e. its suspensory thong [or cord or shoulder-belt], by which the wearer hangs it upon his neck; (S, TA;) as also HimaAlapN↓ (S, Msb, K) and HamiylapN↓: (IDrd, K:) and the HimaAlap↓ of the bow is similar to that of the sword: the wearer throws it upon his right shoulder, and puts forth his left arm from it, so that the bow is on his back: (AHn, TA:) the pl. of miHomalN is maHaAmilu: (Az, Msb:) and that of HimaAlapN, (S, Msb,) or of HamiylapN, (Kh, TA,) is HamaAYilu↓; (Kh, S, TA;) or, accord. to As, HamaAYilu has no proper sing., its sing. being only miHomalN. (S, TA.) ― -b3- Dhu-r-Rummeh applies it to (tropical:) The root of a tree; (S, K;) likening this to the mHml of a sword. (S.) ― -b4- maHaAmilu AlcRakari and HamaAYiluhu↓ (assumed tropical:) The veins in the root and skin of the penis. (M, K.)

naAqapN muHamRalapN nAqp mHmlh nAqp mHmlp
naAqapN muHamRalapN A she-camel heavily burdened, or overburdened. (TA.)

maHomuwlN mHmwl
maHomuwlN: see HamiylN. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A fortunate man: from the riding of beasts such as are termed furRahN, (K, * TA,) i. e. brisk, sharp, and strong. (TA in art. frh.) ― -b3- [In logic, (assumed tropical:) A predicate: and (assumed tropical:) an accident: in each of these senses contr. of mawoDuwEN.]

maHomuwlapN mHmwl mHmwlh mHmwlp
maHomuwlapN A dust-coloured wheat, (K, TA,) like the pod of the cotton-plant, (TA,) having many grains, (K, TA,) and large ears, and of much increase, but not approved in colour nor in taste: so in the M. (TA.)

muHaAmilN mHAml
muHaAmilN (assumed tropical:) One who is unable to answer thee; and who does it not, to preserve thine affection. (TA.)

maHaAmiliIRN mHAmlI mHAmly
maHaAmiliIRN: see maHomilN.

muHotamilu AlOamaAnapi c
muHotamilu AlOamaAnapi: see OamaAnapN, last sentence but one.

mutaHaAmalN mtHAml
mutaHaAmalN: see 6, last sentence.

XahorN musotaHomilN c
XahorN musotaHomilN A month that brings people into difficulty, or distress; (K, TA;) that is not as it should be. (TA.) Such is said by the Arabs to be the case UicaA naHara hilaAlN XimaAlFA [app. meaning when a new moon faces a north-east wind]. (TA.)

Q. 1 Hamolaqa Hmlq
Q. 1. Hamolaqa, (S, K,) inf. n. HamolaqapN, (Har p. 273,) said of a man, (S, TA,) and of a lion, (TA,) He opened his eyes, and looked hard: (S, K:) or he opened his eyes: and Hmlq Uilayohi He looked at him, or it: or he looked hard at him, or it. (TA.)

HimolaAqu AlEayoni HmlAq AlEyn
HimolaAqu AlEayoni (S, M, Sgh, K) and HumolaAquhaA and HumoluwquhaA↓ (M, K) The inner part of the eyelids, that is blackened by the collyrium: or the portions of the white of the globe of the eye that are covered by the eyelids: (S, K:) or the red inner part of the eyelid, the redness of which is seen when it is turned out for the application of the collyrium: (L, K:) or what cleaves to the eye, of the place of the collyrium, internally: (M, K:) or the sides of the globe of the eye: or the part of the skin of the eyelid that is next to the globe of the eye: (TA:) pl. HamaAliyqu; (S, K;) which some explain as signifying the portions of the flesh of the eyelids that are next to the globe of the eye. (TA.) One says, jaMCa fulaAnN mutalavRimFA laAyaZoharu mino Husoni wajohih UilRaA HamaAliyqu Hadaqatayohi [Such a one came wearing a livaAma; nothing appearing of the beauty of his face except the inner edges of his eyelids, &c.]. (S.) ― -b2- HamaAliyqu AlmarOapi signifies The part, or parts, upon which close the two edges, or borders, of the labia majora of the vulva of the woman. (T, TA.)

HumoluwqN Hmlwq
HumoluwqN: see the next preceding paragraph.

muHamoliqN mHmlq
muHamoliqN Eyes having around their globes a whiteness unmixed with blackness: [it would seem to be a mistranscription for muHamoliqapN; but perhaps it is an epithet applied to a man having eyes of this description; for it is immediately added,] whence EayonN muHamoliqapN [app. meaning an eye having around it such a whiteness]. (TA.)

HamonN HAm Hmn
HamonN: see what next follows.

HamonaAnN HmnAn
HamonaAnN Small qirodaAn [or ticks]; as also HamonN↓: n. un. with p: (K:) accord. to As, the first of the quraAd is termed qamoqaAmapN, when very small; then it is termed HamonaAnapN; then, quraAdN; then, HalamapN; then, EalRN; and then, TiloHN. (S.) ― -b2- Also A sort of grapes of Et-Táïf, (K,) black inclining to redness, (TA,) of which the berries are small (K) and few: (TA:) or the small berries that are between the large berries, (K,) so in the M, (TA,) among the grapes. (K.)

OaroDN maHomanapN c
OaroDN maHomanapN and muHominapN A land abounding with the small qirodaAn termed HamonaAn. (K.)

HamN Hcm
HamN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) like OabN, originally HamawN, as is shown by its pl., which see below, (S,) and HamFA↓, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and Hamuw↓, (S, Msb, K,) like Oabuw, (S, Msb,) used only as a prefixed n. governing the gen. case, except in poetry, (S, TA,) and HamowN↓, (K,) and HamoCN [mentioned in art. HmO, as well as HamaON], (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) A woman's husband's [male] relation, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) whoever he be, (S, Msb,) such as his father, (S, Msb, K,) and brother, (S, Msb.) and paternal uncle, (Msb,) &c.: (TA:) the fem. is HamaApN↓, (K,) signifying a woman's husband's mother; and having no dial. var.: (S, Msb:) and the pl. is OaHomaMCN: (S, Mgh, K:) and AlrRajuli Hamuw↓, (M, Msb,) or AlrRajuli Hamowu↓, (K,) signifies the man's wife's father, (IF, M, Msb, K,) or wife's brother, or wife's paternal uncle; (M, Msb, K;) so that Hmw applies to a relation on either side, like SihorN: (Msb:) and OaHomaMCN means a husband's people: (Mgh:) or the OaHomaMC are peculiarly of the wife; (K;) and the OaxotaAn are of the man [or husband]: (TA:) or [in other words] the AHyMC are [the woman's relations] on the side of the husband; (As, TA;) and the AxtAn are [the husband's relations] on the side of the wife; (As, S, Msb, TA;) and those of both sides are included by the term [OaSohaArN, pl. of] SihorN: (As, S, TA:) and OaHomaMCu fulaAnapa is said to mean such a woman's husband's people. (IB, TA.)

HumapN Hm Hmh Hmp
HumapN: see art. HmI.

HamFA Hm HmA
HamFA: see HamN, above, in three places.

Hamuw Hm Hmw
Hamuw: see HamN, above, in three places.

HamowN Hm Hmw
HamowN: see HamN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Hayowu AlXRamosi
[in the CK HamoWu] The heat of the sun: (Ks, S, * K:) as also HamoyuhaA.(Ks, S.)

HamaApN HAmy Hm HmAh HmAp HmI Hmp
HamaApN: see HamN. ＝ -A2- Also The muscle (EaDalap) of the saAq [which means the shank of a human being, and, properly speaking, the corresponding part (commonly called the thigh) of a horse and the like]: (S, K:) an elevated piece of flesh in the inner side of the sAq: (Lth:) As says, in the sAq of the horse are the HamaAtaAni, which are the two pieces of flesh that are in the side of the sAq, appearing like two sinews, in the outer side and the inner side: (S, TA:) or, accord. to ISh, they are the two elevated pieces of flesh in the half of each sAq, in the outer side: or, accord. to ISd, the two compact pieces of flesh in the upper portion of the outer side of each sAq: (TA:) pl. HamawaAtN. (S, K.)

HamowapN Hm HmI Hmw Hmwh Hmwp Hmy
HamowapN: see HamaI AlkalaOa, in the second sentence of art. HmI.

HimowapN Hm HmI Hmw Hmwh Hmwp Hmy
HimowapN: see Hamayotu AlmariyDa, in art. HmI.

HimawaAni HmwAn
HimawaAni an irregular dual of HimFI. (Ks, S and TA in art. HmI, q. v.)

HumuwRapN Hm HmI Hmw Hmwh Hmwp Hmy
HumuwRapN: see HumayRaA, in art. HmI.

1 HamaAhu HAmy Hm HmAh HmAp HmI Hmp
1. HamaAhu, (S, Mgh, K,) aor.
HamiIa
, (K,) inf. n. HimaAyapN (S, Mgh, K [but said in the Msb to be a simple subst., though afterwards there mentioned as an inf. n.,]) and HamoIN and maHomiyapN, (K,) He prohibited it, or interdicted it; or he protected it, defended it, or guarded it, from, or against, encroachment, invasion, or attack. (S, * Mgh, K, * TA.) You say, HamaI AlkalaOa, inf. n. HamoIN and HamiyRapN and HimaAyapN and HamowapN, [the last irreg.,] He prohibited, or interdicted, &c., the herbage, or pasture. (K, * TA.) And HamaI AlmakaAna mina AlnRaAsi, aor.
HamiIa
, inf. n. HamoIN and HimoyapN [and HimaAyapN, though here, in the Msb, said to be a simple subst.], He prohibited, or interdicted, the place; or he protected, defended, or guarded, it; from the people [in general]: (Msb:) and, accord. to IB, AHmAhu↓ signifies the same as HamaAhu: (TA:) or AlmkAn AHmI↓ signifies he made the place to be what is termed HimFI, (S, Msb, K,) not to be approached (Msb, K) nor ventured upon, or attempted: (Msb:) or it signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (Msb,) he found it to be what is termed HimFI: (Msb, K:) or AlHimaI AHmI↓ signifies he made the HmI to be refrained from by people, and to be acknowledged as a HmI: and HamaAhu, he prohibited, or interdicted, it; or he protected it, defended it, or guarded it, from, or against, encroachment, invasion, or attack: (AZ:) accord. to Suh, in the R, AHmAhu↓ is of weak authority; but both these verbs are chaste. (TA.) [Hence,] HamaI Zahorahu [He prohibited, or interdicted, his back to be used for bearing a rider or any burden], said of a stallion-camel when he is termed HaAmK, q. v. (Fr, S, K.) You say also, HamaAhu mina AlXRaIoCi and HamaAhu AlXRaIoCa [He protected, defended, or guarded, him from the thing]. (TA.) And Eanohu HaAmayotu↓, inf. n. muHaAmaApN and HimaMCN, (S, K,) I protected, defended, or guarded, him. (K.) One says, Eano waladihaA AlDRaruwsu tuHaAmiI↓ [The biting she-camel defends her offspring]. (S.) And fulaAnN EiroDahu AHmI↓ [Such a one defended his honour, or reputation]. (TA.) And Hamayotu Alqawoma, inf. n. HimaAyapN, I aided [and defended] the people, or party. (Msb.) And Hamayotu AlmariyDa (S, Msb, K) AlTRaEaAma, (S,) or maA yaDurRuhu, (K,) inf. n. HimoyapN (S, Msb) and HimowapN, (S, TA,) [the latter irreg.,] I prohibited, or interdicted, the sick man, (K,) or ordered him to abstain, (PS,) from the food, (PS,) or from what would injure him. (K.) ＝ -A2- HamiIa, said of the day, and of an oven, (S,) and Hamiyato, said of the sun, and of fire, aor.
HamaIa
, (K,) inf. n. HamoIN (S, K) and HumiIRN (K) and HumuwRN [originally HumuwIN], (Lh, K,) It was, or became, vehemently hot. (S, K.) And HamiIa AlmisomaAru, inf. n. HamoIN and HumuwRN, The iron nail was, or became, hot. (K.) And Hamiyati AlHadiydapu The piece of iron was, or became, vehemently hot by means of fire. (Msb.) ― -b2- HamiIa AlwaTiysu [lit. The oven became vehemently hot;] means (assumed tropical:) the war, or fight, became vehement; (S and K in art. wTs;) and is used as a prov., relating to a severe case or event. (As, TA in that art.) ― -b3- HamiIa Alfarasu, inf. n. HimFI [and app., accord. to the TA, HamoIN also], The horse was, or became, hot, and sweated. (K.) ― -b4- Hamiytu fiI AlgaDabi [I was, or became, hot in anger], inf. n. HamiIRN. (Lh, TA.) And gaDabFA AHtmI↓ [He became hot by reason of anger]. (A in art. lgd.) And Hamiytu Ealayohi, accord. to El-Umawee, [HamiYotu,] with hemz, I was, or became, angry with him. (S, TA.) And HamiIa Oanofuhu He became vehemently angry, or enraged. (IAth, TA in art. Anf.) And HamiIa Eanohu, (S,) or minohu, (K,) or both, (TA,) aor.
HamaIa
, (K,) inf. n. HamiyRapN (S, Mgh, * Msb, * K) and maHomiyapN, (S, Mgh, * K,) i. q. Oanifa [He disdained it; scorned it; &c.]; (S, Mgh, * Msb, * K;) he was ashamed, and he disdained, or scorned, to do it. (S, TA.) And HamiIa mino celika OanofFA He was seized, or affected, thereat, or by reason of that, with disdain, scorn, or indignation. (TA, from a trad.) And HamiIa also signifies He refused to bear, endure, or tolerate, wrongful treatment. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also 4.

HumapN The venom, or poison, (Lth, Lh, S, K,) and hurt, (S,) of a scorpion, (Lth, S,) and of anything that stings or bites: (Lth:) originally HumawN or HumFI: (S:) and IAar mentions HumRapN [q. v. in art. Hm]. (TA.) ― -b2- And The sting of the hornet, (Lth, K,) and of the scorpion, (Lth, IAth,) and the like, (Lth,) and of the serpent; (K;) because the venom comes forth from it: (IAth:) so applied by the vulgar: (Lth:) pl. HumaAtN and HumFI. (K.) ― -b3- Vehemence of cold. (K, * TA.)

HamaI waQllRehi [or HamaA wAllReh] i. q. OamaAwAllReh q. v. (Sgh, K.) ＝ -A2- AlHamaI [or AlHamaA] for AlHamaAm: see HamaAmN, in art. Hm.

HimFI Hm HmI Hmp Hmy
HimFI A thing prohibited, or interdicted; (S, K;) as also HimaMCN↓ and HimoyapN↓; (K;) and not to be approached: (S:) [and, as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] a place of herbage, or pasture, (Lth, Mgh, Msb, * TA, and Ham p. 539,) and of water, (Ham ibid.,) prohibited to the people, [i. e. to the public,] (Lth, Mgh, and Ham ubi suprà,) so that they may not pasture their beasts in it, (Lth, Mgh,) nor approach it, (Mgh, Msb,) nor venture upon it: (Msb:) it was a custom of the noble among the Arabs, in the Time of Ignorance, when he alighted in a district [that pleased him], among his kinsfolk, to incite a dog to bark, and to prohibit for his own special friends or dependents the space throughout which the bark of the dog was heard, so that none else should pasture his beasts there; while he shared with the people in the other places of pasture, around it: but the Prophet forbade this: (Esh-Sháfi'ee, TA:) he said, “ There shall be no HmI except for God and for his Apostle; ” (Esh-Sháfi'ee, S, Mgh, TA;) meaning, except for the horses employed in war against the unbelievers and for the camels taken for the poor-rate: (Esh-Sháfi'ee, Mgh, TA:) afterwards, the term was applied in a general sense: (Esh-Sháfi'ee, TA:) the pl. is OaHomaMCN (S
and K in art. Hjr) and OaHomiyapN: (Ham p. 496:) and the dual is HimayaAni and HimawaAni; (ISk, S, Msb, TA;) the latter irreg., (TA,) heard by Ks, but be preferred the former. (S.) You say, hecaA XaIoCN HimFI This is a thing prohibited, or interdicted; not to be approached. (S.) And kalaON HimFI Herbage, or pasture, that is prohibited, or interdicted. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also HimaMCN.

HimoyapN Hm Hmy Hmyh Hmyp
HimoyapN: see the next preceding paragraph. ＝ -A2- Also an inf. n. of HamaI AlmakaAna [q. v.]: (Msb:) and of Hamayotu AlmariyDa [q. v.]. (S, Msb.) ＝ -A3- Also The practising abstinence; (PS in art. Azm;) [especially the abstaining from things injurious in a case of sickness;] the abstaining, or desisting, from eating. (TA in that art.)

HimaMCN HmMC
HimaMCN: see HimFI. ＝ -A2- HimaMCN laka or HimaMCF laka i. q. fidaMCN laka [May such a person, or thing, be a ransom for thee!] or fidaMCF laka [meaning fudiyta, i. e. mayest thou be ransomed!] or fadaAka, i. e. may such a one ransom thee!]. (S, accord. to different copies.) [And in like manner,] the Arabs said, laka AlfidaI waAlHimaI↓ [Ransom, or ransoming, be for thee!] pronouncing the former noun with the short alif when thus coupling it with AlHimaI. (El-Kálee, TA in art. fdI.)

HamiIRN Hm HmI Hmp Hmy
HamiIRN A sick man prohibited, or interdicted, from what would injure him, (IAar, K,) of food and drink. (IAar.) ― -b2- Protected, defended, or guarded (S, * Mgh, K, TA) from evil, &c. (TA.) 'Ásim Ibn-Thábit El Ansáree was called HamiIRu AldRabori [The protected by hornets, or by the swarm of bees], (S, Mgh,) because his corpse was protected from his enemies by large hornets, (S in art. dbr,) or by a swarm of bees. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- One who will not bear, endure, or tolerate, wrongful treatment. (K.) And HamiIRu AlOanofi A man who refuses to submit to wrongful treatment. (TA. [See also OanofN.])

HamiyRapN Hm Hmy Hmyh Hmyp
HamiyRapN an inf. n. of HamiIa: (S, K: [see HamiIa Eanohu:]) Disdain, scorn, or indignation; and anger; syn. OanafapN, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) and gayorapN; (TA;) because a means of protection: (Mgh:) care of what is sacred, or inviolable, or of what one is bound to respect, or honour, and to defend, and of religion, to avoid suspicion. (KT.)

HumayRaA HmI Hmy HmyA
HumayRaA The vehemence of anger; and the commencement [or outburst] thereof: (K:) spirit, and anger; as in the saying, UinRahu laXadiydu AlHumayRaA [Verily he is vehement in spirit, and in anger]. (TA.) ― -b2- The assault of wine upon the head; or its rush into the head: (K:) or the beginning of its assault upon, or rush into, the head: (S:) and its force, or vehemence: or its intoxicating operation: or its overpowering influence upon the head; (K;) or upon the drinker: (Lth, TA:) or the creeping [of the fumes] of wine [through the drinker]. (A 'Obeyd, TA.) One says, saArato fiyhi HumayRaA AlkaOosi, meaning [The fumes of] the cup of wine mounted into his head. (TA.) And HumuwRapN [originally HumuwyapN] signifies The assault, or attack, of pain. (S, TA.) ― -b3- The prime, and sprightliness, of youth; (K:) and the flush, or impetuosity, (saworap,) thereof. (TA.) You say, faEala celika fiI HumayRaA XabaAbihi He did that in the flush, or impetuosity, (swrp,) and sprightliness, of his youth. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AlHumayRaA huwa HaAmiI↓ He is the protector, defender, or guarder [from encroachment], of that which he possesses, and of which he has the superintendence, or management. (S, K.)

HaAmK HAm HAmy
HaAmK [act. part. n. of HamaI. And hence,] A stallion-camel that has prohibited, or interdicted, his back [to be used for bearing a rider or any burden]; (Zahorahu HamaI↓; Fr, S, K;) that is not ridden, (Fr, S, Mgh,) nor shorn of any of his fur; (Fr, S;) that is left at liberty, not made any use of, (K,) nor debarred from pasturage (Fr, S, Mgh, K) nor from water: (K:) he is one that has long continued with a people: (S:) or whose offspring's offspring has conceived: (Fr, S Mgh:) or that has covered a certain number of times, or ten times: (K:) it is mentioned in the Kur [v. 102]. (S, Mgh. [See also baHiyrapN]) ― -b2- AlHaAmiI is also an appellation applied to The lion; and so AlmaHomiIRu↓; (K;) in the Tekmileh, AlHAmI and AlmuHomI↓ [app. AlmuHomiI, as in a copy of the K]. (TA.) ― -b3- You say also, fulaAnN HaAmiI AlHaqiyqapi [Such a one is the protector, or defender, of that which, or those whom, it is necessary for him, or incumbent on him, to protect, or defend]; like HaAmiI AlcRimaAri [q. v. in art. cmr]; and HaAmiI AlHumayRaA [explained in the next preceding paragraph]: pl. HumaApN and [coll. gen. n.] HaAmiyapN↓: (S:) this last word signifies a company, or party, protecting, or defending, their companions, (K,) or themselves: (TA:) and also a man who is a protector, or defender, of his companions (K) in war: (TA:) or a strenuous protector and defender of a party; for the p is to give intensiveness to the signification: (Mgh:) and you say, huwa EalaI HaAmiyapi Alqawomi, meaning He is the last of those who protect, or defend, the party in their going away (K) and in their state of defeat. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [Hot: or vehemently hot.] You say HadiydapN HaAmiyapN A piece of iron vehemently hot by means of fire. (Msb.) And qidoru Alqawomi HaAmiyapN tafuwru The people's cooking-pot is hot, boiling: meaning (assumed tropical:) the people are mighty, strong, or invincible, and vehemently impetuous in valour. (TA.)

HaAmiypN HAmy HAmyh HAmyp
HaAmiypN: see HaAmK. ― -b2- Also A great, or wide, or great and wide, mass of stone, (HimaArapN K accord. to the TA,) or the stones, (HijaArap, so in some copies of the K,) with which a well is cased: (K:) pl. HawaAmK: (TA:) or the latter signifies the stones &c. with which a well is cased, to protect its sides from becoming dirty and disordered: (Ham p. 62:) or great and heavy stones: and also large masses of rock which are placed in the last parts of the casing [of a well] if it falls out through age: they dig out hollows, and build them therein, so that they suffer not the earth to come near to the casing, but repel it: (ISh:) and all the stones [of the casing] of a well, matching one another, none of them larger than another. (AA.) ― -b3- The circuit of the solid hoof: (Ham p. 62:) or [the dual] HaAmiyataAni signifies the part on the right and left of the toe of the solid hoof: (AO, S:) or [the pl.] HawaAmK signifies the right and left edges of the solid hoofs; (As, TA;) between them are [the] nusuwr [or frogs], like hard date-stones: (Aboo-Dáwood, TA:) or the right and left sides of the solid hoof. (K.) ― -b4- [The pl. also signifies The sides of a mountain. (Freytag, from the Deewán of Jereer.)] ― -b5- Also, the sing., i. q. OuvofiyRapN [i. e. Any one of the three stones on which the cookingpot is placed]: (AA, K:) pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b6- maDayotu EalaI HaAmiyatiI means I went my own way. (Sgh, K.)

huwa OaHomaI OanofFA mino fulaAnK (S, TA) He is more resistive than such a one. (TA.)

AlmaHomiIRu: see HaAmK.

muHomawomK Black; applied to such a thing as the night, and a collection of clouds: or, applied to the latter, heaped up, and black. (Lth.)

1 HanRa HAn Hn Hnn
1. HanRa, aor.
Hanina
, inf. n. HaniynN, He was, or became, affected with [a yearning, longing, or desire, or] an intense emotion of grief or of joy; as also AstHnR↓ and tHAnR↓. (K.) [See an instance of its denoting an emotion of joy voce HanRaAnN.] You say, HanRa Uilayohi, aor. and inf. n. as above, He, or his soul, yearned towards, longed for, or desired, him, or it. (S.) And HanRa UilaI waTanihi He yearned towards, longed for, or desired, his home. (TA.) And taHinRa UilaI zawojihaA AlOawRali [She yearns towards her first, or former, husband]. (TA.) And HanRato, inf. n. as above, She (a woman) yearned towards, longed for, or desired, her child, or children. (Msb.) So, too, one says of a she-camel, meaning She yearned towards, longed for, or desired, her home, or her young one; and in like manner, of a pigeon: but in most instances it means she (a camel) yearned with a cry, or uttered a cry when yearning [or a yearning cry or the cry produced by yearning], towards her young one or her companions: or she uttered a cry with emotion after her young one: in its primary sense, she reiterated her [yearning] cry after her young one: but when you say, HanRa qalobiI Uilayohi, you mean My heart yearned towards, longed for, or desired, him, or it, without the uttering of a cry or sound. (TA.) They said also, laAOafoEaluhu HatRaI yaHinRa AlDRabRu fiI Oavari AlUibili AlSRaAdirapi [I will not do it until the lizard called DbR yearn after the camels returning from the water; meaning I will never do it]: this is only a prov.; for the DbR has no Haniyn nor does it ever go to the water. (TA.) [And HnRa AlEuwdu, aor. and inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) The lute produced plaintive sounds: or excited lively emotions of sadness, or of mirth: see HanRaAnN. And in like manner one says of a musical reed: see
muvaqRab.] And HanRati Alqawosu, (K,) aor. as above, (S,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The bow [twanged, or] made a sound (K, TA) when its string had been pulled and then let go. (S.) And HanRati AlTRasotu UicaA nuqirato (tropical:) [The brazen basin rang when it was knocked, or pecked]. (TA.) And HanRati AlsRaAriyapu [The mast creaked, or made a creaking sound]. (TA in art. Sr.) And HanRa qidoHu layosa minohaA (assumed tropical:) [An arrow of those used in the game called Almayosir produced a sound: it was not of them]: a prov., applied to a man who ascribes to himself a false origin, or who arrogates to himself that to which he has no relation: by the qdH is meant one of the arrows of the mysr; for when this is not of the same substance as the others, and is made to vibrate, it produces a sound different from the sounds of the others, and is known thereby. (TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 341.]) And HanRati AlrRiyHu and AstHnRt↓ (assumed tropical:) [The wind made a plaintive, or moaning, or perhaps a shrill, sound; made a sound like the Haniyn of camels: see HanuwnN]: both signify the same. (TA.) [See also HaniynN, below.] ― -b2- HanRa Ealayohi, (S, Msb, TA,) aor. as above, (S, Msb,) inf. n. HanaAnN (S, Msb, K *) and HanRapN (Msb, TA *) and HanRN, (K, * TA,) He was merciful, compassionate, or pitiful, towards him, or it; (S, Msb, K, * TA:) as also tHnRn↓: (S, K:) he was, or became, favourably inclined towards him, or it; (Msb;) and so tHnRn↓: (TA:) he was, or became, affectionate, or pitiful, or compassionate, towards him; (K, * TA;) as also HanoHana↓. (IAar, Az, K.) And EalaI waladihaA taHanRanato↓ She (a camel, and a ewe or goat,) became favourably inclined, or compassionate, towards her young one. (Lh, TA.) ― -b3- See also 2. ― -b4- HanRa EanRiI, aor.
Hanuna
, means SadRa; (S;) i. e. He turned away from me, avoided me, or shunned me: so that it is anomalous; for by rule the aor. should be
Hanina
; and it is not mentioned among the exceptions [to the rule applying to a case of this kind]. (MF, TA.) [But it appears from what here follows that SadRa may perhaps be here meant to be understood in its trans. sense.] ＝ -A2- HanRahu, (K,) [aor.
Hanuna
, as is shown below,] inf. n. HanRN, (TA,) signifies SadRahu and Sarafahu [He turned him, or it, away, or back]. (K, TA.) You say, HunRa EanRiI XarRaka, inf. n. HanRN, Turn thou away, or back, from me thy evil, or mischief. (K.) And maA taHunRuniI XayoYFA mino XarRika Thou dost not turn away, or back, from me aught of thy evil, or mischief (S.) ＝ -A3- [HunRa, inf. n. HanRN, app. He was, or became, possessed by a demon, or by one of the tribe or kind or class termed AlHinR; and hence, he was, or became, mad, or insane: for] HanRN is syn. with junuwnN; (TA as from the K; [but not in the CK nor in my MS. copy of the K;]) whence maHonuwnN applied to a man [as meaning majonuwnN]. (TA.)

2: [HnRnhu EalaI gayorihi, accord. to modern usage, and perhaps classical also, He, or it, caused him to be merciful, compassionate, pitiful, or favourably inclined, towards another.] ＝ -A2- Hamala faHanRana He charged, or made an assault or attack, and was cowardly, and retreated. (K, TA.) ― -b2- maA HanRana EanRiI He did not turn away from me; did not leave, or relinquish, me. (TA.) [And AHnR↓, or HanRa↓, seems to have a similar meaning: for] you say, OavarN laA yuHinRu Eani Aljilodi A mark that does not go away from the skin: or, accord. to Th, who does not explain it, it is yaHinRu. (TA.) ＝ -A3- HanRanati AlXRajarapu The tree blossomed, or flowered: (K:) and in like manner one says of a herb. (TA.)

AlHinRu A tribe of the jinR [or genii], (S, K,) that were before Adam; (TA;) of which are black dogs: (K:) or the lowest, or meanest, sort of the jinR: (K:) or the weak ones thereof: (IAar, K:) or the dogs thereof: (Fr, TA:) or certain creatures between the jinR and mankind. (S, K.)

HanRapN: see HanaAnN. ― -b2- It is said in a prov., laA taEodamu naAqapN mino OumRihaA HanRapF, and HaniynFA↓, meaning [The she-camel will not be without] likeness [to her mother]: and one says of a man who resembles another man, and of any one who resembles his father and his mother, laA taEodamu OadomaMCu mino OumRihaA HanRapF [A female camel of the colour termed Oudomap (i. e. white, or very white, &c.,) will not be without likeness to her mother]. HanaAnN HnAn
HanaAnN Mercy, compassion, or pity: (S, K:) tenderness of heart; (K;) which is the same; (TA;) as also HinRapN↓, with kesr; (Kr, TA;) for which the vulgar say HanRiyRipN↓: (TA:) and HanRapN↓ [in like manner] signifies affection, and compassion. (Az, TA.) waHanaAnFA mino ladunRaA, in the Kur [xix. 14], respecting which I 'Ab is related by 'Ikrimeh to have said, I know not what is AlHanaAnu, means And mercy from us. (S, TA.) The Arabs say, HanaAnaka yaA rabRi and HanaAnayoka [I beg thy mercy, O my Lord]: both signify the same; i. e. raHomataka: (S:) the latter is the expression commonly used: (A 'Obeyd, in a marginal note in a copy of the S:) or [rather] the latter means have mercy on me time after time, and with mercy after mercy: (K, * TA:) it is a dualized inf. n., of which the verb is not expressed; like labRayoka and saEodayoka: (TA:) or it means [let thy mercy be continuous to me;] whenever I receive mercy and good from Thee, let it not cease, but be conjoined with other mercy from Thee: (ISd, TA:) the dual form is not to be understood as restricting the signification to duality: (Suh, TA:) the word is not used in this form otherwise than as a prefixed noun: (Sb, TA:) but sometimes they said HanFAnFA, in the sing., without prefixing it. (ISd, TA.) They said also, suboHaAna QllRehi waHanaAnayohi meaning [I extol, or celebrate, or declare, the absolute purity, or perfection, or glory, of God,] and I beg his mercy; like as they said, suboHaAna QllRehi warayoHaAnahu. (TA.) And HanaAna QllRehi as meaning maEaAca QllRehi [I seek the protection, or preservation, of God]. (K.) ― -b2- Also i. q. rizoqN [Means of subsistence, &c.]: and barakapN [a blessing; any good that is bestowed by God; prosperity, or good fortune; increase; &c.]. (K.) ― -b3- A quality inspiring reverence or veneration or respect or honour: (El-Umawee, K:) gravity, staidness, or sedateness. (K.) One says, maAtaraI lahu HanaAnFA Thou seest him not to possess any quality inspiring reverence &c. (El-Umawee, TA.) ＝ -A2- Evil, or mischief, long continuing. (K.)

HanuwnN Hnwn
HanuwnN A wind (riyH) [that makes a plaintive, or moaning, or perhaps a shrill, sound;] that makes a sound like the Haniyn of camels. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- A woman who marries from a motive of tenderness, or compassion, for her children, (K, TA,) when they are young, (TA,) in order that the husband may maintain them. (K, TA.)

HaniynN Hnyn
HaniynN an inf. n. of 1: (S, Msb, K:) A yearning, longing, or desire; (S, K;) a yearning, or longing, of the soul: (S:) or the expression of pain arising from yearning or longing or desire: (Ham p. 538:) violence of weeping: and a lively emotion: or the sound produced by such emotion, proceeding from grief, or from joy: (K:) or a sound proceeding from the bosom on the occasion of weeping: xaniynN is from the nose: (TA:) or the former is [a sound] without weeping and without tears: if with weeping, it is termed xaniynN: (R, TA:) or the former is a yearning, or longing, or desire, with affection, or pity, or compassion; as when one speaks of the Hnyn of a woman and of a she-camel for her young one: and sometimes this is accompanied with a sound, or cry; wherefore it is explained as a sound, or cry, indicating yearning or longing or desire, and affection or pity or compassion: and sometimes it is confined to the form; as in the case of the Hnyn [or leaning, or inclining,] of the trunk of a palm-tree [which is mentioned in a trad.]: (Er-Rághib:) the Hnyn of the she-camel is ber cry in her yearning towards her young one: (S:) or her yearning towards her young one with a cry, and without a cry; (Lth, TA;) mostly the former: originally, her reiterating her [yearning] cry after her young one. (TA.) You say also, riyHN lahaA HaniynN kaHaniyni AlUibili (assumed tropical:) [A wind that has a plaintive, or moaning, or perhaps a shrill, sound, like the Hnyn of camels]. (S, K *) ― -b2- See also HanRapN ＝ -A2- HaniynN and AlHaniynu, and HinRiynN↓ and AlHinRiynu, two names of [The
months called] jumaAdaI AlOuwlaI and AlMxirapu: (K:) or HaniynN is a name of jmAdI AlAwlI, like a proper name; as also AlHaniynu: (M, TA:) or the name by which the tribe of 'Ád called jmAdI AlMxrp: (Ibn-El-Kelbee, in TA voce muWotamirN: see XahorN:) or, accord. to Fr and El-Mufaddal, the Arabs used to call this month HunayonN↓: (T, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaHinRapN and [of mult.] HunuwnN and HanaAYinu. (K.)

HunayonN Hnyn
HunayonN: see what next precedes.

kalobN HinRiIRN A dog of the tribe of the jinR called AlHinR. (TA.)

HanRiyRapN Hny Hnyh Hnyp
HanRiyRapN: see HanaAnN.

HanRaAnN HnAn
HanRaAnN One who yearns towards, longs for, or desires, a thing, (K,) and inclines to it. (TA.) [Hence,] HanRaAnapN A woman who remembers a former husband with yearning (AlHnyn) and grieving, or moaning, (K, TA,) in tenderness for her children, when they are young, that the husband may maintain them; like OanRaAnapN: or who yearns towards her former husband, and inclines to him: or who yearns towards her child, or children, by her husband who has separated from her: (TA:) or a woman who yearns towards her former husband, and grieves for him: or who marries, having been divorced, and yearns towards him who has divorced her. (Har p. 569.) And (assumed tropical:) A bow; (K;) [because of the sound made by the twanging of its string;] accord. to AHn, as a proper name; but ISd holds it to be, when thus applied, an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant: (TA:) or a bow that [twangs, or] makes a sound (S, K) when its string has been pulled and then let go. (S.) And EuwdN HanRaAnN (tropical:) [A lute that produces plaintive sounds: or] that excites lively emotions of sadness, or of mirth. (TA.) And saHaAbN HanRaAnN (assumed tropical:) Clouds that have [or produce] a Haniyn [or moaning sound, by their thunder heard from a distance,] like the Haniyn of camels. (TA.) And sahomN HanRaAnN (assumed tropical:) An arrow that produces a sound when thou triest its sonorific quality by turning it round between thy fingers: (AHeyth, K, TA: [in the CK, naqarotuhu is erroneously put for naqRarotahu:]) or that produces a sound when it is turned round (Oudiyra [or OudirRa]) with the ends of the fingers upon the thumbs, by reason of the excellence and compactness of its wood. (TA. [See darRa AlsRahomu, in art. dr.]) And ximosN HanRaAnN (tropical:) i. q. baAYiSN [A hurrying, or hard, journey in which the camels are watered only on the first and fifth days: (in the CK and a MS. copy of the K, erroneously, nAbDN:)] (K, TA) i. e. (As, TA) in which there is a Haniyn [or yearning of the camels] by reason of its quickness; (As, K, TA;) or in which the camels yearn [towards their accustomed places] (taHinRu) by reason of fatigue. (A, TA.) And TariyqN HanRaAnN (tropical:) A conspicuous road, (S, K, TA,) in which the old camel becomes joyous (yaHinRu, i. e. yanobasiTu): or, accord. to the A, a road in which there is [heard] a Haniyn [or yearning cry] of the camels; like TariyqN nahRaAmN meaning a road in which is [heard] a nahiym [or chiding] of camels. (TA.) ― -b2- One who shows favour, or presents a favourable aspect, to him who turns from him, or shuns him. (K.) ― -b3- Merciful, or having mercy. (S.) [Hence,] AlHanRaAnu a name of God; (K;) meaning The Merciful (Aboo-Is-hák, Az, IAth, K) to his servants. (IAth, TA.)

HinRaAnN HnAn
HinRaAnN i. q. HinRaMCN [Lawsonia inermis, or Egyptian privet, mentioned in art. HnO]; (K;) a dial. var. of the latter: (Fr, Th, TA:) and HunRaAnN is said to be a pl.; (TA in the present art.;) i. e. of HinRaMC, anomalously; or a dial. var. thereof. (TA in art. HnO.) [See also what next follows.]

HanRuwnN Hnwn
HanRuwnN i. q. faAgiyapN [The flower of the HinRaMC]: or the flower of any tree (K) and plant: n. un. with p. (TA.) [See also what next precedes.]

HinRiynN Hnyn
HinRiynN and AlHinRiynu: see HaniynN

HaAnRN HAn
HaAnRN Yearning, longing, or desiring: (S:) or being affected with an intense emotion of grief or of joy. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence, the fem.] HaAnRapN signifies A she-camel; [because of her yearning towards her young one;] (S, K;) as also musotaHanRN↓, (as in some copies of the S,) or musotaHinRN↓, (as in other copies of the S and in the K,) [both of which may be correct, as AstHnR is both trans. and intrans.:] or musotaHanRN signifies one who is affected with intense emotion by longing for his home (AlRaciI QsotaHanRahu AlXRawoqu UilaI waTanihi). (IB, TA.) One says, maAlahu HaAnRapN walaA MnRapN He has not a she-camel nor a sheep, or goat. (S, TA.) [See also MnRN.] AZ mentions the saying, maAlahu HaAnRapN walaA jaArRapN, as meaning He has not camels that yearn [towards their young ones] (taHinRu) nor such as carry goods, or furniture and utensils, and wheat, or food. (TA.)

maHonuwnN, applied to a man, (S, i. q. majonuwnN [properly Possessed by a jinRiIR; and hence, mad, or insane]: (S, K: [see AlHinRu:]) or i. q. maSoruwEN [as meaning affected with epilepsy]: (K:) or one who is affected with epilepsy (yuSoraEu) and then revives for a time. (AA, TA.)

musotaHanRN mstHn
musotaHanRN, or musotaHinRN: see HaAnRN

HinRaMCN [A certain plant] well known; (S, K;) [the Lawsonia inermis, or Egyptian privet;] used for dyeing the extremities [i. e. the hands and feet and head]: (TA:) [in the present day, the plant itself is called vamaru AlHinRaMCi, (vulgo tamarHinRaA,) and its leaves, used for dyeing the hands &c., are called HinRaMC:] accord. to some, it is the pl. of HinRaMCapN; [or rather a coll. gen. n., of which HnRMCp is the n. un.;] but it is generally asserted that HnRMCp is a more special word than HnRMC, [as in the S and Msb,] and not the sing. of the latter: (TA:) pl. HunoMnN. (K.) HunRaMnN is said to be an anomalous pl. of HnRMC; or a dial. var. of the latter, and not a pl.: (TA:) and HinRaAnN is a dial. var. of HinRaMCN. (Fr, Th, TA in art. Hn.)

HinRaAYiIRN A seller of HinRaMC: pl. HinRaAYiyRuwna. (K.)

2 HnRbhu Hnbh Hnbp
2. HnRbhu, inf. n. taHoniybN, It (old age, TA) bent him down. (K, * TA.) [See its quasi-pass., 5.] ― -b2- HnRb OazajFA He built firmly a structure of the kind called Oazaj, and made it curved. (K.) ― -b3- taHoniybN [as an inf. n. of which the verb, if it have one in any of the following senses, is HunRiba,] also signifies A bending, or curving, and tension [of the sinews] (tawotiyrN), of the backbone (Sulob) and fore legs of a horse: (As, S:) or a convexity in the shank (waZiyf) of each of the fore legs of a horse, (K, * TA,) not being a great curvature, (TA,) and in the backbone (Sulob): (K:) it is a quality indicative of strength: (Az, TA:) tajoniybN (with j) is [the same] in the hind legs: (As, S, K:) or it [i. e. tHnyb as indicated in the K and by an explanation of muHanRabN, but the same explanation is also given to mujanRabN,] is width in the space between the hind legs, without what is termed fajajN [i. e. straddling], or faHajN [i. e. the having the fore parts of the feet near together and the heels distant, or having the legs wide apart (like fajajN), or having the thighs or the middles of the legs wide apart]; (so accord. to different copies of the K;) which is a quality approved: (TA:) or a curving in the saAqaAni [here app. meaning the hind legs, or rather the hind shanks; see muHanRabN]: as also HanabN [an inf. n. of which the verb, if it have one, is app. Haniba↓]: (K:) or a curving of the ribs. (TA.) [See tajoniybN: and see also muHanRabN.]

5. tHnRb He (a man, S) was, or became, crooked, curved, or bent. (S, K.) ― -b2- [And hence,] tHnRb Ealayohi (tropical:) He was, or became, affected with compassion for him. (K, TA.)

muHanRabN An old man bent (K, TA) with age. (TA.) ― -b2- A horse characterized by what is termed
taHoniybN: (K:) [see 2:]) accord. to A 'Obeyd, wide in the space between the hind legs, without fajajN, or faHajN: (so accord. to different copies of the S: [see these terms explained above, conj. 2:]) an epithet of commendation: (S:) accord. to ISh, having curved bones: the mare, he says, is termed HanobaMCu↓: and this latter, accord. to As, is an epithet applied to a mare curved in the saAqaAni [or shanks] of the fore legs: or, accord. to IAar, in [the shanks of] the hind legs: or, as he says in another place, curved in the sAq [here app. meaning the hind shank]. (TA.) [See also mujanRabN.]

Hbl,] applied to a man, (S, Msb,) Short: (S, Msb, K:) and, (K,) as some say, (Msb,) large in the belly, (Az, ISd, Msb, K,) and short: (Az, ISd, Msb:) and [in the CK “ or ”] fleshy; (ISd, K;) as also HinobaAlN↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- A fur-garment: (Az, S, K:) or an old and worn-out fur-garment. (ISd, K.) ― -b2- An old and worn-out boot. (ISd, K.) ＝ -A3- The sea; as also HinobaAlapN↓. (ISd, K.)

HanotamN A green jarRap [or jar], (S, K,) to which some add, including to redness: (TA:) or winejars, (A 'Obeyd, Nh,) glazed, or varnished, green, (Nh,) which used to be carried to El-Medeeneh, with wine in them: (A 'Obeyd, Nh:) the use of which, for preparing nabiyc therein, is forbidden in a trad., because it quickly became potent in them, by reason of the glazing, or varnish; or, as some say, because they used to be made of clay kneaded with blood and hair; but the former is the right reason: afterwards applied to any jars, or pottery: (Nh:) thus some explain it as a sing.; (MF;) and the pl. is HanaAtimu: (Az, TA:) others, as a pl. [or coll. gen. n.], of which the sing. [or n. un.] is with p: (MF:) some say that the n is augmentative: so says the author of the Msb: others, that it is radical. (TA.) [See art. Htm.] ― -b2- Black clouds; (Az, K;) as also [the pl.] HanaAtimu: (Az, S, K:) because, with the Arabs, AlsRawaAdu is [used for] xuDorapN: (S: [see Oasowadu; and see also HanotamN in art. Htm:]) or as being likened to HanaAtim (meaning jars) filled [with water]: (Az, TA:) n. un. with p. (K.) ― -b3- The colocynthplant; (K, TA;) because of its intense greenness: n. un. with p. (TA.)

Hanava
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. HinovN (S, * A, Msb, K *) and HanavN, (TA,) He violated, or broke, or failed of performing, his oath: (A, Msb, K, TA:) he was untrue in his oath: (S, TA:) he committed a sin, or crime, in his oath. (TA.) Also He retracted, or revoked, his oath. (TA.) ― -b2- And the verb alone, He said what was not true. (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, TA.) ― -b3- He inclined from what was false to what was true: or from what was true to what was false. (K.) ― -b4- [And app. (assumed tropical:) He committed a sin, or crime: a meaning which seems to be indicated in the K: see HinovN, below.]

4. OaHonavotuhu (S, K) fiI yamiynihi (S) I made him to violate, or break, or fail of performing, his oath. (S, K. *) ― -b2- AHnv fulaAnN qasama fulaAnK Such a one assented not, or consented not, to the conjurement of such a one; contr. of OabarRa. (T and TA in art. br.)

5. tHnRv (assumed tropical:) He put away, or cast away, from himself AlHinov, i. e. sin, or crime: (ISd, Towsheeh, TA:) it is said that there are only six verbs of the measure of this signifying the putting away, or casting away, from oneself a thing, [i. e. the thing denoted by the root,] which are tHnRv and tOvRm and tHwRb and tHrRj and tnjRs and thjRd: (TA:) (assumed tropical:) he did a work whereby to escape from sin, or crime: (IAar, Msb:) (assumed tropical:) he applied himself to acts, or exercises, of devotion; (S, A, Msb, K;) accord. to Ez-Zuhree and the K, during numerous nights; but it has been shown by the Expositors of El-Bukháree, and others, that this addition is taken from words following the verb in the explanation of a trad., and has nothing to do with the meaning of the verb itself: (MF, TA:) (assumed tropical:) he relinquished [the worship of] idols; (S, K;) like tHnRf; (S;) and it may be that the v in this verb is interchangeable with f, (A,) or a substitute for f. (TA.) You say also, tHnRv mino kacaA (tropical:) He abstained from such a thing as a sin, or crime; syn. tOvRm, (S, A, K,) and tHrRj. (A.) And tHnRv biOafoEaAlK (assumed tropical:) He sought to bring himself near unto God, or to advance himself in God's favour, by works [of devotion &c.]. (TA.)

HinovN The violation, or failure of performance, of an oath: (S, A, K, TA:) [an inf. n. used as a simple subst.:] pl. OaHonaAvN; as in the saying, Ealayohi OaHonaAvN kaviyrapN [He is accountable for, or chargeable with, many violations, or failures of performance, of oaths]. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A sin, a crime, an offence, or an act of disobedience. (S, A, Msb, K.) So in the saying [in the Kur lvi. 45], wakaAnuwA yuSirRuwna EalaI AlHinovi AlEaZiymi (tropical:) [And they persisted in great sin]; (A;) meaning belief in a plurality of gods. (Bd, Jel.) And hence, (Bd in lvi. 45,) balaga AlHinova (tropical:) He (a boy) attained to the age when he was punishable for sin: (A, * Bd:) or attained to [the age when he became punishable for] disobedience and [rewardable for] obedience: (S:) or attained to the age when the pen [of the recording angels] began to register his acts of obedience and of disobedience: attained to the age of puberty: attained to manhood. (TA.) [Hence also,] OawolaAdu AlHinovi (assumed tropical:) The children of adultery or fornication: occurring in a trad., accord. to one reading: accord. to another reading, AwlAd Alxubovi. (L.)

HanoZalN HnZl
HanoZalN [The colocynth; cucumis colocynthis;] a certain bitter plant; (Msb;) [and its fruit;] well known; (K;) i. q. XaroIN: (S:) n. un. with p: (S, Msb, K: *) [accord. to Freytag (who refers to Avic. p. 175, and Sprengel. hist. rei herb. vol. i. p. 269,) applied also to the momordica elaterium, or cucumis prophetarum:] there is a male species, and a female; the former fibrous; the latter soft, or easily broken, white, and easy to swallow: (TA:) the choice sort of it is the yellow; (K;) or, accord. to the “ Kánoon ” of the Ra-ees [Ibn-Seenà, from which the description of its properties and uses, in the K and TA, is, with some slight variations, taken], the white, very white, and soft; for the black and the hard are bad, and it is not plucked until it becomes yellow, and the greenness has completely gone from it; (TA:) its pulp attenuates the thick phlegmatic humour that flows upon the joints (K, TA) and tendons, (TA,) when swallowed (K, TA) in the dose of of twelve keeráts, (TA,) or used in the manner of a cluster: it is beneficial for melancholy, and epilepsy, and the [sort of doting termed] wasowaAs, and alopecia (daMC AlvRaEolab), and elephantiasis (AljucaAm), (K, TA,) and [the disease of the tumid leg, termed] daMC Alfiyl; for these three used by rubbing; and for the cold niqoris [i. e. arthritis, or gout], (TA,) and for the bite of vipers, and the sting of scorpions, especially its root; (K, TA;) for this last being the most beneficial of medicines; a drachm of its root, administered to an Arab stung by a scorpion in four places, being said to have cured him on the spot: that which is plucked green relaxes [the bowels] excessively, and produces excessive vomiting: so in the “ Kánoon: ” (TA:) it is also beneficial for the tooth-ache, by fumigating with its seeds; and for killing fleas, by sprinkling what is cooked thereof; and for the sciatica, by rubbing with what is green thereof: (K, TA:) its root is cooked with vinegar, and one rinses the mouth with it for the tooth-ache; and the vinegar is cooked in it in hot ashes: when cooked in olive-oil, that oil, being dropped [into the ear-hole], is beneficial for ringing in the ears: it is beneficial also for the moist and flatulent colic: and sometimes it attenuates the blood: administered as a suppository in the vagina, it kills the fœtus: (TA:) when the plant bears a single fruit, this is very deadly. (K, TA.) [See also habiydN.] Accord. to [many of] the leading authorities among the Arabs, (TA,) the n in this word is augmentative; (Msb, TA;) because of their saying, HaZila AlbaEiyru, meaning “ the camel became sick from eating HanoZal; ” and J and Sgh [and Fei and others] have mentioned it in art. HZl: but ISd says that this is not an evidence of its being radically triliteral; and that HaZila is
like DagobapN (as an epithet applied to a woman) from AlDRagaAbiysu, which must be acknowledged to be radically quadriliteral. (TA.)

HaAjapN (S, K, &c.) and HaAYijapN↓, (AA, IDrd, &c.,) of which latter the former is a contraction, (Kh in the 'Eyn, TA,) or the latter word is unused [except as an epithet, as will be seen below], and HawojaMCu↓, (S, K, &c.,) are syn. words, of which the meaning is well known: (S, K, TA:) Want; need; necessity, or necessitude; exigency: (TA:) [whence,] Aibonu HaAjapF one who is constantly in want, or need: (Har p. 143:) HaAjapN is a more general term than faqorN; or each of these terms is more general than the other in some respects, and more particular in others: (TA:) and the former signifies also a thing wanted, needed, or required; an object of want, of need, or of exigence; a want; a needful, or requisite, thing, affair, or business: (A, TA:) [and a thing to be done, an affair, or a business:] pl. HaAjN↓, [or rather this is a coll. gen. n., of which HaAjapN is the n. un.,] and HaAjaAtN, [which is of more frequent occurrence,] (S, Msb, K,) and HiwajN, [which is of rare occurrence,] (S, K,) and HawaAYiju, (S, Msb, K,) which is anomalous, (S, K,) and was disapproved by As, and pronounced by him to be post-classical, but he disapproved it only because of its being anomalous, (S,) and he is said to have retracted his assertion of its being post-classical, (TA,) for it is of frequent occurrence in the [classical] language of the Arabs, (S,) in their verses and in the traditions: (IB, TA:) it seems as though formed from the sing. HaAYijapN, (S, K,) which some assert to have been not used; or, accord. to some, it may be pl.
of HawojaMCu, changed from the regular form of HawaAjK, [originally HawaAjiIu,] like SaHaArK, by putting the [elided] I before the j, agreeably with what is often done in the language of the Arabs. (TA.) You say, qaDaI HaAjatahu [He accomplished his want]: (TA:) a phrase which signifies [also] he did his business; meaning he eased nature. (ISk, TA.) And xuco HaAjataka mina AlTRaEaAmi [Take what thou wantest, or requirest, of the food]. (A.) And fiI nafosiI HaAjapN and HaAYijapN↓ and HawojaMCu↓ [In my mind is a want]. (AA, TA.) And liI Einoda fulaAnK HaAjapN [I want a thing of such a one]. (TA.) [When the thing wanted, or not wanted, is mentioned, or referred to by a pronoun, the subst. denoting it, or the pronoun referring to it, is preceded by UilaI, as in the sayings liI HaAjapN UilaI kacaA I have a want of such a thing, and maA liI Uilayohi HaAjapN I have not any want of it, and maA HaAjatuka Uilayohi What is the reason of thy want of it, or thy wanting it?] You say also, walaA lawojaMCu UilRaA qaDaAhaA maA baqiIa fiI HawojaMCu↓ There remained not in his bosom a want but he accomplished it. (TA.) [The dim. of HawojaMCu is HuwayojaMCu↓: whence the saying,] maA liI fiyhi HawojaMCu↓ walaA luwayojaMCu walaA lawojaMCu walaA HuwayojaMCu↓ I have no want, [nor any little want,] with respect to him, or it. (Lh, S, K.) [See also HawojaMCu, below.] In the phrase Hujo HujayRaAka [Seek the little thing that thou wantest], it seems that the second and third radical letters of the latter word [originally HuwayojaMCaka] have been transposed [and that HujayowaMCaka has been then changed into HujayRaAka]. (IDrd, AAF, TA.) ― -b2- maA tarakotu mino HaAjapK walaA daAjapK I left not any act of disobedience to which I was enticed. (TA from a trad. [But see daAjapN in art. dwj.])

TA.) ― -b2- Also He collected the camels together to drive them. (L.) ― -b3- And Hucotu AlUibila and HicotuhaA, I mastered, or gained the mastery over, the camels: two forms of the verb mentioned by Zj and IKtt and others, as coordinate to qaAla and xaAfa. (MF, TA.) And HAc AlHimaAru Outunahu The he-ass gained the mastery over his she-asses, and collected them together; like HAzhA: (L:) [and so jaAnibayohaA OaHowaca↓:] Lebeed says,
IiXaA LjotamaEatn waOaHowaXa jaAnibatohaA
waOaworadahaA EalaI EuwjK TawaAli
[When they became collected together, and he gained the mastery over their flanks, or] drew them together so that not one of them escaped him, [and brought them to the watering-place, galloping upon long crooked legs; for] by Ewj he means [crooked] legs. (S, L.) ― -b4- And [hence,] HAXhu n. as above; (L;) and AisotaHowaca↓ Ealayohi, (S, A, L, K, *) and AstHAc; (S, L;) He overcame, mastered, or gained the mastery over, him, or it: (S, A, L, K:) [like HAzhu.] You say, EalaI kacaA AstHwc↓ He mastered such a thing; gained the mastery over it; gained possession of it. (L.) Ealayohimu AlXRayoTaAnu AstHwc↓ [in the Kur [viii. 20] means The devil hath overcome them, or gained the mastery over them: (S, L:) or hath gained the mastery over their hearts: (Th, L:) or hath gained the mastery over them, and inclined them to that which he desired of them: (Msb:) or drove them, having gained the mastery over them. (B.) And Ealayokumo Oalamo nasotaHowico↓ [in the Kur iv. 140], Did we not acquire the mastery over your affairs, and gain possession of your affection? (S, L:) or did we not gain the mastery over you by befriending and aiding you? (Aboo-Ishák, L:) or did we not overcome you, and have it in our power to slay you? (Bd.) AZ says that in all verbs coordinate to AstHwc, the original letters of the root may be preserved: that the Arabs say AisotaSaAba and AisotaSowaba, and AisotajaAba and Aisotajowaba: and that their doing so is agreeable with a rule constantly obtaining with them. (S.) The grammarians say that he who says HaAca, aor. yaHuwcu, says only AstHAc; and he who says OaHowaca, says in like manner AstHwc. (L.) ― -b5- Also HAc, aor. yaHuwcu, (L,) inf. n.
