6. tHAwrwA, (Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. taHaAwurN, (S, K,) They returned one another answer for answer, or answers for answers; held a dialogue, colloquy, conference, disputation, or debate, one with another; or bandied words, one with another; syn. tajaAwabuwA, (S, K,) and taraAjaEuwA, (Jel in lviii. & A,) or taraAjaEuwA AlkalaAma, (Msb, K,) or taraAjaEuwA fiI AlkalaAmi. (Bd in lviii. 1.) [And They vied, or competed, or contended for superiority, one with another, in glorying, or boasting, or the like: see 3.]

9 AHwRr AHwr OHwr HAr Hwr
9. AHwRr, (S, K, &c.,) inf. n. AiHowiraArN, (K,) It (a thing, S, Msb, and the body, TA, and the part around the eye, A, and bread, S, or some other thing, TA) was, or became, white. (S, A, Msb, K.) ― -b2- See also 1, last sentence.

10 AstHArhu AstHArh AstHArp
10. AstHArhu He desired him to speak [or to return an answer or a reply; he interrogated him]. (S, K.) And AstHAr AldRaAra He desired the house to speak [to him; he interrogated the house; as a lover does in addressing the house in which the object of his love has dwelt]. (IAar.)

HaworN OHwr Hwr Hwryp
HaworN inf. n. of HaAra. (S, A, Msb, K.) [Hence,] naEuwcu biQllRehi mina AlHawori baEoda Alkawoni, (TA on the authority of 'Ásim, and so in a copy of the S,) a trad., (TA,) meaning We have recourse to God for preservation from decrease, or defectiveness, after increase, or redundance: (S:) or mina AlHawori baEoda Alkawori, (TA, and so in copies of the S,) meaning as above: (S, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) from a bad state of affairs after a good state; from HaworN signifying the “ untwisting ” a turban: (TA:) or from returning and departing from the community [of the faithful] after having been therein; [from HaAra “ he untwisted ” his turban, and] from kaAra “ he twisted ” his turban upon his head. (Zj, TA. [See also kaworN.]) fiI maHaArapK↓ HuwrN↓, (S, K,) and HaworN, (K,) Deficiency upon deficiency, (S, K,) and return upon return, (TA,) is a prov., applied to him whose good fortune is retiring; (S, K;) or to him who is not in a good state; or to him who has been in a good state and has become in a bad state: (K:) or the saying is, fulaAnN HaworN fiI maHaArapK↓ [Such a one is suffering deficiency upon deficiency: HaworN being used in the sense of HaAYirN, like baworN in the sense of baAYirN]: so heard by IAar; and said by him to be applied in
the case of a thing not in a good state; or to him who has been in a good state and has become in a bad state. (TA.) One says also, AlbaATilu fiI HaworK What is false, or vain, is waning and retreating. (TA.) And wabuwrK UinRahu fiI HuwrK↓, (K,) or HuwrK buwrK, (K in art. Hyr,) Verily he is engaged in that which is not a skilful nor a good work or performance: (fiI gayori SanoEapK walaA UijaAdapK: so in the L: in the K, for AHAdp is put UitaAwapK [which is evidently a mistake]: TA:) or he is in a bad state, and a state of perdition: (TA in art. Hyr:) or in error. (K. [See also buwrN: and see baAYirN, in art. bwr; where it is implied that bwr is here an imitative sequent of Hwr.]) And cahaba fulaAnN fiI waAlbawaAru AlHawaAri↓ Such a one went away in a defective and bad state. (L, TA.) ― -b2- See also HawiyrN. ＝ -A2- What is beneath the [part called] kaworN of a turban. (K.) ＝ -A3- The bottom of a well or the like. (K.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) huwa baEiydu AlHawori (assumed tropical:) He is intelligent; (K;) deep in penetration. (TA.)

HuwrN OHwr Hwr Hwryp
HuwrN: see HaworN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also [app. A return of flour for the loan of a hand-mill; like EuqobapN (a subst. from OaEoqaba) signifying some broth which is returned with a borrowed cooking-pot:] a subst. from AHArt in the phrase TaHanato famaA OaHaArato XayoYFA [q. v. suprà]. (S, K.)

HawarN OHwr Hwr Hwryp
HawarN Intense whiteness of the white of the eye and intense blackness of the black thereof, (S, Msb, K,) with intense whiteness, or fairness, of the rest of the person: (K:) or intense whiteness of the white of the eye and intense blackness of the black thereof, with roundness of the black, and thinness of the eyelids, and whiteness, or fairness, of the parts around them: (K:) or blackness of the whole [of what appears] of the eye, as in the eyes of gazelles (AA, S, Msb, K) and of bulls and cows: (AA, S:) and this is not found in human beings, but is attributed to them by way of comparison: (AA, S, Msb, K:) As says, I know not what is AlHawaru in the eye. (S.) ― -b2- Also [simply] Whiteness. (A.) ＝ -A2- Red skins, with which [baskets of the kind called] silaAl are covered: (S, K:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p: (S:) pl. HuwraAnN: (K, TA: in the CK HawarAnN:) or (so in the TA, but in the K “ and ”) a hide dyed red: (K, TA:) or red skins, not [such as are termed] qaraZiyRap: pl. OaHowaArN: (AHn:) or skins tanned without qaraZ: or thin white skins, of which [receptacles of the kind called] OasofaAT are made: or prepared sheep-skins. (TA.) [In the present day, pronounced Hawor, applied to Sheep-skin leather.] ＝ -A3- A certain kind of tree: the people of Syria apply the name of HaworN to the plane-tree (dulob); but it is HawarN, with two fet-hahs: in the account of simples in the Kánoon [of Ibn-Seenà], it is said to be a certain tree of which the gum is called khrbAC: (Mgh:) [by the modern Egyptians (pronounced Hawor) applied to the white poplar:] a certain kind of wood, called AlbayoDaMCu, (K,) because of its whiteness. (TA.) ＝ -A4- AlHawaru The third star, [e,] that next the body, of the three in the tail of Ursa Major. (Mir-át ez-Zemán, &c. [In the K it is incorrectly said to be the third star of banaAtu naEoXK AlSRugoraI. See AlqaAYidu, in art. qwd.])

HaArapN HAr HArh HArp
HaArapN [A quarter of a city or town; generally consisting of several narrow streets, or lanes, of houses, and having but one general entrance, with a gate, which is closed at night; or, which is the case in some instances, having a by-street passing through it, with a gate at each end:] a place of abode of a people, whereof the houses are contiguous: (Msb:) any place of abode of a people whereof the houses are near [together]: (K in art. Hyr:) a spacious encompassed tract or place; syn. musotadaArN mino faDaMCK: (A:) pl. HaAraAtN. (A, Msb.)

HiyrapN Hyr Hyrh Hyrp
HiyrapN: see HawiyrN.

HaworaMCu HwrMC
HaworaMCu fem. of OaHowaru [q. v.]. ― -b2- Also A round, or circular, burn, made with a hot iron; (K;) [around the eye of a camel; (see 2;)] so called because its place becomes white. (TA.)

HawarowarapN Hwrwrh Hwrwrp
HawarowarapN: see HawaAriyRapN, under HawaAriIRN.

HawaArN HArp HwAr
HawaArN: see HawiyrN: ＝ -A2- and see HaworN.

HuwaArN HArp HwAr
HuwaArN, (S, K, &c.,) and sometimes with kesr [HiwaArN↓], (K,) but this latter is a bad form, (Yaakoob,) A young camel when just born: (T, K:) or until weaned; (S, K;) i. e. from the time of its birth until big and weaned; (TA;) when it is called faSiylN: (S:) fem. with p: (IAar:) pl. (of pauc., S) OaHowirapN and (of mult., S) HiyraAnN and HuwraAnN. (S, K.) [Its flesh is insipid: see a verse cited as an ex. of the word masiyxN.] ― -b2- [Hence,] Eaqorabu AlHiyraAni The scorpion of winter; because it injures the HuwaAr, (K, TA,) i. e. the young camel. (TA.)

HiwaArN HArp HwAr
HiwaArN: see HawiyrN: ＝ -A2- and see also HuwaArN.

HawiyrN Hwyr
HawiyrN (S, K,) and HawiyrapN↓, (S, and so in some copies of the K,) or HuwayorapN↓, (so in other copies of the K and in the TA,) and HawaArN↓ (S, K) and HiwaArN↓ (K) and maHuwrapN↓ (S, K, TA, in the CK maHowurapN) and maHowarapN↓ and muHaAwarapN↓ [originally an inf. n. of 3] and HiyrapN↓ (K) and HaworN↓, (TA,) An answer; a reply. (S, K.) You say, maA rajaEa UilaIRa HawiyrFA, &c., He did not return to me an answer, or a reply. (S.) [See a verse of Tarafeh cited voce mujomidN.]

HawiyrapN Hwyrh Hwyrp
HawiyrapN, or HuwayorapN: see what next precedes.

HawaAriIRN HArp HwAr HwArI HwAry HwAryy
HawaAriIRN One who whitens clothes, or garments, by washing and beating them. (S, M, Msb, K.) Hence its pl. HawaAriyRuwna is applied to The companions [i. e. apostles and disciples] of Jesus, because their trade was to do this. (S, M, Msb.) [Or it is so applied from its bearing some one or another of the following significations.] ― -b2- One who is freed and cleared from every vice, fault, or defect: [or] one who has been tried, or proved, time after time, and found to be free from vices, faults, or defects; from HaAra “ he returned. ” (Zj, TA.) ― -b3- A thing that is pure, or unsullied: anything of a pure, or an unsullied, colour: and hence, ― -b4- One who advises, or counsels, or acts, sincerely, honestly, or faithfully: (Sh:) or a friend; or true, or sincere, friend: (TA:) or an assistant: (S, Msb, K:) or a strenuous assistant: (TA:) or an assistant of prophets: (K:) or a particular and select friend and assistant of a prophet: and hence the pl. is applied to the companions of Mohammad also. (Zj.) ― -b5- A relation. (K.) ― -b6- And HawaAriyRapN A white, or fair, woman; (A;) as also HawarowarapN↓; (T, K;) and so HaworaMCu↓, without implying HawarN of the eye: (TA:) pl. of the first HawaAriyRaAtN: (A:) or this pl. signifies women of the cities or towns; (K;) so called by the Arabs of the desert because of their whiteness, or fairness, and cleanness: (TA:) or women clear in complexion and skin; because of their whiteness, or fairness: (TA:) or women inhabitants of regions, districts, or tracts, of cities, towns, or villages, and of cultivated land: (Ksh and Bd in iii. 45:) or [simply] women; because of their whiteness, or fairness. (S.)

HuwRaAraI HArp HwAr HwArI HwAry HwAryy
HuwRaAraI White, applied to flour: (A, * K:) such is the best and purest of flour: (K, TA:) and in like manner applied to bread: (A:) or whitened, applied to flour; (S;) and, in this latter sense, to any food. (S, K.) [See also samiydN: and see muHawRarN.]

rajulN HaAYirN baAYirN c
rajulN HaAYirN baAYirN A man in a defective and bad state: (S, TA:) or perishing, or dying. (S.) [See the same phrase in art. Hyr: see also HaworN: and see baAYirN, in art. bwr; where it is said that bAYr is here an imitative sequent of HAYr.] ＝ -A2- See also maHaArapN.

OaHowaru c
OaHowaru, (K,) applied to a man, (TA,) Having eyes characterized by the quality termed HawarN as explained above: (K:) and so HaworaMCu, [the fem.,] applied to a woman: (S, Msb, K: *) pl. HuwrN. (S, K.) And Huwru AlEiyni, applied to women, Having eyes like those of gazelles and of cows. (AA, S.) Az says that a woman is not termed HaworaMC unless Combining Hawar of the eyes with whiteness, or fairness, of complexion. (TA.) See also HawaAriyRapN, under HawaAriIRN. ― -b2- TarofN OaHowaru An eye of pure white and black. (A.) ― -b3- AlOaHowaru A certain star: (S, K:) or (K) Jupiter. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- Also (tropical:) Intellect: (ISk, S, K:) or pure, or clear, intellect; like an eye so termed, of pure white and black. (A.) So in the saying, maA yaEiyXu buOaHowara (tropical:) [He does not live by intellect: or by pure, or clear, intellect]. (ISk, S, A.)

OaHowariIRN c
OaHowariIRN A man (TA) white, or fair, (S, K,) of the people of the towns or villages. (TA.) [See also HawaAriIRN; of which the fem. is applied in like manner to a woman.]

maHaArN mHAr
maHaArN: see maHaArapN, in two places.

miHowarN mHwr
miHowarN The pin of wood, or, as is sometimes the case, of iron, on which the sheave of a pulley turns; (S;) the iron [pin] that unites the bent piece of iron which is on each side of the sheave of a pulley, and in which it [the mHwr] is inserted, and the sheave itself: and a piece of wood which unites (tajomaEu) the sheave of a large pulley
[app. with what is on each side of the latter; for it seems to mean here, also, the pivot]: (K:) some say that it is so called because it turns round, returning to the point from which it departed: others, that it is so called because, by its revolving, it is polished so that it becomes white: (Zj:) pl. maHaAwiru. (A.) One says, qaliqato maHaAwiruhu, meaning (tropical:) His circumstances, (A,) or affair, or case, (K,) became unsettled: (A, K:) from the state of the pin of the sheave of a pulley when it becomes smooth, and the hole becomes large, so that it wabbles. (A.) ― -b2- Also A thing (K) of iron (TA) upon which turns the tongue of a buckle at the end of a waist-belt. (K.) ― -b3- And An iron instrument for cauterizing [app. of a circular form: see 2]. (K.) ― -b4- And The wooden implement (S, K) of the baker, or maker of bread, (S,) with which he expands the dough, (K,) and prepares it, and makes it round, to put it into the hot ashes in which it is baked: (TA:) so called because of its turning round upon the dough, as being likened to the mHwr of the sheave of a pulley, and because of its roundness. (T.)

maHaArapN mHAr mHArh mHArp
maHaArapN: see HaworN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also A place that returns [like a circle]: or in which a return is made [to the point of commencement]. (K.) ― -b2- A mother-of-pearl shell; an oyster-shell: (S, IAth, Msb, K:) or the like thereof, of bone: (S, K:) pl. maHaAwiru and [coll. gen. n.] maHaArN↓. (L.) ― -b3- And hence, A thing in which water is collected; as also HaAYirN↓. (IAth.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] An oyster [itself]; expl. by daAbRapN fiI AlSRadafayoni. (L in art. mHr.) ― -b5- The cavity of the ear; (K;) i. e. the external, deep, and wide, cavity, around the ear-hole; or the Sadafap [or concha] of the ear. (TA.) ― -b6- The part of the shoulder-blade called its marojiE [q. v.]: (S, K:) or the small round hollow that is in that part of the shoulder-blade in which the head of the humerus turns. (TA.) ― -b7- The small round cavity of the hip: and the dual signifies the two round heads [?] of the hips, in which the heads of the thighs turn. (TA.) ― -b8- The palate; syn. HanakN: and without p, i. e. maHaArN↓, the same, of a man: and, this latter, the place, in a beast, where the farrier performs the operation termed taHoniykN: (TA:) or the former signifies the upper part of the mouth of a horse, internally: (IAar, TA:) or the inner part of the palate: (Abu-l-' Omeythil, TA:) or, [which seems to be the same,] the portion of the upper part of the mouth which is behind the firaAXap [or firaAX]: and the passage of the breath to the innermost parts of the nose: (TA:) or maHaArapu AlHanaki signifies the part [of the palate] which is a little above the place where the farrier performs the operation termed tHnyk. (S.) ― -b9- The part between the frog and the extremity of the fore part of a solid hoof. (Abu-l-' Omeythil, K.) What is beneath the UiTaAr [q. v., app. here meaning the ATAr of the hoof of a horse or the like]. (TA.) And The manosim [i. e. toe, or nail, &c.,] of a camel. (TA.) ＝ -A3- A thing resembling [the kind of vehicle called] a hawodaj; (K;) pronounced by the vulgar [maHaArRap,] with teshdeed: pl. maHaAroAtN (TA) [and maHaAYiru, which is often applied in the present day to the dorsers, or panniers, or oblong chests, which are borne, one on either side, by a camel, and, with a small tent over them, compose a hwdj]: the [ornamented hwdj called the] maHomil [vulgarly pronounced maHomal] of the pilgrims [which is borne by a camel, but without a rider, and is regarded as the royal banner of the caravan; such as is described and figured in my work on the Modern Egyptians]. (Msb.) ＝ -A4- I. q. xaTRN [A line, &c.]. (K.) ― -b2- And i. q. naAHiyapN [A side, region, quarter, tract, &c.]. (K.)

maHuwrapN mHcwr mHcwrh mHcwrp
maHuwrapN and maHowarapN: see HawiyrN.

muHowarRu Alqidori mHwr Alqdr
muHowarRu Alqidori The whiteness of the froth, or of the scum, of the cooking-pot. (S.) ― -b2- jafonapN muHowarRapN, [in the copies of the K, erroneously, muHawRarapN,] A bowl whitened by [containing] camel's hump, (S, L, K,) or its fat. (A.)

muHawRarN mHwr
muHawRarN Dough of which the surface has been moistened with water, so that it is shining. (TA.) [See also 2.] ― -b2- OaEoyunN muHawRaraAtN, in a verse of El- 'Ajjáj, Eyes of a clear white [in the white parts] and intensely black in the black parts. (S.) ＝ -A2- A boot lined with skin of the kind called HawarN. (K.)

muHawRirN mHwr
muHawRirN A possessor of [flour, or bread, such as is termed] HuwRaAraI. (TA.)

muHaAwarapN mHAwr mHAwrh mHAwrp mHwr
muHaAwarapN: see HawiyrN.

1 HaAzahu HAz HAzh HAzp
1. HaAzahu, (S, A, Msb,) aor. yaHuwzuhu, (Msb,) inf. n. HawozN and HiyaAzapN; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also HaAzahu, [aor. yaHiyzuhu,] inf. n. HayozN; (Msb;) He drew, collected, or gathered, it together; (S, A, Msb, K;) and so AHtAzhu↓, (TA,) inf. n. AiHotiyaAzN; (K;) and HwRzhu↓, inf. n. taHowiyzN: (TA:) he drew, collected, or gathered, it together (namely, property or wealth &c., TA) to himself; (S, A, Msb;) as also AHtAzhu↓, (S,) and linafosihi AHtAzhu↓, (A, TA,) and HaAzahu Uilayohi, and Alyh AHtAzhu↓. (TA.) You say, Ealayoka biHiyaAzapi AlmaAli Take thou to the collecting of wealth. (A, TA.) ― -b2- HaAzahu, aor. yaHuwzuhu, (TA,) inf. n. HawozN, (K, TA,) He had, held, or possessed, it; had it, or held it, in his possession; had, took, got, obtained, or acquired, possession, or occupation, of it; (AA, K, * TA; [Almaliku, given as an explanation of the inf. n. in the CK, is a mistake for Almiloku;]) he took, or received, it; he had it, or took it, to, or for, himself. (AA, TA.) [See HawozapN, below. Hence, It comprehended, comprised, or embraced, it.] ― -b3- HaAza AlOaroDa, inf. n. HawozN, He took for himself the land, and marked out its boundaries, and had an exclusive right to it. (TA: but only the inf. n. is there mentioned.) ― -b4- HaAza, aor. yaHuwzu, also signifies [He or] it overcame, conquered, or mastered, [a thing,] as in an instance in art. Hz, voce HazRaAzN: (Sh, K:) [as also HaAca.] ― -b5- Also, (A, TA,) inf. n. HawozN, (K,) (tropical:) He compressed a woman: (A, * K, * TA:) [as though he mastered her.] ― -b6- HaAza AlHimaAru Outunahu The he-ass gained the mastery over his she-asses, and collected them together; as also HaAcahaA. (L in art. Hwc.) ― -b7- HaAza AlUibila, aor. yaHuwzuhaA, (S, A, Msb,) inf. n. HawozN, (S, K,) He drove the camels gently; (S, Msb, K;) as also HaAzahaA, aor. yaHiyzuhaA, (S, Msb,) inf. n. HayozN; (S, TA;) and HwRzhA↓. (TA.) Also He drove the camels vehemently; (K;) and so HAzhA, aor. yaHiyzuhaA, (TA in art. Hyz,) inf. n. HayozN: (K in art. Hyz:) thus bearing two contr. significations: (K:) [as also HaAcahaA:] you say [also] OaHizohaA↓, [unless this be a mistranscription for HuzohaA,] meaning, Drive thou them vehemently. (TA.) Also He drove the camels to water; (A;) and so HwRzhA↓; (S, A;) [and HaAcahaA:] or HwRzhA↓, (As, S, K,) inf. n. taHowiyzN, (K,) signifies he drove them during the first night to water, (As, S, K,) it being distant from the pasture: (As, S:) because in that night they are driven gently. (TA.) [See also HawozN, below.] ― -b8- HaAza AlXRaIoCa He removed the thing from its place; put it away; placed it at a distance. (Sh, TA.

2 HwRzhu Hwz Hwzh Hwzp
2. HwRzhu: see 1, first sentence: ― -b2- and HwRz: AlUibila: see 1, in three places.

4 OaHizi AlUibila c
4. OaHizi AlUibila: see 1.

5 tHwRz HAz tHwz
5. tHwRz He, or it, writhed, or twisted, about, (K, TA,) and turned over and over; (TA;) as also tHyRz↓: (K:) or was restless, or unquiet, not remaining still, upon the ground. (Lth, TA.) You say, tHwRzt AlHayRapu, and tHyzRt↓, The serpent writhed, or twisted, about. (Both in the S; and the latter in the K in art. Hyz.) And maA laka tataHawRazu taHawRuza AlHayRapi, and taHayRuza AlHayRapi tataHayRazu↓, Wherefore dost thou writhe about like the writhing about of the serpent? the latter verb, accord. to Sb, is of the measure tafayoEala, from Huzotu AlXRaIoCa. (S.) ― -b2- He removed, withdrew, or retired to a distance, (A'Obeyd, S, K,) and drew back, (S,) Eanohu [or minohu] from him or it; (TA;) as also tHyRz↓; (A'Obeyd, S;) and AnHAz↓. (A.) You say, daxala Ealayohi famaA taHawRaza lahu Eano firaAXihi He went in to him and he did not move for him from his bed, or mattress. (TK.) And El-Katámee says, (S, TA,) describing an old woman of whom he sought hospitality, and who eluded him, (TA,)
minRiI xaXoyapF Oano OaDiyfahaA taHayRazu↓
AlOafoEaI maxaAfapa DaAribi kamaA QnoHaAzati↓
She (this old woman) retires and draws back from me for fear of my alighting at her abode as a guest [like as the viper turns away in fear of a beater]: or, as some relate the verse, taHawRazu. (S.) ― -b3- He tarried, or loitered: he was slow in rising; as also tHwRs: he desired to rise, and it was tedious to him to do so; as also tHyRz↓. (TA.) AA says, taHawRaza taHawRuza AlHayRapi, [as though meaning, He was slow in rising like as the rising of the serpent is slow: for he adds,] and it is slow in rising when it desires to rise. (S.)

6 tHAwz AlfariyqaAni tHAwz AlfryqAn
6. tHAwz AlfariyqaAni The two parties, or divisions,
turned away, each from the other, (S, K,) in war or battle. (S.)

7 UinoHawaza
7: AnHAz Alqawomu The company of men left their appointed station, (S, K, TA,) and place of fighting, (TA,) and turned away to another place. (S, * K, * TA.) You say also, AnHAz Eanohu He turned away from him: (S, K:) and AnHAz Uilayohi he turned to, or towards, him; and he joined himself to him. (Har pp. 122 and 326.) You say of friends, AnHAzw Eani AlEaduwRi, and HaASuwA; [They turned away from the enemy;] and of enemies, AinohazamuwA, and walRawo mudobiriyna. (S, TA.) Or AnHAz signifies He separated himself from others that he might be with those who were fighting. (Aboo-Is-hák, TA.) And AnHAz AlrRaHulu UilaI Alqawomi signifies the same as Uilayohimo tHyRz↓ [The man turned, removed, withdrew, or retired, or he joined himself, to the company of men]. (Msb.) See 5, in two places. ― -b2- AnHAz EalaI AlXRaIoCi [for En, in the TA, I have substituted ElI, as the former is apparently a mistranscription] He drew himself together, and fell to the thing; expl. by DamRa baEoDahu EalaI baEoDK waOakabRa Ealayohi. (TA.)

8 AHtAzhu AHtAzh AHtAzp OHtAzh QHtAz QHtAzh
8. AHtAzhu: see HaAzahu, in four places, first sentence.

Q. Q. 2 taHayRaza HAz tHyz
Q. Q. 2. taHayRaza, [originally taHayowza,] of the measure tafayoEala, (Sb, S, TA,) [from HayRizN, originally HayowizN,] He turned aside to a HayRiz [or place, &c.]. (Mgh.) You say also tHyRz AlmaAlu [The property, or the camels or the like,] became drawn, collected, or gathered, together; or drew, collected, or gathered, themselves together; to a HayRiz. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 5, throughout; and see 7.

HawozN Hwz
HawozN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. ― -b2- fiI Hawozihi: see HawozapN. ＝ -A2- A place of which a man takes possession, (TA,) and around which a dam (musanRaApN) is made: (K, TA:) pl. OaHowaAzN. (TA.) ― -b2- Hawozu AldRaAri: see HayRizN. ＝ -A3- layolapu AlHawozi The first night during which camels repair towards the water (As, S, K) when it is distant from the pasture: (As, S:) because they are driven gently that night: but when their faces are turned towards the water and they are left to pasture that night, the night is called layolapu AlTRalaqi. (TA.) One says to a man, when he holds back respecting an affair, daEoniI mino Hawozika waTalaqika (assumed tropical:) [Let me alone and cease from this and that discursion of thine]. (TA.) And one says also, TawRala EalayonaA fulaAnN biQloHawozi waQlTRalaqi qabola Alqarabi (assumed tropical:) [Such a one was prolix, or tedious, to us with this and that discursion before coming to the point]. (TA.) ― -b2- HawozN is also used as an epithet; though properly an inf. n.: you say, sawoqN HawozN [A gentle driving: or a vehement driving]. (TA.)

HawozapN Hwz Hwzh Hwzp
HawozapN i. q. HayRizN, as pointed out in two places below. (S, Msb, &c.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A thing that is in one's possession or occupation; a thing that is one's property: so in the saying of a certain woman, waOaHomiI Hawozapa AlgaAYibi (assumed tropical:) And I guard from encroachment the property of the absent: meaning her faroj, which was the property of her husband by the marriage-contract: whence it appears that, if this saying be the only ground upon which Az has asserted that one of the significations of HawozapN is the faroj of a woman, [as is also said in the K,] his assertion requires consideration; for a woman's frj is her own when she has no husband; and when she is married, it is her husband's property. (L, TA.) You say also, SaArafiI Hawozatihi, and fiI Hawozihi↓, [and fI HayRizihi↓,] It became in his possession, or occupation. (L, TA.) And fulaAnN maAniEN Hawozatahu (assumed tropical:) Such a one defends, or guards, from encroachment, or invasion, or attack, what is in his HayRiz [or place; meaning, in his possession or occupation]. (TA.) In like manner, a poet says,
HamaI HawozaAtihi faturikona qaforFA
He guarded from encroachment his tracts of pasture-land [so that they were left deserted]. (Fr, TA.) And it is said in a trad., faHamaI HawozapF AlUisolaAmi (tropical:) And he defended, or protected, or guarded, from encroachment, or invasion, or attack, the limits, [meaning, what the limits comprised, i. e., the territory,] and the tracts, or regions, of El-Islám [meaning, of the Muslims]. (TA.) Hawozapu Almuloki signifies [in like manner] bayoDatuhu [i. e. (assumed tropical:) The seat of regal power: or the heart, or principal part, of the kingdom]. (S, K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Nature; or natural disposition, temper, or other quality or property; (K, TA;) whether good or evil. (TA.)

HayRizN Hyz
HayRizN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) of the measure fayoEilN, (Mgh, Msb,) from AlHawozu, (S, * Mgh,) as signifying “ the drawing, collecting, or gathering, together, ” (Mgh,) originally HayowizN, (TA,) and also contracted into HayozN, (S, Msb, TA,) like hayRinN and hayonN, and layRinN and layonN; (S, TA;) [The continent, or container, or receptacle, of anything; like bayoDapN; as also HawozapN↓, q. v.:] any place in which a thing is: (Mgh:) in scholastic theology, the imaginary portion of space occupied by a thing having extent, as a body; or by a thing not having extent, as an indivisible atom: in philosophy, the inner surface of a container, which is contiguous [in every part] to the outer surface of the thing contained: and [hence,] AlHayRizu AlTabiyEiIRu [the proper natural place of a thing;] that in which the nature of a thing requires it to be. (KT.) ― -b2- A quarter, tract, region, or place, considered relatively, or as part of a whole; or a part, or portion, of a place; syn. naAHiyapN; (S, Mgh, Msb;) as also HawozapN↓: (S, Msb, K:) so the authors on practical law mean by HayRizN; such, for instance, as a room, or an apartment, of a house: (Mgh:) pl. OaHoyaAzN, (S, Msb, TA,) which is extr., (TA,) being from the contracted form [HayozN]: (Msb:) by rule it should be OaHowaAzN, (Az, Msb, TA,) like OamowaAtN, pl. of mayRitN [and mayotN]: (Az, TA:) or by rule [if from the uncontracted form HayRizN] it should be HayaAYizu, with hemz, accord. to Sb; or HayaAwizu, with w, accord. to Abu-l-Hasan. (TA.) HayRizu AldRaAri, (S, Msb, TA,) as also AldRAri Hawozu↓, (TA,) signifies What is annexed to the house, (S, TA,) or appertains thereto, (Msb,) of the maraAfiq (S, Msb, TA) and manaAfiE (TA) and nawaAHK; (Msb;) [i. e., of the conveniences thereof, such as the privy and the kitchen and the like, and other parts or apartments;] such are termed collectively OaHoyaAzu AldRaAri; (Msb;) and each part or apartment (naAHiyap), by itself, is termed HayRizN. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence the saying,] OanaA fiI HayRizihi wakanafihi (tropical:) [I am in his quarter and protection]. (A, TA.) ― -b4- [And hence also the saying,] fiI HayRizi AltRawaAtiru (tropical:) In the manner, and place, of [that kind of transmission which is termed] AltwAtr [which is “ transmission by such a number of persons as cannot be supposed to have agreed to a falsehood: ” as explained in the Mz, 3rd nwE]. (Mgh.) ― -b5- And SaAra fiI HayRizihi: see HawozapN. ― -b6- [And EalaI HayRizihi By himself or itself.]

AlUivomu HawRaAzu Alquluwbi AlAvm HwAz Alqlwb
AlUivomu HawRaAzu Alquluwbi: see HazRaAzu, in art. Hz.

(Aboo-Is-hák, TA.) The original form of mutaHayRizN is mutaHayowizN. (TA.)

HawoXN and HiyaAXN, (TA,) He came around the chase, or game, to turn it towards the snare; (S, A, K;) as also OaHaAXahu↓, and OaHowaXahu↓, (S, K,) inf. n. UiHaAXapN and UiHowaAXN. (TA.) ― -b2- HuXotu Ealayohi AlSRayoda I aided him to hunt, or catch, the chase, or game; as also Elyh OaHaXotuhu↓, and OaHowaXotuhu↓ Elyh, and OaHowaXotuhu UiyRaAhu, on the authority of Th: (TA:) and HaAXa Ealayohi AlSRayoda He scared the chase, or game, towards him, and drove and collected it to him; as also AHAXhu↓. (TA.) ― -b3- HaAXa AlcRiYobu Alganama The wolf drove along the sheep or goats. (TA.) ― -b4- HaAXa AlUibila He collected together, and drove, the camels. (S, K.) ― -b5- HaAXahu, inf. n. HawoXN, also signifies [simply] He collected it; drew it together. (TA.) [See also 2.] ― -b6- huwa yaHuwXu AlTRaEaAma, (A,) inf. n. HawoXN, (K,) He eats from the sides of the food so as to consume it: (A, K:) from IF. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [See also 7.]

(Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) HaAwaXahu, (A,) inf. n. muHaAwaXapN, (TA,) He circumvented him: or he endeavoured to induce him to turn, or incline, or decline; or endeavoured to turn him by deceit, or guile: syn. daAwarahu: (A,
TA: *) in war, and in litigation or contention [&c.]. (TA.) You say, Zalitu OuHaAwiXuhu waOuHaAwituhu HatRaI faEala [I continued during the day to circumvent him, or to endeavour to induce him to turn, &c., and to delude him, or act towards him with artifice, like a fish in the water, until he did what I desired: see also what next follows]. (A.) ― -b3- [And hence,] HaAwaXotuhu Ealayohi I excited, incited, urged, or instigated, him to do it. (Ibn-'Abbád, A, * Sgh, K.) [It is indicated in the A that in the ex. immediately preceding this, OuHaAwiXuhu may also be rendered agreeably with this explanation.]

(TA.) ― -b2- tHwRXt mino zawojihaA She became forlorn of her husband; syn. taOayRamato. (Sgh, K.) ― -b3- tHwRX He felt, or had a sense of, or was moved with, shame, or shyness, or bashfulness. HyX; but it belongs to the present art. (IAth.) You say, zajarahu famaA QnoHaAXa lizajorihi He chid him (meaning a wolf or other animal) but he did not take fright and flee, &c., at his chiding. AHtwX Alqawomu AlSRayoda, (S, Msb, K,) and, more commonly, biAlSRayodi, (Msb,) The people, or company of men, encompassed, or surrounded, the chase, or game: (Msb:) or scared it, one, or one party, to another: (S, K:) the w remaining here unchanged as it does in AijotawaruwA. (S.) And AHtwXw fulaAnFA (A, TA) They encompassed, or surrounded, such a one: (A:) or they made such a one to be in the midst of them; (TA;) as also AHtwXwA Ealayohi, (S, K,) [and AHtwXwA HawaAlayohi, (M and O in art. Hwl,)] and tHAwXwhu↓, (K,) or tHAwXwhu bayonahumo. HuwXiIRN Wild; untamed; undomesticated; uncivilized; unfamiliar; syn. waHoXiIRN. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- Applied to a man, (tropical:) Wild; uncivilized; unfamiliar; (A;) unsociable; that does not mix with others. (S, A.) ― -b3- Applied to a camel, or other [animal], Wild: (K:) [or] the epithet thus applied is tropical; (A, TA;) and what are thus called, (K,) or AlUibilu AlHuwXiyRapu [the camels termed HwXyRp], (S, A, Msb,) are so named from AlHuwXu↓, the appellation of certain stallions of the camels of the jinn, or genii, which covered some of the she-camels of Arabs, (IKt, S, A, Msb, K,) as they assert, (S, K,) namely, of the she-camels of Mahrah, (K,) meaning the Benoo-Mahrah-Ibn-Heydán, (TA,) and the offspring were the camels called AlnRajaAYibu AlmahoriyRapu, (Msb, TA,) which scarcely ever become tired; and the like of this is said by AHeyth: (TA:) it is also said that AlHuwXu↓, (S, K,) from which the epithet above mentioned, thus applied, is a rel. n., (TA,) is the country of the jinn, (S, K,) beyond the sands of Yebreen, which no man inhabits: (S:) or an appellation of certain sons of the jinn, whose country is called bilaAdu AlHuwXi by Ru-beh: (TA:) or it is like AlwaHoX: (Msb:) or UibilN HuwXiyRapN means camels of the jinn: or wild camels; (TA;) as also HuwXN↓: (S:) or camels not completely broken or trained, because of their unyielding spirit. (TA.) ― -b4- Hence, (A,) rajulN HuwXiIRN AlfuWaAdi, (A,) or AlfuWaAdi HuwXu↓, (S, K,) (tropical:) A man acute, or sharp, in intellect. (Mz, 13th nwE.) ― -b6- And layolN HuwXiIRN (tropical:) A night that is dark (A, K) and terrible. (A, TA.)

1. HaASahu, (A, TA,) aor. yaHuwSu, (A, K,) inf. n. HawoSN (S, A, Mgh, K) and HiyaASapN, (A, TA,) He sewed it, or sewed it up or together; (S, * A, Mgh, * K, TA;) namely, a garment, or piece of cloth: (A, TA:) or he sewed it with stitches far apart: (IB, TA:) or he sewed it without a patch; and only said of a skin, or of skin, and of a camel's foot. (TA.) Hence the prov., UinRa dawaMCa AlXRaqRi Oano taHuwSahu [Verily the remedy for the rent is that thou sew it up]. (A, K.) [And hence the saying,] laOaToEananRa fiI HawoSihimo (S, A) (tropical:) I will assuredly mar what they have repaired: (A:) or I will assuredly make a hole in what they have sewed up, and I will assuredly mar what they have repaired. (S, IB.) Or laOaToEananRa fiI HawoSika (tropical:) I will assuredly circumvent thee, (laOakiydanRaka [so in copies of the K, and in the TA, but in the CK, erroneously, laAkobidanRaka,]) and I will assuredly labour for thy destruction. (AZ, K.) And it is said in a prov., TaEana fiI HawoSi OamorK layosa minohu fiI XaIoCK, (K,) and OamorK HuwSi↓, and OamorK HuwSaI↓, (Yoo, K,) (tropical:) He laboured at that which he could not do well, and tasked himself to do that with which he had no concern. (ISh, K.) Or TaEanota fiI HawoSi OamorK lasota minohu fiI XaIoCK (tropical:) Thou hast spoken of a thing with which thou hast no concern. (A.) You say also, qabola Oano Oadoxula HawoSi AlnRaAsi OaTomaEu fiI Darobihimo (tropical:) Before I penetrate into the case of the people, and test them, I am ambitious of smiting them. (A.) And maA TaEanota fiI HawoSihi (tropical:) Thou hast not attained the object of thy desire [with respect to him or it: or perhaps the right reading is HawoSika, in which case the addition which I have made should be omitted]. (IB, as quoted in the L and TA.) ― -b2- HuSotu Eayona AlbaAziI, (S,) or Eayona AlSRaqori, (A,) aor. as above, and inf. n. of both the forms mentioned above, (S,) [He seeled the falcon, or hawk; closed its eyes by running a thread through their lids.] ― -b3- HaASa siqaMCahu He closed a rent in his skin for water or milk by inserting into it two pieces of stick or wood; not having a siraAd with which to sew it. (TA.) ― -b4- HawoSN also signifies The making a coarctation between two things; (S, K;) and so HiyaASapN. (K.) You say HaASa bayonahumaA [He contracted the space between them; meaning two things]. (TK.) ＝ -A2- HawiSato Eayonuhu, (A, Msb,) aor. taHowaSu, inf. n. HawaSN, (Msb,) His eye was, or became, narrow, or contracted, in its outer angle. (A, Msb.) [But see HawaSN below.] And HawiSa, (S, K,) aor. HawaSN, (TA,) said of a man, (S,) he had, in his eye, or eyes, what is termed HawaSN [as explained below]. (S, K.) [See also xawiSato Eayonuhu.]

(TA.) You say, laA zilota fiI HiyaATapi QllRehi Mayest thou not cease to be in the protection of God. (TA.) And maEa fulaAnK HiyTapN laka There is with such a one compassion and affection for thee: you should not say Ealayoka. (S.) And OaHuwTu EiroDiI [I guard, or defend, or take care of, my honour, or reputation]. (TA.) And OaxaAhu huwa yataHawRaTu↓ He takes care of, or pays frequent attention to, his brother; and undertakes, or superintends, or manages, his affairs. (TA.) And HaATahumo qaSaMCahumo and biqaSaAYihimo He fought in their defence. (TA.) [But this is generally meant ironically.] When an affliction befalls thee, and thy brother does not guard thee, or defend thee, and does not aid thee, one says [to thee], HaATaka AlfaDaMCa [so in the TA, app. a mistranscription for AlqaSaMCa or AlqaSaA, with which, however, it is nearly syn.,] which is used ironically; i. e. He guarded thee, or defended thee, in
a distant quarter; meaning, (tropical:) he did not guard thee, or defend thee; for he who guards, or defends, his brother, draws near to him, and supports him, or aids him. (A, TA.) [See also 1 in art. Hbw.] You say also, HaATuwnaA AlqaSaMCa, (K,) or AlqaSaA, (TK,) [both are said to be correct in the TA in art. qSw, on the authority of Ibn-Wellád,] in some of the copies of the K with f and D, and in some with f and D, the latter unpointed, and so in [a copy of] the A, (TA,) (tropical:) They retired to a distance from us, they being around us, and we not being distant from them, had they desired to come to us. (K, TA.) And HuToniI AlqaSaA (tropical:) Retire thou to a distance from me; (Ibn-Wellád, and K in art. qSw;) as also AlqaSaMCa. (Ibn-Wellád, and TA in that art.) And laOaHuwTanRaka AlqaSaA walaOagozuwanRaka biAlEaSaA, in each case with the short & A, meaning I will assuredly leave thee, and not go near thee; [and I will assuredly go against thee to fight thee with the staff.] (Ks, TA in art. qSw.) HuTo HuTo means Take thou care of the tie of kindred, and preserve it. (IAar, K. *) It also signifies Deck thou the boys (AlSRiboyap [in the CK AlSRabiyRap the girl]) with the HawoT [for preservation from the evil eye]. (IAar, K.) And HuwTuwA gulaAmakumo Deck ye your boy with the HawoT. (AA.) ― -b3- HaATa AlHimaAru EaAnatahu, (S, * Msb, K,) nor, as above, (S, Msb,) inf. n. HawoTN, (Msb,) The [wild] he-ass collected, or drew together, (S, * Msb, K, *) and guarded, or took care of, (TA,) his EaAnap [app. meaning his herd of wild asses: or the phrase may mean the he-ass drew towards himself, or compressed, and guarded, his she-ass: Freytag here renders EAnp by “ pubem; ” and Golius, by “ veretrum ”]. (S, Msb, K.)

See also 4.] ― -b3- HwRT HaAYiTFA, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He made a HAYT [meaning either a walled garden or a wall; app. a wall of enclosure]; (K, TA;) as also AHAThu↓. 3. HAwT fulaAnFA (tropical:) He endeavoured to induce such a one to turn, or incline; or endeavoured to turn him by deceit, or guile; (daAwarahu;) in a matter that he desired of him, and which he refused him: (K:) as though each of them were guarding, or taking care of, (yaHuwTu,) the other. (K: and so in the A, in illustration of what next follows.) HaAwiTohu faUinRahu yaliynu laka (tropical:) Endeavour thou to induce him to turn, or incline; or endeavour thou to turn him by deceit, or guile; [for he will relent to thee;] syn. daAwirohu. (A, TA.)

4 AHAT bihi c and bihi
4. AHAT bihi bihi HaATa↓ signify the same [i. e. It, or he, surrounded, encompassed, environed, enclosed, or hemmed in, it, or him]. (TA.) You say, AHAT Alqawomu biAlbaladi, inf. n. UiHaATapN; and HaATuwA↓ bihi; The people surrounded, encompassed, environed, encircled, or beset, the sides of the town. (Msb.) And AHATt Alxayolu bifulaAnK, (S, TA,) and bh HaATato↓, (TA,) and bh AHtATt↓, (S,) The horses, or horsemen, surrounded, encompassed, environed, encircled, or beset, such a one. (S, TA.) [And AHATwA bihi mino jaAnibayohi, meaning They surrounded him on all his sides; lit. on his two sides: see janobN.] ― -b2- It is said in the Kur [xvii. 62], UinRa rabRaka OaHaATa biAlnRaAsi (assumed tropical:) Verily thy Lord hath men in his grasp, or power: (Bd, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) hath destroyed them; meaning Kureysh. (Bd.) You say also, OuHiyTa bifulaAnK, meaning (assumed tropical:) Such a one was destroyed: or (assumed tropical:) his destruction drew near. (TA.) And hence the saying in the Kur [xviii. 40], waOuHiyTa bivamarihi (assumed tropical:) And its fruit became smitten by that which destroyed and spoiled it: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) his possessions became destroyed: from OaHaATa bihi AlEaduwRu [the enemy surrounded him]. (Bd.) [Hence also, in the same, ii. 75,] waOaHaATato bihi xaTiyoYatuhu (assumed tropical:) And over whom his sin hath gained the mastery, affecting all the circumstances of his case, so that he hath become as though he were entirely encompassed thereby: (Bd:) or (assumed tropical:) who hath died in the belief of a plurality of Gods. (TA.) You also say, AHAT bihi AlOamoru (assumed tropical:) The thing beset him on every side, so that he had no place of escape from it. (TA.) And AHAT Ealayohi (assumed tropical:) He took it entirely to himself, debarring others from it: [see also 2.] (TA in art Xrb.) ― -b3- AHAT bihi, (K,) or AHAT bihi EilomFA, (S, Msb, TA,) and AHAT bihi Eilomuhu, (S, TA,) (tropical:) [He comprehended it, or knew it altogether, in all its modes or circumstances;] he knew it extrinsically and intrinsically; (Msb;) or he attained the utmost particular thereof, and had a comprehensive and complete knowledge thereof: or he attained everything [relating to it], and the utmost knowledge thereof. (K, accord. to different copies. [In the CK, AaHoSeI Eilomuhu is put, erroneously, for AHSI Eilomahu.]) It is said in the Kur [xxvii. 22], OaHaTotu bimaA lamo tuHiTo bihi (tropical:) I have known in all its circumstances, or modes, that which thou hast not so known. (TA.) And you say also, Ealimahu Eiloma UiHaATapK (tropical:) He knew it in all its circumstances, or modes; nothing of them escaping him. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 2.

Hyk.] ― -b2- Hence, HAk AlXRiEora, aor. as above, inf. n. HawokN, (tropical:) He wove poetry. (Mbr, TA.) ― -b3- And AlmaTaru yaHuwku AlOaroDa, inf. n. HawokN, (tropical:) [The rain frets the surface of the ground; makes rippling lines upon it.] (TA.) ― -b4- HAk AlXRaIoCu fiI SadoriI, (K,) inf. n. HawokN, or, accord. to Az, the aor. of the verb in this case is yaHiyku, (TA,) [and the inf. n. is HayokN, (see art. Hyk,)] (assumed tropical:) The thing became fixed in my mind. (K.) [See also HakRa.]

He drew his legs against his belly with the garment, or piece of cloth, confining them therewith, together with his back, and binding it, or making it tight, upon them, so as to preserve him from falling, [when he sat,] like a wall. (IAth, TA in art. Hbw.) [See 1 in art. Hbk.]
