1 HaAla HAl
1. HaAla, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) aor. yaHuwlu, Msb, Er-Rághib,) inf. n. HawolN and HuWuwlN (K, Er-Rághib) [and HawalaAnN], It (a thing) became altered, transmuted, or changed, (S, * Mgh, Msb, Er-Rághib, TA,) from its state, or condition, (S, Mgh,) or from its natural state or condition, and its constitution; as also AstHAl↓; (Msb;) i. q. tHwRl↓; (K:) which [here] signifies [as above; or] it became altered, transmuted, or changed, whether essentially or substantially, or in respect of predicament [or state or condition], or by saying; (Er-Rághib, TA;) and AHAl↓ signifies the same: (K:) or this last is said of a man meaning mino XaIoCK UilaI XaIoCK tHwRl↓ [he shifted, or turned, from one thing to another]: (TA:) and hence, (TA,) he became a Muslim: (IAar, K, TA:) for in this case one says of a man, EamRaA kaAna tHwRl↓ yaEobudu UilaI AlUisolaAmi [he turned from that which he was worshipping to El-Islám]. (IAar, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, also,] HAl, inf. n. maHaAlN and HiylapN, i. q. AHtAl, q. v. (Ham p. 652.) ― -b3- And HAl and AstHAl↓ It (anything) shifted, or removed, or went, or became shifted or transferred; syn. tHwRl: or it moved; syn. tHrRk: so accord. to different copies of the K: or, accord. to the O, the former verb has both of these significations: (TA:) or it has the latter of these significations, said of a XaxoS [i. e. a man, or person, or the figure of a thing seen from a distance]: (S:) or both verbs signify it (anything) became altered, or changed, (M, K,) from straightness, or evenness, (K,) to crookedness, or unevenness. (M, K.) You say, HaAlati Alqawosu The bow became crooked (K, TA) in the portion between the part grasped by the hand and the curved extremity; or in the curved extremity: (TA:) or reverted from the state into which it was brought by pressure [with the viqaAf], and became crooked in the portion between the part grasped by the hand and the curved extremity; as also AstHAlt↓: (S, O:) and in like manner, AlOaroDu Eani AlAisotiwaMCi UilaI AstHAlti↓ AlEiwaji [The ground became altered, or changed, from evenness to unevenness]: (S:) or [simply] AstHAlt↓ it became uneven: (Msb:) [and AlArD OaHaAlati↓ (K in art. Smt) app. signifies the same:] or AstHAl↓ signifies it (a thing) was disposed, or was about, to become altered, or changed. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And HAl lawonuhu Its colour altered, or changed, and became black. (S.) And HAl It (a thing) shifted from its way, or manner, or direction. (TA.) And HAl wataru Alqawosi The string of the bow shifted from its place on the occasion of shooting: and HaAlati Alqawosu watarahaA, [the bow shifted from its string.] (TA.) And HAl mino makaAnihi, inf. n. HiwalN, (O, TA,) or this is a simple subst., (S, M, K,) He, or it, shifted, or removed, from his, or its, place. (O, TA. [See HiwalN, below.]) And HAl UilaI makaAnK Mxiri i. q. tHwRl↓ [i. e. He, or it, shifted, or removed, or became shifted or transferred, to another place]. (S.) And HAl Eani AlEahodi, inf. n. HuWuwlN, i. q. Anqlb [i. e. He withdrew, or receded, from the covenant, compact, agreement, or engagement]. (S.) ― -b4- HAl fiI matoni farasihi, inf. n. HuWuwlN, He leaped, and rode, upon the back of his horse; as also AHAl↓: (S:) or HAl fiI Zahori daAbRatihi he leaped, and seated himself firmly, upon the back of his beast; as also AHAl↓: (K, TA:) and HAl EalaI Alfarasi, (TA,) inf. n. HawolapN, (K, * TA,) he seated himself firmly upon the horse. (K, * TA.) ― -b5- HAl SabuwHuhumo EalaI gabuwqihimo, Their morning-draught and their evening-draught became one, is said of people suffering from drought, and scarcity of milk. (TA.) ― -b6- HAl, (Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. as above, inf. n. HawolN, (Msb,) said of a year (HawolN), (Mgh, K,) It passed: (Msb:) or it revolved and passed: (Mgh:) or it became complete. (K.) You say, HAl Ealayohi AlHawolu, (S, K,) inf. n. HawolN and HuWuwlN, (K,) The year passed over him, or it; [or he, or it, became a year old;] (S, K;) as also AHAl↓. (S.) And HAl, alone, (Msb, TA,) and AHAl↓ and OaHowala↓, (Msb,) The year passed over it. (Msb, TA.) And AHAl↓ (S, K) and OaHowala↓ (S, TA) and AHtAl↓ (K) A year passed over it; [or it became a year old;] (S, K, TA;) said of wheat, or food, and of other things: (S, TA:) and so HAlt and AHAlt↓ and OaHowalato↓ said of a dAr [or house]: (S:) or HaAlati AldRaAru and AHAlt↓ and OaHowalat↓ and Hiyla biAldRaAri years passed over the house: (K:) or the house became altered, or changed, and years passed over it: and in like manner one says, OaEaAmat and OaXoharat. (TA.) And HAl said of a boy, A year passed over him; [or he became a year old;] (S;) as also AHwl↓. (K.) And biAlmakaAni AHAl↓ (Ks, S, Msb, K) and OaHowala↓ (Ks, S, K) He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, a year in the place: (Ks, S, Msb, K:) or, as some say, a long time. (TA.) ― -b7- HaAlato, inf. n. HiyaAlN (S, Msb, K) and HiyaAlapN and HuWuwlN (K) and HuwlN; (S;) and AHAlt↓, and HwRlt↓; (K;) said of a she-camel, (S, K,) &c., (K,) She did not conceive, or become pregnant, during a year, or two years, or some years: (K:) or she, having been covered by the stallion, did not become pregnant: (S, K:) or, said of a woman, and of a she-camel, she did not become pregnant. (Msb.) And HAlt, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) and AHAlt↓, (Mgh,) said of a palm-tree (naxolapN), It bore one year, and not another year: (Mgh, TA:) or did not bear, (S, Msb,) having been fecundated. (S.) ― -b8- HAl AlXRaIoCu bayoniI wabayonaka, (S, Er-Rághib,) or bayona AlXRayoYayoni, (Mgh, * K,) inf. n. HayoluwlapN, [originally HayowaluwlapN,] (Mgh, Msb,) like kayonuwnapN [&c.], (Mgh,) and HuWuwlN (Mgh) and HawolN, (Er-Rághib, TA,) The thing intervened as a separation, a partition, a fence, a barrier, or an obstacle, or obstruction, (S, K, Er-Rághib, TA,) between me and thee, (S, Er-Rághib, TA,) or between the two things. (K.) You say, HAl AlnRahoru bayonanaA The river intervened as a separation, or an obstacle, between us, preventing conjunction, or communication. (Msb.) And HAl AlXRaIoCu duwna AlXRaIoCi [The thing intervened as an obstacle in the way to the thing]. (S voce AiEotaraDa.) It is said in the Kur [viii. 24], waQEolamuwA OanRa QllReha yaHuwlu bayona AlmaroCi waqalobihi [And know ye that God interveneth, or interposeth, between the man and his heart, or secret thoughts, or desire]: indicating that He turns him from his desire: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or that He possesses his heart, and
turns it as He wills: (O, TA:) or that a man cannot believe nor disbelieve unless it be God's will: (Jel:) or, as some say, that God destroys a man; or reduces him to the vilest condition of life, in order that he may not know, after knowing, anything. (Er-Rághib, TA. [See other remote interpretations in the Ksh, and the Expos. of Bd.]) And in the same [xxxiv. 53], waHiyla bayonahumo wa bayona maA yaXotahuwna [And an obstacle shall be made to intervene between them and that which they shall eagerly desire]. (TA.) ― -b9- And HAl AlXRaIoCu The thing poured out, or forth. (TA.) [See also 4.] ＝ -A2- Hawilato Eayonuhu, (S, K,) and HaAlato, inf. n. taHaAlu, (K,) the latter, of the dial. of Temeem, accord. to Lth, (TA,) [but see what follows,] inf. n. HawalN; (S, M, Mgh, K;) and AHwlRt↓, (S, K,) inf. n. AiHowilaAlN↓; (K;) His eye [squinted; i. e.] had the white apparent at the outer angle, and the black next the inner angle: (M, K:) or had the black turning towards the nose: (Lth, M, K:) or had one of the two blacks turned towards the nose, and the other towards the temple: (Mgh:) or had its black next the outer angle: or his eye was as though it looked towards the HijaAj [or supraorbital bone]: or had the black inclining towards the outer angle: (M, K:) the first of which meanings is that commonly known: but some say that HaAlato signifies it was turned from its proper state: or it is anomalous: (TA:) the epithet applied to the man is OaHowalu↓, (S, Mgh, K,) and HawilN↓: and that applied to the eye is [the fem. of the former of these, i. e.] HawolaMCu↓: (K:) the pl. of which, and of the masc., is HuwlN. (Har p. 412.)

2 HwRlhu Hwl Hwlh Hwlp
2. HwRlhu, inf. n. taHowiylN, He altered it, transmuted it, or changed it, whether essentially, or substantially, or in respect of predicament [or state or condition], or by saying; (Er-Rághib, TA:) [as also AHAlhu↓.] ― -b2- [Hence, He turned it over, or about, in his mind, considering what might be its results, and so managed it; namely, an affair; like qalRabahu.] You say, rajulN baSiyrN bitaHowiyli AlOumuwri [A man who is knowing, skilful, or intel-ligent, in turning affairs over, or about, in his mind, &c.]. (S, TA.) And raOoyahu fiI AlOamori AHAl↓ He altered, or changed, his opinion respecting the thing, or affair. (MA.) ― -b3- He shifted it, removed it, or transferred it, from one place to another: (S, * Mgh, O, Msb, TA:) or HwRlhu Uilayohi he shifted it, removed it, or transferred it, to it, or him: (K:) and AHAlhu↓ signifies the same. (Msb.) [Hence,] HwRl AlrRidaMCa, (Msb,) inf. n. as above, (Mgh,) He put the right side of the [garment called] rdAC on the left: (Mgh:) or he shifted each extremity of the rdAC to the place of the other. (Msb.) ― -b4- He transferred, or transcribed, what was in it, namely, a book, or writing, to another, without doing away with the original form. (TA.) ― -b5- He made it, or pronounced it to be, muHaAl [i. e. absurd, inconsistent, self-contradictory, unreal, or impossible]. (K. [See also 4.]) ― -b6- HwRl Eayonuhu: see 4. ＝ -A2- See also 5, in two places. ― -b2- HawRalato said of a she-camel &c., i. q. HaAlato: (K:) see 1.

3 HAwlhu HAwl HAwlh HAwlp
3. HAwlhu, (S, M, K,) inf. n. muHaAwalapN (M, K, KL) and HiwaAlN, (M, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, HawAl,]) He desired it: (S, KL:) he sought it: (M, K, KL:) or he sought it by an artful contrivance or device; or by artful, or skilful, management; by turning over, or revolving, thoughts, ideas, schemes, or contrivances, in his mind, so as to find a way of attaining his object; syn. Talabahu biHiylapK, (A,) or biQloHiylapi. (Har p. 326.) Aboo-Heiyeh En-Numeyree says,
wamano yuHaAwilu XayoYFA fiI fami AlOasadi
[And who will seek to get a thing in the mouth of the lion?] (Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 714.) And one says, HAwl minohaA AljimaAEa [He desired, or sought, of her, copulation, using blandishment, or artifice, for that purpose]. (T in art. rwd, bika OuHaAwilu occurring in a trad., means bk OuTaAlibu [app. By means of Thee I seek, or demand, that which I want]. (Az, M, A, TA.) One says also, HaAwalotuhu Oano yafoEala AlOamora [I sought, or endeavoured, to induce him to do the thing], and Oano yatorukahu [to leave it]. (A in art. dwr.) And, of water, HAwl Oano yajomuda (L and K in art. jmd) (assumed tropical:) It was about to congeal, or freeze; was at the point of congealing, or freezing. (TK in that art.) ― -b2- HaAwalotu lahu baSariI I looked sharply, or intently, at him; I cast my eyes at him. (ISd, K.)

4 AHAl AHAl OHAl
4. AHAl, as an intrans. v.: see 1, in eighteen places. ― -b2- tajanRaba rawoDapF waOaHaAla yaEoduw [He withdrew from a meadow, and set to running,] is a prov., meaning he forsook abundance of herbage, or of the goods and conveniences and comforts of life, and preferred to it straitness, or difficulty. (S.) ― -b3- AHAl Ealayohi biAlsRawoTi He set upon him with the whip, (S, MA, K,) yaDoribuhu [striking him]: (S:) or he desired to strike him with the whip: or he struck him with the whip: (MA:) and OaHalotuhu biAlsRawoTi, and biAlrRumoHi, [if AHlth be not a mistranscription for OaHalotu Ealayohi, in the MS. from which I take this, as it may be inferred to be from what here precedes and follows,] I aimed at him with the whip, and with the spear, and set upon him with it: whence the saying, of him who has struck one at the point of death, and killed him, yuHiylu Almawota EalaI AlDRarobi, i. e. (assumed tropical:) He makes death [as it were] to hang upon, and cleave to, striking; like as the spear is made to cleave to the muHaAl Ealayoh, who is the person thrust, or pierced. (Msb.) El-Farezdak says, (S, TA,) addressing Hubeyreh Ibn-Damdam, (TA,)
wakunota kaciYobi AlsRawoCi lamRaA raOaI damFA
biSaAHibihi yawomFA OaHaAla EalaI AldRami
i. e. [And thou mast like the wicked wolf: when he saw blood upon his companion, one day,] he set upon the blood. (S, TA.) ― -b4- [Hence, perhaps,] HAl Ealayohi He reckoned him, or esteemed him, weak. (K.) ― -b5- AHAl AllRayoli Night poured upon the earth; (K;) and came on. (TA.) [See also 1, last sentence but one.] ― -b6- AHAl bifulaAnK Alxubozu The bread fattened such a one; and in like manner one says of anything by which one becomes fat. (AA, TA.) ― -b7- And AHAl He did, or said, what was muHaAl [i. e. absurd, inconsistent, self-contradictory, unreal, or impossible]. (S, Sgh, K. *) ― -b8- And His camels did not conceive, or become pregnant, (AA, S, K,) during a year, or two years, or some years, (K,) having been covered. (S.) ＝ -A2- As a trans. v.: see 2, in three places. ― -b2- AHAl Algariyma He referred the creditor, from himself, [for the payment of what was due to him,] to another. (M, K.) And OaHalotuhu bidayonihi I transferred his debt [i. e. the debt due to him from me] by making another person than myself responsible for it. (Msb.) And OaHalotu zayodFA bimaA kaAna lahu EalaIRa EalaI rajulK I referred, or turned over, Zeyd, for the payment of what was due to him from me, to a certain man, transferring the responsibility for the debt to the latter: in which case, I am termed muHiylN↓; and Zeyd is termed muHaAlN↓; and the other man, Ealayohi muHaAlN↓, and Elyh muHotaAlN↓, and HawiylN↓; and the property, bihi muHaAlN↓: (Mgh:) and HayRilN↓, [originally HawiylN or HayowilN,] also, is applied to him to whom the reference is made; and to him who accepts the reference; both together being termed HayRilaAni. (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA.) And you say, AHAl Ealayohi bidayonihi [He referred a person to him for the payment of his debt]. (S.) And AHAl [alone] He transferred the debt for which he was responsible to the responsibility of another. (Har p. 59.) And OaHalotu AlOamora EalaI zayodK [I turned over the affair to Zeyd;] I made the performance of the affair to be required restrictively of Zeyd. (Msb.) ― -b3- AHAl Ealayohi AlmaMCa He poured out the water upon it: (K:) or AHAl AlmaMCa mina AldRalowi he poured forth the water from the bucket, and turned over the latter. (S.) ― -b4- AHAl QllRehu Ealayohi AlHawola [God made the year to pass over him, or it]: (Lh, TA:) or AHAl AllReh AlHawola God made the year complete. (K, TA.) ― -b5- AHAl AlrRajulu Uibilahu AlEaAma [The man made his she-camels to pass the year without becoming pregnant; or] the stallion did not cover the man's she-camels during the year. (Lh, TA.) ― -b6- OaHowala Eayonahu, (Ks, Lh, S,) or OaHaAlahaA, and HwRlhA↓, (K,) He made his eye to be HawolaMCa [i. e. squinting, &c.]. (Ks, Lh, S, K.) [See 1, last sentence.] ― -b7- AHAl kalaAmahu He made his speech muHaAl [i. e. absurd, inconsistent, or self-contradictory]. (S. [See also 2.]) ＝ -A3- maA OaHowala Hiylaka How fluctuating, and shifting, and varying, are thy evasions, wiles, artifices, or artful contrivances or devices! (Har p. 309.) ― -b2- And maA OaHowalahu How surpassing is he in the practice of evasions, shifts, wiles, artifices, or artful contrivances or devices; or in turning over, or revolving, thoughts, ideas, schemes, or contrivances, in his mind, so as to find a way of attaining his object! (Fr, S, K;) as also mA OaHoyalahu. (Fr, S in art. Hyl, and K.)

5 tHwRl HAl Hwl tHwl QHwl
5. tHwRl: see 1, first sentence, in three places. [Hence,] tHwRl mubotadiEFA [He turned innovator]. (O and K in art. bdE.) ― -b2- It shifted, or removed,
or went, or became shifted or transferred, (S, Msb, K,) from one place to another, (S,) or from its place; (Msb;) as also HwRl↓ (S, * Msb, K *) [and HAl and AstHAl, as shown above: see 1, near the beginning.] You say, tHwRl mino makaAnihi It shifted, &c., from its place. (Msb.) And tHwRl Eanohu It shifted from it to another. (K.) And tHwRl UilaI makaAnK Mxara i. q. HaAla, q. v. (S.) And AlmajarRapu HawRalati↓ The Milky Way became in the midst of the sky; which it does in the summer, (Sh, K, TA,) when the season of heat comes on. (Sh, TA.) ― -b3- See also 8, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also, (S, K,) or tHwRl HaAlFA, (TA,) He carried a bundle upon his back. (S, K, TA.) And tHwRl AlkisaMCi He put a thing in the [garment called] ksAC, and then carried it on his back. (M, K.) ― -b2- tHwRlhu biAlmawoEiZapi He sought to avail himself of the state in which he might be rendered prompt, or willing, to accept admonition. (AA, K.)

8 AHtAl Ealayohi biAldRayoni AHtAl Elyh bAldyn
8. AHtAl Ealayohi biAldRayoni [meaning He was referred, or turned over, to him for the payment of the debt] is from AlHawaAlapu. (S, TA.) You say, AHtAl zayodN bimaA kaAna lahu EalaIRa EalaI rajulK Zeyd was referred, or turned over, for the payment of what was due to him from me, to a certain man, to whom the responsibility for the debt was transferred. (Mgh.) ― -b2- AHtAl said of a year; see 1. ― -b3- AHtAl (S, MA, Msb, K, KL) and tHwRl↓ (S, K) and tHyRl (K) signify the same, (S, K,) from AlHiylapu [q. v.]; (S;) and HaAla↓, (Ham p. 652,) inf n. maHaAlN and HiylapN, (Ham ib. and K, *) also signifies the same as AHtAl; (Ham ib.;) which means He practised Hiylap [i. e. an evasion or elusion, a shift, a wile, an artifice, or an artful contrivance or device, a machination, a trick, a plot, a stratagem, or an expedient, &c.]: (MA, KL:) or he exercised art, artifice, cunning, ingenuity, or shill, and excellence of consideration or deliberation, and ability to manage according to his own free mill, (K, TA,) with subtilty: (TA:) or he sought AlHiylap i. e. [means of evading, or eluding, a thing, or of effecting an object, by] the exercise of art, artifice, cunning, ingenuity, or skill, in the management of affairs; by the turning over, or revolving, thoughts, ideas, schemes, or contrivances, in his mind, so as to find a way of attaining his object. (Msb.) You say, AHtAl fiI AlOamori and tHwRl↓ [&c., He practised an evasion or elusion, &c., in the affair]. (K.) [And AHtAl Ealayohi He practised an artifice, or an artful contrivance or device, &c., against him. And AHtAl liEiyaAlihi He exercised art, artifice, cunning, ingenuity, or skill, in the management of affairs, for his family, or household.] ＝ -A2- AiHotawaluwhu They encompassed, or surrounded, him; or made him to be in the midst of them. (M, O, K.)

9 AHwRlt Eayonuhu AHwlt Eynh AHwlt Eynp
9. AHwRlt Eayonuhu: see 1, last sentence. ― -b2- [AHwRlt AlOaroDu: see 11.]

10 AstHAl AstHAl QstHAl
10. AstHAl: see 1, in six places. ― -b2- Also It (speech, or language, S, Msb, or a thing, TA) became muHaAl [i. e. absurd, inconsistent, selfcontradictory, unreal, or impossible]. (S, Msb, TA.) ＝ -A2- AstHAlhu He looked at it, (S, M, K,) namely, a XaxoS [i. e. a man, or person, or the figure of a thing seen at a distance], (S,) to see if it moved: (S, M, K:) as though he sought, or desired, its motion and change. (TA.) And AstHAl AljahaAma He looked at [the waterless clouds, or the clouds that had poured forth their water, to see if they changed or moved]. (TA.) ― -b2- He reckoned it muHaAl [i. e. absurd, inconsistent, &c.: see above]. (KL.)

11 AHwAlRt AlOaroDu c
11. AHwAlRt AlOaroDu, (K, TA, [in the CK AHwRlt,]) inf. n. AiHowiylaAlN, (TA,) (tropical:) The land became green, and its herbage stood erect, or became strong and erect. (K, TA.) [See HuwalaMCu.]

HaAlN HAl
HaAlN The state, condition, or case, (Sifap,) of a thing; [considered as subject to change;] (Msb, Er-Rághib, TA;) as also HaAlapN↓: (Msb:) or the quality, or manner of being, and state, or condition, of a man, (K, TA,) in respect of good or evil; (TA;) as also HaAlapN↓: (K:) or the particular case, or predicament, of a man &c., in respect of changing events, in the soul and the body and the acquisitions: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and in the coventional language of the logicians, a fleeting, or quickly-transient, quality, such as accidental heat and cold and moisture and dryness; as also HaAlapN↓: (TA:) anything changing: (Ham p. 288:) the time in which one is; (Lth, K;) [the present time;] the end of the past, and the beginning of the future: and as a conventional term, [in grammar, the present tense: and (tropical:) the future: and also] a denotative of state of the agent or of the objective complement; [the former termed HaAlN mina AlfaAEili; and the latter, HaAlN mina AlmafoEuwli; and each said to be manoSuwbN EalaI AlHaAli, i. e. put in the accus. case as a denotative of state, unless expressed by a complete proposition;] as [qaAYimFA] in the phrase zayodN fiI AldRaAra qaAYimFA [Zeyd is in the house, standing], and in Darabotu zayodFA qaAYimFA [I beat Zeyd standing]: (Ibn-El-Kemál, TA:) it is fem., like HaAlapN; (Msb;) and mase.; (Msb, K;) but mostly fem.: (TA:) the pl. is OaHowaAlN and OaHowilapN, (K,) [both properly pls. of pauc., but the former often used as a pl. of mult., and often signifying circumstances,] the latter anomalous: (TA:) the pl. of HaAlapN↓ is HaAlaAtN: (TA:) or HAlp↓ is the n. un. or sing. of HaAlN and OaHowaAlN [and HaAlaAtN], used in relation to a man. (S, O.) You say HaAlN HasanN and HasanapN [A good state or condition &c.; as also HaAlapN↓ HasanapN]. (Msb.) And AldRahori HaAlaAtu↓ and OaHowaAluhu The changes, or vicissitudes, of time or fortune. (K.) [And AifoEalohu HaAlFA and fiI AlHaAli Do thou it now, or immediately. And EalaI kulRi HaAlK In any case: a phrase of frequent occurrence. The phrase qaAla lisaAnu AlHaAli (assumed tropical:) The tongue of the case said, (often used by late writers,) means the case seemed to say.] ＝ -A2- A load, or burden: (Ham p. 299:) [whence, perhaps, xafiyfu AlHaAli (which see in what follows) as meaning (assumed tropical:) having a small family to maintain:] and hence, (Ham ib.,) a bundle, or bundle of clothes, (kaArapN,) which is carried on the back (S, Ham ib.) by a man: (S:) or a thing that a man carries on his back, (ISd, O, K,) whatever it be. (ISd, TA.) ― -b2- A [garment of the kind called] kisaMC in which one collects, or seeks and collects, dry herbage: (O, K:) or a garment, or piece of stuff, of which two ends are tied in a knot behind the flanks, and the other two ends over the head; in which one collects dry herbage; also called XukobaAnN. (TA in art. Xkb.) ＝ -A3- A child's go-cart, by means of which he practises walking; (S, K *, TA;) resembling a small Eajalap; (S;) also called darRaAjapN [q. v.]. (S, TA.) ＝ -A4- The part of a horse that is the place of the libod [or saddle-cloth]: or the line along the middle of the back: (K, TA:) or HaAlu matoni Alfarasi signifies the middle of the back of the horse; the place of the libodi. (S.) [See also its syn. HaAcN.] xafiyfu AlHaAli signifies the the same as xafiyfu AlHaAci, (A in art. Hwc,) which means (tropical:) A man light of back; (S, A, L, Msb, all in art. Hwc;) i. e. having little property: and also having a small family to maintain; (L in that art.;) or having little property and a small family to maintain; (L and K in that art.;) like xafiyfu AlZRahori. (A, L, Msb, all in that art.) ＝ -A5- Black mud: (S, K:) from HaAla “ it became altered, or changed. ” (TA.) It is said in a trad. that the HAl of El-Kowthar is musk: (TA:) and in another, that Gabriel took of the HAl of the river [Nile] and put it into the mouth of Pharaoh; (S, TA;) but here it has the meaning next following. (TA.) Black fetid mud; syn. HamoOapN. (K, and Ham p. 288.) And Soft earth. (K, and Ham ib.) ― -b2- And hence, (tropical:) Weakness, and softness. (Ham ib.) ― -b3- Stinking flesh-meat. (Ham ib.) ― -b4- Hot ashes (IAar, K, and Ham ib.) ― -b5- The leaves of the samur [acacia, or mimosa, gummifera,] beaten and shaken off into a garment, or piece of cloth. (K.) ― -b6- Milk. (M, K.) ＝ -A6- In the dial. of Hudheyl, (IAar, TA,) A wife. (IAar, K.)

HawolN Hwl
HawolN A year; (S Msb, K, Er-Rághib, &c.;) so termed in consideration of its changing, and of the revolution of the sun in its places of rising and setting; (Er-Rághib, TA;) or as being the period in which [certain] plants attain their complete strength: (El-Harállee, TA:) and even if it has not passed; because it will be [properly speaking] a Hawol: an inf. n. used as a simple subst.: (Msb:) pl. [of pauc., but also used as a pl. of mult.,] OaHowaAlN (M, Msb, K) and [of mult.] HuWuwlN and HuwuwlN, (M, K,) the former with C and the latter with w. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Strength, power, might, or force; syn. quwRapN; (S, TA;) as also HiylapN↓ [originally HiwolapN] (TA) and HawolapN↓, (K, TA,) or this last is a n. un. from HawolN: (TA:) it is in the soul and the body and the acquisitions: and hence the saying, in a trad., laA Hawola wa laA quwRapa UilRaA biQllRehi AlEaliIRi AlEaZiymi [There is no strength nor power but in, or by means of, God, the High, the Great]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or it here signifies motion; [see also HawolapN;] and the meaning is, there is no motion nor power,
or ability, but by the will of God: (AHeyth, TA:) or, as some say, the meaning is, there is no Hwl [i. e. changing, or turning, or receding,] from disobedience, nor qwRp [i. e. power] to obey, but by the accommodating, or disposing, of God. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also HiylapN. ＝ -A3- Hawolu XaIoCi The lateral, or adjacent, part to which a thing may shift, or remove: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or the environs [of a thing]. (Msb.) You say, qaEaduwA Hawolahu, (S, K, *) or qaEadonaA Hawolahu, the noun being in the accus. case as an adv. n. of place, i. e., [They sat, or we sat, around him, or it, or] in his, or its, environs; (Msb;) and HawaAlahu↓, and Hawolayohi, (S, K,) dual of Hawol, (TA,) and HawaAlayohi↓, (S, Msb, K,) dual of HawaAl, (TA,) and OaHowaAlahu, (ISd, K,) pl. of Hawol, and used to give intensiveness to the meaning: (ISd, TA:) but you should not say HawaAliyhi. (S, Sgh.) And walaA EalayonaA AallRehumRa HawaAlayonaA↓ [O God, be Thou around us as our protector, and not against us,] occurs in a trad. respecting prayer. (TA.) It is said, in the Expos. of the exs. cited as testimonies by Sb, that one sometimes says HawaAlayoka↓ and Hawolayoka, meaning Around thee, in every direction; dividing the surrounding parts into two; like as one says, OaHaATuwA bihi mino jaAnibayohi, not meaning that any of the surrounding parts remained vacant. (TA.) [See also an ex. voce danodana.]

HawalN Hwl
HawalN inf. n. of Hawilato Eayonuhu. (S, K. [See 1, last sentence.]) ＝ -A2- See also HaAYilN.

HawilN Hwl
HawilN: see HuwRalN: ― -b2- and see also 1, last sentence.

HuwalN Hwl
HuwalN: see HuwRalN: ― -b2- and HaAYilN: ― -b3- and HiyaAlN.

HiwalN Hwl
HiwalN Removal from one place to another, in a passive sense; a subst. from taHawRala: (S, O, K:) and in an active sense; a subst. from HawRalahu; (K;) accord. to ISd, it is the latter [only]; (TA;) as also HawiylN↓. (K.) Hence, in the Kur [xviii. 108], laA yaboguwna EanohaA HawolFA [They shall not desire removal from it]
Hawula
(S, M, O, K:) or, as some say, it here means HiylapF↓; i. e. they shall not [desire to] practise, or seek to practise, any evasion from it to another abode. (TA.) ― -b2- See also HiyalpN [of which it is said to be both a syn. and a pl.]. ― -b3- And see HuwlapN. ＝ -A2- Also A furrow, or trench, in the ground, in which palm-trees are planted in a row. (ISd, K.)

HaAlapN HAl HAlh HAlp
HaAlapN; pl. HaAlaAtN: see HaAlN, in seven places.

HawolapN Hwl Hwlh Hwlp
HawolapN Motion, or removal, (taHarRukN or taHawRulN, accord. to different copies of the K, the former being the reading in the TA,) and change of state. (K.) [See also HawolN. And see HaAla EalaI Alfarasi, of which it is the inf. n.] ― -b2- See also HiylapN. ― -b3- And see HawolN, as meaning quwRapN.

HuwlapN Hwl Hwlh Hwlp
HuwlapN: see HuwRalN: ― -b2- and HiylapN. ― -b3- Also A wonder, or wonderful thing; pl. HuwlN. (K: [but probably this should be HuwalN, as below.]) ― -b4- [It is also used as a pl., signifying Wonders.] You say, hecaA mino Huwlapi AldRahoi This is of the wonders of the age, or of time, or fortune; as also mn HawalaAnihi↓, and Hiwalihi↓ [pl. of HiylapN↓], and HuwalaAYihi↓. (K, TA: the last, in one copy of the K, HuwalaAnihi↓, and in the CK HuwolAnhi↓.) ― -b5- An evil, or abominable, event or accident; (K, * TA;) a calamity, or misfortune: pl. HuwalN: as in the saying, huwa HuwlapN mina AlHuwali It is a calamity of calamities. (S, TA.) It is also used as an epithet; so that one says, jaMCa biOamorK HuwlapK [He did, or brought to pass, an evil, or abominable, thing]. (M, TA.)

HiylapN Hyl Hylh Hylp
HiylapN, (S, M, Msb, K, &c.,) originally HiwolapN, (Er-Rághib, TA,) [said to be an inf. n., (see 8,)] and HawolN↓ (S, M, K) and HayolN and HiwalN↓, (M, K,) which is also a pl. of the first, (K,) and HawolapN↓ (K) and HuwlapN↓ (Ks, TA) and HawiylN↓ (M, K) and HaAYilapN↓ (Ham p. 652) and maHaAlapN↓ (S, K) and maHaAlN↓, (M, K,) [said to be an inf. n., (see 8,)] and maHiylapN↓, (Sgh, TA,) i. q. AiHotiyaAlN and taHawRulN and taHayRulN; (M, K; [see 8;]) [or A mode, or manner, of changing from one state to another, or of shifting from one thing to another; HiylapN being of the measure fiEolapN from HaAla, like jilosapN &c. from jalasa &c.; or from taHawRulN as syn. with HaAla; (see what follows;) a mode, or means, of evading or eluding a thing, or of effecting an object; an evasion or elusion, a shift, a wile, an artifice, or artful contrivance or device, a machination, a trick, a plot, a stratagem, or an expedient;] a means of effecting one's transition from that which he dislikes to that which he likes; (KT, in explanation of the first word;) art, artifice, cunning, ingenuity, or skill, (Msb, K,) in the management of affairs; i. e. the turning over, or revolving, thoughts, ideas, schemes, or contrivances, in the mind, so as to find a way of attaining one's object; (Msb;) and excellence of consideration or deliberation; and ability to manage according to one's own free will, (K, TA,) with subtilty: (TA:) accord. to Er-Rághib, HiylapN signifies a means of attaining to some state concealedly; and it is mostly used of that in which is sin, or offence, or disobedience; but sometimes of that in the exercise of which is wisdom; and hence God is described as Xadiydu AlmaHaAli↓, meaning strong in attaining, concealedly from men, to that in which is wisdom: accord. to Abu-l-Bakà, it is from AltRaHawRulu; because by it one shifts from one state to another, by a species of forecast, and gentleness, or delicacy, so as to change a thing from its outward appearance: (TA:) the pl. of HiylapN is HiwalN and HiyalN [which latter is the most common form, and also, as well as HiwalN, said to be syn. with the sing.,] and HiylaAtN. (K.) One says, laA Hiylapa lahu [He has no mode, or means, of evading &c.]. (TA.) [And maA biyadiI HiylapN I have no mode, or means, of evading &c.]. And AlmaroCu yaEojizu laA maHaAlapa↓ [Man becomes impotent: there is no avoiding it]. (S.) minohu laA maHaAlapa↓ means laA budRa [There is no avoiding it, or escaping it]. (S, * K.) One says, Almawotu MtK laA maHaAlapa↓ [Death comes: there is no avoiding it]. (S.) See also HiwalN. ― -b2- And see HuwlapN: ― -b3- and HawolN. ― -b4- [Eilomu AlHiyali The science of mechanics.]

HuwalapN Hwl Hwlh Hwlp
HuwalapN: see HuwRalN, in two places.

HawoliIRN Hwl HwlI Hwly
HawoliIRN A solid-hoofed animal in his first year: (S, O:) or a solid-hoofed animal, &c., a year old; a yearling: (K:) it is applied in this sense to a camel: and also to a plant: (TA:) and so muHowilN↓ and muHiylN↓ applied to wheat, or food, &c.: (S, O:) and muHowilN↓ applied to a boychild: (K:) or, as some say, this signifies in the state of childhood; not limited to a year old: (TA:) the fem. of HawoliIRN is HawoliyRapN: pl. [masc. HawaAliIRN; and] fem. HawoliyRaAtN. (S, K.) HawoliIRN AlgaDaA Young trees of the kind called gaDFA. (TA.)

HiyaliIRN Hyl HylI Hylp Hyly
HiyaliIRN: see HuwRalN.

HuwalaMCu HwlMC
HuwalaMCu and HiwalaMCu, the latter like EinabaMCu and siyaraMCu, which are the only other words of this measure, (S, K,) accord. to Kh, (S,) [The membrane that encloses the she-camel's fœtus in the womb;] to the she-camel, like the maXiymap (K, TA) to the woman; (TA;) i. e., (K,) a skin (S, K) of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour (xaDoraMC), full of water, (K,) which comes forth with the fœtus, containing OagoraAs [pl. of giros, q. v.], and having lines, or streaks, which are red, and of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour (xuDor): (S, K:) or it comes forth after the fœtus, in the first salaI; and is the first thing that comes forth therefrom: so says ISk: and the word is sometimes used in relation to a woman: (TA:) or, accord. to AZ, the water that comes forth upon the head of the fœtus, [i. e.] at the birth: (S:) or a membrane like a large bucket, which is full of water, and bursts when it falls upon the ground: then comes forth the salaI; and a day, or two days, after that, the SaMCap. (TA.) Hence the saying, nazaluwA fiI mivoli HuwalLACi AlnRaAqapi, (K,) and fI mvl HwlLAC AlsRalaI, (TA,) (tropical:) They alighted amid abundance of water and green herbage. (K, * TA.) And raOayotu OaroDFA mivola AlHwlLACi (tropical:) I saw land having dark green herbage. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also HuwlapN.

HawalaAn HwlAn
HawalaAn and HuwalaAn and HuwolaAn: see HuwlapN.

HuwlalN Hwll
HuwlalN: see HaAYilN, in four places.

HawalowalN Hwlwl
HawalowalN: see HuwRalN, in two places.

HawaAlN HwAl
HawaAlN The changing, or varying, of time, or fortune. (K.) ＝ -A2- HawaAlahu, and HawaAlayohi, and HawaAlayonaA, and HawaAlayoka: see HawolN.

HiwaAlN HwAl
HiwaAlN: see HaAYilN, in two places.

HiyaAlN HyAl
HiyaAlN [in the CK, erroneously, HayAl] The front of a thing, as meaning the part, place, or location, that is over against, opposite, facing, fronting, or in front; syn. qubaAlapN. (K, and Mgh in art. Hyl.) You say, qumotu HiyaAlahu I stood in front of him; in the part, place, or location, that was over against him, opposite to him, &c.; syn. qubaAlatahu. (Msb in art. Hyl.) And qaEada HiyaAlapN
and biHiyaAlihi He sat in front of him, over against him, opposite to him, facing or fronting him; syn. biUizaAYihi. (S, K.) And hecaA HiyaAla kalimatika This is opposite to thy saying; syn. muqaAbalapa; in the accus. case, as an adv. n. of place: thus related by IAar from the Arabs: but one may also say HiyaAlu kalimatika [the opposite of thy saying], making the phrase to consist of an inchoative and an enunciative: so says ISd. (TA.) It is originally with w [in the place of the I]. (S, O.) ― -b2- EalaI HiyaAlihi [By himself or itself; independently]. You say, OaEoTi kulRa waAHidK minohumo EalaI HiyaAlahu Give thou to every one of them by himself; syn. ElI Hidatihi; (S in art. wHd;) or biQnofiraAdihi. (Mgh in art. Hyl.) And faEalotu kulRa XaIoCK EalaI HiyaAlihi I did everything by itself; syn. biQnofiraAdihi. (Msb in art. Hyl.) ＝ -A2- Also A string that is tied from the camel's biTaAn [or belly-girth] to his Haqab [or hind girth], to prevent the Haqab from going against the sheath of his penis: (K:) so, too, in the M: but in the O, as on the authority of AA, HuwalN↓, like SuradN, signifies the string that is between the Haqab and the biTaAn. (TA.)

HawiylN Hwyl
HawiylN: see 4, in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b2- [Hence,] One who is responsible, or answerable. (K.) ― -b3- And A witness. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also HiwalN: ― -b2- and HiylapN. ― -b3- Also [Desire: or a seeking: or a seeking by an artful contrivance or device, or by artful or skilful management, to find a way of attaining an object:] a subst. from HaAwalahu. (S, O, K.)

HawaAlapN HwAl HwAlh HwAlp
HawaAlapN The effecting a transition of one river, or rivulet, to another. (M, K.) [This is what is meant by the HwAlp in AlmuzaAraEap, mentioned in the Mgh, as “ customary in the cases of certain plants, as rice, and the baAcinojaAn, and in planting. ”] ― -b2- The transfer of a claim, or of a debt, by shifting the responsibility from one person to another: (Mgh:) the transfer of a debt by shifting the responsibility of him who transfers it to him to whom it is transferred: (KT:) [a reference made by a debtor, of his creditor, to a debtor of the former, for the payment of what is owed by the former to the latter: an order for the payment of a debt, or of a sum of money, given by one person, upon another, to a third person: so in the present day:] a subst. (S, K) from OaHaAli Ealayohi bidayonihi, (S,) or from OaHalotuhu bidayonihi, (Msb,) or from OaHaAla Algariyma. (K.) [See 4.] ― -b3- A responsibility; accountableness. (K.)

HawaAliIRN HwAl HwAlI HwAly
HawaAliIRN and HuwaAliIRN: see the next paragraph.

HuwRalN Hwl
HuwRalN, applied to a man, signifies baSiyru bitaHowiyli AlOumuwri [i. e. Knowing, skilful, or intelligent, in turning affairs over, or about, in his mind, considering what may be their results, and so managing them]; (S, TA;) as also HuwRalN qulRabN, (TA, and so in copies of the S,) and qulRabN HuwRaliIRN↓, (TA, and so in a copy of the S,) and qulRabiIRN HuwRaliIRN↓, and HawRaAlN↓; (TA;) and HuwalapN↓ signifies muHotaAlN↓ [i. e. one who exercises art, artifice, cunning, ingenuity, or skill, and excellence of consideration or deliberation, and ability to manage according to his own free will, with subtilty; &c.; see the verb (8) of which muHotaAlN is the part. n.]: (S:) or HuwRalN and HuwalN↓ and HuwalapN↓ and HuwolapN↓ and HuwRaliIRN↓, [in the CK, erroneously, HawoleI,] like sukRariIRN, [in the CK like sakorIe,] and HaAliIRN↓ and HuwaAliIRN↓ and HawalowalN↓, signify Xadiydu AlAiHotiyaAli [i. e. one who exercises great art, artifice, &c.]: (Sgh, K:) all of these forms are mentioned by ISd, except HuwolapN and HuwRaliIRN: (TA:) accord. to some, qulRabN HuwRalN signifies experienced, or expert, in affairs; or one who has been tried, or proved, and strengthened by experience in affairs: (Har p. 312:) and HawilN↓ signifies the same as HuwRalN; (Ham p. 34;) having much Hiylap [i. e. art, artifice, &c.]: accord. to analogy, it should be [HaAlN,] like maAlN and SaAtN as epithets applied to a man: (Idem pp. 530 and 531:) HayRaAlN, also, [in like manner,] signifies SaAHibu HiylapK [i. e. one who exercises art, artifice, &c., as above]; and so HiyaliIRN↓ [from HiyalN, pl. of, or syn. with, HiylapN]: (TA:) and HawolowalN↓ [mentioned above (in the CK, erroneously, in this instance, HawAwil)] signifies also cunning, or intelligent, or skilful and knowing; and quick and sharp or vigorous or effective; syn. munokarN kamiyXN; (K, TA;) applied to a man. (TA.)

HayRilN Hyl Hylp
HayRilN: see 4, in the latter half of the paragraph.

HuwRaliIRN Hwl HwlI Hwly
HuwRaliIRN: see HuwRalN, in three places.

HawRaAlN HwAl
HawRaAlN: see HuwRalN.

HaAYilN c
HaAYilN Altering, or being transmuted, or changing; or altered, or transmuted, or changed; [in any manner; and particularly] in colour; (K, TA;) and becoming, or become, black; applied to a bone, and any other thing. (TA.) ― -b2- Anything [shifting, or moving, or] that has shifted, or moved, in fiI [app. a mistranscription for mino from]) its place. (TA.) ― -b3- A she-camel, and any female, not conceiving, or not becoming pregnant, during a year, (M, K,) or two years, (K,) or some years: (M, K:) or a she-camel not pregnant (S, Msb, K) after having been covered by the stallion; (S, K;) because denoting a change from what is usual; (Er-Rághib, TA;) and in like manner applied to a ewe, or she-goat; (TA;) and to a woman: (Msb:) pl. HiyaAlN and HuwlN (S, K) and HuwRalN, (K,) and HuwlalN↓ (M, K) is a quasi-pl. n.: (M, TA:) [whence,] HaAYilu HuwlK and HuwlalN↓ used as intensive epithets: or HaAYilN signifies not conceiving in one year, (K, TA,) when she has been covered: (TA:) and HaAYilu HuwlK and HuwlalK↓, not conceiving during two years; (K;) not conceiving in the first year after having been covered, nor in the next following year; like EaAYiTu EuwTK and EiyTK and EuwTaTK: (S in art. EwT:) one says also, laqiHato EalaI HuwlK and HuwlalK↓ [app. meaning She conceived after having failed to do so for two years; for it seems that in this case Hwl and Hwll are inf. ns., or that the latter is a subst. having the sense of an inf. n.: see 1, and see also EuwTaTN]: (TA:) and muHawRilN↓ signifies the same as HaAYilN. (K.) Also A palm-tree (Msb, K) that bears one year, and not another year: (K:) or not bearing. (Msb.) ― -b4- The female young one of a camel, at the time of her birth: the male is termed saqobN: (S, K:) pl. HuwlN and HawaAYilu. (TA.) One says, nutijati AlnRaAqapu HaAYilFA HasanapF [The she-camel brought forth a beautiful female young one]. (S.) And laA OafoEalu caAka maA Oarozamato OumRu HaAYilK [I will not do that as long as a mother of a female young camel utters her gentle yearning cry]. (S.) ＝ -A2- Also, (Lth, Mgh, O, TA,) and HiwaAlN↓ (Lth, K) and HuwalN↓ and HawalN↓, (K,) A thing that intervenes as a separation, a partition, a fence, a barrier, or an obstacle, or obstruction, between two other things. (Lth, Mgh, * O, K.) One says, bayonahumaA hecaA HiwaAlN↓, i. e. HaAYilN [This is a thing intervening as a separation, &c., between them two]; like HijaAzN and HaAjizN. (Lth, O, TA.)

HaAYilapN c
HaAYilapN: see HiyalpN.

OaHowalu c
OaHowalu; and its fem. HawolaMCu: see 1, last sentence. ― -b2- OaHowalu mino bawoli Aljamali [More wry than the urine of the he-camel]: because it does not come forth straight, but [backwards, and] inclining to one side: a prov.
