UiHoyaMCN, (TA,) said of God, (S, Msb,) He made him alive, to live, or be a living being; quickened, endued with life, vivified, [revivified, revived, or resuscitated,] him. (S, * Msb, * K.) Hence, in the Kur [lxxv. last verse], Oalayosa celika biqaAdirK Oano yuHoyiIa AlmawotaI, (S, TA,) i. e. Is not That Doer of these things (Jel) [able to quicken the dead?]. ― -b2- See also 2, in two places. ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) He (God) endued him with the intellectual faculty: as in the saying, in the Kur [vi. 122], Oawamano kaAna mayRitFA faOaHoyayonaAhu (assumed tropical:) [And is he who was intellectually dead and whom we have endued with the intellectual faculty...?]. (Er-Rághib.) ― -b4- See also 3. ― -b5- AHyA AlOaroDa (assumed tropical:) He (God) revived the earth, or land, by the rain, so as to produce in it plants, or herbage. (TA.) And OuHoyiyati AlOaroDu (assumed tropical:) The land was tilled, and made productive. (AHn.) And AHyA AlmawaAti (tropical:) He turned to use the unowned and unused and uncultivated land by walling it round or sowing it or building upon it and the like. (TA.) ― -b6- Also (assumed tropical:) He (a man) found the land to be fruitful, or abundant in herbage, (S, K,) with fresh herbage. (K.) ― -b7- AHyA AllRayola (assumed tropical:) He passed the night in religious service, worship, adoration, or devotion, abstaining from sleep: (TA:) or [simply] he remained awake during the night. (W p. 9.) And AHyA layolatahu He passed his night awake. (MA.) ＝ -A2- AHyt AlnRaAqapu The she-camel had living offspring; (S, K;) her offspring seldom, or never, died. (S.) ― -b2- AHyA Alqawomu The people, or company of men, had their cattle living: (K:) or had their cattle in good condition: (AA, S, K:) or had rain, so that their beasts obtained herbage to such a degree that they became fat: (AZ:) or they (themselves) became in a state of abundance of herbage, or plenty. (S, K. [See also 1.])

5 tHyRA minohu tHyA mnh tHyA mnp
5. tHyRA minohu (assumed tropical:) He shrank from it: taken from AlHayaMCu [or AlHayaApu]; because it is of the nature of the living to shrink: or it is originally taHawRaI; the w being changed into I; or [in other words] from AlHaIRu “ the act of collecting, ” [inf. n. of HawaAhu,] like taHayRaza from AlHawozu. (TA.) [See also 10.]

6 taHaAyaA tHAyA tHyp
6. taHaAyaA as quasi-pass. of 3, He quickened, enlivened, or revived, himself. See an ex. voce ruwHN.]

10 AstHyAhu AstHyAh AstHyAp QstHyAh QstHyI
10. AstHyAhu He spared him; let him live; or left him alive; (S, Msb, K, TA;) did not slay him; (Msb;) in which sense the verb has but one form: (Msb, TA:) or he left him; let him alone; or forbore from him. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Hence, as some say, (K,) UinRa QllReha laA yasotaHoyiI Oano yaDoriba mavalFA, (S, K,) in the Kur [ii. 24], i. e. laA yasotaboqiI [meaning Verily God will not spare to propound, or refrain from propounding, a parable, or as a parable]. (S.) [Hence, also,] UinRa QllReha yasotaHoyiI mino ciI AlXRayobapi Almusolimi Oano yuEacRibahu, i. e. [Verily God] forbears from punishing [the hoary Muslim]. (Er-Rághib.) ― -b3- [AisotaHoyaI, or AisotaHoyaA, which latter is the more proper mode of writing it, also signifies He felt, or had a sense of, or he was, or became, moved or affected with, shame, shyness, or bashfulness; and particularly, but not always, honest shame, or pudency, or modesty; or his soul shrank from foul things; as also AisotaHaI; and HayiIa↓, inf. n. HayaMCN.] AstHyI is of the dial. of El-Hijáz; and AstHI, with a single I, is of the dial. of Temeem; (Akh, S, Msb;) the former being the original, (Akh, S,) and that which is used in the Kur: (Msb:) in the latter, the first I [of the original] is suppressed, [and its vowel is transferred to the H,] to facilitate the pronunciation, because of the occurrence of the two I s together: this is the opinion of Sb; and with it agrees that of Aboo-'Othmán [ElMázinee]: the opinion ascribed to Sb in the S, namely, that AisotaHayotu is changed from AisotaHoyayotu in like manner as AisotabaEotu is changed from AisotabNyaEotu, is that of Kh, and is disallowed by El-Mázinee. (IB.) You say, AstHyI mnh, (S, K, [in the CK, erroneously, Eanohu,]) or AstHyA mnh, (Mgh, Msb,) and AstHI mnh, and AstHyAhu, (S, Msb, K, TA,) and AstHAhu; (TA, [and so in the CK in the place of AstHyAhu;]) as also mnh HayiIa↓, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. yaHoyaA, (S,) inf. n. HayaMCN; (S, * Mgh, Msb, K;) He was ashamed of it or on account of it, or ashamed to do it, or shy of doing it; [generally meaning a foul thing;] he was ashamed for himself, or of himself, or was bashful, or shy, with respect to it, or him; he was abashed at, or shy of, it, or him; (K;) he shrank from it, or him: (Msb, K: *) and AstHyI mino kacaA [or AstHyA] He disdained, or scorned, such a thing; abstained from it, or refused to do it, by reason of disdain and pride; he dislike, or hated, it, and his soul was above it; he shunned it, avoided it, or kept himself far from it; syn. Oanifa minohu. (TA.)

HaIRa HI Hy
HaIRa a verbal noun, (S, M, Mgh, TA,) and therefore immediately followed by EalaI, (M, TA,) used as an imperative [addressed to a single person, male or female, and to more than one]; (S;) used in calling, or summoning, or inviting, and urging; (Lth, T, TA;) and having no verb derived from it [alone, for HayoEala is derived from HaIRa and EalaI together]; (Lth, T, Msb, TA;) meaning Come: (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, TA, &c.:) or come quickly: or hasten. (Mgh, TA.) Hence, HaIRa EalaI AlSRalaAhN (in the OacaAn, TA) Come to prayer: (IKt, S, M, Msb, K:) or come ye to prayer: or come ye quickly: or hasten ye. (TA.) And HaIRa EalaI AlfalaAHo [in the same: see art. flH]. (Mgh, TA.) And HaIRa EalaI AlgadaMCi [Come to the morning-meal]: and ElI AlEaXaMCi [to the evening-meal]: (Msb:) and ElI AlvRariydi [to the crumbled bread moistened with broth]: (S:) and ElI Alxayori [to good, good fortune, prosperity, &c.]. (Lth, T, TA.) The saying of Ibn-Ahmar,
HaIRa AlHumuwla faUinRa AlrRakoba qado cahabaA
means Keep thou to the loads [for the riders upon the camels have gone]. (TA.) ― -b2- In the phrase HaIRa hala, and HaIRa halFA, followed by EalaI kacaA and UilaI kacaA, and HaIRa halaA, (K,) which last is used in a case of pausation, but is bad in other cases, (S in art. hl,) and HaIRa halo, and HayRahol, [so in the copies of the K,] with the h quiescent, (K,) and HIR hln [app. HaIRa halano, for HaIRa halFA, or perhaps a mistranscription for HaIRa halaka], (TA,) [the most common rendering of HaIRa hala &c. is like that of HaIRa alone, namely, Come: or] HIR signifies hasten thou; and [hl or] hlA, come to it, or reach it; [so that the meaning is hasten thou: come to such a thing:] or HIR signifies come; and [hl or] hlA, quickly (HaviyvFA), or be thou quick; [so that the meaning is come quickly to such a thing:] or [hl or] hlA signifies be thou quiet; and the meaning is OasoriEo Einoda cikorihi waQsokuno HatRaI yanoqaDiIa [Speed thou at the mention thereof, and be quiet until it is finished]. (K.) Accord. to Abu-lKhattáb, the Arabs used to say, HaIRa hala AlSRalaApa, meaning Come thou to prayer. (TA.) And one says, HaIRa halo bifulaAnK, (IAar, and so in the CK,) and HaIRa halFA bflAn, (IAar, and so in MS. copies of the K,) and HaIRa hala bflAn, meaning Hasten thou with such a one: (IAar:) or keep thou to such a one, and call him. (K.) It is said in a trad.,
UicaA cukira AlSRaAliHuwna fiHaIRa hala biEumara, (S in art. hl,) or faHayRahalFA biEumara, (TA,) i. e. [When the good, or righteous, are mentioned, then] keep thou to 'Omar, and call 'Omar, (S ubi suprà, and TA,) and begin with him, and be quick in mentioning him; (TA;) for he is of such. (S ubi suprà.) Accord. to some of the grammarians, (TA,) when you say HaIRa halFA, with tenween, it is as though you said HavRFA; and without tenween, it is as though you said AlHavRa; the tenween being made a sign of indeterminateness; and the omission of it, a sign of determinateness: and so it is in all compounds of this kind. (K.) [See also art. hl.]

HaIRN HI Hy
HaIRN Living, having life, alive, or quick; contr. of mayRitN [or mayotN]; (S, Mgh, * Msb, * K;) and HayawaAnN↓ is syn. with HaIRN [as meaning having animal life]: (IB:) dim. of the former HuyaIRN↓: (Msb:) and pl. OHoyaMCN. (Msb, K.) When you say of a person, layosa biHaIRK, you mean that he is dead: (Lh:) but minohaA Duriba DarobapF layosa biHaAIK↓, (Lh, K,) [in the CK Daraba, and] in [some of] the copies of the K, erroneously, biHaMCK, (TA,) means [He was struck a blow] in consequence of which he will not live: (Lh, K: *) like as the saying laA taOokulo kacaA faUinRaka maAriDN means Thou wilt be sick if thou eat such a thing. (Lh, K.) Accord. to ISh, one says, OataAnaA HaIRu fulaAnK, meaning Such a one came to us in his life [-time]: and samiEotu HaIRa fulaAnK yaquwlu kacaA, meaning I heard such a one say thus in his life [-time]: (TA:) [or the former may mean Such a one himself came to us: and the latter, I heard such a one himself say thus: for] HI [i. e. HaIR as a prefixed noun] is sometimes redundant, like Ml and cuw: (Ham p. 308:) [and] IB says that HaIRu fulaAnK means Such a one himself. (TA.) And they say, Oaholika kayofa Oanota waHayRapu↓, i. e. How art thou, and those remaining alive of thy family? (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to God, Deathless. (Er-Rághib.) ― -b3- Possessing the faculty of growth, as an animal, and as a plant: (Er-Rághib:) and, applied to a plant, fresh, juicy, or succulent, and growing tall. (TA.) ― -b4- [Sensitively alive;] possessing the faculty of sensation. (Er-Rághib.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) [Intellectually alive;] possessing the faculty of intellect. (Er-Rághib.) [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A Muslim; like as mayRitN means an unbeliever. (TA.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) Lively, as meaning free from grief or sorrow. (Er-Rághib.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) Whole, sound, or unbroken. (L and TA in art. SOb.) ― -b8- OaraDN HayRapN (assumed tropical:) Fruitful land; or land abounding with herbage; (K, TA;) like as ArD mayotapN means unfruitful land. (TA.) ― -b9- AlXRamosu HayRapN (assumed tropical:) The sun is, or was, of a clear colour, unaltered by approaching the place of setting; as though its setting were regarded as death: (TA:) or still bright and white: or still hot and powerful: but the former of these two meanings is the more probable. (Mgh.) ― -b10- naArN HayRapN (assumed tropical:) [A live, or burning, fire. (AHn.) ― -b11- TariyqN HaIRN (assumed tropical:) An apparent, or a distinct, road or way: (K:) pl. OaHoyaMCN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also HayRapN, first sentence. ＝ -A3- [A tribe] of the Arabs: (S:) the children, or descendants, of one father or ancestor, whether many or few: and a XaEob comprising qabaAYil: (Az, TA:) or a qabiylap of the Arabs: (Msb:) or a baTon of the buTuwn of the Arabs: (K, TA:) pl. OaHoyaMCN. (S, Msb, K.) ＝ -A4- The vulva, or external portion of the organs of generation, of a woman. (Az, K. See also HayaMCN, of which HaIRN is also said to be a pl.) Hence, saEafu AlHaIRi, applied by an Arab of the desert to The paraphernalia of a bride. (Az, TA.) ＝ -A5- laAHaIRa Eanohu means laAmanoEa minohu, (Ks, K, *) i. e. [There is no forbiddance of him; or] nothing is forbidden him. (Fr.) ＝ -A6- laA yaEorifu AlHaIRa mina AllRaIRi He knows not, or will not know, what is true from what is false; (IAar, K, Har p. 236;) and so AlHawRa mn AllRawRi: (TA:) or the HawiyRap [or winding gut, &c.,] from the twisting of the rope: (K:) or overt speech from covert: or the living from the dead: or the act of turning round, or winding, [see HawaAhu, (in art. HwI,) of which HaIRN is an inf. n.,] from the act of twisting. (Har ubi suprà.) ＝ -A7- The act of collecting. (TA. [But in this and some other senses it is an inf. n. of HawaI: see 1 in art. HwI.]) ＝ -A8- OaHoyaMCN as pl. of HaMCN: see art. HwO.

HiIRN HI Hy
HiIRN: see HayaApN, of which it is said to be a syn.: and of which it is also said to be a pl.: ＝ -A2- and see HayaMCN, of which, also, it is said to be a pl.

HayRapN Hy Hyh Hyp
HayRapN [A serpent;] a certain thing well known: (K, TA:) [improperly explained in the Msb as syn. with OafoEFI:] applied to the male and the female; (S, Msb;) the p being added to denote one of a kind, as in baTRapN and dajaAjapN; [although HaIRN is not used as a coll. gen. n.; and] although the saying EalaI HayRapK raOayotu HayRFA↓, as meaning [I saw] a male [serpent] upon a female [serpent], is related as having been heard from the Arabs: (S:) but HayRuwtN↓ is also applied to the male; (Az, S, K;) the t being augmentative; for the word is originally HayRuw [or HayRuwRN]: (Az, TA:) it is said that it does not die unless by an accident: and they say of a long-lived man, maA huwa UilRaA HayRapN [He is none other than a serpent]; and in like manner they say of a woman; as though it were called HyRp because of its long life: [for] some, including Sb, say that it is derived from HayaApN, as the rel. n. is HayawiIRN, not HawawiIRN: and to him who objects that one says rajulN HawRaMCN [meaning “ a man who collects serpents ”], it is replied that HayRapN and HawRaMCN are of different roots, like luWoluWN and laORlN, &c.: but it may be from taHawRaI, because of its winding, or coiling, itself; and some say that it is originally HawoyapN; some, that it is originally HayowapN: (TA:) [the dim. is HuyayRapN↓:] the pl. is HayRaAtN (K) and HayowaAtN, (K, TA,) or HayawaAtN. (So in some copies of the K [agreeably with the dial. of Hudheyl].) Hence the prov. huwa OaboSaru mino HayRapK [He is more sharp-sighted than a serpent]; because of the sharpness of its sight: and OaZolamu mino HayRapK [more wrongful in conduct than a serpent]; because it comes to the burrow of the [lizard called] DabR, and eats its young one, and takes up its abode in its burrow. (TA.) And saqaAhu QllRehu dama AlHayRaAti [May God give him to drink the blood of the serpents]; i. e., (assumed tropical:) destroy him. (TA.) And laA talidu AlHayRapu UilRaA HuyayRapF↓ [The serpent does not bring forth anything save a little serpent]: a prov. applied to the cunning and mischievous, or malignant. (TA.) And fulaAnN HayRapu AlwaAdiI, or AlOaroDi, or Albaladi, or AlHamaATi, (assumed tropical:) Such a one is cunning and mischievous, or malignant, (IAar, K,) and intelligent, in the utmost degree: (IAar:) [or] flAn HyRp AlwAdI means (assumed tropical:) such a one is strong in resisting, a defender of his possessions. (TA.) And HayRapu AlwaAdiI is also an appellation applied to (assumed tropical:) The lion; (K, TA;) because of his cunning, or craftiness. (TA.) One says also, humo HayRapu AlOaroDi, meaning (assumed tropical:) They are cunning, guileful, malignant, or mischievous, and strong, not neglecting to take blood-revenge: so in a saying of Dhu-l-Isba' El-'Adwánee cited voce EaciyrN. (TA.) And fulaAnN HayRapN cakarN (S, TA) (assumed tropical:) Such a one is courageous and strong. (TA.) And raOosuhu raOosu HayRapK (assumed tropical:) He is clever, or ingenious; acute, or sharp; intelligent. (TA.) And raOayotu fI kitaAbihi HayRaAti waEaqaAriba (assumed tropical:) I saw in his letter slanders, or calumnies, addressed to the ruling power, in order to cause the object thereof to fall into embarrassment from which escape would be difficult. (TA.) ― -b2- AlHayRapu is also a name of (assumed tropical:) [The constellation Draco; commonly called AltRinRiynu;] certain stars [partly] between the faroqadaAni [or B and y of Ursa Minor] and banaAtu naEoXK [meaning the stars in the tail of Ursa Major]: (K:) so called by way of comparison. (TA.) ― -b3- And HayRapN also signifies (assumed tropical:) A certain mark made with a hot iron upon the neck, and upon the thigh, of a camel, twisting, or winding, like the HayRap [properly so called]. (Ibn- Habeeb, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also HaIRN.

HayFA Hy HyA
HayFA Rain; (S, Msb, K;) as also HayaMCN↓: (K:) or much rain: (Har p. 185:) as being the means of giving life to the earth: (TA:) and (assumed tropical:) plenty; or abundance of herbage, (S, K,) and the means of giving life to the earth and to men; as being caused by the rain; and so HayaMCN↓: (TA:) or [simply] herbage; because produced by the rain: and fat, and fatness; because produced by the herbage: (Ham p. 662:) dual. HayayaAni: (S:) and pl. OaHoyaMCN. (TA.) HayaA AlrRabiyEi means The rain [called rbyE, or of the season thus called,] that gives life to the earth. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph.

HayaMCN HyMC
HayaMCN an inf. n. of HayiIa in the first of the senses explained in this art. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] syn. with HayFA, in two senses: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places. ― -b3- Also inf. n. of HayiIa as syn. with AisotaHoyaI; (S, * Mgh, Msb, K;) i. q. AisotiHoyaMCN; (S;) Shame; a sense of shame; shyness, or bashfulness; [and particularly, but not
always, honest shame, or pudency, or modesty;] syn. HiXomapN; (K;) a shrinking of the soul from foul conduct, (Bd in ii. 24, and Er-Rághib,) through fear of blame; (Bd ibid.;) a languor that affects the animal faculty, (Bd ibid, and Mgh, *) and turns it back from its actions: (Bd:) and repentance; syn. tawobapN. (K.) ― -b4- And hence, as being a thing that should be concealed, and of which one is ashamed to speak plainly, (TA,) The vulva, or external portion of the female organs of generation, (faroj, El-Fárábee, Msb, K, or raHim, [which here means the same,] S,) of a camel, (El-Fárábee, S, Msb, K,) or an animal having feet like those of the camel, and of a cloven-hoofed animal, and of a beast of prey: (K:) accord. to AZ, the dubur [here meaning the same as faroj] of any of these and of other animals: (Msb:) accord. to IAar, it is of the ewe or she-goat, the cow, and the gazelle: (ISd, TA:) and [sometimes] the faroj of a girl, (El-Fárábee, Msb,:) or of a woman: (Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán: ” [see also HaIRN:]) and HayFA↓ signifies the same; (K;) but accord. to Az, this is not allowable except in poetry, in a case of necessity: (TA:) pl. OaHoyaMCN (AZ, IJ, K) and OaHoyiyapN (As, Sb, S, K) and, by contraction, OaHiyRapN, (Sb, IB, TA,) which is said to be preferable, (TA,) and [quasi-pl. n.] HaIRN↓ and HiIRN↓ [which two have been mistaken by Freytag for syns. of taHiyRapN, immediately following them in the K]. (Sb, K.)

HayaApN Hy HyA HyAh HyAp
HayaApN, or Hayewp↓, (as in different copies of the K, in the latter manner in copies of the S,) written with w in the Kur, to show that w follows I in the pl. [HayawaAtN, like SalawaAtN], or because the sound of the A is inclined towards that of w, (ISd, TA,) and HayawopN↓, with sukoon to the w, (K,) which is substituted for the A of HayaApN, as is done by the people of El-Yemen in the case of every A that is changed from w, as in SalaApN and zakaApN, though the final radical letter of the verb of HayaApN is I, (TA,) an inf. n. of HayiIa in the first of the senses explained in this art.; (IB, Mgh, Msb;) Life; contr. of mawotN; (S, K;) as also HayawaAnN↓ and HiIRN↓, (K,) or this last is asserted to be a pl. of HayewpN, (S,) and as also maHoyFA↓, (S, * Har pp. 25 and 350,) of which the pl. is maHaAIK: (S:) HayaApN signifies the faculty of growth, as in an animal, and in a plant: and the faculty of sensation: and (assumed tropical:) the faculty of intellect: and (assumed tropical:) freedom from grief or sorrow: and everlasting life in the world to come; to which one attains by that HyAp which is intelligence and knowledge: and the HyAp that is an attribute of God. (Er-Rághib.) yaA layotaniI qadRamotu liHayaAtiI, in the Kur [lxxxix. 25], means [O, would that I had prepared, or laid up in store,] for my everlasting state of existence. (Er-Rághib.) And faUinRa AldRaAra AlMxirapa lahiIa AlHayawaAnu↓, in the Kur [xxix. 64], means [And verily the last abode is] the abode of everlasting life: (TA:) or AlHywAn here means the life that will not be followed by death: or much life; like as mawataAnN signifies much death: (Msb:) and it is also the name of a certain fountain in Paradise, [the water of] which touches nothing but it lives, by permission of God. (TA.) AlHayewpu AlTRayRibapu, accord. to I'Ab, explaining xvi. 99 of the Kur, (TA,) means Lawful means of subsistence (K, TA) in the present world: (TA:) or Paradise. (K, TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Advantage, or profit; or a cause, or means, thereof: whence the saying, layosa lifulaAnK HayaApN There is not, in such a one, profit, nor good: and so it is said to mean in the Kur [ii. 175], walakumo fiI AlqiSaASi HayewpN (assumed tropical:) [And there is to you, in retaliation, an advantage]: (TA:) or this means that the knowledge of the law of retaliation restrains from slaughter, and so is a cause of life to two persons; and because they used to slay one who was not the slayer, retaliation upon the slayer is a cause of saving the lives of the rest: or the meaning is life in the world to come; for when the slayer has suffered retaliation in the present world, he is not punished for his act in the world to come. (Bd.) ― -b3- HayaApu AlXRamosi means (assumed tropical:) The remaining of the light and whiteness of the sun: or the remaining of its heat and power: but the former of these two meanings is the more probable. (Mgh. [See AlXRamosu HayRapN, voce HaIRN.])

HayewpN Hyewh Hyewp
HayewpN and HayawopN: see the next preceding paragraph.

HayiIRN Hy HyI Hyy Hyyy
HayiIRN Having HayaMC [i. e. shame, shyness, bashfulness, pudency, or modesty]; (K;) part. n. of HayiIa as syn. with AstHyI; of the measure faEiylN: (Msb:) fem. HayiyRapN. (TA.) The saying of I'Ab, AallRehu HayiIRN, means God is one who acts with others in the manner of him who has HayaMC; for HayaMC in its proper sense is not ascribable to Him: (Mgh:) or one who leaves undone evil deeds, and does good deeds. (Er-Rághib.)

HuyaIRN Hy HyI Hyy Hyyy
HuyaIRN: see HaIRN, of which it is the dim.

HuyayRapN Hy Hyy Hyyh Hyyp
HuyayRapN: see HayRapN, (of which it is the dim.,) in two places. ＝ -A2- And dim. of HaMCN, q. v. in art. HwO. (Lth, TA in bAb AlAlf AllyRnp.)

HayawiIRN HywI Hywy
HayawiIRN [Of, or relating to, the serpent;] rel. n. of HayRapN. (S.) ＝ -A2- [And rel. n. of HaA: see HaAYiIRN in art. HwO.]

HayawaAnN HywAn
HayawaAnN an inf. n. of HayiIa, like HayaApN, (IB,) but having an intensive signification: (Msb:) see HayaApN, in two places. ― -b2- See also HaIRN, first sentence. ― -b3- Also Any thing, or things, possessing animal life, (Msb, K, *) whether rational or irrational; [an animal, and animals;] used alike as sing. and pl., because originally an inf. n.; (Msb;) contr. of mawataAnN [q. v.]. (S.) [HayawaAnaAtN is used as its pl. of pauc. And hence,] AlHayawaAnaAtu Alxamosu [The five animals] is applied to what may be killed by a person in the state of UiHoraAm, and by one engaged in prayer: (Msb in art. fsq:) these are the rat, or mouse, and the biting dog, and either the serpent, the crow termed OaboqaE, and the kite, or the serpent, the scorpion, and the kite, or the serpent, the scorpion, and the crow, or the scorpion, the crow, and the kite. (Es-Suyootee, in “ El-Jámi' es-Sagheer, ” voce xamosN.) It is originally HayayaAnN; (Sb, K, TA;) the I which is the final radical letter being changed into w because the occurrence of two I together is disliked: (Sb, TA:) Aboo-'Othmán [El-Má- zinee] holds the w to be a radical letter; but his opinion is said to be not admissible, because it is asserted that there is no instance in the language of a word of which the medial radical is I, and the final w. (TA.)

HayawaAniIRN HywAn HywAnI HywAny HywAnyy
HayawaAniIRN [Of, or relating to, an animal or animals]. ― -b2- It is [also] particularly applied to A seller of birds. (TA.)

HayawaAniyRapN HywAn HywAny HywAnyh HywAnyp
[HayawaAniyRapN Animality; or animal nature.]

HayRuwtN Hywt
HayRuwtN: see HayRapN.

HaAIK HAI HAy
HaAIK, of the measure faAEilN, [said to be] originally HaAyiwN, is syn. with HaAwK and HawRaMCN, belonging to art. HwI [q. v.]. (Az, TA.)

OuHaIRu c
OuHaIRu and OuHaIRN and OuHaIRK: see art. Hw.

OuHayowK c
OuHayowK: see art. Hw.

OaHoyaI c
OaHoyaI in the saying OaHoyaI mino DabRK [More longlived than a DbR, a kind of lizard, which is supposed to live seven hundred years,] is from AlHayaApu. (TA.) ― -b2- In the sayings OaHoyaI mino hadiIRK [More shy, or bashful, than the bride] and OaHoyaI mino muxadRarapK [More shy, or bashful, than a girl kept behind the curtain] it is from AlHayaMCu. (TA.)

tiHoyaApN tHyAh tHyAp wHI
tiHoyaApN: see the next paragraph.

AltRaHaAyiI AltHAyI AltHAyy
AltRaHaAyiI The two stars in the foot and before the foot of the foremost of Gemini: (Kzw:) or three stars over against AlhanoEap [which is the Sixth Mansion of the Moon]; (IKt, K;) and sometimes the moon deviates from AlhnEp, and makes its abode in AltHAyI: (IKt:) they are between the Milky Way and the stars that follow AlEayRuwq [or Capella]: Aboo-Ziyád El-Kilábee used to say that this name means AlhnEp, and is also pronounced AltRaHaAYiI, withC: but AHn says that the moon makes its abode in these stars, and not in AlhnEp itself: (TA:) its sing. is tiHoyaApN↓; (IKt, AHn, TA;) if so, of the measure tifoEalapN, like tiHolabapN, not fiEolaApN, like EizohaApN, because there is no such root as taHI; derived from AlHayaA, because its nawoC [here meaning its auroral setting, in midwinter,] is attended with much rain: but AltHAYI, with C, is irreg.; as though pl. of taHiyRapN↓ likened to a word of the measure faEiylapN. (IB.)

taHiyRapN OHyI Hy HyA tHyh tHyp wHI
taHiyRapN inf. n. of 2. (Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also A salutation, or greeting, (A'Obeyd, AHeyth, Mgh, Msb,) pronounced by one person to another on their meeting; (AHeyth;) particularly the saying salaAmN Ealayoka; (Mgh, * Msb;) and the like; (Mgh;) the most comprehensive form thereof, used by the believer [to his fellow-believer], being the saying AlsRalaAmu Ealayokumo waraHomapu QllRehi wabarakaAtuhu: (AHeyth:) hence it is pluralized; the pl. being taHiyRaAtN and taHaAyaA. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Also Continuance, or endurance; or endless, or everlasting, existence:
(IAar, Msb, K, &c.:) and so it is said to mean in the following verse of Zuheyr Ibn-Jenáb ElKelbee; who was a [kind of] king among his people:
qado nilotuhu UilRaA AltRaHiyRaho
walakulRu maA naAla AlfataI
[And indeed everything that the young man has attained, I have attained it, except endless existence]: or, as some say, it here means security from death and from evils. (TA. [But more probably the meaning is that next following: for in the Mz, 49th nwE, where this verse is cited, but with mino kulRi in the place of walakulRu, he is said to have been (not a king, but,) “ a nobleman. ” See also, respecting him, p. x. of my Preface.]) And (tropical:) Dominion, or kingship: (Fr, AA, S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.:) because the people of the Time of Ignorance used to greet kings [or rather those of Himyer] by the saying Oabayota AlRaEona, which they addressed to none other than a king; so that when any one of them became a king, it was said of him, fulaAnN naAla AltRaHiyRapa [meaning (tropical:) Such a one has attained the kingship]. (Mgh: in which, and in the S, the foregoing verse is cited as an ex. of this last meaning.) AltRaHiyRaAtu lilRehi means Endless existence belongs to God: (Lth, Msb, TA:) or dominion, or kingship: (Lth, Yaakoob, S, Msb, TA:) or freedom, or security, from all evils, (Khálid Ibn-Yezeed, AHeyth,) and from all causes of the cessation of existence: (AHeyth:) or endless existence, and security from evils, and dominion, and the like: (Fr:) or the expressions [of praise] that indicate and imply the ascription of dominion and endless existence: (Kt:) or salutations and benedictions are Gods, and at his disposal. (Mgh.) [AltRaHiyRaAtu is also a term applied to the following form of words repeated in the ordinary prayers: AltRaHiyRaAtu lilRehi waAlSRalawaAtu waAlTRayRibaAtu AlsRalaAmu Ealayoka yaAOayRuhaA AlnRabiIRu waraHomapu QllRehi wabarakaAtuhu AlsRalaAmu EalayonaA waEalaI EibaAdi QllRehi AlSRaAliHiyna OaXohadu Oano laA UilaAha UilRaA QllRehu waOaXohadu OanRa muHamRadFA Eaboduhu warasuwluhu, or (instead of Ebdh wrswlh) rasuwlu QllRehi: see 5 in art. Xhd.] ― -b4- The assigning to this word, as used in the Kur iv. 88, the meaning of A gift is a mistake. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- See also AltRaHaAyiI.

maHoyFA mHyA
maHoyFA: see HayaApN. ― -b2- Also A time, and a place, of life. (TA.)

muHoIK mH mHI mHy mHyy
muHoIK and muHoyiyapN, applied to a she-camel, Having living offspring; whose offspring seldom, or never, die. (S.)

muHayRFA mHyA
muHayRFA The face (S, K, Ham p. 23) of a man, because it is specified in salutation; [see 2;] (Ham ubi suprá;) a term used only in praise; (Ham p. 640;) i. e. the face altogether: or the HurR of the face [i. e. the ball of the cheek; or what appears of the elevated part thereof; or what fronts one, of the face, &c.]. (K.) ― -b2- Of a horse, it is The place where the flesh is separated (Hyv Anfrq AllHm) beneath the forelock. (Ham p. 23.) And daAYirapu AlmuHayRaA, in a horse, [The feather in] the place of separation [of the hair] beneath the forelock, in the upper part of the forehead. (TA.)

mHayRiIN mHyI mHyy
mHayRiIN act. part. n. of 2; fem. muHayRiyapN: (S, TA:) for in every noun in which three Is occur together, [the last of them being the final radical, and ending the word,] if it is not formed from a verb, the final radical letter is elided from it, as in EuTaIRN the dim. of EaTaMCN, and in OuHaIRu the dim. of OaHowaI: but if it is formed from a verb, that letter remains, as in muHayRiIN from HayRaI. (S.)

OaroDN maHoyaApN c
OaroDN maHoyaApN i. q. maHowaApN, i. e. A land containing serpents: (Ibn-Es-Sarráj, S:) or abounding with serpents. (TA in art. HwI.)

Oabuw yaHoyaI c
Oabuw yaHoyaI Death. (TA, Har p. 218.)

Hayovu Hyv
Hayovu, (S, Msb, Mughnee, K,) indecl., (S, Msb,) with damm for its termination, (S, Msb, Mughnee,) as being likened to final words [such as qabolu and baEodu ending a proposition], (S, Mughnee,) because it does not [regularly] occur otherwise than prefixed to a proposition, (S,) for the being prefixed to a proposition is like the not being prefixed to anything, as the consequence of being prefixed, which is the sign of the gen. case, is not apparent: (Mughnee:) and Hayova, (S, Mughnee, K,) also indecl., (S,) with fet-h, (S, Mughnee,) to render the pronunciation more easy, (Mughnee,) because damm with I is deemed difficult to pronounce: (S:) and Hayovi, (Mughnee, K,) with kesr, accord. to the general rule observed to prevent the concurrence of two quiescent letters: (Mughnee:) and in like manner, Hawovu and Hawova and Hawovi: (Mughnee, TA:) of which forms, Hwv is asserted to be the original; (L;) though Hayovu is more chaste than Hawovu, and is the form used in the Kur-án: (Az and TA in art. Hwv:) but some of the Arabs make Hyv decl.: (Mughnee:) it is an adverbial noun of place, (S, Msb,) a vague adverbial noun of place, (L,) [signifying Where,] like Hiyna with respect to time: (S, K:) or it is a denotative of place, by general consent: but accord. to Akh it sometimes occurs as denoting time, [signifying when,] as in the following verse, (Mughnee, TA,) which is the strongest evidence of its use in this sense: (TA:)
HayovamaA tasotaqimo yuqadRiro laka QllRe
hu najaAHFA fiI gaAbiri AlOazomaAni
[Whenever thou shalt pursue a right course, God will decree thee success in the time to come]: (Mughnee, TA:) but in most instances it occupies the place of an accus., as an adverbial noun of place; or of a gen., governed by mino, and sometimes by another prep., as in the saying (of Zuheyr, TA in art. qXEm),
ladaI Hayovu Oaloqato raHolahaAOumRu qaXoEami
[At the place where Calamity, or Fate, has put down her saddle, i. e., made her abode]: and sometimes it occurs as an objective complement, as it is said to do in AallRehu OaEolamu Hayovu yajoEalu risaAlaAtihi [in the Kur vi. 124], i. e. God is knowing: He knows where to bestow his apostolic commissions; yaEolamu being suppressed, as implied by OaEolamu; or OaEolamu may be rendered by EaAlimN, and so may govern the accus. case. (Mughnee.) Accord. to rule, (Mughnee,) in every instance, (S, Mughnee,) it is prefixed to a proposition, (S, Msb, Mughnee,) nominal, or verbal, but in most cases the latter; (Mughnee;) as in Oaquwmu Hayovu yaquwmu zayodN [I will stand where Zeyd shall stand]; and Hayovu takuwnu Oakuwnu [Where thou shalt be, I will be]; (S;) and jalasotu Hayovu zayodFA OaraAhu [I sat where I saw Zeyd], the accus. case being preferred in an instance like this; (Mughnee;) and Acohabo Hayovu XYota [Go thou whither thou wilt.] (Msb in art. Hayn.) You should not say Hayovu zayodN [alone]: (S:) or it occurs prefixed to a single word in poetry; (Msb, Mughnee;) as in the saying,
wanaToEunuhumo taHota AlkulaI baEoda Darobihimo
bibiyDi AlmawaADiI Hayovu laIRi AlEamaAYimi
[And we pierce them beneath the kidneys, after smiting them, with the sharp swords, where the turbans are wound]; (Mughnee;) but this is irregular; (Msb, Mughnee;) though Ks holds it to be regular. (Mughnee.) Lh relates, on the authority of Ks, that some make Hyv to govern a noun in the gen. case, as in the saying,
OamaA taraI Hayovu suhayolK TaAliEaA
[Seest thou not where Canopus is, rising?]: but he says that this is not of respectable authority: (L:) some write Hayova suhayolK: and some, Hayovu suhayolN, [which is the common reading, shyl being an inchoative, and] the enunciative, mawojuwdN, being suppressed. (Mughnee.) Abu-l-Fet-h says that he who prefixes Hyv to a single word makes it declinable. (Mughnee.) [Accord. to Fei,] BenooTemeem say Hayova when it occupies the place of an accus., as in the phrase, qumo Hayova yaquwmu zayodN [Stand thou where Zeyd shall stand]. (Msb.) Ks says, I have heard among Benoo-Temeem, of Benoo-Yarbooa and Tuheiyeh, those who say Hayova in every case, when it occupies the place of a gen., and that of an accus., and that of a nom.; saying mino Hayova laAyaEolamuwna [Whence they know not], and Hayova QlotaqayonaA [Where we met]: and he says also, I have heard some of Benu-l-HárithIbn-Asad-Ibn-El-Hárith-Ibn-Thaalabeh, and all Benoo-Fak'as, say Hayovi when it occupies the place of a gen., and Hayova when it occupies the place of an accus.; saying mino Hayovi laA yaEolamuwna, and Hayova QlotaqayonaA. (L.) Sometimes the proposition after Hyv commences with UinRa, as in Aijoliso Hayovu UinRa zayodFA jaAlisN [Sit thou where Zeyd is sitting]. (K in art. On, and IAk p. 92.) ― -b2- It sometimes comprises the meanings of two adverbial nouns of place, as when you say, Hayovu Eabodu QllRehi qaAEidN zayodN qaAYimN [Where' Abd-Allah is sitting, there Zeyd is standing]. (AHeyth, L.) ― -b3- The restrictive maA (maA kaAfRapN) is sometimes affixed to it, and in this case it implies a conditional meaning, [signifying Wherever, or wheresoever, and, accord. to Akh, whenever, or whensoever,] (Mughnee, TA,) and renders two verbs mejzoom, (Mughnee,) as in the saying, HayovumaA tajoliso Oajoliso [Wherever thou shalt
sit, I will sit], (S,) and in the first of the verses cited above: (Mughnee, TA:) it is not [properly, though it is sometimes improperly,] used as a conditional without mA. (S.) ― -b4- [It is also used, in scientific and other post-classical works, in senses different from those explained above. Thus, mino Hayovu is used to signify As to, or in respect of: so in the phrase mino Hayovu AllRafoZi waAlmaEonaI As to, or in respect of, the word and the meaning. Also As, or considered as, absolutely, or abstractedly: so in the phrase mino Hayovu huwa, or mino Hayovu huwa huwa, As, or considered as, such, absolutely, or abstractedly; and AlUinosaAnu mino Hayovu huwa UinosaAnN Man, as, or considered as, man, absolutely, or abstractedly. And As, meaning considered merely or only or simply as: so in the saying, AlUinosaAnu mino Hayovu UinRahu yaSiHRu watazuwlu Eanohu AlsRiHRapu mawoDuwEu AlTRibRi Man, as, or considered merely or only or simply as, being healthy and ceasing to be healthy, is the object of therapeutics. And As, meaning since, or because: so in the saying, AlnRaAru mino Hayovu UinRahaA HaArRapN tusaxRinu AlmaMCa Fire, as, or since, or because, it is hot, heats water. biHayovu is also vulgarly used in this sense. And correctly as meaning So that; so as that; in such a state, or condition, that: often syn. with HatRaI.]

1 HaAja HAj
1. HaAja, aor. yaHiyju, (Kr, K,) inf. n. HayojN, (TA,) i. q. HaAja, aor. yaHuwju: (Kr, K:) extr., because the A of HaAjapN [which is its logical root] is [originally] w. (TA.)

4 OaHoyajati AlOaroDu c
4. OaHoyajati AlOaroDu, (K,) irregular, like OaHuwaja, (TA,) and OaHaAjat, The land produced the thorny plants, or trees, called HaAjN: (K:) or abounded therewith. (TA.)

HaAjN HAj
HaAjN, a coll. gen. n., n. un. with p, (TA,) A certain kind of thorny plant, or tree; (S, K;) a plant of the sour kind (mina AlHamoDi): accord. to ISd, a kind of thorny plant or tree, i. q. kaburN [or caper]: or a certain plant different from that just named: or a certain kind of tree: accord. to AHn, an evergreen, of which the roots extend far into the ground; which, cooked, is used as a medicine; having slender and long leaves, seeming as numerous as the thorns: (TA:) [asparago sylvestri similis: (Golius, from Ibn-Beytár:) this name, and EaAquwl, are now applied by the Arabs to the plant called by European botanists hedysarum alhagi: see EaAquwlN and taranojubiynN:] dim. HuyayojN↓; therefore its medial radical letter is I; (K;) and HiyayojN↓ is a chaste dial. var. of this dim., agreeably with a usage observed in similar cases [when the medial radical letter is I]. (TA.)

HuyayojN Hyyj
HuyayojN and HiyayojN: see what next precedes.

1 HaAda Eanohu HAd Enh HAd Enp
1. HaAda Eanohu, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor. yaHiydu, inf. n. HuyuwdN and HayodapN (S, Msb, K) and HayodN and HayadaAnN and maHiydN (K) and HayoduwdapN, (S, K,) which last is originally HayaduwdapN, with the I movent; this letter being afterwards made quiescent; for there is not in the language any word of the measure faEoluwlN, except SaEofuwqN; (S; [see the remarks on XayoxuwxapN, voce XaAxa;]) He declined, or turned aside or away, from it; (S, A, K;) removed, went away, or went far away, from it; (Msb;) namely, a road, (S,) or a thing: (Msb:) he shunned, or avoided, it, from fear, or from disdain. (Az, L.) [See also 3.] You say, maA laka maHiydN Eano celika There is not, for thee, any avoiding that. (L.) And HaAdati AldRaAbRapu The beast became scared, or shied, and quitted the middle of the road. (L.) ― -b2- HAd bihi, and AHAdhu↓, He removed, took away, or took far away, him, or it; [Eano XaIoCK from a thing;] similar to cahaba bihi and Oacohabahu. (Msb.)

2 qadRa AlsRayora faHayRadahu qd Alsyr fHydh qd Alsyr fHydp
2. qadRa AlsRayora faHayRadahu He cut, or cut lengthwise, the thong, or strip of skin or leather, and made it to have parts projecting beyond the rest. (L, K.)

3 HAydhu HAyd HAydh HAydp
3. HAydhu, inf. n. muHaAyadapN and HiyaAdN, He went, or turned, aside from, or away from, or he avoided, or he went, or removed, to a distance from, him, or it: (S, L, K:) [see also 1:] or, accord. to the A, he inclined upon, or against, him, or it. (TA.)

4 OaHoyada
4: see 1.

HayodN Hyd
HayodN A rising, or protuberant, or prominent, part of a side of a thing: (L, K:) so of the head; (Lth, L;) as also HayodapN↓: (A:) a knot, knob, or protuberance, of a stick or branch; [as also HayodapN↓: (AHn, TA voce baloTN, q. v.:)] a part of a strap, or thong, projecting beyond the rest: (L:) any rib, (L, K,) or other bone, (L,) that curves much [and is therefore prominent]: (L, K:) [see an ex. voce HaAbK, in art. Hbw:] a knot in the horn of a mountain-goat; (A, * L, K;) or this is termed HayodapN↓: (S, L:) a twisted part of a horn: a twisted internodal portion of a horn: (L:) any prominence in a horn, and in a mountain, (S, L, K,) &c.: (S, L:) a prominent and curved part of a mountain: (T:) a projecting portion, or ledge, of a mountain, resembling a wing: (S, M, L, K:) pl. (of the former word, S) OaHoyaAdN [a pl. of pauc.] and (of both words, S) HuyuwdN and (of the latter, S) HiyadN: (S, K:) the Huyuwd of a camel are such parts as the hips, or haunches, and thighs. (L.) You say jabalN cuw HuyuwdK and OaHoyaAdK, meaning A mountain having projecting edges in its lower parts, not in its upper parts. (S.) And qaEadotu taHota Hayodi Aljabali I sat beneath the part of the mountain that projected like a wing. (A.)

HayodapN Hyd Hydh Hydp
HayodapN: see HayodN, in three places. ― -b2- Also The rugged part of a road. (A.) ― -b3- An evil look, (A, K,) with a turning aside. (A.) You say, maA naZara UilaIRa UilRaA AlHayodapa, (A,) or UilRaA naZara AlHayodapi, (TA,) He looked not towards me save with an evil look, with a turning aside. (A, TA.)

HayadaI Hyd HydI Hydy
HayadaI The manner of walking of a proud and self-conceited person. (K.) ― -b2- HimaArN HayadaI (S, K) and HayRidN↓, (K,) each occurring in a verse of [Umeiyeh the son of] Aboo-'Áïdh El-Hudhalee accord. to different relations thereof, (L, [see jamRaAzN,]) An ass that turns aside from, or shies at, his shadow, by reason of his briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness: (S, K:) or that is wont often to turn aside from things, or to shy at them. (S.) HayadaI is also applied as an epithet to a she-ass. (IAar.) It is [said to be] the only masc. epithet of the measure faEalaI, (S, K,) except dalaZaI a man “ who thrusts vehemently, ” (IJ,) and waqaraI [but this is written in the K waqariIRN] “ a pastor of a waqiyr, or flock of sheep, ” and qafaTaI vir “ multum coiens, ” and jamazaI a “ quick ” ass. (MF.) But probably HayRidN is the only correct word of the two above mentioned. (L.) [Or HimaArN HayadaI is for HimaArN cuw HayadaI: see jamazaI, voce jamRaAzN.]

HayodaAnN HydAn
HayodaAnN Pebbles that become thrown aside from the legs of a beast as he goes along. (S, K.)

HayRidN Hyd
HayRidN: see HayadaI.

HayaAdi HyAd
HayaAdi, like qaTaAmi, (L,) indecl., with kesr for its termination, [and of the fem. gender,] occurs in the phrase (TA) HiydiI HayaAdi, similar to fiyHiI fayaAHi, (S, L, K,) meaning Turn thou aside, or away, [from me:] (A, L:) said by one when the time for fighting is come, (L,) and by one fleeing. (Ibn-Abi-l-Hadeed.)

HayuwdN Hywd
HayuwdN [That declines, or goes away, much, or frequently]: an intensive epithet, applied by 'Alee to worldly prosperity (AldRunoyaA). (L.)

maHiydN mHyd
maHiydN an inf. n. of HaAda. (K.) ― -b2- [It may also be used, agreeably with analogy, as a noun of place, signifying A place to which one turns aside or away; to which one removes, goes away, or goes far away.]

1 HaAra HAr
1. HaAra, [sec. pers. Hirota,] aor. yaHaAru, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and some say yaHiyru, but this is a mistake, (MF,) inf. n. HayorapN (S, A, Mgh, K) and HayarN (S, Msb, K) and HayorN and HayaraAnN, (K,) He was, or became, dazzled by a thing at which he looked, (T, Msb, K,) so that he turned away his eyes from it: this is the primary signification: (T, Msb:) and so tHyRr↓ (A, * Mgh, * K) and AstHAr↓, (K,) and HArbaSaruhu (A, * TA) and bSrh tHyRr↓. (Mgh, and S and A and K in art. qmr, &c.) ― -b2- And hence, (T, Msb,) He was, or became, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; (T, Msb, K, * TA;) as also tHyRr↓ (Msb, K) and AstHAr↓. (K.) And HAr, (S, A,) or HAr fiI Oamorihi, (Msb,) i. q. fI Amrh tHyRr↓ [He was, or became, confounded, &c., in his affair, or case]. (S, A.) And [HAr (see its part. n. HaAYirN) and] tHyRr↓ [and AstHAr↓] He erred, or lost his way. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, said of water, (A, Msb, K,) and tHyRr↓ (S, A, K) and AstHAr↓, (A, K,) (tropical:) It became collected, (S, A, K,) and stayed, (A,) or went round, (S, K, *) or went to and fro, or fluctuated, (Msb, K,) in a place, as
though it knew not which way to run. (A.) ― -b4- See also 5.

2 HyRrhu Hyr Hyrh Hyrp
2. HyRrhu He, or it, caused him to become confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course. (S, * Msb, KL.) ― -b2- [Accord. to Golius, as on the authority of the KL, HyRr, said of water, means (assumed tropical:) It was whirled round in an eddy: but to have this meaning, which I do not find in my copy of the KL, the verb should be HuyRira.]

4 AHAr AHAr OHAr HAr
4. AHAr [He, or it, caused a thing to descend easily down the throat: or it transmitted food to the stomach: see 10: and see also 4 in art. Hwr]. (S and K voce miXofarN, q. v.)

5 tHyRr OHAr Hyr tHyr
5. tHyRr: see 1, in six places. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) It (a cloud) continued without motion, pouring forth its rain, and not being driven by the wind: (IAar:) or went not in any direction: (K:) [and so AstHAr↓: see mutaHayRirN.] ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) It continued; said of time; (TA;) and in like manner it is said of a man. (MF.) And bihi HiyruwA↓ [if not a mistranscription for taHayRaruwA] occurs as meaning (assumed tropical:) Remain ye therein; referring to a place. (TA.) And bimakaAnK AstHAr↓ (assumed tropical:) He alighted and abode some days in a place. (TA.) ― -b4- tHyRr biAlmaMCa (tropical:) It (a place, S, K, and land, TA) became full of water; as also AstHAr↓. 2. taHoyiyfN The taking a thing, or something, from the side: and diminishing [from the side]. (KL.)

5. taHayRafotuhu I took by little and little from its sides; (S, K;) as also tHwRfthu. (S.)

HiyfapN Hyf Hyfh Hyfp
HiyfapN A side, or lateral part: pl. HiyafN; (K;) which is likewise pl. of HaAfapN. (TA.) [See also HaAYifN, below.]

HaAYifN Acting wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically: (Lth, Msb, K: [in some copies of the K, HaAYirN is erroneously put for jaAYirN:] pl. HaAfapN (Msb, K) and HuyRafN (K, Msb *) and HuyufN. (TA.) ― -b2- An arrow declining from the right direction. (TA.) ― -b3- And, as being likened thereto, (tropical:) An impotent man, who does not attain the object of his want. (TA.) ＝ -A2- The side of a mountain. (K, TA.) [See also HiyfapN.]

baladN OaHoyafu c
baladN OaHoyafu, and OaroDN HayoqaMCu, A district or the like, and a land, upon which rain has not fallen: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) as though the rain treated it wrongfully. (TA.)

1 HaAqa bihi HAq bh HAq bp
1. HaAqa bihi, aor. yaHiyqu, (S, K,) inf. n. HayoqN and HuyuwqN and HayaqaAnN, (K,) It surrounded, encompassed, encircled, or beset, him, or it; (S, K;) only used in relation to evil; (Bd in xvi. 36;) [as also HAq bh, aor. yaHuwqu, inf. HawoqN;] and so bh AHAq↓. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) So in the Kur [xxxv. 41], walaA yaHiyqu Almakoru AlsRayRiYu UilRaA biOaholihi [And evil artifice shall not beset any save the authors thereof]: (S:) or this means shall not befall: (Msb:) [for] HAq bh, (Ibn-'Arafeh, Msb, K, *) aor. as above, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. HayoqN and HaAqN, (TA,) signifies [also] it clave to him, and became his due, (Ibn-'Arafeh, K,) and befell him: (Ibn- 'Arafeh, Msb, K,) and thus it is said to mean in the Kur [xi. 11, &c.], waHaAqa bihimo maA kaAnuwA bihi yasotahoziYuwna [And that at which they used to mock shall cleave to them, or be their due, or befall them; namely, the punishment at which they mocked.] (TA.) You say also, HAq bihimu AlEacaAbu
Punishment beset them, and befell them. (S.) And HAq bihi AlbalaMCu Trial, or trouble, beset him. (TA in art. Hq.) ＝ -A2- HAq fiyi, (K,) inf. n. HayoqN, (TA,) i. q. HAk. (K.)

3 HAyqhu HAyqh HAyqp
3. HAyqhu, (AA, K,) inf. n. muHaAyaqapN, (AA, TA,) He envied him, and hated him. (AA, K.)

HAqu AljuwEi Vehemence of hunger. (TA.) See also HaAqRN, in art. Hq

HayoqN Hyq

maHoyuwqN mHywq
maHoyuwqN: see art. Hwq.

1 HaAka HAk HAky
1. HaAka, aor. yaHiyku, inf. n. HayokN and HayakN and HiyaAkapN, accord. to Lth, signifies He wove a piece of cloth: [and it is said in the K, in art. Hwk, that the root of the verb in this sense is with w and with I:] but Az says that this is a mistake; and that the verb is only HAk having for its aor. yaHuwku, inf. n. HawokN. (TA. [See, however, what follows.]) ＝ -A2- HAk, (S, K,) or HAk fiI miXoyatihi, (TA,) aor. yaHiyku, inf. n. HayakaAnN (S, K) and HayokN (K) and HayakaI (Mbr, TA) [and HiyaAkapN, which see in what follows], He (a man, TA) walked with an elegant and a proud and selfconceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side, or with a twisting of the back: or he moved about his shoulder-joints and his body in walking, (K, TA,) having much flesh; which manner of walking in women is commended, but in men it is discommended; for the woman walks thus by reason of the largeness of her thighs; but the man, when his thighs, or legs, are wide apart: or, as some say, it signifies he trod the ground vehemently: (TA:) or he moved about his shoulder-joints, and parted his legs widely, in walking, [as short persons do: for] HayakaAnN signifies the manner of walking of him who is short: (S:) or a walking in which a man moves about his posteriors: all which meanings are borrowed from the action of the HaAYik [or weaver, who straddles when at work]: HiyaAkapN, likewise, signifies a walking with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side, or with a twisting of the back, and in a lagging manner. (TA.) And you say also, jMCa yataHayRaku↓, and yataHaAyaku↓, meaning He came walking with his legs parted as though there were something between them. (TA.) ＝ -A3- HAk, (K,) aor. yaHiyku, inf. n. HayokN, (TA,) said of a sword, (K,) and of an axe, (TA,) It made an impression, or had effect; as also AHAk↓. (K, TA.) HAk fiyhi (S) and fyh AHAk↓ (S, K) and AaHAkhu↓, (K,) said of a sword, signify the same: (S, K:) one says, fiyhi AlsRayofa Darabahu famaA OaHaAka↓, i. e. [He struck him, but the sword] made no impression, or had no effect, upon him. (S, TA.) And HaAkat AlXRaforapu The [knife called] Xfrp cut; as also AHAkt↓. (K.) And mA taHiyku Almudoyapu AllRaHoma [The butcher's knife does not cut the flesh-meat], and mA tHyk fiyhi: both signify alike. (El-Ámidee, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] HAk Alqawolu fiI Alqalobi, inf. n. HayokN, (assumed tropical:) The saying took effect upon the heart; (Sh, S, K, TA;) and became fixed therein. (Sh, TA.) And maA yaHiyku fiyhi AlmalaAmu (assumed tropical:) Blame does not make any impression upon him. (S.) And maA yaHiyku kalaAmuka fiI flaAnK (assumed tropical:) Thy speech does not make any impression upon such a one. (TA.) And it is said [in a trad., as some read it], AlUivomu maA HaAka fiI Sadorika wakarihota Oano yaTRaliEa Ealayohi AlnRaAsu (assumed tropical:) Sin is that which makes an impression upon thy mind, and becomes fixed [therein, and with which thou dislikest that men should become acquainted]. (Az, TA. [See also HakRa; and see HazRa.])

HayokaAnapN and HiykaAnapN and HuyakaAnapN: see HaAYikN. The first also signifies A man who walks with his legs parted as though there were something between them. (TA.) And A bulky [lizard such as is called] DabRap; that moves about its shoulder-joints, and parts its legs widely, in going along; (S;) as also the second and third. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.)

HiyaAkapN: see art. Hwk.

HuyayokapN Short, and thick and compact in body; applied to a woman. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

HayRaAkN Hy HyA HyAk
HayRaAkN and HayRaAkapN: see HaAYikN; for the former, in two places. ― -b2- The latter also signifies A female ostrich; as being likened to the HaAYik in her [manner of] walking. (TA.)

HaAYikN: see art. Hwk. [In the present day, HayRaAkN↓ signifies the same; i. e. A weaver.] ＝ -A2- Also, and HayRaAkN↓, applied to a man; and HayRaAkapN↓ and HayokaAnapN↓ and HiykaAnapN↓ and HuyakaAnapN↓, (K, TA,) and, accord. to the K, HayakaI↓, but this is an inf. n., and is here a mistake for HiykaI↓, originally HuyokaI, mentioned by Sb, (TA,) applied to a woman; Walking, or who walks, in the manner denoted by the verb HAk, i. e., with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, &c. (K, TA.) ＝ -A3- And the first, i. e. HAYk, Becoming fixed in the heart, and disquieting one. (Az, TA in art. Hwk.) [See 1.]

(TA.) ― -b2- HAl AlmaMCu, aor. as above, The water remained, or stagnated, and collected; or remained long, and became altered; or became yellow and altered; in the bottom of a valley. (TA.)

Hayoli Hayoli A cry with which goats are chidden. (K.)

HayolN Water that remains, or stagnates, and collects, or that remains long, and becomes altered, or that becomes yellow and altered, in the bottom of a valley: pl. [of pauc.] OaHoyaAlN and [of mult.] HuyuwlN. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also a subst. from AlAiHotiyaAlu; (S, K;) and so HiylapN↓, with kesr; (S;) or HayolapN↓ [perhaps a mistake for HiylapN]; (K;) and maHaAlapN↓, and maHaAlN↓. (AZ, S.) [See HiylapN in art. Hwl.) ― -b2- Strength, power, might, or force; syn. quwRapN; as also HawolN; (TA;) of which it is a dial. var. (S, Msb.) So in the saying, laA Hayola walaA quwRapa UilRaA biQllRehi. (S, * Msb, TA. [See HawolN.]) So, too, in the phrase, in a form of prayer, AallRehumRa caA AlHayoli AlXRadiydi [O God, Possessor of great might]: perverted by the relaters of traditions into cA AlHaboli, with b. (TA.) If it be a contraction of HayRlN, originally HayowilN, its proper place is art. Hwl: otherwise, this is its proper place. (TA.)

HayolapN Hyl Hylh Hylp
HayolapN A large number of goats: (S:) or a herd of goats: and a flock of sheep. (K.) ― -b2- Stones rolled down from the side of a mountain to its bottom until they become many: (K:) or an overhanging mass of rock that falls down from the head of a mountain to its bottom. (Abu-l-Mekárim, O.) ＝ -A2- See also HayolN.

HiylapN Hyl Hylh Hylp
HiylapN: see HayolN, above; and see art. Hwl.

HiyaliIRN Hyl HylI Hylp Hyly

HiyaAlN; and HiyaAlahu and biHiyaAlihi: and EalaI HiyaAlihi: see art. Hwl.

HayRilN Hyl Hylp
HayRilN: see 4 in art. Hwl, in the latter half of the paragraph.

HayRaAlN: see its syn. HuwRalN, in art. Hwl.

OaHoyalu: see art. Hwl.

maHaAlN mHAl mHl
maHaAlN: see HayolN, above; and see HiylapN in

maHaAlapN: art. Hwl.

1 HaAna HAn
1. HaAna, (Msb, K,) or HAn Hiynuhu, (S,) aor. yaHiynu, (S, Msb,) [inf. n. as in the exs. following,] It, (Msb, K,) or its time, or season, (S,) was, or became, or drew, near; or was at hand: (S, Msb, K:) and its time came. (Msb, K. *) You say, HaAna lahu Oano yafoEala kacaA, aor. as above, inf. n. HiynN [and as in the next ex.], The time came, or drew near, for him to do, or that he should
do, such a thing; syn. Mna. (S.) And HaAnati AlSRalaApu, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. HayonN and HiynN and HayonuwnapN, The time of prayer came: (Msb:) or the prayer was, or became, or drew, near. (TA.) ― -b2- HAn AlsRunobulu The ears of corn became dry, (K, TA,) so that the time of the reaping thereof came, or drew near. (TA.) ― -b3- HAn Hayonu AlnRafosi The soul died, or perished. (TA.) ― -b4- And HAn, inf. n. HayonN, He (a man) died, or perished. (S.) ― -b5- He experienced a trial, or trying affliction. (K: a meaning indicated therein, but not expressed.) ― -b6- Also, (Az, K,) aor. as above, inf. n. HayonN, (Az, TA,) It (anything) was not accomodated, adapted, or disposed, to the right way or course or direction; (Az, K, TA;) as also tHyRn↓. (K.) ― -b7- And i. q. AitRafaqa [It happened, &c.]. (Har p. 382.)

2 HyRnhu 3
2. HyRnhu, [inf. n. taHoyiynN,] He assigned, or appointed, for him, or it, a time. (K.) HayRanuwA Duyuwfahumo and OaHaAnuwhumo↓ have the same meaning [app. They assigned, or appointed, a time for their guests]. (TA.) ― -b2- HyRn AlnRaAqapa He appointed for the she-camel a time in every day and night in which he should milk her; (S, K;) as also taHayRanahaA↓; (K;) said when one milks her in the day and night once: As says that taHoyiynN is like tawojiybN [the milking a camel but once in the course of each day and night]; but is only after she has shown herself to be pregnant, and her milk has become little in quantity. (TA.) ＝ -A2- He (God) made him, or it, to be not accommodated, adapted, or disposed, to the right way or course or direction. (K) ― -b2- See also 4.

3 muHaAyanapN c and HiyaAnN
3. muHaAyanapN HiyaAnN [are the inf. ns. of HaAyana]. You say, EaAmalahu muHaAyanapF (S, K) and HiyaAnFA (Lh, TA) [He bargained or contracted with him for work for a certain time]; like musaAwaEapF; (S, K;) from AlHiynu meaning Alwaqotu. (Lh, TA.) And in like manner, AisotaOojarahu muHaAyanapF (TA) and HiyaAnFA (Lh, TA) [He hired him, or took him as a hired man or a hireling, for a certain time].

4 AHAn Hyn Hynh Hynp
4. AHAn i. q. Oazomana [i. e. Time, or a long time, passed over him, or it; he, or it, endured, or continued, for a time, or for a long time]. (TA.) ― -b2- OaHoyana He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, (S, K,) for a time in a place. (S.) ― -b3- OaHoyanati AlUibilu The time came, or drew near, for the camels to be milked: or for the camels to have their loads bound upon them. (AA, K. [In the CK, yuEolama is erroneously put for yuEokama.]) ― -b4- OaHoyana Alqawomu The time of what they desired, or sought, came, or drew near, to the company of men: (K:) the time of their attainment of what they hoped for came, or drew near, to them. (IAar, TA.) ＝ -A2- As a trans. verb: see 2. ― -b2- AHAnhu QllRehu God caused him to die, or destroyed him; (S;) as also HyRnhu↓, inf. n. taHoyiynN. (KL: but only the inf. n. is there given.) ― -b3- God tried him, or afflicted him with a trial. (K: a meaning indicated therein, but not expressed.)

5 tHyRn HAn tHyn tHynn wHI
5. tHyRn, said of spunger (waAriX), He watched for the time of eating, in order that he might enter. (S.) And tHyRn AlTRaEaAma [He watched for the time of the food]. (K voce HaDirN.) And taHayRanotu ruWoyapa fulaAnK I watched for the time of seeing such a one. (TA.) And tHyRn waqota AlSRalaApi He sought [to know] the time of prayer. (TA.) [And accord. to Freytag's Lex., AstHAn↓ has a similar meaning; i. e. He waited for the just time of a thing; delayed a thing till the fit time.] ― -b2- tHyRn AlnRaAqapa: see 2. ＝ -A2- See also 1. ＝ -A3- As meaning AisotagonaI, it is a vulgar word. (TA.)

10 UisotaHoyana
10: see 5.

HayonN Hyn
HayonN Death; a state of destruction or perdition: (S, K, TA:) or the time of the appointed term [of life]; or time of death. (Har p. 322.) ― -b2- A trial, or trying affliction. (K.)

HiynN Hyn
HiynN i. q. dahorN [Time; or a time; or a space, or period, of time; &c.]: (K:) or, accord. to EshSháfi'ee, time, from the beginning of the world to its end; as also dahorN: (Az voce dahorN:) or a time, (Az, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) in a vague sense, (Mgh, K,) applicable to any time, (Az, K,) little or much, (Mgh, Msb,) long or short, that may be a year and more: or [in some cases] particularly meaning forty years: or seven years: or two years: or six months: or two months: or any morning and evening: (K:) also a space of time; (S, K;) as in the Kur lxxvi. I, (S,) and in the Kur xxxvii. 178: (K:) and a continuous time: (Ham p. 381:) and the day of resurrection; (K;) or the coming to pass of the resurrection; as in the Kur xxxviii. last verse: (Mgh, TA:) or it has two meanings; namely, a time of unknown limit, and also, as in the Kur xiv. 30, six months: (Fr, Msb:) accord. to Er-Rághib, the time of a thing's arriving, or coming, and happening; having a vague meaning, and rendered particular, or special, by that to which it is prefixed: some say that it occurs applied in different ways: to an appointed term; as that to which God makes one to live: and a year; as in the Kur xiv. 30: and to the time when an event takes place; as in the Kur xxx. 16: and to time absolutely: accord. to El-Munáwee, in the [genuine] language of the Arabs, it is applied to [the time of] a glance of the eye, and more than that, to time without end: (TA:) the pl. is OaHoyaAnN, (S, Msb, K,) and pl. pl. OaHaAyiynu; (S, * K;) as in the saying, fulaAnN yafoEalu kacaA OaHoyaAnFA and fiI AlOaHaAyiyni [Such a one does so at times, or sometimes]. (S.) In the Kur [xiv. 30], tuWotiI, OukulahaA kulRa HiynK means [Which yieldeth its fruit] every six months: (Fr, Msb, TA:) or every year: or every morning and evening: or, accord. to Az, in every season, uninterruptedly. (TA.) XaIoCK miHoyaAnu↓, also, means Hiynuhu [The time, or season, of a thing]. (K.) [You say, UilaI HiynK For a time, or season.] And HiynFA At one time; sometime; at some time; awhile. (Mgh.) Hiyna in the phrase qumotu Hiyna qumota [I stood in the time when thou stoodest, or I stood when thou stoodest,] is an adv. n. of time; (Msb;) [see also an ex. in a verse cited voce xaXafa, and the remarks there subjoined:] and one may well employ in its place lamRaA and UicaA (Msb, TA) and Uico and mataI and saAEapa (TA) and waqota (Msb, TA) and the like; but not, as many have said, Hayovu; for this is an adv. n. of place. (Msb.) ― -b2- When they make the two times to be distant, the one from the other, [i. e. the time of speaking and the time spoken of,] they do so by means of Uc, and thus, (K,) they say HiynaYicK [meaning At that time; then]: (S, K:) and sometimes they suppress the C, substituting for it I. (TA.) ― -b3- Sometimes, also, they prefix ta to Hiyna; (S, TA;) and say laA taHiyna, meaning It is not, or was not, a time [of such a thing; but this is generally written laAta Hiyna]; as in the Kur xxxviii. 2 [respecting which see art. lyt]. (TA.) Aboo-Wejzeh Es-Saadee says,
AaloEaATifuwna taHiyna maA mino EaATifK
waAlmuToEimuwna zamaAna Oayona AlmuToEiwu
[The persons who return to the attack when there is none other that returns to the attack, (as is said in the S and L in art. ETf,) or it may mean who act affectionately in the time when there is none other that acts affectionately; as is said in the L in that art.;) and the feeders in the time when it is said, Where is the feeder?]: (S:) ISd says that t is thus prefixed to Hyn like as it is in talaAna meaning AlMna: but IB says that Ibn-Es-Seeráfee cites the former hemistich thus:
AaloEaATifuwnaho Hiyna maAmino EaATifK
[with the h of pausation]: and some say that the h of pausation is likened to the fem. p, and is then made movent with fet-h. (TA. [See more in art. lyt.]) ― -b4- See also HiynapN, in two places.

HaAnapN HAn HAnh HAnp
HaAnapN: see art. Hwn.

HayonapN Hyn Hynh Hynp
HayonapN: see what next follows.

HiynapN Hyn Hynh Hynp
HiynapN [The time appointed for a she-camel to be milked in every day and night;] a subst. from HayRana AlnRaAqapa; as also HiynN↓: you say, mataI Hiynapu naAqatika, meaning When is the time of the milking of thy she-camel? and kamo HiynatuhaA, meaning How many times is she milked? (K.) One says also, of a man, (S,) yaOokulu AlHiynapa and AlHayonapa↓, meaning He eats once in the day and the night: (S, K:) or, accord. to Aboo-'Amr Ez-Záhid, Alwajobap is used as meaning a man's eating once in the day, and AlHynp as meaning a she-camel's being milked once in the day. (IB, TA.) And one says, maA OaloqaAhu UilRaA AlHiynapa baEoda AlHiynapa, i. e. AlHiyna baEoda AlHiyni↓ [I do not meet him save time after time; meaning, occasionally]. (K.)

HaAnaApN: see art. Hnw.

HaAniyapN: see art. Hnw.

HaAniIRN: see art. Hnw.

HaAYinN c
HaAYinN Stupid; foolish; or having little, or no, intellect, or understanding. (K.)

HaAYinapN c
HaAYinapN A deadly, or destructive, calamity that befalls one: (K, TA:) a calamity in which is AlHayon: (TA:) pl. HawaAYinu. (K.) [In the CK it is, in one place, erroneously substituted for HaAniyRapN, as meaning “ wine. ”]

maHuwnapN mHA mHwnh mHwnp
maHuwnapN [mentioned in the K in art. mHn] is from AlHayonu or AlmiHonapu. (TA.)

miHoyaAnN mHyAn
miHoyaAnN: see its syn. HynN.

HayohalN Hyhl
HayohalN (En-Nadr, AHn, K) and HayRaholN and HayRiholN (K) A certain shrub of the smaller kind of HamoD, having no leaves: (En-Nadr, AHn, K:) or the species of HamoD termed harom: (AA, TA:) a coll. gen. n.: (TA:) n. un. with p: (K:) so called because, when rain falls upon it, it grows quickly; and when the camels eat it, and do not speedily void their excrement, they die: (AA, TA: [see the next paragraph:]) at the end of a verse of Homeyd Ibn-Thowr, the name is written AlHayRahulN, with the vowel of the l transferred to the h. (AHn, K.)

HayRahala Hyhl
HayRahala and HayRahalN and HayRahalano and HayRahalFA and HayRahalaA words used in inciting, or urging on: see more in art. HI; (K;) and in art. hl. (TA.)
